Arxiv Astronomy Papers

ArxivID Published Authors Title Abstract key citation url
0 2207.04542 2023-04-24 Keith Hawkins Chemical Cartography with LAMOST and Gaia Reveal Azimuthal and Spiral Structure in the Galactic Disk Chemical Cartography, or mapping, of our Galaxy has the potential to fully\ntransform our view of its structure and formation. In this work, we use\nchemical cartography to explore the metallicity distribution of OBAF-type disk\nstars from the LAMOST survey and a complementary sample of disk giant stars\nfrom Gaia DR3. We use these samples to constrain the radial and vertical\nmetallicity gradients across the Galactic disk. We also explore whether there\nare detectable azimuthal variations in the metallicity distribution on top of\nthe radial gradient. For the OBAF-type star sample from LAMOST, we find a\nradial metallicity gradient of $\Delta$[Fe/H]/$\Delta$R $\sim -0.078 \pm 0.001$\ndex/kpc in the plane of the disk and a vertical metallicity gradient of\n$\Delta$[Fe/H]/$\Delta$Z $\sim -0.15 \pm 0.01$ dex/kpc in the solar\nneighborhood. The radial gradient becomes shallower with increasing vertical\nheight while the vertical gradient becomes shallower with increasing\nGalactocentric radius, consistent with other studies. We also find detectable\nspatially-dependent azimuthal variations on top of the radial metallicity\ngradient at the level of $\sim$0.10 dex. Interestingly, the azimuthal\nvariations appear be close to the Galactic spiral arms in one dataset (Gaia\nDR3) but not the other (LAMOST). These results suggest that there is azimuthal\nstructure in the Galactic metallicity distribution and that in some cases it is\nco-located with spiral arms. Hawkins_2023 Hawkins 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2207.04542
1 2303.01637 2023-04-24 Nolan Dickson, Vincent Hénault-Brunet, Holger Baumgardt, Mark Gieles, Peter Smith Multimass modelling of Milky Way globular clusters -- I. Implications on their stellar initial mass function above 1 M$_{\odot}$ The distribution of stars and stellar remnants (white dwarfs, neutron stars,\nblack holes) within globular clusters holds clues about their formation and\nlong-term evolution, with important implications for their initial mass\nfunction (IMF) and the formation of black hole mergers. In this work, we\npresent best-fitting multimass models for 37 Milky Way globular clusters, which\nwere inferred from various datasets, including proper motions from Gaia EDR3\nand HST, line-of-sight velocities from ground-based spectroscopy and deep\nstellar mass functions from HST. We use metallicity dependent stellar evolution\nrecipes to obtain present-day mass functions of stars and remnants from the\nIMF. By dynamically probing the present-day mass function of all objects in a\ncluster, including the mass distribution of remnants, these models allow us to\nexplore in detail the stellar (initial) mass functions of a large sample of\nMilky Way GCs. We show that, while the low-mass mass function slopes are\nstrongly dependent on the dynamical age of the clusters, the high-mass slope\n($\alpha_3; m > 1 M_\odot$) is not, indicating that the mass function in this\nregime has generally been less affected by dynamical mass loss. Examination of\nthis high-mass mass function slope suggests an IMF in this mass regime\nconsistent with a Salpeter IMF is required to reproduce the observations. This\nhigh-mass IMF is incompatible with a top-heavy IMF, as has been proposed\nrecently. Finally, based on multimass model fits to our sample of Milky Way\nGCs, no significant correlation is found between the high-mass IMF slope and\ncluster metallicity. Dickson_2023 Dickson et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.01637
2 2302.06644 2023-04-14 Stephanie Monty, David Yong, Davide Massari, Madeleine McKenzie, GyuChul Myeong, Sven Buder, Amanda I. Karakas, Ken C. Freeman, Anna F. Marino, Vasily Belokurov, N. Wyn Evans Peeking beneath the precision floor -- II. Probing the chemo-dynamical histories of the potential globular cluster siblings, NGC 288 and NGC 362 The assembly history of the Milky Way (MW) is a rapidly evolving subject,\nwith numerous small accretion events and at least one major merger proposed in\nthe MW's history. Accreted alongside these dwarf galaxies are globular clusters\n(GCs), which act as spatially coherent remnants of these past events. Using\nhigh precision differential abundance measurements from our recently published\nstudy, we investigate the likelihood that the MW clusters NGC 362 and NGC 288\nare galactic siblings, accreted as part of the Gaia-Sausage-Enceladus (GSE)\nmerger. To do this, we compare the two GCs at the 0.01 dex level for 20+\nelements for the first time. Strong similarities are found, with the two\nshowing chemical similarity on the same order as those seen between the three\nLMC GCs, NGC 1786, NGC 2210 and NGC 2257. However, when comparing GC abundances\ndirectly to GSE stars, marked differences are observed. NGC 362 shows good\nagreement with GSE stars in the ratio of Eu to Mg and Si, as well as a clear\ndominance in the r- compared to the s-process, while NGC 288 exhibits only a\nslight r-process dominance. When fitting the two GC abundances with a GSE-like\ngalactic chemical evolution model, NGC 362 shows agreement with both the model\npredictions and GSE abundance ratios (considering Si, Ni, Ba and Eu) at the\nsame metallicity. This is not the case for NGC 288. We propose that the two are\neither not galactic siblings, or GSE was chemically inhomogeneous enough to\nbirth two similar, but not identical clusters with distinct chemistry relative\nto constituent stars. Monty_2023 Monty et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.06644
3 2304.00865 2023-04-03 Ranjan Kumar, Ananta C. Pradhan, Snehalata Sahu, Annapurni Subramaniam, Sonika Piridi, Santi Cassisi, Devendra K. Ojha Globular Cluster UVIT Legacy Survey (GlobULeS) $-$ II. Evolutionary status of hot stars in M3 and M13 We present a far-ultraviolet (FUV) study of hot stellar populations in the\nsecond parameter pair globular clusters (GCs) M3 and M13, as a part of the\nGlobular cluster UVIT Legacy Survey program (GlobULeS). We use observations\nmade with F148W and F169M filters of the Ultraviolet Imaging Telescope (UVIT)\nonboard {\em AstroSat} along with ground-based data (UBVRI filters), {\em\nHubble Space Telescope (HST)} GC catalogue, and {\em Gaia} EDR3 catalogue.\nBased on the FUV-optical colour-magnitude diagrams, we classify the sources\ninto the horizontal branch (HB) stars, post-HB stars, and hot white dwarfs\n(WDs) in both the GCs. The comparison of synthetic and observed colours of the\nobserved HB stars suggests that the mass-loss at the red giant branch (RGB) and\nHe spread in both clusters have a simultaneous effect on the different HB\ndistributions detected in M3 and M13, such that, HB stars of M13 require a\nlarger spread in He (${\rm 0.247-0.310}$) than those of M3 (${\rm Y=\n0.252-0.266}$). The evolutionary status of HB stars, post-HB stars, and WDs are\nstudied using SED fit parameters and theoretical evolutionary tracks on the H-R\ndiagram. We found that the observed post-HB stars have evolved from zero-age HB\n(ZAHB) stars of the mass range $0.48-0.55$ \Msun\ in M3 and M13. We detect 24\nWD candidates in each cluster having ${\rm \log(L_{bol}/L_\odot)}$ in the range\n$-0.8$ to $+0.6$ and ${\rm \log(T_{eff}/K)}$ in the range of 4.2 to 5.0.\nPlacing the WDs on the H-R diagram and comparing them with models suggest that\nM13 has a population of low-mass WDs, probably originating from binary\nevolution. Kumar_2023 Kumar et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.00865
4 2303.15253 2023-03-27 M. Scalco, A. Livernois, E. Vesperini, M. Libralato, A. Bellini, L. R. Bedin First observational evidence of a relation between globular clusters' internal rotation and stellar masses Several observational studies have shown that many Galactic globular clusters\n(GCs) are characterised by internal rotation. Theoretical studies of the\ndynamical evolution of rotating clusters have predicted that, during their\nlong-term evolution, these stellar systems should develop a dependence of the\nrotational velocity around the cluster's centre on the mass of stars, with the\ninternal rotation increasing for more massive stars. In this paper we present\nthe first observational evidence of the predicted rotation-mass trend. In our\ninvestigation, we exploited the $\mathit{Gaia}$ Data Release 3 catalogue of\nthree GCs: NGC 104 (47 Tuc), NGC 5139 ($\omega$ Cen) and NGC 5904 (M 5). We\nfound clear evidence of a cluster rotation-mass relation in 47 Tuc and M 5,\nwhile in $\omega$ Cen, the dynamically youngest system among the three clusters\nstudied here, no such trend was detected. Scalco_2023 Scalco et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.15253
5 2303.08344 2023-03-15 Dan Qiu, Hao Tian, Jing Li, Chao Liu, Lin Long, Jian-Rong Shi, Ming Yang, Bo Zhang Atmospheric parameters and kinematic information for the M giants stars from LAMOST DR9 A catalog of more than 43,000 M giant stars has been selected by Li et al.\nfrom the ninth data release of LAMOST. Using the data-driven method SLAM, we\nobtain the stellar parameters (Teff, logg, [M/H], [$\alpha$/M]) for all the M\ngiant stars with uncertainties of 57 K, 0.25 dex, 0.16 dex and 0.06 dex at SNR\n> 100, respectively. With those stellar parameters, we constrain the absolute\nmagnitude in K-band, which brings distance with relative uncertainties around\n25% statistically. Radial velocities are also calculated by applying cross\ncorrelation on the spectra between 8000 A $\AA$ and 8950 A $\AA$ with synthetic\nspectra from ATLAS9, which covers the Ca II triplet. Comparison between our\nradial velocities and those from APOGEE DR17 and Gaia DR3 shows that our radial\nvelocities have a system offset and dispersion around 1 and 4.6 km s$^{-1}$,\nrespectively. With the distances and radial velocities combining with the\nastrometric data from Gaia DR3, we calculate the full 6D position and velocity\ninformation, which are able to be used for further chemo-dynamic studies on the\ndisk and substructures in the halo, especially the Sagittarius Stream. Qiu_2023 Qiu et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08344
6 2211.15689 2023-03-15 Martin P. Rey, Oscar Agertz, Tjitske K. Starkenburg, Florent Renaud, Gandhali D. Joshi, Andrew Pontzen, Nicolas F. Martin, Diane K. Feuillet, Justin I. Read VINTERGATAN-GM: The cosmological imprints of early mergers on Milky-Way-mass galaxies We present a new suite of cosmological zoom-in hydrodynamical ($\approx 20\,\n\mathrm{pc}$ spatial resolution) simulations of Milky-Way mass galaxies to\nstudy how a varying mass ratio for a Gaia-Sausage-Enceladus (GSE) progenitor\nimpacts the $z=0$ chemodynamics of halo stars. Using the genetic modification\napproach, we create five cosmological histories for a Milky-Way-mass dark\nmatter halo ($M_{200} \approx 10^{12} \, M_\mathrm{\odot}$), incrementally\nincreasing the stellar mass ratio of a $z\approx2$ merger from 1:25 to 1:2,\nwhile fixing the galaxy's final dynamical, stellar mass and large-scale\nenvironment. We find markedly different morphologies at $z=0$ following this\nchange in early history, with a growing merger resulting in increasingly\ncompact and bulge-dominated galaxies. Despite this structural diversity, all\ngalaxies show a radially-biased population of inner halo stars like the\nMilky-Way's GSE which, surprisingly, has a similar magnitude, age, $\rm [Fe/H]$\nand $\rm [\alpha/Fe]$ distribution whether the $z\approx2$ merger is more minor\nor major. This arises because a smaller ex-situ population at $z\approx2$ is\ncompensated by a larger population formed in an earlier merger-driven starburst\nwhose contribution to the GES can grow dynamically over time, with both\npopulations strongly overlapping in the $\rm [Fe/H]-\rm [\alpha/Fe]$ plane. Our\nstudy demonstrates that multiple high-redshift histories can lead to similar\n$z=0$ chemodynamical features in the halo, highlighting the need for additional\nconstraints to distinguish them, and the importance of considering the full\nspectrum of progenitors when interpreting $z=0$ data to reconstruct our\nGalaxy's past. Rey_2023 Rey et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.15689
7 2301.00203 2023-03-14 A. M. Dmytrenko, P. N. Fedorov, V. S. Akhmetov, A. B. Velichko, S. I. Denyshchenko The vertex coordinates of the Galaxy's stellar systems according to the Gaia DR3 catalogue We present the results of determining the coordinates of the vertices of\nvarious stellar systems, the centroids of which are located in the Galactic\nplane. To do this, the positions, parallaxes, proper motions, and radial\nvelocities of red giants and subgiants contained in the $Gaia$~DR3 catalogue\nhave been used. When determining the components of the deformation velocity\ntensors in local coordinate systems, we found the coordinates of the vertices\nof the stellar systems under study. It turned out that there is a complex\ndependence of vertex deviations $l_{xy}$ in Galactocentric cylindrical ($R,\n\theta$) and Galactic rectangular ($X,Y$) coordinates. Based on the approach\nproposed in this paper, heliocentric distances to vertices have been determined\nfor the first time. The results obtained show that in addition to the fact that\nthe angular coordinates of the Galactic center and the vertices of stellar\nsystems do not coincide, their heliocentric distances do not coincide as well.\nThis presumably indicates that there are structures in the Galaxy that\nnoticeably affect its axisymmetry. Dmytrenko_2023 Dmytrenko et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.00203
8 2211.01006 2023-03-10 Ioana Ciucă, Daisuke Kawata, Yuan-Sen Ting, Robert J. J. Grand, Andrea Miglio, Michael Hayden, Junichi Baba, Francesca Fragkoudi, Stephanie Monty, Sven Buder, Ken Freeman Chasing the impact of the Gaia-Sausage-Enceladus merger on the formation of the Milky Way thick disc We employ our Bayesian Machine Learning framework BINGO (Bayesian INference\nfor Galactic archaeOlogy) to obtain high-quality stellar age estimates for\n68,360 red giant and red clump stars present in the 17th data release of the\nSloan Digital Sky Survey, the APOGEE-2 high-resolution spectroscopic survey. By\nexamining the denoised age-metallicity relationship of the Galactic disc stars,\nwe identify a drop in metallicity with an increase in [Mg/Fe] at an early\nepoch, followed by a chemical enrichment episode with increasing [Fe/H] and\ndecreasing [Mg/Fe]. This result is congruent with the chemical evolution\ninduced by an early-epoch gas-rich merger identified in the Milky Way-like\nzoom-in cosmological simulation Auriga. In the initial phase of the merger of\nAuriga 18 there is a drop in metallicity due to the merger diluting the metal\ncontent and an increase in the [Mg/Fe] of the primary galaxy. Our findings\nsuggest that the last massive merger of our Galaxy, the Gaia-Sausage-Enceladus,\nwas likely a significant gas-rich merger and induced a starburst, contributing\nto the chemical enrichment and building of the metal-rich part of the thick\ndisc at an early epoch. Ciucă_2023 Ciucă et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.01006
9 2301.04154 2023-03-03 Elliot Y. Davies, Adam M. Dillamore, Eugene Vasiliev, Vasily Belokurov Accelerated phase-mixing in the stellar halo due to a rotating bar In a galaxy merger, the stars tidally stripped from the satellite and\naccreted onto the host galaxy undergo phase mixing and form finely-grained\nstructures in the phase space. However, these fragile structures may be\ndestroyed in the subsequent galaxy evolution, in particular, by a rotating bar\nthat appears well after the merger is completed. In this work, we investigate\nthe survivability of phase-space structures in the presence of a bar. We find\nthat a bar with amplitude and pattern speed similar to those of the Milky Way\nwould blur and destroy a substantial amount of the substructure that consists\nof particles with pericentre radii comparable to the bar length. While this\nappears to be in tension with the recent discovery of phase-space chevrons in\n\textit{Gaia} DR3 data, the most prominent chevrons in our simulations can\nstill be recovered when applying the same analysis procedure as in\nobservations. Moreover, the smoothing effect is less pronounced in the\npopulation of stars whose angular momenta have the opposite sign to the bar\npattern speed. Davies_2023 Davies et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.04154
10 2210.04245 2023-02-28 Giulia Pagnini, Paola Di Matteo, Sergey Khoperskov, Alessandra Mastrobuono-Battisti, Misha Haywood, Florent Renaud, Françoise Combes The distribution of globular clusters in kinematic spaces does not trace the accretion history of the host galaxy Reconstructing how all the stellar components of the Galaxy formed and\nassembled over time, by studying the properties of the stars which make it, is\nthe aim of Galactic archeology. In these last years, thanks to the launch of\nthe ESA Gaia astrometric mission, and the development of many spectroscopic\nsurveys, we are for the first time in the position to delve into the layers of\nthe past of our galaxy. Globular clusters (GCs) play a fundamental role in this\nresearch field since they are among the oldest stellar systems in the Milky Way\n(MW) and so bear witness of its entire past. In the recent years, there have\nbeen several attempts to constrain the nature of clusters (accreted or formed\nin the MW itself) through the analysis of kinematic spaces and to reconstruct\nfrom this the properties of the accretions events experienced by the MW through\ntime. This work aims to test a widely-used assumption about the clustering of\nthe accreted populations of GCs in the integrals of motions space. We analyze a\nset of dissipation-less N-body simulations that reproduce the accretion of one\nor two satellites with their GC population on a MW-type galaxy. Our results\ndemonstrate that a significant overlap between accreted and\n"kinematically-heated" in-situ GCs is expected in kinematic spaces, for mergers\nwith mass ratios of 1:10. In contrast with standard assumptions made in the\nliterature so far, we find that accreted GCs do not show dynamical coherence,\nthat is they do not cluster in kinematic spaces. In addition, GCs can also be\nfound in regions dominated by stars which have a different origin (i.e.\ndifferent progenitor). This casts doubt on the association between GCs and\nfield stars that is generally made in the literature to assign them to a common\norigin. Our findings severely question the recovered accretion history of the\nMW based on the phase-space clustering of the GC population. Pagnini_2023 Pagnini et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2210.04245
11 2302.14524 2023-02-28 Lawrence M. Widrow Swing Amplification and the Gaia Phase Spirals We explore the interplay between in-plane and vertical dynamics in stellar\ndiscs within the framework of the shearing box approximation. Julian and Toomre\nused the shearing sheet to show that leading density waves are amplified as\nthey swing into a trailing ones. We extend their formalism into the dimension\nperpendicular to the disc and obtain explicit solutions for the response of a\ndisc to an impulsive, external excitation. An excitation that is is symmetric\nabout the mid plane produces a density/breathing wave as well as two-armed\nphase spirals in the vertical phase space plane. On the other hand, an\nexcitation that is antisymmetric about the mid plane leads to a bending wave\nand single-armed phase spirals. In either case, self-gravity plays a crucial\nrole in driving the evolution of the disturbance and determining the amplitude\nand pitch angle of the ensuing spirals. We also show that when the disc is\nexcited by a co-rotating cloud, it develops stationary phase spirals in the\nwake of the cloud. The results call into question simple kinematic arguments\nthat have been used to determine the age of the phase spirals seen in the Gaia\nsurvey Widrow_2023 Widrow 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.14524
12 2205.01735 2023-02-25 Geovanny Briceño-Morales, Julio Chanamé Substructure, supernovae, and a time-resolved star formation history for Upper Scorpius The improved astrometry precision of Gaia-eDR3 allows us to perform a\ndetailed study of the Upper Scorpius OB association and revisit its spatial,\nkinematic, and age substructure. We achieve this by combining clustering\ntechniques and complementing with age estimations based on Gaia photometry. Our\ncensus retrieves 3661 candidate members for Upper Scorpius with contamination\n$\sim$9\%. We also extract an astrometrically clean sample of 3004 sources with\ncontamination $\sim$6\%. We show that Upper Scorpius can be divided into at\nleast 3 main kinematic groups. We systematically investigate and characterize\nthe Upper Scorpius' internal structure, revealing that at least $\sim 34\%$ of\nits stellar populations are contained in 7 spatial substructures, with well\ndefined boundaries, kinematics and relative ages, with suggested names: $\pi$\nScorpii (20 $^{\pm2}_{\pm1}$ Myr), $\alpha$ Scorpii (14$^{\pm2}_{\pm1}$ Myr),\n$\delta$ Scorpii (9$^{\pm2}_{\pm1}$ Myr), $\beta$ Scorpii (8$^{\pm1}_{\pm1}$\nMyr), $\omega$ Scorpii (8$^{\pm1}_{\pm1}$ Myr), $\nu$ Scorpii\n(7$^{\pm1}_{\pm1}$ Myr), after their brightest member, and the well known\n$\rho$ Ophiuchi (4$^{\pm1}_{\pm1}$ Myr). We find a clear correlation in (1)\ndensity-age, providing an empirical expansion law to be tested in other\nassociations, and (2) tangential velocity-age, providing constrains on the\ndynamics of these substructures and the position of potential past triggering\nevents. We estimate the time at which 4 potential supernovae events occurred in\nUpper Scorpius. Based on these findings, we tie together previous work on the\nregion and suggest a star formation history with unprecedented temporal\nresolution. Briceño-Morales_2023 Briceño-Morales and Chanamé 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2205.01735
13 2302.12036 2023-02-23 Phillip A. B. Galli, Núria Miret-Roig, Hervé Bouy, Javier Olivares, David Barrado Dynamical age of the Tucana-Horologium young stellar association The Tucana-Horologium association is one of the closest young stellar groups\nto the Sun and despite the close proximity its age is still debated in the\nliterature. We take advantage of the state-of-the-art astrometry delivered by\nthe third data release of the Gaia space mission combined with precise radial\nvelocity measurements obtained from high-resolution spectroscopy to investigate\nthe dynamical age of the association. We perform an extensive traceback\nanalysis using a combination of different samples of cluster members, metrics\nto evaluate the minimum size of the association in the past and models for the\ngalactic potential to integrate the stellar orbits back in time. The dynamical\nage of $38.5^{+1.6}_{-8.0}$ Myr that we derive in this paper is consistent with\nthe various age estimates obtained from isochrone fitting in the literature\n(30-50 Myr) and reconciles, for the first time, the dynamical age of the\nTucana-Horologium association with the age obtained from lithium depletion\n($\sim40$ Myr). Our results are independent from stellar models and represent\none more step towards constructing a self-consistent age scale for the young\nstellar groups of the Solar neighbourhood based on the 3D space motion of the\nstars. Galli_2023 Galli et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.12036
14 2302.09851 2023-02-20 Yüksel Karataş, Hikmet Çakmak, İnci Akkaya Oralhan, Charles Bonatto, Raúl Michel, Martin Netopil Study of the Open Clusters in Kepler Prime Field We present a detailed study of NGC 6791, NGC 6811, NGC 6819 and NGC 6866, the\nfour open clusters that are located in the Kepler prime field. We use new CCD\nUBV(RI)KC photometry, which was combined with Gaia EDR3 photometric/astrometric\ndata, to derive the astrophysical parameters with two independent methods - one\nof them the fitCMD algorithm. Furthermore, we provide among others estimates of\nthe mass and mass function, the cluster structure, derive the cluster orbits,\nand discuss the cluster dynamics. All objects belong to the older open cluster\npopulation (1-7Gyr), are in an advanced dynamical stage with signs of mass\nsegregation, and are located close to the solar circle, but show a large range\nin respect of radii, member stars or observed cluster mass (100-2000 Msolar).\nFor the three younger objects we were also able to provide photometric\nmetallicity estimates, which confirms their status as clusters with a roughly\nsolar metallicity. The most outstanding object is clearly NGC 6791, a very old\ncluster with a high metallicity at a distance of about 4.5 kpc from the Sun. We\nestimate a probable radial migration by about 7 kpc, resulting in a birth\nposition close to the Galactic center. Karataş_2023 Karataş et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.09851
15 2302.10024 2023-02-20 Hanyuan Zhang, Jason L. Sanders A kinematic calibration of the O-rich Mira variable period-age relation from Gaia Empirical and theoretical studies have demonstrated that the periods of Mira\nvariable stars are related to their ages. This, together with their brightness\nin the infrared, makes them powerful probes of the formation and evolution of\nhighly-extincted or distant parts of the Local Group. Here we utilise the Gaia\nDR3 catalogue of long-period variable candidates to calibrate the period-age\nrelation of the Mira variables. Dynamical models are fitted to the O-rich Mira\nvariable population across the extended solar neighbourhood and then the\nresulting solar neighbourhood period-kinematic relations are compared to\nexternal calibrations of the age-kinematic relations to derive a Mira variable\nperiod-age relation of\n$\tau\approx(6.9\pm0.3)\,\mathrm{Gyr}(1+\tanh((330\,\mathrm{d}-P)/(400\pm90)\mathrm{d})$.\nOur results compare well with previous calibrations using smaller datasets as\nwell as the period-age properties of Local Group cluster members. This\ncalibration opens the possibility of accurately characterising the star\nformation and the impact of different evolutionary processes throughout the\nLocal Group. Zhang_2023 Zhang and Sanders 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.10024
16 2211.04495 2023-02-16 Sergey E. Koposov, Denis Erkal, Ting S. Li, Gary S. Da Costa, Lara R. Cullinane, Alexander P. Ji, Kyler Kuehn, Geraint F. Lewis, Andrew B. Pace, Nora Shipp, Daniel B. Zucker, Joss Bland-Hawthorn, Sophia Lilleengen, Sarah L. Martell $S^5$: Probing the Milky Way and Magellanic Clouds potentials with the 6-D map of the Orphan-Chenab stream We present a 6-D map of the Orphan-Chenab (OC) stream by combining the data\nfrom Southern Stellar Stream Spectroscopic Survey ($S^5$) and {\it Gaia}. We\nreconstruct the proper motion, radial velocity, distance, on-sky track and\nstellar density along the stream with spline models. The stream has a total\nluminosity of $M_V=-8.2$ and metallicity of $\mathrm{[Fe/H]}=-1.9$, similar to\nclassical Milky Way (MW) satellites like Draco. The stream shows drastic\nchanges in its physical width varying from 200 pc to 1 kpc, but a constant line\nof sight velocity dispersion of 5 km/ss. Despite the large apparent variation\nin the stellar number density along the stream, the flow rate of stars along\nthe stream is remarkably constant. We model the 6-D stream track by a\nLagrange-point stripping method with a flexible MW potential in the presence of\na moving extended Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC). This allows us to constrain the\nmass profile of the MW within the distance range 15.6 < r < 55.5 kpc, with the\nbest measured enclosed mass of $(2.85\pm 0.1)\times 10^{11}\,M_\odot$ within\n32.4 kpc. Our stream measurements are highly sensitive to the LMC mass profile\nwith the most precise measurement of its enclosed mass made at 32.8 kpc,\n$(7.02\pm 0.9)\times10^{10}\, {\rm M}_\odot$. We also detect that the LMC dark\nmatter halo extends to at least 53 kpc. The fitting of the OC stream allows us\nto constrain the past LMC trajectory and the degree of dynamical friction it\nexperienced. We demonstrate that the stars in the OC stream show large energy\nand angular momentum spreads caused by LMC perturbation. Koposov_2023 Koposov et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.04495
17 2206.07419 2023-02-10 Stan Barmentloo, Marius Cautun Determining Satellite Infall Times Using Machine Learning A key unknown of the Milky Way (MW) satellites is their orbital history, and,\nin particular, the time they were accreted onto the MW system since it marks\nthe point where they experience a multitude of environmental processes. We\npresent a new methodology for determining infall times, namely using a neural\nnetwork (NN) algorithm. The NN is trained on MW-analogues in the EAGLE\nhydrodynamical simulation to predict if a dwarf galaxy is at first infall or a\nbacksplash galaxy and to infer its infall time. The resulting NN predicts with\n85\% accuracy if a galaxy currently outside the virial radius is a backsplash\nsatellite and determines the infall times with a typical 68\% confidence\ninterval of 4.4 Gyrs. Applying the NN to MW dwarfs with Gaia EDR3 proper\nmotions, we find that all of the dwarfs within 300 kpc had been inside the\nGalactic halo. The overall MW satellite accretion rate agrees well with the\ntheoretical prediction except for late times when the MW shows a second peak at\na lookback time of 1.5 Gyrs corresponding to the infall of the LMC and its\nsatellites. We also find that the quenching times for ultrafaint dwarfs show no\nsignificant correlation with infall time and thus supporting the hypothesis\nthat they were quenched during reionisation. In contrast, dwarfs with stellar\nmasses above $10^5~M_\odot$ are found to be consistent with environmental\nquenching inside the Galactic halo, with star-formation ceasing on average at\n$0.5^{+0.9}_{-1.2}$ Gyrs after infall. Barmentloo_2023 Barmentloo and Cautun 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.07419
18 2209.11331 2023-02-06 Ilija Medan, Sébastien Lépine Chemodynamical Ages of Small-Scale Kinematic Structures of the Galactic Disc in the Solar Neighborhood from ~250,000 K and M Dwarfs We combine photometric metallicities with astrometry from Gaia DR3 to examine\nthe chemodynamic structure of ~250,000 K dwarfs in the Solar Neighborhood (SN).\nIn kinematics, we observe ridges/clumps of "kinematic groups", like studies of\nmore massive main-sequence stars. Here we note clear differences in both\nmetallicity and vertical velocity as compared to the surrounding regions in\nvelocity space and hypothesize this is due to differences in mean age. To test\nthis, we develop a method to estimate the age distribution of sub-populations\nof stars. In this method, we use GALAH data to define probability distributions\nof W vs. [M/H] in age bins of 2 Gyr and determine optimal age distributions as\nthe best fit weighted sum of these distributions. This process is then\nvalidated using the GALAH subset. We estimate the probable age distribution for\nregions in the kinematic plane, where we find significant sub-structure that is\ncorrelated with the kinematic groups. Most notably, we find an age gradient\nacross the Hercules streams that is correlated with birth radius. Finally, we\nexamine the bending and breathing modes as a function of age. From this, we\nobserve potential hints of an increase in the bending amplitude with age, which\nwill require further analysis in order to confirm it. This is one of the first\nstudies to examine these chemodynamics in the SN using primarily low-mass stars\nand we hope these findings can better constrain dynamical models of the Milky\nWay due to the increase in resolution the sample size provides. Medan_2023 Medan and Lépine 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2209.11331
19 2206.01798 2023-02-03 Madeline Lucey, Sarah Pearson, Jason A. S. Hunt, Keith Hawkins, Melissa Ness, Michael S. Petersen, Adrian M. Price-Whelan, Martin D. Weinberg Dynamically constraining the length of the Milky Way bar We present a novel method for constraining the length of the Galactic bar\nusing 6D phase space information to directly integrate orbits. We define a\npseudo-length for the Galactic bar, named $R_{Freq}$, based on the maximal\nextent of trapped bar orbits. We find the $R_{Freq}$ measured from orbits is\nconsistent with the $R_{Freq}$ of the assumed potential only when the length of\nthe bar and pattern speed of said potential is similar to the model from which\nthe initial phase-space coordinates of the orbits are derived. Therefore, one\ncan measure the model's or the Milky Way's bar length from 6D phase-space\ncoordinates by determining which assumed potential leads to a self-consistent\nmeasured $R_{Freq}$. When we apply this method to $\approx$210,000 stars in\nAPOGEE DR17 and $Gaia$ eDR3 data, we find a consistent result only for\npotential models with a dynamical bar length of $\approx$3.5 kpc. We find the\nMilky Way's trapped bar orbits extend out to only $\approx$3.5 kpc, but there\nis also an overdensity of stars at the end of the bar out to 4.8 kpc which\ncould be related to an attached spiral arm. We also find that the measured\norbital structure of the bar is strongly dependent on the properties of the\nassumed potential. Lucey_2023 Lucey et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.01798
20 2302.01618 2023-02-03 V. V. Bobylev, A. T. Bajkova 3-D kinematics of classical Cepheids according to Gaia, EDR3 catalog The kinematics of about 2000 classical Cepheids of the Milky Way with data\nfrom Gaia\,EDR3 catalog has been studied. For some of these stars, there are\nline-of-sight velocities. On the basis of the nonlinear rotation model, the\nparameters of the rotation curve of the Galaxy were determined. The circular\nlinear rotation velocity of the near-solar neighborhood around the Galaxy\ncenter was $V_0=236\pm 3$~km s$^{-1}$ for the assumed Sun's galactocentric\ndistance $R_0=8.1\pm0.1$~kpc. Analysis of residual velocities of Cepheids based\non the linear Ogorodnikov-Milne model showed the presence of the following\nsignificantly different from zero gradients: $\partial U/\partial x,$ $\partial\nU/\partial z,$ $\partial V/\partial x,$ $\partial V/\partial z$ and $\partial\nW/\partial x,$ which behaves differently depending on the selection radius. The\nmost interesting is the gradient $\partial W/\partial x\sim-0.5\pm0.1$~km\ns$^{-1}$ kpc$^{-1}$ (positive rotation of this star system around the galactic\naxis $y$, $\Omega_y$) since the velocities $W$ are free of galactic rotation.\nHere we have an indirect influence of various effects leading to a perturbation\nof the vertical velocities of the galactic disk stars. Based on a simpler\nmodel, a more accurate estimate of this rotation is obtained,\n$\Omega_y=0.51\pm0.07$~km s$^{-1}$ kpc$^{-1}$. Bobylev_2023 Bobylev and Bajkova 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.01618
21 2302.01379 2023-02-02 Francesco Sylos Labini, Zofia Chrobakova, Roberto Capuzzo-Dolcetta, Martin Lopez-Corredoira Mass models of the Milky Way and estimation of its mass from the GAIA DR3 data-set We use data from the Gaia DR3 dataset to estimate the mass of the Milky Way\n(MW) by analyzing the rotation curve in the range of distances 5 kpc to 28 kpc.\nWe consider three mass models: the first model adds a spherical dark matter\n(DM) halo, following the Navarro-Frenk-White (NFW) profile, to the known\nstellar components. The second model assumes that DM is confined to the\nGalactic disk, following the idea that the observed density of gas in the\nGalaxy is related to the presence of more massive DM disk (DMD), similar to the\nobserved correlation between DM and gas in other galaxies. The third model only\nuses the known stellar mass components and is based on the Modified Newton\nDynamics (MOND) theory. Our results indicate that the DMD model is comparable\nin accuracy to the NFW and MOND models and fits the data better at large radii\nwhere the rotation curve declines but has the largest errors. For the NFW model\nwe obtain a virial mass $M_{vir}= (6.5 \pm 0.3) \times 10^{11} \; M_\odot$ with\nconcentration parameter $c=14.5$, that is lower than what is typically\nreported. In the DMD case we find that the MW mass is $M_d = (1.6 \pm 0.5)\n\times 10^{11} \; M_\odot$ with a disk's characteristic radius of $R_d=17$ kpc. Labini_2023 Labini et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.01379
22 2302.00053 2023-01-31 Akshara Viswanathan, Else Starkenburg, Helmer H. Koppelman, Amina Helmi, Eduardo Balbinot, Anna F. Esselink Hidden deep in the halo: Selection of a reduced proper motion halo catalogue and mining retrograde streams in the velocity space The Milky Way halo is one of the few galactic haloes that provides a unique\ninsight into galaxy formation by resolved stellar populations. Here, we present\na catalogue of $\sim$47 million halo stars selected independent of parallax and\nline-of-sight velocities, using a combination of Gaia DR3 proper motion and\nphotometry by means of their reduced proper motion. We select high tangential\nvelocity (halo) main sequence stars and fit distances to them using their\nsimple colour-absolute-magnitude relation. This sample reaches out to $\sim$21\nkpc with a median distance of $6.6$ kpc thereby probing much further out than\nwould be possible using reliable Gaia parallaxes. The typical uncertainty in\ntheir distances is $0.57_{-0.26}^{+0.56}$ kpc. Using the colour range\n$0.45<(G_0-G_\mathrm{RP,0})<0.715$ where the main sequence is narrower, gives\nan even better accuracy down to $0.39_{-0.12}^{+0.18}$ kpc in distance. The\nmedian velocity uncertainty for stars within this colour range is 15.5 km/s.\nThe distribution of these sources in the sky, together with their tangential\ncomponent velocities, are very well-suited to study retrograde substructures.\nWe explore the selection of two complex retrograde streams: GD-1 and Jhelum.\nFor these streams, we resolve the gaps, wiggles and density breaks reported in\nthe literature more clearly. We also illustrate the effect of the kinematic\nselection bias towards high proper motion stars and incompleteness at larger\ndistances due to Gaia's scanning law. These examples showcase how the full RPM\ncatalogue made available here can help us paint a more detailed picture of the\nbuild-up of the Milky Way halo. Viswanathan_2023 Viswanathan et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.00053
23 2206.07744 2023-01-30 G. C. Myeong, Vasily Belokurov, David S. Aguado, N. Wyn Evans, Nelson Caldwell, James Bradley Milky Way's eccentric constituents with $Gaia$, APOGEE $\&$ GALAH We report the results of an unsupervised decomposition of the local stellar\nhalo in the chemo-dynamical space spanned by the abundance measurements from\nAPOGEE DR17 and GALAH DR3. In our Gaussian Mixture Model, only four independent\ncomponents dominate the halo in the Solar neighborhood, three previously known\n$Aurora$, $Splash$ and Gaia-Sausage/Enceladus (GS/E) and one new, $Eos$. Only\none of these four is of accreted origin, namely the GS/E, thus supporting the\nearlier claims that the GS/E is the main progenitor of the Galactic stellar\nhalo. We show that $Aurora$ is entirely consistent with the chemical properties\nof the so-called Heracles merger. In our analysis in which no predefined\nchemical selection cuts are applied, $Aurora$ spans a wide range of [Al/Fe]\nwith a metallicity correlation indicative of a fast chemical enrichment in a\nmassive galaxy, the young Milky Way. The new halo component dubbed $Eos$ is\nclassified as $in situ$ given its high mean [Al/Fe]. $Eos$ shows strong\nevolution as a function of [Fe/H], where it changes from being the closest to\nGS/E at its lowest [Fe/H] to being indistinguishable from the Galactic\nlow-$\alpha$ population at its highest [Fe/H]. We surmise that at least some of\nthe outer thin disk of the Galaxy started its evolution in the gas polluted by\nthe GS/E, and $Eos$ is an evidence of this process. Myeong_2023 Myeong et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.07744
24 2209.09989 2023-01-27 P. A. Palicio, A. Recio-Blanco, E. Poggio, T. Antoja, P. J. McMillan, E. Spitoni Spiral-like features in the disc revealed by Gaia DR3 radial actions We aim to explore the actions of the new Gaia DR3 astrometry to find\nstructures in the Galactic disc. We compute the actions and the orbital\nparameters of the Gaia DR3 stars with full astrometry and velocities assuming\nan axisymmetric model for the Milky Way. Using Gaia DR3 photometric data, we\nselect a subset of giants stars with better astrometry as control sample. The\nmaps of the percentiles of the radial action J_R reveal spiral-like shape\nstructures. We find a high J_R region centered at R~10.5 kpc of 1 kpc width, as\nwell as three arc-shape regions dominated by circular orbits at inner radii. We\nalso identify the spiral arms in the overdensities of the giant population. We\nfind a good agreement with the literature in the innermost region for the\nScutum-Sagittarius spiral arms. At larger radii, the low J_R structure tracks\nthe Local arm at negative X, while for the Perseus arm the agreement is\nrestricted to the X<2 kpc region, with a displacement with respect to the\nliterature at more negative longitudes. We detect a high J_R area at a\nGalactocentric radii of ~10.5 kpc, consistent with some estimations of the\nOuter Lindblad Resonance location. We conclude that the pattern in the dynamics\nof the old stars is consistent in several places with spatial distribution of\nthe spiral arms traced by young populations, with small potential contributions\nfrom the moving groups. Palicio_2023 Palicio et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2209.09989
25 2207.12977 2023-01-20 Ronald Drimmel, Shourya Khanna, Elena D'Onghia, Thorsten Tepper-García, Joss Bland-Hawthorn, Laurent Chemin, Vincenzo Ripepi, Mercé Romero-Gómez, Pau Ramos, Eloisa Poggio, Rene Andrae, Ronny Blomme, Tristan Cantat-Gaudin, Alfred Castro-Ginard, Gisella Clementini, Francesca Fiqueras, Yves Frémat, Morgan Fouesneau, Alex Lobel, Douglas Marshall, Tatiana Muraveva A new resonance-like feature in the outer disc of the Milky Way Modern astrometric and spectroscopic surveys have revealed a wealth of\nstructure in the phase space of stars in the Milky Way, with evidence of\nresonance features and non-equilibrium processes. Using Gaia's third data\nrelease, we present evidence of a new resonance-like feature in the outer disc\nof the Milky Way. The feature is most evident in the angular momentum\ndistribution of the young Classical Cepheids, a population for which we can\nderive accurate distances over much of the Galactic disc. We then search for\nsimilar features in the outer disc using a much larger sample of red giant\nstars, as well as a compiled list of over 31 million stars with spectroscopic\nline-of-sight velocity measurements. While much less evident in these two older\nsamples, the distribution of stars in action-configuration space suggests that\nresonance features are present here as well. The position of the feature in\naction-configuration space suggests that the new feature may be related to the\nGalactic bar, but other possibilities are discussed. Drimmel_2023 Drimmel et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2207.12977
26 2204.13672 2023-01-19 Shourya Khanna, Sanjib Sharma, Joss Bland-Hawthorn, Michael Hayden Measuring the Streaming motion in the Milky Way disc with Gaia EDR3 + We map the 3D kinematics of the Galactic disc out to 3.5 kpc from the Sun,\nand within 0.75 kpc from the midplane of the Galaxy. To this end, we combine\nhigh quality astrometry from \gedrthree{}, with heliocentric line-of-sight\nvelocities from \gdrtwo{}, and spectroscopic surveys including \apogee{},\n\galah{}, and \lamost{}. We construct an axisymmetric model for the mean\nvelocity field, and subtract this on a star-by-star basis to obtain the\nresidual velocity field in the Galactocentric components (\vphi{}, \vR, \vz),\nand \vlos{}. The velocity residuals are quantified using the power spectrum,\nand we find that the peak power ($A/$[\rm \kms{}]) in the midplane ($|z|<0.25$\nkpc) is ($A_{\phi},A_{\rm R},A_{\rm Z},A_{\rm los}$)=($4.2,8.5,2.6,4.6$), at\n$0.25 < |z|/[{\rm kpc}] < 0.5$, is ($A_{\phi},A_{\rm R},A_{\rm Z},A_{\rm\nlos}$)=($4.0,7.9,3.6,5.3$), and at $0.5 < |z|/[{\rm kpc}] < 0.75$, is\n($A_{\phi},A_{\rm R},A_{\rm Z},A_{\rm los}$)=($1.9,6.9,5.2,6.4$). Our results\nprovide a sophisticated measurement of the streaming motion in the disc and in\nthe individual components. We find that streaming is most significant in \vR,\nand at all heights ($|Z|$) probed, but is also non-negligible in other\ncomponents. Additionally, we find that patterns in velocity field overlap\nspatially with models for Spiral arms in the Galaxy. Our simulations show that\nphase-mixing of disrupting spiral arms can generate such residuals in the\nvelocity field, where the radial component is dominant, just as in real data.\nWe also find that with time evolution both the amplitude and physical scale of\nthe residual motion decrease. Khanna_2023 Khanna et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2204.13672
27 2301.05166 2023-01-12 Salvatore Ferrone, Paola Di Matteo, Alessandra Mastrobuono-Battisti, Misha Haywood, Owain N. Snaith, Marco Montouri, Sergey Khoperskov, David Valls-Gabaud The e-TidalGCs Project: Modeling the extra-tidal features generated by Galactic globular clusters We present the e-TidalGCs Project which aims at modeling and predicting the\nextra-tidal features surrounding all Galactic globular clusters for which 6D\nphase space information, masses and sizes are available (currently 159 globular\nclusters). We focus the analysis and presentation of the results on the\ndistribution of extra-tidal material on the sky, and on the different\nstructures found at different heliocentric distances. We emphasize the wide\nvariety of morphologies found: beyond the canonical tidal tails, our models\nreveal that the extra-tidal features generated by globular clusters take a wide\nvariety of shapes, from thin and elongated shapes, to thick, and complex\nhalo-like structures. We also compare some of the most well studied stellar\nstreams found around Galactic globular clusters to our model predictions,\nnamely those associated to the clusters NGC 3201, NGC 4590, NGC 5466 and Pal 5.\nAdditionally, we investigate how the distribution and extension in the sky of\nthe simulated streams vary with the Galactic potential by making use of three\ndifferent models, containing or not a central spheroid, or a stellar bar.\nOverall, our models predict that the mass lost by the current globular cluster\npopulation in the field from the last 5 Gyrs is between\n$0.3-2.1\times10^{7}M_{\odot}$, an amount comparable between 7-55 % of current\nmass. Most of this lost mass is found in the inner Galaxy, with the half-mass\nradius of this population being between 4-6 kpc. The outputs of the simulations\nwill be publicly available, at a time when the ESA Gaia mission and\ncomplementary spectroscopic surveys are delivering exquisite data to which\nthese models can be compared. Ferrone_2023 Ferrone et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.05166
28 2212.07441 2023-01-08 Francois Hammer, Hefan Li, Gary A. Mamon, Marcel S. Pawlowski, Piercarlo Bonifacio, Yongjun Jiao, Haifeng Wang, Jianling Wang, Yanbin Yang The accretion history of the Milky Way. I. How it shapes globular clusters and dwarf galaxies Halo inhabitants are individual stars, stellar streams, star and globular\nclusters, and dwarf galaxies. Here we compare the two last categories that\ninclude objects of similar stellar mass, which are often studied as\nself-dynamical equilibrium systems. We discover that the half-light radius of\nglobular clusters depends on their orbital pericenter and total energy, and\nthat Milky Way (MW) tides may explain the observed correlation. We also suggest\nthat the accretion epoch of stellar systems in the MW halo can be calibrated by\nthe total orbital energy, and that such a relation is due to both the mass\ngrowth of the MW and dynamical friction affecting mostly satellites with\nnumerous orbits. This calibration starts from the bulge, to Kraken, Gaia\nSausage Enceladus, Sagittarius stellar systems, and finally to the new coming\ndwarfs, either or not linked to the vast-polar structure. The most eccentric\nglobular clusters and dwarfs have their half-light radius scaling as the\ninverse of their binding energy, and this over more than two decades. This\nmeans that earlier arriving satellites are smaller due to the tidal effects of\nthe MW. Therefore, most halo inhabitants appear to have their structural\nparameters shaped by MW tides and also by ram-pressure for the most recent\narrivals, the dwarf galaxies. The correlations found in this study can be used\nas tools to further investigate the origin of globular clusters and dwarfs, as\nwell as the assembly history of our Galaxy. Hammer_2023 Hammer et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.07441
29 2301.02251 2023-01-05 J. Pflamm-Altenburg, P. Kroupa, I. Thies, T. Jerabkova, G. Beccari, T. Prusti, H. M. J. Boffin On the degree of stochastic asymmetry in the tidal tails of star clusters Context: Tidal tails of star clusters are commonly understood to be populated\nsymmetrically. Recently, the analysis of Gaia data revealed large asymmetries\nbetween the leading and trailing tidal tail arms of the four open star clusters\nHyades, Praesepe, Coma Berenices and NGC 752. Aims: As the evaporation of stars\nfrom star clusters into the tidal tails is a stochastic process, the degree of\nstochastic asymmetry is quantified in this work. Methods: For each star cluster\n1000 configurations of test particles are integrated in the combined potential\nof a Plummer sphere and the Galactic tidal field over the life time of the\nparticular star cluster. For each of the four star clusters the distribution\nfunction of the stochastic asymmetry is determined and compared with the\nobserved asymmetry. Results: The probabilities for a stochastic origin of the\nobserved asymmetry of the four star clusters are: Praesepe ~1.7 sigma, Coma\nBerenices ~2.4 sigma, Hyades ~6.7 sigma, NGC 752 ~1.6 sigma. Conclusions: In\nthe case of Praesepe, Coma Berenices and NGC 752 the observed asymmetry can be\ninterpreted as a stochastic evaporation event. However, for the formation of\nthe asymmetric tidal tails of the Hyades additional dynamical processes beyond\na pure statistical evaporation effect are required. Pflamm-Altenburg_2023 Pflamm-Altenburg et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.02251
30 2301.01943 2023-01-05 Sharmila Rani, Gajendra Pandey, Annapurni Subramaniam, N. Kameswara Rao UOCS-IX. AstroSat/UVIT study of the open cluster NGC 2818: Blue Stragglers, Yellow Stragglers, Planetary Nebula, and their membership We present the first far-UV (FUV) imaging results of the intermediate-age\nGalactic open cluster NGC 2818 that has a Planetary nebula (PN) within the\nfield using images taken from the Ultra-violet Imaging Telescope (UVIT) aboard\nAstroSat. We identify cluster members by combining UVIT-detected sources with\nGaia EDR3 data. We detect four bright and hot blue straggler stars (BSSs) and\ntwo yellow straggler stars (YSSs) based on their location in the optical and\nFUV-optical color-magnitude diagrams. Based on the parameters estimated using\nSpectral Energy Distribution (SED), we infer that BSSs are either collisional\nproducts or might have undetectable white dwarf (WD) companions. Our\nphotometric analysis of YSSs confirms their binarity, consistent with the\nspectroscopic results. We find YSSs to be formed through a mass-transfer\nscenario and the hot components are likely to be A-type subdwarfs. A comparison\nof the radial velocity (RV), Gaia EDR3 proper motion of the PN with the\ncluster, and reddening towards the PN and the cluster does not rule out the\nmembership of the PN. Comparing the central star's position with theoretical\npAGB models suggest that it has already entered the WD cooling phase, and its\nmass is deduced to be ~0.66Msun. The corresponding progenitor mass turns out to\nbe ~2.1Msun, comparable to the turn-off mass of the cluster, implying that the\nprogenitor could have formed in the cluster. We suggest that the NGC 2818 might\nbe one of the few known clusters to host a PN, providing a unique opportunity\nto test stellar evolution models. Rani_2023 Rani et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.01943
31 2212.08294 2023-01-03 Daniela Carollo, Norbert Christlieb, Patricia B. Tissera, Emanuel Sillero Understanding the early stages of galaxy formation using very metal-poor stars from the Hamburg/ESO survey We explore the chemo-dynamical properties of a sample of very metal-poor\n(VMP) stars selected from the Hamburg/ESO survey, matched with Gaia EDR3, in\nthe phase-space identified by the three integrals of motion ($L_z$, $E$,\n$I_3$). Disk and halo orbits are separated by using the criteria defined in\nCarollo et al. (2021). We found 26 stars with $[Fe/H] \leq -2.5$ possessing\ndisk kinematics, of which 14 are extremely metal-poor. At these metallicities,\nthe number of stars with disk kinematics is three times its retrograde\ncounterpart. In the same range of metallicity we also identified 37 halo stars\nmost tightly bound to the gravitational potential of the progenitor halo. The\norigin of these stars are investigated by comparing the observational results\nwith simulated galaxies from the Aquarius Project and the IllustrisTNG\nsimulations. We found two mechanisms of formation of VMP stars with disk\nkinematics: accretion from early satellites (which is dominant), and {\it\nin-situ} formation. These stars are very old, with ages > 12.5 Gyr ($z$ > 5),\nand they are $\alpha$-enriched. Accretion and {\it in-situ} formation are also\nfound for the retrograde counterparts with being accretion also the dominant\nmode. Contributing accreted satellites have stellar masses in the range\n$[10^{6}-10^9]$ M_sun, and are very gas-rich. The most bound halo stars are the\noldest detected with a median age of ~ 13.3 Gyr ($z$ ~ 11), and\n$\alpha$-enriched. Our finding clearly show that very old, very metal-poor\nstars store important information on the first stages of assembly of our Galaxy\nand its halo. Carollo_2023 Carollo et al. 2023 https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.08294
32 2212.11989 2022-12-22 Daniel Mikkola, Paul J. McMillan, David Hobbs New stellar velocity substructures from Gaia DR3 proper motions Local stellar motions are expected, and have been shown, to include\nsignatures of the Galaxy's past dynamical evolution. These are typically\ndivided into the disc, which shows the dynamical effects of spiral arms and the\nbar, and the stellar halo, with structures thought to be debris from past\nmergers. We use Gaia Data Release 3 to select large samples of these\npopulations without limiting them to sources with radial velocities. We apply a\npenalised maximum likelihood method to these samples to determine the full 3D\nvelocity distribution in Cartesian $(U, V, W)$ or spherical $(v_r, v_\phi,\nv_\theta)$ coordinates. We find that the disc population is dominated by four\nmoving groups and also detect a new moving group at $(U, V) = (-10, -15)$ km\ns$^{-1}$ which we call MMH-0. For the stellar halo, we isolate the accreted\ncomponent with cuts in transverse velocity and the colour-magnitude diagram. In\nthis component we find several known structures believed to be caused by past\nmergers, particularly one around $(v_r, v_\phi, v_\theta) = (-150, -300, -100)$\nkm s$^{-1}$ appears more prominent than previously claimed. Furthermore we also\nidentify two new structures near $(v_r, v_\phi, v_\theta) = (225, 25, 325)$ km\ns$^{-1}$ and $(0, 150, -125)$ km s$^{-1}$ which we refer to as MMH-1 and MMH-2\nrespectively. These results give new insights into local stellar motions and\nshows the potential of using samples that are not limited to stars with\nmeasured line-of-sight velocities, which is key to providing large samples of\nstars, necessary for future studies. Mikkola_2022a Mikkola et al. 2022a https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.11989
33 2212.11991 2022-12-22 Neige Frankel, Jo Bovy, Scott Tremaine, David W. Hogg Vertical motion in the Galactic disc: unwinding the Snail The distribution of stars in the Milky Way disc shows a spiral structure--the\nSnail--in the space of velocity and position normal to the Galactic mid-plane.\nThe Snail appears as straight lines in the vertical frequency--vertical phase\nplane when effects from sample selection are removed. Their slope has the\ndimension of inverse time, with the simplest interpretation being the inverse\nage of the Snail. Here, we devise and fit a simple model in which the spiral\nstarts as a lopsided perturbation from steady state, that winds up into the\npresent-day morphology. The winding occurs because the vertical frequency\ndecreases with vertical action. We use data from stars in Gaia EDR3 that have\nmeasured radial velocities, pruned by simple distance and photometric selection\nfunctions. We divide the data into boxels of dynamical invariants (radial\naction, angular momentum); our model fits the data well in many of the boxels.\nThe model parameters have physical interpretations: one, $A$, is a perturbation\namplitude, and one, $t$, is interpretable in the simplest models as the time\nsince the event that caused the Snail. We find trends relating the strength and\nage to angular momentum: (i) the amplitude $A$ is small at low angular momentum\n($<1\,600\mathrm{\,kpc\,km\,s}^{-1}$ or guiding-centre radius $< 7.3\,$kpc),\nand over a factor of three larger, with strong variations, in the outer disc;\n(ii) there is no single well-defined perturbation time, with $t$ varying\nbetween 0.2 and 0.6 Gyr. Residuals between the data and the model display\nsystematic trends, implying that the data call for more complex models. Frankel_2022 Frankel et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.11991
34 2212.08519 2022-12-16 Yunpeng Jia, Yuqin Chen, Cuihua Du, Gang zhao Investigating the vertical distribution of the disk as a function of radial action As heating processes can broaden the distributions of radial actions and the\nvertical distributions of the Galactic disks, we investigate the vertical\ndistribution of the Galactic disks as a function of radial action based on\nApache Point Observatory Galactic Evolution Experiment(APOGEE) and Gaia data in\norder to deepen our understanding of the formation and heating history of the\nGalactic disks. We find that the distributions of radial action for both the\nthin and thick disks can be approximately described by pseudo-isothermal\ndistributions, which give a statistical measurement for the temperature of the\ndisk as indicated by the mean radial action of the star sample. Estimations of\nthe scale heights in different radial action ranges for these pseudo-isothermal\ndistributions of the disks seem to show fixed relationships between radial\naction $J_R$ and scale height $h$. We describe these relationships with a\ntwo-parameter function of $h = \sqrt{J_R /a} + b$, where $a$ and $b$ are free\nparameters. When testing with a three-parameter function of\n$h=\sqrt[\alpha]{J_R/a}+b$, we find that this two-parameter function describes\nthe thin disk well, but we note the function should be used with care for the\nthick disk. When comparing the best-fit relationships between the inner and\nouter disk for both of the thin and thick disks, we find that the relationships\nare nearly the same for the thin disks but are different for the thick disks.\nThe inner thick disk shows a nearly flattened relationship, while the outer\nthick disk presents a gradually increasing relationship. This work highlights\nan alternative way to unveil the heating history of the disks by investigating\nthe relationship between scale height and radial action, as these relationships\nencode the formation and heating history of the Galactic disks. Jia_2022 Jia et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.08519
35 2207.05368 2022-12-15 G. Contursi, P. de Laverny, A. Recio-Blanco, E. Spitoni, P. A. Palicio, E. Poggio, V. Grisoni, G. Cescutti, F. Matteucci, L. Spina, M. A. Alvarez, G. Kordopatis, C. Ordenovic, I. Oreshina-Slezak, H. Zhao The cerium content of the Milky Way as revealed by Gaia DR3 GSP-Spec abundances The recent Gaia Third Data Release contains a homogeneous analysis of\nmillions of high-quality Radial Velocity Spectrometer (RVS) stellar spectra by\nthe GSP-Spec module. This led to the estimation of millions of individual\nchemical abundances and allows us to chemically map the Milky Way. Among the\npublished GSP-Spec abundances, three heavy-elements produced by\nneutron-captures in stellar interiors can be found: Ce, Zr and Nd. We use a\nsample of about 30,000 LTE Ce abundances, selected after applying different\ncombinations of GSP-Spec flags. Thanks to the Gaia DR3 astrometric data and\nradial velocities, we explore the cerium content in the Milky Way and, in\nparticular, in its halo and disc components. The high quality of the Ce\nGSP-Spec abundances is quantified thanks to literature comparisons. We found a\nrather flat [Ce/Fe] versus [M/H] trend. We also found a flat radial gradient in\nthe disc derived from field stars and, independently, from about 50 open\nclusters, in agreement with previous studies. The [Ce/Fe] vertical gradient has\nalso been estimated. We also report an increasing [Ce/Ca] vs [Ca/H] in the\ndisc, illustrating the late contribution of AGB with respect to SN II. Our\ncerium abundances in the disc, including the young massive population, are well\nreproduced by a new three-infall chemical evolution model. Among the halo\npopulation, the M 4 globular cluster is found to be enriched in cerium.\nMoreover, eleven stars with cerium abundances belonging to the Thamnos, Helmi\nStream and Gaia-Sausage-Enceladus accreted systems were identified from\nchemo-dynamical diagnostics. We found that the Helmi Stream could be slightly\nunderabundant in cerium, compared to the two other systems. This work\nillustrates the high quality of the GSP-Spec chemical abundances, that\nsignificantly contributes to unveil the heavy elements evolution history of the\nMilky Way. Contursi_2022 Contursi et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2207.05368
36 2206.12436 2022-12-13 E. Spitoni, A. Recio-Blanco, P. de Laverny, P. A. Palicio, G. Kordopatis, M. Schultheis, G. Contursi, E. Poggio, D. Romano, F. Matteucci Beyond the two-infall model I. Indications for a recent gas infall with Gaia DR3 chemical abundances The recent Gaia Data Release 3 (DR3) represents an unparalleled revolution in\nGalactic Archaeology, providing us with numerous radial velocities chemical\nabundances for millions of stars, with all-sky coverage. We present a new\nchemical evolution model for the Galactic disc components (high- and low-\n$\alpha$ sequence stars) designed to reproduce the new abundance ratios\nprovided by the GSP-spec module for the Gaia DR3 and also constrained by the\ndetailed star formation histories for both the thick and thin disc stars\ninferred from previous Gaia releases. Sophisticated modeling based on previous\nGaia releases has found evidence for narrow episodes of enhanced SF inferred in\nrecent time. Additionally, Gaia DR3 highlighted the presence of young (massive)\nlow-$\alpha$ disc stars which show evidence of a recent chemical impoverishment\nin several elements. Hence, in this study, we compare Gaia DR3 chemical\nabundances with the predictions of a three-infall chemical evolution model for\nthe high- and low-$\alpha$ components. The proposed three-infall chemical\nevolution model nicely reproduces the main features of the abundance ratio\n[X/Fe] versus [M/H] (X=Mg, Si, Ca, Ti, $\alpha$) of Gaia DR3 stars in different\nage bins for the considered $\alpha$ elements. Moreover, the most recent gas\ninfall - which started $\sim$ 2.7 Gyr ago - allows us to predict well the Gaia\nDR3 young population which has experienced a recent chemical impoverishment. Spitoni_2022 Spitoni et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.12436
37 2212.02337 2022-12-13 Elisa R. Garro, José G. Fernández-Trincado, Dante Minniti, Wisthon H. Moya, Tali Palma, Timothy C. Beers, Vinicius M. Placco, Beatriz Barbuy, Chris Sneden, Alan Alves-Brito, Bruno Dias, Melike Afşar, Heinz Frelijj, Richard R. Lane Gaia-IGRINS synergy: Orbits of Newly Identified Milky Way Star Clusters The recent exquisite Gaia astrometric, photometric, and radial velocity (RV)\nmeasurements resulted in a substantial advancement for the determination of the\norbits for old star clusters, including the oldest Milky Way globular clusters\n(MW GCs). The main goal of this paper is to use the Gaia DR3 and the VVVX\nmeasurements to obtain the orbits for nearly a dozen new Galactic GC candidates\nthat have been poorly studied or previously unexplored. We use the Gaia DR3 and\nVVVX databases to identify bonafide members of the Galactic GC candidates:\nVVV-CL160, Patchick122, Patchick125, Patchick126, Kronberger99, Kronberger119,\nKronberger143, ESO92-18, ESO93-08, Gaia2, and Ferrero54. The relevant mean\ncluster physical parameters are derived (distances, Galactic coordinates,\nproper motions, RVs). We measure accurate mean RVs for the GCs VVV-CL160 and\nPatchick126, using observations acquired at the Gemini-South telescope with the\nIGRINS high-resolution spectrograph. Orbits for each cluster are then computed\nusing the GravPot16 model, assuming typical Galactic bar pattern speeds. We\nreconstruct the orbits for these clusters for the first time. These include\nstar clusters with retrograde and prograde orbital motions, both in the\nGalactic bulge and disk. Orbital properties, such as the mean time-variations\nof perigalactic and apogalactic distances, eccentricities, vertical excursions\nfrom the Galactic plane, and Z-components of the angular momentum are obtained\nfor our sample. Our main conclusion is that, based on the orbital parameters,\nPatchick125 and Patchick126 are genuine MW bulge/halo GCs; Ferrero54, Gaia2 and\nPatchick122 are MW disk GCs. The orbits of Kronberger99, Kronberger119,\nKronberger143, ESO92-18, and ESO93-08 are more consistent with old MW disk open\nclusters. VVV-CL160 falls very close to the Galactic centre, but reaches larger\ndistances beyond the Sun, thus its origin is still unclear. Garro_2022a Garro et al. 2022a https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.02337

Long, Xuelei Chen, Qi Gao Classifying globular clusters and applying them to estimate the mass of the Milky Way We combine the kinematics of 159 globular clusters (GCs) provided by the Gaia\nEarly Data Release 3 (EDR3) with other observational data to classify the GCs,\nand to estimate the mass of the Milky Way (MW). We use the age-metallicity\nrelation, integrals of motion, action space and the GC orbits to identify the\nGCs as either formed in-situ (Bulge and Disk) or ex situ (via accretion). We\nfind that $45.3\%$ have formed in situ, $38.4\%$ may be related to known merger\nevents: Gaia-Sausage-Enceladus, the Sagittarius dwarf galaxy, the Helmi\nstreams, the Sequoia galaxy, and the Kraken galaxy. We also further identify\nthree new sub-structures associated with the Gaia-Sausage-Enceladus. The\nremaining $16.3\%$ of GCs are unrelated to the known mergers and thought to be\nfrom small accretion events. We select 46 GCs which have radii $8.0 Sun_2022 Sun et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2210.12336
39 2212.05021 2022-12-09 A. Arellano Ferro, F. C. Rojas Galindo, I. H. Bustos Fierro, S. Muneer, M. A. Yepez, Sunetra Giridhar Detailed analysis of the variable star population in the globular cluster NGC 7006 A five year CCD photometric \emph{VI} time-series of NGC 7006 is employed to\nperform a detailed analysis of the known population of variable stars. In the\nprocess we have corrected inconsistent classifications, sky coordinates and\nfound ten new cluster member variables. An independent reddening estimate with\na value $E(B-V)=0.08\pm0.05$ is made. Using Fourier decompositions of RR Lyrae\nlight curves and well established calibrations, the cluster mean metallicity\nand distance [Fe/H]$_{\rm ZW}= -1.53\pm0.15$ and $41.2\pm1.4$ kpc are estimated\nbased on an extended sample of cluster member RRab stars. Using the $Gaia$-DR3\ndata we performed an extensive membership analysis which leads to a clean\nColour-Magnitude diagram, and hence to the identification of variables that are\nlikely field stars, and to considerations on the variables distribution in the\nHorizontal Branch (HB). A double mode RR Lyrae and three CW star are discussed.\nThe origin of CW stars from precursors in the blue tail of the HB with very\nthin ($\sim 0.06 \pm 0.01 M_{\odot}$) envelopes is argued. Our models indicate\nthat the Main Sequence predecessor of RR Lyrae stars had a mass of 0.82-0.85\n$M_{\odot}$ and lost about 25-35\% of its mass during the red giant branch\nevents before settling in the HB some 12-13.5 Gyrs later. 40 2211.14132 2022-12-09 M. L. L. Dantas, G. Guiglion, R. Smiljanic, D. Romano, L. Magrini, T. Bensby, C. Chiappini, E. Franciosini, S. Nepal, G. Tautvaišienė, G. Gilmore, S. Randich, A. C. Lanzafame, U. Heiter, L. Morbidelli, L. Prisinzano, S. Zaggia The Gaia-ESO Survey: Probing the lithium abundances in old metal-rich dwarf stars in the Solar vicinity We test a scenario in which radial migration could affect the Li abundance\npattern of dwarf stars in the solar neighbourhood. This may confirm that the Li\nabundance in these stars can not serve as a probe for the Li abundance in the\ninterstellar medium. We use the high-quality data (including Li abundances)\nfrom the 6th internal Data Release of the Gaia-ESO survey. In this sample, we\ngroup stars by similarity in chemical abundances via hierarchical clustering.\nOur analysis treats both measured Li abundances and upper limits. The Li\nenvelope of the previously identified radially migrated stars is well below the\nbenchmark meteoritic value (<3.26 dex); the star with the highest detected\nabundance has A(Li) = 2.76 dex. This confirms the previous trends observed for\nold dwarf stars (median ages $\sim$ 8 Gyr), where Li decreases for\n[Fe/H]$\gtrsim$0. This result acts as supporting evidence that the abundance of\nLi measured in the upper envelope of old dwarf stars should not be considered a\nproxy for the interstellar medium Li. Our scenario also indicates that the\nstellar yields for [M/H]>0 should not be decreased, as recently proposed in the\nliterature. Our study backs the recent studies that claimed that old dwarfs on\nthe hot side of the dip are efficient probes of the ISM abundance of Li,\nprovided atomic diffusion does not lower significantly the initial Li abundance\nin the atmospheres of metal-rich objects. Wright, Theodora Xylakis-Dornbusch, Kris Youakim, Stefano Zibetti, Cristina Zurita The wide-field, multiplexed, spectroscopic facility WEAVE: Survey design, overview, and simulated implementation WEAVE, the new wide-field, massively multiplexed spectroscopic survey\nfacility for the William Herschel Telescope, will see first light in late 2022.\nWEAVE comprises a new 2-degree field-of-view prime-focus corrector system, a\nnearly 1000-multiplex fibre positioner, 20 individually deployable 'mini'\nintegral field units (IFUs), and a single large IFU. These fibre systems feed a\ndual-beam spectrograph covering the wavelength range 366$-$959\,nm at\n$R\sim5000$, or two shorter ranges at $R\sim20\,000$. After summarising the\ndesign and implementation of WEAVE and its data systems, we present the\norganisation, science drivers and design of a five- to seven-year programme of\neight individual surveys to: (i) study our Galaxy's origins by completing\nGaia's phase-space information, providing metallicities to its limiting\nmagnitude for $\sim$3 million stars and detailed abundances for $\sim1.5$\nmillion brighter field and open-cluster stars; (ii) survey $\sim0.4$ million\nGalactic-plane OBA stars, young stellar objects and nearby gas to understand\nthe evolution of young stars and their environments; (iii) perform an extensive\nspectral survey of white dwarfs; (iv) survey $\sim400$\nneutral-hydrogen-selected galaxies with the IFUs; (v) study properties and\nkinematics of stellar populations and ionised gas in $z<0.5$ cluster galaxies;\n(vi) survey stellar populations and kinematics in $\sim25\,000$ field galaxies\nat $0.3\lesssim z \lesssim 0.7$; (vii) study the cosmic evolution of accretion\nand star formation using $>1$ million spectra of LOFAR-selected radio sources;\n(viii) trace structures using intergalactic/circumgalactic gas at $z>2$.\nFinally, we describe the WEAVE Operational Rehearsals using the WEAVE\nSimulator.
