42 2211.07452 2022-12-05 Barry T. Chiang, Jeremiah P. Ostriker, Hsi-Yu Schive Can ultralight dark matter explain the age-velocity dispersion relation of the Milky Way disc: A revised and improved treatment Ultralight axion-like particles $m_a \sim 10^{-22}$ eV, or Fuzzy Dark Matter\n(FDM), behave comparably to cold dark matter (CDM) on cosmological scales and\nexhibit a kpc-size de Broglie wavelength capable of alleviating established\n(sub-)galactic-scale problems of CDM. Substructures inside an FDM halo incur\ngravitational potential perturbations, resulting in stellar heating sufficient\nto account for the Galactic disc thickening over a Hubble time, as first\ndemonstrated by Church et al. We present a more sophisticated treatment that\nincorporates the full baryon and dark matter distributions of the Milky Way and\nadopts stellar disc kinematics inferred from recent Gaia, APOGEE, and LAMOST\nsurveys. Ubiquitous density granulation and subhalo passages respectively drive\ninner disc thickening and flaring of the outer disc, resulting in an\nobservationally consistent `U-shaped' disc vertical velocity dispersion profile\nwith the global minimum located near the solar radius. The observed\nage-velocity dispersion relation in the solar vicinity can be explained by the\nFDM-substructure-induced heating and places an exclusion bound $m_a \gtrsim\n0.4\times10^{-22}$ eV. We assess non-trivial uncertainties in the empirical\ncore-halo relation, FDM subhalo mass function and tidal stripping, and stellar\nheating estimate. The mass range $m_a\simeq 0.5-0.7\times10^{-22}$ eV favoured\nby the observed thick disc kinematics is in tension with several exclusion\nbounds inferred from dwarf density profiles, stellar streams, and Milky Way\nsatellite populations, which could be significantly relaxed due to the\naforesaid uncertainties. Additionally, strongly anisotropic heating could help\nexplain the formation of ultra-thin disc galaxies. Chiang_2022 Chiang et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.07452
43 2204.01794 2022-12-05 Tilly A Evans, Azadeh Fattahi, Alis J Deason, Carlos S Frenk Observing EAGLE galaxies with JWST: predictions for Milky Way progenitors and their building blocks We present predictions, derived from the EAGLE LCDM cosmological\nhydrodynamical simulations, for the abundance and properties of galaxies\nexpected to be detected at high redshift by the James Webb Space Telescope\n(JWST). We consider the galaxy population as a whole and focus on the\nsub-population of progenitors of Milky Way (MW) analogues, defined to be\ngalaxies with accretion histories similar to the MW's, that is, galaxies that\nunderwent a merger resembling the Gaia-Enceladus-Sausage (GES) event and that\ncontain an analogue of the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) satellite today. We\nderive the luminosity function of all EAGLE galaxies in JWST NIRCam passbands,\nin the redshift range z=2-8, taking into account dust obscuration and different\nexposure times. For an exposure time of $T=10^5$s, average MW progenitors are\nobservable as far back as z~6 in most bands, and this changes to z~5 and z~4\nfor the GES and LMC progenitors, respectively. The progenitors of GES and LMC\nanalogues are, on average, ~2 and ~1 mag fainter than the MW progenitors at\nmost redshifts. They lie, on average, within ~60 and ~30 arcsec, respectively,\nof their future MW host at all times, and thus will appear within the\nfield-of-view of JWST NIRCam. We conclude that galaxies resembling the main\nprogenitor of the MW and its major accreted components should be observable\nwith JWST beyond redshift 2, providing a new and unique window in studying the\nformation history of our own galaxy. Evans_2022 Evans et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2204.01794
44 2201.03571 2022-11-29 Khyati Malhan, Monica Valluri, Katherine Freese, Rodrigo A. Ibata New constraints on the dark matter density profiles of dwarf galaxies from proper motions of globular cluster streams The central density profiles in dwarf galaxy halos depend strongly on the\nnature of dark matter. Recently, in Malhan et al. (2021), we employed N-body\nsimulations to show that the cuspy cold dark matter (CDM) subhalos predicted by\ncosmological simulations can be differentiated from cored subhalos using the\nproperties of accreted globular cluster (GC) streams since these GCs experience\ntidal stripping within their parent halos prior to accretion onto the Milky\nWay. We previously found that clusters that are accreted within cuspy subhalos\nproduce streams with larger physical widths and higher dispersions in\nline-of-sight velocity and angular momentum than streams that are accreted\nwithin cored subhalos. Here, we use the same suite of simulations to\ndemonstrate that the dispersion in the tangential velocities of streams\n($\sigma_{v_\mathrm{Tan}}$) is also sensitive to the central DM density\nprofiles of their parent dwarfs and GCs that were accreted from: cuspy subhalos\nproduce streams with larger $\sigma_{v_\mathrm{Tan}}$ than those accreted\ninside cored subhalos. Using Gaia EDR3 observations of multiple GC streams we\ncompare their $\sigma_{v_\mathrm{Tan}}$ values with simulations. The measured\n$\sigma_{v_\mathrm{Tan}}$ values are consistent with both an ``in situ'' origin\nand with accretion inside cored subhalos of $M\sim 10^{8-9}M_{\odot}$ (or very\nlow-mass cuspy subhalos of mass $\sim 10^8M_{\odot}$). Despite the large\ncurrent uncertainties in $\sigma_{v_\mathrm{Tan}}$, we find a low probability\nthat any of the progenitor GCs were accreted from cuspy subhalos of $M_{\rm\nsubhalo}\buildrel > \over \sim$ $10^9 M_{\odot}$. The uncertainties on Gaia\ntangential velocity measurements are expected to decrease in future and will\nallow for stronger constraints on subhalo DM density profiles. Malhan_2022a Malhan et al. 2022a https://arxiv.org/abs/2201.03571
45 2207.11084 2022-11-28 P. Jofre, A. Jorissen, C. Aguilera-Gomez, S. Van Eck, J. Tayar, M. Pinsonneault, J. Zinn, S. Goriely, H. Van Winckel Cannibals in the thick disk II -- Radial-velocity monitoring of the young alpha-rich stars Determining ages of stars for reconstructing the history of the Milky Way\nremains one of the most difficult tasks in astrophysics. This involves knowing\nwhen it is possible to relate the stellar mass with its age and when it is not.\nThe young $\alpha-$rich (YAR) stars present such a case in which we are still\nnot sure about their ages because they are relatively massive, implying young\nages, but their abundances are $\alpha-$enhanced, which implies old ages. We\nreport the results from new observations from a long-term\nradial-velocity-monitoring campaign complemented with high-resolution\nspectroscopy, as well as new astrometry and seismology of a sample of 41 red\ngiants from the third version of APOKASC, which includes YAR stars. The aim is\nto better characterize the YAR stars in terms of binarity, mass, abundance\ntrends, and kinematic properties.The radial velocities of HERMES, APOGEE, and\nGaia were combined to determine the binary fraction among YAR stars. In\ncombination with their mass estimate, evolutionary status, chemical\ncomposition, and kinematic properties, it allowed us to better constrain the\nnature of these objects. We found that stars with $\mathrm{M} < 1\n\mathrm{M}_\odot$ were all single, whereas stars with $\mathrm{M} > 1\n\mathrm{M}_\odot$ could be either single or binary. This is in agreement with\ntheoretical predictions of population synthesis models. Studying their [C/N],\n[C/Fe], and [N/Fe], trends with mass, it became clear that many YAR stars do\nnot follow the APOKASC stars, favoring the scenario that most of them are the\nproduct of mass transfer. Abr. Jofre_2022 Jofre et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2207.11084
46 2211.03416 2022-11-24 Viola Hegedűs, Szabolcs Mészáros, Paula Jofré, Guy S. Stringfellow, Diane Feuillet, Domingo Aníbal García-Hernández, Christian Nitschelm, Olga Zamora Comparative analysis of atmospheric parameters from high-resolution spectroscopic sky surveys: APOGEE, GALAH, Gaia-ESO SDSS-IV APOGEE-2, GALAH and Gaia-ESO are high resolution, ground-based,\nmulti-object spectroscopic surveys providing fundamental stellar atmospheric\nparameters and multiple elemental abundance ratios for hundreds of thousands of\nstars of the Milky Way. We undertake a comparison between the most recent data\nreleases of these surveys to investigate the accuracy and precision of derived\nparameters by placing the abundances on an absolute scale. We discuss the\ncorrelations in parameter and abundance differences as a function of main\nparameters. Uncovering the variants provides a basis to on-going efforts of\nfuture sky surveys. Quality samples from the APOGEE-GALAH, APOGEE-GES and\nGALAH-GES overlapping catalogs are collected. We investigate the mean variants\nbetween the surveys, and linear trends are also investigated. We compare the\nslope of correlations and mean differences with the reported uncertainties. The\naverage and scatter of vrad, Teff, log g, [M/H] and vmicro, along with numerous\nspecies of elemental abundances in the combined catalogs show that in general\nthere is a good agreement between the surveys. We find large radial velocity\nscatters ranging from 1.3 km/s to 4.4 km/s when comparing the three surveys. We\nobserve weak trends: e.g. in $\Delta$Teff vs. $\Delta$log g for the APOGEE-GES\nstars, and a clear correlation in the vmicro-$\Delta$vmicro planes in the\nAPOGEE-GALAH common sample. For [$\alpha$/H], [Ti/H] (APOGEE-GALAH giants) and\n[Al/H] (APOGEE-GALAH dwarfs) potential strong correlations are discovered as a\nfunction of the differences in the main atmospheric parameters, and we find\nweak trends for other elements. In general we find good agreement between the\nthree surveys within their respective uncertainties. However, there are certain\nregimes in which strong variants exist, which we discuss. There are still\noffsets larger than 0.1 dex in the absolute abundance scales. Hegedűs_2022 Hegedűs et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.03416
47 2207.02861 2022-11-24 Benjamin C. Dodge, Oren Slone, Mariangela Lisanti, Timothy Cohen Dynamics of Stellar Disk Tilting from Satellite Mergers The Milky Way's stellar disk can tilt in response to torques that result from\ninfalling satellite galaxies and their associated tidal debris. In this work,\nwe explore the dynamics of disk tilting by running N-body simulations of\nmergers in an isolated, isotropic Milky Way-like host galaxy, varying over\nsatellite virial mass, initial position, and orbit. We develop and validate a\nfirst-principles understanding of the dynamics that govern how the host\ngalaxy's stellar disk responds to the satellite's dark matter debris. We find\nthat the degree of disk tilting can be large for cosmologically-motivated\nmerger histories. In particular, our results suggest that the Galactic disk may\nstill be tilting in response to Gaia-Sausage-Enceladus, one of the most\nsignificant recent mergers in the Milky Way's history. These findings have\nimplications for terrestrial direct detection experiments as disk tilting\nchanges the relative location of the Sun with respect to dark matter\nsubstructure left behind by a merging galaxy. Dodge_2022 Dodge et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2207.02861
48 2211.12684 2022-11-23 George A. Gontcharov, Maxim Yu. Khovritchev, Aleksandr V. Mosenkov, Vladimir B. Il'in, Alexander A. Marchuk, Denis M. Poliakov, Olga S. Ryutina, Sergey S. Savchenko, Anton A. Smirnov, Pavel A. Usachev, Jae-Woo Lee, Conner Camacho, Noah Hebdon Isochrone fitting of Galactic globular clusters -- IV. NGC6362 and NGC6723 We present new isochrone fits to the colour-magnitude diagrams of the\nGalactic globular clusters NGC\,6362 and NGC\,6723. We utilize 22 and 26\nphotometric filters for NGC\,6362 and NGC\,6723, respectively, from the\nultraviolet to mid-infrared using data sets from {\it HST}, {\it Gaia}, unWISE,\nand other photometric sources. We use models and isochrones from the Dartmouth\nStellar Evolution Database (DSED) and Bag of Stellar Tracks and Isochrones\n(BaSTI) for $\alpha$-enhanced [$\alpha$/Fe]$=+0.4$ and different helium\nabundances. The metallicities [Fe/H]$=-1.04\pm0.07$ and $-1.09\pm0.06$ are\nderived from the red giant branch slopes in our fitting for NGC\,6362 and\nNGC\,6723, respectively. They agree with spectroscopic estimates from the\nliterature. We find a differential reddening up to $\Delta E(B-V)=0.13$ mag in\nthe NGC\,6723 field due to the adjacent Corona Australis cloud complex. We\nderive the following for NGC\,6362 and NGC\,6723, respectively: distances\n$7.75\pm0.03\pm0.15$ (statistic and systematic error) and $8.15\pm0.04\pm0.15$\nkpc; ages $12.0\pm0.1\pm0.8$ and $12.4\pm0.1\pm0.8$ Gyr; extinctions\n$A_\mathrm{V}=0.19\pm0.04\pm0.06$ and $0.24\pm0.03\pm0.06$ mag; reddenings\n$E(B-V)=0.056\pm0.01\pm0.02$ and $0.068\pm0.01\pm0.02$ mag. DSED provides\nsystematically lower [Fe/H] and higher reddenings than BaSTI. However, the\nmodels agree in their relative estimates: NGC\,6723 is $0.44\pm0.04$ kpc\nfurther, $0.5\pm0.1$ Gyr older, $\Delta E(B-V)=0.007\pm0.002$ more reddened,\nand with $0.05\pm0.01$ dex lower [Fe/H] than NGC\,6362. The lower metallicity\nand greater age of NGC\,6723 with respect to NGC\,6362 explain their horizontal\nbranch morphology difference. This confirms age as the second parameter for\nthese clusters. We provide lists of the cluster members from the {\it Gaia}\nData Release 3. Gontcharov_2022 Gontcharov et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.12684
49 2211.13153 2022-11-23 Yongda Zhu, Hai-Xia Ma, Xiao-Bo Dong, Yang Huang, Tobias Mistele, Bo Peng, Qian Long, Tianqi Wang, Liang Chang, Xi Jin How Close Dark Matter Halos and MOND Are to Each Other: Three-Dimensional Tests Based on Gaia DR2 Aiming at discriminating different gravitational potential models of the\nMilky Way, we perform tests based on the kinematic data powered by the Gaia DR2\nastrometry, over a large range of $(R,z)$ locations. Invoking the complete form\nof Jeans equations that admit three integrals of motion, we use the independent\n$R$- and $z$-directional equations as two discriminators ($T_R$ and $T_z$). We\napply the formula for spatial distributions of radial and vertical velocity\ndispersions proposed by Binney et al., and successfully extend it to azimuthal\ncomponents, $\sigma_\theta(R,z)$ and $V_\theta(R,z)$; the analytic form avoids\nthe numerical artifacts caused by numerical differentiation in Jeans-equations\ncalculation given the limited spatial resolutions of observations, and more\nimportantly reduces the impact of kinematic substructures in the Galactic disk.\nIt turns out that whereas the current kinematic data are able to reject\nMoffat's Modified Gravity (let alone the Newtonian baryon-only model),\nMilgrom's MOND is still not rejected. In fact, both the carefully calibrated\nfiducial model invoking a spherical dark matter (DM) halo and MOND are equally\nconsistent with the data at almost all spatial locations (except that probably\nboth have respective problems at low-$|z|$ locations), no matter which a tracer\npopulation or which a meaningful density profile is used. Because there is no\nfree parameter at all in the quasi-linear MOND model we use, and the baryonic\nparameters are actually fine-tuned in the DM context, such an effective\nequivalence is surprising, and might be calling forth a transcending synthesis\nof the two paradigms. Zhu_2022 Zhu et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.13153
50 2202.02132 2022-11-22 Hanneke C. Woudenberg, Orlin Koop, Eduardo Balbinot, Amina Helmi Characterization and dynamics of the peculiar stream Jhelum, A tentative role for the Sagittarius dwarf galaxy Stellar streams are a promising tool to study the Milky Way's dark matter\nsubhalo population, as interactions with subhalos could produce substructure in\nstreams. However, other possible causes for substructure first need to be well\nunderstood. Here we studied the kinematics and the unusual morphology of the\nstellar stream Jhelum. Using a combination of ground-based photometry and Gaia\nEDR3 astrometry, we characterized the morphology of Jhelum. We combined this\nnew data with radial velocities from the literature to perform orbit\nintegrations of the stream in static Galactic potentials. We also carried out\nN-body simulations in the presence of the Sagittarius dwarf galaxy. The new\ndata reveal a previously unreported tertiary component in the stream, as well\nas several gaps and a kink-like feature in its narrow component. We find that\nfor a range of realistic Galactic potentials, no single orbit is able to\nreproduce Jhelum's radial velocity data entirely. A generic property of the\norbital solutions is that they share a similar orbital plane to Sagittarius and\nthis leads to repeated encounters with the stream. Using N-body simulations\nthat include a massive Sagittarius, we explored its effect on Jhelum, and we\nshow that these encounters can qualitatively reproduce the narrow and broad\ncomponents in Jhelum, as well as create a tertiary component in some cases. We\nalso find evidence that such encounters can result in an apparent increase in\nthe velocity dispersion of the stream by a factor up to four due to overlapping\nnarrow and broad components. Our findings suggest that the Jhelum stream is\neven more complex than once thought; however, its morphology and kinematics can\ntentatively be explained via the interactions with Sagittarius. In this\nscenario, the formation of Jhelum's narrow and broad components occurs\nnaturally, yet some of the smaller gap-like features remain to be explained. Woudenberg_2022 Woudenberg et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2202.02132
51 2207.11263 2022-11-16 Steffani M. Grondin, Jeremy J. Webb, Nathan W. C. Leigh, Joshua S. Speagle, Reem J. Khalifeh Searching for the extra-tidal stars of globular clusters using high-dimensional analysis and a core particle spray code Three-body interactions can eject stars from the core of a globular cluster,\ncausing them to enter the Galactic halo as extra-tidal stars. While finding\nextra-tidal stars is imperative for understanding cluster evolution, connecting\nisolated extra-tidal field stars back to their birth cluster is extremely\ndifficult. In this work, we present a new methodology consisting of\nhigh-dimensional data analysis and a particle spray code to identify\nextra-tidal stars of any Galactic globular cluster using M3 as a case study.\nUsing the t-Stochastic Neighbour Embedding (t-SNE) and Uniform Manifold\nApproximation and Projection (UMAP) machine learning dimensionality reduction\nalgorithms, we first identify a set of 103 extra-tidal candidates in the APOGEE\nDR17 data catalogue with chemical abundances similar to M3 stars. To confirm\neach candidate's extra-tidal nature, we introduce corespray - a new\nPython-based three-body particle spray code that simulates extra-tidal stars\nfor any Galactic globular cluster. Using Gaia EDR3 proper motions and APOGEE\nDR17 radial velocities, we apply multivariate Gaussian modelling and an extreme\ndeconvolution to identify the extra-tidal candidates that are more likely to be\nassociated with a distribution of corespray-simulated M3 extra-tidal stars than\nthe field. Through these methods, we identify 10 new high-probability\nextra-tidal stars produced via three-body interactions in M3. We also explore\nwhether any of our extra-tidal candidates are consistent with being ejected\nfrom M3 through different dynamical processes. Future applications of corespray\nwill yield better understandings of core dynamics, star formation histories and\nbinary fractions in globular clusters. Grondin_2022 Grondin et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2207.11263
52 2208.13791 2022-11-11 Federico Sestito, Kim A. Venn, Anke Arentsen, David Aguado, Collin L. Kielty, Carmela Lardo, Nicolas F. Martin, Julio F. Navarro, Else Starkenburg, Fletcher Waller, Raymond G. Carlberg, Patrick François, Jonay I. González Hernández, Georges Kordopatis, Sara Vitali, Zhen Yuan The Pristine Inner Galaxy Survey (PIGS) V: a chemo-dynamical investigation of the early assembly of the Milky Way with the most metal-poor stars in the bulge The investigation of the metal-poor tail in the Galactic bulge provides\nunique information on the early Milky Way assembly and evolution. A\nchemo-dynamical analysis of 17 very metal-poor stars (VMP, [Fe/H] $<-2.0$)\nselected from the Pristine Inner Galaxy Survey was carried out based on\nGemini/GRACES spectra. The chemistry suggests that the majority of our stars\nare very similar to metal-poor stars in the Galactic halo. Orbits calculated\nfrom {\it Gaia} EDR3 imply these stars are brought into the bulge during the\nearliest Galactic assembly. Most of our stars have large [Na,Ca/Mg] abundances,\nand thus show little evidence of enrichment by pair-instability supernovae. Two\nof our stars (P171457, P184700) have chemical abundances compatible with\nsecond-generation globular cluster stars, suggestive of the presence of ancient\nand now dissolved globular clusters in the inner Galaxy. One of them (P171457)\nis extremely metal-poor ([Fe/H] $<-3.0$) and well below the metallicity floor\nof globular clusters, which supports the growing evidence for the existence of\nlower-metallicity globular clusters in the early Universe. A third star\n(P180956, [Fe/H] $\sim-2$) has low [Na,Ca/Mg] and very low [Ba/Fe] for its\nmetallicity, which are consistent with formation in a system polluted by only\none or a few low-mass supernovae. Interestingly, its orbit is confined to the\nGalactic plane, like other very metal-poor stars found in the literature, which\nhave been associated with the earliest building blocks of the Milky Way. Sestito_2022 Sestito et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2208.13791
53 2211.06086 2022-11-11 G. Cescutti, P. Bonifacio, E. Caffau, L. Monaco, M. Franchini, L. Lombardo, A. M. Matas Pinto, F. Lucertini, P. François, E. Spitoni, R. Lallement, L. Sbordone, A. Mucciarelli, M. Spite, C. J. Hansen, P. Di Marcantonio, A. Kučinskas, V. Dobrovolskas, A. J. Korn, M. Valentini, L. Magrini, S. Cristallo, F. Matteucci MINCE I. Presentation of the project and of the first year sample In recent years, Galactic archaeology has become a particularly vibrant field\nof astronomy, with its main focus set on the oldest stars of our Galaxy. In\nmost cases, these stars have been identified as the most metal-poor. However,\nthe struggle to find these ancient fossils has produced an important bias in\nthe observations - in particular, the intermediate metal-poor stars\n(-2.5<[Fe/H]< -1.5) have been frequently overlooked. The missing information\nhas consequences for the precise study of the chemical enrichment of our\nGalaxy, in particular for what concerns neutron-capture elements and it will be\nonly partially covered by future multi-object spectroscopic surveys such as\nWEAVE and 4MOST. Measuring at Intermediate Metallicity Neutron Capture Elements\n(MINCE) is gathering the first high-quality spectra (high S/N ratio and high\nresolution) for several hundreds of bright and metal-poor stars, mainly located\nin our Galactic halo. We compiled our selection mainly on the basis of Gaia\ndata and determined the stellar atmospheres of our sample and the chemical\nabundances of each star. In this paper, we present the first sample of 59\nspectra of 46 stars. We measured the radial velocities and computed the\nGalactic orbits for all stars. We found that 8 stars belong to the thin disc,\n15 to disrupted satellites, and the remaining cannot be associated to the\nmentioned structures, and we call them halo stars. For 33 of these stars, we\nprovide abundances for the elements up to zinc. We also show the chemical\nevolution results for eleven chemical elements, based on recent models. Our\nobservational strategy of using multiple telescopes and spectrographs to\nacquire high S/N and high-resolution spectra has proven to be very efficient\nsince the present sample was acquired over only about one year of observations.\nFinally, our target selection strategy proved satisfactory for our purposes. Cescutti_2022 Cescutti et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.06086
54 2206.09246 2022-11-07 Matthew D. A. Orkney, Chervin F. P. Laporte, Robert J. J. Grand, Facundo A. Gómez, Freeke van de Voort, Federico Marinacci, Ruediger Pakmor, Volker Springel The impact of two massive early accretion events in a Milky Way-like galaxy: repercussions for the buildup of the stellar disc and halo We identify and characterise a Milky Way-like realisation from the Auriga\nsimulations with two consecutive massive mergers $\sim2\,$Gyr apart at high\nredshift, comparable to the reported Kraken and Gaia-Sausage-Enceladus. The\nKraken-like merger ($z=1.6$, $M_{\rm Tot} = 8\times10^{10}\,$M$_{\odot}$) is\ngas-rich, deposits most of its mass in the inner $10\,$kpc, and is largely\nisotropic. The Sausage-like merger ($z=1.14$, $M_{\rm Tot} =\n1\times10^{11}\,$M$_{\odot}$) leaves a more extended mass distribution at\nhigher energies, and has a radially anisotropic distribution. For the higher\nredshift merger, the stellar mass ratio of the satellite to host galaxy is 1:3.\nAs a result, the chemistry of the remnant is indistinguishable from\ncontemporaneous in-situ populations, making it challenging to identify this\ncomponent through chemical abundances. This naturally explains why all\nabundance patterns attributed so far to Kraken are in fact fully consistent\nwith the metal-poor in-situ so-called Aurora population and thick disc.\nHowever, our model makes a falsifiable prediction: if the Milky Way underwent a\ngas-rich double merger at high redshift, then this should be imprinted on its\nstar formation history with bursts about $\sim2\,$Gyrs apart. This may offer\nconstraining power on the highest-redshift major mergers. Orkney_2022 Orkney et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.09246
55 2204.04233 2022-11-02 Danny Horta, Ricardo P. Schiavon, J. Ted Mackereth, David H. Weinberg, Sten Hasselquist, Diane Feuillet, Robert W. O'Connell, Borja Anguiano, Carlos Allende-Prieto, Rachael L. Beaton, Dmitry Bizyaev, Katia Cunha, Doug Geisler, D. A. García-Hernández, Jon Holtzman, Henrik Jönsson, Richard R. Lane, Steve R. Majewski, Szabolcs Mészáros, Dante Minniti, Christian Nitschelm, Matthew Shetrone, Verne V. Smith, Gail Zasowski The chemical characterisation of halo substructure in the Milky Way based on APOGEE Galactic haloes in a $\Lambda$-CDM universe are predicted to host today a\nswarm of debris resulting from cannibalised dwarf galaxies. The chemo-dynamical\ninformation recorded in their stellar populations helps elucidate their nature,\nconstraining the assembly history of the Galaxy. Using data from APOGEE and\n\textit{Gaia}, we examine the chemical properties of various halo\nsubstructures, considering elements that sample various nucleosynthetic\npathways. The systems studied are Heracles, \textit{Gaia}-Enceladus/Sausage\n(GES), the Helmi stream, Sequoia, Thamnos, Aleph, LMS-1, Arjuna, I'itoi, Nyx,\nIcarus, and Pontus. Abundance patterns of all substructures are cross-compared\nin a statistically robust fashion. Our main findings include: {\it i)} the\nchemical properties of most substructures studied match qualitatively those of\ndwarf Milky Way satellites, such as the Sagittarius dSph. Exceptions are Nyx\nand Aleph, which are chemically similar to disc stars, implying that these\nsubstructures were likely formed \textit{in situ}; {\it ii)} Heracles differs\nchemically from {\it in situ} populations such as Aurora and its inner halo\ncounterparts in a statistically significant way. The differences suggest that\nthe star formation rate was lower in Heracles than in the early Milky Way; {\it\niii)} the chemistry of Arjuna, LMS-1, and I'itoi is indistinguishable from that\nof GES, suggesting a possible common origin; {\it iv)} all three Sequoia\nsamples studied are qualitatively similar. However, only two of those samples\npresent chemistry that is consistent with GES in a statistically significant\nfashion; {\it v)} the abundance patterns of the Helmi stream and Thamnos are\ndifferent from all other halo substructures.
