56 2207.03492 2022-10-31 Axel Widmark, Lawrence M. Widrow, Aneesh Naik Mapping Milky Way disk perturbations in stellar number density and vertical velocity using Gaia DR3 We have mapped the number density and mean vertical velocity of the Milky\nWay's stellar disk out to roughly two kiloparsecs from the Sun using Gaia Data\nRelease 3 (DR3) and complementary photo-astrometric distance information from\nStarHorse. For the number counts, we carefully masked spatial regions that are\ncompromised by open clusters, great distances, or dust extinction and used\nGaussian processes to arrive at a smooth, non-parametric estimate for the\nunderlying number density field. We find that the number density and velocity\nfields depart significantly from an axisymmetric and mirror-symmetric model.\nThese departures, which include projections of the Gaia phase-space spiral,\nsignal the presence of local disturbances in the disk. We identify two features\nthat are present in both stellar number density and mean vertical velocity. One\nof these features appears to be associated with the Local Spiral Arm. It is\nmost prominent at small heights and is largely symmetric across the mid-plane\nof the disk. The density and velocity field perturbations are phase-shifted by\nroughly a quarter wavelength, suggesting a breathing mode that is propagating\nin the direction of Galactic longitude $l\sim 270$ deg. The second feature is a\ngradient in the stellar number density and mean vertical velocity with respect\nto Galactocentric radius. This feature, which extends across the entire region\nof our analysis, may be associated with the extension of the Galactic warp into\nthe Solar neighbourhood in combination with more localised bending waves. Widmark_2022a Widmark et al. 2022a https://arxiv.org/abs/2207.03492
57 2210.15525 2022-10-27 L. Magrini, C. Viscasillas Vazquez, L. Spina, S. Randich, D. Romano, E. Franciosini, A. Recio-Blanco, T. Nordlander, V. D'Orazi, M. Baratella, R. Smiljanic, M. L. L. Dantas, L. Pasquini, E. Spitoni, G. Casali, M. Van der Swaelmen, T. Bensby, E. Stonkute, S. Feltzing. G. G. Sacco, A. Bragaglia, E. Pancino, U. Heiter, K. Biazzo, G. Gilmore, M. Bergemann, G. Tautvaivsiene, C. Worley, A. Hourihane, A. Gonneau, L. Morbidelli The Gaia-ESO survey: mapping the shape and evolution of the radial abundance gradients with open clusters The spatial distribution of elemental abundances and their time evolution are\namong the major constraints to disentangle the scenarios of formation and\nevolution of the Galaxy. We used the sample of open clusters available in the\nfinal release of the Gaia-ESO survey to trace the Galactic radial abundance and\nabundance to iron ratio gradients, and their time evolution. We selected member\nstars in 62 open clusters, with ages from 0.1 to about 7~Gyr, located in the\nGalactic thin disc at Galactocentric radii from about 6 to 21~kpc. We analysed\nthe shape of the resulting [Fe/H] gradient, the average gradients [El/H] and\n[El/Fe] combining elements belonging to four different nucleosynthesis\nchannels, and their individual abundance and abundance ratio gradients. We also\ninvestigated the time evolution of the gradients dividing open clusters in\nthree age bins. The[Fe/H] gradient has a slope of -0.054 dex~kpc-1. We saw\ndifferent behaviours for elements belonging to different channels. We found\nthat the youngest clusters in the inner disc have lower metallicity than their\nolder counterpart and they outline a flatter gradient. We considered some\npossible explanations, including the effects of gas inflow and migration. We\nsuggested that it might be a bias introduced by the standard spectroscopic\nanalysis producing lower metallicities in low gravity stars. To delineate the\nshape of the `true' gradient, we should limit our analysis to stars with low\nsurface gravity logg>2.5 and xi<1.8 km~s-1. Based on this reduced sample, we\ncan conclude that the gradient has minimally evolved over the time-frame\noutlined by the open clusters, indicating a slow and stationary formation of\nthe thin disc in the latest Gyr. We found a secondary role of clusters'\nmigration in shaping the gradient, with a more prominent role of migration for\nthe oldest clusters. Magrini_2022 Magrini et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2210.15525
58 2210.13472 2022-10-24 Pavel Kroupa, Tereza Jerabkova, Ingo Thies, Jan Pflamm-Altenburg, Benoit Famaey, Henri M. J. Boffin, Joerg Dabringhausen, Giacomo Beccari, Timo Prusti, Christian Boily, Xufen Wu, Jaroslav Haas, Hosein Haghi, Akram Hasani Zonoozi, Guillaume Thomas, Ladislav Subr, Sverre J. Aarseth Asymmetrical tidal tails of open star clusters: stars crossing their cluster's prah challenge Newtonian gravitation After their birth a significant fraction of all stars pass through the tidal\nthreshold (prah) of their cluster of origin into the classical tidal tails. The\nasymmetry between the number of stars in the leading and trailing tails tests\ngravitational theory. All five open clusters with tail data (Hyades, Praesepe,\nComa Berenices, COIN-Gaia 13, NGC 752) have visibly more stars within dcl = 50\npc of their centre in their leading than their trailing tail. Using the\nJerabkova-compact-convergent-point (CCP) method, the extended tails have been\nmapped out for four nearby 600-2000 Myr old open clusters to dcl>50 pc. These\nare on near-circular Galactocentric orbits, a formula for estimating the\norbital eccentricity of an open cluster being derived. Applying the Phantom of\nRamses code to this problem, in Newtonian gravitation the tails are\nnear-symmetrical. In Milgromian dynamics (MOND) the asymmetry reaches the\nobserved values for 50 < dcl/pc < 200, being maximal near peri-galacticon, and\ncan slightly invert near apo-galacticon, and the K\"upper epicyclic\noverdensities are asymmetrically spaced. Clusters on circular orbits develop\norbital eccentricity due to the asymmetrical spill-out, therewith spinning up\nopposite to their orbital angular momentum. This positive dynamical feedback\nsuggests Milgromian open clusters to demise rapidly as their orbital\neccentricity keeps increasing. Future work is necessary to better delineate the\ntidal tails around open clusters of different ages and to develop a Milgromian\ndirect n-body code. Kroupa_2022 Kroupa et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2210.13472
59 2210.07905 2022-10-14 Ayeon Lee, Young Sun Lee, Young Kwang Kim, Timothy C. Beers, Deokkeun An Chemodynamical Analysis of Metal-rich High-eccentricity Stars in the Milky Way's Disk We present a chemodynamical analysis of 11,562 metal-rich, high-eccentricity\nhalo-like main-sequence (MS) stars, which has been referred to as the Splash or\nSplashed Disk, selected from Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) and Large Sky Area\nMulti-Object Fiber Spectroscopic Telescope (LAMOST). When divided into two\ngroups, a low-[$\alpha$/Fe] population (LAP) and a high-[$\alpha$/Fe]\npopulation (HAP), based on kinematics and chemistry, we find that they exhibit\nvery distinct properties, indicative of different origins. From a detailed\nanalysis of their orbital inclinations, we suggest that the HAP arises from a\nlarge fraction (~ 90%) of heated disk stars and a small fraction (~ 10%) of in\nsitu stars from a starburst population, likely induced by interaction of the\nMilky Way with Gaia Sausage/Enceladus (GSE) or other early merger. The LAP\ncomprises about half accreted stars from the GSE and half formed by the\nGSE-induced starburst. Our findings further imply that the Splash stars in our\nsample originated from at least three different mechanisms - accretion, disk\nheating, and a merger induced starburst. Lee_2022 Lee et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2210.07905
60 2210.05688 2022-10-11 R. Forsberg, R. M. Rich, N. Nieuwmunster, H. Jönsson, M. Schultheis, N. Ryde, B. Thorsbro The first r-process enhanced star confirmed to be a member of the Galactic bulge Aims. Stars with strong enhancements of r-process elements are rare and tend\nto be metal-poor, with generally [Fe/H] <-2 dex and found in the halo. In this\nwork we aim to investigate a candidate r-process enriched bulge star with a\nrelatively high metallicity of -0.65 dex, and compare it with a previously\npublished r-rich candidate star in the bulge. Methods. We reconsider the\nabundance analysis of a high-resolution optical spectrum of the red-giant star\n2MASS J18082459-2548444 and determine its europium (Eu) and molybdenum (Mo)\nabundance, using stellar parameters from five different previous studies.\nApplying 2MASS photometry, Gaia astrometry and kinematics, we estimate\ndistance, orbits, and population membership of 2MASS J18082459-2548444 and a\npreviously reported r-enriched star 2MASS J18174532-3353235. Results. We find\nthat 2MASS J18082459-2548444 is a relatively metal rich enriched r-process star\nthat is enhanced in Eu and Mo but not substantially enhanced in s-process\nelements. It has a high probability of membership in the Galactic bulge based\non its distance and orbit. We find that both stars show r-process enhancement\nwith elevated [Eu/Fe]-values, even though 2MASS J18174532-3353235 is 1 dex\nlower in metallicity. Additionally, we find that 2MASS J18174532-3353235\nplausibly has a halo or thick disc origin. Conclusions. We conclude that 2MASS\nJ18082459-2548444 represents the first example of a confirmed r-process\nenhanced star confined to the inner bulge, possibly a relic from a period of\nenrichment associated with the formation of the bar. Forsberg_2022 Forsberg et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2210.05688
61 2210.03615 2022-10-07 T. E. Dharmawardena, C. A. L. Bailer-Jones, M. Fouesneau, D. Foreman-Mackey, P. Coronica, T. Colnaghi, T. Müller, J. Henshaw The three-dimensional structure of Galactic molecular cloud complexes out to 2.5 kpc Knowledge of the three-dimensional structure of Galactic molecular clouds is\nimportant for understanding how clouds are affected by processes such as\nturbulence and magnetic fields and how this structure effects star formation\nwithin them. Great progress has been made in this field with the arrival of the\nGaia mission, which provides accurate distances to $\sim10^{9}$ stars.\nCombining these distances with extinctions inferred from optical-IR, we recover\nthe three-dimensional structure of 16 Galactic molecular cloud complexes at\n$\sim1$pc resolution using our novel three-dimensional dust mapping algorithm\n\texttt{Dustribution}. Using \texttt{astrodendro} we derive a catalogue of\nphysical parameters for each complex. We recover structures with aspect ratios\nbetween 1 and 11, i.e.\ everything from near-spherical to very elongated\nshapes. We find a large variation in cloud environments that is not apparent\nwhen studying them in two-dimensions. For example, the nearby California and\nOrion A clouds look similar on-sky, but we find California to be more\nsheet-like, and massive, which could explain their different star-formation\nrates. In Carina, our most distant complex, we observe evidence for dust\nsputtering, which explains its measured low dust mass. By calculating the total\nmass of these individual clouds, we demonstrate that it is necessary to define\ncloud boundaries in three-dimensions in order to obtain an accurate mass;\nsimply integrating the extinction overestimates masses. We find that Larson's\nrelationship on mass vs radius holds true whether you assume a spherical shape\nfor the cloud or take their true extents. Dharmawardena_2022 Dharmawardena et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2210.03615
62 2106.09699 2022-10-07 James M. M. Lane, Jo Bovy, J. Ted Mackereth The Kinematic Properties of Milky Way Stellar Halo Populations In the $Gaia$ era stellar kinematics are extensively used to study Galactic\nhalo stellar populations, to search for halo structures, and to characterize\nthe interface between the halo and hot disc populations. We use distribution\nfunction-based models of modern datasets with 6D phase space data to\nqualitatively describe a variety of kinematic spaces commonly used in the study\nof the Galactic halo. Furthermore, we quantitatively assess how well each\nkinematic space can separate radially anisotropic from isotropic halo\npopulations. We find that scaled action space (the ``action diamond'') is\nsuperior to other commonly used kinematic spaces at this task. We present a\nnew, easy to implement selection criterion for members of the\nradially-anisotropic $Gaia$-Enceladus merger remnant. Assuming a 1:1 ratio of\n$Gaia$-Enceladus stars to more isotropic halo, we find our selection achieves a\nsample purity of 82 per cent in our models with respect to contamination from\nthe more isotropic halo. We compare this criterion to literature criteria,\nfinding that it produces the highest purity in the resulting samples, at the\nexpense of a modest reduction in completeness. We also show that selection\nbiases that underlie nearly all contemporary spectroscopic datasets can\nnoticeably impact the $E-L_{z}$ distribution of samples in a manner that may be\nconfused for real substructure. We conclude by providing recommendations for\nhow authors should use stellar kinematics in the future to study the Galactic\nstellar halo. Lane_2022 Lane et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2106.09699
63 2210.02193 2022-10-05 D. Geisler, M. C. Parisi, B. Dias, S. Villanova, F. Mauro, I. Saviane, R. E. Cohen, C. Moni Bidin, D. Minniti Ca Triplet Metallicities and Velocities for twelve Globular Clusters towards the Galactic Bulge Globular clusters (GCs) are excellent tracers of the formation and early\nevolution of the Milky Way. The bulge GCs (BGCs) are particularly important\nbecause they can reveal vital information about the oldest, in-situ component\nof the Milky Way. We aim at deriving mean metallicities and radial velocities\nfor 13 GCs that lie towards the bulge and are generally associated with this\ncomponent. We use near infrared low resolution spectroscopy with the FORS2\ninstrument on the VLT to measure the wavelengths and equivalent widths of the\nCaII triplet (CaT) lines for a number of stars per cluster. We derive radial\nvelocities, ascertain membership and apply known calibrations to determine\nmetallicities for cluster members, for a mean of 11 members per cluster. We\nderive mean cluster RV values to 3 km/s, and mean metallicities to 0.05 dex.\nOur sample has metallicities lying between -0.21 and -1.64 and is distributed\nbetween the traditional metal-rich BGC peak near [Fe/H] aprox. -0.5 and a more\nmetal-poor peak around [Fe/H] aprox. -1.1, which has recently been identified.\nThese latter are candidates for the oldest GCs in the Galaxy, if blue\nhorizontal branches are present, and include BH 261, NGC 6401, NGC 6540, NGC\n6642, and Terzan 9. Finally, Terzan 10 is even more metal-poor. However,\ndynamically, Terzan 10 is likely an intruder from the halo, possibly associated\nwith the Gaia-Enceladus or Kraken accretion events. Terzan 10 is also confirmed\nas an Oosterhotype II GC based on our results. The lone halo intruder in our\nsample, Terzan 10, is conspicuous for also having by far the lowest\nmetallicity, and casts doubt on the possibility of any bonafide BGCs at\nmetallicities below about aprox. -1.5. Geisler_2022 Geisler et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2210.02193
64 2210.02012 2022-10-05 Chikako Yasui, Naoto Kobayashi, Masao Saito, Natsuko Izumi, Yuji Ikeda Mass function of a young cluster in a low-metallicity environment. Sh 2-209 We present deep near-infrared (NIR) imaging of Sh 2-209 (S209), a\nlow-metallicity (${\rm [O/H]} = - 0.5$ dex) HII region in the Galaxy. From the\nNIR images, combined with astrometric data from Gaia EDR3, we estimate the\ndistance to S209 to be 2.5 kpc. This is close enough to enable us to resolve\ncluster members clearly ($\simeq$1000 AU separation) down to a mass-detection\nlimit of $\simeq$0.1 $M_\odot$, and we have identified two star-forming\nclusters in S209, with individual cluster scales $\sim$1 pc. We employ a set of\nmodel luminosity functions to derive the underlying initial mass functions\n(IMFs) and ages for both clusters. The IMFs we obtained for both clusters\nexhibit slightly flat high-mass slopes ($\Gamma \simeq -1.0$) compared to the\nSalpeter IMF ($\Gamma = -1.35$), and their break mass of $\simeq$0.1 $M_\odot$\nis lower than those generally seen in the solar neighborhood ($\sim$0.3\n$M_\odot$). In particular, because the S209 main cluster is a star-forming\ncluster with a larger number of members ($\sim$1500) than the number\n($\sim$100) in regions previously studied in such environments, it is possible\nfor the first time to derive the IMF in a low-metallicity environment with high\naccuracy over the wide mass range 0.1--20 $M_\odot$. Yasui_2022 Yasui et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2210.02012
65 2204.06003 2022-10-05 Cameren Swiggum, João Alves, Elena D'Onghia, Robert A. Benjamin, Lekshmi Thulasidharan, Catherine Zucker, Eloisa Poggio, Ronald Drimmel, John S. Gallagher III, Alyssa Goodman The Radcliffe Wave as the gas spine of the Orion Arm The Radcliffe Wave is a $\sim3$ kpc long coherent gas structure containing\nmost of the star-forming complexes near the Sun. In this Letter we aim to find\na Galactic context for the Radcliffe Wave by looking into a possible\nrelationship between the gas structure and the Orion (Local) Arm. We use\ncatalogs of massive stars and young open clusters based on \textit{Gaia} EDR3\nastrometry, in conjunction with kiloparsec-scale 3D dust maps, to investigate\nthe Galactic \textit{XY} spatial distributions of gas and young stars. We find\na quasi-parallel offset between the luminous blue stars and the Radcliffe Wave,\nin that massive stars and clusters are found essentially inside and downstream\nfrom the Radcliffe Wave. We examine this offset in the context of color\ngradients observed in the spiral arms of external galaxies, where the interplay\nbetween density wave theory, spiral shocks, and triggered star formation has\nbeen used to interpret this particular arrangement of gas/dust and OB stars,\nand outline other potential explanations as well. We hypothesize that the\nRadcliffe Wave constitutes the gas reservoir of the Orion (Local) Arm, and\npresents itself as a prime laboratory to study the interface between Galactic\nstructure, the formation of molecular clouds in the Milky Way, and star\nformation. Swiggum_2022 Swiggum et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2204.06003
66 2206.04102 2022-09-28 Aneesh Naik, Axel Widmark The missing radial velocities of Gaia: blind predictions for DR3 While Gaia has observed the phase space coordinates of over a billion stars\nin the Galaxy, in the overwhelming majority of cases it has only obtained five\nof the six coordinates, the missing dimension being the radial (line-of-sight)\nvelocity. Using a realistic mock dataset, we show that Bayesian neural networks\nare highly capable of 'learning' these radial velocities as a function of the\nother five coordinates, and thus filling in the gaps. For a given star, the\nnetwork outputs are not merely point predictions, but full posterior\ndistributions encompassing the intrinsic scatter of the stellar phase space\ndistribution, the observational uncertainties on the network inputs, and any\n'epistemic' uncertainty stemming from our ignorance about the stellar phase\nspace distribution. Applying this technique to the real Gaia data, we generate\nand publish a catalogue of posteriors (median width: 25 km/s) for the radial\nvelocities of 16 million Gaia DR2/EDR3 stars in the magnitude range 6 Naik_2022 Naik and Widmark 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.04102
67 2209.12938 2022-09-26 N. Miret-Roig, P. A. B. Galli, J. Olivares, H. Bouy, J. Alves, D. Barrado The star formation history of Upper Scorpius and Ophiuchus We aim to study spatial and kinematic substructures of the region encompassed\nby Upper Scorpius and Ophiuchus star-forming regions, determining dynamical\ntraceback ages and studying the star formation history of the complex. We\nidentified seven different groups in this region. Four groups (nu Sco, beta\nSco, sigma Sco and delta Sco) are part of Upper Scorpius, two groups (rho Oph\nand alpha Sco) are in Ophiuchus, and another group (pi Sco) is a nearby young\npopulation. We found an age gradient from the rho Oph group (the youngest) to\nthe delta Sco group (<~5 Myr), showing that star formation was a sequential\nprocess for the past 5 Myr. Our traceback analysis shows that Upper Scorpius\nand rho Oph groups share a common origin. The closer group of pi Sco is\nprobably older, and the traceback analysis suggests that this group and the\nalpha Sco group have a different origin, likely related to other associations\nin the Sco-Cen complex. Our study shows that this region has a complex star\nformation history that goes beyond the current formation scenario, likely a\nresult of stellar feedback from massive stars, supernovae explosions, and\ndynamic interactions between stellar groups and the molecular gas. In\nparticular, we speculate that photo-ionisation from the massive delta Sco star\ncould have triggered star formation first in the beta Sco group and then in the\nnu Sco group. The perturbations of stellar orbits due to stellar feedback and\ndynamical interactions could also be responsible for the 1-3 Myr difference\nthat we found between dynamical traceback ages and isochronal ages. Miret-Roig_2022 Miret-Roig et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2209.12938
68 2206.04059 2022-09-22 Paul J. McMillan, Jonathan Petersson, Thor Tepper-Garcia, Joss Bland-Hawthorn, Teresa Antoja, Laurent Chemin, Francesca Figueras, Shourya Khanna, Georges Kordopatis, Pau Ramos, Merce Romero-Gómez, George Seabroke The disturbed outer Milky Way disc The outer parts of the Milky Way's disc are significantly out of equilibrium.\nUsing only distances and proper motions of stars from Gaia's Early Data Release\n3, in the range |b|<10{\deg}, 130{\deg} McMillan_2022 McMillan et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.04059
69 2209.07885 2022-09-16 Gaochao Liu, Yang Huang, Sarah Ann Bird, Huawei Zhang, Fei Wang, Haijun Tian Probing the Galactic halo with RR Lyrae stars $-$ III. The chemical and kinematic properties of the stellar halo Based on a large spectroscopic sample of $\sim$ 4,300 RR Lyrae stars with\nmetallicity, systemic radial velocity and distance measurements, we present a\ndetailed analysis of the chemical and kinematic properties of the Galactic\nhalo. Using this sample, the metallicity distribution function (MDF) as a\nfunction of $r$ and the velocity anisotropy parameter $\beta$ profiles (for\ndifferent metallicity populations) are derived for the stellar halo. Both the\nchemical and kinematic results suggest that the Galactic halo is composed of\ntwo distinct parts, the inner halo and outer halo. The cutoff radius ($\sim$ 30\nkpc) is similar to the previous break radius found in the density distribution\nof the stellar halo. We find that the inner part is dominated by a metal-rich\npopulation with extremely radial anisotropy ($\beta \sim 0.9$). These features\nare in accordance with those of ``{\it Gaia}-Enceladus-Sausage'' (GES) and we\nattribute this inner halo component as being dominantly composed of stars\ndeposited from this ancient merged satellite. We find that GES probably has a\nslightly negative metallicity gradient. The metal-poor populations in the inner\nhalo are characterized as a long-tail in MDF with an anisotropy of $\beta \sim\n0.5$, which is similar to that of the outer part. The MDF for the outer halo is\nvery broad with several weak peaks and the value of $\beta$ is around 0.5 for\nall metallicities. Liu_2022 Liu et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2209.07885
70 2106.09419 2022-09-13 Pierre Boldrini, Jo Bovy No globular cluster progenitors in Milky Way satellite galaxies In order to find the possible progenitors of Milky Way globular clusters, we\nperform orbit integrations to track the orbits of 170 Galactic globular\nclusters and the eleven classical Milky Way satellite galaxies backwards in\ntime for 11 Gyr in a Milky-Way-plus-satellites potential including the response\nof the MW to the infall of the Large Magellanic Cloud and the effect of\ndynamical friction on the satellites. To evaluate possible past associations,\nwe devise a globular-cluster--satellite binding criterion based on the\nsatellite's tidal radius and escape velocity and we test it on globular\nclusters associated with the Sagittarius dwarf and on dwarf galaxies associated\nwith the Large Magellanic Cloud. For these, we successfully recover the\ndynamical associations highlighted by previous studies and we derive their time\nof accretion by the Galaxy by using Gaia EDR3 data. Assuming that Milky Way\nglobular clusters are and have been free of dark matter and thus consist of\nstars alone, we demonstrate that none of the globular clusters show any clear\nassociation with the eight classical dwarf spheroidal galaxies even though a\nlarge fraction of them are believed to be accreted. This means that accreted\nglobular clusters either came in as part of now-disrupted satellite galaxies or\nthat globular clusters may have had dark matter halos in the past -- as\nsuggested by the similar metallicity between globular clusters and dwarf\ngalaxies. Boldrini_2022 Boldrini and Bovy 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2106.09419
71 2208.13827 2022-09-13 A. C. Robin, O. Bienaymé, J. B. Salomon, C. Reylé, N. Lagarde, F. Figueras, R. Mor, J. G. Fernández-Trincado, J. Montillaud A self-consistent dynamical model of the Milky Way disc adjusted to Gaia data This paper shows how a self-consistent dynamical model can be obtained by\nfitting the gravitational potential of the Milky Way to the stellar kinematics\nand densities from Gaia data. Using the Besancon Galaxy Model we derive a\npotential and the disc stellar distribution functions are computed based on\nthree integrals of motion to model stationary stellar discs. The gravitational\npotential and the stellar distribution functions are built self-consistently,\nand then adjusted to be in agreement with the kinematics and the density\ndistributions obtained from Gaia observations. A Markov chain Monte Carlo\n(MCMC) is used to fit the free parameters of the dynamical model to Gaia\nparallax and proper motion distributions.\n The fit is done on several sets of Gaia eDR3 data, widely spread in\nlongitudes and latitudes. We are able to determine the velocity dispersion\nellipsoid and its tilt for sub-components of different ages, both varying with\nR and z. The density laws and their radial scale lengths, for the thin and\nthick disc populations are also obtained self-consistently. This new model has\nsome interesting characteristics, such as a flaring thin disc. The thick disc\nis found to present very distinctive characteristics from the old thin disc,\nboth in density and kinematics. This well supports the idea that thin and thick\ndiscs were formed in distinct scenarios as the density and kinematics\ntransition between them is found to be abrupt. The dark matter halo is shown to\nbe nearly spherical. We also derive the Solar motion to be (10.79 $\pm$ 0.56,\n11.06 $\pm$ 0.94, 7.66 $\pm$ 0.43) km/s, in good agreement with recent studies.\nThe resulting fully self-consistent gravitational potential, still\naxisymmetric, is a good approximation of a smooth mass distribution in the\nMilky Way and can be used for further studies, including to compute orbits for\nreal stars in our Galaxy (abridged). Robin_2022 Robin et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2208.13827
72 2209.03792 2022-09-08 E. Trentin, V. Ripepi, G. Catanzaro, J. Storm, M. Marconi, G. De Somma, V. Testa, I. Musella Cepheid Metallicity in the Leavitt Law (C- MetaLL) survey: II.High-resolution spectroscopy of the most metal poor Galactic Cepheids Classical Cepheids (DCEPs) are the first fundamental step in the calibration\nof the cosmological distance ladder. Furthermore, they represent powerful\ntracers in the context of Galactic studies. We have collected high-resolution\nspectroscopy with UVES@VLT for a sample of 65 DCEPs. The majority of them are\nthe faintest DCEPs ever observed in the Milky Way. For each target, we derived\naccurate atmospheric parameters, radial velocities, and abundances for 24\ndifferent species. The resulting iron abundances range between +0.3 and $-$1.1\ndex with the bulk of stars at [Fe/H]$\sim-0.5$ dex. Our sample includes the\nmost metal-poor DCEPs observed so far with high-resolution spectroscopy. We\ncomplement our sample with literature data obtaining a complete sample of 637\nDCEPs and use Gaia Early Data Release 3 (EDR3) photometry to determine the\ndistance of the DCEPs from the Period-Wesenheit-Metallicity relation. Our more\nexternal data trace the Outer arm (at Galactocentric radius\n($R_{GC})\sim$16--18 kpc) which appears significantly warped. We investigate\nthe metallicity gradient of the Galactic disc using this large sample, finding\na slope of $-0.060 \pm 0.002$ dex kpc$^{-1}$, in very good agreement with\nprevious results based both on DCEPs and open clusters. We also report a\npossible break in the gradient at $R_{GC}$=9.25 kpc with slopes of $-0.063 \pm\n0.007$ and $-0.079 \pm 0.003$ dex kpc$^{-1}$ for the inner and outer sample,\nrespectively. The two slopes differ by more than 1 $\sigma$. A more homogeneous\nand extended DCEPs sample is needed to further test the plausibility of such a\nbreak. Trentin_2022 Trentin et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2209.03792
73 2209.03384 2022-09-07 A. Bhardwaj, S. M. Kanbur, M. Rejkuba, M. Marconi, M. Catelan, V. Ripepi, H. P. Singh Near-infrared observations of RR Lyrae and Type II Cepheid variables in the metal-rich bulge globular cluster NGC 6441 NGC 6441 is a bulge globular cluster with an unusual horizontal branch\nmorphology and a rich population of RR Lyrae (RRL) and Type II Cepheid (T2C)\nvariables that is unexpected for its relatively high metallicity. We present\nnear-infrared (NIR, $JHK_s$) time-series observations of 42 RRL, 8 T2Cs, and 10\neclipsing binary candidate variables in NGC 6441. The multi-epoch observations\nwere obtained using the FLAMINGOS-2 instrument on the 8-m Gemini South\ntelescope. Multi-band data are used to investigate pulsation properties of RRL\nand T2C variables including their light curves, instability strip,\nperiod--amplitude diagrams, and period--luminosity and period--wesenheit\nrelations (PLRs and PWRs) in $JHK_s$ filters. NIR pulsation properties of RRL\nvariables are well fitted with theoretical models that have canonical helium\ncontent and mean-metallicity of NGC 6441 ([Fe/H]$=-0.44\pm0.07$~dex). The\nhelium-enhanced RRL models predict brighter NIR magnitudes and bluer colors\nthan the observations of RRL in the cluster. This suggests that these RRL\nvariables in NGC 6441 are either not significantly helium enhanced as\npreviously thought or the impact of such enhancement is smaller in NIR than the\npredictions of the pulsation models. We also use theoretical calibrations of\nRRL period--luminosity--metallicity (PLZ) relations to simultaneously estimate\nthe mean reddening, $E(J-K_s)=0.26\pm0.06$~mag, and the distance,\n$d=12.67\pm0.09$~kpc, to NGC 6441. Our mean reddening value and the distance\nare consistent with the independent estimates from the bulge reddening map\nbased on red clump stars and the latest Gaia data, respectively. Our distance\nand reddening values provide a very good agreement between the PLRs of T2Cs in\nNGC 6441 and those for RRL and T2Cs in Galactic globular clusters that span a\nbroad range of metallicity. Bhardwaj_2022 Bhardwaj et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2209.03384
74 2209.02553 2022-09-06 Connor P. Fallows, Jason L. Sanders A machine learning approach to photometric metallicities of giant stars Despite the advances provided by large-scale photometric surveys, stellar\nfeatures - such as metallicity - generally remain limited to spectroscopic\nobservations often of bright, nearby low-extinction stars. To rectify this, we\npresent a neural network approach for estimating the metallicities and\ndistances of red giant stars with 8-band photometry and parallaxes from Gaia\nEDR3 and the 2MASS and WISE surveys. The algorithm accounts for uncertainties\nin the predictions arising from the range of possible outputs at each input and\nfrom the range of models compatible with the training set (through drop-out). A\ntwo-stage procedure is adopted where an initial network to estimate\nphoto-astrometric parallaxes is trained using a large sample of noisy parallax\ndata from Gaia EDR3 and then a secondary network is trained using spectroscopic\nmetallicities from the APOGEE and LAMOST surveys and an augmented feature space\nutilising the first-stage parallax estimates. The algorithm produces\nmetallicity predictions with an average uncertainty of $\pm0.19$ dex. The\nmethodology is applied to stars within the Galactic bar/bulge with particular\nfocus on a sample of 1.69 million objects with Gaia radial velocities. We\ndemonstrate the use and validity of our approach by inspecting both spatial and\nkinematic gradients with metallicity in the Galactic bar/bulge recovering\nprevious results on the vertical metallicity gradient ($-0.528 \pm 0.002$\ndex/kpc) and the vertex deviation of the bar ($-21.29 \pm 2.74$ deg). Fallows_2022 Fallows and Sanders 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2209.02553
75 2209.02722 2022-09-06 Hans-Walter Rix, Vedant Chandra, René Andrae, Adrian M. Price-Whelan, David H. Weinberg, Charlie Conroy, Morgan Fouesneau, David W. Hogg, Francesca De Angeli, Rohan P. Naidu, Maosheng Xiang, Daniela Ruz-Mieres The Poor Old Heart of the Milky Way Massive disk galaxies like our Milky Way should host an ancient, metal-poor,\nand centrally concentrated stellar population. This population reflects the\nstar formation and enrichment in the few most massive progenitor components\nthat coalesced at high redshift to form the proto-Galaxy. While metal-poor\nstars are known to reside in the inner few kiloparsecs of our Galaxy, current\ndata do not yet provide a comprehensive picture of such a metal-poor "heart" of\nthe Milky Way. We use information from Gaia DR3, especially the XP spectra, to\nconstruct a sample of 2 million bright (BP $<15.5$ mag) giant stars within\n$30^\circ$ of the Galactic Center with robust [M/H] estimates, $\delta$ [M/H]\n$\lesssim 0.1$. For most sample members we can calculate orbits based on Gaia\nRVS velocities and astrometry. This sample reveals an extensive, ancient, and\nmetal-poor population that includes $\sim 18,000$ stars with $-2.7<$ [M/H]\n$<-1.5$, representing a stellar mass of $\gtrsim 5\times 10^7$ M$_\odot$. The\nspatial distribution of these [M/H] $<-1.5$ stars has a Gaussian extent of only\n$\sigma_{\mathrm{R_{GC}}} \sim 2.7$ kpc around the Galactic center, with most\nof these orbits being confined to the inner Galaxy. At high orbital\neccentricities, there is clear evidence for accreted halo stars in their\npericentral orbit phase. Stars with [M/H] $< -2$ show no net rotation, whereas\nthose with [M/H] $\sim -1$ are rotation dominated. Most of the tightly bound\nstars show $[\alpha/\text{Fe}]$-enhancement and [Al/Fe]-[Mn/Fe] abundance\npatterns expected for an origin in the more massive portions of the\nproto-Galaxy. These central, metal-poor stars most likely predate the oldest\npart of the disk ($\tau_{\text{age}}\approx 12.5$ Gyrs), which implies that\nthey formed at $z\gtrsim 5$, forging the proto-Milky Way. Rix_2022 Rix et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2209.02722
76 2209.02731 2022-09-06 B. Lemasle, H. N. Lala, V. Kovtyukh, M. Hanke, Z. Prudil, G. Bono, V. F. Braga, R. da Silva, M. Fabrizio, G. Fiorentino, P. Francois, E. K. Grebel, A. Kniazev Tracing the Milky Way warp and spiral arms with classical Cepheids Mapping the Galactic spiral structure is a difficult task since the Sun is\nlocated in the Galactic plane and because of dust extinction. For these\nreasons, molecular masers in radio wavelengths have been used with great\nsuccess to trace the Milky Way spiral arms. Recently, Gaia parallaxes have\nhelped in investigating the spiral structure in the Solar extended\nneighborhood. In this paper, we propose to determine the location of the spiral\narms using Cepheids since they are bright, young supergiants with accurate\ndistances (they are the first ladder of the extragalactic distance scale). They\ncan be observed at very large distances; therefore, we need to take the\nGalactic warp into account. Thanks to updated mid-infrared photometry and to\nthe most complete catalog of Galactic Cepheids, we derived the parameters of\nthe warp using a robust regression method. Using a clustering algorithm, we\nidentified groups of Cepheids after having corrected their Galactocentric\ndistances from the (small) effects of the warp. We derived new parameters for\nthe Galactic warp, and we show that the warp cannot be responsible for the\nincreased dispersion of abundance gradients in the outer disk reported in\nprevious studies. We show that Cepheids can be used to trace spiral arms, even\nat large distances from the Sun. The groups we identify are consistent with\nprevious studies explicitly deriving the position of spiral arms using young\ntracers (masers, OB(A) stars) or mapping overdensities of upper main-sequence\nstars in the Solar neighborhood thanks to Gaia data. Lemasle_2022 Lemasle et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2209.02731
77 2208.13353 2022-09-02 Yuqin Chen, Gang Zhao, Haopeng Zhang Evidence for Co-rotation Origin of Super Metal Rich Stars in LAMOST-Gaia: Multiple Ridges with a Similar Slope in phi versus Lz Plane Super metal-rich (SMR) stars in the solar neighborhood are thought to be born\nin the inner disk and came to present location by radial migration, which is\nmost intense at the co-rotation resonance (CR) of the Galactic bar. In this\nwork, we show evidence for the CR origin of SMR stars in LAMOST-Gaia by\ndetecting six ridges and undulations in the phi versus Lz space coded by median\nVR, following a similar slope of -8 km/s kpc/deg. The slope is predicted by\nMonario et al.'s model for CR of a large and slow Galactic bar. For the first\ntime, we show the variation of angular momentum with azimuths from -10 deg to\n20 deg for two outer and broad undulations with negative VR around -18 km/s\nfollowing this slope. The wave-like pattern with large amplitude outside CR and\na wide peak of the second undulations indicate that minor merger of the\nSagittarius dwarf galaxy with the disk might play a role besides the\nsignificant impact of CR of the Galactic bar. Chen_2022 Chen et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2208.13353
78 2206.14849 2022-09-01 E. Poggio, A. Recio-Blanco, P. A. Palicio, P. Re Fiorentin, P. de Laverny, R. Drimmel, G. Kordopatis, M. G. Lattanzi, M. Schultheis, A. Spagna, E. Spitoni The chemical signature of the Galactic spiral arms revealed by Gaia DR3 Taking advantage of the recent Gaia Data Release 3 (DR3), we map chemical\ninhomogeneities in the Milky Way's disc out to a distance of $\sim$ 4 kpc from\nthe Sun, using different samples of bright giant stars. The samples are\nselected using effective temperatures and surface gravities from the GSP-Spec\nmodule, and are expected to trace stellar populations of different typical age.\nThe cool (old) giants exhibit a relatively smooth radial metallicity gradient\nwith an azimuthal dependence. Binning in Galactic azimuth $\phi$, the slope\ngradually varies from $d$[M/H]$/dR \sim -0.054$ dex kpc$^{-1}$ at $\phi \sim\n-20^{\circ}$ to $\sim -0.035$ dex kpc$^{-1}$ at $\phi \sim 20^{\circ}$. On the\nother hand, the relatively hotter (and younger) stars present remarkable\ninhomogeneities, apparent as three (possibly four) metal-rich elongated\nfeatures in correspondence of the spiral arms' locations in the Galactic disc.\nWhen projected onto Galactic radius, those features manifest themselves as\nstatistically significant bumps on top of the observed radial metallicity\ngradients with amplitudes up to $ \sim 0.05-0.1$ dex, making the assumption of\na linear radial decrease not applicable to this sample. The strong correlation\nbetween the spiral structure of the Galaxy and the observed chemical pattern in\nthe young sample indicates that the spiral arms might be at the origin for the\ndetected chemical inhomogeneities. In this scenario, the spiral arms would\nleave in the younger stars a strong signature, which progressively disappears\nwhen cooler (and older) giants are considered. Poggio_2022 Poggio et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.14849
79 2205.13547 2022-09-01 Adam M. Dillamore, Vasily Belokurov, N. Wyn Evans, Adrian M. Price-Whelan The impact of a massive Sagittarius dSph on GD-1-like streams We investigate the effects of a massive ($\gtrsim4\times10^{10}M_\odot$)\nSagittarius dwarf spheroidal galaxy (Sgr) on stellar streams using test\nparticle simulations in a realistic Milky Way potential. We find that Sgr can\neasily disrupt streams formed more than $\sim3$ Gyr ago, while stars stripped\nmore recently are generally unaffected. In certain realizations, Sgr is able to\nproduce asymmetry between the leading and trailing tails of Pal 5,\nqualitatively similar to observations. Using data from the Gaia space telescope\nand elsewhere, we fit models to the GD-1 stream in the presence of a Sgr with\nvarious initial masses. While the best-fitting models do show perturbations\nresulting from interactions with Sgr, we find that the level of disruption is\nnot significantly greater than in the observed stream. To investigate the\ngeneral effects of Sgr on a population of streams, we generate 1000 mock\nstreams on GD-1-like orbits with randomized orientations. Some streams show\nclear evidence of disruption, becoming folded on the sky or developing\nasymmetry betweeen their two tails. However, many survive unaffected and the\npeak surface brightness of stars is decreased by no more than $\sim0.3$\nmag/arcsec$^2$ on average. We conclude that Sgr having an initial mass of\n$\gtrsim4\times10^{10}M_\odot$ is compatible with the survival and detection of\nstreams formed more than 3 Gyr ago. Dillamore_2022a Dillamore et al. 2022a https://arxiv.org/abs/2205.13547
80 2206.03495 2022-08-30 T. Antoja, P. Ramos, F. López-Guitart, F. Anders, M. Bernet, C. Laporte Tidally induced spiral arm wraps encoded in phase space We study the dynamics of tidally induced spiral arms in our Galaxy in the\ncontext of its encounters with Sagittarius. We built toy models of the\ninteraction between a host and a satellite galaxy using orbital integrations\nafter a tidal encounter. We derived analytically the shape of the structures in\nphase space as a function of time for simple power-law potential models. We\ncompared these models to a more realistic N-body simulation of the MW\nSagittarius-like interaction and to data from Gaia DR3. As found before, an\nimpulsive distant tidal approach of a galactic satellite leads to a two-armed\nspiral structure made of orbits in between their apocentres and pericentres,\nthus, with average negative galactocentric radial velocity. The two-arm pattern\nrotates at an angular speed of $\omega-1/2\kappa$ which depends on radius, thus\ncausing a wind-up with time. This produces ridges in the $R$-$V_\phi$\nprojection with alternating signs of $V_R$ and oscillations of $V_R$ in the\n$L_Z$-$\phi$ space, like those observed in the Gaia data. The frequency of\nthese kinematic features increases with time, offering a powerful means to\ninfer the potential and the perturbation's onset time and azimuthal phase.\nFourier analysis allows us to date the impact times of simple models and even\nto date perturbations from various pericentric passages. For the MW, the\nFourier analysis indicates a superposition of two different frequencies, as in\nprevious studies. Assuming that both are due to impulsive and distant\npericentre passages, we find perturbation times <0.6 Gyr and in the range of\n0.8-2.1 Gyr. The latter is compatible with a previous pericentre of Sagittarius\nand would be related to four wraps of the spiral arms in the observed radial\nrange. Further work on the self-gravitating response of galactic discs and\npossible degeneracies with secular processes by the bar is necessary. (ABR) Antoja_2022 Antoja et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.03495
81 2208.07849 2022-08-28 A. Arellano Ferro, I. Bustos Fierro, S. Muneer, S. Giridhar RR Lyrae stars in the globular cluster Palomar 2 A CCD VI imaging time-series over 11-year is employed to explore the light\ncurves of stars in the field of Palomar 2. We discovered 20 RRab and 1 RRc\nvariables. A revision of Gaia-DR3 data enabled us to identify 10 more variables\nand confirm the RRab nature of 6 of them and one RGB. The cluster membership is\ndiscussed and 18 variables are most likely cluster members. The Fourier light\ncurve decomposition for the 11 best quality light curves of cluster member\nstars leads to independent estimates of the cluster distance 27.2 +- 1.8 kpc\nand [Fe/H]ZW=-1.39 +- 0.55. We confirm the cluster as of the Oo I type. Ferro_2022a Ferro et al. 2022a https://arxiv.org/abs/2208.07849
82 2207.12024 2022-08-26 K. Sysoliatina, A. Just Towards a fully consistent Milky Way disk model V. The disk model for 4 $-$ 14 kpc We present a generalised version of the semi-analytic Just-Jahreiss (JJ)\nmodel of the Galactic disk that incorporates our findings for the solar\nneighbourhood and is applicable to a wide range of galactocentric distances, 4\nkpc $\lesssim R \lesssim $ 14 kpc. The JJ model is a flexible tool for stellar\npopulation synthesis with a fine age resolution of 25 Myr. It includes six\nMilky-Way (MW) components: the four flattened (exponential thin and thick disk,\natomic and molecular gas) and two spheroidal (spherical stellar halo and a\ncored isothermal dark matter sphere). The overall thin-disk thickness is\nassumed to be constant at all radii, though flaring can also be tested. The\nadopted radial variation in the thin-disk star-formation rate (SFR) reflects\nthe inside-out disk growth scenario. We allow a smooth power-law SFR continuum\nto be modified by an arbitrary number of Gaussian peaks. We present a public\ncode of the JJ model complemented by the three sets of isochrones (PARSEC,\nMIST, and BaSTI). Using metallicity distributions of the red clump giants from\nAPOGEE, we constrain the radial variation of the JJ-model age-metallicity\nrelation (AMR) and propose a new analytic form for the AMR function. The\ngeneralised JJ model is a publicly available tool for studying different\nstellar populations across the MW disk. With its fine age resolution and\nflexibility, it can be particularly useful for reconstructing the thin-disk\nSFR, as a variety of different SFR shapes can be constructed within its\nframework. Sysoliatina_2022 Sysoliatina and Just 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2207.12024
83 2208.11135 2022-08-23 Vasily Belokurov, Eugene Vasiliev, Alis J. Deason, Sergey E. Koposov, Azadeh Fattahi, Adam M. Dillamore, Elliot Y. Davies, Robert J. J. Grand Energy wrinkles and phase-space folds of the last major merger Relying on the dramatic increase in the number of stars with full 6D\nphase-space information provided by the Gaia Data Release 3, we discover\nunambiguous signatures of phase-mixing in the stellar halo around the Sun. We\nshow that for the stars likely belonging to the last massive merger, the\n(v_r,r) distribution contains a series of long and thin chevron-like\noverdensities. These phase-space sub-structures are predicted to emerge\nfollowing the dissolution of a satellite, when its tidal debris is given time\nto wind up, thin out and fold. Additionally, the observed energy and angular\nmomentum (E, L_z) distribution appears more prograde at high energies, possibly\nrevealing the original orbital angular momentum of the in-falling galaxy. The\nenergy distribution of the debris is strongly asymmetric with a peak at low E\n-- which, we surmise, may be evidence of the dwarf's rapid sinking -- and\nriddled with wrinkles and bumps. If these small-scale energy inhomogeneities\nhave been seeded during or immediately after the interaction with the Milky\nWay, and are not due to the spatial restriction of our study, then making use\nof the (v_r,r) chevrons to constrain the time of the merger becomes cumbersome.\nNonetheless, we demonstrate that similar phase-space and (E,L_z) sub-structures\nare present in numerical simulations of galaxy interactions, both in bespoke\nN-body runs and in cosmological hydrodynamical zoom-in suites. The remnant\ntraces of the progenitor's disruption and the signatures of the on-going\nphase-mixing discovered here will not only help to constrain the properties of\nour Galaxy's most important interaction, but also can be used as a novel tool\nto map out the Milky Way's current gravitational potential and its\nperturbations. Belokurov_2022 Belokurov et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2208.11135
84 2208.08872 2022-08-18 M. Ambrosch, G. Guiglion, Š. Mikolaitis, C. Chiappini, G. Tautvaišienė, S. Nepal, G. Gilmore, S. Randich, T. Bensby, M. Bergemann, L. Morbidelli, E. Pancino, G. G. Sacco, R. Smiljanic, S. Zaggia, P. Jofré, F. M. Jiménez-Esteban The Gaia-ESO Survey: Chemical evolution of Mg and Al in the Milky Way with Machine-Learning We aim to prepare the machine-learning ground for the next generation of\nspectroscopic surveys, such as 4MOST and WEAVE. Our goal is to show that\nconvolutional neural networks can predict accurate stellar labels from relevant\nspectral features in a physically meaningful way. We built a neural network and\ntrained it on GIRAFFE spectra with associated stellar labels from the sixth\ninternal Gaia-ESO data release. Our neural network predicts the atmospheric\nparameters Teff and log(g) as well as the chemical abundances [Mg/Fe], [Al/Fe],\nand [Fe/H] for 30115 stellar spectra. The scatter of predictions from eight\nslightly different network models shows a high internal precision of the\nnetwork results: 24 K for Teff, 0.03 for log(g), 0.02 dex for [Mg/Fe], 0.03 dex\nfor [Al/Fe], and 0.02 dex for [Fe/H]. The network gradients reveal that the\nnetwork is inferring the labels in a physically meaningful way from spectral\nfeatures. Validation with benchmark stars and several scientific applications\nconfirm that our network predictions are accurate for individual stars and\nrecover the properties of different stellar populations in the Milky Way\ngalaxy. Such a study provides very good insights into the application of\nmachine-learning for the spectral analysis of large-scale spectroscopic\nsurveys, such as WEAVE and 4MIDABLE-LR and -HR (4MOST Milky Way disk and bulge\nlow- and high-resolution). The community will have to put a substantial effort\ninto building proactive training sets for machine-learning methods to minimize\nthe possible systematics. Ambrosch_2022 Ambrosch et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2208.08872
85 2208.06469 2022-08-12 Alan J. Tu, Catherine Zucker, Joshua S. Speagle, Angus Beane, Alyssa Goodman, João Alves, Jacqueline Faherty, Andreas Burkert Characterizing the 3D Kinematics of Young Stars in the Radcliffe Wave We present an analysis of the kinematics of the Radcliffe Wave, a\n2.7-kpc-long sinusoidal band of molecular clouds in the solar neighborhood\nrecently detected via 3D dust mapping. With Gaia DR2 astrometry and\nspectroscopy, we analyze the 3D space velocities of $\sim 1500$ young stars\nalong the Radcliffe Wave in action-angle space, using the motion of the wave's\nnewly born stars as a proxy for its gas motion. We find that the vertical angle\nof young stars -- corresponding to their orbital phase perpendicular to the\nGalactic plane -- varies significantly as a function of position along the\nstructure, in a pattern potentially consistent with a wave-like oscillation.\nThis kind of oscillation is not seen in a control sample of older stars from\nGaia occupying the same volume, disfavouring formation channels caused by\nlong-lived physical processes. We use a ``wavy midplane'' model to try to\naccount for the trend in vertical angles seen in young stars, and find that\nwhile the best-fit parameters for the wave's spatial period and amplitude are\nqualitatively consistent with the existing morphology defined by 3D dust, there\nis no evidence for additional velocity structure. These results support more\nrecent and/or transitory processes in the formation of the Radcliffe Wave,\nwhich would primarily affect the motion of the wave's gaseous material.\nComparisons of our results with new and upcoming simulations, in conjunction\nwith new stellar radial velocity measurements in Gaia DR3, should allow us to\nfurther discriminate between various competing hypotheses. Tu_2022 Tu et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2208.06469
86 2109.13244 2022-08-10 Adam M. Dillamore, Vasily Belokurov, Andreea S. Font, Ian G. McCarthy Merger-induced galaxy transformations in the ARTEMIS simulations Using the ARTEMIS set of 45 high-resolution cosmological simulations, we\ninvestigate a range of merger-induced dynamical transformations of Milky\nWay-like galaxies. We first identify populations of accreted stars on highly\nradial orbits, similar to the 'Gaia Sausage' in the Milky Way. We show that\n$\approx1/3$ of the ARTEMIS galaxies contain a similar feature, and confirm\nthat they usually comprise stellar debris from the most massive accreted\nsatellite. Selecting 15 galaxies with discs at the present-day, we study their\nchanges around the times of the GS-like mergers. Dark matter haloes of many of\nthese exhibit global changes in shape and orientation, with almost half\nbecoming significantly more spherical when the mergers occur. Focusing on the\ngalaxies themselves, we find that 4/15 have stellar discs which experience\nlarge changes in the orientation of their angular momentum (AM) axes, at rates\nof up to $\sim60$ degrees Gyr$^{-1}$. By calculating the orbital angular\nmomentum axes of the satellites before they are accreted, we show that there is\na tendency for the disc's AM to become more aligned with this axis after the\nmerger. We also investigate the origin of in situ retrograde stars, analogous\nto the 'Splash' in the Milky Way. Tracing them back to earlier snapshots, we\ndemonstrate that they were often disrupted onto their extreme orbits by\nmultiple early mergers. We also find that the total mass of these stars outside\nthe central regions positively correlates with the total accreted stellar mass. Dillamore_2022 Dillamore et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2109.13244
87 2208.05176 2022-08-10 Yong Yang, Jing-Kun Zhao, Xiang-Xiang Xue, Xian-Hao Ye, Gang Zhao A New Cold Stream near the Southern Galactic Pole We report the discovery of a cold stream near the southern Galactic pole\n(dubbed as SGP-S) detected in $Gaia$ Early Data Release 3. The stream is at a\nheliocentric distance of $\sim$ 9.5 kpc and spans nearly 58$^\circ$ by\n0.6$^\circ$ on sky. The colour-magnitude diagram of SGP-S indicates an old and\nmetal-poor (age $\sim$ 12 Gyr, [M/H] $\sim$ -2.0 dex) stellar population. The\nstream's surface brightness reaches an exceedingly low level of $\Sigma_G\n\simeq$ 36.2 mag arcsec$^{-2}$. Neither extant globular clusters nor other\nknown streams are associated with SGP-S. Zucker The Gaia-ESO Public Spectroscopic Survey: Motivation, implementation, GIRAFFE data processing, analysis, and final data products The Gaia-ESO Public Spectroscopic Survey is an ambitious project designed to\nobtain astrophysical parameters and elemental abundances for 100,000 stars,\nincluding large representative samples of the stellar populations in the\nGalaxy, and a well-defined sample of 60 (plus 20 archive) open clusters. We\nprovide internally consistent results calibrated on benchmark stars and star\nclusters, extending across a very wide range of abundances and ages. This\nprovides a legacy data set of intrinsic value, and equally a large wide-ranging\ndataset that is of value for homogenisation of other and future stellar surveys\nand Gaia's astrophysical parameters. This article provides an overview of the\nsurvey methodology, the scientific aims, and the implementation, including a\ndescription of the data processing for the GIRAFFE spectra. A companion paper\n(arXiv:2206.02901) introduces the survey results. Gaia-ESO aspires to quantify\nboth random and systematic contributions to measurement uncertainties. Thus all\navailable spectroscopic analysis techniques are utilised, each spectrum being\nanalysed by up to several different analysis pipelines, with considerable\neffort being made to homogenise and calibrate the resulting parameters. We\ndescribe here the sequence of activities up to delivery of processed data\nproducts to the ESO Science Archive Facility for open use. The Gaia-ESO Survey\nobtained 202,000 spectra of 115,000 stars using 340 allocated VLT nights\nbetween December 2011 and January 2018 from GIRAFFE and UVES. The full\nconsistently reduced final data set of spectra was released through the ESO\nScience Archive Facility in late 2020, with the full astrophysical parameters\nsets following in 2022. Gilmore_2022 Gilmore et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2208.05432
89 2202.00591 2022-08-09 Thomas M. Callingham, Marius Cautun, Alis J. Deason, Carlos S. Frenk, Robert J. J Grand, Federico Marinacci The Chemo-Dynamical Groups of Galactic Globular Clusters We introduce a multi-component chemo-dynamical method for splitting the\nGalactic population of Globular Clusters (GCs) into three distinct\nconstituents: bulge, disc, and stellar halo. The latter is further decomposed\ninto the individual large accretion events that built up the Galactic stellar\nhalo: the Gaia-Enceladus-Sausage, Kraken and Sequoia structures, and the\nSagittarius and Helmi streams. Our modelling is extensively tested using mock\nGC samples constructed from the AURIGA suite of hydrodynamical simulations of\nMilky Way (MW)-like galaxies. We find that, on average, a proportion of the\naccreted GCs cannot be associated with their true infall group and are left\nungrouped, biasing our recovered population numbers to approximately 80 percent\nof their true value. Furthermore, the identified groups have a completeness and\na purity of only 65 percent. This reflects the difficulty of the problem, a\nresult of the large degree of overlap in energy-action space of the debris from\npast accretion events. We apply the method to the Galactic data to infer, in a\nstatistically robust and easily quantifiable way, the GCs associated with each\nMW accretion event. The resulting groups' population numbers of GCs, corrected\nfor biases, are then used to infer the halo and stellar masses of the now\ndefunct satellites that built up the halo of the MW. Callingham_2022 Callingham et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2202.00591
90 2208.01056 2022-08-01 Xiaowei Ou, Lina Necib, Anna Frebel Robust Clustering of the Local Milky Way Stellar Kinematic Substructures with Gaia eDR3 We apply the clustering algorithm HDBSCAN on the Gaia early third data\nrelease astrometry combined with the Gaia second data release radial velocity\nmeasurements of almost 5.5 million stars to identify the local stellar\nkinematic substructures in the solar neighborhood. Understanding these\nstructures helps build a more complete picture of the formation of the Milky\nWay, as well as an empirical phase space distribution of dark matter that would\ninform detection experiments. The main goal of this study is to provide a list\nof the most stable clusters, by taking into account the measurement\nuncertainties and studying the stability of the clustering results. We apply\nthe clustering algorithm in two spaces, in velocity space in order to study\nrecently accreted structures, and in action-angle space to find phase-mixed\nstructures. We find 23 (6) robust clusters in velocity space (action-angle\nspace) that are consistently not associated with noise. They are attributed to\nthe known structures: the Gaia Sausage-Enceladus, the Helmi Stream, and\nglobular cluster NGC 3201 are found in both spaces, while NGC 104 and the thick\ndisk (Sequoia) are identified in velocity space (action-angle space). We\ndiscuss the kinematic properties of these structures and study whether many of\nthe small clusters belong to a similar larger cluster based on their chemical\nabundances. Although we do not identify any new structures, we find that the\nHDBSCAN member selection of already known structures is unstable to input\nkinematics of the stars when resampled within their uncertainties. We therefore\npresent the most stable subset of local kinematic structures, which are\nconsistently identified by the clustering algorithm, and emphasize the need to\ntake into account error propagation during both the manual and automated\nidentification of stellar structures, both for existing ones as well as future\ndiscoveries. (abridged) Ou_2022 Ou et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2208.01056
91 2207.14747 2022-07-29 M. Van der Swaelmen, C. Viscasillas Vázquez, G. Cescutti, L. Magrini, S. Cristallo, D. Vescovi, S. Randich, G. Tautvaišienė, V. Bagdonas, T. Bensby, M. Bergemann, A. Bragaglia, A. Drazdauskas, F. Jiménez-Esteban, G. Guiglion, A. Korn, T. Masseron, R. Minkevičiūtė, R. Smiljanic, L. Spina, E. Stonkutė, S. Zaggia The Gaia-ESO survey: placing constraints on the origin of r-process elements A renewed interest about the origin of \emph{r}-process elements has been\nstimulated by the multi-messenger observation of the gravitational event\nGW170817, with the detection of both gravitational waves and electromagnetic\nwaves corresponding to the merger of two neutron stars. Such phenomenon has\nbeen proposed as one of the main sources of the \emph{r}-process. However, the\norigin of the \emph{r}-process elements at different metallicities is still\nunder debate. We aim at investigating the origin of the \emph{r}-process\nelements in the Galactic thin disc population. From the sixth internal data\nrelease of the \emph{Gaia}-ESO we have collected a large sample of Milky Way\nthin- and thick-disc stars for which abundances of Eu, O, and Mg are available.\nThe sample consists of members of 62 open clusters, located at a Galactocentric\nradius from $\sim 5$ kpc to $\sim 20$ kpc in the disc, in the metallicity range\n$[-0.5, 0.4]$ and covering an age interval from 0.1 to 7 Gy, and about 1300\nMilky Way disc field stars in the metallicity range $[-1.5, 0.5]$. We compare\nthe observations with the results of a chemical evolution model, in which we\nvaried the nucleosynthesis sources for the three considered elements. Our main\nresult is that Eu in the thin disc is predominantly produced by sources with\nshort lifetimes, such as magneto-rotationally driven SNe. There is no strong\nevidence for additional sources at delayed times. Our findings do not imply\nthat there cannot be a contribution from mergers of neutron stars in other\nenvironments, as in the halo or in dwarf spheroidal galaxies, but such a\ncontribution is not needed to explain Eu abundances at thin disc metallicities. Swaelmen_2022 Swaelmen et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2207.14747
92 2206.01216 2022-07-28 Marcel Bernet, Pau Ramos, Teresa Antoja, Benoit Famaey, Giacomo Monari, Hussein Al Kazwini, Mercè Romero-Gómez From ridges to manifolds: 3D characterization of the moving groups in the Milky Way disc The stellar velocity distribution in the Solar Neighbourhood displays\nkinematic substructures, which are possibly signatures of the bar and spiral\narms of the Milky Way and of previous accretion events. These kinematic\nsubstructures -- moving groups -- can be thought of as continuous manifolds in\nthe 6D phase space, and the ridges in the $V_{\phi}-R$ and arches in the\n$V_\phi-V_R$ plane, discovered with the Gaia mission, as projections of these\nmanifolds. We develop and apply a methodology to perform a blind search for\nsubstructure in the Gaia EDR3 6D data, and obtain a sampling of the manifolds.\nThe method consists in the execution of the Wavelet Transform in small volumes\nof the Milky Way disc, and the grouping of these local solutions into global\nones with a method based on the Breadth-first search algorithm from Graph\nTheory. We reveal the complex skeleton of the velocity distribution, sampling\nnine main moving groups in a large region of the disc ($6$ kpc, $60$ deg, and\n$2$ kpc in the radial, azimuthal, and vertical directions). In the radial\ndirection, the groups deviate from lines of constant angular momentum that one\nwould naively expect from first order effect of resonances. The azimuthal\nvelocity of Acturus, Bobylev, and Hercules is non-axisymmetric. For Hercules,\nwe measure an azimuthal gradient of $-0.50$ km/s/deg at $R=8$ kpc. We detect a\nvertical asymmetry in the azimuthal velocity for Coma Berenices, which is not\nexpected in a resonance of the bar, supporting previous hypothesis of\nincomplete vertical phase-mixing. When we apply the same methodology to\nsimulations of barred galaxies, we extract substructures corresponding to the\nOuter Linbdlad and the 1:1 Resonances and observe patterns consistent with the\ndata. This data-driven characterization allows for a quantitative comparison\nwith models, providing a key tool to comprehend the dynamics of the Milky Way.\n(Abridged) Bernet_2022 Bernet et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.01216
93 2206.06125 2022-07-27 Jason A. S. Hunt, Adrian M. Price-Whelan, Kathryn V. Johnston, Elise Darragh-Ford Multiple phase spirals suggest multiple origins in Gaia DR3 {\it Gaia} Data Release 2 (DR2) revealed that the Milky Way contains\nsignificant indications of departures from equilibrium in the form of\nasymmetric features in the phase space density of stars in the Solar\nneighborhood. One such feature is the $z$--$v_z$ phase spiral, interpreted as\nthe response of the disk to the influence of a perturbation perpendicular to\nthe disk plane, which could be external (e.g., a satellite) or internal (e.g.,\nthe bar or spiral arms). In this work we use {\it Gaia} DR3 to dissect the\nphase spiral by dividing the local data set into groups with similar azimuthal\nactions, $J_\phi$, and conjugate angles, $\theta_\phi$, which selects stars on\nsimilar orbits and at similar orbital phases, thus having experienced similar\nperturbations in the past. These divisions allow us to explore areas of the\nGalactic disk larger than the surveyed region. The separation improves the\nclarity of the $z$--$v_z$ phase spiral and exposes changes to its morphology\nacross the different action-angle groups. In particular, we discover a\ntransition to two armed `breathing spirals' in the inner Milky Way. We conclude\nthat the local data contains signatures of not one, but multiple perturbations\nwith the prospect to use their distinct properties to infer the properties of\nthe interactions that caused them. Hunt_2022 Hunt et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.06125
94 2207.09206 2022-07-19 Janet E. Drew, Flora Blake Parsons, Michael Mohr-Smith Radial velocities from far red spectra of Carina Arm O and early B stars Massive O and early B stars are important markers of recent star formation\nand exert a significant influence on their environments during their short\nlives via photoionization and winds and when they explode as supernovae. In the\nMilky Way they can be detected at great distances but often lie behind large\ndust columns, making detection at short wavelengths difficult. In this study\nthe use of the less extinguished far-red spectrum (8400 -- 8800 \AA ) for\nradial velocity measurement is examined. Results are reported for a sample of\n164 confirmed OB stars within a 2-degree field positioned on the Carina Arm.\nMost stars are at distances between 3 and 6 kpc, and Westerlund 2 is at the\nfield edge. The measured radial velocities have errors concentrated in the\n3--10 km s$^{-1}$ range, with a systematic uncertainty of 2--3 km s$^{-1}$.\nThese are combined with Gaia-mission astrometry to allow full space motions to\nbe constructed. Up to 22 stars are likely to be runaways although 8 of them are\nas likely to be interloping (so far undetected) binaries. The mean azimuthal\nmotion of the sample fits in with recent measurements of Galactic disk\nrotation. In the Galactocentric radial direction the mean motion indicates\nmodest infall at a speed of $\sim$ 10 km s$^{-1}$. This experiment shows that\nweak Paschen lines in the far-red can yield credible radial velocity\ndetermination, offering the prospect of exploring OB-star kinematics over much\nmore of the Galactic disk than has hitherto been possible. Drew_2022 Drew et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2207.09206
95 2207.09121 2022-07-19 Xiaoting Fu, Angela Bragaglia, Chao Liu, Huawei Zhang, Yan Xu, Ke Wang, Zhi-Yu Zhang, Jing Zhong, Jiang Chang, Lu Li, Li Chen, Yang Chen, Fei Wang, Eda Gjergo, Chun Wang, Nannan Yue, Xi Zhang LAMOST meets Gaia: The Galactic Open Clusters Open Clusters are born and evolve along the Milky Way plane, on them is\nimprinted the history of the Galactic disc, including the chemical and\ndynamical evolution. Chemical and dynamical properties of open clusters can be\nderived from photometric, spectroscopic, and astrometric data of their member\nstars. Based on the photometric and astrometric data from the Gaia mission, the\nmembership of stars in more than 2000 Galactic clusters has been identified in\nthe literature. The chemical and kinematical properties, however, are still\npoorly known for many of these clusters. In synergy with the large\nspectroscopic survey LAMOST (data release 8) and Gaia (data release 2), we\nreport a new comprehensive catalogue of 386 open clusters. This catalogue has\nhomogeneous parameter determinations of radial velocity, metallicity, and\ndynamical properties, such as orbit, eccentricity, angular momenta, total\nenergy, and 3D Galactic velocity. These parameters allow the first radial\nvelocity determination and the first spectroscopic [Fe/H] determination for 44\nand 137 clusters, respectively. The metallicity distribution of majority\nclusters shows falling trends in the parameter space of the Galactocentric\nradius, the total energy, and the Z component of angular momentum -- except for\ntwo old groups that show flat tails in their own parameter planes. Cluster\npopulations of ages younger and older than 500 Myrs distribute diversely on the\ndisc. The latter has a spatial consistency with the Galactic disc flare. The\n3-D spatial comparison between very young clusters (< 100 Myr) and nearby\nmolecular clouds revealed a wide range of metallicity distribution along the\nRadcliffe gas cloud wave, indicating a possible inhomogeneous mixing or fast\nstar formation along the wave. This catalogue would serve the community as a\nuseful tool to trace the chemical and dynamical evolution of the Milky Way. Fu_2022 Fu et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2207.09121
96 2207.06586 2022-07-19 Thorold Tronrud, Patricia B. Tissera, Facundo A. Gómez, Robert J. J. Grand, Ruediger Pakmor, Federico Marinacci, Christine M. Simpson Machine Learning for Galactic Archaeology: A chemistry-based neural network method for identification of accreted disc stars We develop a method ('Galactic Archaeology Neural Network', GANN) based on\nneural network models (NNMs) to identify accreted stars in galactic discs by\nonly their chemical fingerprint and age, using a suite of simulated galaxies\nfrom the Auriga Project. We train the network on the target galaxy's own local\nenvironment defined by the stellar halo and the surviving satellites. We\ndemonstrate that this approach allows the detection of accreted stars that are\nspatially mixed into the disc. Two performance measures are defined - recovery\nfraction of accreted stars, and the probability that a star with a positive\n(accreted) classification is a true-positive result, P(TP). As the NNM output\nis akin to an assigned probability, we are able to determine positivity based\non flexible threshold values that can be adjusted easily to refine the\nselection of presumed-accreted stars. We find that GANN identifies accreted\ndisc stars within simulated galaxies, with high recovery fraction and/or high\nP(TP). We also find that stars in Gaia-Enceladus-Sausage (GES) mass systems are\nover 50% recovered by our NNMs in the majority (18/24) of cases. Additionally,\nnearly every individual source of accreted stars is detected at 10% or more of\nits peak stellar mass in the disc. We also demonstrate that a conglomerated\nNNM, trained on the halo and satellite stars from all of the Auriga galaxies\nprovides the most consistent results, and could prove to be an intriguing\nfuture approach as our observational capabilities expand. Tronrud_2022 Tronrud et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2207.06586
97 2206.11248 2022-07-19 Emma Dodd, Thomas M. Callingham, Amina Helmi, Tadafumi Matsuno, Tomás Ruiz-Lara, Eduardo Balbinot, Sofie Lövdal The Gaia DR3 view of dynamical substructure in the stellar halo near the Sun The debris from past merger events is expected and, to some extent, known to\npopulate the stellar halo near the Sun. We aim to identify and characterise\nsuch merger debris using Gaia DR3 data supplemented by metallicity and chemical\nabundance information from LAMOST LRS and APOGEE for halo stars within 2.5 kpc\nfrom the Sun. We utilise a single linkage-based clustering algorithm to\nidentify over-densities in Integrals of Motion space that could be due to\nmerger debris. Combined with metallicity information and chemical abundances,\nwe characterise these statistically significant over-densities. We find that\nthe local stellar halo contains 7 main dynamical groups, some of in-situ and\nsome of accreted origin, most of which are already known. We report the\ndiscovery of a new substructure, which we name ED-1. In addition, we find\nevidence for 11 independent smaller clumps, 5 of which are new: ED-2, 3, 4, 5\nand 6 are typically rather tight dynamically, depict a small range of\nmetallicities, and their abundances when available, as well as their location\nin Integrals of Motion space, suggest an accreted origin. The local halo\ncontains an important amount of substructure, of both in-situ and accreted\norigin. Dodd_2022 Dodd et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.11248
98 2207.08839 2022-07-18 Sarah A. Bird, Xiang-Xiang Xue, Chao Liu, Chris Flynn, Juntai Shen, Jie Wang, Chengqun Yang, Meng Zhai, Ling Zhu, Gang Zhao, Hai-Jun Tian Milky Way Mass with K Giants and BHB Stars Using LAMOST, SDSS/SEGUE, and Gaia: 3D Spherical Jeans Equation and Tracer Mass Estimator We measure the enclosed Milky Way mass profile to Galactocentric distances of\n$\sim70$ and $\sim50$ kpc using the smooth, diffuse stellar halo samples of\nBird et al. The samples are LAMOST and SDSS/SEGUE K giants (KG) and SDSS/SEGUE\nblue horizontal branch (BHB) stars with accurate metallicities. The 3D\nkinematics are available through LAMOST and SDSS/SEGUE distances and radial\nvelocities and {\it Gaia} DR2 proper motions. Two methods are used to estimate\nthe enclosed mass: 3D spherical Jeans equation and Evans et al. tracer mass\nestimator (TME). We remove substructure via the Xue et al. method based on\nintegrals of motion. We evaluate the uncertainties on our estimates due to\nrandom sampling noise, systematic distance errors, the adopted density profile,\nand non-virialization and non-spherical effects of the halo. The tracer density\nprofile remains a limiting systematic in our mass estimates, although within\nthese limits we find reasonable agreement across the different samples and the\nmethods applied. Out to $\sim70$ and $\sim50$ kpc, the Jeans method yields\ntotal enclosed masses of $4.3\pm0.95$ (random) $\pm0.6$ (systematic)\n$\times10^{11}$ M$_\odot$ and $4.1\pm1.2$ (random) $\pm0.6$ (systematic)\n$\times10^{11}$ M$_\odot$ for the KG and BHB stars, respectively. For the KG\nand BHB samples we find a dark matter virial mass of\n$M_{200}=0.55^{+0.15}_{-0.11}$ (random) $\pm0.083$ (systematic) $\times10^{12}$\nM$_\odot$ and $M_{200}=1.00^{+0.67}_{-0.33}$ (random) $\pm0.15$ (systematic)\n$\times10^{12}$ M$_\odot$, respectively. Bird_2022 Bird et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2207.08839
99 2111.12626 2022-07-15 Eduardo Balbinot, Ivan Cabrera-Ziri, Carmela Lardo Evidence for C and Mg variations in the GD-1 stellar stream Dynamically cold stellar streams are the relics left over from globular\ncluster dissolution. These relics offer a unique insight into a now fully\ndisrupted population of ancient clusters in our Galaxy. Using a combination of\nGaia eDR3 proper motions, optical and near-UV colours we select a sample of\nlikely Red Giant Branch stars from the GD-1 stream for medium-low resolution\nspectroscopic follow-up. Based on radial velocity and metallicity, we are able\nto find 14 new members of GD-1, 5 of which are associated with the \emph{spur}\nand \emph{blob/cocoon} off-stream features. We measured C-abundances to probe\nfor abundance variations known to exist in globular clusters. These variations\nare expected to manifest in a subtle way in globular clusters with such low\nmasses ($\sim10^4 {\rm ~M_{\odot}}$) and metallicities (${\rm[Fe/H]}\sim-2.1\n{\rm ~dex}$). We find that the C-abundances of the stars in our sample display\na small but significant ($ 3\sigma$ level) spread. Furthermore, we find $\sim\n3\sigma$ variation in Mg-abundances among the stars in our sample that have\nbeen observed by APOGEE. These abundance patterns match the ones found in\nGalactic globular clusters of similar metallicity. Our results suggest that\nGD-1 represents another fully disrupted low mass globular cluster where\nlight-element abundance spreads have been found. Balbinot_2022 Balbinot et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.12626
100 2207.06407 2022-07-13 T. Yontan, H. Cakmak, S. Bilir, T. Banks, M. Raul, R. Canbay, S. Koc, S. Tasdemir, H. Ercay, B. Tanik Ozturk, D. C. Dursun A study of the NGC 1193 and NGC 1798 open clusters using CCD UBV photometric and Gaia EDR3 data We present photometric, astrometric, and kinematic studies of the old open\nstar clusters NGC 1193 and NGC 1798. Both of the clusters are investigated by\ncombining data sets from Gaia EDR3 and CCD UBV observational data. Analysis of\nthe radial distribution of stars through the cluster regions indicates that the\ncluster limit radii are $r_{\rm lim}=8'$ for both of the clusters. We determine\nthe membership probabilities of stars considering Gaia EDR3 proper motion and\ntrigonometric parallax data, resulting in 361 stars in NGC 1193 and 428 in NGC\n1798 being identified as most likely cluster members, having membership\nprobabilities greater than P>0.5. Mean proper motion components are estimated\nas ($\mu_{\alpha}\cos \delta$, $\mu_{\delta}) = (-0.207(0.009), -0.431(0.008)$)\nfor NGC 1193 and ($\mu_{\alpha}\cos \delta$, $\mu_{\delta})=(0.793(0.006),\n-0.373(0.005)$) mas/yr for NGC 1798. E(B-V) color excesses were derived for NGC\n1193 as $0.150(0.037)$ and for NGC 1798 as 0.505(0.100) mag through the use of\ntwo-color diagrams. Photometric metallicities are also determined from\ntwo-color diagrams with the results of [Fe/H] = -0.30(0.06) dex for NGC 1193\nand [Fe/H]=-0.20(0.07) dex for NGC 1798. The isochrone fitting distance and age\nof NGC 1193 are 5562(381) pc and 4.6(1) Gyr, respectively. For NGC 1798, these\nparameters are 4451(728) pc and 1.3(0.2) Gyr. These ages indicate that NGC 1193\nand NGC 1798 are old open clusters. The overall present-day mass function\nslopes for main-sequence stars are found as 1.38(2.16) for NGC 1193 and\n1.30(0.21) for NGC 1798, which are in fair agreement with the value of Salpeter\n(1955).
