Kinematic and dynamic orbital calculations indicate that NGC 1193 and\nNGC 1798 belong to the thick-disk and thin-disk populations, respectively. In\naddition, both of the clusters were born outside the solar circle, and both\norbit in the metal-poor region of the Galactic disk. Yontan_2022 Yontan et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2207.06407
101 2207.05693 2022-07-12 C. Vargas, S. Villanova, D. Geisler, C. Muñoz, L. Monaco, J. O'Connell, Ata Sarajedini Investigating a predicted metallicity [Fe/H] variation in the Type II Globular Cluster NGC 362 NGC 362 is a non-common Type II Galactic globular cluster, showing a complex\npseudo two-color diagram or 'chromosome map'. The clear separation of its\nstellar populations in the color-magnitude diagram and the distribution of the\ngiant stars in the chromosome map strongly suggests that NGC 362 could host\nstars with both cluster-nominal as well as enhanced heavy-element abundances,\nand one of them could be iron. However, despite previous spectroscopic\nobservations of NGC 362, no such iron variation has been detected. Our main\ngoal is to confirm or disprove this result by searching for any internal\nvariation of [Fe/H] which would give us insight into the formation and\nevolution of this interesting globular cluster. In this paper, we present the\nabundance analysis for a sample of 11 red giant branch members based on\nhigh-resolution and high S/N spectra obtained with the MIKE echelle\nspectrograph mounted at the Magellan-Clay telescope. HST and GAIA photometry\nand astrometry has been used to determine atmospheric parameters and\nmembership. We obtained T$_{\text{eff}}$, log(g) and v$_{\text{t}}$ for our\ntarget stars and measured the mean iron content of the sample and its\ndispersion with three different methods, which lead to\n[Fe/H]$_1$=-1.10$\pm0.02$, [Fe/H]$_2$=-1.09$\pm0.01$ and\n[Fe/H]$_3$=-1.10$\pm0.01$, while the internal dispersion turned out to be\n$\sigma_{[\text{Fe/H}]_1}$=0.06$\pm0.01$,\n$\sigma_{[\text{Fe/H}]_2}$=0.03$\pm0.01$ and\n$\sigma_{[\text{Fe/H}]_3}$=0.05$\pm0.01$ respectively. The error analysis gives\nan internal dispersion due to observational error of 0.05 dex. Comparing the\nobserved dispersion with the internal errors, we conclude that NGC 362 does not\nshow any trace of an internal iron spread. Vargas_2022 Vargas et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2207.05693
102 2207.03516 2022-07-07 Haochuan Li, Lawrence Widrow Residuals of an Equilibrium Model for the Galaxy Reveal a State of Disequilibrium in the Solar Neighborhood We simultaneously model the gravitational potential and phase space\ndistribution function (DF) of giant stars near the Sun using the {\it Gaia} DR2\nradial velocity catalog. We assume that the Galaxy is in equilibrium and is\nsymmetric about both the spin axis of the disk and the Galactic midplane. The\npotential is taken as a sum of terms that nominally represent contributions\nfrom the gas disk, stellar disk, bulge, and dark matter halo. Our DF model for\nthe giants comprise two components to account for a mix of thin and thick disk\nstars. The DF for each component is described by an analytic function of the\nenergy, the spin angular momentum, and the vertical energy, in accord with\nJeans theorem. We present model predictions for the radial and vertical forces\nwithin $\sim 2\,{\rm kpc}$ of the Sun, highlighting the rotation curve and\nvertical force profile in the Solar Neighbourhood. Finally, we show residuals\nfor star counts in the $R-z$ and $z-v_z$ planes as well as maps of the mean\nradial and azimuthal velocities in the $z-v_z$ plane. Using our model for the\npotential, we also examine the star count residuals in action-frequency-angle\ncoordinates. The {\it Gaia} phase spirals, velocity arches, some of the known\nmoving groups and bending modes appear as well-defined features in these maps. Li_2022a Li and Widrow 2022a https://arxiv.org/abs/2207.03516
103 2112.06514 2022-07-01 A. Pozo, T. Broadhurst, R. Emami, G. Smoot Understanding the "Feeble Giant" Crater II with tidally stretched Wave Dark Matter The unusually large "dwarf" galaxy Crater II, with its small velocity\ndispersion, $\simeq 3$ km/s, defies expectations that low mass galaxies should\nbe small and dense. We combine the latest stellar and velocity dispersion\nprofiles finding Crater II has a prominent dark core of radius $\simeq\n0.71^{+0.09}_{-0.08}$ kpc, surrounded by a low density halo, with a transition\nvisible between the core and the halo. We show that this profile matches the\ndistinctive core-halo profile predicted by "Wave Dark Matter" as a\nBose-Einstein condensate, $\psi$DM, where the ground state soliton core is\nsurrounded by a tenuous halo of interfering waves, with a marked density\ntransition predicted between the core and halo. Similar core-halo structure is\nseen in most dwarf spheroidal galaxies (dSph), but with smaller cores, $\simeq\n0.25$ kpc and higher velocity dispersions, $\simeq 9$km/s, and we argue here\nthat Crater II may have been a typical dSph that has lost most of its halo mass\nto tidal stripping, so its velocity dispersion is lower by a factor of 3 and\nthe soliton is wider by a factor of 3, following the inverse scaling required\nby the Uncertainty Principle. This tidal solution for Crater II in the context\nof $\psi$DM, is supported by its small pericenter of $\simeq 20$ kpc\nestablished by Gaia, implying significant tidal stripping of Crater II by the\nMilky Way is expected. Pozo_2022 Pozo et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.06514
104 2206.13836 2022-06-28 Linda Lombardo, Piercarlo Bonifacio, Patrick François, Camilla J Hansen, Elisabetta Caffau, Michael Hanke, {Á}sa Skúladóttir, Almudena Arcones, Marius Eichler, Moritz Reichert, Athanasios Psaltis, Andreas J Koch Hansen, Luca Sbordone Chemical Evolution of R-process Elements in Stars (CERES). I. Stellar parameters and chemical abundances from Na to Zr Aims. The Chemical Evolution of R-process Elements in Stars (CERES) project\naims to provide a homogeneous analysis of a sample of metal-poor stars\n([Fe/H]<-1.5). We present the stellar parameters and the chemical abundances of\nelements up to Zr for a sample of 52 giant stars.Methods. We relied on a sample\nof high signal-to-noise UVES spectra. We determined stellar parameters from\nGaia photometry and parallaxes. Chemical abundances were derived using spectrum\nsynthesis and model atmospheres.Results. We determined chemical abundances of\n26 species of 18 elements: Na, Mg, Al, Si, Ca, Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni,\nCu, Zn, Sr, Y, and Zr. For several stars, we were able to measure both neutral\nand ionised species, including Si, Sc, Mn, and Zr. We have roughly doubled the\nnumber of measurements of Cu for stars at [Fe/H] <= -2.5. The homogeneity of\nthe sample made it possible to highlight the presence of two Zn-rich stars\n([Zn/Fe]~+0.7), one r-rich and the other r-poor. We report the existence of two\nbranches in the [Zn/Fe] versus [Ni/Fe] plane and suggest that the high [Zn/Fe]\nbranch is the result of hypernova nucleosynthesis. We discovered two stars with\npeculiar light neutron-capture abundance patterns: CES1237+1922 (also known as\nBS 16085-0050), which is ~1 dex underabundant in Sr, Y, and Zr with respect to\nthe other stars in the sample, and CES2250-4057 (also known as HE 2247-4113),\nwhich shows a ~1 dex overabundance of Sr with respect to Y and Zr.Conclusions.\nThe high quality of our dataset allowed us to measure hardly detectable ions.\nThis can provide guidance in the development of line formation computations\nthat take deviations from local thermodynamic equilibrium and hydrodynamical\neffects into account. Lombardo_2022 Lombardo et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.13836
105 2203.01365 2022-06-28 Raymond G. Carlberg, Carl J. Grillmair The Dark Matter Halo of M54 M54 is a prototype of a globular cluster embedded in a dark matter halo. Gaia\nEDR3 photometry and proper motions separate the old, metal-poor stars from the\nmore metal rich and younger dwarf galaxy stars. The metal poor stars dominate\nthe inner 50 pc, with a velocity dispersion profile that declines to a minimum\naround 30 pc then rises back to nearly the central velocity dispersion, as\nexpected for a globular cluster at the center of a dark matter halo. The Jeans\nanalysis of the three separate stellar populations give consistent masses that\nrise approximately linearly with radius to 1 kpc, implying a small core or\ncuspy halo. These data are compatible with an infalling CDM dark matter halo\nreduced to 3x10^8 M_sun at the 50 kpc apocenter 2.3 Gyr ago, with a central\nglobular cluster surrounded by the remnant of a dwarf galaxy. Tides gradually\nremove material beyond 1 kpc but have little effect on the stars and dark\nmatter within 300 pc of the center. M54 appears to be a transitional system\nbetween globular clusters with and without local dark halos, whose evolution\nwithin the galaxy depends sensitively on the time of accretion and orbital\npericenter. Carlberg_2022 Carlberg and Grillmair 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2203.01365
106 2205.01455 2022-06-27 Chengdong Li, James Binney Our Galaxy's youngest disc We investigate the structure of our Galaxy's young stellar disc by fitting\nthe distribution functions (DFs) of a new family to five-dimensional Gaia data\nfor a sample of $47\,000$ OB stars. Tests of the fitting procedure show that\nthe young disc's DF would be strongly constrained by Gaia data if the\ndistribution of Galactic dust were accurately known. The DF that best fits the\nreal data accurately predicts the kinematics of stars at their observed\nlocations, but it predicts the spatial distribution of stars poorly, almost\ncertainly on account of errors in the best-available dust map. We argue that\ndust models could be greatly improved by modifying the dust model until the\nspatial distribution of stars predicted by a DF agreed with the data. The\nsurface density of OB stars is predicted to peak at $R\simeq5.5\mbox{kpc}$,\nslightly outside the reported peak in the surface density of molecular gas; we\nsuggest that the latter radius may have been under-estimated through the use of\npoor kinematic distances. The velocity distributions predicted by the best-fit\nDF for stars with measured line-of-sight velocities $v_\parallel$ reveal that\nthe outer disc is disturbed at the level of 10 $\mbox{km}~\mbox{s}^{-1}$ in\nagreement with earlier studies, and that the measured values of $v_\parallel$\nhave significant contributions from the orbital velocities of binaries. Hence\nthe outer disc is colder than it is sometimes reported to be. Li_2022 Li and Binney 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2205.01455
107 2206.12817 2022-06-26 Tommaso Marchetti, Christian I. Johnson, Meridith Joyce, R. Michael Rich, Iulia Simion, Michael D. Young, William I. Clarkson, Catherine A. Pilachowski, Scott Michael, Andrea Kunder, Andreas J. Koch-Hansen Blanco DECam Bulge Survey (BDBS) V. Cleaning the foreground populations from Galactic bulge colour-magnitude diagrams using Gaia EDR3 The Blanco DECam Bulge Survey (BDBS) has imaged more than 200 square degrees\nof the southern Galactic bulge, providing photometry in the ugrizy filters for\n$\sim 250$ million unique stars. The presence of a strong foreground disk\npopulation, along with complex reddening and extreme image crowding, has made\nit difficult to constrain the presence of young and intermediate age stars in\nthe bulge population. We employed an accurate cross-match of BDBS with the\nlatest data release (EDR3) from the Gaia mission, matching more than 140\nmillion sources with BDBS photometry and Gaia EDR3 photometry and astrometry.\nWe relied on Gaia EDR3 astrometry, without any photometric selection, to\nproduce clean BDBS bulge colour-magnitude diagrams (CMDs). Gaia parallaxes were\nused to filter out bright foreground sources, and a Gaussian mixture model fit\nto Galactic proper motions could identify stars kinematically consistent with\nbulge membership. We applied this method to 127 different bulge fields of $1$\ndeg$^2$ each, with $|\ell| \leq 9.5^\circ$ and $-9.5^\circ \leq b \leq\n-2.5^\circ$. The astrometric cleaning procedure removes the majority of blue\nstars in each field, especially near the Galactic plane, where the ratio of\nblue to red stars is $\lesssim 10\%$, increasing to values $\sim 20\%$ at\nhigher Galactic latitudes. We rule out the presence of a widespread population\nof stars younger than 2 Gyr. The vast majority of blue stars brighter than the\nturnoff belong to the foreground population, according to their measured\nastrometry. We introduce the distance between the observed red giant branch\nbump and the red clump as a simple age proxy for the dominant population in the\nfield, and we confirm the picture of a predominantly old bulge. Further work is\nneeded to apply the method to estimate ages to fields at higher latitudes, and\nto model the complex morphology of the Galactic bulge. Marchetti_2022a Marchetti et al. 2022a https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.12817
108 2206.12935 2022-06-26 Alexander A. Chemel, Richard de Grijs, Elena V. Glushkova, Andrey K. Dambis Search for OB associations in {\sl Gaia} early Data Release 3 The distribution of young stars into OB associations has long been in need of\nupdating. High-precision {\sl Gaia} early Data Release 3 astrometry, coupled\nwith modern machine-learning methods, allows this to be done. We have compiled\na well-defined sample which includes OB stars and young open clusters, in total\ncomprising about 47,700 objects. To break the sample down into groupings\nresembling associations, we applied the HDBSCAN$^{*}$ clustering algorithm. We\nused a Monte Carlo method to estimate the kinematic ages of the resulting\nclusters and the Student's $t$-test to assess the significance of the linear\ncorrelations between proper motions and coordinates, indicating the presence of\npossible cluster expansion signatures. The ages of the majority of clusters\ndemonstrating a general expansion at a 1$\sigma$ confidence level are several\ntens of Myr, which is in agreement with the expected ages of OB associations.\nWe found 32 open clusters which turned out to be members of the resulting\ngroupings; their ages are consistent with one another within the uncertainties.\nComparison of the clusters thus obtained with the historical composition of OB\nassociations in the literature shows a correspondence between their positions\nin the Galaxy but an apparent absence of good one-to-one stellar matches.\nTherefore, we suggest that the historical composition of OB associations needs\nto be revised. Chemel_2022 Chemel et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.12935
109 2206.06962 2022-06-24 Tommaso Marchetti, Fraser A. Evans, Elena Maria Rossi Gaia DR3 in 6D: The search for fast hypervelocity stars and constraints on the Galactic Centre environment The third data release (DR3) of the European Space Agency satellite Gaia\nprovides coordinates, parallaxes, proper motions, and radial velocities for a\nsample of $\sim 34$ million stars. We use the combined 6-dimensional phase\nspace information to search for hypervelocity stars (HVSs), unbound stars\naccelerated by dynamical processes happening in the Galactic Centre. By looking\nat the kinematics of Gaia DR3 stars in Galactocentric coordinates and by\nintegrating their orbits in the Galactic potential, we do not identify any HVS\ncandidates with a velocity higher than $700$ km s$^{-1}$ and robustly observed\nkinematics. Assuming a scenario wherein the interaction between a stellar\nbinary and the massive black hole Sgr A$^*$ is responsible for HVS ejections\nfrom the Galactic Centre, we derive degenerate limits on the ejection rate of\nHVSs and the slope of the initial mass function of the primary star among\nbinaries in the Galactic Centre. Our results indicate that the HVS ejection\nrate is $\lesssim 8\times10^{-5}$ yr$^{-1}$ assuming a Salpeter mass function,\nand this upper limit becomes progressively smaller for an increasingly\ntop-heavy mass distribution. A fiducial HVS ejection rate of $10^{-4}$\nyr$^{-1}$ prefers a mass function slope $\lesssim -2.35$, disfavouring\npreviously claimed top-heavy initial mass functions among stars in the Galactic\nCentre. Marchetti_2022 Marchetti et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.06962
110 2111.12414 2022-06-23 Begoña García-Conde, Santi Roca-Fàbrega, Teresa Antoja, Pau Ramos, Octavio Valenzuela Phase spirals in cosmological simulations of Milky Way-size galaxies We study the vertical perturbations in the galactic disc of the Milky\nWay-size high-resolution hydrodynamical cosmological simulation named GARROTXA.\nWe detect phase spirals in the vertical projection $Z- V_{Z}$ of disc's stellar\nparticles for the first time in this type of simulations. Qualitatively similar\nstructures were detected in the recent Gaia data, and their origin is still\nunder study. In our model the spiral-like structures in the phase space are\npresent in a wide range of times and locations across the disc. By accounting\nfor an evolving mix of stellar populations, we observe that, as seen in the\ndata, the phase spirals are better observed in the range of\nyounger-intermediate star particles. We measure the intensity of the spiral\nwith a Fourier decomposition and find that these structures appear stronger\nnear satellite pericenters. Current dynamical models of the phase spiral\nconsidering a single perturber required a mass at least of the order of\n10$^{10}$ M$_\odot$, but all three of our satellites have masses of the order\nof $\sim$10$^8$ M$_\odot$. We suggest that there are other mechanisms at play\nwhich appear naturally in our model such as the physics of gas, collective\neffect of multiple perturbers, and a dynamically cold population that is\ncontinuously renovated by the star formation Complementing collisionless\nisolated N-body models with the use of fully-cosmological simulations with\nenough resolution can provide new insights into the nature/origin of the phase\nspiral. García-Conde_2022 García-Conde et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.12414
111 2206.08459 2022-06-16 Mohammad K. Mardini, Anna Frebel, Anirudh Chiti, Yohai Meiron, Kaley V. Brauer, Xiaowei Ou The Atari Disk, a Metal-Poor Stellar Population in the Disk System of the Milky Way We have developed a chemo-dynamical approach to assign 36,010 metal-poor\nSkyMapper stars to various Galactic stellar populations. Using two independent\ntechniques (velocity and action space behavior), $Gaia$ EDR3 astrometry, and\nphotometric metallicities, we selected stars with the characteristics of the\n"metal-weak" thick disk population by minimizing contamination by the canonical\nthick disk or other Galactic structures. This sample comprises 7,127 stars,\nspans a metallicity range of $-3.50<${\metal}~$<-0.8$, and has a systematic\nrotational velocity of $\langle V_\phi\rangle=154$\,km\,s$^{-1}$ that lags that\nof the thick disk. Orbital eccentricities have intermediate values between\ntypical thick disk and halo values. The scale length is\n$h_{R}=2.48^{+0.05}_{-0.05}$\,kpc and the scale height is\n$h_{Z}=1.68^{+0.19}_{-0.15}$\,kpc. The metallicity distribution function is\nwell fit by an exponential with a slope of $\Delta\log{\rm\nN}/\Delta\metal=1.13\pm0.06$. Overall, we find a significant metal-poor\ncomponent consisting of 261 SkyMapper stars with \metal$<-2.0$. While our\nsample contains only eleven stars with {\metal}~$\lesssim-3.0$, investigating\nthe JINAbase compilation of metal-poor stars reveals another 18 such stars\n(five have {\metal}$<-4.0$) that kinematically belong to our sample. These\ndistinct spatial, kinematic and chemical characteristics strongly suggest this\nmetal-poor, phase-mixed kinematic sample to represent an independent disk\ncomponent with an accretion origin in which a massive dwarf galaxy radially\nplunged into the early Galactic disk. Going forward, we propose to call the\nmetal-weak thick disk population as the Atari disk, given its likely accretion\norigin, and in reference to it sharing space with the Galactic thin and thick\ndisks. Mardini_2022 Mardini et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.08459
112 2206.07937 2022-06-16 G. Kordopatis, M. Schultheis, P. J. McMillan, P. A. Palicio, P. de Laverny, A. Recio-Blanco, O. Creevey, M. A. Álvarez, R. Andrae, E. Poggio, E. Spitoni, G. Contursi, H. Zhao, I. Oreshina-Slezak, C. Ordenovic, A. Bijaoui Stellar ages, masses, extinctions and orbital parameters based on spectroscopic parameters of Gaia DR3 Gaia DR3 provides radial velocities for 33 million stars and\nspectroscopically derived atmospheric parameters for more than five million\ntargets. When combined with the astrometric data, these allow us to derive\norbital and stellar parameters that are key in order to understand the stellar\npopulations of the Milky Way and perform galactic archaeology. We use the\ncalibrated atmospheric parameters, 2MASS and Gaia-EDR3 photometry, and\nparallax-based distances to compute, via an isochrone fitting method, the ages,\ninitial stellar masses and reddenings for the stars with spectroscopic\nparameters. We also derive the orbits (actions, eccentricities, apocentre,\npericentre and Zmax) for all of the stars with measured radial velocities and\nastrometry, adopting two sets of line-of-sight distances from the literature\nand an axisymmetric potential of the Galaxy. Comparisons with reference\ncatalogues of field and cluster stars suggest that reliable ages are obtained\nfor stars younger than 9-10Gyr when the estimated relative age uncertainty is\n<50%. For older stars, ages tend to be under-estimated. The most reliable\nstellar type for age determination are turn-off stars, even when the input\natmospheric parameters have large uncertainties. Ages for giants and\nmain-sequence stars are retrieved with uncertainties of ~2Gyr when extinction\ntowards the star's line-of sight is smaller than A_V<2.5mag. The full catalogue\nis made publicly available to be downloaded. With it, the full chemo-dynamical\nproperties of the extended Solar neighbourhood unfold, and allow us to better\nidentify the properties of the spiral arms, to parameterise the dynamical\nheating of the disc, or to thoroughly study the chemical enrichment of the\nMilky Way. Kordopatis_2022 Kordopatis et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.07937
113 2110.11465 2022-06-16 Thomas Donlon II, Heidi Jo Newberg, Bokyoung Kim, Sebastien Lepine The Local Stellar Halo is Not Dominated by a Single Radial Merger Event We use halo dwarf stars with photometrically determined metallicities that\nare located within 2 kpc of the Sun to identify local halo substructure. The\nkinematic properties of these stars do not indicate a single, dominant radial\nmerger event (RME). The retrograde Virgo Radial Merger (VRM) component has\n[Fe/H] = -1.7. A second, non-rotating RME component we name Nereus is\nidentified with [Fe/H] = -2.1 and has similar energy as the VRM. A possible\nthird RME we name Cronus is identified that is co-rotating with the disk, has\nlower energy than the VRM, and has [Fe/H] = -1.2. We identify the Nyx Stream in\nthe data. In addition to these substructures, we observe metal-poor halo stars\n([Fe/H] ~ -2.0 and $\sigma_v$ ~ 180 km s$^{-1}$) and a disk/Splash component\nwith lower rotational velocity than the disk and lower metallicity than\ntypically associated with the Splash. An additional excess of halo stars with\nlow velocity and metallicity of [Fe/H] = -1.5 could be associated with the\nshell of a lower energy RME or indicate that lower energy halo stars have\nhigher metallicity. Stars which comprise the "Gaia Sausage" velocity structure\nare a combination of the components identified in this work. II_2022 II et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2110.11465
114 2206.07251 2022-06-15 Jiaming Pan, Eric F. Bell, Adam Smercina, Paul Price, Colin T. Slater, Jeremy Bailin, Roelof S. de Jong, Richard D'Souza, In Sung Jang, Antonela Monachesi New Globular Cluster Candidates in the M81 group The study of outer halo globular cluster (GC) populations can give insight\ninto galaxy merging, globular cluster accretion and the origin of GCs. We use\narchival Subaru Hyper Suprime-Cam (HSC) data in concert with space-based GALEX,\nIRAC and Gaia EDR3 data to select candidate Globular clusters (GCs) in the\nouter halo of the M81 group for confirmation and future study. We use a small\nsample of previously-discovered GCs to tune our selection criteria, finding\nthat bright already-known GCs in the M81 group have sizes that are typically\nslightly larger than the Subaru PSF in our fields. In the optical bands, GCs\nappear to have colours that are only slightly different from stars. The\ninclusion of archival IRAC data yields dramatic improvements in colour\nseparation, as the long wavelength baseline aids somewhat in the separation\nfrom stars and clearly separates GCs from many compact background galaxies. We\nshow that some previously spectroscopically-identified GCs in the M81 group are\ninstead foreground stars or background galaxies. GCs close to M82 have radial\nvelocities suggesting that they fell into the M81 group along with M82. The\noverall M81 GC luminosity function is similar to the Milky Way and M31. M81's\nouter halo GCs are similar to the Milky Way in their metallicities and numbers,\nand much less numerous than M31's more metal-rich outer halo GC population.\nThese properties reflect differences in the three galaxies' merger histories,\nhighlighting the possibility of using outer halo GCs to trace merger history in\nlarger samples of galaxies. Pan_2022 Pan et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.07251
115 2206.04627 2022-06-14 Patrick Nelson, Lawrence M. Widrow Gaussian Process Model for the Local Stellar Velocity Field from Gaia Data Release 2 We model the local stellar velocity field using position and velocity\nmeasurements for 4M stars from the second data release of Gaia. We determine\nthe components of the mean or bulk velocity in ~27k spatially-defined bins. Our\nassumption is that these quantities constitute a Gaussian process where the\ncorrelation between the bulk velocity at different locations is described by a\nsimple covariance function or kernel. We use a sparse Gaussian process\nalgorithm based on inducing points to construct a non-parametric, smooth, and\ndifferentiable model for the underlying velocity field. We estimate the Oort\nconstants A, B, C, and K and find values in excellent agreement with previous\nresults. Maps of the velocity field within 2 kpc of the Sun reveal complicated\nsubstructures, which provide clear evidence that the local disk is in a state\nof disequilibrium. We present the first 3D map of the divergence of the stellar\nvelocity field and identify regions of the disk that may be undergoing\ncompression and rarefaction. Nelson_2022 Nelson and Widrow 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.04627
116 2205.13839 2022-06-13 K. J. Nikitha, S. Vig, S. K. Ghosh Stellar populations of the globular cluster NGC 5053 investigated using AstroSat-Ultra Violet Imaging Telescope Globular clusters being old and densely packed serve as ideal laboratories to\ntest stellar evolution theories. Although there is enormous literature on\nglobular clusters in optical bands, studies in the ultraviolet (UV) regime are\nsparse. In this work, we study the stellar populations of a metal poor and a\nrather dispersed globular cluster, NGC 5053, using the UV instrument of\nAstroSat, namely the Ultra Violet Imaging Telescope in three far-UV (F154W,\nF169M, F172M) and three near-UV (N219M, N245M, N263M) filters. Photometry was\ncarried out on these images to construct a catalogue of UV stars, of which the\ncluster members were identified using Gaia EDR3 catalogue. UV and optical CMDs\nhelp us locate known stellar populations such as BHB stars, RR-Lyrae stars, RHB\nstars, BSSs, SX-Phe, RGB and AGB stars. Based on their locations in the CMDs,\nwe have identified 8 new BSS candidates, 6 probable eBSSs, and an EHB\ncandidate. Their nature has been confirmed by fitting their spectral energy\ndistributions with stellar atmospheric models. We believe the BSS population of\nthis cluster is likely to have a collisional origin based on our analyses of\ntheir radial distribution and SEDs. BaSTI-IAC isochrones were generated to\ncharacterize the cluster properties, and we find that the observed brightness\nand colours of cluster members are best-fit with a model that is alpha-enhanced\nwith a helium fraction of 0.247, metallicity of -1.9 dex and age within a range\nof 10.5-14.5 Gyr. Nikitha_2022 Nikitha et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2205.13839
117 2206.05287 2022-06-10 Richa Kundu, Camila Navarrete, Luca Sbordone, Julio A. Carballo-Bello, José G. Fernández-Trincado, Dante Minniti, Harinder P. Singh Extra-tidal star candidates in globular clusters of the Sagittarius dwarf spheroidal galaxy Globular clusters (GCs) associated with the Sagittarius dwarf spheroidal\ngalaxy (Sgr dSph) have evolved under the gravitational potential of both Sgr\ndSph and the Milky Way. The effects of these potentials are most pronounced in\nthe extra-tidal regions as compared to the central regions of the GCs.We aim to\nstudy the extra-tidal regions of the GCs that are possibly associated with Sgr\ndSph, namely Arp 2, Terzan 8, NGC 5634, NGC 6284, Terzan 7, NGC 2419, NGC 4147,\nM 54 and Pal 12, using data from the {\it Gaia} early data release 3. We\nselected the extra-tidal candidates based on their angular distances from the\ncluster centre in the RA-Dec plane, proper motions of the clusters and the\nindividual extra-tidal star candidates, and their positions on the\ncolour-magnitude diagrams of the clusters. We found extra-tidal candidates for\nthe nine studied GCs. For eight of them, the surface density of candidate\nextra-tidal stars in the vicinity of the clusters is in significant excess with\nrespect to more distant surrounding fields. No extended extra-tidal features\nbeyond 5 tidal radii were detected for any of the clusters. We publish a list\nof the most probable extra-tidal candidates that we determined using Gaia\nastrometric and photometric data. Our analysis shows that the clusters that are\nassociated with Sgr dSph are more likely affected by the gravitational\npotential of the Sgr, as the distribution of extra-tidal stars is elongated in\nthe same direction as the local stream. NGC 4147 is the only exception. We\nfound some high-probability candidate extra-tidal stars in several of the\nanalysed clusters. We failed to detect any coherent large-scale tidal tail\naround them. Kundu_2022 Kundu et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.05287
118 2206.03875 2022-06-08 Diane K. Feuillet, Sofia Feltzing, Christian Sahlholdt, Thomas Bensby An old, metal-rich accreted stellar component in the Milky Way stellar disk We study the possibility that the Milky Way's cool stellar disc includes\nmergers with ancient stars. Galaxies are understood to form in a hierarchical\nmanner, where smaller (proto-)galaxies merge into larger ones. Stars in\ngalaxies, like the Milky Way, contain in their motions and elemental abundances\ntracers of past events and can be used to disentangle merger remnants from\nstars that formed in the main galaxy. The merger history of the Milky Way is\ngenerally understood to be particularly easy to study in the stellar halo. The\nadvent of the ESA astrometric satellite Gaia has enabled the detection of\ncompletely new structures in the halo such as the Gaia-Enceladus-Sausage.\nHowever, simulations also show that mergers may be important for the build-up\nof the cool stellar disks. Combining elemental abundances for 100 giant branch\nstars from APOGEE DR17 and astrometric data from Gaia we use elemental\nabundance ratios to find an hitherto unknown, old stellar component in the cool\nstellar disk in the Milky Way. We further identify a small sample of RR Lyrae\nvariables with disk kinematics that also show the same chemical signature as\nthe accreted red giant stars in the disk. These stars allows us to date the\nstars in the accreted component. We find that they are exclusively old. Feuillet_2022 Feuillet et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.03875
119 2206.03523 2022-06-07 James Binney, Eugene Vasiliev Self-consistent models of our Galaxy A new class of models of stellar discs is introduced and used to build a\nself-consistent model of our Galaxy. The model is defined by the parameters\nthat specify the action-based distribution functions (DFs) f(J) of four stellar\ndiscs (three thin-disc age cohorts and a thick disc), spheroidal bulge and\nspheroidal stellar and dark haloes. From these DFs plus a specified\ndistribution of gas, we solve for the densities of stars and dark matter and\nthe potential they generate. The principal observational constraints are the\nkinematics of stars with Gaia RVS data and the density of stars in the column\nabove the Sun. The model predicts the density and kinematics of stars and dark\nmatter throughout the Galaxy. We determine the structure of the dark halo prior\nto the infall of baryons. A simple extension of the DFs of stellar components\nto include chemistry allows the model to reproduce the way the Galaxy's\nchemistry is observed to vary in the (R,z) plane. Surprisingly, the data\nindicate that high-alpha stars are confined to orbits with J_z >~ 50 kpc km/s.\nThe code used to create the model is available on Github. Binney_2022 Binney and Vasiliev 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.03523
120 2202.01599 2022-06-06 Eduardo Vitral, Kyle Kremer, Mattia Libralato, Gary A. Mamon, Andrea Bellini Stellar graveyards: Clustering of compact objects in globular clusters NGC 3201 and NGC 6397 We analyse Gaia EDR3 and re-calibrated HST proper motion data from the\ncore-collapsed and non core-collapsed globular clusters NGC 6397 and NGC 3201,\nrespectively, with the Bayesian mass-orbit modelling code MAMPOSSt-PM. We use\nBayesian evidence and realistic mock data sets constructed with AGAMA to select\nbetween different mass models. In both clusters, the velocities are consistent\nwith isotropy within the extent of our data. We robustly detect a dark central\nmass (DCM) of roughly 1000 solar masses in both clusters. Our MAMPOSSt-PM fits\nstrongly prefer an extended DCM in NGC 6397, while only presenting a mild\npreference for it in NGC 3201, with respective sizes of a roughly one and a few\nper cent of the cluster effective radius. We explore the astrophysics behind\nour results with the CMC Monte Carlo N-body code, whose snapshots best matching\nthe phase space observations lead to similar values for the mass and size of\nthe DCM. The internal kinematics are thus consistent with a population of\nhundreds of massive white dwarfs in NGC 6397, and roughly 100 segregated\nstellar-mass black holes in NGC 3201, as previously found with CMC. Such\nanalyses confirm the accuracy of both mass-orbit modelling and Monte Carlo\nN-body techniques, which together provide more robust predictions on the DCM of\nglobular clusters (core-collapsed or not). This opens possibilities to\nunderstand a vast range of interesting astrophysical phenomena in clusters,\nsuch as fast radio bursts, compact object mergers, and gravitational waves. Vitral_2022 Vitral et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2202.01599
121 2205.15507 2022-05-31 Zehao Lin, Ye Xu, Ligang Hou, Dejian Liu, Yingjie Li, Chaojie Hao, Jingjing Li, Shuaibo Bian Local Spiral Structure Traced by Red Clump Stars Using the cross-matched data of Gaia EDR3 and the 2MASS Point Source Catalog,\na sample of RC stars with parallax accuracies better than 20% is identified and\nused to reveal the nearby spiral pattern traced by old stars. As shown in the\noverdensity distribution of RC stars, there is an arc-like feature extended\nfrom $l~\sim$ 90$^\circ$ to $\sim$ 243$^\circ$, which passed close to the Sun.\nThis feature is probably an arm segment traced by old stars, indicating the\nGalaxy potential in the vicinity of the Sun. By comparing to the spiral arms\ndepicted by young objects, we found that there are considerable offsets between\nthe two different components of Galactic spiral arms. The spiral arm traced by\nRC stars tends to have a larger pitch angle, hence a more loose wound pattern. Lin_2022 Lin et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2205.15507
122 2205.12278 2022-05-24 Adriana Dropulic, Hongwan Liu, Bryan Ostdiek, Mariangela Lisanti Revealing the Milky Way's Most Recent Major Merger with a Gaia EDR3 Catalog of Machine-Learned Line-of-Sight Velocities Machine learning can play a powerful role in inferring missing line-of-sight\nvelocities from astrometry in surveys such as Gaia. In this paper, we apply a\nneural network to Gaia Early Data Release 3 (EDR3) and obtain line-of-sight\nvelocities and associated uncertainties for ~92 million stars. The network,\nwhich takes as input a star's parallax, angular coordinates, and proper\nmotions, is trained and validated on ~6.4 million stars in Gaia with complete\nphase-space information. The network's uncertainty on its velocity prediction\nis a key aspect of its design; by properly convolving these uncertainties with\nthe inferred velocities, we obtain accurate stellar kinematic distributions. As\na first science application, we use the new network-completed catalog to\nidentify candidate stars that belong to the Milky Way's most recent major\nmerger, Gaia-Sausage-Enceladus (GSE). We present the kinematic, energy, angular\nmomentum, and spatial distributions of the ~450,000 GSE candidates in this\nsample, and also study the chemical abundances of those with cross matches to\nGALAH and APOGEE. The network's predictive power will only continue to improve\nwith future Gaia data releases as the training set of stars with complete\nphase-space information grows. This work provides a first demonstration of how\nto use machine learning to exploit high-dimensional correlations on data to\ninfer line-of-sight velocities, and offers a template for how to train,\nvalidate and apply such a neural network when complete observational data is\nnot available. Dropulic_2022 Dropulic et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2205.12278
123 2201.02404 2022-05-17 S. Sofie Lövdal, Tomás Ruiz-Lara, Helmer H. Koppelman, Tadafumi Matsuno, Emma Dodd, Amina Helmi Substructure in the stellar halo near the Sun. I. Data-driven clustering in Integrals of Motion space Aims: Develop a data-driven and statistically based method for finding such\nclumps in Integrals of Motion space for nearby halo stars and evaluating their\nsignificance robustly. Methods: We use data from Gaia EDR3 extended with radial\nvelocities from ground-based spectroscopic surveys to construct a sample of\nhalo stars within 2.5 kpc from the Sun. We apply a hierarchical clustering\nmethod that uses the single linkage algorithm in a 3D space defined by the\ncommonly used integrals of motion energy $E$, together with two components of\nthe angular momentum, $L_z$ and $L_\perp$. To evaluate the statistical\nsignificance of the clusters found, we compare the density within an\nellipsoidal region centered on the cluster to that of random sets with similar\nglobal dynamical properties. We pick out the signal at the location of their\nmaximum statistical significance in the hierarchical tree. We estimate the\nproximity of a star to the cluster center using the Mahalanobis distance. We\nalso apply the HDBSCAN clustering algorithm in velocity space. Results: Our\nprocedure identifies 67 highly significant clusters ($ > 3\sigma$), containing\n12\% of the sources in our halo set, and in total 232 subgroups or individual\nstreams in velocity space. In total, 13.8\% of the stars in our data set can be\nconfidently associated to a significant cluster based on their Mahalanobis\ndistance. Inspection of our data set reveals a complex web of relationships\nbetween the significant clusters, suggesting that they can be tentatively\ngrouped into at least 6 main structures, many of which can be associated to\npreviously identified halo substructures, and a number of independent\nsubstructures. This preliminary conclusion is further explored in an\naccompanying paper by Ruiz-Lara et al., where we also characterize the\nsubstructures in terms of their stellar populations. Conclusions: We find...\n(abridged version) Lövdal_2022 Lövdal et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2201.02404
124 2112.03973 2022-05-12 Guillaume F. Thomas, Giuseppina Battaglia The Cetus-Palca stream: A disrupted small dwarf galaxy. A prequel to the science possible with WEAVE with precise spectro-photometric distances We present a new fully data-driven approach to derive spectro-photometric\ndistances based on artificial neural networks. The method was developed and\ntested on SEGUE data and will serve as a reference for the $Contributed$ $Data$\n$Product$ SPdist of the WEAVE survey. With this method, the relative precision\nof the distances is of $\sim 13 \%$. The catalogue of more than 300,000 SEGUE\nstars for which we have derived spectro-photometric distances will soon be\npublicly available on the Vizier service of the Centre de Donn\'ees de\nStrasbourg. With this 6D catalogue of stars with positions, distances,\nline-of-sight velocity, and $Gaia$ proper motions, we were able to identify\nstars belonging to the Cetus stellar stream in the integrals of motion space.\nGuided by the properties we derived for the Cetus stream from this 6D sample,\nwe searched for additional stars from the blue horizontal and from the red\ngiant branches in a 5D sample. We find that the Cetus stream and the Palca\noverdensity are actually two parts of the same structure, which therefore we\npropose to rename the Cetus-Palca stream. We found that the Cetus-Palca stream\nhas a stellar mass of $\simeq 1.5 \times 10^6$ M$_\odot$ and presents a\nprominent distance gradient of 15 kpc over the $\sim 100 \deg$ that it covers\non the sky. Additionally, we also report the discovery of a second structure,\nalmost parallel to the Cetus stream, covering $\sim 50 \deg$ of the sky, that\ncould potentially be a stellar stream formed by the tidal disruption of a\nglobular cluster that was orbiting around the Cetus stream progenitor. Thomas_2022 Thomas and Battaglia 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.03973
125 2205.03444 2022-05-06 E. R. Garro, D. Minniti, M. Gómez, J. G. Fernández-Trincado, J. Alonso-García, M. Hempel, R. Zelada Bacigalupo A new low-luminosity globular cluster discovered in the Milky Way with the VVVX survey The VISTA Variables in the Via L\'actea Extended Survey (VVVX) allows probing\npreviously unexplored regions of the inner Milky Way (MW). We are looking for\nnew candidate globular clusters (GCs), with the aim of completing the census of\nthe MW GC system. We searched and characterised new GCs, using a combination of\nthe near-IR VVVX survey and 2MASS datasets, and the optical Gaia EDR3\nphotometry and its precise proper motions (PMs). We report the discovery of a\nnew Galactic GC, named Garro 02, situated at RA=18:05:51.1, Dec=-17:42:02 and\nl=12.042 deg, b=+1.656 deg. Performing a PM-decontamination procedure, we built\na final catalogue with all cluster members, on which we performed a photometric\nanalysis. We calculated a reddening of $E(J-K_s)=1.07\pm 0.06$ mag and\nextinction of $A_{Ks}=0.79\pm 0.04$ mag in the near-IR; while $E(BP-RP)=2.40\pm\n0.01$ mag and $A_{G}=4.80\pm 0.02$ mag in optical passbands. Its heliocentric\ndistance is $D=5.6\pm 0.8$ kpc, which places Garro 02 at a Galactocentric\ndistance of $R_G=2.9$ kpc and Z=0.006 kpc above the Galactic plane. We\nestimated the metallicity and age by comparison with known GCs and by fitting\nPARSEC isochrones, finding [Fe/H]$=-1.30\pm 0.2$ dex and age=$12\pm 2$ Gyr. We\nderived the mean cluster PM of $(\mu_{\alpha}^{\ast}, \mu_{\delta}) = (-6.07\pm\n0.62, -6.15\pm 0.75)$ mas yr$^{-1}$. We calculated the cluster luminosity in\nthe near-IR of $M_{Ks}=-7.52\pm 1.23$ mag, which is equivalent to $M_{V}=-5.44$\nmag. The core and tidal radii from the radial density profile are $r_c =1.25\pm\n0.27$ arcmin (2.07 pc) and $r_t = 7.13\pm 3.83$ arcmin (11.82 pc),\nrespectively. We confirm Garro 02 as a new genuine Galactic GC, located in the\nMW bulge. It is a low-luminosity, metal-poor, and old GC, and it is a lucky\nsurvivor of the strong dynamical processes that occurred during the MW's entire\nlife. Garro_2022 Garro et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2205.03444
126 2205.01129 2022-05-02 Matthew R Buckley, Sung Hak Lim, Eric Putney, David Shih Measuring Galactic Dark Matter through Unsupervised Machine Learning Measuring the density profile of dark matter in the Solar neighborhood has\nimportant implications for both dark matter theory and experiment. In this\nwork, we apply autoregressive flows to stars from a realistic simulation of a\nMilky Way-type galaxy to learn -- in an unsupervised way -- the stellar phase\nspace density and its derivatives. With these as inputs, and under the\nassumption of dynamic equilibrium, the gravitational acceleration field and\nmass density can be calculated directly from the Boltzmann Equation without the\nneed to assume either cylindrical symmetry or specific functional forms for the\ngalaxy's mass density. We demonstrate our approach can accurately reconstruct\nthe mass density and acceleration profiles of the simulated galaxy, even in the\npresence of Gaia-like errors in the kinematic measurements. Buckley_2022 Buckley et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2205.01129
127 2107.10875 2022-04-28 Jonathan Clarke, Ortwin Gerhard The Pattern Speed of the Milky Way Bar/Bulge from VIRAC & Gaia We compare distance resolved, absolute proper motions in the Milky Way\nbar/bulge region to a grid of made-to-measure dynamical models with well\ndefined pattern speeds. The data are obtained by combining the relative VVV\nInfrared Astrometric Catalog v1 proper motions with the Gaia DR2 absolute\nreference frame. We undertake a comprehensive analysis of the various errors in\nour comparison, from both the data and the models, and allow for additional,\nunknown, contributions by using an outlier-tolerant likelihood function to\nevaluate the best fitting model. We quantify systematic effects such as the\nregion of data included in the comparison, the possible overlap from spiral\narms, and the choice of synthetic luminosity function and bar angle used to\npredict the data from the models. Resulting variations in the best-fit\nparameters are included in their final errors. We thus measure the bar pattern\nspeed to be ${\Omega}_b=33.29\pm1.81 \mathrm{km \, s^{-1} \, kpc^{-1}}$ and the\nazimuthal solar velocity to be $V_{\phi,\,\odot} = 251.31 \pm 1.95 \mathrm{km\n\, s^{-1}}$. These values, when combined with recent measurements of the\nGalactic rotation curve, yield the distance of corotation, 6.5 < $R_{CR}$ [kpc]\n< 7.5, the outer Lindblad resonance (OLR), 10.7 < $R_{OLR}$ [kpc] < 12.4, and\nthe higher order, m = 4, OLR, 8.7 < $R_{{OLR}_4}$ [kpc] < 10.0. The measured\npattern speed provides strong evidence for the "long-slow" bar scenario. Clarke_2022 Clarke and Gerhard 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2107.10875
128 2201.02405 2022-04-28 Tomás Ruiz-Lara, Tadafumi Matsuno, S. Sofie Lövdal, Amina Helmi, Emma Dodd, Helmer H. Koppelman Substructure in the stellar halo near the Sun. II. Characterisation of independent structures In L\"ovdal et al, we presented a data-driven method for clustering in\nIntegrals of Motion space and applied it to a large sample of nearby halo stars\nwith 6D phase-space information. We identified a large number of clusters, many\nof which could tentatively be merged into larger groups. Our goal is to\nestablish the reality of the clusters through a combined study of their stellar\npopulations to gain more insights into the accretion history of the Milky Way.\nWe develop a procedure that quantifies the similarity of clusters based on KS\ntests using their metallicity distribution functions, and an isochrone fitting\nmethod to determine their average age, which is also used to compare the\ndistribution of stars in the Colour-Absolute magnitude diagram. This allows us\nto group clusters into substructures, and to compare substructures with one\nanother. The clusters identified are merged into 12 extended substructures,\nwhile 8 small clusters remain as such. The large substructures include the\npreviously known Gaia-Enceladus, Helmi streams, Sequoia, and Thamnos 1 and 2.\nWe identify overdensities associated with the hot thick disc and hosting a\nmetal-poor population. Especially notable is our largest substructure which,\nalthough peaking at the metallicity characteristic of the thick disk has a well\npopulated metal-poor component, and dynamics in-between hot thick disc and\nhalo. We identify additional debris in the region occupied by Sequoia with\ndistinct kinematics, likely remnants of three different accretion events with\nprogenitors of similar mass. We also identify different trends of [Mg/Fe] vs\n[Fe/H] for the various substructures confirming our dissection of the nearby\nhalo. At least 20\% of the halo near the Sun is associated to substructures.\nWhen comparing their global properties, we note that those substructures on\nretrograde orbits are not only more metal-poor on average but also older. Ruiz-Lara_2022 Ruiz-Lara et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2201.02405
129 2204.12886 2022-04-27 Snehalata Sahu, Annapurni Subramaniam, Gaurav Singh, Ramakant Yadav, Aldo R. Valcarce, Samyaday Choudhury, Sharmila Rani, Deepthi S. Prabhu, Chul Chung, Patrick Côté, Nathan Leigh, Aaron M. Geller, Sourav Chatterjee, N. Kameswara Rao, Avrajit Bandyopadhyay, Michael Shara, Emanuele Dalessandro, Gajendra Pandey, Joesph E. Postma, John Hutchings, Mirko Simunovic, Peter B. Stetson, Sivarani Thirupathi, Thomas Puzia, Young-Jong Sohn Globular Clusters UVIT Legacy Survey (GlobULeS) I. FUV-optical Color-Magnitude Diagrams for Eight Globular Clusters We present the first results of eight Globular Clusters (GCs) from the\nAstroSat/UVIT Legacy Survey program GlobULeS based on the observations carried\nout in two FUV filters (F148W and F169M). The FUV-optical and FUV-FUV\ncolor-magnitude diagrams (CMDs) of GCs with the proper motion membership were\nconstructed by combining the UVIT data with HST UV Globular Cluster Survey\n(HUGS) data for inner regions and Gaia Early Data Release (EDR3) for regions\noutside the HST's field. We detect sources as faint as F148W $\sim$ 23.5~mag\nwhich are classified based on their locations in CMDs by overlaying stellar\nevolutionary models. The CMDs of 8 GCs are combined with the previous UVIT\nstudies of 3 GCs to create stacked FUV-optical CMDs to highlight the\nfeatures/peculiarities found in the different evolutionary sequences. The FUV\n(F148W) detected stellar populations of 11 GCs comprises 2,816 Horizontal\nBranch (HB) stars (190 Extreme HB candidates), 46 post-HB (pHB), 221 Blue\nStraggler Stars (BSS), and 107 White Dwarf (WD) candidates. We note that the\nblue HB color extension obtained from F148W$-$G color and the number of FUV\ndetected EHB candidates are strongly correlated with the maximum internal\nHelium (He) variation within each GC, suggesting that the FUV-optical plane is\nthe most sensitive to He abundance variations in the HB. We discuss the\npotential science cases that will be addressed using these catalogues including\nHB morphologies, BSSs, pHB, and, WD stars. Sahu_2022 Sahu et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2204.12886
130 2204.12551 2022-04-26 Henry W. Leung, Jo Bovy, J. Ted Mackereth, Jason A. S. Hunt, Richard R. Lane, John C. Wilson A direct measurement of the distance to the Galactic center using the kinematics of bar stars The distance to the Galactic center $R_0$ is a fundamental parameter for\nunderstanding the Milky Way, because all observations of our Galaxy are made\nfrom our heliocentric reference point. The uncertainty in $R_0$ limits our\nknowledge of many aspects of the Milky Way, including its total mass and the\nrelative mass of its major components, and any orbital parameters of stars\nemployed in chemo-dynamical analyses. While measurements of $R_0$ have been\nimproving over a century, measurements in the past few years from a variety of\nmethods still find a wide range of $R_0$ being somewhere within $8.0$ to\n$8.5\,\mathrm{kpc}$. The most precise measurements to date have to assume that\nSgr A$^*$ is at rest at the Galactic center, which may not be the case. In this\npaper, we use maps of the kinematics of stars in the Galactic bar derived from\nAPOGEE DR17 and Gaia EDR3 data augmented with spectro-photometric distances\nfrom the \texttt{astroNN} neural-network method. These maps clearly display the\nminimum in the rotational velocity $v_T$ and the quadrupolar signature in\nradial velocity $v_R$ expected for stars orbiting in a bar. From the minimum in\n$v_T$, we measure $R_0 = 8.23 \pm 0.12\,\mathrm{kpc}$. We validate our\nmeasurement using realistic $N$-body simulations of the Milky Way. We further\nmeasure the pattern speed of the bar to be $\Omega_\mathrm{bar} =\n40.08\pm1.78\,\mathrm{km\,s}^{-1}\mathrm{kpc}^{-1}$. Because the bar forms out\nof the disk, its center is manifestly the barycenter of the bar+disc system and\nour measurement is therefore the most robust and accurate measurement of $R_0$\nto date. Leung_2022 Leung et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2204.12551
131 2204.09702 2022-04-20 José G. Fernández-Trincado, Timothy C. Beers, Beatriz Barbuy, Dante Minniti, Cristina Chiappini, Elisa R. Garro, Baitian Tang, Alan Alves-Brito, Sandro Villanova, Doug Geisler, Richard R. Lane, Danilo G. Diaz Galactic ArchaeoLogIcaL ExcavatiOns (GALILEO) I. An updated census of APOGEE N-rich giants across the Milky Way (ABRIDGED) We use the 17th data release of the second phase of the Apache\nPoint Observatory Galactic Evolution Experiment (APOGEE-2) to provide a\nhomogenous census of N-rich red giant stars across the Milky Way (MW). We\nreport a total of 149 newly identified N-rich field giants toward the bulge,\nmetal-poor disk, and halo of our Galaxy. They exhibit significant enrichment in\ntheir nitrogen abundance ratios ([N/Fe] $\gtrsim+0.5$), along with simultaneous\ndepletions in their [C/Fe] abundance ratios ([C/Fe] $< +0.15$), and they cover\na wide range of metallicities ($-1.8 < $ [Fe/H] $ <-0.7$). The final sample of\ncandidate N-rich red giant stars with globular-cluster-like (GC-like) abundance\npatterns from the APOGEE survey includes a grand total of $\sim$ 412 unique\nobjects. These strongly N-enhanced stars are speculated to have been stripped\nfrom GCs based on their chemical similarities with these systems. Even though\nwe have not found any strong evidence for binary companions or signatures of\npulsating variability yet, we cannot rule out the possibility that some of\nthese objects were members of binary systems in the past and/or are currently\npart of a variable system. In particular, the fact that we identify such stars\namong the field stars in our Galaxy provides strong evidence that the\nnucleosynthetic process(es) producing the anomalous [N/Fe] abundance ratios\noccurs over a wide range of metallicities. This may provide evidence either for\nor against the uniqueness of the progenitor stars to GCs and/or the existence\nof chemical anomalies associated with likely tidally shredded clusters in\nmassive dwarf galaxies such as "Kraken/Koala," \textit{Gaia}-Enceladus-Sausage,\namong others, before or during their accretion by the MW. A dynamical analysis\nreveals that the newly identified N-rich stars exhibit a wide range of\ndynamical characteristics throughout the MW, ... Fernández-Trincado_2022 Fernández-Trincado et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2204.09702
132 2204.09058 2022-04-19 Khyati Malhan A new member of the Milky Way's family tree: Characterizing the Pontus merger of our Galaxy We study the $\textit{Pontus}$ structure -- a recently discovered merger that\nbrought in $\sim7$ globular clusters in the course of the hierarchical build-up\nof the Milky Way's halo. Here, we analyse the stellar population of\n$\textit{Pontus}$ and examine (1) its phase-space distribution using the\nESA/$\textit{Gaia}$ dataset, (2) its metallicity and chemical abundances (i.e.,\n[Fe/H], [$\alpha$/Fe], [Mg/Fe], [Al/Fe]) using the spectroscopic catalogue of\nAPOGEE DR17, and (3) the colour-magnitude diagram that shows interesting\nfeatures, including a possibly double horizontal branch and a small population\nof blue stragglers. In sum, the $\textit{Pontus}$ stars show some unique\nproperties that suggest they likely originated from the merging of an\nindependent satellite galaxy; future analysis will shed more light on the true\nnature of this structure. This chemo-dynamical analysis of $\textit{Pontus}$\nstars is another step forward in our bigger quest to characterize\n$\textit{all}$ the merging events of our Milky Way. Malhan_2022 Malhan 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2204.09058
133 2204.08481 2022-04-18 Ali Rostami Shirazi, Hosein Haghi, Pouria Khalaj, Ahmad Farhani Asl, Akram Hasani Zonoozi The Escape of Globular Clusters from the Satellite Dwarf Galaxies of the Milky Way Using numerical simulations, we have studied the escape of globular clusters\n(GCs) from the satellite dwarf spheroidal galaxies (dSphs) of the Milky Way\n(MW). We start by following the orbits of a large sample of GCs around dSphs in\nthe presence of the MW potential field. We then obtain the fraction of GCs\nleaving their host dSphs within a Hubble Time. We model dSphs by a Hernquist\ndensity profile with masses between $10^7\,\mathrm{M}_{\odot}$ and $7\times\n10^9\,\mathrm{M}_{\odot}$. All dSphs lie on the Galactic disc plane, but they\nhave different orbital eccentricities and apogalactic distances. We compute the\nescape fraction of GCs from 13 of the most massive dSphs of the MW, using their\nrealistic orbits around the MW (as determined by Gaia). The escape fraction of\nGCs from 13 dSphs is in the range $12\%$ to $93\%$. The average escape time of\nGCs from these dSphs was less than 8 $\,\mathrm{Gyrs}$, indicating that the\nescape process of GCs from dSphs was over. We then adopt a set of\nobservationally-constrained density profiles for specific case of the Fornax\ndSph. According to our results, the escape fraction of GCs shows a negative\ncorrelation with both the mass and the apogalactic distance of the dSphs, as\nwell as a positive correlation with the orbital eccentricity of dSphs. In\nparticular, we find that the escape fraction of GCs from the Fornax dSph is\nbetween $13\%$ and $38\%$. Finally, we observe that when GCs leave their host\ndSphs, their final orbit around the MW does not differ much from their host\ndSphs. Shirazi_2022 Shirazi et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2204.08481
134 2204.05868 2022-04-12 Brian T. Cook, Deborah F. Woods, Jessica D. Ruprecht, Jacob Varey, Radha Mastandrea, Kaylee de Soto, Jacob F. Harburg, Umaa Rebbapragada, Ashish A. Mahabal Tracing Milky Way substructure with an RR Lyrae hierarchical clustering forest RR Lyrae variable stars have long been reliable standard candles used to\ndiscern structure in the Local Group. With this in mind, we present a routine\nto identify groupings containing a statistically significant number of RR Lyrae\nvariables in the Milky Way environment. RR Lyrae variable groupings, or\nsubstructures, with potential Galactic archaeology applications are found using\na forest of agglomerative, hierarchical clustering trees, whose leaves are\nMilky Way RR Lyrae variables. Each grouping is validated by ensuring that the\ninternal RR Lyrae variable proper motions are sufficiently correlated.\nPhotometric information was collected from the Gaia second data release and\nproper motions from the (early) third data release. After applying this routine\nto the catalogue of 91234 variables, we are able to report sixteen unique RR\nLyrae substructures with physical sizes of less than 1 kpc. Five of these\nsubstructures are in close proximity to Milky Way globular clusters with\npreviously known tidal tails and/or a potential connection to Galactic merger\nevents. One candidate substructure is in the neighbourhood of the Large\nMagellanic Cloud but is more distant (and older) than known satellites of the\ndwarf galaxy. Our study ends with a discussion of ways in which future surveys\ncould be applied to the discovery of Milky Way stellar streams. Cook_2022 Cook et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2204.05868
135 2111.13707 2022-04-11 Axel Widmark, Chervin F. P. Laporte, Giacomo Monari Weighing the Galactic disk using phase-space spirals III. Probing distant regions of the disk using the Gaia EDR3 proper motion sample We have applied our method for weighing the Galactic disk using phase-space\nspirals to the Gaia EDR3 proper motion sample. For stars in distant regions of\nthe Galactic disk, the latitudinal proper motion has a close projection with\nvertical velocity, such that the phase-space spiral in the plane of vertical\nposition and vertical velocity can be observed without requiring that all stars\nhave available radial velocity information. We divided the Galactic plane into\n360 separate data samples, each corresponding to an area cell in the Galactic\nplane in the distance range of 1.4-3.4 kpc, with an approximate cell length of\n200-400 pc. Roughly half of our data samples were disqualified altogether due\nto severe selection effects, especially in the direction of the Galactic\ncentre. In the remainder, we were able to infer the vertical gravitational\npotential by fitting an analytic model of the phase-space spiral to the data.\nThis work is the first of its kind, in the sense that we are weighing distant\nregions of the Galactic disk with a high spatial resolution, without relying on\nthe strong assumptions of axisymmetry. Post-inference, we fit a thin disk scale\nlength of $2.2\pm 0.1$ kpc, although this value is sensitive to the considered\nspatial region. We see surface density variations as a function of azimuth on\nthe order of 10-20 %, which is roughly the size of our estimated sum of\npotential systematic biases. With this work, we have demonstrated that our\nmethod can be used to weigh distant regions of the Galactic disk despite strong\nselection effects. We expect to reach even greater distances and improve our\naccuracy with future Gaia data releases and further improvements to our method. Widmark_2022 Widmark et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.13707
136 2204.01953 2022-04-05 A. Arellano Ferro A vindication of the RR Lyrae Fourier light curve decomposition for the calculation of metallicity and distance in globular clusters We report the mean metallicity and absolute magnitude of RR Lyrae stars in a\nsample of 37 globular clusters, calculated via the Fourier decomposition of\ntheir light curves and ad hoc semiempirical calibrations, in an unprecedented\nhomogeneous approach. This enabled a new discussion of the metallicity\ndependence of the horizontal branch (HB) luminosity, as a fundamental distance\nindicator. The calibration for the RRab and RRc stars should be treated\nseparately. For the RRab the dispersion is larger and non-linear. For the RRc\nstars the correlation is less steep, very tight and linear. The relevance of\nthe HB structural parameter L, is highlighted and offer a non-linear\ncalibration of the form MV ([Fe/H],L). Excellent agreement is found between\nvalues of [Fe/H] and MV from the light curve decomposition with spectroscopic\nvalues and distances obtained via Gaia-DR3 and HST. The variable stars census\nin 35 clusters includes 326 stars found by our program. Ferro_2022 Ferro 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2204.01953
137 2204.01917 2022-04-05 Hannah Richstein, Ekta Patel, Nitya Kallivayalil, Joshua D. Simon, Paul Zivick, Erik Tollerud, Tobias Fritz, Jack T. Warfield, Gurtina Besla, Roeland P. van der Marel, Andrew Wetzel, Yumi Choi, Alis Deason, Marla Geha, Puragra Guhathakurta, Myoungwon Jeon, Evan N. Kirby, Mattia Libralato, Elena Sacchi, Sangmo Tony Sohn Structural parameters and possible association of the Ultra-Faint Dwarfs Pegasus III and Pisces II from deep Hubble Space Telescope photometry We present deep Hubble Space Telescope (HST) photometry of the ultra-faint\ndwarf (UFD) galaxies Pegasus III (Peg III) and Pisces II (Psc II), two of the\nmost distant satellites in the halo of the Milky Way (MW). We measure the\nstructure of both galaxies, derive mass-to-light ratios with newly determined\nabsolute magnitudes, and compare our findings to expectations from UFD-mass\nsimulations. For Peg III, we find an elliptical half-light radius of\n$a_h{{=}}1.88^{+0.42}_{-0.33}$ arcminutes ($118^{+31}_{-30}$ pc) and\n$M_V{=}{-4.17}^{+0.19}_{-0.22}$; for Psc II, we measure\n$a_h{=}1.31^{+0.10}_{-0.09}$ arcminutes ($69\pm8$ pc) and\n$M_V{=}{-4.28}^{+0.19}_{-0.16}$. We do not find any morphological features that\nindicate a significant interaction between the two has occurred, despite their\nclose separation of only $\sim$40 kpc. Using proper motions (PMs) from Gaia\nearly Data Release 3, we investigate the possibility of any past association by\nintegrating orbits for the two UFDs in a MW-only and a combined MW and Large\nMagellanic Cloud (LMC) potential. We find that including the gravitational\ninfluence of the LMC is crucial, even for these outer-halo satellites, and that\na possible orbital history exists where Peg III and Psc II experienced a close\n($\sim$10-20 kpc) passage about each other just over $\sim$1 Gyr ago, followed\nby a collective passage around the LMC ($\sim$30-60 kpc) just under $\sim$1 Gyr\nago. Considering the large uncertainties on the PMs and the restrictive priors\nimposed to derive them, improved PM measurements for Peg III and Psc II will be\nnecessary to clarify their relationship. This would add to the rare findings of\nconfirmed pairs of satellites within the Local Group. Richstein_2022 Richstein et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2204.01917
138 2111.01809 2022-04-04 Danny Horta, Melissa K. Ness, Jan Rybizki, Ricardo P. Schiavon, Sven Buder Neutron-capture elements record the ordered chemical evolution of the disc over time An ensemble of chemical abundances probing different nucleosynthetic channels\ncan be leveraged to build a comprehensive understanding of the chemical and\nstructural evolution of the Galaxy. Using GALAH DR3 data, we seek to trace the\nenrichment by the supernovae Ia, supernovae II, asymptotic giant branch stars,\nand neutron-star mergers and/or collapsars nucleosynthetic sources by studying\nthe [Fe/H], [$\alpha$/Fe], [Ba/Fe], and [Eu/Fe] chemical compositions of\n$\sim$50,000 red giant stars, respectively. Employing small\n[Fe/H]-[$\alpha$/Fe] cells, which serve as an effective reference-frame of\nsupernovae contributions, we characterise the abundance-age profiles for\n[Ba/Fe] and [Eu/Fe]. Our results disclose that these age-abundance relations\nvary across the [Fe/H]-[$\alpha$/Fe] plane. Within cells, we find negative\nage-[Ba/Fe] relations and flat age-[Eu/Fe] relations. Across cells, we see the\nslope of the age-[Ba/Fe] relations evolve smoothly and the [Eu/Fe] relations\nvary in amplitude. We subsequently model our empirical findings in a\ntheoretical setting using the flexible Chempy Galactic chemical evolution (GCE)\ncode, using the mean [Fe/H], [Mg/Fe], [Ba/Fe], and age values for stellar\npopulations binned in [Fe/H], [Mg/Fe], and age space. We find that within a\none-zone framework, an ensemble of GCE model parameters vary to explain the\ndata. Using present day orbits from \textit{Gaia} EDR3 measurements we infer\nthat the GCE model parameters, which set the observed chemical abundance\ndistributions, vary systematically across mean orbital radii. Under our\nmodelling assumptions, the observed chemical abundances are consistent with a\nsmall gradient in the high mass end of the initial mass function (IMF) across\nthe disc, where the IMF is more top heavy towards the inner disc and more\nbottom heavy in the outer disc. Horta_2022 Horta et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.01809
139 2203.17032 2022-03-31 F. Wang, H. -W. Zhang, X. -X. Xue, Y. Huang, G. -C. Liu, L. Zhang, C. -Q. Yang Probing the Galactic Halo with RR Lyrae Stars. II. The Substructures of the Milky Way We identify substructures of the Galactic halo using 3,003 type $ab$ RR\nLyraes (RRab) with 6D position-velocity information from the SDSS, LAMOST, and\nGaia EDR3. Based on the information, we define the separation of any two of the\nstars in the integrals of motion space and identify substructures by utilizing\nthe friends-of-friends algorithm. We identify members belonging to several\nknown substructures: the Sagittarius stream, the Gaia-Enceladus-Sausage (GES),\nthe Sequoia, and the Helmi streams. In addition to these known substructures,\nthere are three other substructures possibly associated with globular clusters\nNGC 5272, NGC 6656, and NGC 5024, respectively. Finally, we also find three\nremaining unknown substructures and one of them has large angular momentum and\na mean metallicity $\rm -2.13\,dex$ which may be a new substructure. As for\nGES, we find that it accounts for a large part of substructures in the inner\nhalo and the range of apocenter distance is from 10 to $34\,\rm kpc$, which\nsuggests that the GES is mainly distributed in the inner halo. The near\none-third proportion of the GES and the peak value $20\,\rm kpc$ of the\napocenter distances suggest that GES could account for the break in the density\nprofile of the Galactic halo at Galactocentric distance ${\sim}20-25\,\rm kpc$.\nThe similarity of comparing the kinematic properties of Gaia-Enceladus-Sausage\nwith the Hercules-Aquila Cloud and Virgo Overdensity suggests that the three\nsubstructures may have similar origins. Wang_2022 Wang et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2203.17032
140 2011.02783 2022-03-29 Govind Nandakumar, Michael R. Hayden, Sanjib Sharma, Sven Buder, Martin Asplund, Joss Bland-Hawthorn, Gayandhi M. De Silva, Valentina D'Orazi, Ken C. Freeman, Janez Kos, Geraint F. Lewis, Sarah L. Martell, Katharine J. Schlesinger, Jane Lin, Jeffrey D. Simpson, Daniel B. Zucker, Tomaz Zwitter, Thomas Nordlander, Luca Casagrande, Karin Lind, Klemen Cotar, Dennis Stello, Robert A. Wittenmyer, Thor Tepper-Garcia Combined APOGEE-GALAH stellar catalogues using the Cannon APOGEE and GALAH are two high resolution multi-object spectroscopic surveys\nthat provide fundamental stellar parameters and multiple elemental abundance\nestimates for about half a million stars in the Milky Way. Both surveys observe\nin different wavelength regimes and use different data reduction pipelines\nleading to significant offsets and trends in stellar parameters and abundances\nfor the common stars observed in both surveys. Such systematic\ndifferences/offsets in stellar parameters and abundances make it difficult to\neffectively utilise them to investigate Galactic abundance trends in spite of\nthe unique advantage provided by their complementary sky coverage and different\nMilky Way components they observe. Hence, we use the \textit{Cannon}\ndata-driven method selecting a training set of 4418 common stars observed by\nboth surveys. This enables the construction of two catalogues, one with the\nAPOGEE scaled and the other with the GALAH scaled stellar parameters. Using\nrepeat observations in APOGEE and GALAH, we find high precision in metallicity\n(~ 0.02-0.4 dex) and alpha abundances (~ 0.02-0.03 dex) for spectra with good\nsignal-to-noise ratio (SNR > 80 for APOGEE, SNR > 40 for GALAH). We use open\nand globular clusters to validate our parameter estimates and find small\nscatter in metallicity (0.06 dex) and alpha abundances (0.03 dex) in APOGEE\nscaled case. The final catalogues have been cross matched with the Gaia EDR3\ncatalogue to enable their use to carry out detailed chemo-dynamic studies of\nthe Milky Way from perspectives of APOGEE and GALAH. Nandakumar_2022 Nandakumar et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2011.02783
141 2203.14991 2022-03-28 L. Spina, L. Magrini, G. G. Sacco, G. Casali, A. Vallenari, G. Tautvaisienė, F. Jiménez-Esteban, G. Gilmore, S. Randich, S. Feltzing, R. D. Jeffries, T. Bensby, A. Bragaglia, R. Smiljanic, G. Carraro, L. Morbidelli, S. Zaggia The Gaia-ESO Survey: Chemical tagging in the thin disk. Open clusters blindly recovered in the elemental abundance space The chemical makeup of a star provides the fossil information of the\nenvironment where it formed. Under this premise, it should be possible to use\nchemical abundances to tag stars that formed within the same stellar\nassociation. This idea - known as chemical tagging - has not produced the\nexpected results, especially within the thin disk where open stellar clusters\nhave chemical patterns that are difficult to disentangle. The ultimate goal of\nthis study is to probe the feasibility of chemical tagging within the thin disk\npopulation using high-quality data from a controlled sample of stars. We also\naim at improving the existing techniques of chemical tagging and giving\nguidance on different strategies of clustering analysis in the elemental\nabundance space. Here we develop the first blind search of open clusters'\nmembers through clustering analysis in the elemental abundance space using the\nOPTICS algorithm applied to data from the Gaia-ESO survey. First, we evaluate\ndifferent strategies of analysis, determining which ones are more performing.\nSecond, we apply these methods to a data set including both field stars and\nopen clusters attempting a blind recover of as many open clusters as possible.\nWe show how specific strategies of data analysis can improve the final results.\nSpecifically, we demonstrate that open clusters can be more efficaciously\nrecovered with the Manhattan metric and on a space whose dimensions are\ncarefully selected. Using these (and other) prescriptions we are able to\nrecover open clusters hidden in our data set and find new members of these\nstellar associations. Our results indicate that there are chances of recovering\nopen clusters' members via clustering analysis in the elemental abundance\nspace. Presumably, the performances of chemical tagging will further increase\nwith higher quality data and more sophisticated clustering algorithms. Spina_2022 Spina et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2203.14991
142 2203.13414 2022-03-25 Yong Yang, Jing-Kun Zhao, Miho N. Ishigaki, Jian-Zhao Zhou, Cheng-Qun Yang, Xiang-Xiang Xue, Xian-Hao Ye, Gang Zhao Revisit NGC 5466 Tidal Stream with $Gaia$, SDSS/SEGUE and LAMOST By mining the data from $Gaia$ EDR3, SDSS/SEGUE DR16 and LAMOST DR8, 11\nmember stars of the NGC 5466 tidal stream are detected and 7 of them are newly\nidentified. To reject contaminators, a variety of cuts are applied in sky\nposition, color-magnitude diagram, metallicity, proper motion and radial\nvelocity. We compare our data to a mock stream generated by modeling the\ncluster's disruption under a smooth Galactic potential plus the Large\nMagellanic Cloud (LMC). The concordant trends in phase-space between the model\nand observations imply that the stream might have been perturbed by LMC. The\ntwo most distant stars among 11 detected members trace the stream's length to\n$60^\circ$ of sky, supporting and extending the previous length of $45^\circ$.\nGiven that NGC 5466 is so distant and potentially has a longer tail than\npreviously thought, we expect that NGC 5466 tidal stream could be a useful tool\nin constraining the Milky Way gravitational field. Yang_2022 Yang et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2203.13414
143 2203.11808 2022-03-22 Tadafumi Matsuno, Emma Dodd, Helmer H. Koppelman, Amina Helmi, Miho N. Ishigaki, Wako Aoki, Jingkun Zhao, Zhen Yuan, Kohei Hattori High-precision chemical abundances of Galactic building blocks. II. Revisiting the chemical distinctness of the Helmi streams Context: The Helmi streams are kinematic substructures whose progenitor is\nlikely a dwarf galaxy. Although 20 years have past since their discovery, it is\nstill unclear whether their members are chemically distinguishable from other\nhalo stars in the Milky Way. Aim: We aim to precisely characterize the chemical\nproperties of the Helmi streams. Methods: We analysed high-resolution,\nhigh-signal-to-noise ratio spectra for eleven Helmi streams' stars through a\nline-by-line abundance analysis. We compared the derived abundances to\nhomogenized literature abundances of the other halo stars, including those\nbelonging to other kinematic substructures, such as Gaia-Enceladus and Sequoia.\nResults: Compared to typical halo stars, the Helmi streams' members clearly\nshow low values of [X/Fe] in elements produced by massive stars, such as Na and\n$\alpha$-elements. This tendency is seen down to metallicities of at least\n$[\mathrm{Fe/H}]\sim -2.2$, suggesting type~Ia supernovae already started to\ncontribute to the chemical evolution at this metallicity. We found that the\n[$\alpha$/Fe] ratio does not evolve much with metallicity, making the Helmi\nstreams' stars less distinguishable from Gaia-Enceladus stars at\n$[\mathrm{Fe/H}]\gtrsim -1.5$. The almost constant but low value of\n[$\alpha$/Fe] might be indicative of quiescent star formation with low\nefficiency at the beginning and bursty star formation at later times. We also\nfound extremely low values of [Y/Fe] at low metallicity, providing further\nsupport that light neutron capture-elements are deficient in Helmi streams.\nWhile Zn is deficient at low metallicity, it shows a large spread at high\nmetallicity. The origin of the extremely low Y abundances and Zn variations\nremain unclear. Conclusion: The Helmi streams' stars are distinguishable from\nthe majority of the halo stars if homogeneously derived abundances are\ncompared. Matsuno_2022 Matsuno et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2203.11808
144 2203.11843 2022-03-22 Heinz Frelijj, Douglas geisler, Sandro Villanova, Cesar Munoz C,T1,T2: A complementary method to detect Multiple Populations with the Washington filter system In this research we test the ability of a three Washington filter\ncombination, (C-T1)-(T1-T2), compared with that of the traditional C-T1 color\nto find multiple populations on two globular clusters: NGC 7099 and NGC 1851,\ntypes I and II Globular clusters, respectively. Our improved photometry and\nmembership selection, now using Gaia proper motions, finds that the second\npopulation stars are more centrally concentrated than first population stars,\nas expected and contrary to our previous findings for NGC 7099. We find that\nmultiple populations are more easily detected in both clusters using the new\n(C-T1)-(T1-T2) color, although C-T1 conserves the best width/error ratio. We\nalso search for differences of both colors while splitting the red-RGB and the\nblue-RGB in NGC 1851, but no significant improvement was found. Frelijj_2022 Frelijj et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2203.11843
145 2111.08737 2022-03-17 Yuewen Qi, Paul Zivick, Andrew B. Pace, Alexander H. Riley, Louis E. Strigari Stellar proper motions in the outskirts of classical dwarf spheroidal galaxies with Gaia EDR3 We use Gaia EDR3 data to identify stars associated with six classical dwarf\nspheroidals (Draco, Ursa Minor, Sextans, Sculptor, Fornax, Carina) at their\noutermost radii, beyond their nominal King stellar limiting radius. For all of\nthe dSphs examined, we find radial velocity matches with stars residing beyond\nthe King limiting radius and with $> 50\%$ astrometric probability (four in\nDraco, two in Ursa Minor, eight in Sextans, two in Sculptor, twelve in Fornax,\nand five in Carina), indicating that these stars are associated with their\nrespective dwarf spheroidals (dSphs) at high probability.
