We compare the\npositions of our candidate "extra-tidal" stars with the orbital tracks of the\ngalaxies, and identify stars, both with and without radial velocity matches,\nthat are consistent with lying along the orbital track of the satellites.\nHowever, given the small number of candidate stars, we cannot make any\nconclusive statements about the significance of these spatially correlated\nstars. Cross matching with publicly available catalogs of RR Lyrae, we find one\nRR Lyrae candidate with $> 50\%$ astrometric probability outside the limiting\nradius in each of Sculptor and Fornax, two such candidates in Draco, nine in\nUrsa Minor, seven in Sextans, and zero in Carina. Follow-up spectra on all of\nour candidates, including possible metallicity information, will help confirm\nassociation with their respective dSphs, and could represent evidence for\nextended stellar halos or tidal debris around these classical dSphs. Qi_2022 Qi et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.08737
146 2111.09072 2022-03-15 Shumeng Zhang, Dougal Mackey, Gary Da Costa A search for stellar structures around nine outer halo globular clusters in the Milky Way We use deep imaging from the Dark Energy Camera to explore the peripheral\nregions of nine globular clusters in the outer halo of the Milky Way. Apart\nfrom Whiting 1 and NGC 7492, which are projected against the Sagittarius\nstream, we see no evidence for adjacent stellar populations to indicate any of\nthese clusters is associated with coherent tidal debris from a destroyed host\ndwarf. We also find no evidence for tidal tails around any of the clusters in\nour sample; however, both NGC 1904 and 6981 appear to possess outer envelopes.\nMotivated by a slew of recent Gaia-based discoveries, we compile a sample of\nclusters with robust detections of extra-tidal structure, and search for\ncorrelations with orbital properties. While we observe that clusters with tidal\ntails are typically on moderately or very eccentric orbits that are highly\ninclined to the Galactic plane and often retrograde, these are neither\nnecessary nor sufficient conditions for the formation of extra-tidal structure.\nThat many objects with tidal tails appear to be accreted leads us to speculate\nthat this lack of consistency may stem from the inhomogeneous dynamical history\nof the Milky Way globular cluster system. Finally, we note that clusters with\nprominent stellar envelopes detected in ground-based imaging (such as NGC 1851\nand 7089) are now all known from Gaia to possess long tidal tails --\nexperimental confirmation that the presence of an extended envelope is\nindicative of tidal erosion. Zhang_2022 Zhang et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.09072
147 2203.07435 2022-03-14 A. Garofalo, H. E. Delgado, L. M. Sarro, G. Clementini, T. Muraveva, M. Marconi, V. Ripepi New LZ and PW(Z) relations of RR Lyrae stars calibrated with Gaia EDR3 parallaxes We present new luminosity-metallicity (LZ; MV-[Fe/H] and MG-[Fe/H]) relations\nand, for the first time, empirical, Gaia three-band (G,GBP,GRP)\nperiod-Wesenheit-metallicity (PWZ) relations of RR Lyrae stars (RRLs) derived\nusing a hierarchical Bayesian approach and new accurate parallaxes published\nfor these variables in the Gaia Early Data Release 3 (EDR3). In a previous\nstudy we obtained Bayesian hierarchically-derived LZ relations from a sample of\nabout four hundred Milky Way field RRLs with G-band light curves and\ntrigonometric parallaxes published in the Gaia Data Release 2 (DR2), using V\nmean magnitudes, metallicities, absorptions and pulsation periods available in\nthe literature. We now extend that study in two directions. Firstly, we update\nour previous results using trigonometric parallaxes from Gaia EDR3 and\nincorporate the Bayesian analysis of a first empirical PWZ relation derived\nusing those field RRLs with G, GBP and GRP time-series photometry available in\nGaia DR2. Secondly, we use Bayesian inference to derive LZ relations and\nempirical PW Gaia three-band relations from 385 RRLs belonging to 15 Milky Way\nglobular clusters (GC) with literature-compiled spectroscopic metallicities\nranging from -0.36 to -2.39 dex and prior distances extending from 2.2 to 41.2\nkpc. From the samples of RRLs analysed in this paper we infer a mean Gaia EDR3\nzero-point offset of -0.028 mas with median values ranging from -0.033 (LZ and\nPWZ models for field stars) to -0.024 mas (LZ model in the V-band for GC RRLs). Garofalo_2022 Garofalo et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2203.07435
148 2109.04696 2022-03-13 Luis Martinez-Medina, Angeles Pérez-Villegas, Antonio Peimbert Kinematic footprint of the Milky Way spiral arms in Gaia EDR3 The Milky Way spiral arms are well established from star counts as well as\nfrom the locus of molecular clouds and other young objects, however, they have\nonly recently started to be observed from a kinematics point of view. Using the\nkinematics of thin disc stars in Gaia EDR3 around the extended solar\nneighbourhood, we create x-y projections coloured by the radial, residual\nrotational, and vertical Galactocentric velocities ($U,\Delta V,W$). The maps\nare rich in substructures and reveal the perturbed state of the Galactic disc.\nWe find that local differences between rotational velocity and the azimuthally\naveraged velocity, $\Delta V$, display at least five large-scale kinematic\nspirals; two of them closely follow the locus of the Sagittarius-Carina and\nPerseus spiral arms, with pitch angles of 9.12$^{\circ}$ and 7.76$^{\circ}$,\nand vertical thickness of $\sim400$ pc and $\sim600$ pc, respectively. Another\nkinematic spiral is located behind the Perseus arm and appears as a distortion\nin rotation velocities left by this massive arm but with no known counterpart\nin gas/stars overdensity. A weaker signal close to the Sun's position is\npresent in our three velocity maps, and appears to be associated with the Local\narm. Our analysis of the stellar velocities in the Galactic disc shows\nkinematic differences between arms and inter-arms, that are in favour of Milky\nWay spiral arms that do not corotate with the disc. Moreover, we show that the\nkinematic spirals are clumpy and flocculent, revealing the underlying nature of\nthe Milky Way spiral arms. Martinez-Medina_2022 Martinez-Medina et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2109.04696
149 2203.05658 2022-03-10 Sergio B. Fajardo-Acosta, Andreas Faisst, Carl J. Grillmair, Ranga-Ram Chary, Roberta Paladini, Ben Rusholme, Nathaniel Stickley Joint Survey Processing II: Stellar Proper Motions in the COSMOS Field, from Hubble Space Telescope ACS and Subaru Telescope HSC Observations We analyze stellar proper motions in the COSMOS field to assess the presence\nof bulk motions. At bright magnitudes (G-band 18.5--20.76 AB), we use the\nproper motions of 1,010 stars in the Gaia DR2 catalog. At the faint end, we\ncomputed proper motions of 11,519 point-like objects at i-band magnitudes\n19--25 AB using Hubble ACS and Subaru HSC, which span two epochs about 11 years\napart. In order to measure these proper motions with unprecedented accuracy at\nfaint magnitudes, we developed a foundational set of astrometric tools which\nwill be required for Joint Survey Processing (JSP) of data from the next\ngeneration of optical/infrared surveys. The astrometric grids of Hubble ACS and\nSubaru HSC mosaics were corrected at the catalog level, using proper\nmotion-propagated and parallax-corrected Gaia DR2 sources. These astrometric\ncorrections were verified using compact extragalactic sources. Upon comparison\nof our measured proper motions with Gaia DR2, we estimate the uncertainties in\nour measurements to be ~2--3 mas/yr per axis, down to 25.5 AB mag. We corrected\nproper motions for the mean motion of the Sun, and we find that late-type\nmain-sequence stars predominantly in the thin disk in the COSMOS field have\nspace velocities mainly towards the Galactic center. We detect candidate\nhigh-velocity (> 220 km/s) stars, 6 of them at ~0.4-6 kpc from the Gaia sample,\nand 5 of them at ~20 kpc from the faint star HSC and ACS sample. The sources\nfrom the faint star sample may be candidate halo members of the Sangarius\nstream. Fajardo-Acosta_2022 Fajardo-Acosta et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2203.05658
150 2203.04425 2022-03-08 Carl J. Grillmair The Extended Tidal Tails of NGC 7089 (M2) Using photometry and proper motions from Gaia Early Data Release 3, we detect\na 45 degree-long trailing stellar debris stream associated with the old,\nmetal-poor globular cluster NGC 7089. With a width on the order of 100 pc, the\nextended stream appears to be as dynamically cold as the coldest known streams\nfound to date. There is some evidence for an extended leading tail extending\nbetween 28 and 37 degrees from the cluster, though the greater distance of this\ntail, combined with proper motions that are virtually indistinguishable from\nthose of foreground stars, make the detection much less certain. The proper\nmotion profile and the path on the sky of the trailing tail are not well\nmatched using a simple Galactic potential comprised purely of a disk, bulge,\nand spherical halo. However, the addition of a moving, massive (M = 1.88 x\n10^(11) solar masses) Large Magellanic Cloud brings the model predictions into\nmuch better agreement with the observables. We provide tables of the most\nhighly ranked candidate stream stars for follow-up by ongoing and future\nspectroscopic surveys. Grillmair_2022 Grillmair 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2203.04425
151 2111.01788 2022-03-07 Hsiang-Chih Hwang, Yuan-Sen Ting, Charlie Conroy, Nadia L. Zakamska, Kareem El-Badry, Phillip Cargile, Dennis Zaritsky, Vedant Chandra, Jiwon Jesse Han, Joshua S. Speagle, Ana Bonaca Wide binaries from the H3 survey: the thick disk and halo have similar wide binary fractions Due to the different environments in the Milky Way's disk and halo, comparing\nwide binaries in the disk and halo is key to understanding wide binary\nformation and evolution. By using Gaia Early Data Release 3, we search for\nresolved wide binary companions in the H3 survey, a spectroscopic survey that\nhas compiled $\sim$150,000 spectra for thick-disk and halo stars to date. We\nidentify 800 high-confidence (a contamination rate of 4%) wide binaries and two\nresolved triples, with binary separations mostly between $10^3$-$10^5$ AU and a\nlowest [Fe/H] of $-2.7$. Based on their Galactic kinematics, 33 of them are\nhalo wide binaries, and most of those are associated with the accreted\nGaia-Sausage-Enceladus galaxy. The wide binary fraction in the thick disk\ndecreases toward the low metallicity end, consistent with the previous findings\nfor the thin disk. Our key finding is that the halo wide binary fraction is\nconsistent with the thick-disk stars at a fixed [Fe/H]. There is no significant\ndependence of the wide binary fraction on the $\alpha$-captured abundance.\nTherefore, the wide binary fraction is mainly determined by the iron abundance,\nnot their disk or halo origin nor the $\alpha$-captured abundance. Our results\nsuggest that the formation environments play a major role for the wide binary\nfraction, instead of other processes like radial migration that only apply to\ndisk stars. Hwang_2022 Hwang et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.01788
152 2203.03741 2022-03-07 Tigran Khachaturyants, Leandro Beraldo e Silva, Victor P. Debattista, Kathryne J. Daniel Bending waves excited by irregular gas inflow along warps Gaia has revealed clear evidence of bending waves in the vertical kinematics\nof stars in the Solar Neighbourhood. We study bending waves in two simulations,\none warped, with the warp due to misaligned gas inflow, and the other unwarped.\nWe find slow, retrograde bending waves in both models, with the ones in the\nwarped model having larger amplitudes. We also find fast, prograde bending\nwaves. Prograde bending waves in the unwarped model are very weak, in agreement\nwith the expectation that these waves should decay on short, ~ crossing,\ntimescales, due to strong winding. However, prograde bending waves are much\nstronger for the duration of the warped model, pointing to irregular gas inflow\nalong the warp as a continuous source of excitation. We demonstrate that large\namplitude bending waves that propagate through the Solar Neighbourhood give\nrise to a correlation between the mean vertical velocity and the angular\nmomentum, with a slope consistent with that found by Gaia. The bending waves\naffect populations of all ages, but the sharpest features are found in the\nyoung populations, hinting that short wavelength waves are not supported by the\nolder, kinematically hotter, populations. Our results demonstrate the\nimportance of misaligned gas accretion as a recurrent source of vertical\nperturbations of disc galaxies, including in the Milky Way. Khachaturyants_2022 Khachaturyants et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2203.03741
153 2203.01627 2022-03-03 R. Lallement, J. -L. Vergely, C. Babusiaux, N. L. J. Cox Updated Gaia-2MASS 3D maps of Galactic interstellar dust Three-dimensional (3D) maps of Galactic interstellar dust are a tool for a\nwide range of uses. We aim to construct 3D maps of dust extinction in the Local\nArm and surrounding regions. Gaia EDR3 photometric data were combined with\n2MASS measurements to derive extinction towards stars with accurate photometry\nand relative uncertainties on parallaxes of less than 20%. We applied our\nhierarchical inversion algorithm adapted to inhomogeneous spatial distributions\nof target stars to this catalogue of extinctions. We present the updated 3D\ndust extinction distribution and provide an estimate of the error on integrated\nextinctions from the Sun to each area in the 3D map. The computational area is\nsimilar to the one of the previous DR2 map, a 6 kpc x 6 kpc x 0.8\nkpcAstrophysics volume around the Sun. Due to the addition of fainter target\nstars, the volume in which the clouds can be reconstructed has increased. Due\nto the improved accuracy of the parallaxes and photometric data in EDR3,\nextinctions among neighbouring targets are more consistent, allowing one to\nreach an increased contrast in the dense areas, while cavity contours are more\nregular. We show several comparisons with recent results on dust and star\ndistributions. The wavy pattern around the Plane of the dust concentrations is\nbetter seen and exists over large regions. Its mean vertical peak-to-peak\namplitude is of the order of 300 pc; interestingly, it is similar to the\nvertical period of the spectacular snail-shaped stellar kinematical pattern\ndiscovered in Gaia data. The Gaia EDR3 catalogue allows for a significant\nimprovement of the extinction maps to be made and the hierarchical technique\nconfirms its efficiency for massive datasets. Future comparisons between 3D\nmaps of interstellar matter and stellar distributions may help to understand\nwhich mergers or internal perturbations have shaped the Galaxy within the first\n3 kpc. Lallement_2022 Lallement et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2203.01627
154 2111.01819 2022-03-02 A. Castro-Ginard, C. Jordi, X. Luri, T. Cantat-Gaudin, J. M. Carrasco, L. Casamiquela, F. Anders, L. Balaguer-Núñez, R. M. Badia Hunting for open clusters in Gaia EDR3: $628$ new open clusters found with OCfinder The improvements in the precision of the published data in \textit{Gaia} EDR3\nwith respect to \textit{Gaia} DR2, particularly for parallaxes and proper\nmotions, offer the opportunity to increase the number of known open clusters in\nthe Milky Way by detecting farther and fainter objects that have so far go\nunnoticed. Our aim is to keep completing the open cluster census in the Milky\nWay with the detection of new stellar groups in the Galactic disc. We use\n\textit{Gaia} EDR3 up to magnitude $G = 18$ mag, increasing in one unit the\nmagnitude limit and therefore the search volume explored in our previous\nstudies. We use the \texttt{OCfinder} method to search for new open clusters in\n\textit{Gaia} EDR3 using a Big Data environment. As a first step,\n\texttt{OCfinder} identifies stellar statistical overdensities in the five\ndimensional astrometric space (position, parallax and proper motions) using the\n\texttt{DBSCAN} clustering algorithm. Then, these overdensities are classified\ninto random statistical overdensities or real physical open clusters using a\ndeep artificial neural network trained on well-characterised $G$, $G_{\rm BP} -\nG_{\rm RP}$ colour-magnitude diagrams. We report the discovery of $664$ new\nopen clusters within the Galactic disc, most of them located beyond $1$ kpc\nfrom the Sun. From the estimation of ages, distances and line-of-sight\nextinctions of these open clusters, we see that young clusters align following\nthe Galactic spiral arms while older ones are dispersed in the Galactic disc.\nFurthermore, we find that most open clusters are located at low Galactic\naltitudes with the exception of a few groups older than $1$ Gyr. We show the\nsuccess of the \texttt{OCfinder} method leading to the discovery of a total of\n$1\,310$ open clusters (joining the discoveries here with the previous ones\nbased on \textit{Gaia} DR2)[abridged] Castro-Ginard_2022 Castro-Ginard et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.01819
155 2203.00786 2022-03-01 Andrea Mejías, Dante Minniti, Javier Alonso-García, Juan Carlos Beamín, Roberto K. Saito, Enrique Solano VVVX near-IR photometry for 99 low-mass stars in the Gaia EDR3 Catalog of Nearby Stars Red dwarf stars, which represent 75% of stars in the Milky Way, can be\nstudied in great detail in the solar neighborhood where the sample is more\ncomplete. We intend to better characterize red dwarf candidates selected from\nthe Gaia Catalog of Nearby Stars using optical and near-infrared photometry\nfrom the VVVX Survey, DECaPS, Pan-STARRS, and WISE. We performed a\ncross-matching procedure among the positions of a color-selected sample of M\ndwarfs in the VVVX Survey and the Gaia EDR3 sub-catalog of nearby stars. We\nexplored their stellar parameters and spectral types using VOSA. Radii were\nalso obtained using the Stefan-Boltzmann equation. Masses and ages were\ncomputed for some of the objects using evolutionary tracks and isochrones.\nAdditional mass estimations were obtained with the MKs - M* relation. We then\nvalidated our results for the stellar parameters of two of our objects with\nspectra obtained with the TripleSpec instrument at the SOAR telescope, as well\nas those of our total amount of stars through a direct comparison with an\nindependent sample from the literature. We revised the objects in our sample\nand compared their proper motion vectors with other sources within 30" to\nidentify possible companions and probed their RUWE values to identify\nunresolved companions. We present a catalog of physical parameters for 99\nlow-mass objects with distances from 43.2 to 111.3 pc. Teffs range from 2500 to\n3400 K, with the majority of stars in the sample compatible with being M4\ndwarfs. We obtained a good agreement between the stellar parameters computed\nwith VOSA and the estimations from observed spectra, also when comparing with\nan independent sample from the literature. The distribution of masses obtained\nwith VOSA is concentrated toward the very low-mass regime. Eight objects\npresent values of RUWE >= 1.4 and seven are consistent with being part of a\nbinary system. Mejías_2022 Mejías et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2203.00786
156 2202.12517 2022-02-25 Guozhen Hu, Zhengyi Shao Quantifying chemical and kinematical properties of Galactic disks We aim to quantify the chemical and kinematical properties of the Galactic\ndisks with a sample of 119,558 giant stars having abundances and 3D velocities\ntaken or derived from the APOGEE DR17 and Gaia EDR3 catalogs. The Gaussian\nMixture Model is employed to distinguish the high-$\alpha$ and low-$\alpha$\nsequences along the metallicity by simutaneously using the chemical and\nkinematical data. Four disk components are identified and quantified that named\nas h$\alpha$mp, h$\alpha$mr, l$\alpha$mp, and l$\alpha$mr disks, which\ncorrespond to the features of high-$\alpha$ or low-$\alpha$, and metal-poor or\nmetal-rich. Combined with the spatial and stellar age information, we confirm\nthat they are well interpreted in the two-infall formation model. The first\ninfall of turbulent gas quickly forms the hot and thick h$\alpha$mp disk with\nconsequent thinner h$\alpha$mr and l$\alpha$mr disks. Then the second gas\naccretion forms a thinner and outermost l$\alpha$mp disk. We find that the\ninside-out and upside-down scenario does not only satisfy the overall Galactic\ndisk formation of these two major episodes, but also presents in the formation\nsequence of three inner disks. Importantly, we reveal the inverse Age-[M/H]\ntrend of the l$\alpha$mr disk, which means its younger stars are more\nmetal-poor, indicating that the rejuvenate gas from the second accretion\ngradually dominates the later star formation. Meanwhile, the recently formed\nstars convergence to [M/H]$\sim$-0.1 dex, demonstrating a sufficiently mixture\nof gas from two infalls. Hu_2022 Hu and Shao 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2202.12517
157 2112.04318 2022-02-24 Devika Kamath, Hans Van Winckel, Paolo Ventura, Maksym Mohorian, Bruce Hrivnak, Flavia Dell'Agli, Amanda Karakas Luminosities and masses of single Galactic Post-Asymptotic Giant Branch (Post-AGB) stars with distances from $Gaia$ EDR3: The revelation of an $s$-process diversity Post-AGB stars are exquisite probes of AGB nucleosynthesis. However, the\nprevious lack of accurate distances jeopardised comparison with theoretical AGB\nmodels. The $Gaia$ Early Data Release 3 ($Gaia$ EDR3) has now allowed for a\nbreakthrough in this research landscape. In this study, we focus on a sample of\nsingle Galactic post-AGBs for which chemical abundance studies were completed.\nWe combined photometry with geometric distances to carry out a spectral energy\ndistribution (SED) analysis and derive accurate luminosities. We subsequently\ndetermined their positions on the HR-diagram and compared this with theoretical\npost-AGB evolutionary tracks. While most objects are in the post-AGB phase of\nevolution, we found a subset of low-luminosity objects that are likely to be in\nthe post-horizontal branch phase of evolution, similar to AGB-manqu\'e objects\nfound in globular clusters. Additionally, we also investigated the observed\nbi-modality in the $s$-process enrichment of Galactic post-AGB single stars of\nsimilar Teff, and metallicities. This bi-modality was expected to be a direct\nconsequence of luminosity with the $s$-process rich objects having evolved\nfurther on the AGB. However, we find that the two populations: the $s$-process\nenriched and non-enriched, have similar luminosities (and hence initial\nmasses), revealing an intriguing chemical diversity. For a given initial mass\nand metallicity, AGB nucleosynthesis appears inhomogeneous and sensitive to\nother factors which could be mass-loss, along with convective and\nnon-convective mixing mechanisms. Modelling individual objects in detail will\nbe needed to investigate which parameters and processes dominate the\nphotospheric chemical enrichment in these stars. Kamath_2022 Kamath et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.04318
158 2110.00018 2022-02-24 Lilia Correa Magnus, Eugene Vasiliev Measuring the Milky Way mass distribution in the presence of the LMC The ongoing interaction between the Milky Way (MW) and its largest satellite\n- the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) - creates a significant perturbation in the\ndistribution and kinematics of distant halo stars, globular clusters and\nsatellite galaxies, and leads to biases in MW mass estimates from these tracer\npopulations. We present a method for compensating these perturbations for any\nchoice of MW potential by computing the past trajectory of LMC and MW and then\nintegrating the orbits of tracer objects back in time until the influence of\nthe LMC is negligible, at which point the equilibrium approximation can be used\nwith any standard dynamical modelling approach. We add this orbit-rewinding\nstep to the mass estimation approach based on simultaneous fitting of the\npotential and the distribution function of tracers, and apply it to two\ndatasets with the latest Gaia EDR3 measurements of 6d phase-space coordinates:\nglobular clusters and satellite galaxies. We find that models with LMC mass in\nthe range (1-2)x10^11 Msun better fit the observed distribution of tracers, and\nmeasure MW mass within 100 kpc to be (0.75+-0.1)x10^12 Msun, while neglecting\nthe LMC perturbation increases it by ~15%. Magnus_2022 Magnus and Vasiliev 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2110.00018
159 2202.10416 2022-02-21 Andreia Carrillo, Keith Hawkins, Paula Jofré, Danielle de Brito Silva, Payel Das, Madeline Lucey The detailed chemical abundance patterns of accreted halo stars from the optical to infrared Understanding the assembly of our Galaxy requires us to also characterize the\nsystems that helped build it. In this work, we accomplish this by exploring the\nchemistry of accreted halo stars from the Gaia-Enceladus/Gaia-Sausage (GES)\nselected in the infrared from the Apache Point Observatory Galactic Evolution\nExperiment (APOGEE) Data Release 16. We use high resolution optical spectra for\n62 GES stars to measure abundances in 20 elements spanning the $\alpha$,\nFe-peak, light, odd-Z, and notably, the neutron-capture groups of elements to\nunderstand their trends in the context of and in contrast to the Milky Way and\nother stellar populations. Using these derived abundances we find that the\noptical and the infrared abundances agree to within 0.15 dex except for O, Co,\nNa, Cu, and Ce. These stars have enhanced neutron-capture abundance trends\ncompared to the Milky Way, and their [Eu/Mg] and neutron-capture abundance\nratios (e.g., [Y/Eu], [Ba/Eu], [Zr/Ba], [La/Ba], and [Nd/Ba]) point to\nr-process enhancement and a delay in s-process enrichment. Their [$\alpha$/Fe]\ntrend is lower than the Milky Way trend for [Fe/H]$>$-1.5 dex, similar to\nprevious studies of GES stars and consistent with the picture that these stars\nformed in a system with a lower rate of star formation. This is further\nsupported by their depleted abundances in Ni, Na, and Cu abundances, again,\nsimilar to previous studies of low-$\alpha$ stars with accreted origins. Carrillo_2022 Carrillo et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2202.10416
160 2009.02343 2022-02-17 Soumavo Ghosh, Victor P. Debattista, Tigran Khachaturyants Age dissection of the vertical breathing motions in Gaia DR2: evidence for spiral driving Gaia DR2 has revealed breathing motions in the Milky Way, with stars on both\nsides of the Galactic mid-plane moving coherently towards or away from it. The\ngenerating mechanism of these breathing motions is thought to be spiral density\nwaves. Here we test this hypothesis. Using a self-consistent, high-resolution\nsimulation with star formation, and which hosts prominent spirals, we first\nstudy the signatures of breathing motions excited by spirals. In the model, the\nbreathing motions induced by the spiral structure have an increasing amplitude\nwith distance from the mid-plane, pointing to an internal cause for them. We\nthen show that, at fixed height, the breathing motion amplitude decreases with\nage. Next, we investigate the signature of the breathing motions in the Gaia\nDR2 dataset. We demonstrate that, at the location with a consistently large\nbreathing motion, the corresponding amplitude increases monotonically with\ndistance from the mid-plane, in agreement with the model. Furthermore, we show\nthat at the same location, the breathing motion amplitude decreases with age,\nagain similar to what we find in the model. This strengthens the case that the\nobserved breathing motions are driven by spiral density waves. Ghosh_2022 Ghosh et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2009.02343
161 2202.07672 2022-02-15 Daniel Mikkola, Paul J. McMillan, David Hobbs, John Wimarsson The velocity distribution of white dwarfs in Gaia EDR3 Using a penalised maximum likelihood we estimate, for the first time, the\nvelocity distribution of white dwarfs in the Solar neighbourhood. Our sample\nconsists of 129 675 white dwarfs within 500 pc in Gaia Early Data Release 3 The\nwhite dwarf velocity distributions reveal a similar structure to the rest of\nthe Solar neighbourhood stars, reflecting that white dwarfs are subjected to\nthe same dynamical processes. In the velocity distribution for three\nmagnitude-binned subsamples we however find a novel structure at $(U, V) = (7,\n-19)$ km s$^{-1}$ in fainter samples, potentially related to the Coma Berenices\nstream. We also see a double-peaked feature in $U$-$W$ at $U \approx -30$ km\ns$^{-1}$ and in $V$-$W$ at $V \approx -20$ km s$^{-1}$ for fainter samples. We\ndetermine the velocity distribution and velocity moments as a function of\nabsolute magnitude for two samples based on the bifurcation identified in Gaia\nData Release 2 in the colour-magnitude diagram. The brighter, redder sequence\nhas a larger velocity dispersion than the fainter, bluer sequence across all\nmagnitudes. It is hard to reconcile this kinematic difference with a\nbifurcation caused purely by atmospheric composition, while it fits neatly with\na significant age difference between the two sequences. Our results provide\nnovel insights into the kinematic properties of white dwarfs and demonstrate\nthe power of analytical techniques that work for the large fraction of stars\nthat do not have measured radial velocities in the current era of large-scale\nastrometric surveys. Mikkola_2022 Mikkola et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2202.07672
162 2202.07662 2022-02-15 Jiwon Jesse Han, Rohan P. Naidu, Charlie Conroy, Ana Bonaca, Dennis Zaritsky, Nelson Caldwell, Phillip Cargile, Benjamin D. Johnson, Vedant Chandra, Joshua S. Speagle, Yuan-Sen Ting, Turner Woody A Tilt in the Dark Matter Halo of the Galaxy Recent observations of the stellar halo have uncovered the debris of an\nancient merger, Gaia-Sausage-Enceladus, estimated to have occurred ~8 Gyr ago.\nFollow-up studies have associated GSE with a large-scale tilt in the stellar\nhalo that links two well-known stellar over-densities in diagonally opposing\noctants of the Galaxy (the Hercules-Aquila Cloud and Virgo Overdensity; HAC and\nVOD). In this paper, we study the plausibility of such unmixed merger debris\npersisting over several Gyr in the Galactic halo. We employ the simulated\nstellar halo from Naidu et al. (2021), which reproduces several key properties\nof the merger remnant, including the large-scale tilt. By integrating the\norbits of these simulated stellar halo particles, we show that adoption of a\nspherical halo potential results in rapid phase mixing of the asymmetry.\nHowever, adopting a tilted halo potential preserves the initial asymmetry in\nthe stellar halo for many Gyr. The asymmetry is preserved even when a realistic\ngrowing disk is added to the potential. These results suggest that HAC and VOD\nare long-lived structures that are associated with GSE and that the dark matter\nhalo of the Galaxy is tilted with respect to the disk and aligned in the\ndirection of HAC-VOD. Such halo-disk misalignment is common in modern\ncosmological simulations. Lastly, we study the relationship between the local\nand global stellar halo in light of a tilted global halo comprised of highly\nradial orbits. We find that the local halo offers a dynamically biased view of\nthe global halo due to its displacement from the Galactic Center. Han_2022 Han et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2202.07662
163 2202.04863 2022-02-10 C. Viscasillas Vázquez, L. Magrini, G. Casali, G. Tautvaišienė, L. Spina, M. Van der Swaelmen, S. Randich, T. Bensby, A. Bragaglia, E. Friel, S. Feltzing, G. G. Sacco, A. Turchi, F. Jiménez-Esteban, V. D'Orazi, E. Delgado-Mena, Š. Mikolaitis, A. Drazdauskas, R. Minkevičiūtė, E. Stonkutė, V. Bagdonas, D. Montes, G. Guiglion, M. Baratella, H. M. Tabernero, G. Gilmore, E. Alfaro, P. Francois, A. Korn, R. Smiljanic, M. Bergemann, E. Franciosini, A. Gonneau, A. Hourihane, C. C. Worley, S. Zaggia The Gaia-ESO Survey: Age-chemical-clock relations spatially resolved in the Galactic disc The last decade has seen a revolution in our knowledge of the Galaxy thanks\nto the Gaia and asteroseismic space missions and the ground-based spectroscopic\nsurveys. To complete this picture, it is necessary to map the ages of its\nstellar populations. During recent years, the dependence on time of abundance\nratios involving slow (s) neutron-capture and $\alpha$ elements (called\nchemical-clocks) has been used to provide estimates of stellar ages, usually in\na limited volume close to the Sun. We aim to analyse the relations of chemical\nclocks in the Galactic disc extending the range to R$_{\rm GC}\sim$6-20~kpc.\nUsing the sixth internal data release of the Gaia-ESO survey, we calibrated\nseveral relations between stellar ages and abundance ratios [s/$\alpha$] using\na sample of open clusters, the largest one so far used with this aim. Thanks to\ntheir wide galactocentric coverage, we investigated the radial variations of\nthe shape of these relations, confirming their non-universality. We estimated\nour accuracy and precision in recovering the global ages of open clusters, and\nthe ages of their individual members. We applied the multi-variate relations\nwith the highest correlation coefficients to the field star population. We\nconfirm that there is no single age-chemical clock relationship valid for the\nwhole disc, but that there is a dependence on the galactocentric position,\nwhich is related to the radial variation of the star formation history combined\nwith the non-monotonic dependence on metallicity of the yields of the s-process\nelements from low- and intermediate-mass stars. Finally, the abundance ratios\n[Ba/$\alpha$] are more sensitive to age than those with [Y/$\alpha$] for young\ndisc stars, and their slopes vary less with galactocentric distance. Vázquez_2022 Vázquez et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2202.04863
164 2202.04548 2022-02-09 Pete B. Kuzma, Annette M. N. Ferguson, Anna Lisa Varri, Michael J. Irwin, Edouard J. Bernard, Eline Tolstoy, Jorge Peñarrubia, Daniel B. Zucker Forward and Back: Kinematics of the Palomar 5 Tidal Tails The tidal tails of Palomar 5 (Pal 5) have been the focus of many\nspectroscopic studies in an attempt to identify individual stars lying along\nthe stream and characterise their kinematics. The well-studied trailing tail\nhas been explored out to a distance of 15^\text{o} from the cluster centre,\nwhile less than four degrees have been examined along the leading tail. In this\npaper, we present results of a spectroscopic study of two fields along the\nleading tail that we have observed with the AAOmega spectrograph on the\nAnglo-Australian telescope. One of these fields lies roughly 7^\text{o} along\nthe leading tail, beyond what has been previously been explored\nspectroscopically. Combining our measurements of kinematics and line strengths\nwith Pan-STARRS1 photometric data and Gaia EDR3 astrometry, we adopt a\nprobabilistic approach to identify 16 stars with high probability of belonging\nto the Pal 5 stream. Eight of these stars lie in the outermost field and their\nsky positions confirm the presence of ``fanning'' in the leading arm. We also\nrevisit previously-published radial velocity studies and incorporate Gaia EDR3\nastrometry to remove interloping field stars. With a final sample of 109 {\it\nbona fide} Pal 5 cluster and tidal stream stars, we characterise the 3D\nkinematics along the the full extent of the system. We provide this catalogue\nfor future modeling work. Kuzma_2022 Kuzma et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2202.04548
165 2201.10018 2022-01-28 Thomas Schmidt, Maria-Rosa L. Cioni, Florian Niederhofer, Kenji Bekki, Cameron P. M. Bell, Richard de Grijs, Dalal El Youssoufi, Valentin D. Ivanov, Joana M. Oliveira, Vincenzo Ripepi, Jacco Th. van Loon The VMC survey -- XLV. Proper motion of the outer LMC and the impact of the SMC The Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) is the most luminous satellite galaxy of the\nMilky Way and owing to its companion, the Small Magellanic Cloud (SMC),\nrepresents an excellent laboratory to study the interaction of dwarf galaxies.\nThe aim of this study is to investigate the kinematics of the outer regions of\nthe LMC by using stellar proper motions to understand the impact of\ninteractions, e.g. with the SMC about 250 Myr ago. {We calculate proper motions\nusing multi-epoch $K_\mathrm{s}$-band images from the VISTA survey of the\nMagellanic Clouds system (VMC). Observations span a time baseline of 2$-$5 yr.\nWe combine the VMC data with data from the Gaia early Data Release 3 and\nintroduce a new method to distinguish between Magellanic and Milky Way stars\nbased on a machine learning algorithm. This new technique enables a larger and\ncleaner sample selection of fainter sources as it reaches below the red clump\nof the LMC. We investigate the impact of the SMC on the rotational field of the\nLMC and find hints of stripped SMC debris. The south east region of the LMC\nshows a slow rotational speed compared to the overall rotation. $N$-body\nsimulations suggest that this could be caused by a fraction of stripped SMC\nstars, located in that particular region, that move opposite to the expected\nrotation. Schmidt_2022 Schmidt et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2201.10018
166 2111.01145 2022-01-28 R. Raddi, S. Torres, A. Rebassa-Mansergas, J. Maldonado, M. E. Camisassa, D. Koester, N. P. Gentile Fusillo, P. -E. Tremblay, M. Dimpel, U. Heber, T. Cunningham, J. -J. Ren Kinematic properties of white dwarfs. Galactic orbital parameters and age-velocity dispersion relation We present the first detailed 3D kinematic analysis of a sample of 3133 white\ndwarfs that use Gaia astrometry plus radial velocities, which were measured\neither by Gaia or by ground based spectroscopic observations. The sample\nincludes either isolated white dwarfs that have direct radial velocity\nmeasurements, or white dwarfs that belong to common proper motion pairs that\ncontain nondegenerate companions with available radial velocities. A subset of\ncommon proper motion pairs also have metal abundances that have been measured\nby large scale spectroscopic surveys or by our own follow-up observations. We\nused the white dwarfs as astrophysical clocks, by determining their masses and\ntotal ages via interpolation with dedicated evolutionary models. We also used\nthe nondegenerate companions in common proper motions to chemically tag of the\npopulation. Combining accurate radial velocities with Gaia astrometry and\nproper motions, we derived the velocity components of our sample in the\nGalactic rest frame and their Galactic orbital parameters. The sample is mostly\nlocated within ~300 pc from the Sun. It contains predominantly (90-95%)\nthin-disk stars with close-to-circular Galactic orbits, while the remaining\n5-10% of stars have more eccentric trajectories and belong to the thick disk.\nWe identified seven isolated white dwarfs and two common proper motion pairs as\nhalo members. We determined the age - velocity dispersion relation for the\nthin-disk members, which shows signatures of dynamical heating and saturation\nafter 4-6 Gyr. We observed a mild anti-correlation between [Fe/H] and the\nradial component of the average - velocity dispersion, showing that dynamical\nmixing of populations takes place in the Galactic disk, as was detected via the\nanalysis of other samples of FGK stars. [Abridged] Raddi_2022 Raddi et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.01145
167 2201.11045 2022-01-26 Yansong Qian, Yumna Arshad, Jo Bovy The structure of accreted stellar streams Many of the Milky Way's globular clusters are likely accreted from satellite\ngalaxies that have long since merged with the Milky Way. When these globular\nclusters are susceptible to tidal disruption, this process likely starts\nalready inside the parent satellite leading to an early stellar stream within\nthe satellite. When the parent satellite merges with the Milky Way, the\nglobular cluster and its pre-merger stellar stream are accreted in a somewhat\nchaotic process. Here, we investigate the properties of the accreted stream\nafter the merger as we would see it today using a suite of simulations of\naccretion events. We find that the accretion process leads to a wide range of\nbehaviors, but generally scatters the accreted stream over a wide,\ntwo-dimensional area of the sky. The behavior ranges from a set of a few or\nmore well-defined "sub-streams" extending out from the post-merger thin stream\nby tens of degrees, to more widely dispersed debris over much of the sky,\ndepending on how close to the center of the MilkyWay the merger happened. Using\nmock Gaia-like observations of the simulated streams, we demonstrate that an\naccreted-stream component can explain the off-track features observed in the\nGD-1 stream. Sub-streams can appear like thin tidal streams themselves that are\nseemingly unassociated with the post-merger stream, raising the possibility\nthat some of the progenitor-less streams observed in the Milky Way are part of\na single or a few accreted streams created in an ancient merger event. Qian_2022 Qian et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2201.11045
168 2109.04059 2022-01-06 Sven Buder, Karin Lind, Melissa K. Ness, Diane K. Feuillet, Danny Horta, Stephanie Monty, Tobias Buck, Thomas Nordlander, Joss Bland-Hawthorn, Andrew R. Casey, Gayandhi M. De Silva, Valentina D'Orazi, Ken C. Freeman, Michael R. Hayden, Janez Kos, Sarah L. Martell, Geraint F. Lewis, Jane Lin, Katharine. J. Schlesinger, Sanjib Sharma, Jeffrey D. Simpson, Dennis Stello, Daniel B. Zucker, Tomaz Zwitter, Ioana Ciuca, Jonathan Horner, Chiaki Kobayashi, Yuan-Sen Ting, Rosemary F. G. Wyse, The GALAH Collaboration The GALAH Survey: Chemical tagging and chrono-chemodynamics of accreted halo stars with GALAH+ DR3 and $Gaia$ eDR3 Since the advent of $Gaia$ astrometry, it is possible to identify massive\naccreted systems within the Galaxy through their unique dynamical signatures.\nOne such system, $Gaia$-Sausage-Enceladus (GSE), appears to be an early\n"building block" given its virial mass $> 10^{10}\,\mathrm{M_\odot}$ at infall\n($z\sim1-3$). In order to separate the progenitor population from the\nbackground stars, we investigate its chemical properties with up to 30 element\nabundances from the GALAH+ Survey Data Release 3 (DR3). To inform our choice of\nelements for purely chemically selecting accreted stars, we analyse 4164 stars\nwith low-$\alpha$ abundances and halo kinematics. These are most different to\nthe Milky Way stars for abundances of Mg, Si, Na, Al, Mn, Fe, Ni, and Cu. Based\non the significance of abundance differences and detection rates, we apply\nGaussian mixture models to various element abundance combinations. We find the\nmost populated and least contaminated component, which we confirm to represent\nGSE, contains 1049 stars selected via [Na/Fe] vs. [Mg/Mn] in GALAH+ DR3. We\nprovide tables of our selections and report the chrono-chemodynamical\nproperties (age, chemistry, and dynamics). Through a previously reported clean\ndynamical selection of GSE stars, including $30 <\n\sqrt{J_R~/~\mathrm{kpc\,km\,s^{-1}}} < 55$, we can characterise an\nunprecedented 24 abundances of this structure with GALAH+ DR3. Our chemical\nselection allows us to prevent circular reasoning and characterise the\ndynamical properties of the GSE, for example mean\n$\sqrt{J_R~/~\mathrm{kpc\,km\,s^{-1}}} = 26_{-14}^{+9}$. We find only\n$(29\pm1)\%$ of the GSE stars within the clean dynamical selection region. Our\nmethodology will improve future studies of accreted structures and their\nimportance for the formation of the Milky Way. Buder_2022 Buder et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2109.04059
169 2201.01822 2022-01-05 S. Sivertsson, J. I. Read, H. Silverwood, P. F. de Salas, K. Malhan, A. Widmark, C. F. P. Laporte, S. Garbari, K. Freese Estimating the local dark matter density in a non-axisymmetric wobbling disc The density of dark matter near the Sun is important for experiments hunting\nfor dark matter particles in the laboratory, and for constraining the local\nshape of the Milky Way's dark matter halo. Estimates to date have typically\nassumed that the Milky Way's stellar disc is axisymmetric and in a\nsteady-state. Yet the Milky Way disc is neither, exhibiting prominent spiral\narms and a bar, and vertical and radial oscillations. We assess the impact of\nthese assumptions on determinations of the local dark matter density by\napplying a free-form, steady-state, Jeans method to two different N-body\nsimulations of Milky Way-like galaxies. In one, the galaxy has experienced an\nancient major merger, similar to the hypothesized Gaia-Sausage-Enceladus; in\nthe other, the galaxy is perturbed more recently by the repeated passage and\nslow merger of a Sagittarius-like dwarf galaxy. We assess the impact of each of\nthe terms in the Jeans-Poisson equations on our ability to correctly extract\nthe local dark matter density from the simulated data. We find that common\napproximations employed in the literature - axisymmetry and a locally flat\nrotation curve - can lead to significant systematic errors of up to a factor\n~1.5 in the recovered surface mass density ~2kpc above the disc plane, implying\na fractional error on the local dark matter density of order unity. However,\nonce we add in the tilt term and the rotation curve term in our models, we\nobtain an unbiased estimate, consistent with the true value within our 95%\nconfidence intervals for realistic 20% uncertainties on the baryonic surface\ndensity of the disc. Other terms - the axial tilt, 2:nd Poisson and time\ndependent terms - contribute less than 10% to the local dark matter density\n(given current data) and can be safely neglected for now. In the future, as\nmore data become available, these terms will need to be included in the\nanalysis. Sivertsson_2022 Sivertsson et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2201.01822
170 2201.01126 2022-01-04 V. Ripepi, G. Catanzaro, G. Clementini, G. De Somma, R. Drimmel, S. Leccia, M. Marconi, R. Molinaro, I. Musella, E. Poggio Classical Cepheid period-Wesenheit-metallicity relation in the Gaia bands Classical Cepheids (DCEPs) represent a fundamental tool to calibrate the\nextragalactic distance scale. However, they are also powerful stellar\npopulation tracers in the context of Galactic studies. The forthcoming Data\nRelease 3 (DR3) of the Gaia mission will allow us to study, with unprecedented\ndetail, the structure, the dynamics, and the chemical properties of the\nGalactic disc, and in particular of the spiral arms, where most Galactic DCEPs\nreside. In this paper, we aim to quantify the metallicity dependence of the\nGalactic DCEPs' period-Wesenheit ($PWZ$) relation in the Gaia bands. We adopted\na sample of 499 DCEPs with metal abundances from high-resolution spectroscopy,\nin conjunction with Gaia Early Data Release 3 parallaxes and photometry to\ncalibrate a $PWZ$ relation in the Gaia bands. We find a significant metallicity\nterm, of the order of $-$0.5 mag/dex, which is larger than the values measured\nin the near-infrared (NIR) bands by different authors. Our best $PWZ$ relation\nis $W=(-5.988\pm0.018)-(3.176\pm0.044)(\log P-1.0)-(0.520\pm0.090){\rm\n[Fe/H]}$. We validated our $PWZ$ relations by using the distance to the Large\nMagellanic Cloud as a benchmark, finding very good agreement with the geometric\ndistance provided by eclipsing binaries. As an additional test, we evaluated\nthe metallicity gradient of the young Galactic disc, finding $-0.0527 \pm\n0.0022$ dex/kpc, which is in very good agreement with previous results. Ripepi_2022 Ripepi et al. 2022 https://arxiv.org/abs/2201.01126
171 2104.12789 2021-12-28 David Shih, Matthew R. Buckley, Lina Necib, John Tamanas Via Machinae: Searching for Stellar Streams using Unsupervised Machine Learning We develop a new machine learning algorithm, Via Machinae, to identify cold\nstellar streams in data from the Gaia telescope. Via Machinae is based on\nANODE, a general method that uses conditional density estimation and sideband\ninterpolation to detect local overdensities in the data in a model agnostic\nway. By applying ANODE to the positions, proper motions, and photometry of\nstars observed by Gaia, Via Machinae obtains a collection of those stars deemed\nmost likely to belong to a stellar stream. We further apply an automated\nline-finding method based on the Hough transform to search for line-like\nfeatures in patches of the sky. In this paper, we describe the Via Machinae\nalgorithm in detail and demonstrate our approach on the prominent stream GD-1.\nThough some parts of the algorithm are tuned to increase sensitivity to cold\nstreams, the Via Machinae technique itself does not rely on astrophysical\nassumptions, such as the potential of the Milky Way or stellar isochrones. This\nflexibility suggests that it may have further applications in identifying other\nanomalous structures within the Gaia dataset, for example debris flow and\nglobular clusters. Shih_2021 Shih et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2104.12789
172 2112.13591 2021-12-27 E. R. Garro, D. Minniti, B. Alessi, D. Patchick, M. Kronberger, J. Alonso-García, J. G. Fernández-Trincado, M. Gómez, M. Hempel, J. B. Pullen, R. K. Saito, V. Ripepi, R. Zelada Bacigalupo Unveiling the nature of 12 new low-luminosity Galactic Globular Cluster Candidates The Galactic globular cluster system is incomplete, especially in the low\nlatitude regions of the Galactic bulge and disk. We report the physical\ncharacterization of twelve star clusters in the Milky Way, most of which are\nexplored here for the first time. Our aim is determining their main physical\nparameters, such as reddening and extinction, metallicity, age, total\nluminosity, mean cluster proper motions (PMs), distances, in order to unveil\ntheir physical nature. We study the clusters using optical and near-infrared\n(NIR) datasets. We use the Gaia Early Data Release 3 (EDR3) PMs in order to\nperform a PM-decontamination procedure and build final catalogues. We match the\nGaia EDR3 with the VISTA Variables in the V\'ia L\'actea extended (VVVX) survey\nand Two Micron All Sky survey (2MASS) in the NIR, in order to construct\ncomplete colour-magnitude diagrams (CMDs) and investigate the clusters\nproperties. The extinctions are evaluated using existing reddening maps,\nspanning $0.09\lesssim A_{Ks}\lesssim 0.86$ mag and $0.89 \lesssim\nA_{G}\lesssim 4.72$ mag in the NIR and optical, respectively. We obtain their\nheliocentric distances, that range from about 4 to 20 kpc, placing these\nclusters at $3\lesssim R_{G}\lesssim 14$ kpc from the Galactic centre. The best\nPARSEC isochrone fit yields a metallicity range of $-1.8<$[Fe/H]$<+0.3$ and an\napproximative age range of $2<$Age$<14$ Gyr. We find that all clusters have\nlow-luminosities, with $-6.9 Garro_2021b Garro et al. 2021b https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.13591
173 2112.12122 2021-12-22 Piotr Wielgórski, Grzegorz Pietrzyński, Bogumił Pilecki, Wolfgang Gieren, Bartłomiej Zgirski, Marek Górski, Gergely Hajdu, Weronika Narloch, Paulina Karczmarek, Radosław Smolec, Pierre Kervella, Jesper Storm, Alexandre Gallenne, Louise Breuval, Megan Lewis, Mikołaj Kałuszyński, Dariusz Graczyk, Wojciech Pych, Ksenia Suchomska, Mónica Taormina, Gonzalo Rojas Garcia, Aleksandra Kotek, Rolf Chini, Francisco Pozo Nuñez, Sadegh Noroozi, Catalina Sobrino Figaredo, Martin Haas, Klaus Hodapp, Przemysław Mikołajczyk, Krzysztof Kotysz, Dawid Moździerski, Piotr Kołaczek-Szymański An absolute calibration of the near-infrared Period-Luminosity Relations of Type II Cepheids in the Milky Way and in the Large Magellanic Cloud We present time-series photometry of 21 nearby Type II Cepheids in the\nnear-infrared J, H and Ks passbands. We use this photometry, together with the\nThird Gaia Early Data Release parallaxes, to determine for the first time\nperiod-luminosity relations (PLRs) for Type II Cepheids from field\nrepresentatives of these old pulsating stars in the near-infrared regime. We\nfound PLRs to be very narrow for BL Herculis stars, which makes them candidates\nfor precision distance indicators. We then use archival photometry and the most\naccurate distance obtained from eclipsing binaries to recalibrate PLRs for Type\nII Cepheids in the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC). Slopes of our PLRs in the\nMilky Way and in the LMC differ by slightly more than 2{\sigma} and are in a\ngood agreement with previous studies of the LMC, Galactic Bulge and Galactic\nGlobular Clusters Type II Cepheids samples. We use PLRs of Milky Way Type II\nCepheids to measure the distance to the LMC and we obtain a distance modulus of\n18.540$\pm$0.026(stat.)$\pm$0.034(syst.)mag in the WJKs Wesenheit index. We\nalso investigate the metallicity effect within our Milky Way sample and we find\nrather significant value of about -0.2mag/dex in each band meaning that more\nmetal-rich Type II Cepheids are intrinsically brighter than their more\nmetal-poor counterparts, in agreement with the value obtained from Type II\nCepheids in Galactic Globular Clusters. The main source of systematic error on\nour Milky Way PLRs calibration and the LMC distance is the current uncertainty\nof the Gaia parallax zero point. Wielgórski_2021 Wielgórski et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.12122
174 2112.08218 2021-12-15 Christian L. Sahlholdt, Sofia Feltzing, Diane K. Feuillet Characterizing epochs of star formation across the Milky Way disc using age-metallicity distributions of GALAH stars We provide a detailed map of the ages and metallicities of turnoff stars in\nthe Milky Way disc based on data from GALAH DR3 and Gaia EDR3. From this map,\nwe identify previously undetected features in the age-metallicity distribution\nof disc stars and interpret these results as indicating a three-phase formation\nhistory of the Milky Way. In the first phase, inner disc stars form along a\nsingle age-metallicity sequence and are today kinematically hot. The end of\nthis phase is marked by a local minimum in the inner disc age distribution 10\nGyr ago. At this time, we find the stellar populations to transition from high\nto low alpha-element abundances and from high to low vertical velocity\ndispersion. In the second phase, stars form across the disc with outwardly\ndecreasing metallicity. In this phase, inner disc stars form at super-solar\nmetallicites in a continuation of the early age-metallicity relation while\nouter disc stars begin forming at metallicities at least 0.5 dex lower.\nFinally, the third phase is associated with a recent burst of star formation\nacross the local disc marked by a local minimum in the age-metallicity\ndistribution 4 to 6 Gyr ago. Future quantitative comparisons between the\nobserved age-metallicity distribution and those of simulated galaxies could\nhelp constrain the processes driving each of the star formation phases. Sahlholdt_2021 Sahlholdt et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.08218
175 2112.07419 2021-12-14 Bokyoung Kim, Sebastien Lépine Stars in the Local Galactic Thick Disk and Halo in Gaia EDR3: A catalogue of Half a Million Local Main-sequence Stars with Photometric Metallicities We present a catalogue of 551,214 main-sequence stars in the local ($d < 2$\nkpc) Galactic thick disk and halo, based on a search of stars with large proper\nmotions ($\mu_{\mathrm{tot}} > 40.0$ mas/yr) in the Gaia Early Data Release 3.\nWe derive photometric metallicity calibrated from the\ncolour-luminosity-metallicity distribution of 20,047 stars with spectroscopic\nmetallicities, collected from various spectroscopic surveys, including SDSS\nSEGUE/APOGEE, GALAH DR3, and LAMOST DR6. We combine these results to construct\nan empirical colour-magnitude-metallicity grid, which can be used to estimate\nphotometric metallicities for low-mass metal-poor stars of K and M subtypes\nfrom their absolute $G$ magnitude and colour values. We find that low-mass,\nhigh-velocity stars in our catalogue share similar kinematics as reported in\nrecent studies of more luminous Galactic halo stars. The pseudo-kinematic\nanalysis of our sample recovers the main local halo structures, including the\nGaia-Enceladus Stream and the Helmi stream; aside from these the local halo\nstars appear to show a remarkably smooth distribution in velocity space. Since\nthe future Gaia data release will provide radial velocity measurements for only\na small number of our sample, our catalogue provides targets of high interest\nfor the future spectroscopic observation programs like SDSS-V, DESI MW survey,\nWEAVE, and/or 4MOST. Kim_2021a Kim and Lépine 2021a https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.07419
176 2112.06017 2021-12-11 Kuan-Wei Huang, Sergey E. Koposov Identifying RR Lyrae in the ZTF DR3 dataset We present a RR Lyrae (RRL) catalogue based on the combination of the third\ndata release of the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF DR3) and \textit{Gaia} EDR3.\nWe use a multi-step classification pipeline relying on the Fourier\ndecomposition fitting to the multi-band ZTF light curves and random forest\nclassification. The resulting catalogue contains 71,755 RRLs with period and\nlight curve parameter measurements and has completeness of 0.92 and purity of\n0.92 with respect to the SOS \textit{Gaia} DR2 RRLs. The catalogue covers the\nNorthern sky with declination $\geq -28^\circ$, its completeness is $\gtrsim\n0.8$ for heliocentric distance $\leq 80$~kpc, and the most distant RRL at\n132~kpc. Compared with several other RRL catalogues covering the Northern sky,\nour catalogue has more RRLs around the Galactic halo and is more complete at\nlow Galactic latitude areas. Analysing the spatial distribution of RRL in the\ncatalogue reveals the previously known major over-densities of the Galactic\nhalo, such as the Virgo over-density and the Hercules-Aquila Cloud, with some\nevidence of an association between the two. We also analyse the Oosterhoff\nfraction differences throughout the halo, comparing it with the density\ndistribution, finding increasing Oosterhoff I fraction at the elliptical radii\nbetween 16 and 32 kpc and some evidence of different Oosterhoff fractions\nacross various halo substructures. Huang_2021 Huang and Koposov 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.06017
177 2101.11641 2021-12-07 Jan Rybizki, Gregory Green, Hans-Walter Rix, Kareem El-Badry, Markus Demleitner, Eleonora Zari, Andrzej Udalski, Richard L. Smart, Andrew Gould A classifier for spurious astrometric solutions in Gaia EDR3 The Gaia early Data Release 3 has delivered exquisite astrometric data for\n1.47 billion sources, which is revolutionizing many fields in astronomy. For a\nsmall fraction of these sources, the astrometric solutions are poor, and the\nreported values and uncertainties may not apply. Before any analysis, it is\nimportant to recognize and excise these spurious results - this is commonly\ndone by means of quality flags in the Gaia catalog. Here, we devise a means of\nseparating 'good' from 'bad' astrometric solutions that is an order of\nmagnitude cleaner than any single flag: 99.3% pure and 97.3% complete, as\nvalidated on our test data. We devise an extensive sample of manifestly bad\nastrometric solutions, with parallax that is negative at > 4.5 sigma; and a\ncorresponding sample of presumably good solutions, including sources in HEALPix\npixels on the sky that do not contain such negative parallaxes, and sources\nthat fall on the main sequence in a color-absolute magnitude diagram. We then\ntrain a neural network that uses 17 pertinent Gaia catalog entries and\ninformation about nearby sources to discriminate between these two samples,\ncaptured in a single 'astrometric fidelity' parameter. A diverse set of\nverification tests shows that our approach works very cleanly, including for\nsources with positive parallaxes. The main limitations of our approach are in\nthe very low-SNR and the crowded regime. Our astrometric fidelities for all of\neDR3 can be queried via the Virtual Observatory, our code and data are public. Rybizki_2021 Rybizki et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2101.11641
178 2112.03284 2021-12-06 P. Pietrukowicz, I. Soszynski, A. Udalski Classical Cepheids in the Milky Way We share the most up-to-date, carefully verified list of classical Cepheids\nresiding in the Galaxy. Based on long-term OGLE experience in the field of\nvariable stars, we have inspected candidates for Cepheids from surveys such as\nASAS, ASAS-SN, ATLAS, Gaia, NSVS, VVV, WISE, ZTF, among others, and also known\nsources from the General Catalogue of Variable Stars. Only objects confirmed in\nthe optical range as classical Cepheids are included in the list. We provide\nGaia EDR3 identifications of the stars. Purity of the sample exceeds 97 per\ncent, while its completeness is of about 88 per cent down to a magnitude G=18.\nThe list contains 3352 classical Cepheids, of which 2140 stars are\nfundamental-mode pulsators. Basic statistics and comparison between the\nclassical Cepheids from the Milky Way, Andromeda Galaxy (M31), and Magellanic\nClouds are provided. The list is available at the OGLE Internet Data Archive. Pietrukowicz_2021 Pietrukowicz et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.03284
179 2112.01703 2021-12-03 Arthur Alencastro Puls, Luca Casagrande, Stephanie Monty, David Yong, Fan Liu, Dennis Stello, Victor Aguirre Børsen-Koch, Ken C. Freeman Chemo-dynamics and asteroseismic ages of seven metal-poor red giants from the Kepler field In this work we combine information from solar-like oscillations,\nhigh-resolution spectroscopy and Gaia astrometry to derive stellar ages,\nchemical abundances and kinematics for a group of seven metal-poor Red Giants\nand characterise them in a multidimensional chrono-chemo-dynamical space.\nChemical abundance ratios were derived through classical spectroscopic analysis\nemploying 1D LTE atmospheres on Keck/HIRES spectra. Stellar ages, masses and\nradii were calculated with grid-based modelling, taking advantage of\navailability of asteroseismic information from Kepler. The dynamical properties\nwere determined with Galpy using Gaia EDR3 astrometric solutions. Our results\nsuggest that underestimated parallax errors make the effect of Gaia parallaxes\nmore important than different choices of model grid or -- in the case of stars\nascending the RGB -- mass-loss prescription. Two of the stars in this study are\nidentified as potentially evolved halo blue stragglers. Four objects are likely\nmembers of the accreted Milky Way halo, and their possible relationship with\nknown accretion events is discussed. Puls_2021 Puls et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.01703
180 2112.02105 2021-12-03 P. Ramos, T. Antoja, Z. Yuan, A. Arentsen, P. -A. Oria, B. Famaey, R. Ibata, C. Mateu, J. A. Carballo-Bello The Sagittarius stream in Gaia eDR3 and the origin of the bifurcations The Sagittarius dwarf spheroidal (Sgr) is a dissolving galaxy being tidally\ndisrupted by the Milky Way (MW). Its stellar stream still poses serious\nmodelling challenges, which hinders our ability to use it effectively as a\nprobe of the MW gravitational potential. Our goal is to construct the best\npossible sample of stars with which we can advance our understanding of the\nSgr-MW interaction, focusing on the characterisation of the bifurcations. We\nimprove on previous methods based on the use of the wavelet transform to\nsystematically search for the kinematic signature of the Sgr stream in the Gaia\ndata. We refine our selection via the use of a clustering algorithm on the\nstatistical properties of the colour-magnitude diagrams. Our final sample\ncontains > 700k candidate stars, 3x larger than previous samples. We have been\nable to detect the bifurcation of the stream in both the northern and southern\nhemispheres, requiring four branches to fully describe this system. We present\nthe detailed proper motion distribution of the trailing arm as a function of\nLambda showing the presence of a sharp edge (on the side of the small proper\nmotions) beyond which there are no Sgr stars. We also characterise the\ncorrelation between kinematics and distance. The chemical analysis of our\nsample shows a significant difference between the faint and bright branches. We\nprovide analytical descriptions for the proper motion trends as well as for the\nsky distribution of the four branches of the stream. We interpret the\nbifurcations as the misaligned overlap of the material stripped at the\nantepenultimate pericentre (faint branches) with the stars ejected at the\npenultimate pericentre (bright branch). The source of this misalignment is\nstill unknown but we argue that models with some internal rotation in the\nprogenitor, at least during the time of stripping of the stars in the faint\nbranches, are worth exploring. Ramos_2021 Ramos et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.02105
181 2111.15211 2021-11-30 Sergey Khoperskov, Ortwin Gerhard Chemo-kinematics of the Milky Way spiral arms and bar resonances: connection to ridges and moving groups in the Solar vicinity Using of a new N-body simulation, as well as Gaia DR2/EDR3 data complemented\nby data from the Galah, APOGEE, LAMOST surveys, we explore the possible link\nbetween the MW spiral arms, RVphi-ridges and moving groups in local UV space.\nWe show that the tightly wound main spiral arms in the N-body model can be\nsuccessfully identified using overdensities in angular momentum (AM) or guiding\nspace, as well as in the distribution of dynamically cold stars close to their\nguiding centers. Stars in the AM overdensities that travel over many kpc in\nradius trace extended density ridges in RVphi space and overdensities in the UV\nplane of a SNd-like region, similar to those observed in the Gaia data.\nSimilarly, the AM space of the MW contains several overdensities which\ncorrelate with a wave-like radial velocity pattern; this pattern is also\nreproduced by stars well beyond the SNd. We find that the fraction of Gaia\nstars located near their guiding centers shows three large-scale structures\nthat approximately coincide with the MW spiral arms traced by distributions of\nmaser sources in the Sagittarius, Local, and Perseus arms. Similar to the\nmodel, the stars in the AM overdensities follow the main RVphi ridges. When\nthese ridges cross the SNd, they can be matched with the main UV features. Thus\nwe suggest that the Hat is the inner tail of the Perseus arm, one of the\nHercules components is the Sagittarius arm and the Arcturus stream is likely to\nbe the outermost tail of the Scutum-Centaurus arm. Based on previous work, the\nbar corotation is suggested to coincide with the Hercules stream, and the OLR\nwith the Sirius stream. The latter is supported by a sharp decrease of the mean\nmetallicity beyond the Sirius stream, which is an expected behaviour of the\nOLR. In various phase-space coordinates the AM overdensities stars have\nsystematically higher mean metallicity...(Abridged) Khoperskov_2021 Khoperskov and Gerhard 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.15211
182 2111.15423 2021-11-30 Tadafumi Matsuno, Helmer H. Koppelman, Amina Helmi, Wako Aoki, Miho N. Ishigaki, Takuma Suda, Zhen Yuan, Kohei Hattori High-precision chemical abundances of Galactic building blocks. The distinct chemical abundance sequence of Sequoia Context: Sequoia is a retrograde kinematic substructures in the nearby\nGalactic halo, whose properties are a matter of debate. For example, previous\nstudies do not necessarily agree on the chemical abundances of Sequoia stars,\nwhich are important for understanding its nature. Aim: We characterize the\nchemical properties of a sample of stars from Sequoia by determining\nhigh-precision abundances. Methods: We measure abundances of Na, Mg, Si, Ti,\nCr, Mn, Ni, Zn, Y, and Ba from a differential abundance analysis on high\nsignal-to-noise ratio, high-resolution spectra from new observations and from\narchival data. We compare precisely-measured chemical abundances of 12 Sequoia\ncandidates with those of typical halo stars from literature, which include also\nstars from Gaia-Enceladus. This allows us to characterize Sequoia and compare\nit to another Galactic building block. The comparison is made after putting all\nthe abundances onto the same scale using standard stars. Results: There are\nsignificant difference in [Na/Fe], [Mg/Fe], [Ca/Fe], [Ti/Fe], [Zn/Fe], and\n[Y/Fe] between Sequoia and Gaia-Enceladus stars at $-1.8\lesssim\n[\mathrm{Fe/H}]\lesssim -1.4$ in the sense that these abundance ratios are\nlower in Sequoia. These differences are similar to those seen between\nGaia-Enceladus and in-situ stars at higher metallicity, suggesting that Sequoia\nis affected by type~Ia supernovae at lower metallicity than Gaia-Enceladus. We\nalso confirm that the low [Mg/Fe] of Sequoia is seen in literature and in\nsurveys, namely APOGEE DR16 and GALAH DR3, if the stars are kinematically\nselected in the same way. Conclusion: Sequoia stars have a distinct chemical\nabundance pattern and can be chemically separated from in-situ stars or\nGaia-Enceladus stars if abundances are measured with sufficient precision,\nnamely $\sigma([\mathrm{X/Fe}])\lesssim 0.07\,\mathrm{dex}$. Matsuno_2021a Matsuno et al. 2021a https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.15423
183 2103.15823 2021-11-29 Alexander J. Mustill, Michiel Lambrechts, Melvyn B. Davies Hot Jupiters, cold kinematics: High phase space densities of host stars reflect an age bias Context. The birth environments of planetary systems are thought to influence\nplanet formation and orbital evolution, through external photoevaporation and\nstellar flybys. Recent work has claimed observational support for this, in the\nform of a correlation between the properties of planetary systems and the local\nGalactic phase space density of the host star. In particular, Hot Jupiters are\nfound overwhelmingly around stars in regions of high phase space density, which\nmay reflect a formation environment with high stellar density. Aims. We instead\ninvestigate whether the high phase space density may have a galactic kinematic\norigin: Hot Jupiter hosts may be biased towards being young and therefore\nkinematically cold, because tidal inspiral leads to the destruction of the\nplanets on Gyr timescales, and the velocity dispersion of stars in the Galaxy\nincreases on similar timescales. Methods. We use 6D positions and kinematics\nfrom Gaia for the Hot Jupiter hosts and their neighbours, and construct\ndistributions of the phase space density. We investigate correlations between\nthe stars' local phase space density and peculiar velocity. Results. We find a\nstrong anticorrelation between the phase space density and the host star's\npeculiar velocity with respect to the Local Standard of Rest. Therefore, most\nstars in "high-density" regions are kinematically cold, which may be caused by\nthe aforementioned bias towards detecting Hot Jupiters around young stars\nbefore the planets' tidal destruction. Conclusions. We do not find evidence in\nthe data for Hot Jupiter hosts preferentially being in phase space\noverdensities compared to other stars of similar kinematics, nor therefore for\ntheir originating in birth environments of high stellar density. Mustill_2021 Mustill et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2103.15823
184 2102.08955 2021-11-29 Axel Widmark, Chervin F. P. Laporte, Pablo F. de Salas Weighing the Galactic disk using phase-space spirals I. Tests on one-dimensional simulations We present a new method for inferring the gravitational potential of the\nGalactic disk, using the time-varying structure of a phase-space spiral in the\n$(z,w)$-plane (where $z$ and $w$ represent vertical position and vertical\nvelocity). Our method of inference extracts information from the shape of the\nspiral and disregards the bulk density distribution that is usually used to\nperform dynamical mass measurements. In this manner, it is complementary to\ntraditional methods that are based on the assumption of a steady state. Our\nmethod consists of fitting an analytical model for the phase-space spiral to\ndata, where the spiral is seen as a perturbation of the stellar number density\nin the $(z,w)$-plane. We tested our method on one-dimensional simulations,\nwhich were initiated in a steady state and then perturbed by an external force\nsimilar to that of a passing satellite. We were able to retrieve the true\ngravitational potentials of the simulations with high accuracy. The\ngravitational potential at 400-500 parsec distances from the disk mid-plane was\ninferred with an error of only a few percent. This is the first paper of a\nseries in which we plan to test and refine our method on more complex\nsimulations, as well as apply our method to Gaia data. Widmark_2021 Widmark et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2102.08955
185 2111.09324 2021-11-26 Jianling Wang, Francois Hammer, Yanbin Yang Milky Way total Mass derived by Rotation Curve and Globular Cluster kinematics from Gaia EDR3 Using action-based distribution function for the dynamical model of the Milky\nWay we have estimated its total mass and its density profile. Constraints are\ncoming from the globular cluster proper motions from Gaia EDR3, from the\nrotation curve based on Gaia DR2 data, and from the vertical force data. We use\nBayesian Markov chain Monte Carlo method to explore the parameters, for which\nthe globular cluster distribution function and the Galactic potential are fully\nconstrained. Numerical simulations are used to study the uncertainties on the\npotential constraint if considering a possible massive Large Magellanic Could\n(LMC). We found that a massive LMC (1.5$\times10^{11}$ M$_{\odot}$) will affect\nthe MW mass measurement at large radius, which includes both the Milky Way and\nthe LMC. We also use the FIRE2 Latte cosmological hydrodynamic simulations to\nmake mock data set from a Milky-Way like galaxy that includes many unrelaxed\nsubstructures. We test the effect of these unrelaxed substructures on the final\nresults, and found that the measured rotation curve fluctuated around input\nvalue within 5 percent. By keeping a large freedom in choosing a priori mass\nprofile for both baryonic and dark matter leads a total mass of the MW that\nranges from $5.36_{-0.68}^{+0.81}\times10^{11}$ M$_{\odot}$ to\n$7.84_{-1.97}^{+3.08} \times 10^{11}$ M$\odot$. This includes the contribution\nof a putative massive LMC and significantly narrows the MW total mass range\npublished earlier. Such total mass leads to dark matter density at solar\nposition of $0.34_{-0.02}^{+0.02}$ GeV cm$^{-3}$. Wang_2021 Wang et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.09324
186 2011.01233 2021-11-26 Wilma H. Trick Identifying resonances of the Galactic bar in Gaia DR2: II. Clues from angle space The Milky Way disk exhibits intricate orbit substructure of still-debated\ndynamical origin. The angle variables $(\theta_\phi,\theta_R)$ -- which are\nconjugates to the actions $(L_z,J_R)$, and describe a star's location along its\norbit -- are a powerful diagnostic to identify $l$:$m$ resonances via the orbit\nshape relation $\Delta \theta_R / \Delta \theta_\phi = -m/l$. In the past,\nangle signatures have been hidden by survey selection effects (SEs). Using test\nparticle simulations of a barred galaxy, we demonstrate that \emph{Gaia} should\nallow us to identify the Galactic bar's Outer Lindblad Resonance ($l=+1, m=2$,\nOLR) in angle space. We investigate strategies to overcome SEs. In the angle\ndata of the \emph{Gaia} DR2 RVS sample, we independently identify four\ncandidates for the OLR and therefore for the pattern speed $\Omega_\text{bar}$.\nThe strongest candidate, $\Omega_\text{bar}\sim1.4\Omega_0$, positions the OLR\nabove the `Sirius' moving group, agrees with measurements from the Galactic\ncenter, and might be supported by higher-order resonances around the\n`Hercules/Horn'. But it misses the classic orbit orientation flip, as discussed\nin the companion study on actions. The candidate\n$\Omega_\text{bar}\sim1.2\Omega_0$ was also suggested by the action-based\nstudy, has the OLR at the `Hat', is consistent with \emph{slow bar} models, but\nstill affected by SEs. Weaker candidates are $\Omega_\text{bar}=1.6\Omega_0$\nand $1.74\Omega_0$. In addition, we show that the stellar angles do not support\nthe `Hercules/Horn' being created by the OLR of a \emph{fast bar}. We conclude\nthat -- to resolve if `Sirius' or `Hat' is related to the bar's OLR -- more\ncomplex dynamical explanations and more extended data with well-behaved SEs are\nrequired. Trick_2021 Trick 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2011.01233
187 1906.04786 2021-11-26 Wilma H. Trick, Francesca Fragkoudi, Jason A. S. Hunt, J. Ted Mackereth, Simon D. M. White Identifying resonances of the Galactic bar in Gaia DR2: I. Clues from action space Action space synthesizes the orbital information of stars and is well-suited\nto analyse the rich kinematic substructure of the disc in the \emph{Gaia} DR2\nradial velocity sample (RVS). We revisit the strong perturbation induced in the\nMilky Way (MW) disc by an $m=2$ bar, using test particle simulations and the\nactions $(J_R,L_z,J_z)$ estimated in an axisymmetric potential. These make\nthree useful diagnostics cleanly visible. (1.) We use the well-known\ncharacteristic flip from outward to inward motion at the Outer Lindblad\nResonance (OLR, $l=+1,m=2$), which occurs along the axisymmetric resonance line\n(ARL) in $(L_z,J_R)$, to identify in the \emph{Gaia} action data three\ncandidates for the bar's OLR and pattern speed $\Omega_\text{bar}$:\n$1.85\Omega_0$, $1.20\Omega_0$, and $1.63\Omega_0$ (with $\sim0.1\Omega_0$\nsystematic uncertainty). The \emph{Gaia} data is therefore consistent with both\nslow and fast bar models in the literature, but disagrees with recent\nmeasurements of $\sim1.45\Omega_0$. (2.) For the first time, we demonstrate\nthat bar resonances -- especially the OLR -- cause a gradient in vertical\naction $\langle J_z \rangle$ with $L_z$ around the ARL via "$J_z$-sorting" of\nstars. This could contribute to the observed coupling of $\langle v_R \rangle$\nand $\langle | v_z | \rangle$ in the Galactic disc. (3.) We confirm prior\nresults that the behaviour of resonant orbits is well approximated by\nscattering and oscillation in $(L_z,J_R)$ along a slope $\Delta J_R/\Delta L_z\n= l/m$ centered on the $l$:$m$ ARL. Overall, we demonstrate that\naxisymmetrically estimated actions are a powerful diagnostic tool even in\nnon-axisymmetric systems. Trick_2021a Trick et al. 2021a https://arxiv.org/abs/1906.04786
188 2111.13634 2021-11-26 Owain Snaith, Misha Haywood, Paola Di Matteo, Matthew Lehnert, David Katz, Sergey Khoperskov Rapid early gas accretion for the inner Galactic disc Recent observations of the Milky Way and galaxies at high redshifts suggest\nthat galaxy discs were already in place soon after the Big Bang. While the gas\ninfall history of the Milky Way in the inner disc has long been assumed to be\ncharacterised by a short accretion time scale, this has not been directly\nconstrained using observations. Using the unprecedented amount and quality of\ndata of the inner regions of the Milky Way that has recently been produced by\nAPOGEE and Gaia, we aim to derive strong constraints on the infall history of\nthe inner (less than 6 kpc) Galaxy (with a focus on stars between 4-6 kpc,\nwhich we show is an appropriate proxy for the entire inner disc). We have\nimplemented gas infall into a chemical evolution model of the Galaxy disc, and\nused a Schmidt-Kennicutt law to connect the infall to the star formation.
