We\nexplore a number of models, and two different formulations of the infall law.\nIn one formulation, the infall is non-parametric, and in the other the infall\nhas an explicitly exponential form. We fit the model parameters to the\ntime-[Si/Fe] distribution of solar vicinity stars, and the metallicity and\n[Si/Fe] distribution function of stars with a galactocentric radius between 4-6\nkpc from APOGEE. Our results point to a fast early gas accretion, with an upper\nlimit of accretion timescale of around 2 Gyr in the inner disc of the Milky\nWay. This suggests that at least half the baryons were in place within 2-3 Gyr\nof the Big Bang, and that half the stars of the inner disc formed within the\nfirst 5 Gyr, during the thick disc formation phase. This implies that the\nstellar mass of the inner disc is dominated by the thick disc, supporting our\nprevious work, and that the gas accretion onto the inner disc was rapid and\nearly. Snaith_2021 Snaith et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.13634
189 2111.12859 2021-11-25 T. -S. Yan, J. -R. Shi, H. Tian, W. Zhang, B. Zhang Search for the metal-weak thick disk from the LAMOST DR5 Based on the data release of the Large Sky Area Multi-Object Fiber\nSpectroscopic Telescope survey (LAMOST DR5) and the \emph{Gaia} Early Data\nRelease 3 (\emph{Gaia} EDR3), we construct a sample containing 46,109 giant\n(log~$\emph{g}$ $\leqslant$ 3.5\,dex) stars with heliocentric distance d\n$\leqslant$ 4 kpc, and the sample is further divided into two groups of the\ninner ({\RGC} $<$ 8.34 \,kpc) and outer region ({\RGC} $>$ 8.34\,kpc). The\n{\LZ} distributions of our program stars in the panels with different [Fe/H]\nand [$\alpha$/Fe] suggest that the thick-disk consists of two distinct\ncomponents with different chemical compositions and kinematic properties. For\nthe inner region, the metal-weak thick disk (MWTD) contributes significantly\nwhen [$\alpha$/Fe] $>+$0.2\,dex and [Fe/H] $<-$0.8\,dex, while the canonical\nthick-disk (TD) dominates when [Fe/H]$>-$0.8\,dex. However, MWTD clearly\nappears only when [$\alpha$/Fe] $>+$0.2\,dex and [Fe/H] $<-$1.2\,dex for the\nouter region, and its proportion is lower than that of the inner region within\nthe same metallicity. Similar result can be obtained from the {\VP}\ndistribution. The high fraction of MWTD in the inner than that in the outer\nregion imply that MWTD may form in the inner disk, and is an observational\nevidence about the inside-out disk formation scenario. Yan_2021 Yan et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.12859
190 2004.07328 2021-11-24 Helmer H. Koppelman, Amina Helmi The Reduced Proper Motion selected halo: methods and description of the catalogue The Gaia mission has provided the largest ever astrometric chart of the Milky\nWay. Using it to map the Galactic halo is helpful for disentangling its merger\nhistory. The identification of halo stars in Gaia DR2 with reliable distance\nestimates requires special methods because such stars are typically farther\naway and scarce. We apply the reduced proper motion (RPM) method to identify\nhalo main sequence stars on the basis of Gaia photometry and proper motions.\nUsing the colour-absolute-magnitude relation for this type of stars, we\ncalculate photometric distances. Our selection results in a set of $\sim10^7$\ntentative main sequence halo stars with typical distance uncertainties of $7\%$\nand with median velocity errors of 20 km/s. The median distance of our sample\nis $\sim 4.4$ kpc, with the faintest stars located at $\sim 16$ kpc. The\nspatial distribution of the stars in our sample is centrally concentrated.\nVisual inspection of the mean velocities of stars on the sky reveals\nlarge-scale patterns as well as clear imprints of the GD-1 stream and tentative\nhints of the Jhelum and Leiptr streams. Incompleteness and selection effects\nlimit our ability to interpret the patterns reliably as well as to identify new\nsubstructures. We define a pseudo-velocity space by setting to zero the\nline-of-sight velocities of our sample stars. In this space, we recover several\nknown structures such as the footprint of Gaia-Enceladus (i.e. the\nGaia-Sausage) as well as the Helmi streams and some other retrograde\nsubstructures (Sequoia, Thamnos). We show that the two-point velocity\ncorrelation function reveals significant clustering on scales smaller than 100\nkm/s, of similar amplitude as found for the 6D Gaia halo sample. This\nclustering indicates the presence of nearby streams that are predominantly\nphase-mixed. Koppelman_2021a Koppelman and Helmi 2021a https://arxiv.org/abs/2004.07328
191 2111.10684 2021-11-20 G. Tautvaisiene, A. Drazdauskas, A. Bragaglia, S. L. Martell, E. Pancino, C. Lardo, S. Mikolaitis, R. Minkeviciute, E. Stonkute, M. Ambrosch, V. Bagdonas, Y. Chorniy, N. Sanna, E. Franciosini, R. Smiljanic, S. Randich, G. Gilmore, T. Bensby, M. Bergemann, A. Gonneau, G. Guiglion, G. Carraro, U. Heiter, A. Korn, L. Magrini, L. Morbidelli, S. Zaggia Gaia-ESO Survey: Detailed elemental abundances in red giants of the peculiar globular cluster NGC 1851 Context. NGC 1851 is one of several globular clusters for which multiple\nstellar populations of the subgiant branch have been clearly identified and a\ndifference in metallicity detected. A crucial piece of information on the\nformation history of this cluster can be provided by the sum of A(C+N+O)\nabundances. However, these values have lacked a general consensus thus far. The\nseparation of the subgiant branch can be based on age and/or A(C+N+O) abundance\ndifferences. Aims. Our main aim was to determine carbon, nitrogen, and oxygen\nabundances for evolved giants in the globular cluster NGC1851 in order to check\nwhether or not the double populations of stars are coeval. Methods.\nHigh-resolution spectra, observed with the FLAMES-UVES spectrograph on the ESO\nVLT telescope, were analysed using a differential model atmosphere method.\nResults. We provide abundances of up to 29 chemical elements for a sample of 45\ngiants in NGC 1851. The investigated stars can be separated into two\npopulations with a difference of 0.07 dex in the mean metallicity, 0.3 dex in\nthe mean C/N, and 0.35 dex in the mean s-process dominated element-to-iron\nabundance ratios [s/Fe]. No significant difference was determined in the mean\nvalues of A(C+N+O) as well as in abundance to iron ratios of carbon, alpha- and\niron-peak-elements, and of europium. Conclusions. As the averaged A(C+N+O)\nvalues between the two populations do not differ, additional evidence is given\nthat NGC 1851 is composed of two clusters, the metal-rich cluster being by\nabout 0.6 Gyr older than the metal-poor one. A global overview of NGC 1851\nproperties and the detailed abundances of chemical elements favour its\nformation in a dwarf spheroidal galaxy that was accreted by the Milky Way. Tautvaisiene_2021 Tautvaisiene et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.10684
192 2111.09897 2021-11-18 Maruša Žerjal, Michael J. Ireland, Timothy D. Crundall, Mark R. Krumholz, Adam D. Rains Chronostar. II. Kinematic age and substructure of the Scorpius-Centaurus OB2 association The nearest region of massive star formation - the Scorpius-Centaurus OB2\nassociation (Sco-Cen) - is a local laboratory ideally suited to the study of a\nwide range of astrophysical phenomena. Precision astrometry from the Gaia\nmission has expanded the census of this region by an order of magnitude.\nHowever, Sco-Cen's vastness and complex substructure make kinematic analysis of\nits traditional three regions, Upper Scorpius, Upper Centaurus-Lupus and Lower\nCentaurus-Crux, challenging. Here we use Chronostar, a Bayesian tool for\nkinematic age determination, to carry out a new kinematic decomposition of\nSco-Cen using full 6-dimensional kinematic data. Our model identifies 8\nkinematically distinct components consisting of 8,185 stars distributed in\ndense and diffuse groups, each with an independently-fit kinematic age; we\nverify that these kinematic estimates are consistent with isochronal ages. Both\nUpper Centaurus-Lupus and Lower Centaurus-Crux are split into two parts. The\nkinematic age of the component that includes PDS 70, one of the most well\nstudied systems currently forming planets, is 15$\pm$3 Myr. Žerjal_2021 Žerjal et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.09897
193 2111.08042 2021-11-15 Andrew Everall, N. Wyn Evans, Vasily Belokurov, Douglas Boubert, Robert J. J. Grand The Photo-Astrometric Vertical Tracer Density of the Milky Way I: The Method We introduce a method to infer the vertical distribution of stars in the\nMilky Way using a Poisson likelihood function, with a view to applying our\nmethod to the Gaia catalogue. We show how to account for the sample selection\nfunction and for parallax measurement uncertainties. Our method is validated\nagainst a simulated sample drawn from a model with two exponential discs and a\npower-law halo profile. A mock Gaia sample is generated using the Gaia\nastrometry selection function, whilst realistic parallax uncertainties are\ndrawn from the Gaia Astrometric Spread Function. The model is fit to the mock\nin order to rediscover the input parameters used to generate the sample. We\nrecover posterior distributions which accurately fit the input parameters to\nwithin statistical uncertainties, demonstrating the efficacy of our method.\nUsing the GUMS synthetic Milky Way catalogue we find that our halo parameter\nfits can be heavily biased by our overly simplistic model, however, the fits to\nthe thin and thick discs are not significantly impacted. We apply this method\nto Gaia Early Data Release 3 in a companion paper where we also quantify the\nsystematic uncertainties introduced by oversimplifications in our model. Everall_2021c Everall et al. 2021c https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.08042
194 2111.08043 2021-11-15 Andrew Everall, Vasily Belokurov, N. Wyn Evans, Douglas Boubert, Robert J. J. Grand The Photo-Astrometric Vertical Tracer Density of the Milky Way II: Results from Gaia We use Gaia photometry and astrometry to estimate the vertical spatial\nstructure of the Milky Way at the Solar radius, formally accounting for sample\nincompleteness (the selection function) and parallax measurement uncertainty.\nOur results show impressive precision demonstrating the power of the Gaia data.\nHowever, systematic errors dominate the parameter value uncertainties. We\nthoroughly test and quantify the impacts of all systematic uncertainties. The\nvertical tracer density is modelled as a sum of two exponential profiles for\nthe thin and thick discs, together with a spherically symmetric power-law for\nthe stellar halo. We constrain the thin disc scale height as\n${h_\mathrm{Tn}=260 \pm 3\, (\mathrm{stat}) \pm 26\,\mathrm{pc}\,\n(\mathrm{sys})}$ and thick disc ${h_\mathrm{Tk}=693 \pm 7 \,(\mathrm{stat}) \pm\n121\,\mathrm{pc}\, (\mathrm{sys})}$. For the halo, we obtain a power law\nprofile with $n_\mathrm{H}=3.543\pm0.023 \,(\mathrm{stat}) \pm0.259\,\n(\mathrm{sys})$. We infer a local stellar mass density for non-compact object\nstars of ${\rho_\mathrm{local}^* = 3.66\pm0.03\,(\mathrm{stat})\pm0.52\n\times10^{-2}\,\mathrm{M}_\odot/\mathrm{pc}^3\,(\mathrm{sys})}$ and surface\ndensity of ${\Sigma_\mathrm{local}^* =\n23.17\pm0.08\,(\mathrm{stat})\pm2.43\,\mathrm{M}_\odot/\mathrm{pc}^2\,(\mathrm{sys})}$.\nWe find asymmetries above and below the disc with longer disc scale heights in\nthe north but a flatter halo in the south at the $\lesssim 10$ per cent level. Everall_2021b Everall et al. 2021b https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.08043
195 2111.06672 2021-11-12 T. E. Dharmawardena, C. A. L. Bailer-Jones, M. Fouesneau, D. Foreman-Mackey Three-dimensional dust density structure of the Orion, Cygnus X,Taurus, and Perseus star-forming regions Interstellar dust affects astronomical observations through absorption and\nreddening, yet this extinction is also a powerful tool for studying\ninterstellar matter in galaxies. 3D reconstructions of dust extinction and\ndensity in the Milky Way have suffered from artefacts such as the\nfingers-of-god effect and negative densities, and have been limited by large\ncomputational costs. Here we aim to overcome these issues with a novel\nalgorithm that derives the 3D extinction density of dust in the Milky Way using\na latent variable Gaussian Process and variational inference. Our model\nmaintains non-negative density and hence monotonically non-decreasing\nextinction along all lines-of-sight, and performs inference within a reasonable\ncomputational time. Using extinctions for hundreds of thousands of stars\ncomputed from optical and near-IR photometry, together with distances based on\nGaia parallaxes, we use our algorithm to infer the structure of the Orion,\nTaurus, Perseus, and Cygnus X star-forming regions. A number of features\nsuperimposed in 2D extinction maps are clearly deblended in 3D dust extinction\ndensity maps. We find a large filament on the edge of Orion, identify filament\nthat in the Taurus and Perseus regions, and show that Cygnus X is located at\n1300-1500pc. We compute dust masses of the regions and find these to be\nslightly higher than previous estimates, likely a consequence of our input data\nrecovering the highest column densities more effectively. Comparing our\npredicted extinctions to Planck data, we find that known relationships between\ndensity and dust processing, where high extinction lines of sight have the most\nprocessed grains, hold up in resolved observations when density is included,\nand that they exist at smaller scales than previously suggested. This can be\nused to study the changes in size or composition of dust as they are processed\nin molecular clouds. (Abridged) Dharmawardena_2021 Dharmawardena et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.06672
196 2012.06597 2021-11-10 H. Al Kazwini, Q. Agobert, A. Siebert, B. Famaey, G. Monari, S. Rozier, P. Ramos, R. Ibata, S. Gausland, C. Riviere, D. Spolyar Perturbed distribution functions with accurate action estimates for the Galactic disc In the Gaia era, understanding the effects of the perturbations of the\nGalactic disc is of major importance in the context of dynamical modelling. In\nthis theoretical paper we extend previous work in which, making use of the\nepicyclic approximation, the linearized Boltzmann equation had been used to\nexplicitly compute, away from resonances, the perturbed distribution function\nof a Galactic thin-disc population in the presence of a non-axisymmetric\nperturbation of constant amplitude. Here we improve this theoretical framework\nin two distinct ways in the new code that we present. First, we use better\nestimates for the action-angle variables away from quasi-circular orbits,\ncomputed from the AGAMA software, and we present an efficient routine to\nnumerically re-express any perturbing potential in these coordinates with a\ntypical accuracy at the per cent level. The use of more accurate action\nestimates allows us to identify resonances such as the outer 1:1 bar resonance\nat higher azimuthal velocities than the outer Lindblad resonance (OLR), and to\nextend our previous theoretical results well above the Galactic plane, where we\nexplicitly show how they differ from the epicyclic approximation. In\nparticular, the displacement of resonances in velocity space as a function of\nheight can in principle constrain the 3D structure of the Galactic potential.\nSecond, we allow the perturbation to be time dependent, thereby allowing us to\nmodel the effect of transient spiral arms or a growing bar. The theoretical\nframework and tools presented here will be useful for a thorough analytical\ndynamical modelling of the complex velocity distribution of disc stars as\nmeasured by past and upcoming Gaia data releases. Kazwini_2021 Kazwini et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2012.06597
197 2111.05291 2021-11-09 Y. Tarricq, C. Soubiran, L. Casamiquela, A. Castro-Ginard, J. Olivares, N. Miret-Roig, P. A. B. Galli Structural parameters of 389 local Open Clusters The distribution of member stars in the surroundings of an Open Cluster (OC)\ncan shed light on the process of its formation, evolution and dissolution. The\nanalysis of structural parameters of OCs as a function of their age and\nposition in the Galaxy brings constraints on theoretical models of cluster\nevolution. The Gaia catalogue is very appropriate to find members of OCs at\nlarge distance from their centers. We aim at revisiting the membership lists of\nOCs from the solar vicinity, in particular by extending these membership lists\nto the peripheral areas thanks to Gaia EDR3. We used the clustering algorithm\nHDBSCAN on Gaia parallaxes and proper motions to systematically look for\nmembers up to 50 pc from the cluster centers. We fitted a King's function on\nthe radial density profile of these clusters and a Gaussian Mixture Model on\ntheir two dimensional distribution of members. We also evaluated the degree of\nmass segregation of the clusters. Our methodology performs well on 389 clusters\nout of the 467 selected ones. We report the detection of vast coronae around\nalmost all the clusters and the detection of 71 OCs with tidal tails,\nmultiplying by more than four the number of such structures identified. We find\nthe size of the cores to be on average smaller for old clusters than for young\nones. Also, the overall size of the clusters seems to slightly increase with\nage while the fraction of stars in the halo seems to decrease. As expected the\nmass segregation is more pronounced in the oldest clusters but a clear trend\nwith age is not seen. OCs are more extended than previously expected,\nregardless of their age. The decrease in the proportion of stars populating the\nclusters halos highlights the different cluster evaporation processes and the\nshort timescales they need to affect the clusters. Reported parameters all\ndepend on cluster ages but can not be described as single functions of time. Tarricq_2021 Tarricq et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.05291
198 2111.04126 2021-11-07 Douglas Boubert, Andrew Everall A selection function toolbox for subsets of astronomical catalogues Large catalogues are ubiquitous throughout astronomy, but most scientific\nanalyses are carried out on smaller samples selected from these catalogues by\nchosen cuts on catalogued quantities. The selection function of that scientific\nsample - the probability that a star in the catalogue will satisfy these cuts\nand so make it into the sample - is thus unique to each scientific analysis. We\nhave created a general framework that can flexibly estimate the selection\nfunction of a sample drawn from a catalogue in terms of position, magnitude and\ncolour. Our method is unique in using the binomial likelihood and accounting\nfor correlations in the selection function across position, magnitude and\ncolour using Gaussian processes and spherical harmonics. We have created a new\nopen-source Python package selectionfunctiontoolbox that implements this\nframework and used it to make three different estimates of the APOGEE DR16 red\ngiant sample selection function, as a subset of 2MASS, with each estimate using\nan increasing amount of technical knowledge of the APOGEE targeting. In a\ncompanion paper we applied our methodology to derive estimates of the\nastrometric and spectroscopic selection functions of Gaia EDR3. Our framework\nwill make it trivial for astrophysicists to estimate the selection function\nthat they should be using with the custom sample of stars that they have chosen\nto answer their scientific question. Boubert_2021 Boubert and Everall 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.04126
199 2111.04127 2021-11-07 Andrew Everall, Douglas Boubert Completeness of the Gaia-verse V: Astrometry and Radial Velocity sample selection functions in Gaia EDR3 We risk reaching false scientific conclusions if we test our physical\ntheories against subsets of the Gaia catalogue without correcting for the\nbiased process by which stars make it into our sample. In this paper we produce\nselection functions for three Gaia science samples to enable the community to\ncorrect for this bias. We estimate the probability that a source in Gaia EDR3\nwill have i) a reported parallax and proper motion, ii) an astrometric\nrenormalised unit weight error below 1.4, or iii) a reported radial velocity.\nThese selection functions are estimated as a function of $G$-band apparent\nmagnitude and position on the sky, with the latter two also being dependent on\n$G-G_\mathrm{RP}$ colour. The inferred selection functions have a non-trivial\ndependence on these observable parameters, demonstrating the importance of\nempirically estimating selection functions. We also produce a simple estimate\nfor the selection function of the full Gaia EDR3 source catalogue to be used\nwith the subset selection functions. We make all of our selection functions\neasily accessible through the GitHub repository \textsc{selectionfunctions}. Everall_2021a Everall and Boubert 2021a https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.04127
200 2110.11893 2021-11-07 Martin Netopil, İnci Akkaya Oralhan, Hikmet Çakmak, Raúl Michel, Yüksel Karataş The Galactic metallicity gradient shown by open clusters in the light of radial migration During the last years and decades several individual studies and large-scale\nspectroscopic surveys significantly improved our knowledge of the Galactic\nmetallicity distribution based on open clusters. The availability of Gaia data\nprovided a further step forward in our knowledge. However, still some open\nissues remain, for example the influence of radial migration on the\ninterpretation of the observed gradients. We used spectroscopic metallicities\nfrom individual studies and from the APOGEE survey to compile a sample of 136\nopen clusters, with a membership verification based on Gaia DR2. Additionally,\nwe present photometric metallicity estimates of 14 open clusters in a somewhat\nouter Galactic region. Eight age groups allow us to study the evolution of the\nmetallicity gradient in detail, showing within the errors an almost constant\ngradient of about $-$0.06 dex kpc$^{-1}$. Furthermore, using the derived\ngradients and an analysis of the individual objects, we estimate a mean\nmigration rate of 1 kpc Gyr$^{-1}$ for objects up to about 2 Gyr. Here, the\nchange of the guiding radius is clearly the main contributor. For older and\ndynamically hotter objects up to 6 Gyr we infer a lower migration rate of up to\n0.5 kpc Gyr$^{-1}$. The influence of epicyclic excursions increases with age\nand contributes already about 1 kpc to the total migration distance after 6\nGyr. A comparison of our results with available models shows good agreement.\nHowever, there is still a lack of a suitable coverage of older objects, future\nstudies are still needed to provide a better sampling in this respect. Netopil_2021 Netopil et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2110.11893
201 2110.01475 2021-11-05 J. Maíz Apellániz An estimation of the Gaia EDR3 parallax bias from stellar clusters and Magellanic Clouds data CONTEXT. The Gaia EDR3 parallaxes constitute the most detailed and accurate\ndataset that can be currently used to determine stellar distances in the solar\nneighborhood. Nevertheless, there is still room for improvement in their\ncalibration and systematic effects can be further reduced in some\ncircumstances.\n AIMS. The aim of this paper is to determine an improved Gaia EDR3 parallax\nbias as a function of magnitude, color, and ecliptic latitude using a single\nmethod applied to stars in open clusters, globular clusters, the LMC, and the\nSMC.\n METHODS. I study the behavior of the residuals or differences between the\nindividual (stellar) parallaxes and the group parallaxes, which are assumed\nconstant for the corresponding cluster or galaxy. This is done by first\napplying the Lindegren et al. (2021) zero point and then calculating a new zero\npoint from the residuals of the first analysis.\n RESULTS. The Lindegren zero point shows very small residuals as a function of\nmagnitude between individual and group parallaxes for G < 13 but significant\nones for brighter stars, especially blue ones. The new zero point reduces those\nresiduals, especially in the 9.2 < G < 13 range. The k factor that is used to\nconvert from catalog parallax uncertainties to external uncertainties is small\n(1.1-1.7) for 9.2 < G < 11 and G > 13, intermediate (1.7-2.0) for 11 < G < 13,\nand large (>2.0) for G <9.2. Therefore, significant corrections are needed to\ncalculate distance uncertainties from Gaia EDR3 parallaxes for some stars.\nThere is still room for improvement if future analyses add information from\nadditional stellar clusters, especially for red stars with G < 11 and blue\nstars with G < 9.2. I also calculate k for stars with RUWE values between 1.4\nand 8.0 and for stars with 6-parameter solutions, allowing for a correct\nestiimation of their uncertainties.\n [ABRIDGED] Apellániz_2021b Apellániz 2021b https://arxiv.org/abs/2110.01475
202 2007.12915 2021-11-03 A. B. A. Queiroz, C. Chiappini, A. Perez-Villegas, A. Khalatyan, F. Anders, B. Barbuy, B. X. Santiago, M. Steinmetz, K. Cunha, M. Schultheis, S. R. Majewski, I. Minchev, D. Minniti, R. L. Beaton, R. E. Cohen, L. N. da Costa, J. G. Fernández-Trincado, D. A. Garcia-Hernández, D. Geisler, S. Hasselquist, R. R. Lane, C. Nitschelm, A. Rojas-Arriagada, A. Roman-Lopes, V. Smith, G. Zasowski The Milky Way bar and bulge revealed by APOGEE DR16 and Gaia EDR3 We investigate the inner regions of the Milky Way with a sample of\nunprecedented size and coverage thanks to APOGEE DR16 and Gaia EDR3 data. Our\ninner Galactic sample has more than 26,000 stars within $|X_{\rm Gal}| <5$ kpc,\n$|Y_{\rm Gal}| <3.5$ kpc, $|Z_{\rm Gal}| <1$ kpc, and we also make the analysis\nfor a foreground-cleaned sub-sample of 8,000 stars more representative of the\nbulge-bar populations. The inner Galaxy shows a clear chemical discontinuity in\nkey abundance ratios [$\alpha$/Fe], [C/N], and [Mn/O], probing different\nenrichment timescales, which suggests a star formation gap (quenching) between\nthe high- and low-$\alpha$ populations. For the first time, we are able to\nfully characterize the different populations co-existing in the innermost\nregions of the Galaxy via joint analysis of the distributions of rotational\nvelocities, metallicities, orbital parameters and chemical abundances. The\nchemo-kinematic analysis reveals the presence of the bar; of an inner thin\ndisk; of a thick disk, and of a broad metallicity population, with a large\nvelocity dispersion, indicative of a pressure supported component. We find and\ncharacterize chemically and kinematically a group of counter-rotating stars,\nwhich could be the result of a gas-rich merger event or just the result of\nclumpy star formation during the earliest phases of the early disk, which\nmigrated into the bulge. Finally, based on the 6D information we assign stars a\nprobability value of being on a bar orbit and find that most of the stars with\nlarge bar orbit probabilities come from the innermost 3 kpcs. Even stars with a\nhigh probability of belonging to the bar show the chemical bimodality in the\n[$\alpha$/Fe] vs. [Fe/H] diagram. This suggests bar trapping to be an efficient\nmechanism, explaining why stars on bar orbits do not show a significant\ndistinct chemical abundance ratio signature. Queiroz_2021 Queiroz et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2007.12915
203 2111.02496 2021-11-03 Andrés E. Piatti DECam photometry reveals extra-tidal stars around the Milky Way globular cluster NGC 6864 (M75) Globular clusters are prone to lose stars while moving around the Milky Way.\nThese stars escape the clusters and are distributed throughout extended\nenvelopes or tidal tails. However, such extra-tidal structures are not observed\nin all globular clusters, and yet there is no structural or dynamical\nparameters that can predict their presence or absence. NGC\,6864 is an outer\nhalo globular cluster with reported no observed tidal tails. We used Dark\nEnergy Camera (DECam) photometry reaching $\sim$ 4 mag underneath its main\nsequence turnoff to confidently detect an extra-tidal envelope, and stellar\ndebris spread across the cluster outskirts. These features emerged once robust\nfield star filtering techniques were applied to the fainter end of the observed\ncluster main sequence. NGC\,6864 is associated to the {\it Gaia}-Enceladus\ndwarf galaxy, among others 28 globular clusters. Up-to-date, nearly 64$\%$ of\nthem have been targeted looking for tidal tails and most of them have been\nconfirmed to exhibit tidal tails. Thus, the present outcomes allow us to\nspeculate on the possibility that {\it Gaia}-Enceladus globular clusters share\na common pattern of mass loss by tidal disruption. Piatti_2021 Piatti 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.02496
204 2111.01669 2021-11-02 Camilla C. Borre, Víctor Aguirre Børsen-Koch, Amina Helmi, Helmer H. Koppelman, Martin B. Nielsen, Jakob L. Rørsted, Dennis Stello, Amalie Stokholm, Mark L. Winther, Guy R. Davies, Marc Hon, J. M. Diederik Kruijssen, Chervin Laporte, Claudia Reyes, Jie Yu Age Determination of Galaxy Merger Remnant Stars using Asteroseismology The Milky Way was shaped by the mergers with several galaxies in the past. We\nsearch for remnant stars that were born in these foreign galaxies and assess\ntheir ages in an effort to put upper limits on the merger times and thereby\nbetter understand the evolutionary history of our Galaxy. Using 6D-phase space\ninformation from Gaia eDR3 and chemical information from APOGEE DR16, we\nkinematically and chemically select $23$ red giant stars belonging to former\ndwarf galaxies that merged with the Milky Way. With added asteroseismology from\nKepler and K2, we determine the ages of the $23$ ex-situ stars and $55$ in-situ\nstars with great precision. We find that all the ex-situ stars are consistent\nwith being older than $8$ Gyr. While it is not possible to associate all the\nstars with a specific dwarf galaxy we classify eight of them as\nGaia-Enceladus/Sausage stars, which is one of the most massive mergers in our\nGalaxy's history. We determine their mean age to be $9.5^{+1.2}_{-1.3}$ Gyr\nconsistent with a merger time of $8$-$10$ Gyr ago. The rest of the stars are\npossibly associated with Kraken, Thamnos, Sequoia, or another extragalactic\nprogenitor. The age determination of ex-situ stars paves the way to more\naccurately pinning down when the merger events occurred and hence provide tight\nconstraints useful for simulating how these events unfolded. Borre_2021 Borre et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2111.01669
205 2110.13943 2021-10-26 R. A. P. Oliveira, S. Ortolani, B. Barbuy, L. O. Kerber, F. F. S. Maia, E. Bica, S. Cassisi, S. O. Souza, A. Pérez-Villegas Precise distances from OGLE-IV member RR Lyrae stars in six bulge globular clusters Context. RR Lyrae stars are useful standard candles allowing one to derive\naccurate distances for old star clusters. Based on the recent catalogues from\nOGLE-IV and Gaia Early Data Release 3 (EDR3), the distances can be improved for\na few bulge globular clusters. Aims. The aim of this work is to derive an\naccurate distance for the following six moderately metal-poor, relatively\nhigh-reddening bulge globular clusters: NGC 6266, NGC 6441, NGC 6626, NGC 6638,\nNGC 6642, and NGC 6717. Methods. We combined newly available OGLE-IV catalogues\nof variable stars containing mean I magnitudes, with Clement's previous\ncatalogues containing mean V magnitudes, and with precise proper motions from\nGaia EDR3. Astrometric membership probabilities were computed for each RR\nLyrae, in order to select those compatible with the cluster proper motions.\nApplying luminosity-metallicity relations derived from BaSTI $\alpha$-enhanced\nmodels (He-enhanced for NGC 6441 and canonical He for the other clusters), we\nupdated the distances with relatively low uncertainties. Results. Distances\nwere derived with the I and V bands, with a $5-8\%$ precision. We obtained 6.6\nkpc, 13.1 kpc, 5.6 kpc, 9.6 kpc, 8.2 kpc, and 7.3 kpc for NGC 6266, NGC 6441,\nNGC 6626, NGC 6638, NGC 6642, and NGC 6717, respectively. The results are in\nexcellent agreement with the literature for all sample clusters, considering\nthe uncertainties. Conclusions. The present method of distance derivation,\nbased on recent data of member RR Lyrae stars, updated BaSTI models, and robust\nstatistical methods, proved to be consistent. A larger sample of clusters will\nbe investigated in a future work. Oliveira_2021 Oliveira et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2110.13943

Morgante, N. Morisset, A. Nucita, L. Patrizii, D. Potter, A. Renzi, G. Riccio, A. G. Sanchez, D. Sapone, M. Schirmer, M. Schultheis, V. Scottez, E. Sefusatti, R. Teyssier, O. Tubio, I. Tutusaus, J. Valiviita, M. Viel, H. Hildebrandt Euclid preparation: XVIII. Cosmic Dawn Survey. Spitzer observations of the Euclid deep fields and calibration fields We present a new infrared survey covering the three Euclid deep fields and\nfour other Euclid calibration fields using Spitzer's Infrared Array Camera\n(IRAC). We have combined these new observations with all relevant IRAC archival\ndata of these fields in order to produce the deepest possible mosaics of these\nregions. In total, these observations represent nearly 11% of the total Spitzer\nmission time. The resulting mosaics cover a total of approximately 71.5deg$^2$\nin the 3.6 and 4.5um bands, and approximately 21.8deg$^2$ in the 5.8 and 8um\nbands. They reach at least 24 AB magnitude (measured to sigma, in a 2.5 arcsec\naperture) in the 3.6um band and up to ~ 5 mag deeper in the deepest regions.\nThe astrometry is tied to the Gaia astrometric reference system, and the\ntypical astrometric uncertainty for sources with 16<[3.6]<19 is <0.15 arcsec.\nThe photometric calibration is in excellent agreement with previous WISE\nmeasurements. We have extracted source number counts from the 3.6um band\nmosaics and they are in excellent agreement with previous measurements. Given\nthat the Spitzer Space Telescope has now been decommissioned these mosaics are\nlikely to be the definitive reduction of these IRAC data. This survey therefore\nrepresents an essential first step in assembling multi-wavelength data on the\nEuclid deep fields which are set to become some of the premier fields for\nextragalactic astronomy in the 2020s. Moneti_2021 Moneti et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2110.13928
207 2110.01464 2021-10-16 J. Maíz Apellániz, R. H. Barbá, R. Fernández Aranda, M. Pantaleoni González, P. Crespo Bellido, A. Sota, E. J. Alfaro The Villafranca catalog of Galactic OB groups. II. From Gaia DR2 to EDR3 and ten new systems with O stars CONTEXT. This is the second paper of a series on Galactic OB groups that uses\nastrometric and photometric data from Gaia and spectral classifications from\nGOSSS and LiLiMaRlin. The previous paper was based on Gaia DR2, this is based\non Gaia EDR3.\n AIMS. The two aims of this paper are to revise the results for the sample\nfrom paper I using Gaia EDR3 data and to expand the sample of analyzed stellar\ngroups to 26, from Villafranca O-001 to Villafranca O-026.\n METHODS. We use GOSSS to select Galactic stellar groups with O stars and an\nupdated version of the method in paper 0 of this series, combining Gaia EDR3\nG+GBP+GRP photometry, positions, proper motions, and parallaxes to assign\nmemberships and measure distances. We present 99 spectra from GOSSS and 32 from\nLiLiMaRlin for stars in the analyzed groups or in their foreground.\n RESULTS. We derive distances to the 26 stellar groups with unprecedented\nprecision and accuracy, with total uncertainties <1% within 1 kpc and of ~3%\naround 3 kpc, values that are almost 4x better than for Gaia DR2. We provide\nhomogeneous spectral types for 110 stars and correct a number of errors in the\nliterature, especially for objects in the Orion nebula cluster. For each of the\ngroups we discuss its membership and present possible runaway/walkaway stars.\nAt least two groups, Villafranca O-O12 S and Villafranca O-014 NW, are orphan\nclusters in which the most massive stars have been ejected by dynamical\ninteractions, leaving objects with a capped mass function. The existence of\nsuch clusters has important consequences for the study of the IMF, the\ndistribution of SNe across the Galaxy, and the population and dynamics of\nisolated compact objects. We fit PMS isochrones to four clusters to derive ages\nof 2.0$\pm$0.5 Ma for the sigma Orionis cluster, 4$\pm$2 Ma for NGC 2264,\n5.0$\pm$0.5 Ma for NGC 2362, and 8$\pm$2 Ma for the gamma Velorum cluster.\n [ABRIDGED] Apellániz_2021a Apellániz et al. 2021a https://arxiv.org/abs/2110.01464
208 2110.02081 2021-10-05 J. E. Drew, M. Monguió, N. J. Wright Proper motions of OB stars in the far Carina Arm In large scale maps of the Galactic disc, the Carina Arm stands out as a\nclear spiral feature, hosting prominent star clusters and associations rich in\nmassive stars. We study the proper motions of 4199 O and early B most likely in\nthe far Carina Arm, at distances mainly in excess of 4 kpc from the Sun, within\nthe sky region, $282^{\circ} < \ell < 294^{\circ}$ and $-3^{\circ} < b <\n+1^{\circ}$ (Galactic coordinates). The sample is constructed by extending an\nexisting blue-selected catalogue, and cross-matching with Gaia EDR3 astrometry.\nThe observed pattern of proper motions is modulated into a saw-tooth pattern,\nwith full amplitude approaching 1 mas yr$^{-1}$, recurring roughly every 2--3\ndegrees of longitude (200--300 pc at the median OB-star distance of 5.8 kpc).\nKinematic perturbation of underlying circular rotation is most likely present.\nThe data also reveal a moving group containing $>50$ OB stars at $\ell \sim\n286^{\circ}$, $b \sim -1^{\circ}.4$ behind the main run of the far arm. An\nanalysis of relative proper motions is performed that yields an incidence of\nrunaway O stars of at least 10\% (potentially $>20$\% when full space motions\nbecome available). To map where runaways have run away from, we set up\nsimulations for the region that assume linear trajectories and test for\ntrajectory impact parameter in order to identify likely ejection hot spots. We\nfind the method currently gives good results for times of flight of up to\n$\sim$4 Myr. It shows convincingly that only NGC 3603 and Westerlund 2 have\nejected OB stars in significant numbers. Indeed, both clusters have experienced\nintense spells of ejection between 0.6--0.9 and 0.5--0.8 Myr ago, respectively. Drew_2021 Drew et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2110.02081
209 2107.00188 2021-10-03 Edmundo Moreno, José G. Fernández-Trincado, William J. Schuster, Angeles Pérez-Villegas, Leonardo Chaves-Velasquez Effect of orbital trapping by bar resonances in the local U-V velocity field The effects in the local U-V velocity field due to orbital trapping by bar\nresonances have been studied computing fifteen resonant families in a\nnon-axisymmetric Galactic potential, considering the bar's angular velocity\nbetween 35 and 57.5 ${\rm\,km\,s^{-1}{kpc}^{-1}}$. Only cases in the low, 37.5,\n40 ${\rm\,km\,s^{-1}{kpc}^{-1}}$, and high, 55, 57.5\n${\rm\,km\,s^{-1}{kpc}^{-1}}$, velocity ranges give trapping structures that\nhave some similarity with observed features in the velocity distribution. The\nresulting structures in the local U-V plane form resonant bands appearing at\nvarious levels in velocity V. Cases with angular velocity 40 and 55\n${\rm\,km\,s^{-1}{kpc}^{-1}}$ show the greatest similarity with observed\nbranches. Our best approximation to the local velocity field by orbital\ntrapping is obtained with a bar angular velocity of 40\n${\rm\,km\,s^{-1}{kpc}^{-1}}$ and a bar angle of 40${^\circ}$. With this\nsolution, three main observed features can be approximated: i) the Hercules\nbranch at V=$-50$ ${\rm\,km\,s^{-1}}$ produced by the resonance 8/1 outside\ncorotation, and the close features produced by resonances 5/1 and 6/1, ii) the\nnewly detected low-density arch at V $\simeq$ 40 ${\rm\,km\,s^{-1}}$ produced\napproximately by the resonance 4/3, iii) the inclined structure below the\nHercules branch, also observed in the $\textit{Gaia}$ DR2 data, produced by\ntube orbits around Lagrange point $L_5$ at corotation. Some predicted\ncontributions due to orbital trapping in regions of the U-V plane corresponding\nto the Galactic halo are given, which could help to further restrict the value\nof the angular velocity of the Galactic bar. No support by orbital trapping is\nfound for the Arcturus stream at V $\approx$ $-100$ ${\rm\,km\,s^{-1}}$. Moreno_2021 Moreno et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2107.00188
210 2110.00868 2021-10-02 B. Dias, T. Palma, D. Minniti, J. G. Fernández-Trincado, J. Alonso-García, B. Barbuy, J. J. Clariá, M. Gomez, R. K. Saito FSR 1776: a new globular cluster in the Galactic bulge? (ABRIDGED) Recent near-IR surveys have uncovered a plethora of new globular\ncluster (GC) candidates towards the Milky Way bulge. These new candidates need\nto be confirmed as real GCs and properly characterised. We investigate the\nphysical nature of FSR 1776. This object was originally classified as an\nintermediate-age open cluster and has recently been re-discovered independently\nand classified as a GC candidate (Minni 23). Firstly, we aim at confirming its\nGC nature; secondly we determine its physical parameters. The confirmation of\nthe cluster existence is checked using the radial velocity (RV) distribution of\na MUSE data cube centred at FSR 1776. The cluster parameters are derived from\nisochrone fitting to the RV-cleaned colour-magnitude diagrams (CMDs) from\nvisible and near-infrared photometry. The predicted RV distribution for the FSR\n1776 coordinates, considering only contributions from the bulge and disc field\nstars, is not enough to explain the observed MUSE RV distribution. The extra\npopulation (12\% of the sample) is FSR 1776 with an average RV of $-103.7\pm\n0.4~{\rm km}\,{\rm s}^{-1}$. The CMDs reveal that it is 10$\pm$1~Gyr old and\nmetal-rich, with [Fe/H]$_{phot}\approx + 0.2\pm$0.2,\n[Fe/H]$_{spec}=~+0.02\pm0.01~(\sigma~=~0.14$~dex), located at the bulge\ndistance of 7.24$\pm$0.5~kpc with A$_{\rm V}$ $\approx$ 1.1~mag. The mean\ncluster proper motions are\n($\langle\mu_{\alpha}\rangle,\langle\mu_{\delta}\rangle$) $=$\n($-2.3\pm1.1,-2.6\pm0.8$) ${\rm mas\, yr^{-1}}$.} FSR 1776 is an old GC located\nin the Galactic bulge with a super-solar metallicity, among the highest for a\nGalactic GC. This is consistent with predictions for the age-metallicity\nrelation of the bulge, being FSR 1776 the probable missing link between typical\nGCs and the metal-rich bulge field. High-resolution spectroscopy of a larger\nfield of view and deeper CMDs are now required for a full characterisation. Dias_2021 Dias et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2110.00868
211 2106.03406 2021-10-01 Emma Fernández-Alvar, Georges Kordopatis, Vanessa Hill, Else Starkenburg, Akshara Viswanathan, Nicolas F. Martin, Guillaume F. Thomas, Julio F. Navarro, Khyati Malhan, Federico Sestito, Jonay I. González Hernández, Raymond G. Carlberg The Pristine survey XIII: Uncovering the very metal-poor tail of the thin disc We evaluate the rotational velocity of stars observed by the Pristine survey\ntowards the Galactic anticentre, spanning a wide range of metallicities from\nthe extremely metal-poor regime ($\mathrm{[Fe/H]}<-3$) to nearly solar\nmetallicity. In the Galactic anticentre direction, the rotational velocity\n($V_{\phi}$) is similar to the tangential velocity in the galactic longitude\ndirection ($V_{\ell}$). This allows us to estimate $V_{\phi}$ from Gaia early\ndata-release 3 (Gaia EDR3) proper motions for stars without radial velocity\nmeasurements. This substantially increases the sample of stars in the outer\ndisc with estimated rotational velocities. Our stellar sample towards the\nanticentre is dominated by a kinematical thin disc with a mean rotation of\n$\sim -220$ km $\mathrm{s}^{-1}$. However, our analysis reveals the presence of\nmore stellar substructures. The most intriguing is a well populated extension\nof the kinematical thin disc down to $\mathrm{[Fe/H]} \sim -2$. A scarser fast\nrotating population reaching the extremely metal-poor regime, down to\n$\mathrm{[Fe/H]} \sim -3.5$ is also detected, but without statistical\nsignificance to unambiguously state whether this is the extremely metal-poor\nextension of the thin disc or the high rotating tail of hotter structures (like\nthe thick disc or the halo). In addition, a more slowly rotating kinematical\nthick disc component is also required to explain the observed $V_{\ell}$\ndistribution at $\mathrm{[Fe/H]} > -1.5$. Furthermore, we detect signatures of\na "heated disc", the so-called Splash, at metallicities higher than $\sim-1.5$.\nFinally, at $\mathrm{[Fe/H]} < -1.5$ our anticentre sample is dominated by a\nkinematical halo with a net prograde motion. Fernández-Alvar_2021 Fernández-Alvar et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2106.03406
212 2105.09957 2021-09-27 Emma Dodd, Amina Helmi, Helmer H. Koppelman Substructures, Resonances and debris streams The local stellar halo of the Milky Way contains the debris from several past\naccretion events. Here we study in detail the structure and properties of\nnearby debris associated with the Helmi streams, originally identified as an\noverdensity in integrals of motion space. We use 6D phase-space information\nfrom Gaia EDR3 combined with spectroscopic surveys, and we analyse the orbits\nand frequencies of the stars in the streams using various Galactic potentials.\nWe also explore how the Helmi streams constrain the flattening q, of the\nGalactic dark matter halo. We find that the streams are split into\nsubstructures in integrals of motion space, most notably into two clumps in\nangular momentum space. The clumps have consistent metallicity distributions\nand stellar populations, supporting a common progeny. In all the realistic\nGalactic potentials explored, the Helmi streams stars depict a diffuse\ndistribution close to Omega_z /Omega_R ~0.7. At the same time, the reason for\nthe substructure in angular momentum space appears to be a Omega_z : Omega_phi\nresonance close to the 1:1. This resonance is exactly the 1:1 in the case that\nthe (density) flattening of the dark halo is q = 1.2. For this halo shape the\nsubstructure in angular momenta is also long lasting. Our findings suggest that\nthe structure of the Galactic potential leaves a clear imprint on the\nproperties of phase-mixed debris streams. Dodd_2021 Dodd et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2105.09957
213 2109.13115 2021-09-27 George A. Gontcharov, Maxim Yu. Khovritchev, Aleksandr V. Mosenkov, Vladimir B. Il'in, Alexander A. Marchuk, Sergey S. Savchenko, Anton A. Smirnov, Pavel A. Usachev, Denis M. Poliakov Isochrone fitting of Galactic globular clusters -- III. NGC\,288, NGC\,362, and NGC\,6218 (M12) We present new isochrone fits to colour-magnitude diagrams of the Galactic\nglobular clusters NGC\,288, NGC\,362, and NGC\,6218 (M12). We utilize a lot of\nphotometric bands from the ultraviolet to mid-infrared by use of data from the\n{\it HST}, {\it Gaia}, unWISE, Pan-STARRS, and other photometric sources. In\nour isochrone fitting we use theoretical models and isochrones from the\nDartmouth Stellar Evolution Program and Bag of Stellar Tracks and Isochrones\nfor $\alpha$-enhanced abundance [$\alpha$/Fe]$=+0.40$, different helium\nabundances, and a metallicity of about [Fe/H]$=-1.3$ adopted from the\nliterature. We derive the most probable distances $8.96\pm0.05$, $8.98\pm0.06$,\nand $5.04\pm0.05$ kpc, ages $13.5\pm1.1$, $11.0\pm0.6$, and $13.8\pm1.1$ Gyr,\nextinctions $A_\mathrm{V}=0.08\pm0.03$, $0.11\pm0.04$, and $0.63\pm0.03$ mag,\nand reddenings $E(B-V)=0.014\pm0.010$, $0.028\pm0.011$, and $0.189\pm0.010$ mag\nfor NGC\,288, NGC\,362, and NGC\,6218, respectively. The distance estimates\nfrom the different models are consistent, while those of age, extinction, and\nreddening are not. The uncertainties of age, extinction, and reddening are\ndominated by some intrinsic systematic differences between the models. However,\nthe models agree in their relative age estimates: NGC\,362 is $2.6\pm0.5$ Gyr\nyounger than NGC\,288 and $2.8\pm0.5$ Gyr younger than NGC\,6218, confirming\nage as the second parameter for these clusters. We provide reliable lists of\nthe cluster members and precise cluster proper motions from the {\it Gaia}\nEarly Data Release 3. Gontcharov_2021 Gontcharov et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2109.13115
214 2106.12656 2021-09-21 Alexander P. Ji, Sergey E. Koposov, Ting S. Li, Denis Erkal, Andrew B. Pace, Joshua D. Simon, Vasily Belokurov, Lara R. Cullinane, Gary S. Da Costa, Kyler Kuehn, Geraint F. Lewis, Dougal Mackey, Nora Shipp, Jeffrey D. Simpson, Daniel B. Zucker, Terese T. Hansen, Joss Bland-Hawthorn, S5 Collaboration Kinematics of Antlia 2 and Crater 2 from The Southern Stellar Stream Spectroscopic Survey (S5) We present new spectroscopic observations of the diffuse Milky Way satellite\ngalaxies Antlia 2 and Crater 2, taken as part of the Southern Stellar Stream\nSpectroscopic Survey (S5). The new observations approximately double the number\nof confirmed member stars in each galaxy and more than double the spatial\nextent of spectroscopic observations in Antlia 2. A full kinematic analysis,\nincluding Gaia EDR3 proper motions, detects a clear velocity gradient in Antlia\n2 and a tentative velocity gradient in Crater 2. The velocity gradient\nmagnitudes and directions are consistent with particle stream simulations of\ntidal disruption. Furthermore, the orbit and kinematics of Antlia 2 require a\nmodel that includes the reflex motion of the Milky Way induced by the Large\nMagellanic Cloud. We also find that Antlia 2's metallicity was previously\noverestimated, so it lies on the empirical luminosity-metallicity relation and\nis likely only now experiencing substantial stellar mass loss. Current\ndynamical models of Antlia 2 require it to have lost over 90% of its stars to\ntides, in tension with the low stellar mass loss implied by the updated\nmetallicity. Overall, the new kinematic measurements support a tidal disruption\nscenario for the origin of these large and extended dwarf spheroidal galaxies. 215 2012.12201 2021-09-14 Tomaž Zwitter, Janez Kos, Sven Buder, Klemen Čotar, Martin Asplund, Joss Bland-Hawthorn, Andrew R. Casey, Gayandhi M. De Silva, Valentina D'Orazi, Kenneth C. Beeson, Richard de Grijs, Thomas Nordlander, Yuan-Sen Ting, Gregor Traven, Rok Vogrinčič, Fred Watson, Rob Wittenmyer The GALAH+ Survey: A New Library of Observed Stellar Spectra Improves Radial Velocities and Hints at Motions within M67 GALAH+ is a magnitude-limited survey of high resolution stellar spectra\nobtained by the HERMES spectrograph at the Australian Astronomical Observatory.\nIts third data release provides reduced spectra with new derivations of stellar\nparameters and abundances of 30 chemical elements for 584,015 dwarfs and\ngiants, 88% of them in the Gaia magnitude range 11 < G < 14. Here we use these\nimproved values of stellar parameters to build a library of observed spectra\nwhich is useful to study variations of individual spectral lines with stellar\nparameters. This and other improvements are used to derive radial velocities\nwith uncertainties which are generally within 0.1 km/s or ~25% smaller than in\nthe previous release. Median differences in radial velocities measured here and\nby the Gaia DR2 or APOGEE DR16 surveys are smaller than 30 m/s, a larger offset\nis present only for Gaia measurements of giant stars. We identify 4483 stars\nwith intrinsically variable velocities and 225 stars for which the velocity\nstays constant over >=3 visits spanning more than a year. The combination of\nradial velocities from GALAH+ with distances and sky plane motions from Gaia\nenables studies of dynamics within streams and clusters. For example, we\nestimate that the open cluster M67 has a total mass of ~3300 Msun and its outer\nparts seem to be expanding, though astrometry with a larger time-span than\ncurrently available from Gaia eDR3 is needed to judge if the latter result is\nreal. 216 2106.09531 2021-09-14 A. M. Melnik, A. K. Dambis, E. N. Podzolkova, L. N. Berdnikov Influence of the Galactic bar on the kinematics of the disc stars with Gaia EDR3 data A model of the Galaxy with the outer ring R1R2 can explain the observed\ndistribution of the radial, VR, and azimuthal, VT, velocity components along\nthe Galactocentric distance, R, derived from the Gaia EDR3 data. We selected\nstars from the Gaia EDR3 catalogue with reliable parallaxes, proper motions and\nline-of-sight velocities lying near the Galactic plane, |z|<200 pc, and in the\nsector of the Galactocentic angles |theta|<15 degrees and calculated the median\nvelocities VR and VT in small bins along the distance R. The distribution of\nobserved velocities appears to have some specific features: the radial velocity\nVR demonstrates a smooth fall from +5 km s-1 at the distance of R=R0-1.5 kpc to\n-3 km s-1 at R=R0+1.0 kpc while the azimuthal velocity VT shows a sharp drop by\n7 km s-1 in the distance interval R0 Melnik_2021 Melnik et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2106.09531
217 2108.11922 2021-09-13 F. Gran, M. Zoccali, I. Saviane, E. Valenti, A. Rojas-Arriagada, R. Contreras Ramos, J. Hartke, J. A. Carballo-Bello, C. Navarrete, M. Rejkuba, J. Olivares Carvajal Hidden in the Haystack: Low-luminosity globular clusters towards the Milky Way bulge Recent wide-area surveys have enabled us to study the Milky Way with\nunprecedented detail. Its inner regions, hidden behind dust and gas, have been\npartially unveiled with the arrival of near-IR photometric and spectroscopic\ndatasets. Among recent discoveries, there is a population of low-mass globular\nclusters, known to be missing, especially towards the Galactic bulge. In this\nwork, five new low-luminosity globular clusters located towards the bulge area\nare presented. They were discovered by searching for groups in the\nmulti-dimensional space of coordinates, colours, and proper motions from the\nGaia EDR3 catalogue and later confirmed with deeper VVV survey near-IR\nphotometry. The clusters show well-defined red-giant branches and, in some\ncases, horizontal branches with their members forming a dynamically coherent\nstructure in proper motion space. Four of them were confirmed by spectroscopic\nfollow-up with the MUSE instrument on the ESO VLT. Photometric parameters were\nderived, and when available, metallicities, radial velocities and orbits were\ndetermined. The new clusters Gran 1 and 5 are bulge globular clusters, while\nGran 2, 3, and 4 present halo-like properties. Preliminary orbits indicate that\nGran 1 might be related to the Main Progenitor, or the so-called ''low-energy''\ngroup, while Gran 2, 3 and 5 appear to follow the Gaia-Enceladus-Sausage. This\nstudy demonstrates that the Gaia proper motions, combined with the\nspectroscopic follow-up and colour-magnitude diagrams, are required to confirm\nthe nature of cluster candidates towards the inner Galaxy. High stellar\ncrowding and differential extinction may hide other low-luminosity clusters. Gran_2021 Gran et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2108.11922
218 2107.06294 2021-09-11 Jason A. S. Hunt, Ioana A. Stelea, Kathryn V. Johnston, Suroor S. Gandhi, Chervin F. P. Laporte, Jeroen Bedorf Resolving local and global kinematic signatures of satellite mergers with billion particle simulations In this work we present two new $\sim10^9$ particle self-consistent\nsimulations of the merger of a Sagittarius-like dwarf galaxy with a Milky\nWay-like disc galaxy. One model is a violent merger creating a thick disc, and\na Gaia-Enceladus/Sausage like remnant. The other is a highly stable disc which\nwe use to illustrate how the improved phase space resolution allows us to\nbetter examine the formation and evolution of structures that have been\nobserved in small, local volumes in the Milky Way, such as the $z-v_z$ phase\nspiral and clustering in the $v_{\mathrm{R}}-v_{\phi}$ plane when compared to\nprevious works. The local $z-v_z$ phase spirals are clearly linked to the\nglobal asymmetry across the disc: we find both 2-armed and 1-armed phase\nspirals, which are related to breathing and bending behaviors respectively.\nHercules-like moving groups are common, clustered in $v_{\mathrm{R}}-v_{\phi}$\nin local data samples in the simulation. These groups migrate outwards from the\ninner galaxy, matching observed metallicity trends even in the absence of a\ngalactic bar. We currently release the best fitting `present day' merger\nsnapshots along with the unperturbed galaxies for comparison. Hunt_2021 Hunt et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2107.06294
219 2105.12141 2021-09-10 Diane K. Feuillet, Christian L. Sahlholdt, Sofia Feltzing, Luca Casagrande Selecting accreted populations: metallicity, elemental abundances, and ages of the Gaia-Sausage-Enceladus and Sequoia populations Identifying stars found in the Milky Way as having formed in situ or accreted\ncan be a complex and uncertain undertaking. We use Gaia kinematics and APOGEE\nelemental abundances to select stars belonging to the Gaia-Sausage-Enceladus\n(GSE) and Sequoia accretion events. These samples are used to characterize the\nGSE and Sequoia population metallicity distribution functions, elemental\nabundance patterns, age distributions, and progenitor masses. We find that the\nGSE population has a mean [Fe/H] $\sim -1.15$ and a mean age of $10-12$ Gyr.\nGSE has a single sequence in [Mg/Fe] vs [Fe/H] consistent with the onset of SN\nIa Fe contributions and uniformly low [Al/Fe] of $\sim -0.25$ dex. The derived\nproperties of the Sequoia population are strongly dependent on the kinematic\nselection. We argue the selection with the least contamination is\n$J_{\phi}/J_{\mbox{tot}} < -0.6$ and $(J_z - J_R)/J_{\mbox{tot}} < 0.1$. This\nresults in a mean [Fe/H] $\sim -1.3$ and a mean age of $12-14$ Gyr. The Sequoia\npopulation has a complex elemental abundance distribution with mainly high\n[Mg/Fe] stars. We use the GSE [Al/Fe] vs [Mg/H] abundance distribution to\ninform a chemically-based selection of accreted stars, which is used to remove\npossible contaminant stars from the GSE and Sequoia samples. Feuillet_2021 Feuillet et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2105.12141
220 2104.09737 2021-09-03 Deokkeun An, Timothy C. Beers A Blueprint for the Milky Way's Stellar Populations. III. Spatial Distributions and Population Fractions of Local Halo Stars We analyze the observed spatial, chemical and dynamical distributions of\nlocal metal-poor stars, based on photometrically derived metallicity and\ndistance estimates along with proper motions from the Gaia mission. Along the\nGalactic prime meridian, we identify stellar populations with distinct\nproperties in the metallicity versus rotational velocity space, including Gaia\nSausage/Enceladus (GSE), the metal-weak thick disk (MWTD), and the Splash\n(sometimes referred to as the "in situ" halo). We model the observed\nphase-space distributions using Gaussian mixtures and refine their positions\nand fractional contributions as a function of distances from the Galactic plane\n($|Z|$) and the Galactic center ($R_{\rm GC}$), providing a global perspective\nof the major stellar populations in the local halo. Within the sample volume\n($|Z|<6$ kpc), stars associated with GSE exhibit a larger proportion of\nmetal-poor stars at greater $R_{\rm GC}$ ($\Delta \langle{\rm[Fe/H]}\rangle\n/\Delta R_{\rm GC} =-0.05\pm0.02$ dex kpc$^{-1}$). This observed trend, along\nwith a mild anticorrelation of the mean rotational velocity with metallicity\n($\Delta \langle v_\phi \rangle / \Delta \langle{\rm[Fe/H]} \rangle \sim -10$\nkm s$^{-1}$ dex$^{-1}$), implies that more metal-rich stars in the inner region\nof the GSE progenitor were gradually stripped away, while the prograde orbit of\nthe merger at infall became radialized by dynamical friction. The metal-rich\nGSE stars are causally disconnected from the Splash structure, whose stars are\nmostly found on prograde orbits ($>94\%$) and exhibit a more centrally\nconcentrated distribution than GSE. The MWTD exhibits a similar spatial\ndistribution to the Splash, suggesting earlier dynamical heating of stars in\nthe primordial disk of the Milky Way, possibly before the GSE merger. An_2021 An and Beers 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2104.09737
221 2108.08507 2021-08-19 A. T. Bajkova, V. V. Bobylev Comparison of the Orbital Properties of the Milky Way Globular Clusters from the Data of the Gaia DR2 and EDR3 Catalogs We provide new values of the orbital parameters of 152 globular clusters,\nwhich are calculated using the new mean proper motions obtained from the Gaia\nEDR3 catalog data. The orbits were integrated 5 Gyr back in an axisymmetric\nthree-component potential with a spherical bulge, disk component, and spherical\ndark halo in the Navarro-Frenk-White form, which we refined using the rotation\ncurve of objects with large galactocentric distances up to 200 kpc. The\nobtained orbital parameters were compared with the orbital parameters of the\nsame globular clusters calculated earlier in the same gravitational potential\nusing proper motions from the Gaia DR2 catalog data. The objects whose orbits\nunderwent significant changes were identified. Bajkova_2021 Bajkova and Bobylev 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2108.08507
222 2104.09794 2021-08-09 E. Balbinot, A. Helmi Linking nearby stellar streams to more distant halo overdensities It has been recently shown that the halo near the Sun contains several\nkinematic substructures associated to past accretion events. For the more\ndistant halo, there is evidence of large-scale density variations -- in the\nform of stellar clouds or overdensities. We study the link between the local\nhalo kinematic groups and three of these stellar clouds: the Hercules-Aquila\ncloud, the Virgo Overdensity, and the Eridanus-Phoenix overdensity. We perform\norbital integrations in a standard Milky Way potential of a local halo sample\nextracted from Gaia eDR3, with the goal of predicting the location of the\nmerger debris elsewhere in the Galaxy. We specifically focus on the regions\noccupied by the three stellar clouds and compare their kinematic and distance\ndistributions with those predicted from the orbits of the nearby debris. We\nfind that the local halo substructures have families of orbits that tend to\npile up in the regions where the stellar clouds have been found. The distances\nand velocities of the cloud's member stars are in good agreement with those\npredicted from the orbit integrations, particularly for Gaia-Enceladus stars.\nThis is the dominant contributor of all three overdensities, with a minor part\nstemming from the Helmi streams and to an even smaller extent from Sequoia. The\norbital integrations predict no asymmetries in the sky distribution of halo\nstars, and they pinpoint where additional debris associated with the local halo\nsubstructures may be located. Balbinot_2021 Balbinot and Helmi 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2104.09794
223 2108.02531 2021-08-05 Pete B. Kuzma, Annette M. N. Ferguson, Jorge Peñarrubia Detecting Globular Cluster Tidal Extensions with Bayesian Inference: I. Analysis of $ω$ Centauri with Gaia EDR3 The peripheral regions of globular clusters (GCs) are extremely challenging\nto study due to their low surface brightness nature and the dominance of Milky\nWay contaminant populations along their sightlines. We have developed a\nprobabilistic approach to this problem through utilising a mixture model in\nspatial and proper motion space which separately models the cluster,\nextra-tidal and contaminant stellar populations. We demonstrate the efficacy of\nour method through application to Gaia EDR3 photometry and astrometry in the\ndirection of NGC 5139 ($\omega$ Cen), a highly challenging target on account of\nits Galactic latitude ($b\approx 15^{\circ}$) and low proper motion contrast\nwith the surrounding field. We recover the spectacular tidal extensions,\nspanning the $10^{\circ}$ on the sky explored here, seen in earlier work and\nquantify the star count profile and ellipticity of the system out to a\ncluster-centric radius of $4^{\circ}$. We show that both RR Lyrae and blue\nhorizontal branch stars consistent with belonging to $\omega$ Cen are found in\nthe tidal tails, and calculate that these extensions contain at least $\approx\n0.1$ per cent of the total stellar mass in the system. Our high probability\nmembers provide prime targets for future spectroscopic studies of $\omega$ Cen\nout to unprecedented radii. Kuzma_2021 Kuzma et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2108.02531
224 2107.13199 2021-08-02 Stephanie Monty, Francois Rigaut, Richard McDermid, Holger Baumgardt, Jesse Cranney, Guido Agapito, J. Trevor Mendel, Cedric Plantet, Davide Greggio, Peter B. Stetson, Giuliana Fiorentino, Dionne Haynes Towards Realistic Modeling of the Astrometric Capabilities of MCAO Systems: Detecting an Intermediate Mass Black Hole with MAVIS Accurate astrometry is a key deliverable for the next generation of\nmulti-conjugate adaptive optics (MCAO) systems. The MCAO Visible Imager and\nSpectrograph (MAVIS) is being designed for the Very Large Telescope Adaptive\nOptics Facility and must achieve 150 $\mu$as astrometric precision (50 $\mu$as\ngoal). To test this before going on-sky, we have created MAVISIM, a tool to\nsimulate MAVIS images. MAVISIM accounts for three major sources of astrometric\nerror, high- and low-order point spread function (PSF) spatial variability,\ntip-tilt residual error and static field distortion. When exploring the impact\nof these three error terms alone, we recover an astrometric accuracy of 50\n$\mu$as for all stars brighter than $m=19$ in a 30s integration using\nPSF-fitting photometry. We also assess the feasibility of MAVIS detecting an\nintermediate mass black hole (IMBH) in a Milky Way globular cluster. We use an\nN-body simulation of an NGC 3201-like cluster with a central 1500 M$_{\odot}$\nIMBH as input to MAVISIM and recover the velocity dispersion profile from\nproper motion measurements. Under favourable astrometric conditions, the\ndynamical signature of the IMBH is detected with a precision of ~0.20 km/s in\nthe inner ~4" of the cluster where HST is confusion-limited. This precision is\ncomparable to measurements made by Gaia, HST and MUSE in the outer ~60" of the\ncluster. This study is the first step towards building a science-driven\nastrometric error budget for an MCAO system and a prediction of what MAVIS\ncould do once on sky. Monty_2021 Monty et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2107.13199
225 2107.13979 2021-07-29 P. N. Fedorov, V. S. Akhmetov, A. B. Velichko, A. M. Dmytrenko, S. I. Denischenko Kinematics of the Milky Way from the Gaia EDR3 red giants and sub-giants We present the results of the kinematic investigations carried out with the\nuse of spatial velocities of red giants and sub-giants containing in the\n$Gaia$~EDR3 catalogue. The twelve kinematic parameters of the\nOgorodnikov--Milne model have been derived for stellar systems with radii 0.5\nand 1.0 kpc, located along the direction the Galactic center -- the Sun -- the\nGalactic anticenter within the range of Galactocentric distances $R$\n0--8--16~kpc. By combining some of the local parameters the information related\nto the Galaxy as a whole has been received in the distance range 4--12~kpc, in\nparticular the Galactic rotational curve, its slope, velocity gradients. We\nshow that when using this approach, there is an alternative possibility to\ninfer the behaviour of the Galactic rotational curve and its slope without\nusing the Galactocentric distance $R_\odot$. The kinematic parameters derived\nwithin the Solar vicinity of 1~kpc radius are in good agreement with those\ngiven in literature. Fedorov_2021 Fedorov et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2107.13979
226 2106.15616 2021-07-27 N. Lagarde, C. Reylé, C. Chiappini, R. Mor, F. Anders, F. Figueras, A. Miglio, M. Romero-Gómez, T. Antoja, N. Cabral, J. -B. Salomon, A. C. Robin, O. Bienaymé, C. Soubiran, D. Cornu, J. Montillaud Deciphering the evolution of the Milky Way discs: Gaia APOGEE Kepler giant stars and the Besançon Galaxy Model We investigate the properties of the double sequences of the Milky Way discs\nvisible in the [$\alpha$/Fe] vs [Fe/H] diagram. In the framework of Galactic\nformation and evolution, we discuss the complex relationships between age,\nmetallicity, [$\alpha$/Fe], and the velocity components. We study stars with\nmeasured chemical, seismic and astrometric properties from the APOGEE survey,\nthe Kepler and Gaia satellites, respectively. We separate the\n[$\alpha$/Fe]-[Fe/H] diagram into 3 stellar populations: the thin disc, the\nhigh-$\alpha$ metal-poor thick disc and the high-$\alpha$ metal-rich thick disc\nand characterise each of these in the age-chemo-kinematics parameter space. We\ncompare results obtained from different APOGEE data releases and using two\nrecent age determinations. We use the Besan\c{c}on Galaxy model (BGM) to\nhighlight selection biases and mechanisms not included in the model. The thin\ndisc exhibits a flat age-metallicity relation while [$\alpha$/Fe] increases\nwith stellar age. We confirm no correlation between radial and vertical\nvelocities with [Fe/H], [$\alpha$/Fe] and age for each stellar population.\nConsidering both samples, V$_\varphi$ decreases with age for the thin disc,\nwhile it increases with age for the h$\alpha$mp thick disc. Although the age\ndistribution of the h$\alpha$mr thick disc is very close to that of the\nh$\alpha$mp thick disc between 7 and 14 Gyr, its kinematics seems to follow\nthat of the thin disc. This feature, not predicted by the hypotheses included\nin the BGM, suggests a different origin and history for this population.\nFinally, we show that there is a maximum dispersion of the vertical velocity,\n$\sigma_Z$, with age for the h$\alpha$mp thick disc around 8 Gyr. The\ncomparisons with the BGM simulations suggest a more complex chemo-dynamical\nscheme to explain this feature, most likely including mergers and radial\nmigration effects Lagarde_2021 Lagarde et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2106.15616
227 2107.09987 2021-07-21 E. R. Garro, D. Minniti, M. Gómez, J. Alonso-García Physical characterization of recently discovered globular clusters in the Sagittarius dwarf spheroidal galaxy II. Metallicities, ages and luminosities Globular clusters (GCs) are important tools to rebuild the accretion history\nof a galaxy. There are newly discovered GCs in the Sagittarius (Sgr) dwarf\ngalaxy, that can be used as probes of the accretion event onto the Milky Way\n(MW). Our main aim is to characterize the Sgr GC system by measuring its main\nphysical parameters. We build the optical and near-IR color-magnitude diagrams\n(CMDs) for 21 new Sgr GCs using the VISTA Variables in the Via Lactea Extended\nSurvey (VVVX) near-IR database combined with the Gaia EDR3 optical database. We\nderive metallicities and ages for all targets, using the isochrone-fitting\nmethod and the RGB-slope and metallicity relation. The total luminosities are\ncalculated both in the near-IR and in the optical. We construct the metallicity\ndistribution (MD), the globular cluster luminosity function (GCLF), and the\nage-metallicity relation for the Sgr GC system. We find 17 metal-rich GCs with\n-0.9<[Fe/H]<-0.3, 4 metal-poor GCs with -2.0<[Fe/H]<-1.1 in the new Sgr GC\nsample. Even though our age estimates are rough, we find that the metal-poor\nGCs are consistent with an old population with an average age of ~13 Gyr, while\nthe metal-rich GCs show a wider age range, between 6-8 Gyr and 10-13 Gyr. We\ncompare the MD and the GCLF for the Sgr GC system with those of the MW, M31 and\nLarge Magellanic Cloud (LMC) galaxies. We conclude that the majority of the\nmetal-rich GCs are located within the main body of Sgr galaxy. We confirm that\nthe GCLF is not a universal distribution, since the Sgr GCLF peaks at fainter\nluminosities than the GCLFs of the MW, M31 and LMC. The MD shows a\ndouble-peaked distribution, and we note that the metal-rich population looks\nlike the MW bulge GCs. We compared our results with the literature concluding\nthat the Sgr progenitor could have been a reasonably large galaxy able to\nretain the SNe ejecta, thus enriching its ISM. Garro_2021a Garro et al. 2021a https://arxiv.org/abs/2107.09987
228 2104.09523 2021-07-20 Khyati Malhan, Zhen Yuan, Rodrigo Ibata, Anke Arentsen, Michele Bellazzini, Nicolas F. Martin Evidence of a dwarf galaxy stream populating the inner Milky Way Halo Stellar streams produced from dwarf galaxies provide direct evidence of the\nhierarchical formation of the Milky Way. Here, we present the first\ncomprehensive study of the "LMS-1" stellar stream, that we detect by searching\nfor wide streams in the Gaia EDR3 dataset using the STREAMFINDER algorithm.\nThis stream was recently discovered by Yuan et al. (2020). We detect LMS-1 as a\n$60\deg$ long stream to the north of the Galactic bulge, at a distance of $\sim\n20$ kpc from the Sun, together with additional components that suggest that the\noverall stream is completely wrapped around the inner Galaxy. Using\nspectroscopic measurements from LAMOST, SDSS and APOGEE, we infer that the\nstream is very metal poor (${\rm \langle [Fe/H]\rangle =-2.1}$) with a\nsignificant metallicity dispersion ($\sigma_{\rm [Fe/H]}=0.4$), and it\npossesses a large radial velocity dispersion (${\rm \sigma_v=20 \pm\n4\,km\,s^{-1}}$). These estimates together imply that LMS-1 is a dwarf galaxy\nstream. The orbit of LMS-1 is close to polar, with an inclination of $75\deg$\nto the Galactic plane. Both the orbit and metallicity of LMS-1 are remarkably\nsimilar to the globular clusters NGC 5053, NGC 5024 and the stellar stream\n"Indus". These findings make LMS-1 an important contributor to the stellar\npopulation of the inner Milky Way halo. Malhan_2021 Malhan et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2104.09523
229 2107.08746 2021-07-19 B. Barbuy, E. Cantelli, L. Muniz, S. O. Souza, C. Chiappini, R. Hirschi, G. Cescutti, M. Pignatari, S. Ortolani, L. Kerber, F. F. S. Maia, E. Bica, E. Depagne UVES analysis of red giants in the bulge globular cluster NGC 6522 NGC 6522 is a moderately metal-poor bulge globular cluster\n([Fe/H]$\sim$$-$1.0), and it is a well-studied representative among a number of\nmoderately metal-poor blue horizontal branch clusters located in the bulge. The\nNGC 6522 abundance pattern can give hints on the earliest chemical enrichment\nin the central Galaxy. The aim of this study is to derive abundances of the\nlight elements C and N; alpha elements O, Mg, Si, Ca, and Ti; odd-Z elements Na\nand Al; neutron-capture elements Y, Zr, Ba, La, and Nd; and the r-process\nelement Eu. We verify if there are first- and second-generation stars: we find\nclear evidence of Na-Al, Na-N, and Mg-Al correlations, while we cannot identify\nthe Na-O anti-correlation from our data. High-resolution spectra of six red\ngiants in the bulge globular cluster NGC 6522 were obtained at the 8m VLT\nUT2-Kueyen telescope in FLAMES+UVES configuration. In light of Gaia data, it\nturned out that two of them are non-members, but these were also analysed.\nSpectroscopic parameters were derived through the excitation and ionisation\nequilibrium of FeI and FeII lines from UVES spectra. The abundances were\nobtained with spectrum synthesis. The present analysis combined with previous\nUVES results gives a mean radial velocity of vrhel = -15.62+-7.7 km.s-1 and a\nmetallicity of [Fe/H] = -1.05+-0.20 for NGC 6522. Mean abundances of alpha\nelements for the present four member stars are enhanced with\n [O/Fe]=+0.38, [Mg/Fe]=+0.28, [Si/Fe]=+0.19, and [Ca/Fe]=+0.13, together with\nthe iron-peak element [Ti/Fe]=+0.13, and the r-process element\n[Eu/Fe]=+0.40.The neutron-capture elements Y, Zr, Ba, and La show enhancements\nin the +0.08 < [Y/Fe] < +0.90, 0.11 < [Zr/Fe] < +0.50, 0.00 < [Ba/Fe] < +0.63,\n0.00 < [La/Fe] < +0.45, and -0.10 < [Nd/Fe] < +0.70 ranges. We also discuss the\nspread in heavy-element abundances. Barbuy_2021 Barbuy et al. 2021 https://arxiv.org/abs/2107.08746
230 2102.01076 2021-07-17 Nour Aldein Almusleh, Ali Taani, Sergen Özdemir, Maria Rah, Mashhoor A. Al-Wardat, Gang Zhao, Mohammad K. Mardini Metal-poor Stars Observed with the Automated Planet Finder Telescope. III. CEMP-no Stars are the Descendant of Population III Stars In this study, we report a probabilistic insight into the stellar mass and\nsupernovae (SNe) explosion energy of the possible progenitors of five CEMP-no\nstars. This was done by a direct comparison between the abundance ratios [X/Fe]\nof the light-elements and the predicted nucleosynthetic yields of SN of\nhigh-mass metal-free stars. This comparison suggests possible progenitors with\nstellar mass range of 11 - 22\,M$_{\odot}$ and explosion energies of $0.3 - 1.8\n\times 10^{51}$\,erg. The coupling of the chemical abundances with kinematics\nderived from $Gaia$ DR2 suggests that our sample do not enter the outer-halo\nregion. In addition, we suggest that these CEMP-no stars are not $Gaia$-Sausage\nnor $Gaia$-Sequoia remnant stars, but another accretion event might be\nresponsible for the contribution of these stars to the Galactic Halo of the\nMilky-Way.
