306 2012.04017 2020-12-07 Y. Tarricq, C. Soubiran, L. Casamiquela, T. Cantat-Gaudin, L. Chemin, F. Anders, T. Antoja, M. Romero-Gómez, F. Figueras, C. Jordi, A. Bragaglia, L. Balaguer-Núñez, R. Carrera, A. Castro-Ginard, A. Moitinho, P. Ramos, D. Bossini 3D kinematics and age distribution of the Open Cluster population Open Clusters (OCs) can trace with a great accuracy the evolution of the\nGalactic disk. The aim of this work is to study the kinematical behavior of the\nOC population over time. We take advantage of the latest age determinations of\nOCs to investigate the correlations of the 6D phase space coordinates and\norbital properties with age. We also investigate the rotation curve of the\nMilky Way traced by OCs and we compare it to that of other observational or\ntheoretical studies. We gathered nearly 30000 Radial Velocity (RV) measurements\nof OC members from both Gaia-RVS data and ground based surveys and catalogues.\nWe computed the weighted mean RV, Galactic velocities and orbital parameters of\n1382 OCs. We investigated their distributions as a function of age, and by\ncomparison to field stars. We provide the largest RV catalogue available for\nOCs, half of it based on at least 3 members. Compared to field stars, we note\nthat OCs are not exactly on the same arches in the radial-azimuthal velocity\nplane, while they seem to follow the same diagonal ridges in the Galactic\nradial distribution of azimuthal velocities. Velocity ellipsoids in different\nage bins all show a clear anisotropy. The heating rate of the OC population is\nsimilar to that of field stars for the radial and azimuthal components but\nsignificantly lower for the vertical component. The rotation curve drawn by our\nsample of clusters shows several dips, which match the wiggles derived from\nnon-axisymmetric models of the Galaxy. From the computation of orbits, we\nobtain a clear dependence of the maximum height and eccentricity with age.\nFinally, the orbital characteristics of the sample of clusters as shown by the\naction variables, follow the distribution of field stars. The additional age\ninformation of the clusters points towards some (weak) age dependence of the\nknown moving groups. Tarricq_2020 Tarricq et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2012.04017
307 2012.03908 2020-12-07 Kohei Hattori, Monica Valluri, Eugene Vasiliev Action-based distribution function modelling for constraining the shape of the Galactic dark matter halo We estimate the 3D density profile of the Galactic dark matter (DM) halo\nwithin $r \lesssim 30$ kpc from the Galactic centre by using the astrometric\ndata for halo RR Lyrae stars from Gaia DR2. We model both the stellar halo\ndistribution function and the Galactic potential, fully taking into account the\nsurvey selection function, the observational errors, and the missing\nline-of-sight velocity data for RR Lyrae stars. With a Bayesian MCMC method, we\ninfer the model parameters, including the density flattening of the DM halo\n$q$, which is assumed to be constant as a function of radius. We find that 99\%\nof the posterior distribution of $q$ is located at $q>0.963$, which strongly\ndisfavours a flattened DM halo. We cannot draw any conclusions as to whether\nthe Galactic DM halo at $r \lesssim 30$ kpc is prolate, because we restrict\nourselves to axisymmetric oblate halo models with $q\leq1$. Our result is\ninconsistent with predictions from cosmological hydrodynamical simulations that\nadvocate more oblate ($\langle{q}\rangle \sim0.8 \pm 0.15$) DM halos within\n$\sim 15\%$ of the virial radius for Milky-Way-sized galaxies. An alternative\npossibility, based on our validation tests with a cosmological simulation, is\nthat the true value $q$ of the Galactic halo could be consistent with\ncosmological simulations but that disequilibrium in the Milky Way potential is\ninflating our measurement of $q$ by 0.1-0.2. As a by-product of our analysis,\nour model constrains the DM density in the Solar neighbourhood to be\n$\rho_{\mathrm{DM},\odot} = (9.01^{+0.18}_{-0.20})\times10^{-3}M_\odot\n\mathrm{pc}^{-3} = 0.342^{+0.007}_{-0.007}$ $\;\mathrm{GeV} \mathrm{cm}^{-3}$. Hattori_2020 Hattori et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2012.03908
308 2011.12535 2020-12-07 Benjamin M. Armstrong, Kenji Bekki, Aaron D. Ludlow The orbital evolution of UFDs and GCs in an evolving Galactic potential We use the second Gaia data release to investigate the kinematics of 17\nultra-faint dwarf galaxies (UFDs) and 154 globular clusters (GCs) in the Milky\nWay, focusing on the differences between static and evolving models of the\nGalactic potential. An evolving potential modifies a satellite's orbit relative\nto its static equivalent, though the difference is small compared to existing\nuncertainties on orbital parameters. We find that the UFD Bo\"otes II is likely\non its first passage around the Milky Way. Depending on the assumed mass of the\nMilky Way, the UFDs Triangulum II, Hydrus I, Coma Berenices, Draco II, and Ursa\nMajor II, as well as the GC Pyxis, may also be on first infall so may be useful\nfor constraining the mass of the Galaxy. We identify a clear kinematic\ndistinction between metal-rich (${\rm [Fe/H]}>-1.1$) and metal-poor GCs (${\rm\n[Fe/H]}\leq-1.1$). Although most metal-rich clusters occupy predominately\nprograde orbits, with low eccentricities ($e\approx 0.35$) and similar specific\nangular momenta and orbital planes as the Galactic disc, 7 show potentially\nretrograde orbits, the origin of which is unclear. Metal-poor clusters have\nmore diverse orbits, higher eccentricities ($e\approx 0.65$), and half have\norbital planes offset from the disc by 60 to 120 degrees. The UFDs have similar\n$\theta$ and $\phi$ to the metal-poor GCs, suggesting a similar origin. We\nprovide a catalogue of orbital parameters for UFDs and GCs for two different\nGalaxy masses and their observational uncertainties. Armstrong_2020 Armstrong et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2011.12535
309 2012.01916 2020-12-03 M. Riello, F. De Angeli, D. W. Evans, P. Montegriffo, J. M. Carrasco, G. Busso, L. Palaversa, P. W. Burgess, C. Diener, M. Davidson, N. Rowell, C. Fabricius, C. Jordi, M. Bellazzini, E. Pancino, D. L. Harrison, C. Cacciari, F. van Leeuwen, N. C. Hambly, S. T. Hodgkin, P. J. Osborne, G. Altavilla, M. A. Barstow, A. G. A. Brown, M. Castellani, S. Cowell, F. De Luise, G. Gilmore, G. Giuffrida, S. Hidalgo, G. Holland, S. Marinoni, C. Pagani, A. M. Piersimoni, L. Pulone, S. Ragaini, M. Rainer, P. J. Richards, N. Sanna, N. A. Walton, M. Weiler, A. Yoldas Gaia Early Data Release 3: Photometric content and validation Gaia Early Data Release 3 contains astrometry and photometry results for\nabout 1.8 billion sources based on observations collected by the ESA Gaia\nsatellite during the first 34 months of operations. This paper focuses on the\nphotometric content, describing the input data, the algorithms, the processing,\nand the validation of the results. Particular attention is given to the quality\nof the data and to a number of features that users may need to take into\naccount to make the best use of the EDR3 catalogue. The treatment of the BP and\nRP background has been updated to include a better estimation of the local\nbackground, and the detection of crowding effects has been used to exclude\naffected data from the calibrations. The photometric calibration models have\nalso been updated to account for flux loss over the whole magnitude range.\nSignificant improvements in the modelling and calibration of the point and line\nspread functions have also helped to reduce a number of instrumental effects\nthat were still present in DR2. EDR3 contains 1.806 billion sources with G-band\nphotometry and 1.540 billion sources with BP and RP photometry. The median\nuncertainty in the G-band photometry, as measured from the standard deviation\nof the internally calibrated mean photometry for a given source, is 0.2 mmag at\nmagnitude G=10 to 14, 0.8 mmag at G=17, and 2.6 mmag at G=19. The significant\nmagnitude term found in the Gaia DR2 photometry is no longer visible, and\noverall there are no trends larger than 1 mmag/mag. Using one passband over the\nwhole colour and magnitude range leaves no systematics above the 1% level in\nmagnitude in any of the bands, and a larger systematic is present for a very\nsmall sample of bright and blue sources. A detailed description of the residual\nsystematic effects is provided. Overall the quality of the calibrated mean\nphotometry in EDR3 is superior with respect to DR2 for all bands. Riello_2020 Riello et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2012.01916
310 2009.10097 2020-12-03 Suchira Sarkar, Chanda J. Jog Vertical stellar density distribution in a non-isothermal galactic disc The vertical density distribution of stars in a galactic disc is\ntraditionally obtained by assuming an isothermal vertical velocity dispersion\nof stars. Recent observations from SDSS, LAMOST, RAVE, Gaia etc show that this\ndispersion increases with height from the mid-plane. Here we study the\ndynamical effect of such non-isothermal dispersion on the self-consistent\nvertical density distribution for the thin disc stars in the Galaxy, obtained\nby solving together the Poisson equation and the equation of hydrostatic\nequilibrium. We find that in the non-isothermal case the mid-plane density is\nlower, and the scale height is higher than the corresponding values for the\nisothermal distribution, due to higher vertical pressure, hence the\ndistribution is vertically more extended. The change is ~35% at the solar\nradius for a stars-alone disc for the typical observed linear gradient of +6.7\nkm $s^{-1}kpc^{-1}$ and becomes even higher with increasing radii and\nincreasing gradients explored. The distribution shows a wing at high z, in\nagreement with observations, and is fitted well by a double $sech^{2}$ , which\ncould be mis-interpreted as the existence of a second, thicker disc, specially\nin external galaxies. We also consider a more realistic disc consisting of\ngravitationally coupled stars and gas in the field of dark matter halo. The\nresults show the same trend but the effect of non-isothermal dispersion is\nreduced due to the opposite, constraining effect of the gas and halo gravity.\nFurther, the non-isothermal dispersion lowers the theoretical estimate of the\ntotal mid-plane density i.e, Oort limit value, by 16%. Sarkar_2020 Sarkar and Jog 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2009.10097
311 2012.02036 2020-12-03 Gaia Collaboration, S. A. Klioner, F. Mignard, L. Lindegren, U. Bastian, P. J. McMillan, J. Hernández, D. Hobbs, M. Ramos-Lerate, M. Biermann, A. Bombrun, A. de Torres, E. Gerlach, R. Geyer, T. Hilger, U. Lammers, H. Steidelmüller, C. A. Stephenson, A. G. A. Brown, A. Vallenari, T. Prusti, J. H. J. de Bruijne, C. Babusiaux, O. L. Creevey, D. W. Evans, L. Eyer, A. Hutton, F. Jansen, C. Jordi, X. Luri, C. Panem, D. Pourbaix, S. Randich, P. Sartoretti, C. Soubiran, N. A. Walton, F. Arenou, C. A. L. Bailer-Jones, M. Cropper, R. Drimmel, D. Katz, M. G. Vanel, A. Vecchiato, Y. Viala, D. Vicente, S. Voutsinas, M. Weiler, T. Wevers, Ł. Wyrzykowski, A. Yoldas, P. Yvard, H. Zhao, J. Zorec, S. Zucker, C. Zurbach, T. Zwitter Gaia Early Data Release 3: Acceleration of the solar system from Gaia astrometry Context. Gaia Early Data Release 3 (Gaia EDR3) provides accurate astrometry\nfor about 1.6 million compact (QSO-like) extragalactic sources, 1.2 million of\nwhich have the best-quality five-parameter astrometric solutions.\n Aims. The proper motions of QSO-like sources are used to reveal a systematic\npattern due to the acceleration of the solar system barycentre with respect to\nthe rest frame of the Universe. Apart from being an important scientific result\nby itself, the acceleration measured in this way is a good quality indicator of\nthe Gaia astrometric solution. Methods. The effect of the acceleration is\nobtained as a part of the general expansion of the vector field of proper\nmotions in Vector Spherical Harmonics (VSH). Various versions of the VSH fit\nand various subsets of the sources are tried and compared to get the most\nconsistent result and a realistic estimate of its uncertainty. Additional tests\nwith the Gaia astrometric solution are used to get a better idea on possible\nsystematic errors in the estimate.\n Results. Our best estimate of the acceleration based on Gaia EDR3 is $(2.32\n\pm 0.16) \times 10^{-10}$ m s${}^{-2}$ (or $7.33 \pm 0.51$ km s$^{-1}$\nMyr${}^{-1}$) towards $\alpha = 269.1^\circ \pm 5.4^\circ$, $\delta =\n-31.6^\circ \pm 4.1^\circ$, corresponding to a proper motion amplitude of $5.05\n\pm 0.35$ $\mu$as yr${}^{-1}$. This is in good agreement with the acceleration\nexpected from current models of the Galactic gravitational potential. We expect\nthat future Gaia data releases will provide estimates of the acceleration with\nuncertainties substantially below 0.1 $\mu$as yr${}^{-1}$. Gaia_Collaboration_2020a Gaia Collaboration et al. 2020a https://arxiv.org/abs/2012.02036
312 2012.01213 2020-12-02 Sharmila Rani, Gajendra Pandey, Annapurni Subramaniam, Snehalata Sahu, N. Kameshwara Rao Study of UV bright stellar populations in the globular cluster NGC 1261 using AstroSat We present the UV photometry of the globular cluster NGC 1261 using images\nacquired with the Ultraviolet Imaging Telescope (UVIT) on-board ASTROSAT. We\nperformed PSF photometry on four near-UV (NUV) and two far-UV (FUV) images and\nconstructed UV colour-magnitude diagrams (CMDs), in combination with HST, Gaia,\nand ground-based optical photometry for member stars. We detected the full\nhorizontal branch (HB) in NUV, blue HB in the FUV and identified two extreme HB\n(EHB) stars. HB stars have a tight sequence in UV-optical CMDs well-fitted with\nisochrones generated (12.6 Gyr age, [Fe/H] = -1.27 metallicity) using updated\nBaSTI-IAC models. Effective temperatures (Teff), luminosities and radii of\nbright HB stars were estimated using spectral energy distribution. As we detect\nthe complete sample of UV bright HB stars, the hot end of the HB distribution\nis found to terminate at the G-jump (Teff ~ 11500 K). The two EHB stars, fitted\nwell with single spectra, have Teff= 31,000 K and a mass = 0.495Msun and follow\nthe same Teff-Radius relation of the blue HB stars. We constrain the formation\npathways of these EHB stars to extreme mass loss in the RGB phase (either due\nto rotation or enhanced Helium), OR early hot-flash scenario. Rani_2020 Rani et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2012.01213
313 2012.00036 2020-11-30 Courtney Carter, Charlie Conroy, Dennis Zaritsky, Yuan-Sen Ting, Ana Bonaca, Rohan Naidu, Benjamin Johnson, Phillip Cargile, Nelson Caldwell, Josh Speagle, Jiwon Jesse Han Ancient Very Metal-Poor Stars Associated With the Galactic Disk in the H3 Survey Ancient, very metal-poor stars offer a window into the earliest epochs of\ngalaxy formation and assembly. We combine data from the H3 Spectroscopic Survey\nand Gaia to measure metallicities, abundances of $\alpha$ elements, stellar\nages, and orbital properties of a sample of 482 very metal-poor (VMP;\n[Fe/H]$<-2$) stars in order to constrain their origins. This sample is confined\nto $1\lesssim |Z| \lesssim3$ kpc from the Galactic plane. We find that >70% of\nVMP stars near the disk are on prograde orbits and this fraction increases\ntoward lower metallicities. This result unexpected if metal-poor stars are\npredominantly accreted from many small systems with no preferred orientation,\nas such a scenario would imply a mostly isotropic distribution. Furthermore, we\nfind there is some evidence for higher fractions of prograde orbits amongst\nstars with lower [$\alpha$/Fe]. Isochrone-based ages for main sequence turn-off\nstars reveal that these VMP stars are uniformly old ($\approx12$ Gyr)\nirrespective of the $\alpha$ abundance and metallicity, suggesting that the\nmetal-poor population was not born from the same well-mixed gas disk. We\nspeculate that the VMP population has a heterogeneous origin, including both\nin-situ formation in the ancient disk and accretion from a satellite with the\nsame direction of rotation as the ancient disk at early times. Our precisely\nmeasured ages for these VMP stars on prograde orbits show that the Galaxy has\nhad a relatively quiescent merging history over most of cosmic time, and\nimplies the angular momentum alignment of the Galaxy has been in place for at\nleast 12 Gyr. Carter_2020 Carter et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2012.00036
314 2011.13905 2020-11-27 Iulia T. Simion, Juntai Shen, Sergey E. Koposov, Melissa Ness, Kenneth Freeman, Jonathan Bland-Hawthorn, Geraint F. Lewis Mapping the tilt of the Milky Way bulge velocity ellipsoids with ARGOS and $Gaia$ DR2 Until the recent advent of $Gaia$ Data Release 2 (DR2) and deep multi-object\nspectroscopy, it has been difficult to obtain 6-D phase space information for\nlarge numbers of stars beyond 4 kpc, in particular towards the Galactic centre,\nwhere dust and crowding effects are significant. In this study we combine\nline-of-sight velocities from the Abundances and Radial velocity Galactic\nOrigins Survey (ARGOS) spectroscopic survey with proper motions from $Gaia$\nDR2, to obtain a sample of $\sim$ 7,000 red clump stars with 3-D velocities. We\nperform a large scale stellar kinematics study of the Milky Way (MW) bulge to\ncharacterize the bulge velocity ellipsoids. We measure the tilt $l_{v}$ of the\nmajor-axis of the velocity ellipsoid in the radial-longitudinal velocity plane\nin 20 fields across the bulge. The tilt or vertex deviation, is characteristic\nof non-axisymmetric systems and a significant tilt is a robust indicator of\nnon-axisymmetry or bar presence. We compare the observations to the predicted\nkinematics of an N-body boxy-bulge model formed from dynamical instabilities.\nIn the model, the $l_{v}$ values are strongly correlated with the angle\n($\alpha$) between the bulge major-axis and the Sun-Galactic centre\nline-of-sight. We use a maximum likelihood method to obtain an independent\nmeasurement of $\alpha$, from bulge stellar kinematics alone. The most likely\nvalue of $\alpha$ given our model is $\alpha = (29 \pm 3)^{\circ}$. In the\nBaade's window, the metal-rich stars display a larger vertex deviation ($l_{v}\n= -40^{\circ}$) than the metal-poor stars ($l_{v} = 10^{\circ}$) but we do not\ndetect significant $l_{v}-$metallicity trends in the other fields. Simion_2020 Simion et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2011.13905
315 2011.10525 2020-11-24 Richa Kundu, Camila Navarrete, José G. Fernández-Trincado, Dante Minniti, Harinder P. Singh, Luca Sbordone, Andrés E. Piatti, Céline Reylé The search for extratidal star candidates around Galactic globular clusters NGC 2808, NGC 6266, and NGC 6397 with {\textit{Gaia}} DR2 astrometry Context. Extratidal stars are stellar bodies that end up outside the tidal\nradius of a cluster as a result of internal processes or external forces acting\nupon it. The presence and spatial distribution of these stars can give us\ninsights into the past evolution of a cluster inside our Galaxy. Aims. Previous\nworks suggest that globular clusters, when explored in detail, show evidence of\nextratidal stars. We aim to search for possible extratidal stars in the\nGalactic globular clusters NGC 6397, NGC 2808, and NGC 6266 using the\nphotometry and proper motion measurements from Gaia DR2 database (Gaia\nCollaboration et al. 2018). Results. Finally, 120, 126, and 107 extratidal\ncandidate stars were found lying outside the tidal radius of the globular\nclusters NGC 6397, NGC 2808, and NGC 6266, respectively. 70%, 25.4%, and 72.9%\nof the extratidal stars found are located outside the Jacobi radius of NGC\n6397, NGC 2808, and NGC 6266, respectively. The spatial distribution of the\nextratidal stars belonging to NGC 6397 appears S-like, extending along the\ncurved leading and trailing arms. NGC 2808 has an overdensity of stars in the\ntrailing part of the cluster and NGC 6266 seems to have overdensities of\nextratidal stars in its eastern and northern sides. Conclusions. Proper motions\nand color-magnitude diagrams can be used to identify extratidal candidate stars\naround GCs. Nonetheless, depending on how different the kinematics and stellar\npopulations of a cluster are compared to the Milky Way field, the fraction of\ncontamination can be larger. All three clusters are found to have extratidal\nstars outside their tidal radii. For NGC 6397 and NGC 2808, these stars may be\nthe result of a combined effect of the disc shocks and tidal disruptions. For\nNGC 6266, the distribution of extratidal stars is symmetrical around it, most\nlikely indicating that the cluster has an extended stellar envelope. Kundu_2020 Kundu et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2011.10525
316 1804.09381 2020-11-22 Gaia Collaboration, A. Helmi, F. van Leeuwen, P. J. McMillan, D. Massari, T. Antoja, A. Robin, L. Lindegren, U. Bastian, 445 co-authors Gaia Data Release 2: Kinematics of globular clusters and dwarf galaxies around the Milky Way The goal of this paper is to demonstrate the outstanding quality of the\nsecond data release of the Gaia mission and its power for constraining many\ndifferent aspects of the dynamics of the satellites of the Milky Way. We focus\nhere on determining the proper motions of 75 Galactic globular clusters, nine\ndwarf spheroidal galaxies, one ultra-faint system, and the Large and Small\nMagellanic Clouds. Using data extracted from the Gaia archive, we derived the\nproper motions and parallaxes for these systems, as well as their\nuncertainties. We demonstrate that the errors, statistical and systematic, are\nrelatively well understood. We integrated the orbits of these objects in three\ndifferent Galactic potentials, and characterised their properties. We present\nthe derived proper motions, space velocities, and characteristic orbital\nparameters in various tables to facilitate their use by the astronomical\ncommunity. Our limited and straightforward analyses have allowed us for example\nto (i) determine absolute and very precise proper motions for globular\nclusters; (ii) detect clear rotation signatures in the proper motions of at\nleast five globular clusters; (iii) show that the satellites of the Milky Way\nare all on high-inclination orbits, but that they do not share a single plane\nof motion; (iv) derive a lower limit for the mass of the Milky Way of\n9.8^{+6.7}_{-2.7} x 10^{11} Msun based on the assumption that the Leo I dwarf\nspheroidal is bound; (v) derive a rotation curve for the Large Magellanic Cloud\nbased solely on proper motions that is competitive with line-of-sight velocity\ncurves, now using many orders of magnitude more sources; and (vi) unveil the\ndynamical effect of the bar on the motions of stars in the Large Magellanic\nCloud. All these results highlight the incredible power of the Gaia astrometric\nmission, and in particular of its second data release. Gaia_Collaboration_2020 Gaia Collaboration et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/1804.09381
317 2011.10578 2020-11-20 Douglas Boubert, Andrew Everall, Jack Fraser, Amery Gration, Berry Holl Completeness of the Gaia-verse III: using hidden states to infer gaps, detection efficiencies and the scanning law from the DR2 light curves The completeness of the Gaia catalogues heavily depends on the status of that\nspace telescope through time. Stars are only published with each of the\nastrometric, photometric and spectroscopic data products if they are detected a\nminimum number of times. If there is a gap in scientific operations, a drop in\nthe detection efficiency or Gaia deviates from the commanded scanning law, then\nstars will miss out on potential detections and thus be less likely to make it\ninto the Gaia catalogues. We lay the groundwork to retrospectively ascertain\nthe status of Gaia throughout the mission from the tens of individual\nmeasurements of the billions of stars, by developing novel methodologies to\ninfer both the orientation and angular velocity of Gaia through time and gaps\nand efficiency drops in the detections. We have applied these methodologies to\nthe Gaia DR2 variable star epoch photometry -- which are the only publicly\navailable Gaia time-series at the present time -- and make the results publicly\navailable. We accompany these results with a new Python package scanninglaw\n(https://github.com/gaiaverse/scanninglaw) that you can use to easily predict\nGaia observation times and detection probabilities for arbitrary locations on\nthe sky. Boubert_2020b Boubert et al. 2020b https://arxiv.org/abs/2011.10578
318 2011.10553 2020-11-20 Mark A. Fardal, Roeland van der Marel, Andres del Pino, Sangmo Tony Sohn Mapping Gaia parallax systematic errors over the sky with faint Milky Way stars Parallaxes measured by the Gaia mission have huge significance for astronomy,\nbut parallaxes in Gaia DR2 are known to have systematic errors that depend on\nthe source position and other quantities. We use the abundant information in\nfaint Milky Way stars, along with the GOG simulation of the Gaia catalog, to\nprobe the spatial dependence of Gaia DR2 parallax systematic errors in an\nempirical way. The parallax signal, concentrated in thick disk turnoff stars\nwith magnitude G ~ 17, is sufficient to construct maps of the parallax\nsystematic error over the majority of the sky. These maps show a locally\nregular "waffle pattern" on ~1 degree scales following Gaia scan directions,\nstronger linear "scar" features, and coherent variations on larger scales. The\nparallax bias maps also retain traces of astrophysical effects such as dust\nclouds. The waffle pattern, known from earlier maps of the Magellanic Clouds,\nextends over the entire sky; its local rms amplitude averages 15 microarcsec\nand varies by about a factor of two. The strength of this pattern increases by\na factor ~6 from magnitude G = 13 to G = 20. Correlations with parallaxes of\nquasars and of stars with independent distance estimates support our bias\nestimates. Using similar methods, we map systematic errors in the proper motion\nand examine the relationship with the parallax systematics. We provide a code\npackage to access and query our bias maps. Similar tests on the general stellar\npopulation should be useful in quantifying systematic errors in future Gaia\nreleases. Fardal_2020 Fardal et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2011.10553
319 2011.09812 2020-11-19 R. V. Baluev, V. Sh. Shaidulin, A. V. Veselova High-velocity moving groups in the Solar neighborhood in Gaia DR2 We use an improved wavelet analysis technique to reconstruct the $(U,V,W)$\nvelocity distribution for $\sim 250000$ stars from Gaia DR2, residing in the\nsolar neighborhood of $200$~pc. The 2D wavelet transforms for three bivariate\ndistributions $(U,V)$, $(U,W)$, and $(V,W)$ were investigated. Though most of\ncurrently known (low-velocity) stellar moving groups are densely overlapped in\nthese diagrams, our analysis allowed to detect and disentangle about twenty\nstatistically significant 3D groups of stars with high velocities. Most of them\nappear new. We also discuss the issue of correct noise thresholding in the\nwavelet transform and highlight the importance of using a global rather than\nlocal statistic for that. Using of a local significance measure may lead to an\noverstated statistical confidence for individual patterns due to the effect of\nmultiple testing. Baluev_2020 Baluev et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2011.09812
320 1912.04304 2020-11-14 Rimpei Chiba, Jennifer K. S. Friske, Ralph Schönrich Resonance sweeping by a decelerating Galactic bar We provide the first quantitative evidence for the deceleration of the\nGalactic bar from local stellar kinematics in agreement with dynamical friction\nby a typical dark matter halo. The kinematic response of the stellar disk to a\ndecelerating bar is studied using secular perturbation theory and test particle\nsimulations. We show that the velocity distribution at any point in the disk\naffected by a naturally slowing bar is qualitatively different from that\nperturbed by a steadily rotating bar with the same current pattern speed\n$\Omega_{\rm p}$ and amplitude. When the bar slows down, its resonances sweep\nthrough phase space, trapping and dragging along a portion of previously free\norbits. This enhances occupation on resonances, but also changes the\ndistribution of stars within the resonance. Due to the accumulation of orbits\nnear the boundary of the resonance, the decelerating bar model reproduces with\nits corotation resonance the offset and strength of the Hercules stream in the\nlocal $v_R$-$v_\varphi$ plane and the double-peaked structure of mean $v_R$ in\nthe $L_z$-$\varphi$ plane. At resonances other than the corotation, resonant\ndragging by a slowing bar is associated with a continuing increase in radial\naction, leading to multiple resonance ridges in the action plane as identified\nin the Gaia data. This work shows models using a constant bar pattern speed\nlikely lead to qualitatively wrong conclusions. Most importantly we provide a\nquantitative estimate of the current slowing rate of the bar $d\Omega_{\rm\np}/dt = (-4.5 \pm 1.4)~{\rm km} {\rm s}^{-1} {\rm kpc}^{-1} {\rm Gyr}^{-1}$\nwith additional systematic uncertainty arising from unmodeled impacts of e.g.\nspiral arms. Chiba_2020 Chiba et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/1912.04304
321 2011.05732 2020-11-11 Jairo A. Alzate, Gustavo Bruzual, Daniel J. Díaz-González Star formation history of the solar neighbourhood as told by Gaia The Gaia DR2 catalog is the best source of stellar astrometric and\nphotometric data available today. The history of the Milky Way galaxy is\nwritten in stone in this data set. Parallaxes and photometry tell us where the\nstars are today, when were they formed, and with what chemical content, i.e.\ntheir star formation history (SFH). We develop a Bayesian hierarchical model\nsuited to reconstruct the SFH of a resolved stellar population. We study the\nstars brighter than $G\,=\,15$ within 100 pc of the Sun in Gaia DR2 and derive\na SFH of the solar neighbourhood in agreement with previous determinations and\nimproving upon them because we detect chemical enrichment. Our results show a\nmaximum of star formation activity about 10 Gyr ago, producing large numbers of\nstars with slightly below solar metallicity (Z=0.014), followed by a decrease\nin star formation up to a minimum level occurring around 8 Gyr ago. After a\nquiet period, star formation rises to a maximum at about 5 Gyr ago, forming\nstars of solar metallicity (Z=0.017). Finally, star formation has been\ndecreasing until the present, forming stars of Z=0.03 at a residual level. We\ntest the effects introduced in the inferred SFH by ignoring the presence of\nunresolved binary stars in the sample, reducing the apparent limiting\nmagnitude, and modifying the stellar initial mass function. Alzate_2020 Alzate et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2011.05732
322 2010.06603 2020-11-10 Maria Gabriela Navarro, Dante Minniti, Roberto Capuzzo-Dolcetta, Javier Alonso-Garcia, Rodrigo Contreras Ramos, Daniel Majaess, Vincenzo Ripepi The RR Lyrae projected density distribution from the Galactic centre to the halo The projected density distribution of type ab RR Lyrae (RRab) stars was\ncharacterised from the innermost regions of the Milky Way to the halo, with the\naim of placing constraints on the Galaxys evolution. The compiled sample\n(N_RRab = 64,850) stems from fundamental mode RR Lyrae variables identified by\nthe VVV, OGLE, and Gaia surveys. The distribution is well fitted by three power\nlaws over three radial intervals. In the innermost region (R < 2.2 deg) the\ndistribution follows Sigma_RRab[1] propto R ^(-0.94 +- 0.051), while in the\nexternal region the distribution adheres to Sigma_RRab[2] propto R^(-1.50 +-\n0.019) for 2.2 deg< R <8.0 deg and Sigma_RRab[3] propto R ^(-2.43 +- 0.043) for\n8.0 deg < R <30.0 deg. Conversely, the cumulative distribution of red clump\n(RC) giants exhibits a more concentrated distribution in the mean, but in the\ncentral R < 2.2 deg the RRab population is more peaked, whereas globular\nclusters (GCs) follow a density power law (Sigma_GCs propto R ^(-1.59 +- 0.060)\nfor R<30.0 deg) similar to that of RRab stars, especially when considering a\nmore metal-poor subsample ([Fe/H]<-1.1 dex). The main conclusion emerging from\nthe analysis is that the RRab distribution favours the star cluster infall and\nmerger scenario for creating an important fraction (>18 %) of the central\nGalactic region. The radii containing half of the populations (half populations\nradii) are R_H=6.8 deg (0.99 kpc), R_H =4.2 deg (0.61 kpc), and R_H =11.9 deg\n(1.75 kpc) for the RRab stars, RC giants, and GCs, respectively. Finally,\nmerely 1% of the stars have been actually discovered in the innermost region (R\n< 35 pc) out of the expected (based on our considerations) total number of RRab\ntherein: N sim 1,562. That deficit will be substantially ameliorated with\nfuture space missions like the Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope (formerly\nWFIRST). Navarro_2020 Navarro et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2010.06603
323 2011.02042 2020-11-03 Joel Pfeffer, Carmela Lardo, Nate Bastian, Sara Saracino, Sebastian Kamann The Accreted Nuclear Clusters of the Milky Way A number of the massive clusters in the halo, bulge and disc of the Galaxy\nare not genuine globular clusters (GCs), but instead are different beasts\naltogether. They are the remnant nuclear star clusters (NSCs) of ancient\ngalaxies since accreted by the Milky Way. While some clusters are readily\nidentifiable as NSCs, and can be readily traced back to their host galaxy\n(e.g., M54 and the Sagittarius Dwarf galaxy) others have proven more elusive.\nHere we combine a number of independent constraints, focusing on their internal\nabundances and overall kinematics, to find NSCs accreted by the Galaxy and\ntrace them to their accretion event. We find that the true NSCs accreted by the\nGalaxy are: M54 from the Sagittarius Dwarf, $\omega$ Centari from\nGaia-Enceladus/Sausage, NGC 6273 from Kraken and (potentially) NGC 6934 from\nthe Helmi Streams. These NSCs are prime candidates for searches of intermediate\nmass black holes (BHs) within star clusters, given the common occurrence of\ngalaxies hosting both NSCs and central massive BHs. No NSC appears to be\nassociated with Sequoia or other minor accretion events. Other claimed NSCs are\nshown not to be such. We also discuss the peculiar case of Terzan 5, which may\nrepresent a unique case of a cluster-cluster merger. Pfeffer_2020a Pfeffer et al. 2020a https://arxiv.org/abs/2011.02042
324 2011.01241 2020-11-02 P. Ramos, T. Antoja, C. Mateu, F. Anders, C. F. P. Laporte, J. A. Carballo-Bello, B. Famaey, R. Ibata The outer disc in shambles: blind detection of Monoceros and ACS with Gaia's astrometric sample The astrometric sample of Gaia allows us to study the outermost Galactic\ndisc, the halo and their interface. It is precisely at the very edge of the\ndisc where the effects of external perturbations are expected to be the most\nnoticeable. Our goal is to detect the kinematic substructure present in the\nhalo and at the edge of the Milky Way (MW) disc, and provide observational\nconstraints on their phase-space distribution. We download, one HEALpix at a\ntime, the proper motion histogram of distant stars, to which we apply a Wavelet\nTransformation to reveal the significant overdensities. We then analyse the\nlarge coherent structures that appear in the sky. We reveal a sharp yet complex\nanticentre dominated by Monoceros (MNC) and the Anticentre Stream (ACS) in the\nnorth, which we find with an intensity comparable to the Magellanic clouds and\nthe Sagittarius stream, and by MNC south and TriAnd at negative latitudes. Our\nmethod allows us to perform a morphological analysis of MNC and ACS, both\nspanning more than 100$^\circ$ in longitude, and to provide a high purity\nsample of giants with which we track MNC down to latitudes as low as\n$\sim$5$^\circ$. Their colour-magnitude diagram is consistent with extended\nstructures at a distance of $\sim$10-11 kpc originated in the disc, with a very\nlow ratio of RR Lyrae over M giants, and kinematics compatible with the\nrotation curve at those distances or only slightly slower. We present a precise\ncharacterisation of MNC and ACS, two previously known structures that our\nmethod reveals naturally, allowing us to detect them without limiting ourselves\nto a particular stellar type and, for the first time, using only kinematics.\nOur results allow future studies to model their chemo-dynamics and evolution,\nthus constraining some of the most influential processes that shaped the MW. Ramos_2020a Ramos et al. 2020a https://arxiv.org/abs/2011.01241
325 2005.14014 2020-11-02 Kuan-Wei Huang, Sergey E. Koposov Search for globular clusters associated with the Milky Way dwarf galaxies using Gaia DR2 We report the result of searching for globular clusters (GCs) around 55 Milky\nWay satellite dwarf galaxies within the distance of 450 kpc from the Galactic\nCenter except for the Large and Small Magellanic Clouds and the Sagittarius\ndwarf. For each dwarf, we analyze the stellar distribution of sources in Gaia\nDR2, selected by magnitude, proper motion, and source morphology. Using the\nkernel density estimation of stellar number counts, we identify eleven possible\nGC candidates. Crossed-matched with existing imaging data, all eleven objects\nare known either GCs or galaxies and only Fornax GC 1-6 among them are\nassociated with the targeted dwarf galaxy. Using simulated GCs, we calculate\nthe GC detection limit $M_{\rm V}^{\rm lim}$ that spans the range from $M_{\rm\nV}^{\rm lim} \sim -7$ for distant dwarfs to $M_{\rm V}^{\rm lim} \sim 0$ for\nnearby systems. Assuming a Gaussian GC luminosity function, we compute that the\ncompleteness of the GC search is above 90 percent for most dwarf galaxies. We\nconstruct the 90 percent credible intervals/upper limits on the GC specific\nfrequency $S_{\rm N}$ of the MW dwarf galaxies: $12 < S_{\rm N} < 47$ for\nFornax, $S_{\rm N} < 20$ for the dwarfs with $-12 < M_{\rm V} < -10$, $S_{\rm\nN} < 30$ for the dwarfs with $-10 < M_{\rm V} < -7$, and $S_{\rm N} < 90$ for\nthe dwarfs with $M_{\rm V} > -7$. Based on $S_{\rm N}$, we derive the\nprobability of galaxies hosting GCs given their luminosity, finding that the\nprobability of galaxies fainter than $M_{\rm V} = -9$ to host GCs is lower than\n0.1. Huang_2020a Huang and Koposov 2020a https://arxiv.org/abs/2005.14014
326 2004.14806 2020-11-02 Andrea Miglio, Cristina Chiappini, Ted Mackereth, Guy Davies, Karsten Brogaard, Luca Casagrande, Bill Chaplin, Leo Girardi, Daisuke Kawata, Saniya Khan, Rob Izzard, Josefina Montalban, Benoit Mosser, Fiorenzo Vincenzo, Diego Bossini, Arlette Noels, Thaise Rodrigues, Marica Valentini, Ilya Mandel Age dissection of the Milky Way discs: red giants in the Kepler field [Abridged] Ensemble studies of red-giant stars with exquisite asteroseismic,\nspectroscopic, and astrometric constraints offer a novel opportunity to recast\nand address long-standing questions concerning the evolution of stars and of\nthe Galaxy. Here, we infer masses and ages for nearly 5400 giants with\navailable Kepler light curves and APOGEE spectra, and discuss some of the\nsystematics that may affect the accuracy of the inferred stellar properties.\nFirst, we look at age-chemical-abundances relations. We find a dearth of young,\nmetal-rich stars, and the existence of a significant population of old (8-9\nGyr), low-[$\alpha$/Fe], super-solar metallicity stars, reminiscent of the age\nand metallicity of the well-studied open cluster NGC6791. The\nage-chemo-kinematic properties of these stars indicate that efficient radial\nmigration happens in the thin disk. We find that ages and masses of the nearly\n400 $\alpha$-element-rich red-giant-branch (RGB) stars in our sample are\ncompatible with those of an old (~11 Gyr), nearly coeval, chemical-thick disk\npopulation. Using a statistical model, we show that 95% of the population was\nborn within ~1.5 Gyr. Moreover, we find a difference in the vertical velocity\ndispersion between low- and high-[$\alpha$/Fe] populations, confirming their\ndifferent chemo-dynamical histories. We then exploit the almost coeval\n$\alpha$-rich population to gain insight into processes that may have altered\nthe mass of a star along its evolution, which are key to improve the mapping of\nthe observed stellar mass to age. We find evidence for a mean integrated RGB\nmass loss <$\Delta$M>= 0.10 $\pm$ 0.02 Msun and that the occurrence of massive\n(M $\gtrsim$ 1.1 Msun) $\alpha$-rich stars is of the order of 5% on the RGB,\nand significantly higher in the RC, supporting the scenario in which most of\nthese stars had undergone interaction with a companion. Miglio_2020 Miglio et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2004.14806
327 2004.12666 2020-11-02 G. Guiglion, G. Matijevic, A. B. A. Queiroz, M. Valentini, M. Steinmetz, C. Chiappini, E. K. Grebel, P. J. McMillan, G. Kordopatis, A. Kunder, T. Zwitter, A. Khalatyan, F. Anders, H. Enke, I. Minchev, G. Monari, R. F. G. Wyse, O. Bienayme, J. Bland-Hawthorn, B. K. Gibson, J. F. Navarro, Q. Parker, W. Reid, G. M. Seabroke, A. Siebert The RAdial Velocity Experiment (RAVE): Parameterisation of RAVE spectra based on convolutional neural networks In the context of large spectroscopic surveys of stars, data-driven methods\nare key in deducing physical parameters for millions of spectra in a short\ntime. Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) enable us to connect observables\n(e.g. spectra, stellar magnitudes) to physical properties (atmospheric\nparameters, chemical abundances, or labels in general). We trained a CNN,\nadopting stellar atmospheric parameters and chemical abundances from APOGEE\nDR16 (resolution R=22500) data as training set labels. As input, we used parts\nof the intermediate-resolution RAVE DR6 spectra (R~7500) overlapping with the\nAPOGEE DR16 data as well as broad-band ALL_WISE and 2MASS photometry, together\nwith Gaia DR2 photometry and parallaxes. We derived precise atmospheric\nparameters Teff, log(g), and [M/H] along with the chemical abundances of\n[Fe/H], [alpha/M], [Mg/Fe], [Si/Fe], [Al/Fe], and [Ni/Fe] for 420165 RAVE\nspectra. The precision typically amounts to 60K in Teff, 0.06 in log(g) and\n0.02-0.04 dex for individual chemical abundances. Incorporating photometry and\nastrometry as additional constraints substantially improves the results in\nterms of the accuracy and precision of the derived labels. We provide a\ncatalogue of CNN-trained atmospheric parameters and abundances along with their\nuncertainties for 420165 stars in the RAVE survey. CNN-based methods provide a\npowerful way to combine spectroscopic, photometric, and astrometric data\nwithout the need to apply any priors in the form of stellar evolutionary\nmodels. The developed procedure can extend the scientific output of RAVE\nspectra beyond DR6 to ongoing and planned surveys such as Gaia RVS, 4MOST, and\nWEAVE. We call on the community to place a particular collective emphasis and\non efforts to create unbiased training samples for such future spectroscopic\nsurveys. Guiglion_2020 Guiglion et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2004.12666
328 2011.01189 2020-11-02 G. Cordoni, G. S. Da Costa, D. Yong, A. D. Mackey, A. F. Marino, S. Monty, T. Nordlander, J. E. Norris, M. Asplund, M. S. Bessell, A. R. Casey, A. Frebel, K. Lind, S. J. Murphy, B. P. Schmidt, X. D. Gao, T. Xylakis-Dornbusch, A. M. Amarsi, A. P. Milone Exploring the Galaxy's halo and very metal-weak thick disk with SkyMapper and Gaia DR2 In this work we combine spectroscopic information from the \textit{SkyMapper\nsurvey for Extremely Metal-Poor stars} and astrometry from Gaia DR2 to\ninvestigate the kinematics of a sample of 475 stars with a metallicity range of\n$ -6.5 \leq \rm [Fe/H] \leq -2.05$ dex. Exploiting the action map, we identify\n16 and 40 stars dynamically consistent with the \textit{Gaia Sausage} and\n\textit{Gaia Sequoia} accretion events, respectively. The most metal-poor of\nthese candidates have metallicities of $\rm [Fe/H]=-3.31$ and $\rm\n[Fe/H]=-3.74$, respectively, helping to define the low-metallicity tail of the\nprogenitors involved in the accretion events. We also find, consistent with\nother studies, that $\sim$21\% of the sample have orbits that remain confined\nto within 3~kpc of the Galactic plane, i.e., |Z$_{max}$| $\leq$ 3~kpc. Of\nparticular interest is a sub-sample ($\sim$11\% of the total) of low\n|Z$_{max}$| stars with low eccentricities and prograde motions. The lowest\nmetallicity of these stars has [Fe/H] = --4.30 and the sub-sample is best\ninterpreted as the very low-metallicity tail of the metal-weak thick disk\npopulation. The low |Z$_{max}$|, low eccentricity stars with retrograde orbits\nare likely accreted, while the low |Z$_{max}$|, high eccentricity pro- and\nretrograde stars are plausibly associated with the \textit{Gaia Sausage}\nsystem. We find that a small fraction of our sample ($\sim$4\% of the total) is\nlikely escaping from the Galaxy, and postulate that these stars have gained\nenergy from gravitational interactions that occur when infalling dwarf galaxies\nare tidally disrupted. Cordoni_2020 Cordoni et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2011.01189
329 2010.15381 2020-10-30 Tanuka Chattopadhyay, Sreerup Mondal, Suman Paul, Subhadip Maji, Asis Kumar Chattopadhyay Exploration about the origin of galactic and extragalactic star clusters through simulated H-R diagrams The present work explores the origin of the formation of star clusters in our\nGalaxy and in Small Magellanic Cloud (SMC) through simulated H-R diagrams and\ncompare those with observed star clusters. The simulation study produces\nsynthetic H-R diagrams by Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) technique using star\nformation history (SFH), luminosity function (LF), abundance of heavy metal (Z)\nand a big library of isochrones as basic inputs and compares them with observed\nH-R diagrams of various star clusters. The distance based comparison between\nthose two diagrams is carried out through two dimensional matching of points in\nColor-Magnitude Diagram (CMD) after optimal choice of bin size and appropriate\ndistance function. It is found that a poor medium of heavy elements (Z =\n0.0004), Gaia LF along with mixture of multiple Gaussian distributions of SFH\nmay be the origin of formation of globular clusters (GCs). On the contrary,\nenriched medium (Z = 0.019) is favoured with Gaia LF along with double power\nlaw (i.e. unimodal) SFH. For SMC clusters, the choice of exponential LF and\nexponential SFH is a proper combination for poor medium whereas Gaia LF with\nBeta type SFH is preferred in an enriched medium for the formation of star\nclusters. Chattopadhyay_2020 Chattopadhyay et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2010.15381
330 2010.14281 2020-10-27 Hefan Li, Cuihua Du, Yanbin Yang, Heidi Jo Newberg, Jun Ma, Jianrong Shi, Yunsong Piao Two substructures in the nearby stellar halo found in Gaia and RAVE We use the second Gaia data release (Gaia DR2), combined with RAVE\nspectroscopic surveys, to identify the substructures in the nearby stellar\nhalo. We select 3,845 halo stars kinematically and chemically, and determine\ntheir density distribution in energy and angular momentum space. To select the\nsubstructures from overdensities, we reshuffle the velocities and estimate\ntheir significance. Two statistically significant substructures, GR-1 and GR-2,\nare identified. GR-1 has a high binding energy and small $z$-angular momentum.\nGR-2 is metal-rich but retrograde. They are both new substructure, and may be\naccretion debris of dwarf galaxies. Li_2020a Li et al. 2020a https://arxiv.org/abs/2010.14281
331 1905.01193 2020-10-27 C. G. Palau, J. Miralda-Escudé Statistical detection of a tidal stream associated with the globular cluster M68 using Gaia data A method to search for tidal streams and to fit their orbits based on maximum\nlikelihood is presented and applied to the Gaia data. Tests of the method are\nperformed showing how a simulated stream produced by tidal stripping of a star\ncluster is recovered when added to a simulation of the Gaia catalogue. The\nmethod can be applied to search for streams associated with known progenitors\nor to do blind searches in a general catalogue. As the first example, we apply\nthe method to the globular cluster M68 and detect its clear tidal stream\nstretching over the whole North Galactic hemisphere, and passing within 5 kpc\nof the Sun. This is one of the closest tidal streams to us detected so far, and\nis highly promising to provide new constraints on the Milky Way gravitational\npotential, for which we present preliminary fits finding a slightly oblate dark\nhalo consistent with other observations. We identify the M68 tidal stream with\nthe previously discovered Fj\"orm stream by Ibata et al. The tidal stream is\nconfirmed to contain stars that are consistent with the HR-diagram of M68. We\nprovide a list of 115 stars that are most likely to be stream members, and\nshould be prime targets for follow-up spectroscopic studies. Palau_2020 Palau and Miralda-Escudé 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.01193
332 2010.14279 2020-10-27 Yepeng Yan, Cuihua Du, Hefan Li, Jianrong Shi, Jun Ma, Heidi Jo Newberg Existence of the Metal-Rich Stellar Halo and High-velocity Thick Disk in the Galaxy Based on the second Gaia data release (DR2), combined with the LAMOST and\nAPOGEE spectroscopic surveys, we study the kinematics and metallicity\ndistribution of the high-velocity stars that have a relative speed of at least\n220 ${\rm km\ s^{-1}}$ with respect to the local standard of rest in the\nGalaxy. The rotational velocity distribution of the high-velocity stars with\n[Fe/H] $>-1.0$ dex can be well described by a two-Gaussian model, with peaks at\n$V_{\phi}\sim +164.2\pm0.7$ and $V_{\phi}\sim +3.0\pm0.3$ ${\rm km\ s^{-1}}$,\nassociated with the thick disk and halo, respectively. This implies that there\nshould exist a high-velocity thick disk (HVTD) and a metal-rich stellar halo\n(MRSH) in the Galaxy. The HVTD stars have the same position as the halo in the\nToomre diagram and but show the same rotational velocity and metallicity as the\ncanonical thick disk. The MRSH stars have basically the same rotational\nvelocity, orbital eccentricity, and position in the Lindblad and Toomre diagram\nas the canonical halo stars, but they are more metal-rich. Furthermore, the\nmetallicity distribution function (MDF) of our sample stars are well fitted by\na four-Gaussian model, associated with the outer-halo, inner-halo, MRSH, and\nHVTD, respectively. Chemical and kinematic properties and age imply that the\nMRSH and HVTD stars may form in situ. Yan_2020 Yan et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2010.14279
333 2010.14092 2020-10-27 H. -L. Guo, B. -Q. Chen, H. -B. Yuan, Y. Huang, D. -Z Liu, Y. Yang, X. -Y. Li, W. -X. Sun, X. -W. Liu Three-Dimensional Distribution of the Interstellar Dust in the Milky Way We present a three-dimensional (3D) extinction map of the southern sky. The\nmap covers the SkyMapper Southern Survey (SMSS) area of $\sim$ 14,000 ${\rm\ndeg^{2}}$ and has spatial resolutions between 6.9 and 27 arcmin. Based on the\nmulti-band photometry of SMSS, the Two Micron All Sky Survey, the Wide-Field\nInfrared Survey Explorer Survey and the Gaia mission, we have estimated values\nof the $r$-band extinction for $\sim$ 19 million stars with the spectral energy\ndistribution (SED) analysis. Together with the distances calculated from the\nGaia data release 2 (DR2) parallaxes, we have constructed a three-dimensional\nextinction map of the southern sky. By combining our 3D extinction map with\nthose from the literature, we present an all-sky 3D extinction map, and use it\nto explore the 3D distribution of the Galactic dust grains. We use two\ndifferent models, one consisting a single disk and another of two disks, to fit\nthe 3D distribution of the Galactic dust grains. The data is better fitted by a\ntwo-disk model, yielding smaller values of the Bayesian Information Criterion\n(BIC). The best fit model has scale heights of 73 and 225 pc for the "thin" and\n"thick" dust disks, respectively. Guo_2020a Guo et al. 2020a https://arxiv.org/abs/2010.14092
334 2010.13789 2020-10-26 Denis Erkal, Alis J. Deason, Vasily Belokurov, Xiang-Xiang Xue, Sergey E. Koposov, Sarah A. Bird, Chao Liu, Iulia T. Simion, Chengqun Yang, Lan Zhang, Gang Zhao Detection of the LMC-induced sloshing of the Galactic halo A wealth of recent studies have shown that the LMC is likely massive, with a\nhalo mass $>10^{11} M_\odot$. One consequence of having such a nearby and\nmassive neighbour is that the inner Milky Way is expected to be accelerated\nwith respect to our Galaxy's outskirts (beyond $\sim 30$ kpc). In this work we\ncompile a sample of $\sim 500$ stars with radial velocities in the distant\nstellar halo, $r_{\rm GC}> 50$ kpc, to test this hypothesis. These stars span a\nlarge fraction of the sky and thus give a global view of the stellar halo. We\nfind that stars in the Southern hemisphere are on average blueshifted, while\nstars in the North are redshifted, consistent with the expected, mostly\ndownwards acceleration of the inner halo due to the LMC. We compare these\nresults with simulations and find the signal is consistent with the infall of a\n$1.5\times10^{11} M_\odot$ LMC. We cross-match our stellar sample with\n\textit{Gaia} DR2 and find that the mean proper motions are not yet precise\nenough to discern the LMC's effect. Our results show that the outer Milky Way\nis significantly out of equilibrium and that the LMC has a substantial effect\non our Galaxy. Erkal_2020 Erkal et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2010.13789
335 1909.11969 2020-10-22 Stephanie Monty, Kim A. Venn, James M. M. Lane, Deborah Lokhorst, David Yong Chemo-dynamics of outer halo dwarf stars, including \textit{Gaia}-Sausage and \textit{Gaia}-Sequoia candidates The low-metallicity, kinematically interesting dwarf stars studied by\nStephens \& Boesgaard (2002, SB02) are re-examined using Gaia DR2 astrometry,\nand updated model atmospheres and atomic line data. New stellar parameters are\ndetermined based on the Gaia DR2 parallactic distances and Dartmouth Stellar\nEvolution Database isochrones. These are in excellent agreement with\nspectroscopically determined stellar parameters for stars with [Fe/H]$>-2$;\nhowever, large disagreements are found for stars with [Fe/H]$\le-2$, with\noffsets as large as $\Delta$T$_{\rm eff}\sim+500$ K and\n$\Delta$log\,$g\sim+1.0$. A subset of six stars (test cases) are analysed ab\ninitio using high resolution spectra with Keck HIRES and Gemini GRACES. This\nsub-sample is found to include two $\alpha$-challenged dwarf stars, suggestive\nof origins in a low mass, accreted dwarf galaxy. The orbital parameters for the\nentire SB02 sample are re-determined using \textit{Gaia} DR2 data. We find 11\nstars that are dynamically coincident with the \textit{Gaia}-Sausage accretion\nevent and another 17 with the \textit{Gaia}-Sequoia event in action space. Both\nassociations include low-mass, metal-poor stars with isochrone ages older than\n10 Gyr. Two dynamical subsets are identified within \textit{Gaia}-Sequoia. When\nthese subsets are examined separately, a common knee in [$\alpha$/Fe] is found\nfor the \textit{Gaia}-Sausage and low orbital energy \textit{Gaia}-Sequoia\nstars. A lower metallicity knee is tentatively identified in the\n\textit{Gaia}-Sequoia high orbital energy stars. If the metal-poor dwarf stars\nin these samples are true members of the \textit{Gaia}-Sausage and\n\textit{Gaia}-Sequoia events, then they present a unique opportunity to probe\nthe earlier, more pristine, star formation histories of these systems. Monty_2020 Monty et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/1909.11969
336 2003.00076 2020-10-21 Joel L. Pfeffer, Sebastian Trujillo-Gomez, J. M. Diederik Kruijssen, Robert A. Crain, Meghan E. Hughes, Marta Reina-Campos, Nate Bastian Predicting accreted satellite galaxy masses and accretion redshifts based on globular cluster orbits in the E-MOSAICS simulations The ages and metallicities of globular clusters (GCs) are known to be\npowerful tracers of the properties of their progenitor galaxies, enabling their\nuse in determining the merger histories of galaxies. However, while useful in\nseparating GCs into individual accretion events, the orbits of GC groups\nthemselves have received less attention as probes of their progenitor galaxy\nproperties. In this work, we use simulations of galaxies and their GC systems\nfrom the E-MOSAICS project to explore how the present-day orbital properties of\nGCs are related to the properties of their progenitor galaxies. We find that\nthe orbits of GCs deposited by accretion events are sensitive to the mass and\nmerger redshift of the satellite galaxy. Earlier mergers and larger galaxy\nmasses deposit GCs at smaller median apocentres and lower total orbital energy.\nThe orbital properties of accreted groups of GCs can therefore be used to infer\nthe properties of their progenitor galaxy, though there exists a degeneracy\nbetween galaxy mass and accretion time. Combining GC orbits with other tracers\n(GC ages, metallicities) will help to break the galaxy mass/accretion time\ndegeneracy, enabling stronger constraints on the properties of their progenitor\ngalaxy. In situ GCs generally orbit at lower energies (small apocentres) than\naccreted GCs, however they exhibit a large tail to high energies and even\nretrograde orbits (relative to the present-day disc), showing significant\noverlap with accreted GCs. Applying the results to Milky Way GCs groups\nsuggests a merger redshift $z \sim 1.5$ for the Gaia Sausage/Enceladus and\n$z>2$ for the `low-energy'/Kraken group, adding further evidence that the Milky\nWay had two significant mergers in its past. Pfeffer_2020 Pfeffer et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2003.00076
337 2010.10398 2020-10-20 Xinlun Cheng, Borja Anguiano, Steven R. Majewski, Christian Hayes, Phil Arras, Cristina Chiappini, Sten Hasselquist, Anna Bárbara de Andrade Queiroz, Christian Nitschelm, Domingo Anıbal Garcıa-Hernández, Richard R. Lane, Alexandre Roman-Lopes, Peter Frinchaboy Exploring the Galactic Warp Through Asymmetries in the Kinematics of the Galactic Disk Previous analyses of large databases of Milky Way stars have revealed the\nstellar disk of our Galaxy to be warped and that this imparts a strong\nsignature on the kinematics of stars beyond the solar neighborhood. However,\ndue to the limitation of accurate distance estimates, many attempts to explore\nthe extent of these Galactic features have generally been restricted to a\nvolume near the Sun. By combining Gaia DR2 astrometric solution, StarHorse\ndistance and stellar abundances from the APOGEE survey, we present the most\ndetailed and radially expansive study yet of the vertical and radial motions of\nstars in the Galactic disk. We map stellar velocity with respect to their\nGalactocentric radius, angular momentum, and azimuthal angle and assess their\nrelation to the warp. A decrease in vertical velocity is discovered at\nGalactocentric radius $R=13\ \text{kpc}$ and angular momentum $L_z=2800\\n\text{kpc}\ \text{km}\ \text{s}^{-1}$. Smaller ripples in vertical and radial\nvelocity are also discovered superposed on the main trend. We also discovered\nthat trends in the vertical velocity with azimuthal angle are not symmetric\nabout the peak, suggesting the warp to be lopsided. To explain the global trend\nin vertical velocity, we built a simple analytical model of the Galactic warp.\nOur best fit yields a starting radius of $8.87^{+0.08}_{-0.09}\ \text{kpc}$ and\nprecession rate of $13.57^{+0.20}_{-0.18}\ \text{km}\ \text{s}^{-1}\\n\text{kpc}^{-1}$. These parameters remain consistent across stellar age groups,\na result that supports the notion that the warp is the result of an external,\ngravitationally induced phenomenon. Cheng_2020 Cheng et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2010.10398
338 2010.10524 2020-10-20 José G. Fernández-Trincado, Timothy C. Beers, Dante Minniti Jurassic: A Chemically Anomalous Structure in the Galactic Halo Detailed elemental-abundance patterns of giant stars in the Galactic halo\nmeasured by APOGEE-2 have revealed the existence of a unique and significant\nstellar sub-population of silicon-enhanced ([Si/Fe]$\gtrsim +0.5$) metal-poor\nstars, spanning a wide range of metallicities\n($-1.5\lesssim$[Fe/H]$\lesssim-0.8$). Stars with over-abundances in [Si/Fe] are\nof great interest because these have very strong silicon ($^{28}$Si) spectral\nfeatures for stars of their metallicity and evolutionary stage, offering clues\nabout rare nucleosynthetic pathways in globular clusters (GCs). Si-rich field\nstars have been conjectured to have been evaporated from GCs, however, the\norigin of their abundances remains unclear, and several scenarios have been\noffered to explain the anomalous abundance ratios. These include the hypothesis\nthat some of them were born from a cloud of gas previously polluted by a\nprogenitor that underwent a specific and peculiar nucleosynthesis event, or due\nto mass transfer from a previous evolved companion. However, those scenarios do\nnot simultaneously explain the wide gamut of chemical species that are found in\nSi-rich stars. Instead, we show that the present inventory of such unusual\nstars, as well as their relation to known halo substructures (including the\nin-situ halo, \textit{Gaia}-Enceladus, the Helmi Stream(s), and Sequoia, among\nothers), is still incomplete. We report the chemical abundances of the\niron-peak (Fe), the light- (C and N), the $\alpha-$ (O and Mg), the odd-Z (Na\nand Al), and the \textit{s}-process (Ce and Nd) elements of 55 newly identified\nSi-rich field stars (among more than $\sim$600,000 APOGEE-2 targets), that\nexhibit over-abundance of [Si/Fe] as extreme as those observed in some Galactic\nGCs, and are relatively cleanly from other stars in the [Si/Fe]-[Fe/H] plane.\nThis new census confirms the presence of a statistically significant ... Fernández-Trincado_2020a Fernández-Trincado et al. 2020a https://arxiv.org/abs/2010.10524
339 2007.01102 2020-10-13 Hangci Du, Shude Mao, E. Athanassoula, Juntai Shen, Pawel Pietrukowicz Kinematics of RR Lyrae stars in the Galactic bulge with OGLE-IV and Gaia DR2 We analyze the kinematics and spatial distribution of 15,599 fundamental-mode\nRR Lyrae (RRL) stars in the Milky Way bulge by combining OGLE-IV photometric\ndata and Gaia DR2 proper motions. We show that the longitudinal proper motions\nand the line-of-sight velocities can give similar results for the rotation in\nthe Galactic central regions. The angular velocity of bulge RRLs is found to be\naround $35$ km s$^{-1}$ kpc$^{-1}$, significantly smaller than that for the\nmajority of bulge stars ($50-60$ km s$^{-1}$ kpc$^{-1}$); bulge RRLs have\nlarger velocity dispersion (120$-$140 km s$^{-1}$) than younger stars. The\ndependence of the kinematics of the bulge RRLs on their metallicities is shown\nby their rotation curves and spatial distributions. Metal-poor RRLs\n([Fe/H]<$-1$) show a smaller bar angle than metal-rich ones. We also find clues\nsuggesting that RRLs in the bulge are not dominated by halo stars. These\nresults might explain some previous conflicting results over bulge RRLs and\nhelp understand the chemodynamical evolution of the Galactic bulge. Du_2020 Du et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2007.01102
340 1810.07779 2020-10-07 Azadeh Fattahi, Vasily Belokurov, Alis J. Deason, Carlos S. Frenk, Facundo A. Gomez, Robert J. J. Grand, Federico Marinacci, Rudiger Pakmor, Volker Springel The origin of galactic metal-rich stellar halo components with highly eccentric orbits Using the astrometry from the ESA's Gaia mission, previous works have shown\nthat the Milky Way stellar halo is dominated by metal-rich stars on highly\neccentric orbits. To shed light on the nature of this prominent halo component,\nwe have analysed 28 Galaxy analogues in the Auriga suite of cosmological\nhydrodynamics zoom-in simulations. Some three quarters of the Auriga galaxies\ncontain significant components with high radial velocity anisotropy, beta >\n0.6. However, only in one third of the hosts do the high-beta stars contribute\nsignificantly to the accreted stellar halo overall, similar to what is observed\nin the Milky Way. For this particular subset we reveal the origin of the\ndominant stellar halo component with high metallicity, [Fe/H]~-1, and high\norbital anisotropy, beta>0.8, by tracing their stars back to the epoch of\naccretion. It appears that, typically, these stars come from a single dwarf\ngalaxy with a stellar mass of order of 10^9-10^10 Msol that merged around 6-10\nGyr ago, causing a sharp increase in the halo mass. Our study therefore\nestablishes a firm link between the excess of radially anisotropic stellar\ndebris in the Milky Way halo and an ancient head-on collision between the young\nMilky Way and a massive dwarf galaxy Fattahi_2020 Fattahi et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/1810.07779
341 2004.07261 2020-10-06 Marina Kounkel, Kevin Covey, Keivan G. Stassun Untangling the Galaxy. II. Structure within 3 kpc We present the results of the hierarchical clustering analysis of the Gaia\nDR2 data to search for clusters, co-moving groups, and other stellar\nstructures. The current paper builds on the sample from the previous work,\nextending it in distance from 1 kpc to 3 kpc, increasing the number of\nidentified structures up to 8292. To aid in the analysis of the population\nproperties, we developed a neural network called Auriga to robustly estimate\nthe age, extinction, and distance of a stellar group based on the input\nphotometry and parallaxes of the individual members. We apply Auriga to derive\nthe properties of not only the structures found in this paper, but also\npreviously identified open clusters. Through this work, we examine the temporal\nstructure of the spiral arms. Specifically, we find that the Sagittarius arm\nhas moved by >500 pc in the last 100 Myr, and the Perseus arm has been\nexperiencing a relative lull in star formation activity over the last 25 Myr.\nWe confirm the findings from the previous paper on the transient nature of the\nspiral arms, with the timescale of transition of a few 100 Myr. Finally, we\nfind a peculiar ~1 Gyr old stream of stars that appears to be heliocentric. It\nis unclear what is the origin of it. Kounkel_2020 Kounkel et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2004.07261
342 2010.02113 2020-10-05 E. R. Garro, D. Minniti, M. Gómez, J. Alonso-García, R. H. Barbá, B. Barbuy, J. J. Clariá, A. N. Chené, B. Dias, M. Hempel, V. D. Ivanov, P. W. Lucas, D. Majaess, F. Mauro, C. Moni Bidin, T. Palma, J. B. Pullen, R. K. Saito, L. Smith, F. Surot, S. Ramírez Alegría, M. Rejkuba, V. Ripepi VVVX-Gaia Discovery of a Low Luminosity Globular Cluster in the Milky Way Disk Milky Way globular clusters (MW GCs) are difficult to identify at low\nGalactic latitudes because of high differential extinction and heavy star\ncrowding. The new deep near-IR images and photometry from the VISTA Variables\nin the Via L\'actea Extended Survey (VVVX) allow us to chart previously\nunexplored regions. Our long term aim is to complete the census of MW GCs. The\nimmediate goals are to estimate the astrophysical parameters, measuring their\nreddenings, extinctions, distances, total luminosities, proper motions, sizes,\nmetallicities and ages. We use the near-IR VVVX survey database, in combination\nwith Gaia DR2 optical photometry, and with the Two Micron All Sky Survey\n(2MASS) photometry. We report the detection of a heretofore unknown Galactic\nGlobular Cluster at $RA =$ 14:09:00.0; $DEC=-$65:37:12 (J2000). We calculate a\nreddening of $E(J-K_s)=(0.3\pm 0.03)$ mag and an extinction of\n$A_{K_s}=(0.15\pm 0.01)$ mag for this new GC. Its distance modulus and\ncorresponding distance were measured as $(m-M)=(15.93\pm0.03)$ mag and\n$D=(15.5\pm1.0)$ kpc, respectively. We estimate the metallicity and age by\ncomparison with known GCs and by fitting PARSEC and Dartmouth isochrones,\nfinding $[Fe/H]=(-0.70\pm0.2)$ dex and $t=(11.0\pm1.0)$ Gyr. The mean GC PMs\nfrom Gaia are $\mu_{\alpha^\ast}=(-4.68 \pm 0.47 )$ mas $yr^{-1}$ and\n$\mu_{\delta}=(-1.34 \pm 0.45)$ mas $yr^{-1}$. The total luminosity of our\ncluster is estimated to be $M_{Ks}=(-7.76\pm 0.5)$ mag. We have found a new\nlow-luminosity, old and metal-rich globular cluster, situated in the far side\nof the Galactic disk, at $R_{G}=11.2$ kpc from the Galactic centre, and at\n$z=1.0$ kpc below the plane. Interestingly, the location, metallicity and age\nof this globular cluster are coincident with the Monoceros Ring (MRi)\nstructure. Garro_2020 Garro et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2010.02113
343 2010.01135 2020-10-02 José G. Fernández-Trincado, Timothy C. Beers, Dante Minniti, Baitian Tang, Sandro Villanova, Doug Geisler, Angeles Pérez-Villegas, Katherine Vieira Aluminum Enhanced Metal-Poor Stars buried in the Inner Galaxy Stars with higher aluminum and nitrogen enrichment are often the key pieces\nfor the chemical makeup of multiple populations in almost all globular clusters\n(GCs). There is also compelling observational evidence that some Galactic\ncomponents could be partially built from dissipated GCs. Thus, the\nidentification of such kinds of stars among metal-poor field stars may provide\ninsights on the composite nature of the Milky Way (MW) bulge and inner stellar\nhalo, as well as reveal other chemical peculiarities. Here, based on APOGEE\nspectra, we report the discovery of 29 mildly metal-poor ([Fe/H]$\lesssim-0.7$)\nstars with stellar atmospheres strongly enriched in aluminum (Al-rich stars:\n[Al/Fe]$\gtrsim+0.5$), well above the typical Galactic levels, located within\nthe Solar radius toward the bulge region, which lies in highly eccentric orbits\n($e\gtrsim0.6$). We find many similarities for almost all of the chemical\nspecies measured in this work with the chemical patterns of GCs, so we\nconjecture that they have likely been dynamically ejected into the bulge and\ninner halo from GCs formed in situ and/or GC formed in different progenitors of\nknown merger events experienced by the MW, such as the\n\textit{Gaia}-Sausage-Enceladus and/or Sequoia. Fernández-Trincado_2020 Fernández-Trincado et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2010.01135
344 2008.09096 2020-09-30 Jan Rybizki, Hans-Walter Rix, Markus Demleitner, Coryn Bailer-Jones, William J. Cooper Characterising the Gaia Radial Velocity sample selection function in its native photometry The Gaia DR2 radial velocity sample (GDR2RVS), which provides six-dimensional\nphase-space information on 7.2 million stars, is of great value for inferring\nproperties of the Milky Way. Yet a quantitative and accurate modelling of this\nsample is hindered without knowledge and inclusion of a well-characterized\nselection function. Here we derive the selection function through estimates of\nthe internal completeness, i.e. the ratio of GDR2RVS sources compared to all\nGaia DR2 sources (GDR2all). We show that this selection function or\n"completeness" depends on basic observables, in particular the apparent\nmagnitude GRVS and colour G-GRP, but also on the surrounding source density and\non sky position, where the completeness exhibits distinct small-scale\nstructure. We identify a region of magnitude and colour that has high\ncompleteness, providing an approximate but simple way of implementing the\nselection function. For a more rigorous and detailed description we provide\npython code to query our selection function, as well as tools and ADQL queries\nthat produce custom selection functions with additional quality cuts. Rybizki_2020a Rybizki et al. 2020a https://arxiv.org/abs/2008.09096
345 2009.12779 2020-09-27 F. Comerón, A. A. Djupvik, N. Schneider, A. Pasquali The historical record of massive star formation in Cygnus The Cygnus region, which dominates the local spiral arm of the Galaxy, is one\nof the nearest complexes of massive star formation. Its massive stellar\ncontent, regions of ongoing star formation, and molecular gas have been studied\nin detail. However, little is known of the history of the region beyond the\npast 10 Myr. The brightness and spectroscopic characteristics of red\nsupergiants make it easy to identify them and build up a virtually complete\nsample of such stars at the distance of the Cygnus region, thus providing a\nrecord of massive star formation extending several tens of Myr into the past, a\nperiod inaccessible through the O and early B stars observable at present. We\nhave made a selection of a sample of bright, red stars in an area of 84 square\ndegrees covering the whole present extension of the Cygnus region. We have\nobtained spectroscopy in the red visible range allowing an accurate,\nhomogeneous spectral classification as well as a reliable separation between\nsupergiants and other cool stars. Our data are complemented with Gaia Data\nRelease 2 astrometric data. We have identified 29 red supergiants in the area,\n17 of which had not been previously classified as supergiants. Twenty-four of\nthe 29 most likely belong to the Cygnus region and four of the remaining to the\nPerseus arm. We have used their derived luminosities and masses to infer the\nstar formation history of the region. Intense massive star formation activity\nis found to have started approximately 15 Myr ago, and we find evidence for two\nother episodes, one taking place between 20 and 30 Myr ago and another one\nhaving ended approximately 40 Myr ago. There are small but significant\ndifferences between the kinematic properties of red supergiants younger or\nolder then 20 Myr, hinting that stars of the older group were formed outside\nthe precursor of the present Cygnus complex, possibly in the Sagittarius-Carina\narm. Comerón_2020 Comerón et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2009.12779
346 2007.10374 2020-09-25 Danny Horta, Ricardo P. Schiavon, J. Ted Mackereth, Joel Pfeffer, Andrew C. Mason, Shobhit Kisku, Francesca Fragkoudi, Carlos Allende Prieto, Katia Cunha, Sten Hasselquist, Jon Holtzman, Steven R. Majewski, David Nataf, Robert W. O'Connell, Mathias Schultheis, Verne V. Smith Evidence from APOGEE for the presence of a major building block of the halo buried in the inner Galaxy We report evidence from APOGEE for the presence of a new metal-poor stellar\nstructure located within $\sim$4~kpc of the Galactic centre. Characterised by a\nchemical composition resembling those of low mass satellites of the Milky Way,\nthis new inner Galaxy structure (IGS) seems to be chemically and dynamically\ndetached from more metal-rich populations in the inner Galaxy. We conjecture\nthat this structure is associated with an accretion event that likely occurred\nin the early life of the Milky Way. Comparing the mean elemental abundances of\nthis structure with predictions from cosmological numerical simulations, we\nestimate that the progenitor system had a stellar mass of\n$\sim5\times10^8M_\odot$, or approximately twice the mass of the recently\ndiscovered Gaia-Enceladus/Sausage system. We find that the accreted:{\it in\nsitu} ratio within our metal-poor ([Fe/H]$<$--0.8) bulge sample is somewhere\nbetween 1:3 and 1:2, confirming predictions of cosmological numerical\nsimulations by various groups. 347 2009.11927 2020-09-24 A. Arellano Ferro, M. A. Yepez, S. Muneer, I. H. Bustos Fierro, K. P. Schröder, Sunetra Giridhar, J. H. Calderón The globular cluster M10: Reassessment of stellar membership, distance and age using its variable and HB stars Time-series VI CCD photometry of the globular cluster M10 (NGC 6254) is\nemployed to perform a detailed identification, inspection of their light\ncurves, their classification and their cluster membership, of all the known\nvariables reported up to 2018. The membership analysis is based on the Gaia-DR2\npositions and proper motions. The metallicity of the cluster is estimated based\non the sole RRc star known in the cluster. The Fourier decomposition of its\nlight curve leads to [Fe/H]ZW=-1:59 $\pm$ 0:23 dex. The mean cluster distance,\nestimated by several independent methods is 5.0 $\pm$ 0.3 kpc. A multi-approach\nsearch in a region of about 10x10 arcmin2 around the cluster revealed three new\nvariables, one SX Phe (V35) and two sinusoidal variables on the red giant\nbranch of unclear classification (V36,V37). Modelling the HB stars is very\nsensitive to the stellar hydrogen shell mass, which surrounds the 0.50\nM$_\odot$ helium core. To match the full stretch of the HB population, a range\nof total mass of 0.56 to 0.62 M$_\odot$ is required. These models support a\ndistance of 5.35 kpc and an age of about 13 Gyrs, and hints to some individual\nvariation of the mass loss on the uppper RGB, perhaps caused by the presence of\nclosed magnetic field in red giants.
