348 2009.07192 2020-09-22 Georges Kordopatis, Alejandra Recio-Blanco, Mathias Schultheis, Vanessa Hill The chemodynamics of prograde and retrograde Milky Way stars Context: The accretion history of the Milky Way is still unknown, despite the\nrecent discovery of stellar systems that stand out in terms of their\nenergy-angular momentum space, such as Gaia-Enceladus-Sausage. In particular,\nit is still unclear how these groups are linked and to what extent they are\nwell-mixed.\n Aims: We investigate the similarities and differences in the properties\nbetween the prograde and retrograde (counter-rotating) stars and set those\nresults in context by using the properties of Gaia-Enceladus-Sausage,\nThamnos/Sequoia, and other suggested accreted populations.\n Methods: We used the stellar metallicities of the major large spectroscopic\nsurveys (APOGEE, Gaia-ESO, GALAH, LAMOST, RAVE, SEGUE) in combination with\nastrometric and photometric data from Gaia's second data-release. We\ninvestigated the presence of radial and vertical metallicity gradients as well\nas the possible correlations between the azimuthal velocity, $v_\phi,$ and\nmetallicity, [M/H], as qualitative indicators of the presence of mixed\npopulations.\n Results: We find that a handful of super metal-rich stars exist on retrograde\norbits at various distances from the Galactic center and the Galactic plane. We\nalso find that the counter-rotating stars appear to be a well-mixed population,\nexhibiting radial and vertical metallicity gradients on the order of $\sim$\n-0.04 dex/kpc and -0.06 dex/kpc, respectively, with little (if any) variation\nwhen different regions of the Galaxy are probed. The prograde stars show a\n$v_\phi$-[M/H] relation that flattens -- and, perhaps, even reverses as a\nfunction of distance from the plane. Retrograde samples selected to roughly\nprobe Thamnos and Gaia-Enceladus-Sausage appear to be different populations yet\nthey also appear to be quite linked, as they follow the same trend in terms of\nthe eccentricity versus metallicity space. Kordopatis_2020 Kordopatis et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2009.07192
349 2009.09611 2020-09-21 H. Baumgardt, A. Sollima, M. Hilker Absolute V-band magnitudes and mass-to-light ratios of Galactic globular clusters We have used HST and ground-based photometry to determine total $V$-band\nmagnitudes and mass-to-light ratios of more than 150 Galactic globular\nclusters. We do this by summing up the magnitudes of their individual member\nstars, using color-magnitude information, Gaia DR2 proper motions and radial\nvelocities to distinguish cluster stars from background stars. Our new\nmagnitudes confirm literature estimates for bright clusters with V<8, but can\ndeviate by up to two magnitudes from literature values for fainter clusters.\nThey lead to absolute mass-to-light ratios that are confined to the narrow\nrange 1.4 Baumgardt_2020 Baumgardt et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2009.09611
350 2009.04495 2020-09-16 Jean-Baptiste Salomon, Olivier Bienaymé, Céline Reylé, Annie C. Robin, Benoit Famaey Kinematics and dynamics of Gaia red clump stars We analyse the kinematics and dynamics of a homogeneous sample of red clump\nstars selected from the second Gaia data release catalogue in the direction of\nthe Galactic poles. The level of completeness of the sample at heights between\n0.6 and 3.5 kpc is asserted by comparison with the 2 Micron All Sky Survey\ncatalogue. We show that both the density distribution and velocity dispersion\nare significantly more perturbed in the North than in the South, in all\nanalysed regions of our Galactic neighbourhoods. We provide a detailed\nassessment of these North-South asymmetries at large heights. We then proceed\nto evaluate how such asymmetries could affect determinations of the dynamical\nmatter density under equilibrium assumptions. We find that a Jeans analysis\ndelivers relatively similar vertical forces and integrated dynamical surface\ndensities at large heights above the plane in both hemispheres. At these\nheights, the densities of stars and gas are very low and the surface density is\nlargely dominated by dark matter, which allows to estimate, separately in the\nNorth and South, the local dark matter density derived under equilibrium\nassumptions. In the presence of vertical perturbations, such values should be\nconsidered as an upper limit. This Jeans analysis yields values of the local\ndark matter density above 2~kpc, $\rho_{\rm DM} \sim 0.013 \, {\rm\nM}_\odot/{\rm pc}^3$ ($ \sim 0.509 \, {\rm GeV/cm}^3$) in the perturbed\nNorthern hemisphere, and $\rho_{\rm DM} \sim 0.010 \, {\rm M}_\odot/{\rm pc}^3$\n($ \sim 0.374 \, {\rm GeV/cm}^3$) in the much less perturbed South. As a\ncomparison, we determine the local dark matter density by fitting a global\nphase-space distribution to the data. We end up with a value in the range of\n$\rho_{\rm DM} \sim 0.011 - 0.014 \, {\rm M}_\odot/{\rm pc}^3$ in global\nagreement with Jeans analysis. Salomon_2020 Salomon et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2009.04495
351 2005.14049 2020-09-15 Tetsuro Asano, Michiko S. Fujii, Junichi Baba, Jeroen Bédorf, Elena Sellentin, Simon Portegies Zwart Trimodal structure of Hercules stream explained by originating from bar resonances Gaia Data Release 2 revealed detailed structures of nearby stars in phase\nspace. These include the Hercules stream, whose origin is still debated. Most\nof the previous numerical studies conjectured that the observed structures\noriginate from orbits in resonance with the bar, based on static potential\nmodels for the Milky Way. We, in contrast, approach the problem via a\nself-consistent, dynamic, and morphologically well-resolved model, namely a\nfull $N$-body simulation of the Milky Way. Our simulation comprises about 5.1\nbillion particles in the galactic stellar bulge, bar, disk, and dark-matter\nhalo and is evolved to 10 Gyr. Our model's disk component is composed of 200\nmillion particles, and its simulation snapshots are stored every 10 Myr,\nenabling us to resolve and classify resonant orbits of representative samples\nof stars. After choosing the Sun's position in the simulation, we compare the\ndistribution of stars in its neighborhood with Gaia's astrometric data, thereby\nestablishing the role of identified resonantly trapped stars in the formation\nof Hercules-like structures. From our orbital spectral-analysis we identify\nmultiple, especially higher order resonances. Our results suggest that the\nHercules stream is dominated by the 4:1 and 5:1 outer Lindblad and corotation\nresonances. In total, this yields a trimodal structure of the Hercules stream.\nFrom the relation between resonances and ridges in phase space, our model\nfavored a slow pattern speed of the Milky-Way bar (40--45 $\mathrm{km \; s^{-1}\n\; kpc^{-1}}$). Asano_2020 Asano et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2005.14049
352 2009.06695 2020-09-14 G. Casali, L. Magrini, A. Frasca, A. Bragaglia, G. Catanzaro, V. D'Orazi, R. Sordo, E. Carretta, L. Origlia, G. Andreuzzi, X. Fu, A. Vallenari Stellar Population Astrophysics (SPA) with TNG. The old open clusters Collinder 350, Gulliver 51, NGC 7044, and Ruprecht 171 In the framework of the Stellar Population Astrophysics (SPA) project, we\npresent new observations and spectral analysis of four sparsely studied open\nclusters, namely Collinder 350, Gulliver 51, NGC 7044, and Ruprecht 171. We\nexploit the HARPS-N spectrograph at the TNG telescope to acquire\nhigh-resolution optical spectra for 15 member stars of four clusters. We derive\nstellar parameters using both the EW analysis and the spectral fitting\ntechnique. We compute elemental abundances for light, a-, iron-peak, and\nn-capture elements using the EW measurement approach. We investigate the origin\nof the correlation between metallicity and stellar parameters derived with the\nEW method for the coolest stars of the sample (Teff < 4300 K). The correlation\nis likely due to the challenging continuum setting and to a general inaccuracy\nof model atmospheres used to reproduce the conditions of very cool giant stars.\nWe locate the properties of our clusters in the radial distributions of\nmetallicity and abundance ratios, comparing our results with clusters from the\nGaia-ESO and APOGEE surveys. We present the [X/Fe]-[Fe/H] and [X/Fe]-Rgc trends\nfor elements in common between the two surveys and derive the C and Li\nabundances as a function of the evolutionary phase and compare them with\ntheoretical models. The SPA survey allows us to fully characterise the\nchemistry of nearby clusters. With a single set of spectra, we provide chemical\nabundances for some chemical elements, which are comparable to those obtained\nin two of the largest surveys combined. The metallicities and abundance ratios\nof our clusters fit very well in the radial distributions defined by the recent\nliterature, reinforcing the importance of star clusters to outline the spatial\ndistribution of abundances in our Galaxy. Moreover, the abundances of C and Li\nagree with evolutionary prescriptions for their masses and metallicities. Casali_2020a Casali et al. 2020a https://arxiv.org/abs/2009.06695
353 2009.05773 2020-09-12 J. Maíz Apellániz, P. Crespo Bellido, R. H. Barbá, R. Fernández Aranda, A. Sota The Villafranca catalog of Galactic OB groups: I. Systems with O2-O3.5 stars CONTEXT. The GOSSS spectral classifications and Gaia data have significantly\nimproved our ability to measure distances and determine memberships of stellar\ngroups with OB stars. AIMS. We have started a program to identify, measure\ndistances, and determine the membership of Galactic stellar groups with OB\nstars. We start with the identification and distance determinations of groups\nwith O stars. In this paper we concentrate on groups that contain stars with\nthe earliest spectral subtypes. METHODS. We use GOSSS to select Galactic\nstellar groups with O2-O3.5 stars and a method that combines Gaia DR2\nphotometry, positions, proper motions, and parallaxes to assign robust\nmemberships and measure distances. We also include the two clusters in that\npaper to generate our first list of 16 O-type Galactic stellar groups. RESULTS.\nWe derive distances, determine the membership, and analyze the structure of\nsixteen Galactic stellar groups with O stars, Villafranca O-001 to O-016,\nincluding the 14 groups with the earliest-O-type optically-accessible stars\nknown in the Milky Way. We compare our distance with previous results and\nestablish that the best consistency is with VLBI parallaxes and the worst is\nwith kinematic distances. Our results indicate that massive stars can form in\nrelatively low-mass clusters or even in near-isolation, as is the case for the\nBajamar star in the North America nebula. This lends support to the\nhierarchical scenario of star formation, where some stars are born in\nwell-defined bound clusters but others are born in associations that are\nunbound from the beginning: groups of newborn stars come in many shapes and\nsizes. We propose that HD 64 568 and HD 64 315 AB could have been ejected\nsimultaneously from Villafranca O-012 S. Our results are consistent with a\ndifference of approx. 20 microas in the Gaia DR2 parallax zero point between\nbright and faint stars. (ABRIDGED) Apellániz_2020 Apellániz et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2009.05773
354 2008.09255 2020-09-10 R. Michael Rich, Christian I. Johnson, Michael Young, Iulia Simion, William Clarkson, Catherine Pilachowski, Scott Michael, Andrea Kunder, A Katherine Vivas, Andreas Koch, Tommaso Marchetti, Rodrigo Ibata, Nicolas Martin, Annie C. Robin, Nadege Lagarde, Michelle Collins, Zeljko Ivezic, Roberto de Propris, Juntai Shen, Ortwin Gerhard, Mario Soto The Blanco DECam Bulge Survey. I. The Survey Description and Early Results The Blanco Dark Energy Camera (DECam) Bulge survey is a Vera Rubin\nObservatory (LSST) pathfinder imaging survey, spanning $\sim 200$ sq. deg. of\nthe Southern Galactic bulge, $-2^\circ <$b$< -13^\circ$ and $-11^\circ <$l$ <\n+11^\circ$. We have employed the CTIO-4m telescope and the Dark Energy Camera\n(DECam) to image a contiguous $\sim 200$ sq. deg. region of the relatively less\nreddened Southern Galactic bulge, in SDSS $u$ + Pan-STARRS$grizy$. Optical\nphotometry with its large colour baseline will be used to investigate the age\nand metallicity distributions of the major structures of the bulge. Included in\nthe survey footprint are 26 globular clusters imaged in all passbands. Over\nmuch of the bulge, we have Gaia DR2 matching astrometry to $i\sim 18$, deep\nenough to reach the faint end of the red clump. This paper provides the\nbackground, scientific case, and description of the survey. We present an array\nof new reddening-corrected colour-magnitude diagrams that span the extent of\nSouthern Galactic bulge. We argue that a population of massive stars in the\nblue loop evolutionary phase, proposed to lie in the bulge, are instead at\n$\sim 2$ kpc from the Sun and likely red clump giants in the old disk. A bright\nred clump near $(l,b)=(+8^\circ,-4^\circ)$ may be a feature in the foreground\ndisk, or related to the long bar reported in earlier work. We also report the\nfirst map of the blue horizontal branch population spanning the BDBS field of\nregard, and our data does not confirm the reality of a number of proposed\nglobular clusters in the bulge. Rich_2020 Rich et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2008.09255
355 2009.04487 2020-09-09 Guillaume F. Thomas, Jaclyn Jensen, Alan McConnachie, Patrick Côté, Kim Venn, Nicolas Longeard, Raymond Carlberg, Scott Chapman, Jean-Charles Cuillandre, Benoit Famaey, Laura Ferrarese, Stephen Gwyn, François Hammer, Rodrigo A. Ibata, Khyati Malhan, Nicolas F. Martin, Simona Mei, Julio F. Navarro, Céline Reylé, Else Starkenburg The hidden past of M92: Detection and characterization of a newly formed 17° long stellar stream using the Canada-France Imaging Survey We present an analysis of the structure, kinematics and orbit of a newly\nfound stellar stream emanating from the globular cluster M92 (NGC 6341). This\nstream was discovered in an improved matched-filter map of the outer Galaxy,\nbased on a "color-color-magnitude" diagram, created using photometry from the\nCanada-France Imaging Survey (CFIS) and the Pan-STARRS 1 3$\pi$ survey (PS1).\nWe find the stream to have a length of 17{\deg} (2.5 kpc at the distance of\nM92), a width dispersion of $0.29${\deg}(42 pc) and a stellar mass of $[3.17\n\pm{0.89}] \times 10^{4} $ M$_\odot$ ($10 \%$ of the stellar mass of the\ncurrent main body of M92). We examine the kinematics of main sequence, red\ngiant and blue horizontal branch stars belonging to the stream and that have\nproper motion measurements from the second data release of Gaia. N-body\nsimulations suggest that the stream was likely formed very recently (during the\nlast $\sim 500$ Myr) forcing us to question the orbital origin of this ancient,\nmetal-poor globular cluster. Thomas_2020 Thomas et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2009.04487
356 2006.08764 2020-09-09 Thomas Donlon II, Heidi Jo Newberg, Robyn Sanderson, Lawrence M. Widrow The Milky Way's Shell Structure Reveals the Time of a Radial Collision We identify shell structures in the Milky Way for the first time. We find 2\nshells in the Virgo Overdensity (VOD) region and 2 shells in the Hercules\nAquila Cloud (HAC) region using Sloan Digital Sky Survey, Gaia, and LAMOST\ndata. These shell stars are a subset of the substructure previously identified\nas the Virgo Radial Merger (VRM). Timing arguments for these shells indicate\nthat their progenitor dwarf galaxy passed through the Galactic center 2.7 +/-\n0.2 Gyr ago. Based on the time of collision, it is also possible that the VRM\nis related to the phenomenon that created phase-space spirals in the vertical\nmotion of the disk and/or the Splash, and could have caused a burst of star\nformation in the inner disk.\n We analyze phase mixing in a collection of radial merger N-body simulations,\nand find that shell structure similar to that observed in Milky Way data\ndisappears by 5 Gyr after collision with the Galactic center. The method used\nto calculate the merger time of the VRM was able to reliably recover the\ncorrect merger times for these simulations.\n Previous work supports the idea that the VRM and the Gaia\nSausage/Gaia-Enceladus Merger are the same. However, the Gaia Sausage is widely\nbelieved to be 8--11 Gyr old. The disparate ages could be reconciled if the\nlarger age is associated with an infall time when the progenitor crossed the\nvirial radius; we do not constrain the time at which the progenitor became\nbound to the Milky Way. Alternatively, the Gaia Sausage could be younger than\npreviously thought. II_2020 II et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2006.08764
357 2009.01855 2020-09-03 Julio A. Carballo-Bello, David Martínez-Delgado, Jesús M. Corral-Santana, Emilio J. Alfaro, Camila Navarrete, A. Katherina Vivas, Márcio Catelan A revised view of the Canis Major stellar overdensity with DECam and Gaia: new evidence of a stellar warp of blue stars We present DECam imaging combined with Gaia DR2 data to study the Canis Major\noverdensity. The presence of the so-called Blue Plume stars in a low-pollution\narea of the color-magnitude diagram allows us to derive the distance and proper\nmotions of this stellar feature along the line of sight of its hypothetical\ncore. The stellar overdensity extends on a large area of the sky at low\nGalactic latitudes, below the plane, and between 230$^\circ < \ell <\n255^\circ$. According to the orbit derived for Canis Major, it presents an\non-plane rotation around the Milky Way. Moreover, additional overdensities of\nBlue Plume stars are found around the plane and across the Galaxy, proving that\nthese objects are not only associated with that structure. The spatial\ndistribution of these stars, derived using Gaia astrometric data, confirms that\nthe detection of the Canis Major overdensity results more from the warped\nstructure of the Milky Way disk than from the accretion of a dwarf galaxy. Carballo-Bello_2020 Carballo-Bello et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2009.01855
358 2008.10218 2020-08-24 Weixiang Sun, Yang Huang, Haifeng Wang, Chun Wang, Meng Zhang, Xinyi Li, Bingqiu Chen, Huawei Zhang, Dandan Wei, Dengkai Jiang, Xiaowei Liu Mapping the Galactic disk with the LAMOST and $Gaia$ Red clump sample: V: On the origin of the "young" [$α$/Fe]-enhanced stars Using a sample of nearly 140,000 primary red clump stars selected from the\nLAMOST and $Gaia$ surveys, we have identified a large sample of "young"\n[$\alpha$/Fe]-enhanced stars with stellar ages younger than 6.0 Gyr and\n[$\alpha$/Fe] ratios greater than 0.15 dex. The stellar ages and [$\alpha$/Fe]\nratios are measured from LAMOST spectra, using a machine learning method\ntrained with common stars in the LAMOST-APOGEE fields (for [$\alpha$/Fe]) and\nin the LAMOST-$Kepler$ fields (for stellar age). The existence of these "young"\n[$\alpha$/Fe]-enhanced stars is not expected from the classical Galactic\nchemical evolution models. To explore their possible origins, we have analyzed\nthe spatial distribution, and the chemical and kinematic properties of those\nstars and compared the results with those of the chemically thin and thick disk\npopulations. We find that those "young" [$\alpha$/Fe]-enhanced stars have\ndistributions in number density, metallicity, [C/N] abundance ratio, velocity\ndispersion and orbital eccentricity that are essentially the same as those of\nthe chemically thick disk population. Our results clearly show those so-called\n"young" [$\alpha$/Fe]-enhanced stars are not really young but $genuinely$\n$old$. Although other alternative explanations can not be fully ruled out, our\nresults suggest that the most possible origin of these old stars is the result\nof stellar mergers or mass transfer. Sun_2020 Sun et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2008.10218
359 1908.02336 2020-08-24 Tianyi. Yang, Supranta Sarma Boruah, Niayesh. Afshordi Gravitational Potential from small-scale clustering in action space: Application to Gaia DR2 Most measurements of mass in Astronomy that use kinematics of stars or gas\nrely on assumptions of equilibrium that are often hard to verify. Instead, we\ndevelop a novel idea that uses the clustering in action space, as a probe of\nunderlying gravitational potential: the correct potential should maximize\nsmall-scale clustering in the action space. We provide a first-principle\nderivation of likelihood using the two-point correlation function in action\nspace, and test it against simulations of stellar streams. We then apply this\nmethod to the 2nd data release of Gaia, and use it to measure the radial force\nfraction $f_h$ and logarithmic slope $\alpha$ of dark matter halo profile. We\ninvestigate stars within 9-11 kpc and 11.5-15 kpc from Galactic centre, and\nfind $(f_h,\alpha)= (0.391\pm 0.009, 1.835\pm 0.092) $ and $(0.351\pm\n0.012,1.687\pm 0.079)$, respectively. We also confirm that the set of\nparameters that maximize the likelihood function do correspond to the most\nclustering in the action space. The best-fit circular velocity curve for Milky\nWay potential is consistent with past measurements (although it is $\sim$\n5-10\% lower than previous methods that use masers or globular clusters).\n Our work provides a clear demonstration of the full statistical power that\nlies in the full phase space information, relieving the need for {\it ad hoc}\nassumptions such as virial equilibrium, circular motion, or steam-finding\nalgorithms. Yang_2020 Yang et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/1908.02336
360 2008.07484 2020-08-17 Marco Palla, Francesca Matteucci, Emanuele Spitoni, Fiorenzo Vincenzo, Valeria Grisoni Chemical evolution of the Milky Way: constraints on the formation of the thick and thin discs We study the evolution of Milky Way thick and thin discs in the light of the\nmost recent observational data. In particular, we analyze abundance gradients\nof O, N, Fe and Mg along the thin disc as well as the [Mg/Fe] vs. [Fe/H]\nrelations and the metallicity distribution functions at different\nGalactocentric distances. We run several models starting from the two-infall\nparadigm, assuming that the thick and thin discs formed by means of two\ndifferent infall episodes, and we explore several physical parameters, such as\nradial gas flows, variable efficiency of star formation, different times for\nthe maximum infall onto the disc, different distributions of the total surface\nmass density of the thick disc and enriched gas infall. Our best model suggests\nthat radial gas flows and variable efficiency of star formation should be\nacting together with the inside-out mechanism for the thin disc formation. The\ntimescale for maximum infall onto the thin disc, which determines the gap\nbetween the formation of the two discs, should be $t_{max}\simeq 3.25$ Gyr. The\nthick disc should have an exponential, small scale length density profile and\ngas infall on the inner thin disc should be enriched. We compute also the\nevolution of Gaia-Enceladus system and study the effects of possible\ninteractions with the thick and thin discs. We conclude that the gas lost by\nEnceladus or even part of it could have been responsible for the formation of\nthe thick disc but not the thin disc. Palla_2020 Palla et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2008.07484
361 1805.04503 2020-08-05 Sarah A. Bird, Xiang-Xiang Xue, Chao Liu, Juntai Shen, Chris Flynn, Chengqun Yang Anisotropy of the Milky Way's stellar halo using K giants from LAMOST and $Gaia$ The anisotropy parameter $\beta$ characterizes the extent to which orbits in\nstellar systems are predominantly radial or tangential, and is likely to\nconstrain, for the stellar halo of the Milky Way, scenarios for its formation\nand evolution. We have measured the anisotropy $\beta$ as a function of\nGalactocentric radius from $5-100$ kpc for over 8600 metal poor ([Fe/H]\n$<-1.3$) halo K giants from the LAMOST catalog with line-of-sight velocities\nand distances, matched to proper motions from the second $Gaia$ data release.\nWe construct full 6-D positions and velocities for the K giants to directly\nmeasure the 3 components of the velocity dispersion $(\sigma_r, \sigma_\theta,\n\sigma_\phi)$ (in spherical coordinates). We find that the orbits in the halo\nare radial over our full Galactocentric distance range reaching over 100 kpc.\nThe anisotropy remains remarkably unchanged with Galactocentric radius from\napproximately 5 to 25 kpc, with an amplitude that depends on the metallicity of\nthe stars, dropping from $\beta \approx 0.9$ for $-1.8 \leq$ [Fe/H] $< -1.3$\n(for the bulk of the stars) to $\beta \approx 0.6$ for the lowest metallicities\n([Fe/H] $< -1.8$). Considering our sample as a whole, $\beta\approx0.8$ and,\nbeyond 25 kpc, the orbits gradually become less radial and anisotropy decreases\nto $\beta<0.3$ past 100 kpc. Within 8 kpc, $\beta<0.8$. The measurement of\nanisotropy is affected by substructure and streams, particularly beyond a\nGalactocentric distance of approximately 25 kpc, where the Sagittarius stream\nis prominent in the data. These results are complimentary to recent analysis of\nsimulations by Loebman et al. and of SDSS/$Gaia$ DR1 data by Belokurov et al. Bird_2020 Bird et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/1805.04503
362 2008.00099 2020-07-31 T Canavesi Fractal Gravitation Considering the GAIA data for {$\approx 10^6$} stars around the {barycenter,}\nwe estimate the fractal dimension for different regions in the Milky Way. Then\nwe use those fractal dimensions to calculate the gravitational potential\nconsidering the medium as a continuous fractal. Finally, {we use the\ngravitational potential to infer} the circular velocity {and adjust} rotation\ncurves in the Milky Way. {For this,} we use two numerical models, the first\nconsidering uniform density and a second more realistic of a bulge and a disk.\nIn none of these models we consider dark matter. We study their validity\ncomparing them with circular speed data from the Milky Way. Canavesi_2020 Canavesi 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2008.00099
363 2007.14825 2020-07-29 Ž. Chrobáková, M. López-Corredoira, F. Sylos Labini, H. -F. Wang, R. Nagy Gaia-DR2 extended kinematical maps. Part III: Rotation curves analysis, dark matter, and Modified Newtonian dynamics tests Recent statistical deconvolution methods have produced extended kinematical\nmaps in a range of heliocentric distances that are a factor of two to three\nlarger than those analysed in the Gaia Collaboration based on the same data. In\nthis paper, we use such maps to derive the rotation curve both in the Galactic\nplane and in off-plane regions and to analyse the density distribution. By\nassuming stationary equilibrium and axisymmetry, we used the Jeans equation to\nderive the rotation curve. Then we fit it with density models that include both\ndark matter and predictions of the MOND (Modified Newtonian dynamics) theory.\nSince the Milky Way exhibits deviations from axisymmetry and equilibrium, we\nalso considered corrections to the Jeans equation. To compute such corrections,\nwe ran N-body experiments of mock disk galaxies where the departure from\nequilibrium becomes larger as a function of the distance from the centre. The\nrotation curve in the outer disk of the Milky Way that is constructed with the\nJeans equation exhibits very low dependence on $R$ and $z$ and it is\nwell-fitted both by dark matter halo and MOND models. The application of the\nJeans equation for deriving the rotation curve, in the case of the systems that\ndeviate from equilibrium and axisymmetry, introduces systematic errors that\ngrow as a function of the amplitude of the average radial velocity. In the case\nof the Milky Way, we can observe that the amplitude of the radial velocity\nreaches $\sim 10\%$ that of the azimuthal one at $R\approx 20$ kpc. Based on\nthis condition, using the rotation curve obtained from the Jeans equation to\ncalculate the mass may overestimate its measurement. Chrobáková_2020 Chrobáková et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2007.14825
364 2002.11142 2020-07-23 P. Ramos, C. Mateu, T. Antoja, A. Helmi, A. Castro-Ginard, E. Balbinot, J. M. Carrasco Full 5D characterisation of the Sagittarius stream with Gaia DR2 RR Lyrae The Sagittarius stream is one of the best tools that we currently have to\nestimate the mass and shape of our Galaxy. However, assigning membership and\nobtaining the phase-space distribution of the stars that form the tails is\nquite challenging. Our goal is to produce a catalogue of RR Lyrae stars of\nSagittarius and obtain an empiric measurement of the trends along the stream in\nsky position, distance and tangential velocities. We generate two initial\nsamples from the Gaia DR2 RR Lyrae catalogue: one, selecting only the stars\nwithin \pm20deg of the orbital plane of Sagittarius (Strip) and the other, the\nresult of applying the Pole Count Map (nGC3) algorithm. We then use the\nmodel-independent, deterministic method developed in this work to remove most\nof the contamination by detecting and isolating the stream in distance and\nproper motions. The output is two empiric catalogues: the Strip sample\n(higher-completeness, lower-purity) which contains 11 677 stars, and the nGC3\nsample (higher-purity, lower-completeness) with 6 608 stars. We characterise\nthe changes along the stream in all the available dimensions, the 5 astrometric\nones plus the metallicity, covering more than 2pi rad in the sky and obtain new\nestimates for the apocentres and the mean [Fe/H] of the RR Lyrae population.\nAlso, we show the first map of the two components of the tangential velocity,\nthanks to the combination of distances and proper motions. Finally, we detect\nthe bifurcation in the leading arm and report no significant difference between\nthe two branches, either in metallicity, kinematics or distance. We provide the\nlargest sample of RR Lyrae candidates of Sagittarius, which can be used as an\ninput for a spectroscopic follow-up or as a reference for the new generation of\nmodels of the stream through the interpolators in distance and velocity that we\nhave constructed. Ramos_2020 Ramos et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2002.11142
365 2007.08313 2020-07-16 Alejandra Recio-Blanco, Emma Fernández Alvar, Patrick de Laverny, Teresa Antoja, Amina Helmi, Aurélien Crida The heavy-elements heritage of the falling sky Recent dynamical analysis based on Gaia data have revealed major accretion\nevents in Milky Way's history. Nevertheless, our understanding of the\nprimordial Galaxy is hindered because the bona fide identification of the most\nmetal-poor and correspondently oldest accreted stars remains challenging.\nContrary to alpha-elements, neutron-capture elements present unexplained large\nabundance spreads for low metallicity stars, that could result from a mixture\nof formation sites. We have analysed the abundances of yttrium, europium,\nmagnesium and iron in Milky Way satellite galaxies, field halo stars and\nglobular clusters. The chemical information has been complemented with orbital\nparameters based on Gaia data. In particular, the orbit's average inclination\nhas been considered. The [Y/Eu] abundance behaviour with respect to the [Mg/Fe]\nturnovers for satellite galaxies of different masses reveals that higher\nluminosity systems, for which the [Mg/Fe] abundance declines at higher\nmetallicities, present enhanced [Y/Eu] abundances, particularly in the [Fe/H]\nregime between -2.25 and -1.25 dex. In addition, the analysis has uncovered a\nchemo-dynamical correlation for both globular clusters and field stars of the\nGalactic halo, accounting for about half of the [Y/Eu] abundance spread. [Y/Eu]\nunder-abundances typical of protracted chemical evolutions, are preferentially\nobserved in polar-like orbits, pointing to a possible anisotropy in the\naccretion processes. Our results strongly suggest that the observed [Y/Eu]\nabundance spread in the Milky Way halo could result from a mixture of systems\nwith different masses. They also highlight that both nature and nurture are\nrelevant to the Milky Way formation, since its primordial epochs, opening new\npathways for chemical diagnostics of our Galaxy building up. Recio-Blanco_2020 Recio-Blanco et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2007.08313
366 2001.06009 2020-07-13 Robert J. J. Grand, Daisuke Kawata, Vasily Belokurov, Alis J. Deason, Azadeh Fattahi, Francesca Fragkoudi, Facundo A. Gómez, Federico Marinacci, Rüdiger Pakmor Sausage & Mash: The dual origin of the Galactic thick disc and halo from the gas-rich Gaia-Enceladus-Sausage merger We analyse a set of cosmological magneto-hydrodynamic simulations of the\nformation of Milky Way-mass galaxies identified to have a prominent radially\nanisotropic stellar halo component similar to the so-called "Gaia Sausage"\nfound in the Gaia data. We examine the effects of the progenitor of the Sausage\n(the Gaia-Enceladus-Sausage, GES) on the formation of major galactic components\nanalogous to the Galactic thick disc and inner stellar halo. We find that the\nGES merger is likely to have been gas-rich and contribute 10-50$\%$ of gas to a\nmerger-induced centrally concentrated starburst that results in the rapid\nformation of a compact, rotationally supported thick disc that occupies the\ntypical chemical thick disc region of chemical abundance space. We find\nevidence that gas-rich mergers heated the proto-disc of the Galaxy, scattering\nstars onto less-circular orbits such that their rotation velocity and\nmetallicity positively correlate, thus contributing an additional component\nthat connects the Galactic thick disc to the inner stellar halo. We demonstrate\nthat the level of kinematic heating of the proto-galaxy correlates with the\nkinematic state of the population before the merger, the progenitor mass and\norbital eccentricity of the merger. Furthermore, we show that the mass and time\nof the merger can be accurately inferred from local stars on counter-rotating\norbits. Grand_2020 Grand et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2001.06009
367 2007.05849 2020-07-11 P. Pietrukowicz, A. Udalski, I. Soszynski, D. M. Skowron, M. Wrona, M. K. Szymanski, R. Poleski, K. Ulaczyk, S. Kozlowski, J. Skowron, P. Mroz, K. Rybicki, P. Iwanek, M. Gromadzki Properties of the Milky Way's Old Populations Based on Photometric Metallicities of the OGLE RR Lyrae Stars We have used photometric data on almost 91 000 fundamental-mode RR Lyrae\nstars (type RRab) detected by the OGLE survey to investigate properties of old\npopulations in the Milky Way. Based on their metallicity distributions, we\ndemonstrate that the Galaxy is built from three distinct old components: halo,\nbulge, and disk. The distributions reach their maxima at approximately\n[Fe/H]_J95 = -1.2, -1.0, and -0.6 dex on the Jurcsik's metallicity scale,\nrespectively. We find that, very likely, the entire halo is formed from\ninfalling dwarf galaxies. It is evident that halo stars penetrate the inner\nregions of the Galactic bulge. We estimate that about one-third of all RR Lyr\nstars within the bulge area belong in fact to the halo population. The whole\nold bulge is dominated by two populations, A and B, represented by a double\nsequence in the period-amplitude (Bailey) diagram. The boundary in iron\nabundance between the halo and the disk population is at about [Fe/H]_J95 =\n-0.8 dex. Using Gaia DR2 for RRab stars in the disk area, we show that the\nobserved dispersion of proper motions along the Galactic latitude decreases\nsmoothly with the increasing metal content excluding a bump around [Fe/H]_J95 =\n-1.0 dex. Pietrukowicz_2020 Pietrukowicz et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2007.05849
368 2007.04455 2020-07-08 C. Babusiaux, C. Fourtune-Ravard, C. Hottier, F. Arenou, A. Gomez FEDReD I: 3D extinction and stellar maps by Bayesian deconvolution Context. While Gaia enables to probe in great detail the extended local\nneighbourhood, the thin disk structure at larger distances remains sparsely\nexplored.\n Aims. We aim here to build a non-parametric 3D model of the thin disc\nstructures handling both the extinction and the stellar density simultaneously.\n Methods. We developed a Bayesian deconvolution method in two dimensions:\nextinction and distance. It uses a reference catalogue which completeness\ninformation defines the selection function. It is designed so that any\ncomplementary information from other catalogues can be added. It has also been\ndesigned to be robust to outliers, frequent in crowded fields, and differential\nextinction. The prior information is designed to be minimal: only a reference\nH-R diagram. We derived for this an empirical H-R diagram of the thin disk\nusing Gaia DR2 data and synthetic isochrone-based H-R diagrams can also be\nused.\n Results. We validated the method on simulations and real fields using 2MASS\nand UKIDSS data complemented by Gaia DR2 photometry and parallaxes. We detail\nthe results of two test fields: a 2MASS field centred around the NGC 4815 open\ncluster which shows an over-density of both extinction and stellar density at\nthe cluster distance, and a UKIDSS field at $l=10^{\circ}$ where we recover the\nposition of the Galactic bar. Babusiaux_2020 Babusiaux et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2007.04455
369 2007.03808 2020-07-07 Luciana Bianchi, Bernard Shiao Matched photometric catalogs of GALEX UV sources with Gaia DR2 and SDSS DR14 databases (GUVmatch) We have matched the ultraviolet (UV) sources in GUVcat_AIS (Bianchi et\nal.2017) with optical databases having similar depth and wide sky coverage.\nGUVcat_AIS has GALEX far-UV (FUV, lambda-eff ~1528\AA ) and near-UV (NUV,\nlambda-eff ~2310\AA) photometry of approx 83~million sources, covering 24,788\nsquare degrees of the sky, with typical depth of FUV=19.9, NUV=20.8~ABmag.\nMatches with Gaia and SDSS databases are presented here.\n Gaia data release 2 (DR2), covering the entire GUVcat footprint (Bianchi et\nal. 2019), detected about one third of the $GUVcat\_AIS$ sources. We found\n31,925,294 Gaia~DR2 counterparts to 30,024,791 GUVcat_AIS unique sources, with\nphotometry in $Gaia$~$G$ band, and often also in $Gaia$~$BP$ and $RP$ bands;\n26,275,572 matches have a parallax measurement,\n21,084,628/18,588,140/16,357,505 with parallax error less than 50%/30%/20%.\n The match with SDSS data release 14 (DR14) yields 23,310,532 counterparts to\n22,207,563 unique GUVcat_AIS sources, 10,167,460 of which are point-like, over\na total overlap area of $\approx$11,100~square~degrees (Bianchi et al. 2019)}.\nSDSS adds to the UV photometry five optical magnitudes: $u,g,r,i,z$, and\noptical spectra of 860,224 matched sources.\n We used a match radius of 3arcsec, consistent with previous works (e.g.,\nBianchi et al. 2011a), although the positions agree to $\lesssim$1.5arcsec for\nthe majority of [point-like] matched-sources, in order to identify possible\nmultiple matches whose UV flux could be unresolved in GALEX imaging. The\ncatalogs can be trimmed to a tighter match radius using the provided\nseparation.\n The multi-band photometry is used to identify classes of astrophysical\nobjects that are prominent in UV, to characterise the content of the $GUVmatch$\ncatalogs, where stars in different evolutionary stages, QSOs, and galaxies can\nbe separated. Bianchi_2020 Bianchi and Shiao 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2007.03808
370 2007.02888 2020-07-06 S. Randich, L. Pasquini, E. Franciosini, L. Magrini, R. J. Jackson, R. D. Jeffries, V. d'Orazi, D. Romano, N. Sanna, G. Tautvaisienė, M. Tsantaki, N. J. Wright, G. Gilmore, T. Bensby, A. Bragaglia, E. Pancino, R. Smiljanic, A. Bayo, G. Carraro, A. Gonneau, A. Hourihane, L. Morbidelli, C. C Worley The Gaia-ESO Survey: Galactic evolution of lithium at high metallicity Reconstructing the Galactic evolution of lithium (Li) is the main tool used\nto constrain the source(s) of Li enrichment in the Galaxy. Recent results have\nsuggested a decline in Li at supersolar metallicities, which may indicate\nreduced production. We exploit the unique characteristics of the Gaia-ESO\nSurvey open star cluster sample to further investigate this issue and to better\nconstrain the evolution of Li at high metallicity. We trace the the upper\nenvelope of Li abundance versus metallicity evolution using 18 clusters and\nconsidering members that should not have suffered any Li depletion. At variance\nwith previous claims, we do not find any evidence of a Li decrease at high\nmetallicity. The most metal-rich clusters in the sample ([Fe/H] about 0.3)\nactually show the highest Li abundances, with A(Li) > 3.4. Our results clearly\nshow that previous findings, which were based on field stars, were affected by\nselection effects. The metal-rich population in the solar neighbourhood is\ncomposed of relatively old and cool stars that have already undergone some Li\ndepletion; hence, their measured Li does not represent the initial interstellar\nmedium abundance, but a lower limit to it. Randich_2020 Randich et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2007.02888
371 2007.00852 2020-07-02 Hao Tian, Chao Liu, Yougang Wang, Yan Xu, Chengqun Yang, Bo Zhang, Xiang-Xiang Xue Differential rotation of the halo traced by the K-giant stars We use K-giant stars selected from the LAMOST DR5 to study the variation of\nthe rotational velocity of the galactic halo at different space positions.\nModelling the rotational velocity distribution with both the halo and disk\ncomponents, we find that the rotational velocity of the halo population\ndecreases almost linearly with increasing vertical distance to the galactic\ndisk plane, $Z$, at fixed galactocentric radius, $R$. 372 2003.11039 2020-06-26 Diane K Feuillet, Sofia Feltzing, Christian Sahlholdt, Luca Casagrande The SkyMapper-Gaia RVS view of the Gaia-Enceladus-Sausage -- an investigation of the metallicity and mass of the Milky Way's last major merger We characterize the Gaia-Enceladus-Sausage kinematic structure recently\ndiscovered in the Galactic halo using photometric metallicities from the\nSkyMapper survey, and kinematics from Gaia radial velocities measurements. By\nexamining the metallicity distribution functions (MDFs) of stars binned in\nkinematic/action spaces, we find that the $\sqrt{J_R}$ vs $L_z$ space allows\nfor the cleanest selection of Gaia-Enceladus-Sausage stars with minimal\ncontamination from disc or halo stars formed in situ or in other past mergers.\nStars with $30 \leq \sqrt{J_R} \leq 50$ (kpc km s$^{-1})^{1/2}$ and $-500 \leq\nL_z \leq 500$ kpc km s$^{-1}$ have a narrow MDF centered at [Fe/H] $= -1.17$\ndex with a dispersion of 0.34 dex. This [Fe/H] estimate is more metal-rich than\nliterature estimates by $0.1-0.3$ dex. Based on the MDFs, we find that\nselection of Gaia-Enceladus-Sausage stars in other kinematic/action spaces\nwithout additional population information leads to contaminated samples. The\nclean Gaia-Enceladus-Sausage sample selected according to our criteria is\nslightly retrograde and lies along the blue sequence of the high $V_T$ halo CMD\ndual sequence. Using a galaxy mass-metallicity relation derived from\ncosmological simulations and assuming a mean stellar age of 10 Gyr we estimate\nthe mass of the Gaia-Enceladus-Sausage progenitor satellite to be\n$10^{8.85-9.85}$ M$_{\odot}$, which is consistent with literature estimates\nbased on disc dynamic and simulations. Additional information on detailed\nabundances and ages would be needed for a more sophisticated selection of\npurely Gaia-Enceladus-Sausage stars. Feuillet_2020 Feuillet et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2003.11039
373 2006.14649 2020-06-25 A. M. Melnik, A. K. Dambis Distance scale for high-luminosity stars in OB associations and in field with Gaia DR2. Spurious systematic motions We calculated the median parallaxes for 47 OB associations including at least\n10 stars with known Gaia DR2 parallaxes. A comparison between trigonometric and\nphotometric parallaxes of OB associations reveals a zero-point offset of\ndelta_pi=-0.11 +\- 0.04 mas indicating that Gaia DR2 parallaxes are, on\naverage, underestimated and the distances derived from them are overestimated.\nThe correction of delta_pi=-0.11 mas is consistent with the estimate that\nArenou et al. (2018) obtained for bright stars. An analysis of parallaxes of OB\nassociations and high-luminosity field stars confirms our previous conclusion\n(Dambis et al. 2001) that the distance scale for OB stars established by Blaha\nand Humphreys (1989) must be reduced by 10--20%. Spurious systematic motions of\n10--20 km s-1 at the distances of 2--3 kpc from the Sun are found to arise from\nthe use of the uncorrected Gaia DR2 parallaxes. Melnik_2020a Melnik and Dambis 2020a https://arxiv.org/abs/2006.14649
374 2006.13876 2020-06-24 Chervin F. P. Laporte, Benoit Famaey, Giacomo Monari, Vanessa Hill, Christopher Wegg, Ortwin Gerhard The bar resonances and low angular momentum moving groups in the Galaxy revealed by stellar ages We use the second Gaia data release in combination with the catalog of\nSanders & Das (2018) to dissect the Milky Way disc in phase-space and relative\nages. We confirm and report the existence of multiple velocity moving groups at\nlow azimuthal velocities and angular momenta, below Arcturus, regularly\nseparated by $\sim~18-20\,\rm{km s^{-1}}$ in azimuthal velocity. Such features\nwere predicted to exist more than ten years ago from the reaction of the Milky\nWay to a perturbation in the disc undergoing phase-mixing. These structures\nappear slightly younger than their phase-space surroundings, arguing against an\nextra-galactic origin. We also identify in relative age many of the classical\nridges in the plane of azimuthal velocity vs. Galactocentric radius,\ntraditionally associated with resonance features. These ridges are also younger\nthan their phase-space surroundings in accordance with predictions from recent\nstate-of-the-art cosmological hydrodynamical simulations of Milky Way-like\ngalaxies. We study the response of dynamically young and old stellar disc\npopulations to resonances from an analytic model of a large bar, which,\nremarkably, qualitatively reproduces the trends seen in the data. Our results\nre-inforce the idea that the Galactic disc is currently being shaped by both\ninternal and external perturbations, and that, while absolute isochrone ages\nhave to be taken with great care, exploring the dynamical structure of the disc\nin stellar ages, especially with future asteroseismic data, will provide much\nstronger constraints than metallicity/abundance trends alone. Laporte_2020 Laporte et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2006.13876
375 2003.04318 2020-06-15 Axel Widmark, Khyati Malhan, Pablo F. de Salas, Sofia Sivertsson Measuring the Matter Density of the Galactic Disk Using Stellar Streams We present a novel method for determining the total matter surface density of\nthe Galactic disk by analysing the kinematics of a dynamically cold stellar\nstream that passes through or close to the Galactic plane. The method relies on\nthe fact that the vertical component of energy for such stream stars is\napproximately constant, such that their vertical positions and vertical\nvelocities are interrelated via the matter density of the Galactic disk. By\ntesting our method on mock data stellar streams, with realistic phase-space\ndispersions and Gaia uncertainties, we demonstrate that it is applicable to\nsmall streams out to a distance of a few kilo-parsec, and that the surface\ndensity of the disk can be determined to a precision of 6 %. This method is\ncomplementary to other mass measurements. In particular, it does not rely on\nany equilibrium assumption for stars in the Galactic disk, and also makes it\npossible to measure the surface density to good precision at large distances\nfrom the Sun. Such measurements would inform us of the matter composition of\nthe Galactic disk and its spatial variation, place stronger constraints on dark\ndisk sub-structure, and even diagnose possible non-equilibrium effects that\nbias other types of dynamical mass measurements. Widmark_2020 Widmark et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2003.04318
376 2006.08625 2020-06-15 Rohan P. Naidu, Charlie Conroy, Ana Bonaca, Benjamin D. Johnson, Yuan-Sen Ting, Nelson Caldwell, Dennis Zaritsky, Phillip A. Cargile Evidence from the H3 Survey that the Stellar Halo is Entirely Comprised of Substructure In the $\Lambda$CDM paradigm the Galactic stellar halo is predicted to harbor\nthe accreted debris of smaller systems. To identify these systems, the H3\nSpectroscopic Survey, combined with $Gaia$, is gathering 6D phase-space and\nchemical information in the distant Galaxy. Here we present a comprehensive\ninventory of structure within 50 kpc from the Galactic center using a sample of\n5684 giants at $|b|>40^{\circ}$ and $|Z|>2$ kpc. We identify known structures\nincluding the high-$\alpha$ disk, the in-situ halo (disk stars heated to\neccentric orbits), Sagittarius (Sgr), $Gaia$-Sausage-Enceladus (GSE), the Helmi\nStreams, Sequoia, and Thamnos. Additionally, we identify the following new\nstructures: (i) Aleph ([Fe/H]$=-0.5$), a low eccentricity structure that rises\na surprising 10 kpc off the plane, (ii, iii) Arjuna ([Fe/H]$=-1.2$) and I'itoi\n([Fe/H]$<-2$), which comprise the high-energy retrograde halo along with\nSequoia, and (iv) Wukong ([Fe/H]$=-1.6$), a prograde phase-space overdensity\nchemically distinct from GSE. For each structure we provide [Fe/H],\n[$\alpha$/Fe], and orbital parameters. Stars born within the Galaxy are a major\ncomponent at $|Z|\sim$2 kpc ($\approx$60$\%$), but their relative fraction\ndeclines sharply to $\lesssim$5$\%$ past 15 kpc. Beyond 15 kpc, $>$80$\%$ of\nthe halo is built by two massive ($M_{\star}\sim10^{8}-10^{9}M_{\odot}$)\naccreted dwarfs: GSE ([Fe/H]$=-1.2$) within 25 kpc, and Sgr ([Fe/H]$=-1.0$)\nbeyond 25 kpc. This explains the relatively high overall metallicity of the\nhalo ([Fe/H]$\approx-1.2$). We attribute $\gtrsim$95$\%$ of the sample to one\nof the listed structures, pointing to a halo built entirely from accreted\ndwarfs and heating of the disk. Naidu_2020 Naidu et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2006.08625
377 2001.08227 2020-06-11 Adam Wheeler, Melissa Ness, Sven Buder, Joss Bland-Hawthorn, Gayandhi De Silva, Michael Hayden, Janez Kos, Geraint F. Lewis, Sarah Martell, Sanjib Sharma, Jeffrey D. Simpson, D. B. Zucker, Thomaž Zwitter Abundances in the Milky Way across five nucleosynthetic channels from 4 million LAMOST stars Large stellar surveys are revealing the chemodynamical structure of the\nGalaxy across a vast spatial extent. However, the many millions of\nlow-resolution spectra observed to date are yet to be fully exploited. We\nemploy The Cannon, a data-driven approach to estimating abundances, to obtain\ndetailed abundances from low-resolution (R = 1800) LAMOST spectra, using the\nGALAH survey as our reference. We deliver five (for dwarfs) or six (for giants)\nestimated abundances representing five different nucleosynthetic channels, for\n3.9 million stars, to a precision of 0.05 - 0.23 dex. Using wide binary pairs,\nwe demonstrate that our abundance estimates provide chemical discriminating\npower beyond metallicity alone. We show the coverage of our catalogue with\nradial, azimuthal and dynamical abundance maps, and examine the neutron capture\nabundances across the disk and halo, which indicate different origins for the\nin-situ and accreted halo populations. LAMOST has near-complete Gaia coverage\nand provides an unprecedented perspective on chemistry across the Milky Way. Wheeler_2020 Wheeler et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2001.08227
378 2006.06577 2020-06-11 J. E. Méndez-Delgado, C. Esteban, J. García-Rojas, K. Z. Arellano-Córdova, M. Valerdi Helium abundances and its radial gradient from the spectra of HII regions and ring nebulae of the Milky Way We determine the radial abundance gradient of helium in the disc of the\nGalaxy from published spectra of 19 $\text{H}\thinspace \text{II}$ regions and\nring nebulae surrounding massive O stars. We revise the Galactocentric\ndistances of the objects considering {\it Gaia} DR2 parallaxes and determine\nthe physical conditions and the ionic abundance of He$^{+}$ in a homogeneous\nway, using between 3 and 10 $\text{He}\thinspace \text{I}$ recombination lines\nin each object. We estimate the total He abundance of the nebulae and its\nradial abundance gradient using four different ICF(He) schemes. The slope of\nthe gradient is always negative and weakly dependent on the ICF(He) scheme,\nespecially when only the objects with log($\eta$) $<$ 0.9 are considered. The\nslope values go from $-$0.0078 to $-$0.0044 dex kpc$^{-1}$, consistent with the\npredictions of chemical evolution models of the Milky Way and chemodynamical\nsimulations of disc galaxies. Finally, we estimate the abundance deviations of\nHe, O and N in a sample of ring nebulae around Galactic WR stars, finding a\nquite similar He overabundance of about +0.24 $\pm$ 0.11 dex in three stellar\nejecta ring nebulae. Méndez-Delgado_2020 Méndez-Delgado et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2006.06577
379 2006.04393 2020-06-10 N. Sanna, E. Franciosini, E. Pancino, A. Mucciarelli, M. Tsantaki, C. Charbonnel, R. Smiljanic, X. Fu, A. Bragaglia, N. Lagarde, G. Tautvaisiene, L. Magrini, S. Randich, T. Bensby, A. J. Korn, A. Bayo, M. Bergemann, G. Carraro, L. Morbidelli The Gaia-ESO Survey: an extremely Li-rich giant in the globular cluster NGC 1261 Lithium rich stars in globular clusters are rare. In fact, only 14 have been\nfound so far, in different evolutionary phases from dwarfs to giants. Different\nmechanisms have been proposed to explain this enhancement, but it is still an\nopen problem. Using spectra collected within the Gaia-ESO Survey, obtained with\nthe GIRAFFE spectrograph at the ESO Very Large Telescope, we present the\ndiscovery of the first Li-rich star in the cluster NGC 1261, the second star\nknown in the red giant branch bump phase. The star shows an extreme Li\noverabundance of A(Li)_LTE=3.92\pm0.14, corresponding to A(Li)_NLTE=3.40 dex.\nWe propose that the Li enhancement is caused by fresh Li production through an\nextra mixing process (sometimes referred to as {\em cool bottom burning}) or\ncould be a pre-existing Li overabundance resulting from binary mass transfer,\nlikely from a red giant branch star, because of the low barium abundance. To\nunambiguously explain the Li enhancement in globular cluster stars, however, a\nreliable determination of the abundance of key species like Be, 6Li, 12C/13C,\nand several s-process elements is required, as well as detailed modeling of\nchromospheric activity indicators. Sanna_2020a Sanna et al. 2020a https://arxiv.org/abs/2006.04393
380 2006.05763 2020-06-10 G. Casali, L. Spina, L. Magrini, A. Karakas, C. Kobayashi, A. R. Casey, S. Feltzing, M. Van der Swaelmen, M. Tsantaki, P. Jofré, A. Bragaglia, D. Feuillet, T. Bensby, K. Biazzo, A. Gonneau, G. Tautvaisiene, M. Baratella, V. Roccatagliata, E. Pancino, S. Sousa, V. Adibekyan, S. Martell, A. Bayo, R. J. Jackson, R. D. Jeffries, G. Gilmore, S. Randich, E. Alfaro, S. E. Zaggia The Gaia-ESO survey: the non-universality of the age-chemical-clocks-metallicity relations in the Galactic disc In the era of large spectroscopic surveys, massive databases of high-quality\nspectra provide tools to outline a new picture of our Galaxy. In this\nframework, an important piece of information is provided by our ability to\ninfer stellar ages. We aim to provide empirical relations between stellar ages\nand abundance ratios for a sample of solar-like stars. We investigate the\ndependence on metallicity, and we apply our relations to Gaia-ESO samples of\nopen clusters and field stars. We analyse high-resolution and high-S/N HARPS\nspectra of a sample of solar-like stars to obtain precise determinations of\ntheir atmospheric parameters and abundances through differential spectral\nanalysis and age through isochrone fitting. We investigate the relations\nbetween ages and abundance ratios. For the abundance ratios with a steeper\ndependence on age, we perform multivariate linear regressions, including the\ndependence on metallicity. We apply our relations to a sample of open clusters\nlocated in 47 kpc. In these clusters, the\ncontent of s-elements is lower than expected from chemical evolution models,\nand consequently the [s/$\alpha$] are lower than in clusters of the same age\nlocated in the solar neighbourhood. With our chemical evolution model and a set\nof empirical yields, we suggest that a strong dependence on the star formation\nhistory and metallicity-dependent yields of s-elements can substantially modify\nthe slope of the [s/$\alpha$]-[Fe/H]-age relation in different regions of the\nGalaxy. Our results point towards a non-universal relation\n[s/$\alpha$]-[Fe/H]-age, indicating the existence of relations at different\nR$_{GC}$ or for different star formation history. A better understanding of the\ns-process at high metallicity is necessary to fully understand the origin of\nthese variations. Casali_2020 Casali et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2006.05763
381 2006.06013 2020-06-10 P. E. Nissen, J. Christensen-Dalsgaard, J. R. Mosumgaard, V. Silva Aguirre, E. Spitoni, K. Verma. High-precision abundances of elements in solar-type stars. Evidence of two distinct sequences in abundance-age relations HARPS spectra with signal-to-noise ratios S/N > 600 at 6000 A were analysed\nwith MARCS model atmospheres to obtain 1D LTE abundances of C, O, Na, Mg, Al,\nSi, Ca, Ti, Cr, Fe, Ni, Sr, and Y for 72 nearby solar-type stars with\nmetallicities in the range -0.3 < [Fe/H] < +0.3 and ASTEC stellar models were\nused to determine stellar ages from effective temperatures, luminosities\nobtained via Gaia DR2 parallaxes, and heavy element abundances. The resulting\nage-metallicity distribution appears to consist of two distinct populations: a\nsequence of old stars with a steep rise of [Fe/H] to about +0.3 dex at an age\nof ~7 Gyr and a younger sequence with [Fe/H] increasing from -0.3 dex to about\n+0.2 dex over the last six Gyr. Furthermore, the trends of several abundance\nratios, [O/Fe], [Na/Fe], [Ca/Fe], and [Ni/Fe], as a function of stellar age\nsplit into two corresponding sequences. The [Y/Mg]-age relation, on the other\nhand, shows no offset between the two age sequences and has no significant\ndependence on [Fe/H], but the components of a visual binary star, zeta\nReticuli, have a large and puzzling deviation. The split of the age-metallicity\ndistribution into two sequences may be interpreted as evidence of two episodes\nof accretion of gas onto the Galactic disk with a quenching of star formation\nin between. Some of the [X/Fe]-age relations support this scenario but other\nrelations are not so easy to explain, which calls for a deeper study of\nsystematic errors in the derived abundances as a function of [Fe/H], in\nparticular 3D non-LTE effects. Nissen_2020 Nissen et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2006.06013

Rodrigues, Ralf-Dieter Scholz, Sanjib Sharma, Kseniia Sysoliatina The Sixth Data Release of the Radial Velocity Experiment (RAVE) -- I: Survey Description, Spectra and Radial Velocities The Radial Velocity Experiment (RAVE) is a magnitude-limited (9 Steinmetz_2020 Steinmetz et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2002.04377
383 2006.02686 2020-06-05 Yang Huang, Ralph Schonrich, Huawei Zhang, Yaqian Wu, Bingqiu Chen, Haifeng Wang, Maosheng Xiang, Chun Wang, Haibo Yuan, Xinyi Li, Weixiang Sun, Ji Li, Xiaowei Liu Mapping the Galactic disk with the LAMOST and Gaia Red clump sample: I: precise distances, masses, ages and 3D velocities of $\sim$ 140000 red clump stars We present a sample of $\sim$ 140,000 primary red clump (RC) stars of\nspectral signal-to-noise ratios higher than 20 from the LAMOST Galactic\nspectroscopic surveys, selected based on their positions in the\nmetallicity-dependent effective temperature--surface gravity and\ncolor--metallicity diagrams, supervised by high-quality $Kepler$\nasteroseismology data. The stellar masses and ages of those stars are further\ndetermined from the LAMOST spectra, using the Kernel Principal Component\nAnalysis method, trained with thousands of RCs in the LAMOST-$Kepler$ fields\nwith accurate asteroseismic mass measurements. The purity and completeness of\nour primary RC sample are generally higher than 80 per cent. For the mass and\nage, a variety of tests show typical uncertainties of 15 and 30 per cent,\nrespectively. Using over ten thousand primary RCs with accurate distance\nmeasurements from the parallaxes of Gaia DR2, we re-calibrate the $K_{\rm s}$\nabsolute magnitudes of primary RCs by, for the first time, considering both the\nmetallicity and age dependencies. With the the new calibration, distances are\nderived for all the primary RCs, with a typical uncertainty of 5--10 per cent,\neven better than the values yielded by the Gaia parallax measurements for stars\nbeyond 3--4 kpc. The sample covers a significant volume of the Galactic disk of\n$4 \leq R \leq 16$ kpc, $|Z| \leq 5$ kpc, and $-20 \leq \phi \leq 50^{\circ}$.\nStellar atmospheric parameters, line-of-sight velocities and elemental\nabundances derived from the LAMOST spectra and proper motions of Gaia DR2 are\nalso provided for the sample stars. Finally, the selection function of the\nsample is carefully evaluated in the color-magnitude plane for different sky\nareas. The sample is publicly available. Huang_2020 Huang et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2006.02686
384 2004.07274 2020-06-01 T. Cantat-Gaudin, F. Anders, A. Castro-Ginard, C. Jordi, M. Romero-Gomez, C. Soubiran, L. Casamiquela, Y. Tarricq, A. Moitinho, A. Vallenari, A. Bragaglia, A. Krone-Martins, M. Kounkel Painting a portrait of the Galactic disc with its stellar clusters The large astrometric and photometric survey performed by the Gaia mission\nallows for a panoptic view of the Galactic disc and in its stellar cluster\npopulation. Hundreds of clusters were only discovered after the latest G data\nrelease (DR2) and have yet to be characterised. Here we make use of the deep\nand homogeneous Gaia photometry down to G=18 to estimate the distance, age, and\ninterstellar reddening for about 2000 clusters identified with Gaia~DR2\nastrometry. We use these objects to study the structure and evolution of the\nGalactic disc. We rely on a set of objects with well-determined parameters in\nthe literature to train an artificial neural network to estimate parameters\nfrom the Gaia photometry of cluster members and their mean parallax. We obtain\nreliable parameters for 1867 clusters. Our new homogeneous catalogue confirms\nthe relative lack of old clusters in the inner disc (with a few notable\nexceptions). We also quantify and discuss the variation of scale height with\ncluster age, and detect the Galactic warp in the distribution of old clusters.\nThis work results in a large and homogenous cluster catalogue. However, the\npresent sample is still unable to trace the Outer spiral arm of the Milky Way,\nwhich indicates that the outer disc cluster census might still be incomplete. Cantat-Gaudin_2020 Cantat-Gaudin et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2004.07274
385 2006.00787 2020-06-01 Paolo Molaro, Gabriele Cescutti, Xiaoting Fu Lithium and Beryllium in the Gaia-Enceladus Galaxy Data from Gaia DR2 and APOGEE surveys revealed a relatively new component in\nthe inner Galactic halo, which is likely the dynamical remnant of a disrupted\ndwarf galaxy named Gaia-Enceladus that collided with the Milky Way about 10\nGyrs ago. This merging event offers an extraordinary opportunity to study\nchemical abundances of elements in a dwarf galaxy, since they are generally\nhampered in external galaxies. Here, we focus on Li and Be in dwarf stars which\nare out of reach even in Local Group galaxies.Searching in GALAH, Gaia-ESO\nsurvey and in literature, we found several existing 7Li abundance\ndeterminations of stars belonging to the Gaia-Enceladus galaxy. The 7Li\nabundances of stars at the low metallicity end overlap with those of the\nGalactic halo.These are effective extragalactic 7Li measurements, which suggest\nthat the {\it Spite plateau} is universal, as is the cosmological Li problem.\nWe found a Li-rich giant out of 101 stars, which suggests a small percentage\nsimilar to that of the Milky Way. We also collect 9Be abundances for a\nsubsample of 25 Gaia-Enceladus stars from literature. Their abundances share\nthe Galactic [Be/H] values at the low metallicity end but grow slower with\n[Fe/H] and show a reduced dispersion. This suggests that the scatter observed\nin the Milky Way could reflect the different \beix\ evolution patterns of\ndifferent stellar components which are mixed-up in the Galactic halo. Molaro_2020 Molaro et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2006.00787
386 2005.14534 2020-05-29 Borja Anguiano, Steven R. Majewski, Chris R. Hayes, Carlos Allende Prieto, Xinlun Cheng, Christian Moni Bidin, Rachael L. Beaton, Timothy C. Beers, Dante Minniti The stellar velocity distribution function in the Milky Way galaxy The stellar velocity distribution function (DF) in the solar vicinity is\nre-examined using data from the SDSS APOGEE survey's DR16 and \emph{Gaia} DR2.\nBy exploiting APOGEE's ability to chemically discriminate with great\nreliability the thin disk, thick disk and (accreted) halo populations, we can,\nfor the first time, derive the three-dimensional velocity DFs for these\nchemically-separated populations. We employ this smaller, but more data-rich\nAPOGEE+{\it Gaia} sample to build a \emph{data-driven model} of the local\nstellar population velocity DFs, and use these as basis vectors for assessing\nthe relative density proportions of these populations over 5 $<$ $R$ $<$ 12\nkpc, and $-1.5$ $<$ $z$ $<$ 2.5 kpc range as derived from the larger, more\ncomplete (i.e., all-sky, magnitude-limited) {\it Gaia} database. We find that\n81.9 $\pm$ 3.1$\%$ of the objects in the selected \emph{Gaia} data-set are\nthin-disk stars, 16.6 $\pm$ 3.2$\%$ are thick-disk stars, and 1.5 $\pm$ 0.1$\%$\nbelong to the Milky Way stellar halo. We also find the local thick-to-thin-disk\ndensity normalization to be $\rho_{T}(R_{\odot})$/$\rho_{t}(R_{\odot})$ = 2.1\n$\pm$ 0.2$\%$, a result consistent with, but determined in a completely\ndifferent way than, typical starcount/density analyses. Using the same\nmethodology, the local halo-to-disk density normalization is found to be\n$\rho_{H}(R_{\odot})$/($\rho_{T}(R_{\odot})$ + $\rho_{t}(R_{\odot})$) = 1.2\n$\pm$ 0.6$\%$, a value that may be inflated due to chemical overlap of halo and\nmetal-weak thick disk stars. Anguiano_2020 Anguiano et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2005.14534
387 2005.12018 2020-05-25 Rui Guo, Chao Liu, Shude Mao, Xiang-Xiang Xue, R. J. Long, Lan Zhang Measuring the local dark matter density with LAMOST DR5 and Gaia DR2 We apply the vertical Jeans equation to the kinematics of Milky Way stars in\nthe solar neighbourhood to measure the local dark matter density. More than\n90,000 G- and K-type dwarf stars are selected from the cross-matched sample of\nLAMOST DR5 and Gaia DR2 for our analyses. The mass models applied consist of a\nsingle exponential stellar disc, a razor thin gas disc and a constant dark\nmatter density. We first consider the simplified vertical Jeans equation which\nignores the tilt term and assumes a flat rotation curve. Under a Gaussian prior\non the total stellar surface density, the local dark matter density inferred\nfrom Markov Chain Monte Carlo simulations is $0.0133_{-0.0022}^{+0.0024}\ {\rm\nM}_{\odot}\,{\rm pc}^{-3}$. The local dark matter densities for subsamples in\nan azimuthal angle range of $-10^{\circ} < \phi < 5^{\circ}$ are consistent\nwithin their 1$\sigma$ errors. However, the northern and southern subsamples\nshow a large discrepancy due to plateaux in the northern and southern vertical\nvelocity dispersion profiles. These plateaux may be the cause of the different\nestimates of the dark matter density between the north and south. Taking the\ntilt term into account has little effect on the parameter estimations and does\nnot explain the north and south asymmetry. Taking half of the difference of\n$\sigma_{z}$ profiles as unknown systematic errors, we then obtain consistent\nmeasurements for the northern and southern subsamples. We discuss the influence\nof the vertical data range, the scale height of the tracer population, the\nvertical distribution of stars and the sample size on the uncertainty of the\ndetermination of the local dark matter density. Guo_2020 Guo et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2005.12018
388 2005.11372 2020-05-22 Karla. Z. Arellano-Córdova, César Esteban, Jorge García-Rojas, J. Eduardo Méndez-Delgado The Galactic radial abundance gradients of C, N, O, Ne, S, Cl and Ar from deep spectra of H II regions We present a reassessment of the radial abundance gradients of C, N, O, Ne,\nS, Cl and Ar in the Milky Way using deep spectra of 33 H II regions gathered\nfrom the literature, covering Galactocentric distances from 6 to 17 kpc. The\ndistances of the objects have been revised using Gaia parallaxes. We\nrecalculate the physical conditions and ionic abundances in an homogeneous way\nusing updated atomic data. All the objects have direct determination of the\nelectron temperature, permitting to derive their precise ionic abundances. We\nanalyze and compare different ICF schemes for each element in order to obtain\nthe most confident total abundances. Due to the revised distances, our results\ndo not support previous claims about a possible flattening of the O/H gradient\nin the inner Galactic disk. We find that the Galactic N/O gradient is rather\nflat, in contrast to what has been found in other spiral galaxies. The slope of\nthe gradients of some elements is sensitive to the ICF scheme used, especially\nin the case of Ne. The dispersion around the fit for the gradients of C, N, O,\nS, Cl and Ar is of the order of the typical uncertainties in the determination\nof the abundances, implying the absence of significant inhomogeneities in the\nchemical composition of the ionized gas phase of the ISM. We find flat\ngradients of log(S/O) and log(Cl/O) and very shallow or flat ones for log(Ne/O)\nand log(Ar/O), consistent with a lockstep evolution of Ne, S, Cl and Ar with\nrespect to O. Arellano-Córdova_2020 Arellano-Córdova et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2005.11372
389 2005.05054 2020-05-20 Iryna Kushniruk, Thomas Bensby, Sofia Feltzing, Christian L. Sahlholdt, Diane Feuillet, Luca Casagrande The HR 1614 moving group is not a dissolving cluster The HR 1614 overdensity in velocity space and has for a long time been known\nas an old (~2 Gyr) and metal-rich ([Fe/H]~0.2) nearby moving group that has a\ndissolving cluster origin. The existence of such old and metal-rich groups in\nthe solar vicinity is quite unexpected since the vast majority of nearby moving\ngroups are known to be young. In the light of new and significantly larger data\nsets we aim to re-investigate the properties and origin of the HR 1614 moving\ngroup.\n To identify and characterise the HR 1614 moving group we use astrometric data\nfrom Gaia DR2; distances, extinction, and reddening corrections from the\nStarHorse code; elemental abundances from the GALAH and APOGEE spectroscopic\nsurveys; and photometric metallicities from the SkyMapper survey. Bayesian ages\nwere estimated for the SkyMapper stars. Since the Hercules stream is the\nclosest kinematical structure to the HR 1614 moving group in velocity space, we\nuse it for comparison purposes. Stars that are likely to be members of the two\ngroups were selected based on their space velocities.\n The HR 1614 moving group is located mainly at negative U velocities, does not\nform an arch of constant energy in the U-V space and is tilted in V. The\noverdensity is not chemically homogeneous but that its stars exist at a wide\nrange of both metallicities, ages, and elemental abundance ratios. They are\nessentially similar to what is observed in the Galactic thin and thick disks, a\nyounger population (~3 Gyr) that is metal-rich (-0.2<[Fe/H]<0.4) and\nalpha-poor. It should therefore not be considered as a dissolving open cluster,\nor an accreted population. We suggest that HR 1614 has a complex origin that\ncould be explained by combining several different mechanisms such as resonances\nwith the Galactic bar and spiral structure, phase-mixing of dissolving spiral\nstructure, and phase-mixing due to an external perturbation. Kushniruk_2020 Kushniruk et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2005.05054
390 2005.08983 2020-05-18 Douglas Boubert, Andrew Everall Completeness of the Gaia-verse II: what are the odds that a star is missing from Gaia DR2? The second data release of the Gaia mission contained astrometry and\nphotometry for an incredible 1,692,919,135 sources, but how many sources did\nGaia miss and where do they lie on the sky? The answer to this question will be\ncrucial for any astronomer attempting to map the Milky Way with Gaia DR2. We\ninfer the completeness of Gaia DR2 by exploiting the fact that it only contains\nsources with at least five astrometric detections. The odds that a source\nachieves those five detections depends on both the number of observations and\nthe probability that an observation of that source results in a detection. We\npredict the number of times that each source was observed by Gaia and assume\nthat the probability of detection is either a function of magnitude or a\ndistribution as a function of magnitude. We fit both these models to the 1.7\nbillion stars of Gaia DR2, and thus are able to robustly predict the\ncompleteness of Gaia across the sky as a function of magnitude. We extend our\nselection function to account for crowding in dense regions of the sky, and\nshow that this is vitally important, particularly in the Galactic bulge and the\nLarge and Small Magellanic Clouds. We find that the magnitude limit at which\nGaia is still 99% complete varies over the sky from $G=18.9$ to $21.3$. We have\ncreated a new Python package selectionfunctions\n(https://github.com/gaiaverse/selectionfunctions) which provides easy access to\nour selection functions. Boubert_2020a Boubert and Everall 2020a https://arxiv.org/abs/2005.08983
391 2002.09496 2020-05-18 Johanna Coronado, Hans-Walter Rix, Wilma H. Trick, Kareem El-Badry, Jan Rybizki, Maosheng Xiang From birth associations to field stars: mapping the small-scale orbit distribution in the Galactic disc Stars born at the same time in the same place should have formed from gas of\nthe same element composition. But most stars subsequently disperse from their\nbirth siblings, in orbit and orbital phase, becoming 'field stars'. Here we\nexplore and provide direct observational evidence for this process in the Milky\nWay disc, by quantifying the probability that orbit-similarity among stars\nimplies indistinguishable metallicity. We define the orbit similarity among\nstars through their distance in action-angle space, $\Delta (J,\theta)$, and\ntheir abundance similarity simply by $\Delta$[Fe/H]. Analyzing a sample of main\nsequence stars from Gaia DR2 and LAMOST, we find an excess of pairs with the\nsame metallicity ($\Delta\mathrm{[Fe/H]}<0.1$) that extends to remarkably large\nseparations in $\Delta (J,\theta)$ that correspond to nearly 1 kpc distances.\nWe assess the significance of this effect through a mock sample, drawn from a\nsmooth and phase-mixed orbit distribution. Through grouping such star pairs\ninto associations with a friend-of-friends algorithm linked by $\Delta\n(J,\theta)$, we find 100s of mono-abundance groups with $\ge 3$ (to $\gtrsim\n20$) members; these groups -- some clusters, some spread across the sky -- are\nover an order-of-magnitude more abundant than expected for a smooth phase-space\ndistribution, suggesting that we are witnessing the 'dissolution' of stellar\nbirth associations into the field. Coronado_2020 Coronado et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2002.09496
392 1912.06847 2020-05-12 Deokkeun An, Timothy C. Beers A Blueprint for the Milky Way's Stellar Populations: The Power of Large Photometric and Astrometric Surveys Recent advances from astronomical surveys have revealed spatial, chemical,\nand kinematical inhomogeneities in the inner region of the stellar halo of the\nMilky Way Galaxy. In particular, large spectroscopic surveys, combined with\nGaia astrometric data, have provided powerful tools for analyzing the detailed\nabundances and accurate kinematics for individual stars. Despite these\nnoteworthy efforts, however, spectroscopic samples are typically limited by the\nnumbers of stars considered; their analysis and interpretation are also\nhampered by the complex selection functions that are often employed. Here we\npresent a powerful alternative approach $-$ a synoptic view of the spatial,\nchemical, and kinematical distributions of stars in the Milky Way based on\nlarge photometric survey databases, enabled by a well-calibrated technique for\nobtaining individual stellar metal abundances from broad-band photometry. We\ncombine metallicities with accurate proper motions from the Gaia mission along\nthe Prime Meridian of the Galaxy, and find that various stellar components are\nclearly separated from each other in the metallicity versus rotation-velocity\nspace. The observed metallicity distribution of the inner-halo stars deviates\nfrom the traditional single-peaked distribution, and exhibits complex\nsubstructures comprising varying contributions from individual stellar\npopulations, sometimes with striking double peaks at low metallicities. The\nsubstructures revealed from our less-biased, comprehensive maps demonstrate the\nclear advantages of this approach, which can be built upon by future mixed-band\nand broad-band photometric surveys, and used as a blueprint for identifying the\nstars of greatest interest for upcoming spectroscopic studies. An_2020 An and Beers 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/1912.06847
393 2005.04969 2020-05-11 Tilly A. Evans, Azadeh Fattahi, Alis J. Deason, Carlos S. Frenk How Unusual is the Milky Way's Assembly History? In the $\Lambda$CDM model of structure formation galactic haloes build up by\naccretion of mass and mergers of smaller subunits. The most recent massive\nmerger event experienced by the Milky Way (MW) halo was the accretion of the\nLarge Magellanic Cloud (LMC; which has a stellar mass of $\sim \;\n10^9M_\odot$). Recent analyses of galactic stellar data from the \textit{Gaia}\nsatellite have uncovered an earlier massive accretion event, the\nGaia-Enceladus-Sausage (GES), which merged with the MW around 10 Gyr ago. Here,\nwe use the EAGLE cosmological hydrodynamics simulation to study properties of\nsimulated MW-mass haloes constrained to have accretion histories similar to\nthat of the MW, specifically the recent accretion of an "LMC" galaxy and a\n"GES'' merger, with a quiescent period between the GES merger and the infall of\nthe LMC (the "GES \& LMC" class). We find that $\sim 16$ per cent of MW-mass\nhaloes have an LMC; $\sim 5$ per cent have a GES event and no further merger\nwith an equally massive object since $z=1$; and only $0.65$ per cent belong to\nthe LMC \& GES category. The progenitors of the MWs in this last category are\nmuch less massive than average at early times but eventually catch up with the\nmean. The LMC \& GES class of galaxies naturally end up in the "blue cloud" in\nthe colour-magnitude diagram at $z=0$, tend to have a disc morphology and have\na larger than average number of satellite galaxies. Evans_2020 Evans et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2005.04969
394 2005.04121 2020-05-08 Mark D.
