We look in greater detail\nusing chemistry from LAMOST DR5, identifying a population of retrograde stars\nwith thick-disc chemistry. Our thick disc kinematic model cannot account for\nthis population and so we conclude there is likely to be a contribution from\nheated or accreted stars in the Solar Neighbourhood. We also investigate\nproposed dynamical substructures in this sample, concluding that they are\nprobably due to resonant orbits rather than accreted populations. Finally we\nprovide new insights on the nature of the two sequences and their relation with\npast accretion events and the primordial Galactic disc. Amarante_2020 Amarante et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/1912.12679
439 2001.03627 2020-01-10 Leire Beitia-Antero, Ana Inés Gómez de Castro, Raúl de la Fuente Marcos High reddening patches in Gaia DR2. Possible artifacts or indication of star formation at the edge of the Galactic disk Context: Deep GALEX UV data show that the extreme outskirts of some spiral\ngalaxies are teeming with star formation. Such young stellar populations\nevolving so far away from the bulk of their host galaxies challenge our overall\nunderstanding of how star formation proceeds at galactic scales. It is at\npresent unclear whether our own Milky Way may also exhibit ongoing and recent\nstar formation beyond the conventional edge of the disk ($\sim 15$ kpc). Aims:\nUsing \textit{Gaia} DR2 data, we aim to determine if such a population is\npresent in the Galactic halo, beyond the nominal radius of the Milky Way disk.\nMethods: We studied the kinematics of \textit{Gaia} DR2 sources with parallax\nvalues between 1/60 and 1/30 milliarcseconds towards two regions that show\nabnormally high values of extinction and reddening; the results are compared\nwith predictions from GALAXIA Galactic model. We also plotted the\ncolor-magnitude (CM) diagrams with heliocentric distances computed inverting\nthe parallaxes, and studied the effects of the large parallax errors by Monte\nCarlo sampling. Results: The kinematics point towards a Galactic origin for one\nof the regions, while the provenance of the stars in the other is not clear. A\nspectroscopic analysis of some of the sources in the first region confirms that\nthey are located in the halo. The CM diagram of the sources suggests that some\nof them are young. Beitia-Antero_2020 Beitia-Antero et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2001.03627
440 2001.02916 2020-01-09 A. V. Loktin, M. E. Popova On the Metallicity Gradient in the Galactic Disk The problem of the chemical composition gradient in the galactic disk is\nstudied based on a sample of metallicity estimates of open star clusters, using\nGaia DR2-improved distance estimates. A clearly non-monotonic variation was\nobserved in the average metallicity of clusters with increasing galactocentric\ndistance. One can clearly see the metallicity jump of 0.22 in [Fe/H] at a\nGalactocentric distance of about 9.5 kpc, which appears to be linked to the\nouter boundary of the thinnest and youngest component of the galactic disk. The\nabsence of a significant metallicity gradient in the internal (R<9 kpc) and\nexternal (R>10 kpc) regions of the disk demonstrates the absence of noticeable\nmetal enrichment at times of the order of the ages corresponding to those of\nthe disk regions under consideration. Observational data show that the disk\nexperiences noticeable metal enrichment only during the starburst epochs. No\nsignificant dependence was found between the average metallicity and the age of\nthe clusters. Loktin_2020 Loktin and Popova 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2001.02916
441 1910.06335 2020-01-06 S. Khoperskov, O. Gerhard, P. Di Matteo, M. Haywood, D. Katz, S. Khrapov, A. Khoperskov, M. Arnaboldi Hic sunt dracones: Cartography of the Milky Way spiral arms and bar resonances with Gaia Data Release 2 In this paper we introduce a new method for analysing Milky Way phase-space\nwhich allows us to reveal the imprint left by the Milky Way bar and spiral arms\non the stars with full phase-space data in Gaia Data Release 2. The\nunprecedented quality and extended spatial coverage of these data enable us to\ndiscover six prominent stellar density structures in the disc to a distance of\n5 kpc from the Sun. Four of these structures correspond to the spiral arms\ndetected previously in the gas and young stars (Scutum-Centaurus, Sagittarius,\nLocal and Perseus). The remaining two are associated with the main resonances\nof the Milky Way bar where corotation is placed at around 6.2 kpc and the outer\nLindblad resonance beyond the Solar radius, at around 9 kpc. For the first time\nwe provide evidence of the imprint left by spiral arms and resonances in the\nstellar densities not relying on a specific tracer, through enhancing the\nsignatures left by these asymmetries. Our method offers new avenues for\nstudying how the stellar populations in our Galaxy are shaped. Khoperskov_2020 Khoperskov et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/1910.06335
442 2001.01481 2020-01-06 I. B. Thompson, A. Udalski, A. Dotter, M. Rozyczka, A. Schwarzenberg-Czerny, W. Pych, Y. Beletsky, G. S. Burley, J. L. Marshall, A. McWilliam, N. Morrell, D. Osip, A. Monson, S. E. Persson, M. K. Szymański, I. Soszyński, R. Poleski, K. Ulaczyk, Ł. Wyrzykowski, S. Kozłowski, P. Mróz, P. Pietrukowicz, J. Skowron The Cluster Ages Experiment (CASE). VIII. Age and Distance of the Globular Cluster 47 Tuc from the Analysis of Two Detached Eclipsing Binaries We use photometric and spectroscopic observations of the eclipsing binary E32\nin the globular cluster 47 Tuc to derive the masses, radii, and luminosities of\nthe component stars. The system has an orbital period of 40.9 d, a markedly\neccentric orbit with e = 0.24, and is shown to be a member of or a recent\nescaper from the cluster. We obtain Mp = 0.862(5) Msun , Rp = 1.183(3) Rsun ,\nLp = 1.65(5) Lsun for the primary and Ms = 0.827(5) Msun , Rs = 1.004(4) Rsun ,\nLs = 1.14(4) Lsun for the secondary. Based on these data and on an earlier\nanalysis of the binary V69 in 47 Tuc we measure the distance to the cluster\nfrom the distance moduli of the component stars, and, independently, from a\ncolor - surface brightness calibration. We obtain 4.55(3) and 4.50(7) kpc,\nrespectively - values compatible within 1 sigma with recent estimates based on\nGaia DR2 parallaxes. By comparing the M - R diagram of the two binaries and the\ncolor-magnitude diagram of 47 Tuc to Dartmouth model isochrones we estimate the\nage of the cluster to be 12.0 pm 0.5 Gyr, and the helium abundance of the\ncluster to be Y approx 0.25. Thompson_2020 Thompson et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/2001.01481
443 1912.11142 2020-01-02 D. M. Skowron, J. Skowron, P. Mróz, A. Udalski, P. Pietrukowicz, I. Soszyński, M. K. Szymański, R. Poleski, S. Kozłowski, K. Ulaczyk, K. Rybicki, P. Iwanek, M. Wrona, M. Gromadzki Mapping the Northern Galactic Disk Warp with Classical Cepheids We present an updated three dimensional map of the Milky Way based on a\nsample of 2431 classical Cepheid variable stars, supplemented with about 200\nnewly detected classical Cepheids from the OGLE survey. The new objects were\ndiscovered as a result of a dedicated observing campaign of the ~280 square\ndegree extension of the OGLE footprint of the Galactic disk during 2018-2019\nobserving seasons. These regions cover the main part of the northern Galactic\nwarp that has been deficient in Cepheids so far. We use direct distances to the\nsample of over 2390 classical Cepheids to model the distribution of the young\nstellar population in the Milky Way and recalculate the parameters of the\nGalactic disk warp. Our data show that its northern part is very prominent and\nits amplitude is ~10% larger than that of the southern part. By combining Gaia\nastrometric data with the Galactic rotation curve and distances to Cepheids\nfrom our sample, we construct a map of the vertical component of the velocity\nvector for all Cepheids in the Milky Way disk. We find large-scale vertical\nmotions with amplitudes of 10-20 km/s, such that Cepheids located in the\nnorthern warp exhibit large positive vertical velocity (toward the north\nGalactic pole), whereas those in the southern warp - negative vertical velocity\n(toward the south Galactic pole). Skowron_2020 Skowron et al. 2020 https://arxiv.org/abs/1912.11142
444 1907.02527 2019-12-20 Nicholas W. Borsato, Sarah L. Martell, Jeffrey D. Simpson Identifying Stellar Streams in Gaia DR2 with Data Mining Techniques Streams of stars from captured dwarf galaxies and dissolved globular clusters\nare identifiable through the similarity of their orbital parameters, a fact\nthat remains true long after the streams have dispersed spatially. We calculate\nthe integrals of motion for 44855 stars, to a distance of 4 kpc from the Sun,\nwhich have full and accurate 6D phase space positions in the Gaia DR2\ncatalogue. We then apply a novel combination of data mining, numerical and\nstatistical techniques to search for stellar streams. This process returns\nseven high-confidence streams (including four that were not previously known),\nall of which display tight clustering in the integral of motion space.\nColour-magnitude diagrams indicate that these streams are relatively simple,\nold, metal-poor populations. A combined evaluation of the kinematics and\ncolour-magnitude properties suggests that the previously undiscovered streams\nare fragments of the Gaia-Enceladus progenitor. The success of this project\ndemonstrates the usefulness of data mining techniques in exploring large\ndatasets. Borsato_2019 Borsato et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1907.02527
445 1912.08829 2019-12-18 Suchira Sarkar, Chanda J. Jog General model of vertical distribution of stars in the Milky Way using complete Jeans equations The self-consistent vertical density distribution in a thin, isothermal disc\nis typically given by a sech^2 law, as shown in the classic work by Spitzer\n(1942). This is obtained assuming that the radial and vertical motions are\ndecoupled and only the vertical term is used in the Poisson equation. We argue\nthat in the region of low density as in the outer disc this treatment is no\nlonger valid. We develop a general, complete model that includes both radial\nand vertical terms in the Poisson equation and write these in terms of the full\nradial and vertical Jeans equations which take account of the non-flat observed\nrotation curve, the random motions, and the cross term that indicates the\ntilted stellar velocity ellipsoid. We apply it to the Milky Way and show that\nthese additional effects change the resulting density distribution\nsignificantly, such that the mid-plane density is higher and the disc thickness\n(HWHM) is lower by 30-40% in the outer Galaxy. Further, the vertical\ndistribution is no longer given as a sech^2 function even for an isothermal\ncase. These predicted differences are now within the verification limit of new,\nhigh-resolution data for example from GAIA and hence could be confirmed. Sarkar_2019 Sarkar and Jog 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1912.08829
446 1912.07686 2019-12-16 R. Zinn, X. Chen, A. C. Layden, D. I. Casetti-Dinescu Local RR Lyrae Stars: native and alien Measurements of [Fe/H] and radial velocity are presented for 89 RR Lyrae\n(RRL) candidates within 6 kpc of the Sun. After removal of two suspected\nnon-RRL, these stars were added to an existing database, which yielded 464 RRL\nwith [Fe/H] on a homogeneous scale. Using data from the Gaia satellite (Data\nRelease 2), we calculated the positions and space velocities for this sample.\nThese data confirm the existence of a thin-disc of RRL with [alpha/Fe] ~ solar.\nThe majority of the halo RRL with large total energies have near zero angular\nmomenta about the Z axis. Kinematically these stars closely resemble the\nGaia-Sausage/Gaia-Enceladus stars that others have proposed are debris from the\nmerger of a large galaxy with the Milky Way. The metallicity and period\ndistributions of the RRL and their positions in the period-amplitude diagram\nsuggest that this disrupted galaxy was as massive as the Large Magellanic Cloud\nand possibly greater. Zinn_2019 Zinn et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1912.07686
447 1912.06707 2019-12-13 Christian R. Hayes, Steven R. Majewski, Sten Hasselquist, Borja Anguiano, Matthew Shetrone, David R. Law, Ricardo P. Schiavon, Katia Cunha, Verne V. Smith, Rachael L. Beaton, Adrian M. Price-Whelan, Carlos Allende Prieto, Giuseppina Battaglia, Dmitry Bizyaev, Joel R. Brownstein, Roger E. Cohen, Peter M. Frinchaboy, D. A. Garcia-Hernandez, Ivan Lacerna, Richard R. Lane, Szabolcs Meszaros, Christian Moni Bidin, Ricardo R. Munoz, David L. Nidever, Audrey Oravetz, Daniel Oravetz, Kaike Pan, Alexandre Roman-Lopes, Jennifer Sobeck, Guy Stringfellow Metallicity and $α$-element Abundance Gradients along the Sagittarius Stream as Seen by APOGEE Using 3D positions and kinematics of stars relative to the Sagittarius (Sgr)\norbital plane and angular momentum, we identify 166 Sgr stream members observed\nby the Apache Point Observatory Galactic Evolution Experiment (APOGEE) that\nalso have Gaia DR2 astrometry. This sample of 63/103 stars in the Sgr\ntrailing/leading arm are combined with an APOGEE sample of 710 members of the\nSgr dwarf spheroidal core (385 of them newly presented here) to establish\ndifferences of 0.6 dex in median metallicity and 0.1 dex in [$\alpha$/Fe]\nbetween our Sgr core and dynamically older stream samples. Mild chemical\ngradients are found internally along each arm, but these steepen when anchored\nby core stars. With a model of Sgr tidal disruption providing estimated\ndynamical ages (i.e., stripping times) for each stream star, we find a mean\nmetallicity gradient of 0.12 +/- 0.03 dex/Gyr for stars stripped from Sgr over\ntime. For the first time, an [$\alpha$/Fe] gradient is also measured within the\nstream, at 0.02 +/- 0.01 dex/Gyr using magnesium abundances and 0.04 +/- 0.01\ndex/Gyr using silicon, which imply that the Sgr progenitor had significant\nradial abundance gradients. We discuss the magnitude of those inferred\ngradients and their implication for the nature of the Sgr progenitor within the\ncontext of the current family of Milky Way satellite galaxies, and suggest that\nmore sophisticated Sgr models are needed to properly interpret the growing\nchemodynamical detail we have on the Sgr system. Hayes_2019 Hayes et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1912.06707
448 1903.02003 2019-12-05 Jonathan P. Clarke, Christopher Wegg, Ortwin Gerhard, Leigh C. Smith, Phil W. Lucas, Shola M. Wylie The Milky Way bar/bulge in proper motions: a 3D view from VIRAC & Gaia We have derived absolute proper motions of the entire Galactic bulge region\nfrom VIRAC and Gaia. We present these as both integrated on-sky maps and, after\nisolating standard candle red clump (RC) stars, as a function of distance using\nRC magnitude as a proxy. These data provide a new global, 3-dimensional view of\nthe Milky Way barred bulge kinematics. We find a gradient in the mean\nlongitudinal proper motion, $<\mu_l^\star>$, between the different sides of the\nbar, which is sensitive to the bar pattern speed. The split RC has distinct\nproper motions and is colder than other stars at similar distance. The proper\nmotion correlation map has a quadrupole pattern in all magnitude slices showing\nno evidence for a separate, more axisymmetric inner bulge component. The\nline-of-sight integrated kinematic maps show a high central velocity dispersion\nsurrounded by a more asymmetric dispersion profile. $\sigma_{\mu_l} /\n\sigma_{\mu_b}$ is smallest, $\sim1.1$, near the minor axis and reaches\n$\sim1.4$ near the disc plane. The integrated $<\mu_b>$ pattern signals a\nsuperposition of bar rotation and internal streaming motion, with the near part\nshrinking in latitude and the far part expanding. To understand and interpret\nthese remarkable data, we compare to a made-to-measure barred dynamical model,\nfolding in the VIRAC selection function to construct mock maps. We find that\nour model of the barred bulge, with a pattern speed of 37.5 $\mathrm{km \,\ns^{-1} \, kpc^{-1}}$, is able to reproduce all observed features impressively\nwell. Dynamical models like this will be key to unlocking the full potential of\nthese data. Clarke_2019 Clarke et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1903.02003
449 1912.02816 2019-12-05 J. Grady, V. Belokurov, N. W. Evans Age Demographics of the Milky Way Disk and Bulge We use the extensive $Gaia$ Data Release 2 set of Long Period Variables to\nselect a sample of Oxygen-rich Miras throughout the Milky Way disk and bulge\nfor study. Exploiting the relation between Mira pulsation period and stellar\nage/chemistry, we slice the stellar density of the Galactic disk and bulge as a\nfunction of period. We find the morphology of both components evolves as a\nfunction of stellar age/chemistry with the stellar disk being stubby at old\nages, becoming progressively thinner and more radially extended at younger\nstellar ages, consistent with the picture of inside-out and upside-down\nformation of the Milky Way's disk. We see evidence of a perturbed disk, with\nlarge-scale stellar over-densities visible both in and away from the stellar\nplane. We find the bulge is well modelled by a triaxial boxy distribution with\nan axis ratio of $\sim [1:0.4:0.3]$. The oldest of the Miras ($\sim$ 9-10 Gyr)\nshow little bar-like morphology, whilst the younger stars appear inclined at a\nviewing angle of $\sim 21^{\circ}$ to the Sun-Galactic Centre line. This\nsuggests that bar formation and buckling took place 8-9 Gyr ago, with the older\nMiras being hot enough to avoid being trapped by the growing bar. We find the\nyoungest Miras to exhibit a strong peanut morphology, bearing the\ncharacteristic X-shape of an inclined bar structure. Grady_2019 Grady et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1912.02816
450 1911.08491 2019-11-19 Federico Sestito, Nicolas F. Martin, Else Starkenburg, Anke Arentsen, Rodrigo A. Ibata, Nicolas Longeard, Collin Kielty, Kristopher Youakim, Kim A. Venn, David S. Aguado, Raymond G. Carlberg, Jonay I. Gonzalez Hernandez, Vanessa Hill, Pascale Jablonka, Georges Kordopatis, Khyati Malhan, Julio F. Navarro, Ruben Sanchez-Janssen, Guillame Thomas, Eline Tolstoy, Thomas G. Wilson, Pedro Alonso Palicio, Spencer Bialek, Rafael Garcia-Dias, Romain Lucchesi, Pierre North, Yeisson Osorio, Lee R. Patrick, Luis Peralta de Arriba The Pristine survey X: a large population of low-metallicity stars permeates the Galactic disk The orbits of the least chemically enriched stars open a window on the\nformation of our Galaxy when it was still in its infancy. The common picture is\nthat these low-metallicity stars are distributed as an isotropic,\npressure-supported component since these stars were either accreted from the\nearly building blocks of the assembling Milky Way, or were later brought by the\naccretion of faint dwarf galaxies. Combining the metallicities and radial\nvelocities from the Pristine and LAMOST surveys and Gaia DR2 parallaxes and\nproper motions for an unprecedented large and unbiased sample of very\nmetal-poor stars at $[Fe/H]\leq-2.5$ we show that this picture is incomplete.\nThis sample shows strong statistical evidence (at the $5.0\sigma$ level) of\nasymmetry in their kinematics, favouring prograde motion. Moreover, we find\nthat $31\%$ of the stars that currently reside in the disk do not venture\noutside of the disk plane throughout their orbit. The discovery of this\npopulation implies that a significant fraction of stars with iron abundances\n$[Fe/H]\leq-2.5$ formed within or concurrently with the Milky Way disk and that\nthe history of the disk was quiet enough to allow them to retain their\ndisk-like orbital properties. Sestito_2019a Sestito et al. 2019a https://arxiv.org/abs/1911.08491
451 1907.09298 2019-11-15 Francesco Montanari, David Barrado, Juan García-Bellido Searching for correlations in GAIA DR2 unbound star trajectories Scattering events with compact objects are expected in the primordial black\nhole (PBH) cold dark matter (CDM) scenario due to close encounters between\nstars and PBH in the dense environments of dwarf spheroidals. We develop a\nBayesian framework to search for correlations among Milky Way stellar\ntrajectories and those of globular clusters and dwarf galaxies in the halo, and\nother nearby galaxies. We apply the method to a selection of hypervelocity\nstars (HVS) and globular clusters from Gaia DR2 catalog, and known nearby\n(mostly dwarf) galaxies with full phase-space and size measurements. We report\npositive evidence for trajectory intersection $\sim$20-40 Myr ago of up to 2\nstars, depending on priors, with the Sagittarius dwarf Spheroidal (dSph) galaxy\nwhen assuming Marchetti et al. (2019) distance estimates. We verify that the\nresult is compatible with their evolutionary status, setting a lower bound for\nthe stellar age of $\sim$100 Myr. However, such scattering events are not\nconfirmed when assuming Anders et al. (2019) distance estimates. We discuss\nshortcomings related to present data quality and future prospects for detection\nof HVS with the full Gaia catalog and Sagittarius dSph. Montanari_2019 Montanari et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1907.09298
452 1911.05745 2019-11-13 T. J. L. de Boer, D. Erkal, M. Gieles A closer look at the spur, blob, wiggle, and gaps in GD-1 The GD-1 stream is one of the longest and coldest stellar streams discovered\nto date, and one of the best objects for constraining the dark matter\nproperties of the Milky Way. Using data from {\it Gaia} DR2 we study the proper\nmotions, distance, morphology and density of the stream to uncover small scale\nperturbations. The proper motion cleaned data shows a clear distance gradient\nacross the stream, ranging from 7 to 12 kpc. However, unlike earlier studies\nthat found a continuous gradient, we uncover a distance minimum at\n$\varphi_{1}\approx$-50 deg, after which the distance increases again. We can\nreliably trace the stream between -85$<\varphi_{1}<$15 deg, showing an even\nfurther extent to GD-1 beyond the earlier extension of \citet{Price-Whelan18a}.\nWe constrain the stream track and density using a Boolean matched filter\napproach and find three large under densities and find significant residuals in\nthe stream track lining up with these gaps. In particular, a gap is visible at\n$\varphi_{1}$=-3 deg, surrounded by a clear sinusoidal wiggle. We argue that\nthis wiggle is due to a perturbation since it has the wrong orientation to come\nfrom a progenitor. We compute a total initial stellar mass of the stream\nsegment of 1.58$\pm$0.07$\times$10$^{4}$ M$_{\odot}$. With the extended view of\nthe spur in this work, we argue that the spur may be unrelated to the adjacent\ngap in the stream. Finally, we show that an interaction with the Sagittarius\ndwarf can create features similar to the spur. Boer_2019a Boer et al. 2019a https://arxiv.org/abs/1911.05745
453 1907.09481 2019-11-11 T. S. Li, S. E. Koposov, D. B. Zucker, G. F. Lewis, K. Kuehn, J. D. Simpson, A. P. Ji, N. Shipp, Y. -Y. Mao, M. Geha, A. B. Pace, A. D. Mackey, S. Allam, D. L. Tucker, G. S. Da Costa, D. Erkal, J. D. Simon, J. R. Mould, S. L. Martell, Z. Wan, G. M. De Silva, K. Bechtol, E. Balbinot, V. Belokurov, J. Bland-Hawthorn, A. R. Casey, L. Cullinane, A. Drlica-Wagner, S. Sharma, A. K. Vivas, R. H. Wechsler, B. Yanny The Southern Stellar Stream Spectroscopic Survey (${S}^5$): Overview, Target Selection, Data Reduction, Validation, and Early Science We introduce the Southern Stellar Stream Spectroscopy Survey (${S}^5$), an\non-going program to map the kinematics and chemistry of stellar streams in the\nSouthern Hemisphere. The initial focus of ${S}^5$ has been spectroscopic\nobservations of recently identified streams within the footprint of the Dark\nEnergy Survey (DES), with the eventual goal of surveying streams across the\nentire southern sky. Stellar streams are composed of material that has been\ntidally striped from dwarf galaxies and globular clusters and hence are\nexcellent dynamical probes of the gravitational potential of the Milky Way, as\nwell as providing a detailed snapshot of its accretion history. Observing with\nthe 3.9-m Anglo-Australian Telescope's 2-degree-Field fibre positioner and\nAAOmega spectrograph, and combining the precise photometry of DES DR1 with the\nsuperb proper motions from $Gaia$ DR2, allows us to conduct an efficient\nspectroscopic survey to map these stellar streams. So far ${S}^5$ has mapped 9\nDES streams and 3 streams outside of DES; the former are the first\nspectroscopic observations of these recently discovered streams. In addition to\nthe stream survey, we use spare fibres to undertake a Milky Way halo survey and\na low-redshift galaxy survey. This paper presents an overview of the ${S}^5$\nprogram, describing the scientific motivation for the survey, target selection,\nobservation strategy, data reduction and survey validation. Finally, we\ndescribe early science results on stellar streams and Milky Way halo stars\ndrawn from the survey. Updates on ${S}^5$, including future public data\nrelease, can be found at \url{http://s5collab.github.io}. Li_2019b Li et al. 2019b https://arxiv.org/abs/1907.09481
454 1911.01548 2019-11-05 Jeffrey D. Simpson, Sarah L. Martell, Gary Da Costa, Jonathan Horner, Rosemary F. G. Wyse, Yuan-Sen Ting, Martin Asplund, Joss Bland-Hawthorn, Sven Buder, Gayandhi M. De Silva, Ken C. Freeman, Janez Kos, Geraint F. Lewis, Karin Lind, Sanjib Sharma, Daniel B. Zucker, Tomaž Zwitter, Klemen Čotar, Peter L. Cottrell, Thomas Nordlander The GALAH Survey: Chemically tagging the Fimbulthul stream to the globular cluster $ω$ Centauri Using kinematics from Gaia and the large elemental abundance space of the\nsecond data release of the GALAH survey, we identify two new members of the\nFimbulthul stellar stream, and chemically tag them to massive, multi-metallic\nglobular cluster $\omega$ Centauri. Recent analysis of the second data release\nof Gaia had revealed the Fimbulthul stellar stream in the halo of the Milky\nWay. It had been proposed that the stream is associated with the $\omega$\nCentauri, but this proposition relied exclusively upon the kinematics and\nmetallicities of the stars to make the association. In this work, we find our\ntwo new members of the stream to be metal-poor stars that are enhanced in\nsodium and aluminium, typical of second population globular cluster stars, but\nnot otherwise seen in field stars. Furthermore, the stars share the s-process\nabundance pattern seen in $\omega$ Centauri, which is rare in field stars.\nApart from one star within 1.5 deg of $\omega$ Centauri, we find no other stars\nobserved by GALAH spatially near $\omega$ Centauri or the Fimbulthul stream\nthat could be kinematically and chemically linked to the cluster. Chemically\ntagging stars in the Fimbulthul stream to $\omega$ Centauri confirms the\nearlier work, and further links this tidal feature in the Milky Way halo to\n$\omega$ Centauri. Simpson_2019b Simpson et al. 2019b https://arxiv.org/abs/1911.01548
455 1905.11944 2019-11-04 H. -F. Wang, M. López-Corredoira, Y. Huang, J. L. Carlin, B. -Q. Chen, C. Wang, J. Chang, H. -W. Zhang, M. -S. Xiang, H. -B. Yuan, W. -X. Sun, X. -Y. Li, Y. Yang, L. -C. Deng Mapping the Galactic disk with the LAMOST and Gaia Red clump sample. II. 3D asymmetrical kinematics of mono-age populations in the disk between 6$-14$ \,kpc We perform analysis of the three-dimensional kinematics of Milky Way disk\nstars in mono-age populations. We focus on stars between Galactocentric\ndistances of $R=6$ and 14 \,kpc, selected from the combined LAMOST DR4 red\nclump giant stars and Gaia DR2 proper motion catalogue. We confirm the 3D\nasymmetrical motions of recent works and provide time tagging of the Galactic\nouter disk asymmetrical motions near the anticenter direction out to\nGalactocentric distances of 14\,kpc. Radial Galactocentric motions reach values\nup to 10 km s$^{-1}$, depending on the age of the population, and present a\nnorth-south asymmetry in the region corresponding to density and velocity\nsubstructures that were sensitive to the perturbations in the early 6 \,Gyr.\nAfter that time, the disk stars in this asymmetrical structure have become\nkinematically hotter, and are thus not sensitive to perturbations, and we find\nthe structure is a relatively younger population. With quantitative analysis,\nwe find stars both above and below the plane at $R\gtrsim 9$ kpc that exhibit\nbending mode motions of which the sensitive duration is around 8 \,Gyr. We\nspeculate that the in-plane asymmetries might not be mainly caused by a fast\nrotating bar, intrinsically elliptical outer disk, secular expansion of the\ndisk, or streams. Spiral arm dynamics, out-of-equilibrium models, minor mergers\nor others are important contributors. Vertical motions might be dominated by\nbending and breathing modes induced by complicated inner or external\nperturbers. It is likely that many of these mechanisms are coupled together. Wang_2019b Wang et al. 2019b https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.11944
456 1910.13506 2019-10-29 Andreas Koch, Patrick Côté An outer shade of Pal: Abundance analysis of the outer halo globular cluster Palomar 13 At a Galactocentric distance of 27 kpc, Pal 13 is an old globular cluster\n(GC) in the outer halo. We present a chemical abundance analysis of this remote\nsystem from high-resolution spectra obtained with Keck/HIRES. Owing to the low\nsignal-to-noise ratio of the data, our analysis is based on a coaddition of the\nspectra of 18 member stars. We are able to determine integrated abundance\nratios for 16 species of 14 elements, of $\alpha$-elements (Mg,Si,Ca,Ti),\nFe-peak (Sc,Mn,Cr,Ni,Cu,and Zn), and n-capture elements (Y,Ba). While the mean\nNa abundance is found to be slightly enhanced and halo-like, our method does\nnot allow us to probe an abundance spread that would be expected in this light\nelement if multiple populations are present in Pal 13. We find a metal-poor\nmean metallicity of $-1.91\pm0.05$ (statistical) $\pm$ 0.22 (systematic),\nconfirming that Pal 13 is a typical metal-poor representative of the outer\nhalo. While there are some differences between individual $\alpha$-elements,\nsuch as halo-like Mg and Si versus the mildly lower Ca and Ti abundances, the\nmean [$\alpha$/Fe] of 0.34$\pm$0.06 is consistent with the marginally lower\n$\alpha$ component of the halo field and GC stars. We discuss our results in\nthe context of other objects in the outer halo and consider which of these\nobjects were likely accreted. We also discuss the properties of their\nprogenitors. While chemically, Pal 13 is similar to Gaia-Enceladus and some of\nits GCs, this is not supported by its kinematic properties. Moreover, its\nchemodynamical similarity with NGC 5466, a progeny of the Sequoia accretion\nevent, might indicate a common origin in this progenitor. However, the\nambiguities in the full abundance space of this comparison emphasize the\ndifficulties in unequivocally labeling a single GC as an accreted object, let\nalone assigning it to a single progenitor. (Abridged) Koch_2019 Koch and Côté 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1910.13506
457 1905.11404 2019-10-23 Jo Bovy, Henry W. Leung, Jason A. S. Hunt, J. Ted Mackereth, D. A. Garcia-Hernandez, Alexandre Roman-Lopes Life in the fast lane: a direct view of the dynamics, formation, and evolution of the Milky Way's bar Studies of the ages, abundances, and motions of individual stars in the Milky\nWay provide one of the best ways to study the evolution of disk galaxies over\ncosmic time. The formation of the Milky Way's barred inner region in particular\nis a crucial piece of the puzzle of disk galaxy evolution. Using data from\nAPOGEE and Gaia, we present maps of the kinematics, elemental abundances, and\nage of the Milky Way bulge and disk that show the barred structure of the inner\nMilky Way in unprecedented detail. The kinematic maps allow a direct, purely\nkinematic determination of the bar's pattern speed of 41+/-3 km/s/kpc and of\nits shape and radial profile. We find the bar's age, metallicity, and abundance\nratios to be the same as those of the oldest stars in the disk that are formed\nin its turbulent beginnings, while stars in the bulge outside of the bar are\nyounger and more metal-rich. This implies that the bar likely formed ~8 Gyr\nago, when the decrease in turbulence in the gas disk allowed a thin disk to\nform that quickly became bar-unstable. The bar's formation therefore stands as\na crucial epoch in the evolution of the Milky Way, a picture that is in line\nwith the evolutionary path that emerges from observations of the gas kinematics\nin external disk galaxies over the last ~10 Gyr. Bovy_2019 Bovy et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.11404
458 1910.09683 2019-10-21 A. P. Milone, A. F. Marino, G. S. Da Costa, E. P. Lagioia, F. D'Antona, P. Goudfrooij, H. Jerjen, D. Massari, A. Renzini, D. Yong, H. Baumgardt, G. Cordoni, E. Dondoglio, C. Li, M. Tailo, R. Asa'd, E. M. Ventura Multiple populations in globular clusters and their parent galaxies The 'chromosome map' diagram (ChM) proved a successful tool to identify and\ncharacterize multiple populations (MPs) in 59 Galactic Globular Clusters (GCs).\nHere, we construct ChMs for 11 GCs of both Magellanic Clouds (MCs) and with\ndifferent ages to compare MPs in Galactic and extra-Galactic environments, and\nexplore whether this phenomenon is universal through 'place' and 'time'. MPs\nare detected in five clusters. The fractions of 1G stars, ranging from about\n50% to more than 80%, are significantly higher than those observed in Galactic\nGCs with similar present-day masses. By considering both Galactic and MC\nclusters, the fraction of 1G stars exhibits: (i) a strong anti-correlation with\nthe present-day mass, and (ii) with the present-day mass of 2G stars; (iii) a\nmild anti-correlation with 1G present-day mass. All Galactic clusters without\nMPs have initial masses smaller than ~1.5 10^5 solar masses but a mass\nthreshold governing the occurrence of MPs seems challenged by massive\nsimple-population MC GCs; (iv) Milky Way clusters with large perigalactic\ndistances typically host larger fractions of 1G stars, but the difference\ndisappears when we use initial cluster masses. These facts are consistent with\na scenario where the stars lost by GCs mostly belong to the 1G. By exploiting\nrecent work based on Gaia, half of the known Type II GCs appear clustered in a\ndistinct region of the integral of motions space, thus suggesting a common\nprogenitor galaxy. Except for these Type II GCs,we do not find any significant\ndifference in the MPs between clusters associated with different progenitors. Milone_2019 Milone et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1910.09683
459 1902.09569 2019-10-17 Jennifer Friske, Ralph Schönrich More than just a wrinkle: A wave-like pattern in radial velocity vs. angular momentum from Gaia Data We present a newly found wave--like pattern in mean Galactocentric radial\nvelocity U_g vs. guiding centre radius R_g or angular momentum L_z of stars in\nthe RV subsample of Gaia DR2. The short-wave pattern has a wavelength of order\n1.2 kpc in R_g or 285 kpc km/s in L_z. The pattern shows only weak changes with\nGalactocentric radius R and little change in strength in particular with the\nvertical energy E_z of the stars or respectively the distance to the Galactic\nplane |z|. The pattern is to first order symmetric around the plane, i.e. has\nno significant odd terms in z. There is weak phase shift with the pattern\nmoving towards slightly lower L_z (i.e. trailing) with |z| and E_z. However, we\nobserve a highly significant phase shift in Galactic azimuth phi, which is\ndifferent for different peaks. The peak around L_z ~ 2100 kpc km/s only shows a\nweak change with galactic azimuth, while the rest of the pattern shows a\nclearly detectable shift of d L_z /d phi = (200 +/- 22) kpc km/s/rad. If we\nconsider all peaks to belong to the same pattern, this would suggest a\nwavenumber m = 4. We further find that the wave-like pattern in U_g appears to\nbe related to the W vs. L_z pattern detected in Gaia DR1. A comparison of the\nU_g-L_z wave pattern with changes of U_g vs. R, which have been previously\ndiscussed, suggests that the latter can be understood as just the U_g-L_z\npattern washed out by blurring (i.e. orbital excursions around their\nguiding-centre) of disc stars. Friske_2019 Friske and Schönrich 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1902.09569
460 1910.03076 2019-10-09 Guillaume F. Thomas, Nicholaas Annau, Alan McConnachie, Sebastien Fabbro, Hossen Teimoorinia, Patrick Côté, Jean-Charles Cuillandre, Stephen Gwyn, Rodrigo A. Ibata, Else Starkenburg, Raymond Carlberg, Benoit Famaey, Nicholas Fantin, Laura Ferrarese, Vincent Hénault-Brunnet, Jaclyn Jensen, Ariane Lancon, Geraint F. Lewis, Nicolas F. Martin, Julio F. Navarro, Céline Reylé, Rubén Sánchez-Janssen Dwarfs or giants? Stellar metallicities and distances in the Canada-France-Imaging-Survey from $ugrizG$ multi-band photometry We present a new fully data-driven algorithm that uses photometric data from\nthe Canada-France-Imaging-Survey (CFIS; $u$), Pan-STARRS 1 (PS1; $griz$), and\nGaia ($G$) to discriminate between dwarf and giant stars and to estimate their\ndistances and metallicities. The algorithm is trained and tested using the\nSDSS/SEGUE spectroscopic dataset and Gaia photometric/astrometric dataset. At\n[Fe/H]$<-1.2$, the algorithm succeeds in identifying more than 70% of the\ngiants in the training/test set, with a dwarf contamination fraction below 30%\n(with respect to the SDSS/SEGUE dataset). The photometric metallicity estimates\nhave uncertainties better than 0.2 dex when compared with the spectroscopic\nmeasurements. The distances estimated by the algorithm are valid out to a\ndistance of at least $\sim 80$ kpc without requiring any prior on the stellar\ndistribution, and have fully independent uncertainities that take into account\nboth random and systematic errors. These advances allow us to estimate these\nstellar parameters for approximately 12 million stars in the photometric\ndataset. This will enable studies involving the chemical mapping of the distant\nouter disc and the stellar halo, including their kinematics using the Gaia\nproper motions. This type of algorithm can be applied in the Southern\nhemisphere to the first release of LSST data, thus providing an almost complete\nview of the external components of our Galaxy out to at least $\sim 80$ kpc.\nCritical to the success of these efforts will be ensuring well-defined\nspectroscopic training sets that sample a broad range of stellar parameters\nwith minimal biases. A catalogue containing the training/test set and all\nrelevant parameters within the public footprint of CFIS is available online. Thomas_2019 Thomas et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1910.03076
461 1908.01318 2019-10-07 G. Monari, B. Famaey, A. Siebert, O. Bienaymé, R. Ibata, C. Wegg, O. Gerhard Tracing Hercules in Galactic azimuth with Gaia DR2 The second data release of the Gaia mission has revealed, in stellar velocity\nand action space, multiple ridges, the exact origin of which is still debated.\nRecently, we demonstrated that a large Galactic bar with pattern speed 39\nkm/s/kpc does create most of the observed ridges. Among those ridges, the\nHercules moving group would then be associated to orbits trapped at the\nco-rotation resonance of the bar. Here we show that a distinctive prediction of\nsuch a model is that the angular momentum of Hercules at the Sun's radius must\nsignificantly decrease with increasing Galactocentric azimuth, i.e. when\ngetting closer to the major axis of the bar. We show that such a dependence of\nthe angular momentum of trapped orbits on the azimuth would on the other hand\nnot happen close to the outer Lindblad resonance of a faster bar, unless the\norbital distribution is still far from phase-mixed, namely for a bar\nperturbation younger than ~ 2 Gyr. Using Gaia DR2 and Bayesian distances from\nthe StarHorse code, and tracing the average Galactocentric radial velocity as a\nfunction of angular momentum and azimuth, we show that the Hercules angular\nmomentum changes significantly with azimuth as expected for the co-rotation\nresonance of a dynamically old large bar. Monari_2019a Monari et al. 2019a https://arxiv.org/abs/1908.01318
462 1908.02763 2019-10-02 Alis J. Deason, Vasily Belokurov, Jason L. Sanders The total stellar halo mass of the Milky Way We measure the total stellar halo luminosity using red giant branch (RGB)\nstars selected from Gaia data release 2. Using slices in magnitude, colour and\nlocation on the sky, we decompose RGB stars belonging to the disc and halo by\nfitting 2-dimensional Gaussians to the Galactic proper motion distributions.\nThe number counts of RGB stars are converted to total stellar halo luminosity\nusing a suite of isochrones weighted by age and metallicity, and by applying a\nvolume correction based on the stellar halo density profile. Our method is\ntested and calibrated using Galaxia and N-body models. We find a total\nluminosity (out to 100 kpc) of L_halo = 7.9 +/- 2.0 x 10^8 L_Sun excluding Sgr,\nand L_halo = 9.4 +/- 2.4 x 10^8 L_Sun including Sgr. These values are\nappropriate for our adopted stellar halo density profile and metallicity\ndistribution, but additional systematics related to these assumptions are\nquantified and discussed. Assuming a stellar mass-to-light ratio appropriate\nfor a Kroupa initial mass function (M*/L = 1.5), we estimate a stellar halo\nmass of M*_halo = 1.4 +/- 0.4 x 10^9 M_Sun. This mass is larger than previous\nestimates in the literature, but is in good agreement with the emerging picture\nthat the (inner) stellar halo is dominated by one massive dwarf progenitor.\nFinally, we argue that the combination of a ~10^9 M_Sun mass and an average\nmetallicity of <[Fe/H]> ~ -1.5 for the Galactic halo points to an ancient (~10\nGyr) merger event. Deason_2019a Deason et al. 2019a https://arxiv.org/abs/1908.02763
463 1909.08924 2019-09-19 Helmer H. Koppelman, Amina Helmi, Davide Massari, Adrian M. Price-Whelan, Tjitske K. Starkenburg Multiple retrograde substructures in the Galactic halo: A shattered view of Galactic history Aims. Several kinematic and chemical substructures have been recently found\namongst Milky Way halo stars with retrograde motions. It is currently unclear\nhow these various structures are related to each other. This Letter aims to\nshed light on this issue. Methods. We explore the retrograde halo with an\naugmented version of the Gaia DR2 RVS sample, extended with data from three\nlarge spectroscopic surveys, namely RAVE, APOGEE and LAMOST. In this dataset,\nwe identify several structures using the HDBSCAN clustering algorithm. We\ndiscuss their properties and possible links using all the available chemical\nand dynamical information. Results. In concordance with previous work, we find\nthat stars with [Fe/H] $<-1$ have more retrograde motions than those with\n[Fe/H] $>-1$. The retrograde halo contains a mixture of debris from objects\nlike Gaia-Enceladus, Sequoia, and even the chemically defined thick-disc. We\nfind that the Sequoia has a smaller range in orbital energies than previously\nsuggested and is confined to high-energy. Sequoia could be a small galaxy in\nitself, but since it overlaps both in integrals-of-motion space and chemical\nabundance space with the less bound debris of Gaia-Enceladus, its nature cannot\nbe fully settled yet. In the low-energy part of the halo we find evidence for\nat least one more distinct structure: Thamnos. Stars in Thamnos are on low\ninclination, mildly eccentric retrograde orbits, moving at\n$v_{\phi}\approx-150$ km/s, and are chemically distinct from the other\nstructures. Conclusions. Even with the excellent Gaia DR2 data it remains\nchallenging to piece together all the fragments found in the retrograde halo.\nAt this point, we are very much in need of large datasets with high-quality\nhigh-resolution spectra and tailored high-resolution hydrodynamical simulations\nof galaxy mergers. Koppelman_2019 Koppelman et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1909.08924

Gallart, E. Pancino OCCASO III. Iron peak and $α$ elements of 18 open clusters. In this\npaper we present an extended abundance analysis of 10 species (Fe, Ni, Cr, V,\nSc, Si, Ca, Ti, Mg, O) for red giant stars in 18 OCCASO clusters. This\nrepresents a homogeneous sample regarding the instrument features, method, line\nlist and solar abundances from confirmed member stars. We perform an extensive\ncomparison with previous results in the literature, and in particular with the\nGaia FGK Benchmark stars Arcturus and $\mu$Leo. We investigate the dependence\nof [X/Fe] with metallicity, Galactocentric radius ($6.5 Casamiquela_2019 Casamiquela et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1909.05865
465 1909.05927 2019-09-12 Carl J. Grillmair Detection of a 50 degree-long Trailing Tidal Tail for the Globular Cluster M5 Using photometry and proper motions from Gaia Data Release 2, we detect a 50\ndegree-long stream of about 70 stars extending westward from the halo globular\ncluster M5. Based on the similarities in distance, proper motions, inferred\ncolor-magnitude distribution, and trajectory, we identify this stream as the\ntrailing tidal tail of M5. While the surface density of stars is very low (~1.5\nstars per square degree, or approximately 35 magnitudes per square arcsecond),\nselecting only stars having proper motions consistent with the orbit of the\ncluster yield a detection significance ~10 sigma. While we find a possible\ncontinuation of the stream to ~85 degrees, increasing foreground contamination\ncombined with a greater predicted stream distance make it difficult to detect\nwith current data even if the stream continues unabated. The non-uniform\ndistribution of stars in the stream appears to be consistent with episodic\ntidal stripping, with the most recently shed stars now trailing the cluster by\ntens of degrees. We provide a table of the highest-ranked candidate stream\nstars for ongoing and future spectroscopic surveys. Grillmair_2019 Grillmair 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1909.05927
466 1905.09842 2019-09-12 Christine M. Simpson, Ignacio Gargiulo, Facundo A. Gómez, Robert J. J. Grand, Nicolás Maffione, Andrew P. Cooper, Alis J. Deason, Carlos Frenk, John Helly, Federico Marinacci, Rüdiger Pakmor Simulating cosmological substructure in the solar neighbourhood We explore the predictive power of cosmological, hydrodynamical simulations\nfor stellar phase space substructure and velocity correlations with the Auriga\nsimulations and Aurigaia mock-Gaia catalogues. We show that at the solar circle\nthe Auriga simulations commonly host phase space structures in the stellar\ncomponent that have constant orbital energies and arise from accreted\nsubhaloes. These structures can persist for a few Gyrs, even after coherent\nstreams in position space have been erased. We also explore velocity two-point\ncorrelation functions and find this diagnostic is not deterministic for\nparticular clustering patterns in phase space. Finally, we explore these\nstructure diagnostics with the Aurigaia catalogues and show that the current\ncatalogues have the ability to recover some structures in phase space but\ncareful consideration is required to separate physical structures from\nnumerical structures arising from catalogue generation methods. 467 1907.02839 2019-09-11 H. -F. Wang, J. L. Carlin, Y. Huang, M. López-Corredoira, B. -Q. Chen, C. Wang, J. Chang, H. -W. Zhang, M. -S. Xiang, H. -B. Yuan, W. -X. Sun, X. -Y. Li, Y. Yang, L. -C. Deng Mapping the Galactic disk with the LAMOST and Gaia Red clump sample: III: A new velocity substructure and time stamps of the Galactic disk asymmetry in the disk between 12$-$15 \,kpc We investigate the three-dimensional asymmetrical kinematics and present time\nstamps of the Milky Way disk between Galactocentric distances of $R=12$ and 15\n\,kpc, using red clump stars selected from the LAMOST Galactic survey, also\nwith proper motion measurements provided by the Gaia DR2. We discover velocity\nsubstructure above the Galactic plane corresponding to a density dip found\nrecently ("south-middle opposite" density structure[R $\sim$ 12-15 \,kpc, Z\n$\sim$ 1.5 \,kpc] discovered in \citet{Wang2018b, Wang2018c}) in the radial and\nazimuthal velocity. For the vertical velocity, we detect clear vertical bulk\nmotions or bending mode motions, which has no clear north-south asymmetry\ncorresponding to the in-plane asymmetrical features. In the subsample of stars\nwith different ages, we find that there is little temporal evolution of the\nin-plane asymmetry from 0$-$14 \,Gyr, which means the structure is sensitive to\nthe perturbations in almost cosmic time possibly. We propose that the possible\nscenario of this asymmetric velocity structure is caused by the mechanisms\ngenerated in-plane, rather than vertical perturbations. Wang_2019a Wang et al. 2019a https://arxiv.org/abs/1907.02839
468 1909.04949 2019-09-11 Iryna Kushniruk, Thomas Bensby Disentangling the Arcturus stream The Arcturus stream is an over-density of stars in velocity space and its\norigin has been much debated recently without any clear conclusion. Resolving\nthe nature of the Arcturus stream can provide clues to the formation history of\nthe Milky Way and its stellar populations. The space velocities, angular\nmomenta and actions for a sample of more than 5.8 million stars, composed from\nGaia DR2, are analysed with a wavelet transform. The kinematic characteristics\nof each identified group is used to select possible members of the groups from\nthe GALAH and APOGEE spectroscopic surveys to further study and constrain their\nchemical properties. In the velocity and angular momentum spaces the already\nknown Sirius, Pleiades, Hyades, Hercules, AF06, Arcturus and KFR08 streams are\nclearly identified. The Hercules stream appears to be a mixture of thin and\nthick disk stars. The Arcturus stream, as well as the AF06 and KFR08 streams,\nare low-velocity and low-angular momentum structures with chemical compositions\nsimilar to the thick disk. These three groups extend further from the Galactic\nplane compared to the Hercules stream. The detections of all the groups were\nspaced by approximately 20-30 km/s in azimuthal velocity. A wide spread of\nchemical abundances within the Arcturus stream indicates that the group is not\na dissolved open cluster. Instead the Arcturus stream, together with the AF06\nand KFR08 streams, are more likely to be part of a phase-space wave, that could\nhave been caused by an ancient merger event. This conclusion is based on that\nthe different structures are detected in steps of 20-30 km/s in azimuthal\nvelocity, that the kinematic and chemical features are different from what is\nexpected for bar-originated structures, and that the lower-velocity streams\nextend further from the disk than bar-originated structures. Kushniruk_2019 Kushniruk and Bensby 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1909.04949
469 1909.04679 2019-09-10 Vasily Belokurov, Jason L. Sanders, Azadeh Fattahi, Martin C. Smith, Alis J. Deason, N. Wyn Evans, Robert J. J. Grand The Biggest Splash Using a large sample of bright nearby stars with accurate Gaia Data Release 2\nastrometry and auxiliary spectroscopy we map out the properties of the\nprinciple Galactic components such as the "thin" and "thick" discs and the\nhalo. We show that in the Solar neighborhood, there exists a large population\nof metal-rich ([Fe/H]>-0.7) stars on highly eccentric orbits. By studying the\nevolution of elemental abundances, kinematics and stellar ages in the plane of\nazimuthal velocity v_phi and metallicity [Fe/H], we demonstrate that this\nmetal-rich halo-like component, which we dub the Splash, is linked to the\nalpha-rich (or "thick") disc. Splash stars have little to no angular momentum\nand many are on retrograde orbits. They are predominantly old, but not as old\nas the stars deposited into the Milky Way in the last major merger. We argue,\nin agreement with several recent studies, that the Splash stars may have been\nborn in the Milky Way's proto-disc prior to the massive ancient accretion event\nwhich drastically altered their orbits. We can not, however, rule out other\n(alternative) formation channels. Taking advantage of the causal connection\nbetween the merger and the Splash, we put constraints of the epoch of the last\nmassive accretion event to have finished 9.5 Gyr ago. The link between the\nlocal metal-rich and metal-poor retrograde stars is confirmed using a large\nsuite of cutting-edge numerical simulations of the Milky Way's formation. Belokurov_2019 Belokurov et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1909.04679
470 1906.08271 2019-09-10 Davide Massari, Helmer H. Koppelman, Amina Helmi Origin of the system of globular clusters in the Milky Way $Context$. The assembly history experienced by the Milky Way is currently\nbeing unveiled thanks to the data provided by the $Gaia$ mission. It is likely\nthat the globular cluster system of our Galaxy has followed a similarly\nintricate formation path. $Aims$. To constrain this formation path, we explore\nthe link between the globular clusters and the known merging events that the\nMilky Way has experienced. $Methods$. To this end, we combined the kinematic\ninformation provided by $Gaia$ for almost all Galactic clusters, with the\nlargest sample of cluster ages available after carefully correcting for\nsystematic errors. To identify clusters with a common origin we analysed their\ndynamical properties, particularly in the space of integrals of motion.\n$Results$. We find that about 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ. A\nsimilarly large fraction, 35%, appear to be possibly associated to known merger\nevents, in particular to $Gaia$-Enceladus (19%), the Sagittarius dwarf galaxy\n(5%), the progenitor of the Helmi streams (6%), and to the Sequoia galaxy (5%),\nalthough some uncertainty remains due to the degree of overlap in their\ndynamical characteristics. Of the remaining clusters, 16% are tentatively\nassociated to a group with high binding energy, while the rest are all on\nloosely bound orbits and likely have a more heterogeneous origin. The resulting\nage-metallicity relations are remarkably tight and differ in their detailed\nproperties depending on the progenitor, providing further confidence on the\nassociations made. $Conclusions$. We provide a table listing the likely\nassociations. Improved kinematic data by future Gaia data releases and\nespecially a larger, systematic error-free sample of cluster ages would help to\nfurther solidify our conclusions. Massari_2019 Massari et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1906.08271
471 1812.08232 2019-09-10 P. Di Matteo, M. Haywood, M. D. Lehnert, D. Katz, S. Khoperskov, O. N. Snaith, A. Gómez, N. Robichon The Milky Way has no in-situ halo other than the heated thick disc. Composition of the stellar halo and age-dating the last significant merger with Gaia DR2 and APOGEE Previous studies based on the analysis of Gaia DR2 data have revealed that\naccreted stars, possibly originating from a single progenitor satellite, are a\nsignificant component of the halo of our Galaxy, potentially constituting most\nof the halo stars at $\rm [Fe/H] < -1$ within a few kpc from the Sun and\nbeyond. In this paper, we couple astrometric data from Gaia DR2 with elemental\nabundances from APOGEE DR14 to characterize the kinematics and chemistry of\nin-situ and accreted populations up to $\rm [Fe/H] \sim -2$. Accreted stars\nappear to significantly impact the Galactic chemo-kinematic relations, not only\nat $\rm [Fe/H] < -1$, but also at metallicities typical of the thick and\nmetal-poor thin discs. They constitute about 60% of all stars at $\rm [Fe/H] <\n-1$, the remaining 40% being made of (metal-weak) thick disc stars. We find\nthat the stellar kinematic fossil record shows the imprint left by this\naccretion event which heated the old Galactic disc. We are able to age-date\nthis kinematic imprint, showing that the accretion occurred between 9 and 11\nGyr ago, and that it led to the last significant heating of the Galactic disc.\nAn important fraction of stars with abundances typical of the (metal-rich)\nthick disc, and heated by this interaction, is now found in the Galactic halo.\nIndeed about half of the kinematically defined halo at few kpc from the Sun is\ncomposed of metal-rich thick disc stars. Moreover, we suggest that this\nmetal-rich thick disc component dominates the stellar halo of the inner Galaxy.\nThe new picture that emerges from this study is one where the standard\nnon-rotating in-situ halo population, the collapsed halo, seems to be more\nelusive than ever. Matteo_2019 Matteo et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1812.08232
472 1909.04039 2019-09-09 Sownak Bose, Alis J. Deason, Vasily Belokurov, Carlos S. Frenk The little things matter: relating the abundance of ultrafaint satellites to the hosts' assembly history Ultrafaint dwarf galaxies ($M_\star\lesssim10^{5-6}\,{\rm M}_\odot$) are\nrelics of an early phase of galaxy formation. They contain some of the oldest\nand most metal-poor stars in the Universe which likely formed before the epoch\nof hydrogen reionisation. These galaxies are so faint that they can only be\ndetected as satellites of the Milky Way. They are so small that they are just\nbarely resolved in current cosmological hydrodynamics simulations. Here we\ncombine very high resolution cosmological $N$-body simulations with a\nsemi-analytic model of galaxy formation to study the demographics and spatial\ndistribution of ultrafaint satellites in Milky Way-mass haloes. We show that\nthe abundance of these galaxies is correlated with the assembly history of the\nhost halo: at fixed mass, haloes assembled earlier contain, on average, more\nultrafaint satellites today than haloes assembled later. We identify simulated\ngalactic haloes that experience an ancient Gaia-Enceladus-Sausage-like and a\nrecent LMC-like accretion event and find that the former occurs in 33% of the\nsample and the latter in 9%. Only 3% experience both events and these are\nespecially rich in ultrafaint satellites, most acquired during the ancient\naccretion event. Our models predict that the radial distribution of satellites\nis more centrally concentrated in early-forming haloes. Accounting for the\ndepletion of satellites by tidal interactions with the central disc, we find a\nvery good match to the observed radial distribution of satellites in the Milky\nWay over the entire radial range. This agreement is mainly due to the ability\nof our model to track 'orphan' galaxies after their subhaloes fall below the\nresolution limit of the simulation. Bose_2019 Bose et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1909.04039
473 1909.02016 2019-09-06 Richa Kundu, José G. Fernández-Trincado, Dante Minniti, Harinder P. Singh, Edmundo Moreno, Céline Reylé, Annie C. Robin, Mario Soto The Tale of the Milky Way Globular Cluster NGC 6362 -- I. The Orbit and its possible extended star debris features as revealed by Gaia DR2 We report the identification of possible extended star debris candidates\nbeyond the cluster tidal radius of NGC 6362 based on the second {\it Gaia} data\nrelease ({\it Gaia} DR2). We found 259 objects possibly associated with the\ncluster lying in the vicinity of the giant branch and 1--2 magnitudes\nfainter/brighter than the main-sequence turn-off in the cluster color-magnitude\ndiagram and which cover an area on the sky of $\sim$4.1 deg$^{2}$ centered on\nthe cluster. We traced back the orbit of NGC 6362 in a realistic Milky-Way\npotential, using the \texttt{GravPot16} package, for 3 Gyrs. The orbit shows\nthat the cluster shares similar orbital properties as the inner disk, having\nperi-/apo-galactic distances, and maximum vertical excursion from the Galactic\nplane inside the corotation radius (CR), moving inwards from CR radius to visit\nthe inner regions of the Milky Way. The dynamical history of the cluster\nreveals that it has crossed the Galactic disk several times in its lifetime and\nhas recently undergone a gravitational shock, $\sim 15.9$ Myr ago, suggesting\nthat less than 0.1\% of its mass has been lost during the current disk-shocking\nevent. Based on the cluster's orbit and position in the Galaxy, we conclude\nthat the possible extended star debris candidates are a combined effect of the\nshocks from the Galactic disk and evaporation from the cluster. Lastly, the\nevolution of the vertical component of the angular momentum shows that the\ncluster is strongly affected dynamically by the Galactic bar potential. Kundu_2019 Kundu et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1909.02016
474 1909.02767 2019-09-06 S. Karaali, S. Bilir, E. Yaz Gokce, O. Plevne Analysis of the disc components of our Galaxy via kinematic and spectroscopic procedures We used the spectroscopic and astrometric data provided from the GALAH DR2\nand Gaia DR2, respectively, for a large sample of stars to investigate the\nbehaviour of the [$\alpha$/Fe] abundances via two procedures, i.e.\nkinematically and spectroscopically. With the kinematical procedure, we\ninvestigated the distribution of the [$\alpha$/Fe] abundances into the high/low\nprobability thin disc, and high/low probability thick-disc populations in terms\nof total space velocity, [Fe/H] abundance, and age. The high probability\nthin-disc stars dominate in all sub-intervals of [$\alpha$/Fe], including the\nrich ones: [$\alpha$/Fe]$>0.3$ dex, where the high probability thick-disc stars\nare expected to dominate. This result can be explained by the limiting apparent\nmagnitude of the GALAH DR2 ($V<14$ mag) and intermediate Galactic latitude of\nthe star sample. Stars in the four populations share equivalent [$\alpha$/Fe]\nand [Fe/H] abundances, total space velocities and ages. Hence, none of these\nparameters can be used alone for separation of a sample of stars into different\npopulations. High probability thin-disc stars with abundance\n$-1.3<{\rm[Fe/H]}\leq -0.5$ dex and age $9<\tau\leq13$ Gyr are assumed to have\ndifferent birth places relative to the metal rich and younger ones. With the\nspectroscopic procedure, we separated the sample stars into $\alpha$-rich and\n$\alpha$-poor categories by means of their ages as well as their [$\alpha$/Fe]\nand [Fe/H] abundances. Stars older than 8 Gyr are richer in [$\alpha$/Fe] than\nthe younger ones. We could estimate the abundance [$\alpha$/Fe]=0.14 dex as the\nboundery separating the $\alpha$-rich and $\alpha$-poor sub-samples in the\n[$\alpha$/Fe]$\times$[Fe/H] plane. Karaali_2019 Karaali et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1909.02767
475 1909.03048 2019-09-06 Nathaniel Starkman, Jo Bovy, Jeremy Webb An extended Pal 5 stream in Gaia DR2 We present the results of a detailed search for members of the Pal 5 tidal\ntail system in Gaia Data Release 2 (DR2). Tidal tails provide a sensitive\nmethod for measuring the current and past gravitational potential of their host\ngalaxy as well as for testing predictions for the abundance of dark matter\nsubhalos. The Pal 5 globular cluster and its associated tails are an excellent\ncandidate for such analysis; however, only ~23 degrees of arc are currently\nknown, with in particular the leading tail much shorter than the trailing.\nUsing Gaia DR2 and its precise astrometry, we extend the known extent of the\nPal 5 tail to ~30 degrees, 7 degrees of which are newly detected along the\nleading arm. The detected leading and trailing arms are symmetric in length and\nremain near constant width. This detection constrains proposed models in which\nthe Galactic bar truncates Pal 5's leading arm. Follow-up spectroscopic\nobservations are necessary to verify the candidate stream stars are consistent\nwith the known tidal tails. If confirmed, this Pal 5 stream extension opens up\nnew possibilities to constrain the Galactic potential. Starkman_2019 Starkman et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1909.03048
476 1904.08896 2019-09-06 Keir Darling, Lawrence M. Widrow Eigenfunctions of Galactic Phase Space Spirals from Dynamic Mode Decomposition We investigate the spatiotemporal structure of simulations of the homogeneous\nslab and isothermal plane models for the vertical motion in the Galactic disc.\nWe use Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) to compute eigenfunctions of the\nsimulated distribution functions for both models, referred to as DMD modes. In\nthe case of the homogeneous slab, we compare the DMD modes to the analytic\nnormal modes of the system to evaluate the feasibility of DMD in collisionless\nself gravitating systems. This is followed by the isothermal plane model, where\nwe focus on the effect of self gravity on phase mixing. We compute DMD modes of\nthe system for varying relative dominance of mutual interaction and external\npotential, so as to study the corresponding variance in mode structure and\nlifetime. We find that there is a regime of relative dominance, at\napproximately $ 4:1 $ external potential to mutual interaction where the DMD\nmodes are spirals in the $ (z,v_z) $ plane, and are nearly un-damped. This\nleads to the proposition that a system undergoing phase mixing in the presence\nof weak to moderate self gravity can have persisting spiral structure in the\nform of such modes. We then conclude with the conjecture that such a mechanism\nmay be at work in the phase space spirals observed in Gaia Data Release 2, and\nthat studying more complex simulations with DMD may aid in understanding both\nthe timing and form of the perturbation that lead to the observed spirals. Darling_2019 Darling and Widrow 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1904.08896
477 1909.02007 2019-09-04 Charlie Conroy, Rohan P. Naidu, Dennis Zaritsky, Ana Bonaca, Phillip Cargile, Benjamin D. Johnson, Nelson Caldwell Resolving the Metallicity Distribution of the Stellar Halo with the H3 Survey The Galactic stellar halo is predicted to have formed at least partially from\nthe tidal disruption of accreted dwarf galaxies. This assembly history should\nbe detectable in the orbital and chemical properties of stars. The H3 Survey is\nobtaining spectra for 200,000 stars, and, when combined with Gaia data, is\nproviding detailed orbital and chemical properties of Galactic halo stars.\nUnlike previous surveys of the halo, the H3 target selection is based solely on\nmagnitude and Gaia parallax; the survey therefore provides a nearly unbiased\nview of the entire stellar halo at high latitudes. In this paper we present the\ndistribution of stellar metallicities as a function of Galactocentric distance\nand orbital properties for a sample of 4232 kinematically-selected halo giants\nto 100 kpc. The stellar halo is relatively metal-rich, [Fe/H]=-1.2, and there\nis no discernable metallicity gradient over the range $630$ kpc, respectively. Metal-poor stars with [Fe/H]$<-2$ are a\nsmall population of the halo at all distances and orbital categories. We\nassociate the "in-situ" stellar halo with stars displaying thick-disk chemistry\non halo-like orbits; such stars are confined to $|z|<10$ kpc. The majority of\nthe stellar halo is resolved into discrete features in orbital-chemical space,\nsuggesting that the bulk of the stellar halo formed from the accretion and\ntidal disruption of dwarf galaxies. (ABRIDGED) Conroy_2019a Conroy et al. 2019a https://arxiv.org/abs/1909.02007
478 1902.10113 2019-09-01 Shourya Khanna, Sanjib Sharma, Thor Tepper-Garcia, Joss Bland-Hawthorn, Michael Hayden, Martin Asplund, Sven Buder, Boquan Chen, Gayandhi M. De Silva, Ken C. Freeman, Janez Kos, Jane Lin, Sarah L. Martell, Jeffrey D. Simpson, Dennis Stello, Yuan-Sen Ting, Daniel B. Zucker, Tomaz Zwitter The GALAH survey and Gaia DR2: Linking ridges, arches and vertical waves in the kinematics of the Milky Way Gaia DR2 has revealed new small-scale and large-scale patterns in the\nphase-space distribution of stars in the Milky Way. In cylindrical Galactic\ncoordinates $(R,\phi,z)$, ridge-like structures can be seen in the \vphiR{}\nplane and asymmetric arch-like structures in the \vphivR{} plane. We show that\nthe ridges are also clearly present when the third dimension of the \vphiR{}\nplane is represented by $\langle z \rangle$, $\langle V_z \rangle$, $\langle\nV_R \rangle$, $\langle$[Fe/H]$\rangle$ and $\langle[\alpha/{\rm Fe}]\rangle$.\nThe maps suggest that stars along the ridges lie preferentially close to the\nGalactic midplane ($|z|<0.2$ kpc), and have metallicity and $\alpha$ elemental\nabundance similar to that of the Sun. We show that phase mixing of disrupting\nspiral arms can generate both the ridges and the arches. It also generates\ndiscrete groupings in orbital energy $-$ the ridges and arches are simply\nsurfaces of constant energy. We identify 8 distinct ridges in the \gaia{} data:\nsix of them have constant energy while two have constant angular momentum.\nGiven that the signature is strongest for stars close to the plane, the\npresence of ridges in $\langle z \rangle$ and $\langle V_z \rangle$ suggests a\ncoupling between planar and vertical directions. We demonstrate, using N-body\nsimulations that such coupling can be generated both in isolated discs and in\ndiscs perturbed by an orbiting satellite like the Sagittarius dwarf galaxy. Khanna_2019 Khanna et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1902.10113
479 1908.10977 2019-08-30 Eric Michel, Kévin Belkacem, Benoît Mosser, Réza Samadi, Misha Haywood, David Katz, Benoit Famaey, Tiago L. Campante, Mário J. P. F. G. Monteiro, Margarida S. Cunha, Andrea Miglio, Rafael A. García, Hans Kjeldsen, Juan Carlos Suárez, Sébastien Deheuvels, Jérôme Ballot Chronos --- Taking the pulse of our Galactic neighbourhood (ESA Voyage 2050 White Paper) The period 2035-50 considered in the ESA Voyage long-term plan will coincide\nwith a series of foreseeable advances in the characterization of the stellar\ncontent of the Milky Way. The Gaia mission, combined with large-scale\nspectroscopic surveys, is helping to build an unprecedented census in terms of\nthe astrometric, kinematic and chemical properties of Galactic stellar\npopulations. Within a decade, precise measurements of such properties will be\navailable for hundreds of millions of stars. Meanwhile, time-domain surveys\ninitiated with CoRoT and Kepler/K2 and carried on by space missions such as\nTESS and PLATO or ground-based projects like the LSST, will have brought\nasteroseismology to a high level of maturity. The combination of precise ages\nfrom asteroseismology with astrometric and spectroscopic data, on large stellar\nsamples, is allowing Galactic archaeologists to gain new insight into the\nassembly history of the Milky Way. Recent breakthroughs --- based on the\ndetection of solar-like oscillations in tens of thousands of red-giant stars\n--- demonstrate the potential of such approach. Therefore, we are convinced\nthat an all-sky, high-cadence, long-duration stellar variability survey will\nbecome a scientific priority in the 2035-50 period. The Chronos concept\npresented here consists in a time-domain extension to Gaia. It will allow for\nmass and age estimates for half a million red giants within 1.7 kpc from the\nSun and hence shed a new light on our understanding of the Galactic dynamics\nand archaeology. In terms of the targeted pulsators, Chronos will bridge the\ngap between PLATO and the LSST by surveying stars all the way from the subgiant\nbranch to the early AGB. Finally, it will surpass all previous surveys capable\nof conducting asteroseismology in terms of the combined sky coverage and\nduration of the observations (2 x 3.75 months over the whole sky and >5 years\nin the CVZ). Michel_2019 Michel et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1908.10977
480 1808.07878 2019-08-25 Giacomo Fragione, Alessia Gualandris Hypervelocity stars from star clusters hosting Intermediate-Mass Black Holes Hypervelocity stars (HVSs) represent a unique population of stars in the\nGalaxy reflecting properties of the whole Galactic potential. Determining their\norigin is of fundamental importance to constrain the shape and mass of the dark\nhalo. The leading scenario for the ejection of HVSs is an encounter with the\nsupermassive black hole in the Galactic Centre. However, new proper motions\nfrom the \textit{Gaia} mission indicate that only the fastest HVSs can be\ntraced back to the Galactic centre and the remaining stars originate in the\ndisc or halo. In this paper, we study HVSs generated by encounters of stellar\nbinaries with an intermediate-mass black hole (IMBH) in the core of a star\ncluster. For the first time, we model the effect of the cluster orbit in the\nGalactic potential on the observable properties of the ejected population. HVSs\ngenerated by this mechanism do not travel on radial orbits consistent with a\nGalactic centre origin, but rather point back to their parent cluster, thus\nproviding observational evidence for the presence of an IMBH. We also model the\nejection of high-velocity stars from the Galactic population of globular\nclusters, assuming that they all contain an IMBH, including the effects of the\ncluster's orbit and propagation of the star in the Galactic potential up to\ndetection. We find that high-velocity stars ejected by IMBHs have distinctive\ndistributions in velocity, Galactocentric distance and Galactic latitude, which\ncan be used to distinguish them from runaway stars and stars ejected from the\nGalactic Centre. Fragione_2019 Fragione and Gualandris 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1808.07878
481 1903.01493 2019-08-23 I. Carrillo, I. Minchev, M. Steinmetz, G. Monari, C. F. P. Laporte, F. Anders, A. B. A. Queiroz, C. Chiappini, A. Khalatyan, M. Martig, P. McMillan, B. X. Santiago, K. Youakim Kinematics with Gaia DR2: The Force of a Dwarf We use Gaia DR2 astrometric and line-of-sight velocity information combined\nwith two sets of distances obtained with a Bayesian inference method to study\nthe 3D velocity distribution in the Milky Way disc. We search for variations in\nall Galactocentric cylindrical velocity components ($V_{\phi}$, $V_R$ and\n$V_z$) with Galactic radius, azimuth, and distance from the disc mid-plane. We\nconfirm recent work showing that bulk vertical motions in the $R\text{-}z$\nplane are consistent with a combination of breathing and bending modes. In the\n$x\text{-}y$ plane, we show that, although the amplitudes change, the structure\nproduced by these modes is mostly invariant as a function of distance from the\nplane. Comparing to two different Galactic disc models, we demonstrate that the\nobserved patterns can drastically change in short time intervals, showing the\ncomplexity of understanding the origin of vertical perturbations. A strong\nradial $V_R$ gradient was identified in the inner disc, transitioning smoothly\nfrom $16$ km s$^{-1}$ kpc$^{-1}$ at an azimuth of $30^\circ<\phi<45^\circ$\nahead of the Sun-Galactic centre line, to $-16$ km s$^{-1}$ kpc$^{-1}$ at an\nazimuth of $-45^\circ<\phi<-30^\circ$ lagging the solar azimuth. We use a\nsimulation with no significant recent mergers to show that exactly the opposite\ntrend is expected from a barred potential, but overestimated distances can flip\nthis trend to match the data. Alternatively, using an $N$-body simulation of\nthe Sagittarius dwarf-Milky Way interaction, we demonstrate that a major recent\nperturbation is necessary to reproduce the observations. Such an impact may\nhave strongly perturbed the existing bar or even triggered its formation in the\nlast $1\text{-}2$ Gyr. Carrillo_2019 Carrillo et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1903.01493
482 1902.07732 2019-08-23 Timothy D. Crundall, Michael J. Ireland, Mark R. Krumholz, Christoph Federrath, Maruša Žerjal, Jonah T. Hansen Chronostar: a novel Bayesian method for kinematic age determination. I. Derivation and application to the β Pictoris Moving Group Gaia DR2 provides an unprecedented sample of stars with full 6D phase-space\nmeasurements, creating the need for a self-consistent means of discovering and\ncharacterising the phase-space overdensities known as moving groups or\nassociations. Here we present Chronostar, a new Bayesian analysis tool that\nmeets this need. Chronostar uses the Expectation-Maximisation algorithm to\nremove the circular dependency between association membership lists and fits to\ntheir phase-space distributions, making it possible to discover unknown\nassociations within a kinematic data set. It uses forward-modelling of orbits\nthrough the Galactic potential to overcome the problem of tracing backward\nstars whose kinematics have significant observational errors, thereby providing\nreliable ages. In tests using synthetic data sets with realistic measurement\nerrors and complex initial distributions, Chronostar successfully recovers\nmembership assignments and kinematic ages up to ~ 100 Myr. In tests on real\nstellar kinematic data in the phase-space vicinity of the ${\beta}$ Pictoris\nMoving Group, Chronostar successfully rediscovers the association without any\nhuman intervention, identifies 15 new likely members, corroborates 43 candidate\nmembers, and returns a kinematic age of 17.8+-1.2 Myr. In the process we also\nrediscover the Tucana-Horologium Moving Group, for which we obtain a kinematic\nage of 36.3+1.3-1.4 Myr. Crundall_2019 Crundall et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1902.07732
483 1905.08803 2019-08-22 Angus Beane, Robyn E. Sanderson, Melissa K. Ness, Kathryn V. Johnston, Douglas Grion Filho, Mordecai-Mark Mac Low, Daniel Anglés-Alcázar, David W. Hogg, Chervin F. P. Laporte The Implications of Local Fluctuations in the Galactic Midplane for Dynamical Analysis in the Gaia Era Orbital properties of stars, computed from their six-dimensional phase space\nmeasurements and an assumed Galactic potential, are used to understand the\nstructure and evolution of the Galaxy. Stellar actions, computed from orbits,\nhave the attractive quality of being invariant under certain assumptions and\nare therefore used as quantitative labels of a star's orbit. We report a subtle\nbut important systematic error that is induced in the actions as a consequence\nof local midplane variations expected for the Milky Way. This error is\ndifficult to model because it is non-Gaussian and bimodal, with neither mode\npeaking on the null value. An offset in the vertical position of the Galactic\nmidplane of $\sim15\,\text{pc}$ for a thin disk-like orbit or $\sim\n120\,\text{pc}$ for a thick disk-like orbit induces a $25\%$ systematic error\nin the vertical action $J_z$. In FIRE simulations of Milky Way-mass galaxies,\nthese variations are on the order of $\sim100\,\text{pc}$ at the solar circle.\nFrom observations of the mean vertical velocity variation of\n$\sim5\text{--}10\,\text{km}\,\text{s}^{-1}$ with radius, we estimate that the\nMilky Way midplane variations are $\sim60\text{--}170\,\text{pc}$, consistent\nwith three-dimensional dust maps. Action calculations and orbit integrations,\nwhich assume the global and local midplanes are identical, are likely to\ninclude this induced error, depending on the volume considered. Variation in\nthe local standard of rest or distance to the Galactic center causes similar\nissues. The variation of the midplane must be taken into account when\nperforming dynamical analysis across the large regions of the disk accessible\nto Gaia and future missions. Beane_2019 Beane et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.08803
484 1908.06031 2019-08-16 Zhengyi Shao, Lu Li Gaia Parallax of Milky Way Globular Clusters -- A Solution of Mixture Model We have established a mixture model approach to derive the parallax of the\nMilky Way globular clusters.
