It avoids the problem of cluster membership\ndetermination and provides a completely independent astrometrical solution by\npurely using the parallax data. This method is validated with simulated\nclusters of \cite{2017MNRAS.467..412P}. We have resolved 120 real globular\nclusters by the mixture model using parallaxes of the second data release of\n\gaia. They construct the largest direct parallax sample up to now. In\ncomparing with other direct parallax results based on cluster members,\nincluding 75 clusters of \cite{2018A&A...616A..12G}, our method presents its\naccuracy, especially for some particular clusters. A systematic offset of\n$-27.6\pm1.7$ $\mu$as, together with a scatter of $22.8\pm1.3$ $\mu$as is found\nin comparing with other indirect parallax measurements. They are consistent\nwith the global value and the variation of the zero-point of current \gaia\nparallaxes. Distances of several specific nearby globular clusters are\ndiscussed while the closest ones can reach high precisions, even taking the\nsystematic error into account. Shao_2019 Shao and Li 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1908.06031
485 1908.04808 2019-08-13 A. Arellano Ferro, I. H. Bustos Fierro, J. H. Calderón, J. A. Ahumada NGC 1261: A time-series \emph{VI} study of its variable stars Time-series \emph{VI} CCD photometry of the globular cluster NGC 1261 is\nemployed to study its variable star population. A membership analysis of most\nvariables based on Gaia~DR2 proper motions and colours, was performed prior to\nthe estimation of the mean cluster distance and metallicity. For the member RR\nLyrae, their light curves were Fourier decomposed to calculate their individual\nvalues of distance, [Fe/H], radius and mass. The $I$-band P-L for RR Lyrae\nstars was also employed. Our best estimates of the metallicity and distance of\nthis Oo I cluster are [Fe/H]$_{\rm ZW}$=$-1.42 \pm 0.05$ dex and $d=17.2 \pm\n0.4$ kpc. No mixture of fundamental and first overtone RR Lyrae stars in the\neither-or or bimodal region is seen in this cluster, as it seems to be the rule\nfor Oo~I clusters with a red horizontal branch. A multi-approach search in a\nregion of about 10$\times$10 arcmin$^2$ around the cluster revealed no new\nvariable stars within the limitations of our CCD photometry. Ferro_2019 Ferro et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1908.04808
486 1902.05268 2019-08-13 Jorrit H. J. Hagen, Amina Helmi, P. Tim de Zeeuw, Lorenzo Posti The tilt of the velocity ellipsoid in the Milky Way with Gaia DR2 The velocity distribution of stars is a sensitive probe of the gravitational\npotential of the Galaxy, and hence of its dark matter distribution. In\nparticular, the shape of the dark halo (e.g. spherical, oblate, or prolate)\ndetermines velocity correlations, and different halo geometries are expected to\nresult in measurable differences. Here we explore and interpret the\ncorrelations in the $(v_R, v_z)$-velocity distribution as a function of\nposition in the Milky Way. We selected a high-quality sample of stars from the\nGaia DR2 catalogue and characterised the orientation of the velocity\ndistribution or tilt angle over a radial distance range of $[4-13]~$kpc and up\nto $3.5~$kpc away from the Galactic plane while taking into account the effects\nof the measurement errors. We find that the tilt angles change from spherical\nalignment in the inner Galaxy ($R\sim4~$kpc) towards more cylindrical\nalignments in the outer Galaxy ($R\sim11~$kpc) when using distances that take a\nglobal zero-point offset in the parallax of $-29~\mu$as. However, if the\namplitude of this offset is underestimated, then the inferred tilt angles in\nthe outer Galaxy only appear shallower and are intrinsically more consistent\nwith spherical alignment for an offset as large as $-54~\mu$as. We further find\nthat the tilt angles do not seem to strongly vary with Galactic azimuth and\nthat different stellar populations depict similar tilt angles. Therefore we\nintroduce a simple analytic function that describes the trends found over the\nfull radial range. Since the systematic parallax errors in Gaia DR2 depend on\ncelestial position, magnitude, and colour in complex ways, it is not possible\nto fully correct for them. Therefore it will be particularly important for\ndynamical modelling of the Milky Way to thoroughly characterise the systematics\nin astrometry in future Gaia data releases. Hagen_2019 Hagen et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1902.05268
487 1907.05652 2019-08-12 Christian L. Sahlholdt, Luca Casagrande, Sofia Feltzing Characteristics of the two sequences seen in the high-velocity Hertzsprung-Russell diagram in Gaia DR2 In this study we use a sample of about 9 million SkyMapper stars with\nmetallicities to investigate the properties of the two stellar populations seen\nin the high-velocity ($V_{\rm T} > 200$ km/s) Gaia DR2 Hertzsprung-Russell\ndiagram. Based on 10,000 red giant branch (RGB) stars (out of 75,000 with high\nvelocity), we find that the two sequences have different metallicity\ndistribution functions; one peaks at $-1.4$ dex (blue sequence) and the other\nat $-0.7$ dex (red sequence). Isochrones with ages in the range $11$-$13.5$\nGyr, and metallicities chosen to match the observations for each sequence, fit\nthe turnoffs and broad RGBs well, indicating that the two populations formed at\ncomparable times within the uncertainties. We find that the mean tangential\nvelocity of disk stars increases steadily with decreasing metallicity, and that\nthe red sequence is made up of the high-velocity stars at the lowest\nmetallicities of the thick-disk population. Using relative number densities, we\nfurther find that the red-sequence stars are more centrally concentrated in the\nGalaxy, and we estimate the radial scale length of this population to be on the\norder of $2$-$3$ kpc. The blue-sequence stars, on the other hand, follow a\nnearly flat radial density profile. These findings tighten the link between the\nred-sequence stars and the chemically defined thick disk. Sahlholdt_2019 Sahlholdt et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1907.05652
488 1908.02972 2019-08-08 Santiago Torres, Carles Cantero, María E. Camisassa, Teresa Antoja, Alberto Rebassa-Mansergas, Leandro G. Althaus, Thomas Thelemaque, Héctor Cánovas Gaia DR2 white dwarfs in the Hercules stream We analyzed the velocity space of the thin and thick-disk Gaia white dwarf\npopulation within 100 pc looking for signatures of the Hercules stellar stream.\nWe aimed to identify those objects belonging to the Hercules stream and, by\ntaking advantage of white dwarf stars as reliable cosmochronometers, to derive\na first age distribution. We applied a kernel density estimation to the $UV$\nvelocity space of white dwarfs. For the region where a clear overdensity of\nstars was found, we created a 5-D space of dynamic variables. We applied a\nhierarchichal clustering method, HDBSCAN, to this 5-D space, identifying those\nwhite dwarfs that share similar kinematic characteristics. Finally, under\ngeneral assumptions and from their photometric properties, we derived an age\nestimate for each object. The Hercules stream was firstly revealed as an\noverdensity in the $UV$ velocity space of the thick-disk white dwarf\npopulation. Three substreams were then found: Hercules $a$ and Hercules $b$,\nformed by thick-disk stars with an age distribution peaked $4\,$Gyr in the past\nand extended to very old ages; and Hercules $c$, with a ratio of 65:35\nthin:thick stars and a more uniform age distribution younger than 10 Gyr. Torres_2019 Torres et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1908.02972
489 1908.02772 2019-08-07 Diane K. Feuillet, Neige Frankel, Karin Lind, Peter M. Frinchaboy, D. A. Garcia-Hernandez, Richard R. Lane, Christian Nitschelm, Alexandre Roman-Lopes Spatial variations in the Milky Way disc metallicity-age relation Stellar ages are a crucial component to studying the evolution of the Milky\nWay. Using Gaia DR2 distance estimates, it is now possible to estimate stellar\nages for a larger volume of evolved stars through isochrone matching. This work\npresents [M/H]-age and [$\alpha$/M]-age relations derived for different spatial\nlocations in the Milky Way disc. These relations are derived by hierarchically\nmodelling the star formation history of stars within a given chemical abundance\nbin. For the first time, we directly observe that significant variation is\napparent in the [M/H]-age relation as a function of both Galactocentric radius\nand distance from the disc mid-plane. The [M/H]-age relations support claims\nthat radial migration has a significant effect in the plane of the disc. Using\nthe [M/H] bin with the youngest mean age at each radial zone in the plane of\nthe disc, the present-day metallicity gradient is measured to be $-0.059 \pm\n0.010$ dex kpc$^{-1}$, in agreement with Cepheids and young field stars. We\nfind a vertically flared distribution of young stars in the outer disc,\nconfirming predictions of models and previous observations. The mean age of the\n[M/H]-[$\alpha$/M] distribution of the solar neighborhood suggests that the\nhigh-[M/H] stars are not an evolutionary extension of the low-$\alpha$\nsequence. Our observational results are important constraints to Galactic\nsimulations and models of chemical evolution. Feuillet_2019 Feuillet et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1908.02772
490 1908.02064 2019-08-07 M. Fabrizio, G. Bono, V. F. Braga, D. Magurno, S. Marinoni, P. M. Marrese, I. Ferraro, G. Fiorentino, G. Giuffrida, G. Iannicola, M. Monelli, G. Altavilla, B. Chaboyer, M. Dall'Ora, C. K. Gilligan, A. Layden, M. Marengo, M. Nonino, G. W. Preston, B. Sesar, C. Sneden, E. Valenti, F. Thévenin, E. Zoccali On the use of field RR Lyrae as Galactic probes: I. The Oosterhoff dichotomy based on fundamental variables We collected a large data set of field RR Lyrae stars (RRLs) by using\ncatalogues already available in the literature and Gaia DR2. We estimated the\niron abundances for a sub-sample of 2,382 fundamental RRLs ($\Delta$S method:\nCaIIK, H$\beta$, H$\gamma$ and H$\delta$ lines) for which are publicly\navailable medium-resolution SDSS-SEGUE spectra. We also included similar\nestimates available in the literature ending up with the largest and most\nhomogeneous spectroscopic data set ever collected for RRLs (2,903). The\nmetallicity scale was validated by using iron abundances based on high\nresolution spectra for a fundamental field RRL (V~Ind), for which we collected\nX-shooter spectra covering the entire pulsation cycle. The peak\n([Fe/H]=-1.59$\pm$0.01) and the standard deviation ($\sigma$=0.43 dex) of the\nmetallicity distribution agree quite well with similar estimates available in\nthe literature. The current measurements disclose a well defined metal-rich\ntail approaching Solar iron abundance. The spectroscopic sample plotted in the\nBailey diagram (period vs luminosity amplitude) shows a steady variation when\nmoving from the metal-poor ([Fe/H]=-3.0/-2.5) to the metal-rich\n([Fe/H]=-0.5/0.0) regime. The smooth transition in the peak of the period\ndistribution as a function of the metallicity strongly indicates that the\nlong-standing problem of the Oosterhoff dichotomy among Galactic globulars is\nthe consequence of the lack of metal-intermediate clusters hosting RRLs. We\nalso found that the luminosity amplitude, in contrast with period, does not\nshow a solid correlation with metallicity. This suggests that\nperiod-amplitude-metallicity relations should be cautiously treated. Fabrizio_2019 Fabrizio et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1908.02064
491 1903.02009 2019-08-05 Jason L. Sanders, Leigh Smith, N. Wyn Evans The pattern speed of the Milky Way bar from transverse velocities We use the continuity equation to derive a method for measuring the pattern\nspeed of the Milky Way's bar/bulge from proper motion data. The method has\nminimal assumptions but requires complete coverage of the non-axisymmetric\ncomponent in two of the three Galactic coordinates. We apply our method to the\nproper motion data from a combination of Gaia DR2 and VISTA Variables in the\nVia Lactea (VVV) to measure the pattern speed of the bar as\n$\Omega_\mathrm{p}=(41\pm 3)\,\mathrm{km\,s^{-1}\,kpc^{-1}}$ (where the error\nis statistical). This puts the corotation radius at\n$(5.7\pm0.4)\,\mathrm{kpc}$, under the assumptions of the standard peculiar\nmotion of the Sun and the absence of non-axisymmetric streaming in the Solar\nneighbourhood. The obtained result uses only data on the near-side of the bar\nwhich produces consistent measurements of the distance and velocity of the\ncentre of the Galaxy. Addition of the data on the far-side of the bar pulls the\npattern speed down to $\Omega_\mathrm{p}=(31\pm\n1)\,\mathrm{km\,s^{-1}\,kpc^{-1}}$ but requires a lower transverse velocity for\nthe Galactic centre than observed. This suggests systematics of\n$5-10\,\mathrm{km\,s^{-1}kpc^{-1}}$ dominate the uncertainty. We demonstrate\nusing a dynamically-formed bar/bulge simulation that even with the limited\nfield of view of the VVV survey our method robustly recovers the pattern speed. Sanders_2019a Sanders et al. 2019a https://arxiv.org/abs/1903.02009
492 1810.10645 2019-08-05 Alexander H. Riley, Azadeh Fattahi, Andrew B. Pace, Louis E. Strigari, Carlos S. Frenk, Facundo A. Gómez, Robert J. J. Grand, Federico Marinacci, Julio F. Navarro, Rüdiger Pakmor, Christine M. Simpson, Simon D. M. White The velocity anisotropy of the Milky Way satellite system We analyse the orbital kinematics of the Milky Way (MW) satellite system\nutilizing the latest systemic proper motions for 38 satellites based on data\nfrom Gaia Data Release 2. Combining these data with distance and line-of-sight\nvelocity measurements from the literature, we use a likelihood method to model\nthe velocity anisotropy, $\beta$, as a function of Galactocentric distance and\ncompare the MW satellite system with those of simulated MW-mass haloes from the\nAPOSTLE and Auriga simulation suites. The anisotropy profile for the MW\nsatellite system increases from $\beta\sim -2$ at $r\sim20$ kpc to $\beta\sim\n0.5$ at $r\sim200$ kpc, indicating that satellites closer to the Galactic\ncentre have tangentially-biased motions while those farther out have\nradially-biased motions. The motions of satellites around APOSTLE host galaxies\nare nearly isotropic at all radii, while the $\beta(r)$ profiles for satellite\nsystems in the Auriga suite, whose host galaxies are substantially more massive\nin baryons than those in APOSTLE, are more consistent with that of the MW\nsatellite system. This shape of the $\beta(r)$ profile may be attributed to the\ncentral stellar disc preferentially destroying satellites on radial orbits, or\nintrinsic processes from the formation of the Milky Way system. Riley_2019 Riley et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1810.10645
493 1811.05345 2019-07-31 Eugene Vasiliev Systematic errors in Gaia DR2 astrometry and their impact on measurements of internal kinematics of star clusters We use stellar proper motions (PM) from Gaia Data Release 2 for studying the\ninternal kinematics of Milky Way globular clusters. In addition to statistical\nmeasurement errors, there are significant spatially correlated systematic\nerrors, which cannot be ignored when studying the internal kinematics. We\ndevelop a mathematically consistent procedure for incorporating the spatial\ncorrelations in any model-fitting approach, and use it to determine rotation\nand velocity dispersion profiles of a few dozen clusters. We confirm detection\nof rotation in the sky plane for ~10 clusters reported in previous studies, and\ndiscover a few more clusters with rotation amplitudes exceeding ~0.05 mas/yr.\nHowever, in more than half of these cases the significance of this rotation\nsignature is rather low when taking into account the systematic errors. We find\nthat the PM dispersion is not sensitive to systematic errors in PM, however, it\nis quite sensitive to the selection criteria on the input sample, most\nimportantly, in crowded central regions. When using the cleanest possible\nsamples, PM dispersion can be reliably measured down to 0.1 mas/yr for ~60\nclusters. Vasiliev_2019a Vasiliev 2019a https://arxiv.org/abs/1811.05345
494 1906.02663 2019-07-29 Moiya McTier, David Kipping Not Gone with the Wind: Planet Occurrence is Independent of Stellar Galactocentric Velocity We demonstrate that planet occurrence does not depend on stellar\ngalactocentric velocity in the Solar neighborhood. Using Gaia DR2 astrometry\nand radial velocity data, we calculate 3D galactocentric velocities for 197,090\nKepler field stars, 1647 of which are confirmed planet hosts. When we compare\nthe galactocentric velocities of planet hosts to those of the entire field star\nsample, we observe a statistically significant (KS p-value = $10^{-70}$)\ndistinction, with planet hosts being apparently slower than field stars by\n$\sim$40 km/s. We explore some potential explanations for this difference and\nconclude that it is not a consequence of the planet-metallicity relation or\ndistinctions in the samples' thin/thick disk membership, but rather an artefact\nof Kepler's selection function. Non Kepler-host stars that have nearly\nidentical distances, temperatures, surface gravities, and Kepler magnitudes to\nthe confirmed planet hosts also have nearly identical velocity distributions.\nUsing one of these identical non-host samples, we consider that the probability\nof a star with velocity $v_{\mathrm{tot}}$ hosting a planet can be described by\nan exponential function proportional to $e^{(-v_{\mathrm{tot}}/v_0)}$. Using a\nMarkov Chain Monte Carlo sampler, we determine that $v_0 > $976 km/s to 99%\nconfidence, which implies that planets in the Solar neighborhood are just as\nlikely to form around fast stars as they are around slow stars. Our work\nhighlights the subtle ways in which selection biases can create strong\ncorrelations without physical underpinnings. McTier_2019 McTier and Kipping 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1906.02663
495 1907.12485 2019-07-29 Dana I. Casetti-Dinescu, Terrence M. Girard A Kinematically Cold Structure of Candidate Young OB Stars Toward The Anticenter We combine GALEX and Gaia DR2 catalogs to track star formation in the\noutskirts of our Galaxy. Using photometry, proper motions and parallaxes we\nidentify a structure of ~ 300 OB-type candidates located between 12 and 15 kpc\nfrom the Galactic center that are kinematically cold. The structure is located\nbetween l = 120 and 200 degrees, above the plane up to ~700 pc and below the\nplane to ~ 1 kpc. The bulk motion is disk-like; however we measure a mean\nupward vertical motion of 5.7 +-0.4 km/s, and a mean outward radial motion of\nbetween 8 and 16 km/s. The velocity dispersion along the least dispersed of its\nproper-motion axes (perpendicular to the Galactic disk) is 6.0 +-0.3 km/s\nconfirming the young age of this structure.\n While spatially encompassing the outer spiral arm of the Galaxy, this\nstructure is not a spiral arm. Its explanation as the Milky-Way warp is equally\nunsatisfactory. The structure's vertical extent, mean kinematics and asymmetry\nwith respect to the plane indicate that its origin is more akin to a wobble\ngenerated by a massive satellite perturbing the Galaxy's disk. The mean stellar\nages in this outer structure indicate the event took place some 200 Myr ago. Casetti-Dinescu_2019 Casetti-Dinescu and Girard 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1907.12485
496 1907.10969 2019-07-25 Samuel W. F. Earp, Victor P. Debattista, Andrea V. Macciò, Liang Wang, Tobias Buck, Tigran Khachaturyants Drivers of disc tilting I: Correlations and possible drivers for Milky Way analogues The direction of the spin vectors of disk galaxies change over time. We\npresent the tilting rate of a sample of galaxies in the NIHAO suite of\ncosmological hydrodynamical simulations. Galaxies in our sample have been\nselected to be isolated and to have well determined spins. We compare the\ntilting rates to the predicted observing limit of Gaia, finding that our entire\nsample lies above the limit, in agreement with previous work. To test the role\nof dark matter and of gas we compare the weighted Pearson's correlation\ncoefficients between the tilting rates and various properties. We find no\ncorrelation between the dark halo's tilting rate, shape, or misalignment with\nrespect to the disc, and the tilting rate of the stellar disc. Therefore, we\nargue that, in the presence of gas, the dark halo plays a negligible role in\nthe tilting of the stellar disc. On the other hand, we find a strong\ncorrelation between the tilting rate of the stellar disc and the misalignment\nof the cold gas warp. Adding the stellar mass fraction improves the\ncorrelation, while none of the dark matter's properties together with the cold\ngas misalignment improves the correlation to any significant extent. This\nimplies that the gas cooling onto the disc is the principal driver of disc\ntilting. Earp_2019 Earp et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1907.10969
497 1807.02519 2019-07-25 Lina Necib, Mariangela Lisanti, Vasily Belokurov Inferred Evidence For Dark Matter Kinematic Substructure with SDSS-Gaia We use the distribution of accreted stars in SDSS-Gaia DR2 to demonstrate\nthat a non-trivial fraction of the dark matter halo within Galactocentric radii\nof 7.5-10 kpc and $|z| > 2.5$ kpc is in substructure, and thus may not be in\nequilibrium. Using a mixture likelihood analysis, we separate the contributions\nof an old, isotropic stellar halo and a younger anisotropic population. The\nlatter dominates and is uniform within the region studied. It can be explained\nas the tidal debris of a disrupted massive satellite on a highly radial orbit,\nand is consistent with mounting evidence from recent studies. Simulations that\ntrack the tidal debris from such mergers find that the dark matter traces the\nkinematics of its stellar counterpart. If so, our results indicate that a\ncomponent of the nearby dark matter halo that is sourced by luminous satellites\nis in kinematic substructure referred to as debris flow. These results\nchallenge the Standard Halo Model, which is discrepant with the distribution\nrecovered from the stellar data, and have important ramifications for the\ninterpretation of direct detection experiments. Necib_2019 Necib et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1807.02519
498 1907.09488 2019-07-22 N. Shipp, T. S. Li, A. B. Pace, D. Erkal, A. Drlica-Wagner, B. Yanny, V. Belokurov, W. Wester, S. E. Koposov, G. F. Lewis, J. D. Simpson, Z. Wan, D. B. Zucker, S. L. Martell, M. Y. Wang Proper Motions of Stellar Streams Discovered in the Dark Energy Survey We cross-match high-precision astrometric data from Gaia DR2 with accurate\nmulti-band photometry from the Dark Energy Survey (DES) DR1 to confidently\nmeasure proper motions for nine stellar streams in the DES footprint: Aliqa\nUma, ATLAS, Chenab, Elqui, Indus, Jhelum, Phoenix, Tucana III, and Turranburra.\nWe determine low-confidence proper motion measurements for four additional\nstellar streams: Ravi, Wambelong, Willka Yaku, and Turbio. We find evidence for\na misalignment between stream tracks and the systemic proper motion of streams\nthat may suggest a systematic gravitational influence from the Large Magellanic\nCloud. These proper motions, when combined with radial velocity measurements,\nwill allow for detailed orbit modeling which can be used to constrain\nproperties of the LMC and its affect on nearby streams, as well as global\nproperties of the Milky Way's gravitational potential. Shipp_2019 Shipp et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1907.09488
499 1907.07709 2019-07-19 Marina Kounkel, Kevin Covey Untangling the Galaxy I: Local Structure and Star Formation History of the Milky Way Gaia DR2 provides unprecedented precision in measurements of the distance and\nkinematics of stars in the solar neighborhood. Through applying unsupervised\nmachine learning on DR2's 5-dimensional dataset (3d position + 2d velocity), we\nidentify a number of clusters, associations, and co-moving groups within 1 kpc\nand $|b|<30^\circ$ (many of which have not been previously known). We estimate\ntheir ages with the precision of $\sim$0.15 dex. Many of these groups appear to\nbe filamentary or string-like, oriented in parallel to the Galactic plane, and\nsome span hundreds of pc in length. Most of these string lack a central\ncluster, indicating that their filamentary structure is primordial, rather than\nthe result of tidal stripping or dynamical processing. The youngest strings\n($<$100 Myr) are orthogonal to the Local Arm. The older ones appear to be\nremnants of several other arm-like structures that cannot be presently traced\nby dust and gas. The velocity dispersion measured from the ensemble of groups\nand strings increase with age, suggesting a timescale for dynamical heating of\n$\sim$300 Myr. This timescale is also consistent with the age at which the\npopulation of strings begins to decline, while the population in more compact\ngroups continues to increase, suggesting that dynamical processes are\ndisrupting the weakly bound string populations, leaving only individual\nclusters to be identified at the oldest ages. These data shed a new light on\nthe local galactic structure and a large scale cloud collapse. Kounkel_2019 Kounkel and Covey 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1907.07709
500 1907.08011 2019-07-18 Sofia Feltzing, J. Bradley Bowers, Oscar Agertz Constraining churning and blurring in the Milky Way using large spectroscopic surveys -- an exploratory study We have investigated the possibilities to quantify how much stars move in the\nMilky Way stellar disk due to diffuse processes (i.e. so called blurring) and\ndue to influences from spiral arms and the bar (i.e. so called churning). To\nthis end we assume that it is possible to infer the formation radius of a star\nif we know their elemental abundances and age as well as the metallicity\nprofile of the interstellar medium at the time of the formation of the star.\nUsing this information, coupled with orbital information derived from Gaia DR2\ndata and radial velocities from large spectroscopic surveys, we show that it is\npossible to isolate stellar samples such that we can start to quantify how\nimportant the role of churning is. We use data from APOGEE DR14, parallaxes\nfrom Gaia and stellar ages based on C and N elemental abundances in the stars.\nIn our sample, we find that about half of the stars have experienced some sort\nof radial migration (based solely on their orbital properties), 10 % have\nlikely have suffered only from churning, whilst a modest 5-7 % of stars have\nnever experienced either churning or blurring making them ideal tracers of the\noriginal properties of the cool stellar disk. Our investigation shows that it\nis possible to put up a framework where we can begin to quantify churning and\nblurring an important. Important aspects for future work would include to\ninvestigate how selection effects should be accounted for. Feltzing_2019 Feltzing et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1907.08011
501 1907.07684 2019-07-17 Charlie Conroy, Ana Bonaca, Phillip Cargile, Benjamin D. Johnson, Nelson Caldwell, Rohan P. Naidu, Dennis Zaritsky, Daniel Fabricant, Sean Moran, Jaehyon Rhee, Andrew Szentgyorgyi Mapping the Stellar Halo with the H3 Spectroscopic Survey Modern theories of galaxy formation predict that the Galactic stellar halo\nwas hierarchically assembled from the accretion and disruption of smaller\nsystems. This hierarchical assembly is expected to produce a high degree of\nstructure in the combined phase and chemistry space; this structure should\nprovide a relatively direct probe of the accretion history of our Galaxy.\nRevealing this structure requires precise 3D positions (including distances),\n3D velocities, and chemistry for large samples of stars. The Gaia satellite is\ndelivering proper motions and parallaxes for >1 billion stars to G~20. However,\nradial velocities and metallicities will only be available to G~15, which is\ninsufficient to probe the outer stellar halo (>10 kpc). Moreover, parallaxes\nwill not be precise enough to deliver high-quality distances for stars beyond\n~10 kpc. Identifying accreted systems throughout the stellar halo therefore\nrequires a large ground-based spectroscopic survey to complement Gaia. Here we\nprovide an overview of the H3 Stellar Spectroscopic Survey, which will deliver\nprecise stellar parameters and spectrophotometric distances for 200,000 stars\nto r=18. Spectra are obtained with the Hectochelle instrument at the MMT, which\nis configured for the H3 Survey to deliver resolution R~23,000 spectra covering\nthe wavelength range 5150A-5300A. The survey is optimized for stellar halo\nscience and therefore focuses on high Galactic latitude fields (|b|>30 deg.),\nsparsely sampling 15,000 sq. degrees. Targets are selected on the basis of Gaia\nparallaxes, enabling very efficient selection of bone fide halo stars. The\nsurvey began in the Fall of 2017 and has collected 88,000 spectra to-date. All\nof the data, including the derived stellar parameters, will eventually be made\npublicly available via the survey website: h3survey.rc.fas.harvard.edu. Conroy_2019 Conroy et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1907.07684
502 1907.06348 2019-07-15 Cuihua Du, Hefan Li, Yepeng Yan, Heidi Jo Newberg, Jianrong Shi, Jun Ma, Yuqin Chen, Zhenyu Wu New nearby hypervelocity stars and their spatial distribution from Gaia DR2 Base on about 4,500 large tangential velocity\n($V_\mathrm{tan}>0.75V_\mathrm{esc}$) with high-precision proper motions and\n$5\sigma$ parallaxes in Gaia DR2 5D information derived from parallax and\nproper motion, we identify more than 600 high velocity stars with $50\%$\nunbound probability. Of these, 28 nearby (less than 6 kpc) late-type\nHypervelocity stars (HVSs) with over $99\%$ possibility of unbound are\ndiscovered. In order to search for the unbound stars from the full Gaia DR2 6D\nphase space information derived from parallax, proper motion and radial\nvelocity, we also identify 28 stars from the total velocity\n($V_\mathrm{gc}>0.75V_\mathrm{esc}$) that have probabilities greater than\n$50\%$ of being unbound from the Galaxy. Of these, only three have a nearly\n$99\%$ probabilities of being unbound. On the whole HVSs subsample, there is 12\nsources reported by other surveys. We study the spatial distribution of angular\npositions and angular separation of HVSs. We find the unbound HVSs are\nspatially anisotropic that is most significant in the Galactic longitude at\nmore than $3\sigma$ level, and lower unbound probability HVSs are\nsystematically more isotropic. The spatial distribution can reflect the origin\nof HVSs and we discuss the possible origin link with the anisotropy. Du_2019 Du et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1907.06348
503 1907.03763 2019-07-08 Yusuke Miyachi, Nobuyuki Sakai, Daisuke Kawata, Junichi Baba, Mareki Honma, Noriyuki Matsunaga, Kenta Fujisawa Stellar Overdensity in the Local Arm in Gaia DR2 Using the cross-matched data of Gaia DR2 and 2MASS Point Source Catalog, we\ninvestigated the surface density distribution of stars aged ~1 Gyr in the thin\ndisk in the range of 90{\deg} <= l <= 270{\deg}. We selected 4,654 stars above\nthe turnoff corresponding to the age ~1 Gyr, that fall within a small box\nregion in the color-magnitude diagram, (J-Ks)0 versus M(Ks), for which the\ndistance and reddening are corrected. The selected sample shows an arm-like\noverdensity at 90{\deg} <= l <= 190{\deg}.This overdensity is located close to\nthe Local arm traced by high-mass star forming regions (HMSFRs), but its pitch\nangle is slightly larger than that of the HMSFR-defined arm. Although the\nsignificance of the overdensity we report is marginal, its structure poses\nquestions concerning both of the competing scenarios of spiral arms, the\ndensity-wave theory and the dynamic spiral arm model. The offset between the\narms traced by stars and HMSFRs, i.e., gas, is difficult to be explained by the\ndynamic arm scenario. On the other hand, the pitch angle of the stellar Local\narm, if confirmed, larger than that of the Perseus arm is difficult to be\nexplained with the classical density-wave scenario. The dynamic arm scenario\ncan explain it if the Local arm is in a growing up phase, while the Perseus arm\nis in a disrupting phase. Our result provides a new and complex picture of the\nGalactic spiral arms, and encourages further studies. Miyachi_2019 Miyachi et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1907.03763
504 1906.05227 2019-07-08 R. de la Fuente Marcos, C. de la Fuente Marcos Flying far and fast: the distribution of distant hypervelocity star candidates from Gaia DR2 data Context. Hypervelocity stars move fast enough to leave the gravitational\nfield of their home galaxies and venture into intergalactic space. The most\nextreme examples known have estimated speeds in excess of 1000 km/s. These can\nbe easily induced at the centres of galaxies via close encounters between\nbinary stars and supermassive black holes; however, a number of other\nmechanisms operating elsewhere can produce them as well.\n Aims. Recent studies suggest that hypervelocity stars are ubiquitous in the\nlocal Universe. In the Milky Way, the known hypervelocity stars are\nanisotropically distributed, but it is unclear why. Here, we used Gaia Data\nRelease 2 (DR2) data to perform a systematic exploration aimed at confirming or\nrefuting these findings.\n Methods. We assume that the farther the candidate hypervelocity stars are,\nthe more likely they are to be unbound from the Galaxy. We used the statistical\nanalysis of both the spatial distribution and kinematics of these objects to\nachieve our goals.\n Results. Focussing on nominal Galactocentric distances greater than 30 kpc,\nwhich are the most distant candidates, we isolated a sample with speeds in\nexcess of 500 km/s that exhibits a certain degree of anisotropy but remains\ncompatible with possible systematic effects. We find that the effect of the\nEddington-Trumpler-Weaver bias is important in our case: over 80% of our\nsources are probably located further away than implied by their parallaxes;\ntherefore, most of our velocity estimates are lower limits. If this bias is as\nstrong as suggested here, the contamination by disc stars may not affect our\noverall conclusions.\n Conclusions. The subsample with the lowest uncertainties shows stronger, but\nobviously systematic, anisotropies and includes a number of candidates of\npossible extragalactic origin and young age with speeds of up to 2000 km/s. Marcos_2019 Marcos and Marcos 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1906.05227
505 1901.07568 2019-07-05 F. Fragkoudi, D. Katz, W. Trick, S. D. M. White, P. Di Matteo, M. C. Sormani, S. Khoperskov, M. Haywood, A. Hallé, A. Gómez On the ridges, undulations & streams in Gaia DR2: Linking the topography of phase-space to the orbital structure of an N-body bar We explore the origin of phase-space substructures revealed by the second\nGaia data release in the disc of the Milky Way, such as the ridges in the\n$V_{\phi}$-$r$ plane, the undulations in the $V_{\phi}$-$r$-$V_r$ space and the\nstreams in the $V_{\phi}$-$V_r$ plane. We use a collisionless N-body simulation\nwith co-spatial thin and thick discs, along with orbit integration, to study\nthe orbital structure close to the Outer Lindblad Resonance (OLR) of the bar.\nWe find that a prominent, long-lived ridge is formed in the $V_{\phi}$-$r$\nplane due to the OLR which translates to streams in the $V_{\phi}$-$V_r$ plane\nand examine which closed periodic and trapped librating orbits are responsible\nfor these features. We find that orbits which carry out small librations around\nthe $x_1(1)$ family are preferentially found at negative $V_r$, giving rise to\na `horn'-like feature, while orbits with larger libration amplitudes, trapped\naround the $x_1(2)$ and $x_1(1)$ families, constitute the positive $V_r$\nsubstructure, i.e. the Hercules-like feature. This changing libration amplitude\nof orbits will translate to a changing ratio of thin/thick disc stars, which\ncould have implications on the metallicity distribution in this plane. We find\nthat a scenario in which the Sun is placed close to the OLR gives rise to a\nstrong asymmetry in $V_r$ in the $V_{\phi}$-$V_r$ plane (i.e. Hercules vs. `the\nhorn') and subsequently to undulations in the $V_{\phi}$-$r$-$V_r$ space. We\nalso explore a scenario in which the Sun is placed closer to the bar corotation\nand find that the bar perturbation $alone$ cannot give rise to the these\nfeatures. Fragkoudi_2019 Fragkoudi et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1901.07568
506 1907.02876 2019-07-05 Mikhail Kovalev, Maria Bergemann, Yuan-Sen Ting, Hans-Walter Rix NLTE Chemical abundances in Galactic open and globular clusters Aims We study the effects of non-local thermodynamic equilibrium (NLTE) on\nthe determination of stellar parameters and abundances of Fe, Mg, and Ti from\nthe medium-resolution spectra of FGK stars.} Methods We extend the Payne\nfitting approach to draw on NLTE and LTE spectral models. These are used to\nanalyse the spectra of the Gaia-ESO benchmark stars and the spectra of 742\nstars in 13 open and globular clusters in the Milky Way: NGC 3532, NGC 5927,\nNGC 2243, NGC 104, NGC 1851, NGC 2808, NGC 362, M 2, MGC 6752, NGC 1904, NGC\n4833, NGC 4372 and M 15. Results Our approach accurately recovers effective\ntemperatures, surface gravities, and abundances of the benchmark stars and\nclusters members. The differences between NLTE and LTE are significant in the\nmetal-poor regime, [Fe/H] $\lesssim -1$. The NLTE [Fe/H] values are\nsystematically higher, whereas the average NLTE [Mg/Fe] abundance ratios are\n$\sim 0.15$ dex lower, compared to LTE. Our LTE measurements of metallicities\nand abundances of stars in Galactic clusters are in a good agreement with the\nliterature. Yet, for most clusters, our study yields the first estimates of\nNLTE abundances of Fe, Mg and Ti. Conclusions All clusters investigated in this\nwork are homogeneous in Fe and Ti, with the intra-cluster abundance variations\nof less than 0.04 dex. NGC 2808, NGC 4833, M 2 and M 15 show significant\ndispersions in [Mg/Fe]. Contrary to common assumptions, the NLTE analysis\nchanges the mean abundance ratios in the clusters, but it does not influence\nthe intra-cluster abundance dispersions. Kovalev_2019 Kovalev et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1907.02876
507 1907.02612 2019-07-04 I. H. Bustos Fierro, J. H. Calderón Extraction of globular clusters members with Gaia DR2 astrometry In this work we present a method to identify possible members of globular\nclusters using data from Gaia DR2. The method consists of two stages: the first\none based on a clustering algorithm, and the second one based on the analysis\nof the projected spatial distribution of stars with different proper motions.\nIn order to confirm that the clusters members extracted by the method\ncorrespond to actual globular clusters, the spatial distribution, the vector\npoint diagram of the proper motions and the colour-magnitude diagrams are\nanalysed. We apply the developed method to eight clusters: NGC 1261, NGC 3201,\nNGC 6139, NGC 6205, NGC 6362, NGC 6397, NGC 6712 and Palomar 13; we show the\nnumber of members extracted, the mean proper motions derived from them and\nfinally we compare our results with other authors. In order to analyse the\nefficiency of the extraction method we perform an estimation of the\ncompleteness and the degree of contamination of the extracted members. Fierro_2019 Fierro and Calderón 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1907.02612
508 1810.09489 2019-07-04 A. Udalski, I. Soszyński, P. Pietrukowicz, M. K. Szymański, D. M. Skowron, J. Skowron, P. Mróz, R. Poleski, S. Kozłowski, K. Ulaczyk, K. Rybicki, P. Iwanek, M. Wrona OGLE Collection of Galactic Cepheids We present here a new major part of the OGLE Collection of Variable Stars -\nOGLE Collection of Galactic Cepheids. The new dataset was extracted from the\nGalaxy Variability Survey images - a dedicated large-scale survey of the\nGalactic disk and outer bulge conducted by the OGLE project since 2013.\n The OGLE collection contains 2721 Cepheids of all types - classical, type II\nand anomalous. It more than doubles the number of known Galactic classical\nCepheids. Due to the long-term monitoring and large number of epochs the\nselected sample is very pure, generally free from contaminating stars of other\ntypes often mimicking Cepheids. Its completeness is high at 90% level for\nclassical Cepheids - tested using recent samples of Galactic Cepheids: ASAS-SN,\nATLAS, Gaia DR2 and Wise catalog of variable stars. Our comparisons indicate\nthat the completeness of the two latter datasets, Gaia DR2 and Wise catalog, is\nvery low, at < 10% level in the magnitude range of the OGLE GVS survey (10.8 <\nI < 19.5 mag). Both these samples are severely contaminated by non-Cepheids\n(the purity is 67% and 56%, respectively).\n We also present several interesting objects found in the new OGLE Collection\n- multi-mode pulsators, a first Galactic candidate for eclipsing system\ncontaining Cepheid, a binary Cepheid candidate. Udalski_2019 Udalski et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1810.09489
509 1904.11302 2019-07-03 F. Anders, A. Khalatyan, C. Chiappini, A. B. Queiroz, B. X. Santiago, C. Jordi, L. Girardi, A. G. A. Brown, G. Matijevič, G. Monari, T. Cantat-Gaudin, M. Weiler, S. Khan, A. Miglio, I. Carrillo, M. Romero-Gómez, I. Minchev, R. S. de Jong, T. Antoja, P. Ramos, M. Steinmetz, H. Enke Photo-astrometric distances, extinctions, and astrophysical parameters for Gaia DR2 stars brighter than G = 18 Combining the precise parallaxes and optical photometry delivered by Gaia's\nsecond data release (Gaia DR2) with the photometric catalogues of PanSTARRS-1,\n2MASS, and AllWISE, we derive Bayesian stellar parameters, distances, and\nextinctions for 265 million stars brighter than G=18. Because of the wide\nwavelength range used, our results substantially improve the accuracy and\nprecision of previous extinction and effective temperature estimates. After\ncleaning our results for both unreliable input and output data, we retain 137\nmillion stars, for which we achieve a median precision of 5% in distance, 0.20\nmag in V-band extinction, and 245 K in effective temperature for G<14,\ndegrading towards fainter magnitudes (12%, 0.20 mag, and 245 K at G=16; 16%,\n0.23 mag, and 260 K at G=17, respectively). We find a very good agreement with\nthe asteroseismic surface gravities and distances of 7000 stars in the Kepler,\nthe K2-C3, and the K2-C6 fields, with stellar parameters from the APOGEE\nsurvey, as well as with distances to star clusters. Our results are available\nthrough the ADQL query interface of the Gaia mirror at the Leibniz-Institut\nf\"{u}r Astrophysik Potsdam (gaia.aip.de) and as binary tables at data.aip.de.\nAs a first application, in this paper we provide distance- and\nextinction-corrected colour-magnitude diagrams, extinction maps as a function\nof distance, and extensive density maps, demonstrating the potential of our\nvalue-added dataset for mapping the three-dimensional structure of our Galaxy.\nIn particular, we see a clear manifestation of the Galactic bar in the stellar\ndensity distributions, an observation that can almost be considered a direct\nimaging of the Galactic bar. Anders_2019 Anders et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1904.11302
510 1906.11863 2019-06-27 S. Ortolani, E. V. Held, D. Nardiello, S. Souza, B. Barbuy, A. Pérez-Villegas, S. Cassisi, E. Bica, Y. Momany, I. Saviane Another relic bulge globular cluster: ESO 456-SC38 (Djorgovski~2) The object ESO456-SC38 (Djorgovski 2) is one of the globular clusters that is\nclosest to the Galactic center. It is on the blue horizontal branch and has a\nmoderate metallicity of [Fe/H]~-1.0. It is thus similar to the very old inner\nbulge globular clusters NGC 6522, NGC 6558, and HP 1, and therefore appears to\nbe part of the primeval formation stages of the Milky Way. The aim of this work\nis to determine an accurate distance and metallicity for ESO456-SC38, as well\nas orbital parameters, in order to check similarities with other clusters in\nthe inner bulge that have previously been well studied in terms of spectroscopy\nand photometry. This is a considerably fainter cluster that is contaminated by\na rich stellar field; it is also quite absorbed by the dusty foreground. We\nanalyzed ESO456-SC38 based on Hubble Space Telescope photometry, with the\nfilters F606W from ACS, F110W and F160W from WFC3,and photometry in V and I\nfrom FORS2 at the VLT. We combined this with identified stars that are covered\nby Gaia Data Release 2. The isochrone fitting was carried out with the\nstatistical Markov chain Monte Carlo method. We derive an accurate distance of\ndSun = 8.75+-0.12 kpc and a reddening of E(B-V)=0.81^+0.02_-0.02. The\nbest-fitting BaSTI isochrones correspond to an age of 12.70^{+0.72}_{-0.69} Gyr\nand a metallicity of [Fe/H]=-1.11^{+0.03}_{-0.03}. ESO 456-SC38 adds to the\nlist of moderately metal-poor globular clusters located in the inner bulge. It\nis on the blue horizontal branch and is very old. The cluster is confined to\nthe bulge and bar region, but it does not support the Galactic bar structure.\nThe old stellar population represented by clusters like this has to be taken\ninto account in models of Galactic bulge formation. Studying them also provides\nindications on the formation times of the globular clusters themselves. Ortolani_2019a Ortolani et al. 2019a https://arxiv.org/abs/1906.11863
511 1906.11696 2019-06-27 James Binney The shearing sheet and swing amplification revisited The principal results of the classic analysis of the shearing sheet and swing\namplification by Julian & Toomre (1966) are re-derived in a more accessible way\nand then used to gain a better quantitative understanding of the dynamics of\nstellar discs. The axisymmetric limit of the shearing sheet is derived and used\nto re-derive Kalnajs' 1965 dispersion relation and Toomre's 1964 stability\ncriterion for axisymmetric disturbances. Using the shearing sheet to revisit\nToomre's important 1969 paper on the group velocity implied by Lin-Shu-Kalnajs\ndispersion relation, we discover that two rather than one wavepackets emerges\ninside corotation: one each side of the inner Lindblad resonance. Although LSK\ndispersion relation provides useful interpretations of both wavepackets, the\nshearing sheet highlights the limitations of the LSK approach to disc dynamics.\nDisturbances by no means avoid an annulus around corotation, as the LSK\ndispersion relation implies. While disturbances of the shearing sheet have a\nlimited life in real space, they live on much longer in velocity space, which\nGaia allows us to probe extensively. C++ code is provided to facilitate\napplications of winding spiral waves. Binney_2019 Binney 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1906.11696
512 1906.09828 2019-06-24 D. Hatzidimitriou, E. V. Held, E. Tognelli, A. Bragaglia, L. Magrini, L. Bravi, K. Gazeas, A. Dapergolas, A. Drazdauskas, E. Delgado-Mena, E. D. Friel, R. Minkeviciute, R. Sordo, G. Tautvaisiene, G. Gilmore, S. Randich, S. Feltzing, A. Vallenari, E. J. Alfaro, E. Flaccomio, A. C. Lanzafame, E. Pancino, R. Smiljanic, A. Bayo, M. Bergemann, G. Carraro, A. R. Casey, M. T. Costado, F. Damiani, E. Franciosini, A. Gonneau, P. Jofre', J. Lewis, L. Monaco, L. Morbidelli, C. C. Worley, S. Zaggia The Gaia-ESO Survey: The inner disc, intermediate-age open cluster Pismis 18 Pismis 18 is a moderately populated, intermediate-age open cluster located\nwithin the solar circle at a Galactocentric distance of about 7 kpc. Few open\nclusters have been studied in detail in the inner disc region before the\nGaia-ESO Survey. New data from the Gaia-ESO Survey allowed us to conduct an\nextended radial velocity membership study as well as spectroscopic metallicity\nand detailed chemical abundance measurements for this cluster. Gaia-ESO Survey\ndata for 142 potential members, lying on the upper MS and on the red clump,\nyielded radial velocity measurements, which, together with proper motion\nmeasurements from the Gaia DR2, were used to determine the systemic velocity of\nthe cluster and membership of individual stars. Photometry from Gaia DR2 was\nused to re-determine cluster parameters based on high confidence member stars\nonly. Cluster abundance measurements of six radial-velocity member stars with\nUVES high-resolution spectroscopy are presented for 23 elements. According to\nthe new estimates, based on high confidence members, Pismis 18 has an age of\n$700^{+40}_{-50}$ Myr, interstellar reddening of E(B-V) =\n$0.562^{+0.012}_{-0.026}$ mag and a de-reddened distance modulus of $DM_0 =\n11.96^{+0.10}_{-0.24}$ mag. The median metallicity of the cluster (using the\nsix UVES stars) is [Fe/H] = $+0.23 \pm 0.05$ dex, with [$\alpha$/Fe]= $0.07 \pm\n0.13$ and a slight enhancement of s- and r- neutron-capture elements. With the\npresent work, we fully characterized the open cluster Pismis 18, confirming its\npresent location in the inner disc. We estimated a younger age than the\nprevious literature values and gave, for the first time, its metallicity and\nits detailed abundances. Its [$\alpha$/Fe] and [s-process/Fe], both slightly\nsuper-solar, are in agreement with other inner-disc open clusters observed by\nthe Gaia-ESO survey. [abridged] Hatzidimitriou_2019 Hatzidimitriou et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1906.09828
513 1902.00447 2019-06-19 Jeffrey D. Simpson The retrograde orbit of the globular cluster FSR1758 revealed with Gaia DR2 We report the first radial velocity measurements of the recently identified\nglobular cluster FSR1758. From the two member stars with radial velocities from\nthe Gaia Radial Velocity Spectrograph reported in Gaia DR2, we find FSR1758 has\na radial velocity of $227\pm1$ km/s. We also find potential extra-tidal star\nlost from the cluster in the surrounding 1~deg. Combined with Gaia proper\nmotions and photometric distance estimates, this shows that FSR1758 is on a\nvery retrograde, radial orbit with an pericentre of $3.8_{-0.9}^{+0.9}$ kpc, an\napocentre of $16_{-5}^{+8}$ kpc, and eccentricity of $0.62_{-0.04}^{+0.05}$.\nAlthough it is currently at a Galactocentric distance of $3.8_{-0.9}^{+0.9}$\nkpc --- at the edge of the bulge --- it is an intruder from the halo. We\ninvestigate whether a reported `halo' of stars around FSR1758 is related to the\ncluster, and find that most of these stars are likely foreground dwarf stars.\nWe conclude that FSR1758 is not a dwarf galaxy, but rather a globular cluster. Simpson_2019 Simpson 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1902.00447
514 1801.07136 2019-06-16 José G. Fernández-Trincado, O. Zamora, Diogo Souto, R. E. Cohen, F. Dell'Agli, D. A. García-Hernández, T. Masseron, R. P. Schiavon, Sz. Mészáros, K. Cunha, Sten Hasselquist, M. Shetrone, J. Schiappacasse Ulloa, B. Tang, D. Geisler, D. R. G. Schleicher, S. Villanova, R. E. Mennickent, D. Minniti, J. Alonso-Garcia, A. Manchado, T. C. Beers, J. Sobeck, G. Zasowski, M. Schultheis, S. R. Majewski, A. Rojas-Arriagada, A. Almeida, F. Santana, R. J. Oelkers, P. Longa-Peña, R. Carrera, A. J. Burgasser, R. R. Lane, A. Roman-Lopes, Inese I. Ivans, F. R. Hearty H-band discovery of additional Second-Generation stars in the Galactic Bulge Globular Cluster NGC 6522 as observed by APOGEE and Gaia We present elemental abundance analysis of high-resolution spectra for five\ngiant stars, deriving Fe, Mg, Al, C, N, O, Si and Ce abundances, and spatially\nlocated within the innermost regions of the bulge globular cluster NGC 6522,\nbased on H-band spectra taken with the multi-object APOGEE-north spectrograph\nfrom the SDSS-IV Apache Point Observatory Galactic Evolution Experiment\n(APOGEE) survey. Of the five cluster candidates, two previously unremarked\nstars are confirmed to have second-generation (SG) abundance patterns, with the\nbasic pattern of depletion in C and Mg simultaneous with enrichment in N and Al\nas seen in other SG globular cluster populations at similar metallicity. } In\nagreement with the most recent optical studies, the NGC 6522 stars analyzed\nexhibit (when available) only mild overabundances of the s-process element Ce,\ncontradicting the idea of the NGC 6522 stars being formed from gas enriched by\nspinstars and indicating that other stellar sources such as massive AGB stars\ncould be the primary intra-cluster medium polluters. The peculiar abundance\nsignature of SG stars have been observed in our data, confirming the presence\nof multiple generations of stars in NGC 6522. Fernández-Trincado_2019 Fernández-Trincado et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1801.07136
515 1807.04468 2019-06-13 O. Contigiani, E. M. Rossi, T. Marchetti On measuring the Galactic dark matter halo with hypervelocity stars Hypervelocity stars (HVSs) travel from the Galactic Centre across the dark\nmatter halo of the Milky Way, where they are observed with velocities in excess\nof the Galactic escape speed. Because of their quasi-radial trajectories, they\nrepresent a unique probe of the still poorly constrained dark matter component\nof the Galactic potential. In this paper, we present a new method to produce\nsuch constraints. Our likelihood is based on the local HVS density obtained by\nback-propagating the observed phase space position and quantifies the ejection\nprobability along the orbit. To showcase our method, we apply it to simulated\nGaia samples of $\sim200$ stars in three realistic Galactic potentials with\ndark matter components parametrized by spheroidal NFW profiles. We find that\nindividual HVSs exhibit a degeneracy in the scale mass-scale radius plane\n($M_s-r_s$) and are able to measure only the combination $\alpha = M_s/r_s^2$.\nLikewise, a degeneracy is also present between $\alpha$ and the spheroidal\naxis-ratio $q$. In the absence of observational errors, we show the whole\nsample can nail down both parameters with {\it sub-per cent} precision (about\n$1\%$ and $0.1\%$ for $\alpha$ and $q$ respectively) with no systematic bias.\nThis remarkable power to constrain deviations from a symmetric halo is a\nconsequence of the Galactocentric origin of HVSs. To compare our results with\nother probes, we break the degeneracy in the scale parameters and impose a\nmass-concentration relation. The result is a competitive precision on the\nvirial mass $M_{200}$ of about $10\%$. Contigiani_2019 Contigiani et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1807.04468
516 1811.04082 2019-06-11 G. Torrealba, V. Belokurov, S. E. Koposov, T. S. Li, M. G. Walker, J. L. Sanders, A. Geringer-Sameth, D. B. Zucker, K. Kuehn, N. W. Evans, W. Dehnen The hidden giant: discovery of an enormous Galactic dwarf satellite in Gaia DR2 We report the discovery of a Milky Way satellite in the constellation of\nAntlia. The Antlia 2 dwarf galaxy is located behind the Galactic disc at a\nlatitude of $b\sim 11^{\circ}$ and spans $1.26$ degrees, which corresponds to\n$\sim2.9$ kpc at its distance of 130 kpc. While similar in spatial extent to\nthe Large Magellanic Cloud, Antlia 2 is orders of magnitude fainter at $M_V=-9$\nmag, making it by far the lowest surface brightness system known (at $\sim31.9$\nmag/arcsec$^2$), $\sim100$ times more diffuse than the so-called ultra diffuse\ngalaxies. The satellite was identified using a combination of astrometry,\nphotometry and variability data from \textit{Gaia} Data Release 2, and its\nnature confirmed with deep archival DECam imaging, which revealed a conspicuous\nBHB signal. We have also obtained follow-up spectroscopy using AAOmega on the\nAAT, identifying 159 member stars, and we used them to measure the dwarf's\nsystemic velocity, $290.9\pm0.5$km/s, its velocity dispersion, $5.7\pm1.1$\nkm/s, and mean metallicity, [Fe/H]$=-1.4$. From these properties we conclude\nthat Antlia 2 inhabits one of the least dense Dark Matter (DM) halos probed to\ndate. Dynamical modelling and tidal-disruption simulations suggest that a\ncombination of a cored DM profile and strong tidal stripping may explain the\nobserved properties of this satellite. The origin of this core may be\nconsistent with aggressive feedback, or may even require alternatives to cold\ndark matter (such as ultra-light bosons). Torrealba_2019a Torrealba et al. 2019a https://arxiv.org/abs/1811.04082
517 1906.04373 2019-06-11 Chengqun Yang, Xiang-Xiang Xue, Jing Li, Lan Zhang, Chao Liu, Gang Zhao, Jiang Chang, Hao Tian, Chengdong Li Identifying Galactic Halo Substructure in 6D Phase-space Using $\sim$13,000 LAMOST K Giants We construct a large halo K-giant sample by combining the positions,\ndistances, radial velocities, and metallicities of over 13,000 LAMOST DR5 halo\nK giants with the Gaia DR2 proper motions, which covers a Galactocentric\ndistance range of 5-120 kpc. Using a position-velocity clustering estimator\n(the 6Distance), we statistically quantify the presence of position-velocity\nsubstructure at high significance: K giants have more close pairs in\nposition-velocity space than a smooth stellar halo. We find that the amount of\nsubstructure in the halo increases with increasing distance and metallicity.\nWith a percolation algorithm named friends-of-friends (FoF) to identify groups,\nwe identify members belonging to Sagittarius (Sgr) Streams, Monoceros Ring,\nVirgo overdensity, Hercules-Aquila Cloud, Orphan Streams and other unknown\nsubstructures and find that the Sgr streams account for a large part of grouped\nstars beyond 20 kpc and enhance the increase of substructure with distance and\nmetallicity. For the first time, we identify spectroscopic members of Monoceros\nRing in the south and north Galactic hemisphere, which presents a rotation of\nabout 185 km s^{-1} and mean metallicity is -0.66 dex. Yang_2019 Yang et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1906.04373
518 1904.03185 2019-06-10 G. C. Myeong, E. Vasiliev, G. Iorio, N. W. Evans, V. Belokurov Evidence for Two Early Accretion Events That Built the Milky Way Stellar Halo The Gaia Sausage is the major accretion event that built the stellar halo of\nthe Milky Way galaxy. Here, we provide dynamical and chemical evidence for a\nsecond substantial accretion episode, distinct from the Gaia Sausage. The\nSequoia Event provided the bulk of the high energy retrograde stars in the\nstellar halo, as well as the recently discovered globular cluster FSR 1758.\nThere are up to 6 further globular clusters, including $\omega$~Centauri, as\nwell as many of the retrograde substructures in Myeong et al. (2018),\nassociated with the progenitor dwarf galaxy, named the Sequoia. The stellar\nmass in the Sequoia galaxy is $\sim 5 \times 10^{7} M_\odot$, whilst the total\nmass is $\sim 10^{10} M_\odot$, as judged from abundance matching or from the\ntotal sum of the globular cluster mass. Although clearly less massive than the\nSausage, the Sequoia has a distinct chemo-dynamical signature. The strongly\nretrograde Sequoia stars have a typical eccentricity of $\sim0.6$, whereas the\nSausage stars have no clear net rotation and move on predominantly radial\norbits. On average, the Sequoia stars have lower metallicity by $\sim 0.3$ dex\nand higher abundance ratios as compared to the Sausage. We conjecture that the\nSausage and the Sequoia galaxies may have been associated and accreted at a\ncomparable epoch. Myeong_2019 Myeong et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1904.03185
519 1906.03875 2019-06-10 Yepeng Yan, Cuihua Du, Shuai Liu, Hefan Li, Jianrong Shi, Yuqin Chen, Jun Ma, Zhenyu Wu Chemical and Kinematic Properties of the Galactic Disk from the LAMOST and Gaia Sample Stars We determined the chemical and kinematic properties of the Galactic thin and\nthick disk using a sample of 307,246 A/F/G/K-type giant stars from the LAMOST\nspectroscopic survey and Gaia DR2 survey. Our study found that the thick disk\nglobally exhibits no metallicity radial gradient, but the inner disk ($R \le 8$\nkpc) and the outer disk ($R>8$ kpc) have different gradients when they are\nstudied separately. The thin disk also shows two different metallicity radial\ngradients for the inner disk and the outer disk, and has steep metallicity\nvertical gradient of d[Fe/H]/d$|z|$ $=-0.12\pm0.0007$ dex kpc$^{-1}$, but it\nbecomes flat when it is measured at increasing radial distance, while the\nmetallicity radial gradient becomes weaker with increasing vertical distance.\nAdopting a galaxy potential model, we derived the orbital eccentricity of\nsample stars and found a downtrend of average eccentricity with increasing\nmetallicity for the thick disk. The variation of the rotation velocity with the\nmetallicity shows a positive gradient for the thick disk stars and a negative\none for the thin disk stars. Comparisons of our observed results with models of\ndisk formation suggest that radial migration could have influenced the chemical\nevolution of the thin disk. The formation of the thick disk could be affected\nby more than one processes: the accretion model could play an indispensable\nrole, while other formation mechanisms, such as the radial migration or heating\nscenario model could also have a contribution. Yan_2019 Yan et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1906.03875
520 1903.00607 2019-06-10 Tim Haines, Elena D'Onghia, Benoit Famaey, Chervin Laporte, Lars Hernquist Implications of a time-varying Galactic potential for determinations of the dynamical surface density Recent studies have shown that the passage of a massive satellite through the\ndisk of a spiral galaxy can induce vertical wobbles in the disk and produce\nfeatures such as in-plane rings and phase-space spirals. Here we analyze a\nhigh-resolution N-body simulation of a live stellar disk perturbed by the\nrecent passage of a massive dwarf galaxy that induces such perturbations. We\nstudy the implications of the phase-space structures for the estimate of the\nmatter density through traditional Jeans modelling. The dwarf satellite excites\nrapid time-variations in the potential, leading to a significant bias of the\nlocal matter surface density determined through such a method. In particular,\nwhile the Jeans modelling gives reasonable estimates in the most overdense\nregions of the disk, we show that it tends to overestimate the dynamical\nsurface density in underdense regions. In these regions, the phase-space spiral\nis indeed more marked in the surface of section of height vs. vertical\nvelocity. This prediction can be verified with future Gaia data releases. Our\nfinding is highly relevant for future attempts at determining the dynamical\nsurface density of the outer Milky Way disk as a function of radius. The outer\ndisk of the Milky Way is indeed heavily perturbed, and \textit{Gaia} DR2 data\nhave clearly shown that such phase-space perturbations are even present\nlocally. While our results show that traditional Jeans modelling should give\nreliable results in overdense regions of the disk, the important biases in\nunderdense regions call for the development of non-equilibrium methods to\nestimate the dynamical matter density locally and in the outer disk. Haines_2019 Haines et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1903.00607
521 1810.04445 2019-06-08 Mariateresa Crosta, Marco Giammaria, Mario G. Lattanzi, Eloisa Poggio Testing dark matter and geometry sustained circular velocities in the Milky Way with Gaia DR2 Flat rotation curves in disk galaxies represent the main evidence for large\namounts of surrounding dark matter. Despite of the difficulty in identifying\nthe dark matter contribution to the total mass density in our Galaxy, stellar\nkinematics, as tracer of gravitational potential, is the most reliable\nobservable for gauging different matter components. This work tests the\nflatness of the MW rotation curve with a simple general relativistic model\nsuitable to represent the geometry of a disk as a stationary axisymmetric dust\nmetric at a sufficiently large distance from a central body. Circular\nvelocities of unprecedented accuracy were derived from the Gaia DR2 data for a\ncarefully selected sample of disk stars. We then fit these velocities to both\nthe classical, i.e. including a dark matter halo, rotation curve model and a\nrelativistic analogue, as derived form the solution of Einstein's equation. The\nGR-compliant MW rotational curve model results statistically indistinguishable\nfrom its state-of-the-art DM analogue. This supports our ansatz that a\nstationary and axisymmetric galaxy-scale metric could "fill the gap" in a\nbaryons-only Milky Way, suggestive of star orbits dragged along the background\ngeometry. We confirmed that geometry is a manifestation of gravity according to\nthe Einstein theory, in particular the weak gravitational effect due to the\noff-diagonal term of the metric could mimic for a "DM-like" effect in the\nobserved flatness of the MW rotation curve. In the context of Local Cosmology,\nour findings are suggestive of a Galaxy phase-space as the exterior\ngravitational field of a Kerr-like source (inner rotating bulge) without the\nneed of extra-matter. Crosta_2019 Crosta et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1810.04445
522 1812.07576 2019-06-07 M. Romero-Gómez, C. Mateu, L. Aguilar, F. Figueras, A. Castro-Ginard Gaia kinematics reveal a complex lopsided and twisted Galactic disc warp There are few warp kinematic models of the Galaxy able to characterise\nstructure and kinematics. These models are necessary to study the lopsidedness\nof the warp and the twisting of the line-of-nodes of the stellar warp, already\nseen in gas and dust. We use the \Gaia~Data Release 2 astrometric data up to\n$G=20$mag to characterise the structure of the Galactic warp, the vertical\nmotions and the dependency on the age. We use two populations up to\ngalactocentric distances of $16$kpc, a young (OB-type) and an old (Red Giant\nBranch, RGB). We use the nGC3 PCM and LonKin methods based on the Gaia\nobservables, together with 2D projections of the positions and proper motions\nin the Galactic plane. We confirm the age dependency of the Galactic warp, both\nin positions and kinematics, being the height of the Galactic warp of about\n$0.2$kpc for the OB sample and of $1.$kpc for the RGB at a galactocentric\ndistance of $14$kpc. Both methods find that the onset radius is $12\sim 13$kpc\nfor the OB sample and $10\sim 11$kpc for the RGB. From the RGB sample, we find\nfrom galactocentric distances larger than $10$kpc the line-of-nodes twists away\nfrom the Sun-anticentre line towards galactic azimuths $\sim 180-200^{\circ}$\nincreasing with radius, though possibly influenced by extinction. The RGB\nsample reveals a slightly lopsided stellar warp with $\sim 250$pc between the\nup and down sides. The line of maximum of proper motions in latitude is\nsystematically offset from the line-of-nodes estimated from the spatial data,\nwhich our models predict as a kinematic signature of lopsidedness. We also show\na prominent wave-like pattern of a bending mode different in the OB and RGB,\nand substructures that might not be related to the Galactic warp nor to a\nbending mode. GDR2 triggers the need for complex kinematic models, flexible\nenough to combine both wave-like patterns and an S-shaped lopsided\nwarp.[abridged] Romero-Gómez_2019 Romero-Gómez et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1812.07576
523 1902.05061 2019-06-07 R. Raddi, M. A. Hollands, D. Koester, J. J. Hermes, B. T. Gaensicke, U. Heber, K. J. Shen, D. M. Townsley, A. F. Pala, J. S. Reding, O. F. Toloza, I. Pelisoli, S. Geier, N. P. Gentile Fusillo, U. Munari, J. Strader Partly burnt runaway stellar remnants from peculiar thermonuclear supernovae We report the discovery of three stars that, along with the prototype\nLP40-365, form a distinct class of chemically peculiar runaway stars that are\nthe survivors of thermonuclear explosions. Spectroscopy of the four confirmed\nLP 40-365 stars finds ONe-dominated atmospheres enriched with remarkably\nsimilar amounts of nuclear ashes of partial O- and Si-burning. Kinematic\nevidence is consistent with ejection from a binary supernova progenitor; at\nleast two stars have rest-frame velocities indicating they are unbound to the\nGalaxy. With masses and radii ranging between 0.20-0.28 Msun and 0.16-0.60\nRsun, respectively, we speculate these inflated white dwarfs are the partly\nburnt remnants of either peculiar Type Iax or electron-capture supernovae.\nAdopting supernova rates from the literature, we estimate that ~20 LP40-365\nstars brighter than 19 mag should be detectable within 2 kpc from the Sun at\nthe end of the Gaia mission. We suggest that as they cool, these stars will\nevolve in their spectroscopic appearance, and eventually become peculiar O-rich\nwhite dwarfs. Finally, we stress that the discovery of new LP40-365 stars will\nbe useful to further constrain their evolution, supplying key boundary\nconditions to the modelling of explosion mechanisms, supernova rates, and\nnucleosynthetic yields of peculiar thermonuclear explosions. Raddi_2019 Raddi et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1902.05061
524 1906.02748 2019-06-06 Ana Bonaca, Charlie Conroy, Adrian M. Price-Whelan, David W. Hogg Multiple components of the Jhelum stellar stream In simple models of the Milky Way, tidally disrupting satellites produce long\nand thin---nearly one-dimensional---stellar streams. Using astrometric data\nfrom the Gaia second data release and photometry from the Dark Energy Survey,\nwe demonstrate that the Jhelum stream, a stellar stream in the inner halo, is a\ntwo-dimensional structure. The spatial distribution of highly probable Jhelum\nmembers reveals a dense thin component and an associated diffuse, spatially\noffset component. These two spatial components have indistinguishable proper\nmotions (at $\sigma\sim1\,\rm mas\,yr^{-1}$ level) and a similar ratio of blue\nstraggler to blue horizontal branch stars, which indicates a common origin for\nthe two components. The best-fit orbit to the narrow component (pericenter\n$8\,\rm kpc$, apocenter $24\,\rm kpc$), however, does not explain the wide\ncomponent of the Jhelum stream. On the other hand, an older orbital wrap of\nJhelum's orbit traces the Indus stream, indicating a possible connection\nbetween these two structures and additional complexity in Jhelum's formation.\nSubstructure in the Jhelum progenitor or precession of its tidal debris in the\nMilky Way potential may explain the observed structure of Jhelum. Future\nspectroscopic data will enable discrimination between these "nature" and\n"nurture" formation scenarios. Jhelum adds to the growing list of cold stellar\nstreams that display complex morphologies and promise to reveal the dynamical\nhistory of the Milky Way. Bonaca_2019 Bonaca et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1906.02748
525 1906.01244 2019-06-04 Deokkeun An Asymmetric Mean Metallicity Distribution of the Milky Way's Disk I present the mean metallicity distribution of stars in the Milky Way Galaxy\nbased on photometry from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey. I utilize an empirically\ncalibrated set of stellar isochrones developed in previous work to estimate the\nmetallicities of individual stars to a precision of $0.2$ dex for reasonably\nbright stars across the survey area. I also obtain more precise metallicity\nestimates using priors from the $Gaia$ parallaxes for relatively nearby stars.\nClose to the Galactic mid-plane ($|Z|<2$ kpc), a mean metallicity map reveals\ndeviations from the mirror symmetry between the northern and southern\nhemispheres, displaying wave-like oscillations. The observed metallicity\nasymmetry structure is almost parallel to the Galactic mid-plane, and coincides\nwith the previously known asymmetry in the stellar number density distribution.\nThis result reinforces the previous notion of the plane-parallel vertical waves\npropagating through the disk, in which a local metallicity perturbation from\nthe mean vertical metallicity gradient is induced by the phase-space wrapping\nof stars in the $Z$-$V_Z$ plane. The maximum amplitude of the metallicity\nasymmetry ($\Delta$[Fe/H]$\sim0.05$) implies that these stars have been pulled\naway from the Galactic mid-plane by an order of $\Delta|Z|\sim80$ pc as a\nmassive halo substructure such as the Sagittarius dwarf galaxy plunged through\nthe Milky Way. This work provides evidence that the $Gaia$ phase-space spiral\nmay continue out to $|Z|\sim1.5$ kpc. An_2019 An 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1906.01244
526 1905.13592 2019-05-31 M. Lopez-Corredoira, Y. -W. Lee, F. Garzon, D. Lim Distribution of red clump stars does not support the X-shaped Galactic bulge CONTEXT. Claims of an X-shaped Galactic bulge were based on the assumption of\nred clump stars as standard candles in some lines of sight crossing the\noff-plane bulge. However, some doubts have been cast on whether the two peaks\nin star counts along the line of sight really represent a double peak in the\ndensity distribution, or whether there is something wrong with the assumption\nof a unique constant absolute magnitude for all of these stars.\n AIMS. With the advent of Gaia-DR2 parallaxes in combination with\nnear-infrared VISTA-VVV data, we are able to check which of the hypotheses is\ncorrect.\n METHODS. We calculated the median absolute magnitude $M_K$ corresponding to\nboth peaks of putative red clumps in seven lines of sight with the lowest\nextinction in the interesting coordinates' range.\n RESULTS. The difference between the absolute magnitude of the bright and the\nfaint peak is $\Delta M_K\approx 0.4$. The selected stars in both peaks cannot\nbe represented by the same red clump giants with constant $M_K\approx -1.6$.\n CONCLUSIONS. The hypothesis that the bulge contains an X-shape is based on\nthe assumption that the faint and bright peaks of the density distribution\ntowards the bulge are dominated by standard red clump stars. However, we show\nthat both the faint and bright peaks cannot be dominated by standard red clump\nstars simultaneously. Lopez-Corredoira_2019 Lopez-Corredoira et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.13592
527 1811.12413 2019-05-30 Tyler Kelley, James S. Bullock, Shea Garrison-Kimmel, Michael Boylan-Kolchin, Marcel S. Pawlowski, Andrew S. Graus Phat ELVIS: The inevitable effect of the Milky Way's disk on its dark matter subhaloes We introduce an extension of the ELVIS project to account for the effects of\nthe Milky Way galaxy on its subhalo population. Our simulation suite, Phat\nELVIS, consists of twelve high-resolution cosmological dark matter-only (DMO)\nzoom simulations of Milky Way-size $\Lambda$CDM~ haloes ($M_{\rm v} = 0.7-2\n\times 10^{12} \,\mathrm{M}_\odot$) along with twelve re-runs with embedded\ngalaxy potentials grown to match the observed Milky Way disk and bulge today.\nThe central galaxy potential destroys subhalos on orbits with small pericenters\nin every halo, regardless of the ratio of galaxy mass to halo mass. This has\nseveral important implications. 1) Most of the $\mathtt{Disk}$ runs have no\nsubhaloes larger than $V_{\rm max} = 4.5$ km s$^{-1}$ within $20$ kpc and a\nsignificant lack of substructure going back $\sim 8$ Gyr, suggesting that local\nstream-heating signals from dark substructure will be rare. 2) The pericenter\ndistributions of Milky Way satellites derived from $\mathit{Gaia}$ data are\nremarkably similar to the pericenter distributions of subhaloes in the\n$\mathtt{Disk}$ runs, while the DMO runs drastically over-predict galaxies with\npericenters smaller than 20 kpc. 3) The enhanced destruction produces a tension\nopposite to that of the classic `missing satellites' problem: in order to\naccount for ultra-faint galaxies known within $30$ kpc of the Galaxy, we must\npopulate haloes with $V_\mathrm{peak} \simeq 7$ km s$^{-1}$ ($M \simeq 3 \times\n10^{7} \,\mathrm{M}_\odot$ at infall), well below the atomic cooling limit of\n$V_\mathrm{peak} \simeq 16$ km s$^{-1}$ ($M \simeq 5 \times 10^{8}\n\,\mathrm{M}_\odot$ at infall). 4) If such tiny haloes do host ultra-faint\ndwarfs, this implies the existence of $\sim 1000$ satellite galaxies within 300\nkpc of the Milky Way. Kelley_2019 Kelley et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1811.12413
528 1901.04502 2019-05-30 J. Ted Mackereth, Jo Bovy, Henry W. Leung, Ricardo P. Schiavon, Wilma H. Trick, William J. Chaplin, Katia Cunha, Diane K. Feuillet, Steven R. Majewski, Marie Martig, Andrea Miglio, David Nidever, Marc H. Pinsonneault, Victor Silva Aguirre, Jennifer Sobeck, Jamie Tayar, Gail Zasowski Dynamical heating across the Milky Way disc using APOGEE and $\it{Gaia}$ The kinematics of the Milky Way disc as a function of age are well measured\nat the solar radius, but have not been studied over a wider range of\nGalactocentric radii. Here, we measure the kinematics of mono-age,\nmono-$\mathrm{[Fe/H]}$ populations in the low and high $\mathrm{[\alpha/Fe]}$\ndiscs between $4 \lesssim R \lesssim 13$ kpc and $|z| \lesssim 2$ kpc using\n65,719 stars in common between APOGEE DR14 and $\it{Gaia}$ DR2 for which we\nestimate ages using a Bayesian neural network model trained on asteroseismic\nages. We determine the vertical and radial velocity dispersions, finding that\nthe low and high $\mathrm{[\alpha/Fe]}$ discs display markedly different\nage--velocity-dispersion relations (AVRs) and shapes $\sigma_z/\sigma_R$. The\nhigh $\mathrm{[\alpha/Fe]}$ disc has roughly flat AVRs and constant\n$\sigma_z/\sigma_R = 0.64\pm 0.04$, whereas the low $\mathrm{[\alpha/Fe]}$ disc\nhas large variations in this ratio which positively correlate with the mean\norbital radius of the population at fixed age. The high $\mathrm{[\alpha/Fe]}$\ndisc component's flat AVRs and constant $\sigma_z/\sigma_R$ clearly indicates\nan entirely different heating history. Outer disc populations also have flatter\nradial AVRs than those in the inner disc, likely due to the waning effect of\nspiral arms. Our detailed measurements of AVRs and $\sigma_z/\sigma_R$ across\nthe disc indicate that low $\mathrm{[\alpha/Fe]}$, inner disc ($R \lesssim\n10\,\mathrm{kpc}$) stellar populations are likely dynamically heated by both\ngiant molecular clouds and spiral arms, while the observed trends for outer\ndisc populations require a significant contribution from another heating\nmechanism such as satellite perturbations. We also find that outer disc\npopulations have slightly positive mean vertical and radial velocities, likely\nbecause they are part of the warped disc. Mackereth_2019 Mackereth et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1901.04502
529 1902.02355 2019-05-29 Ralph Schönrich, Paul McMillan, Laurent Eyer Distances and parallax bias in Gaia DR2 We derive Bayesian distances for all stars in the RV sample of Gaia DR2, and\nuse the statistical method of Schoenrich, Binney & Asplund(2012) to validate\nthe distances and test the Gaia parallaxes. In contrast to other methods, which\nrely on special sources, our method directly tests the distances to all stars\nin our sample. We find clear evidence for a near-linear trend of distance bias\nf with distance s, proving a parallax offset delta p. On average, we find delta\np = -0.054 mas (parallaxes in Gaia DR2 need to be increased) when accounting\nfor the parallax uncertainty under-estimate in the Gaia set (delta p = -0.048\nmas on the raw parallax errors) with negligible formal error and a systematic\nuncertainty of about 0.006 mas. The value is in concordance with results from\nasteroseismic measurements, but differs from the much lower bias found on\nquasar samples. We further use our method to compile a comprehensive set of\nquality cuts in colour, apparent magnitude, and astrometric parameters.
