Last,\nwe find that for this sample delta p appears to strongly depend on the parallax\nuncertainty sigma_p (when including the additional 0.043 mas) with a\nstatistical confidence far in excess of 10\sigma and a proportionality factor\nclose to 1, though the dependence varies somewhat with sigma_p. Correcting for\nthe sigma_p dependence also resolves otherwise unexplained correlations of the\noffset with the number of observation periods n_{vis} and ecliptic latitude.\nEvery study using Gaia DR2 parallaxes/distances should investigate the\nsensitivity of their results on the parallax biases described here and - for\nfainter samples - in the DR2 astrometry paper. Schönrich_2019 Schönrich et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1902.02355
530 1905.12633 2019-05-29 James M. M. Lane, Julio F. Navarro, Azadeh Fattahi, Kyle A. Oman, Jo Bovy The Ophiuchus stream progenitor: a new type of globular cluster and its possible Sagittarius connection The Ophiuchus stream is a short arc-like stellar feature of uncertain origin\nlocated $\sim 5$ kpc North of the Galactic centre. New proper motions from the\nsecond $Gaia$ data release reconcile the direction of motion of stream members\nwith the stream arc, resolving a puzzling mismatch reported in earlier work. We\nuse N-body simulations to show that the stream is likely only on its second\npericentric passage, and thus was formed recently. The simulations suggest that\nthe entire disrupted progenitor is visible in the observed stream today, and\nthat little further tidal debris lies beyond the ends of the stream. The\nluminosity, length, width, and velocity dispersion of the stream suggest a\nglobular cluster (GC) progenitor substantially fainter and of lower surface\nbrightness than estimated in previous work, and unlike any other known\nglobulars in the Galaxy. This result suggests the existence of clusters that\nwould extend the known GC population to fainter and more weakly bound systems\nthan hitherto known. How such a weakly-bound cluster of old stars survived\nuntil it was disrupted so recently, however, remains a mystery. Integrating\nbackwards in time, we find that the orbits of Sagittarius and Ophiuchus passed\nwithin $\sim 5$ kpc of each other about $\sim 100$ Myrs ago, an interaction\nthat might help resolve this puzzle. Lane_2019 Lane et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.12633
531 1905.11835 2019-05-27 Tali Palma, Dante Minniti, Javier Alonso-García, Juliana Crestani, Henryka Netzel, Juan J. Clariá, Roberto K. Saito, Bruno Dias, José G. Fernández-Trincado, Roberto Kammers, Douglas Geisler, Matías Gómez, Maren Hempel, Joyce Pullen Analysis of the physical nature of 22 New VVV Survey Globular Cluster candidates in the Milky Way Bulge In order to characterize 22 new globular cluster (GC) candidates in the\nGalactic bulge, we present their colour-magnitude diagrams (CMDs) and Ks-band\nluminosity functions (LFs) using the near-infrared VVV database as well as\nGaia-DR2 proper motion dataset. CMDs were obtained, on one hand, after properly\ndecontaminating the observed diagrams from background/foreground disc stars and\nother sources. On the other hand, CMDs were also obtained based upon star\nselection in proper motion diagrams. Taking into account our deep CMDs and LFs\nanalyses, we find that 17 out of 22 new GC candidates may be real and should\ntherefore be followed-up, while 5 candidates were discarded from the original\nsample. We also search for RR Lyrae and Mira variable stars in the fields of\nthese new GC candidates. In particular, we confirm that Minni 40 may be a real\ncluster. If confirmed by further follow-up analysis, it would be the closest GC\nto the Galactic centre in projected angular distance, located only 0.5 deg away\nfrom it. We consider that it is very difficult to confirm the physical reality\nof these small, poorly-populated bulge GCs so in many cases alternative\ntechniques are needed to corroborate our findings. Palma_2019 Palma et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.11835
532 1905.10779 2019-05-26 Jordi Isern The star formation history in the solar neighborhood as told by massive white dwarfs White dwarfs are the remnants of low and intermediate mass stars. Because of\nelectron degeneracy, their evolution is just a simple gravothermal process of\ncooling. Recently, thanks to Gaia data, it has been possible to construct the\nluminosity function of massive (0.9 < M/Msun < 1.1) white dwarfs in the solar\nneighborhood (d < 100 pc). Since the lifetime of their progenitors is very\nshort, the birth times of both, parents and daughters, are very close and allow\nto reconstruct the (effective) star formation rate. This rate started growing\nfrom zero during the early Galaxy and reached a maximum 6-7 Gyr ago. It\ndeclined and ~5 Gyr ago started to climb once more reaching a maximum 2 - 3 Gyr\nin the past and decreased since then. There are some traces of a recent star\nformation burst, but the method used here is not appropriate for recently born\nwhite dwarfs. Isern_2019 Isern 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.10779
533 1810.12354 2019-05-23 Alexander Rasskazov, Giacomo Fragione, Nathan W. C. Leigh, Hiromichi Tagawa, Alberto Sesana, Adrian Price-Whelan, Elena Maria Rossi Hypervelocity Stars from a Supermassive Black Hole-Intermediate-mass Black Hole binary In this paper we consider a scenario where the currently observed\nhypervelocity stars in our Galaxy have been ejected from the Galactic center as\na result of dynamical interactions with an intermediate-mass black hole (IMBH)\norbiting the central supermassive black hole (SMBH). By performing 3-body\nscattering experiments, we calculate the distribution of the ejected stars'\nvelocities given various parameters of the IMBH-SMBH binary: IMBH mass,\nsemimajor axis and eccentricity. We also calculate the rates of change of the\nBH binary orbital elements due to those stellar ejections. One of our new\nfindings is that the ejection rate depends (although mildly) on the rotation of\nthe stellar nucleus (its total angular momentum). We also compare the ejection\nvelocity distribution with that produced by the Hills mechanism (stellar binary\ndisruption) and find that the latter produces faster stars on average. Also,\nthe IMBH mechanism produces an ejection velocity distribution which is\nflattened towards the BH binary plane while the Hills mechanism produces a\nspherically symmetric one. The results of this paper will allow us in the\nfuture to model the ejection of stars by an evolving BH binary and compare both\nmodels with \textit{Gaia} observations, for a wide variety of environments\n(galactic nuclei, globular clusters, the Large Magellanic Clouds, etc.). Rasskazov_2019 Rasskazov et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1810.12354
534 1905.08593 2019-05-21 Felipe Navarete, Phillip A. B. Galli, Augusto Damineli Gaia-DR2 distance to the W3 Complex in the Perseus Arm The Perseus Arm is the closest Galactic spiral arm from the Sun, offering an\nexcellent opportunity to study in detail its stellar population. However, its\ndistance has been controversial with discrepancies by a factor of two.\nKinematic distances are in the range 3.9-4.2 kpc as compared to 1.9-2.3 kpc\nfrom spectrophotometric and trigonometric parallaxes, reinforcing previous\nclaims that this arm exhibits peculiar velocities. We used the astrometric\ninformation of a sample of 31 OB stars from the star-forming W3 Complex to\nidentify another 37 W3 members and to derive its distance from their Gaia-DR2\nparallaxes with improved accuracy. The Gaia-DR2 distance to the W3\nComplex,2.14$^{+0.08}_{-0.07}$ kpc, coincides with the previous stellar\ndistances of $\sim$ 2 kpc. The Gaia-DR2 parallaxes tentatively show\ndifferential distances for different parts of the W3 Complex: W3 Main, located\nto the NE direction, is at 2.30$^{+0.19}_{-0.16}$ kpc, the W3 Cluster (IC\n1795), in the central region of the complex, is at 2.17$^{+0.12}_{-0.11}$ kpc,\nand W3(OH) is at 2.00$^{+0.29}_{-0.23}$ kpc to the SW direction. The W3 Cluster\nis the oldest region, indicating that it triggered the formation of the other\ntwo star-forming regions located at the edges of an expanding shell around the\ncluster. Navarete_2019 Navarete et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.08593
535 1905.08133 2019-05-20 Wilton S. Dias, Hektor Monteiro, Jacques R. D. Lépine, Douglas A. Barros The spiral pattern rotation speed of the Galaxy and the corotation radius with GAIA DR2 In this work we revisit the issue of the rotation speed of the spiral arms\nand the location of the corotation radius of our Galaxy. This research was\nperformed using homogeneous data set of young open clusters (age < 50 Myr)\ndetermined from Gaia DR2 data. The stellar astrometric membership were\ndetermined using proper motions and parallaxes, taking into account the full\ncovariance matrix. The distance, age, reddening and metallicity of the clusters\nwere determined by our non subjective multidimensional global optimization tool\nto fit theoretical isochrones to Gaia DR2 photometric data. The rotation speed\nof the arms is obtained from the relation between age and angular distance of\nthe birthplace of the clusters to the present-day position of the arms. Using\nthe clusters belonging to the Sagittarius-Carina, Local and Perseus arms, and\nadopting the Galactic parameters $R_0$ = 8.3 kpc and $V_0$ = 240 km\,s$^{-1}$,\nwe determine a pattern speed of $28.2 \pm 2.1$ km\,s$^{-1}$\,kpc$^{-1}$, with\nno difference between the arms. This implies that the corotation radius is $R_c\n= 8.51 \pm 0.64$ kpc, close to the solar Galactic orbit ($R_c/R_0 =\n1.02\pm0.07$). Dias_2019 Dias et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.08133
536 1905.07879 2019-05-20 Bum-Suk Yeom, Young Sun Lee, Jae-Rim Koo, Timothy C. Beers, Young Kwang Kim Origin and Status of Low-Mass Candidate Hypervelocity Stars We present an analysis of the chemical abundances and kinematics of six\nlow-mass dwarf stars, previously claimed to be candidate hypervelocity stars\n(HVSs). We obtained moderate-resolution ($R\sim$ 6000) spectra of these stars\nto estimate their abundances of several chemical elements (Mg, Si, Ca, Ti, Cr,\nFe, and Ni), and derived their space velocity components and orbital parameters\nusing proper motions from \gaia\ Data Release 2. All six stars are shown to be\nbound to the Milky Way, and in fact are not even considered high-velocity stars\nwith respect to the Galactic rest frame. Nevertheless, we attempt to\ncharacterize their parent Galactic stellar components by simultaneously\ncomparing their abundance patterns and orbital parameters with those expected\nfrom various Galactic stellar components. We find that two of our program stars\nare typical disk stars. For four of the program stars, even though their\nkinematic probabilistic membership assignment suggests membership in the\nGalactic disk, based on their distinct orbital properties and chemical\ncharacteristics, we cannot rule out the exotic origins of these objects, as\nfollows. Two stars appear to be runaway stars from the Galactic disk. One\nprogram star has possibly been accreted from a disrupted dwarf galaxy or\ndynamically heated from a birthplace in the Galactic bulge. The last object may\nbe either a runaway disk star or has been dynamically heated. Spectroscopic\nfollow-up observations with higher resolution for these curious objects will\nprovide a better understanding of their origin. Yeom_2019 Yeom et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.07879
537 1812.06318 2019-05-17 S. Mau, A. Drlica-Wagner, K. Bechtol, A. B. Pace, T. Li, M. Soares-Santos, N. Kuropatkin, S. Allam, D. Tucker, L. Santana-Silva, B. Yanny, P. Jethwa, A. Palmese, K. Chen A faint halo star cluster discovered in the Blanco Imaging of the Southern Sky Survey We present the discovery of a faint, resolved stellar system, BLISS\nJ0321+0438 (BLISS 1), found in Dark Energy Camera data from the first observing\nrun of the Blanco Imaging of the Southern Sky (BLISS) Survey. 538 1812.08192 2019-05-14 D. Erkal, V. Belokurov, C. F. P. Laporte, S. E. Koposov, T. S. Li, C. J. Grillmair, N. Kallivayalil, A. M. Price-Whelan, N. W. Evans, K. Hawkins, D. Hendel, C. Mateu, J. F. Navarro, A. del Pino, C. T. Slater, S. T. Sohn The total mass of the Large Magellanic Cloud from its perturbation on the Orphan stream In a companion paper by Koposov et al., RR Lyrae from \textit{Gaia} Data\nRelease 2 are used to demonstrate that stars in the Orphan stream have velocity\nvectors significantly misaligned with the stream track, suggesting that it has\nreceived a large gravitational perturbation from a satellite of the Milky Way.\nWe argue that such a mismatch cannot arise due to any realistic static Milky\nWay potential and then explore the perturbative effects of the Large Magellanic\nCloud (LMC). We find that the LMC can produce precisely the observed\nmotion-track mismatch and we therefore use the Orphan stream to measure the\nmass of the Cloud. We simultaneously fit the Milky Way and LMC potentials and\ninfer that a total LMC mass of $1.38^{+0.27}_{-0.24}\n\times10^{11}\,\rm{M_\odot}$ is required to bend the Orphan Stream, showing for\nthe first time that the LMC has a large and measurable effect on structures\norbiting the Milky Way. This has far-reaching consequences for any technique\nwhich assumes that tracers are orbiting a static Milky Way. Furthermore, we\nmeasure the Milky Way mass within 50 kpc to be\n$3.80^{+0.14}_{-0.11}\times10^{11} M_\odot$. Finally, we use these results to\npredict that, due to the reflex motion of the Milky Way in response to the LMC,\nthe outskirts of the Milky Way's stellar halo should exhibit a bulk, upwards\nmotion. Erkal_2019 Erkal et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1812.08192
539 1905.05542 2019-05-14 Chen Bingqiu, Huang Yang, Hou Ligang, Tian Hao, Li Guangxing, Yuan Haibo, Wang Haifeng, Wang Chun, Tian Zhijia, Liu Xiaowei The Galactic spiral structure as revealed by O- and early B-type stars We investigate the morphology and kinematics of the Galactic spiral structure\nbased on a new sample of O- and early B-type stars. We select 6,858 highly\nconfident OB star candidates from the combined data of the VST Photometric\nH$\alpha$ Survey Data Release 2 (VPHAS+ DR2) and the Gaia Data Release 2 (Gaia\nDR2). Together with the O-B2 stars from the literature, we build a sample\nconsisting of 14,880 O- and early B-type stars, all with Gaia parallax\nuncertainties smaller than 20 per cent. The new sample, hitherto the largest\none of O- and early B-type stars with robust distance and proper motion\nestimates, covers the Galactic plane of distances up to $\sim$ 6 kpc from the\nSun. The sample allows us to examine the morphology of the Scutum, Sagittarius,\nLocal and Perseus Arms in great detail. The spiral structure of the Milky Way\nas traced by O- and early B-type stars shows flocculent patterns. Accurate\nstructure parameters, as well as the means and dispersions of the vertical\nvelocity distributions of the individual Spiral Arms are presented. Bingqiu_2019 Bingqiu et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.05542
540 1903.03465 2019-05-12 Fiorenzo Vincenzo, Emanuele Spitoni, Francesco Calura, Francesca Matteucci, Victor Silva Aguirre, Andrea Miglio, Gabriele Cescutti The Fall of a Giant. Chemical evolution of Enceladus, alias the Gaia Sausage We present the first chemical evolution model for Enceladus, alias the Gaia\nSausage, to investigate the star formation history of one of the most massive\nsatellites accreted by the Milky Way during a major merger event. Our best\nchemical evolution model for Enceladus nicely fits the observed stellar\n[$\alpha$/Fe]-[Fe/H] chemical abundance trends, and reproduces the observed\nstellar metallicity distribution function, by assuming low star formation\nefficiency, fast infall time scale, and mild outflow intensity. We predict a\nmedian age for Enceladus stars $12.33^{+0.92}_{-1.36}$ Gyr, and - at the time\nof the merger with our Galaxy ($\approx10$ Gyr ago from Helmi et al.) - we\npredict for Enceladus a total stellar mass $M_{\star} \approx 5 \times\n10^{9}\,\text{M}_{\odot}$. By looking at the predictions of our best model, we\ndiscuss that merger events between the Galaxy and systems like Enceladus may\nhave inhibited the gas accretion onto the Galaxy disc at high redshifts,\nheating up the gas in the halo. This scenario could explain the extended period\nof quenching in the star formation activity of our Galaxy about 10 Gyr ago,\nwhich is predicted by Milky Way chemical evolution models, in order to\nreproduce the observed bimodality in [$\alpha$/Fe]-[Fe/H] between thick- and\nthin-disc stars. Vincenzo_2019 Vincenzo et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1903.03465
541 1807.07269 2019-05-08 Emma Fernández-Alvar, J. G. Fernández-Trincado, Edmundo Moreno, William J. Schuster, Leticia Carigi, Alejandra Recio-Blanco, Timothy C. Beers, Cristina Chiappini, Friedrich Anders, Basílio X. Santiago, Anna B. A. Queiroz, Ángeles Pérez-Villegas, Olga Zamora, D. A. García-Hernández, Mario Ortigoza-Urdaneta The metal-rich halo component extended in z: a characterization with Gaia DR2 and APOGEE We report an analysis of the metal-rich tail ([Fe/H] $> -0.75$) of halo stars\nlocated at distances from the Galactic plane $z$ up to $|z| \sim 10$ kpc,\nobserved by the Apache Point Observatory Galactic Evolution Experiment\n(APOGEE). We examine the chemistry, kinematics, and dynamics of this metal-rich\nhalo sample using chemical abundances and radial velocities provided by the\nfourteenth APOGEE data release (DR14) and proper motions from the second Gaia\ndata release (DR2). The analysis reveals three chemically different stellar\npopulations in the [Mg/Fe] vs. [Fe/H] space -- the two distinct halo\npopulations already reported in the literature, and a third group with\nintermediate [Mg/Fe] $\sim$+0.1. We derive the $U$, $V$ and $W$ velocity\ncomponents with respect to the Local Standard of Rest, as well as orbits for\nthe three stellar groups, and find that they differ also in their kinematical\nand dynamical properties. The high-[Mg/Fe] population exhibits a mean prograde\nrotation, as well as orbits that are more bound and closer to the plane,\nwhereas the low-[Mg/Fe] population has $$ closer to 0, and stars that move\nin less-bound orbits reaching larger distances from the centre and the Galactic\nplane. The intermediate-Mg stars exhibit different orbital characteristics,\nmoving with a strong prograde rotation and low excentricity, but in less-bound\norbits. This stellar population resembles the two stellar overdensities lying\nabout $|z| \sim 5$ kpc recently reported in the literature, for which a disc\norigin has been claimed. Fernández-Alvar_2019 Fernández-Alvar et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1807.07269
542 1905.03256 2019-05-08 Andrea Kunder, Alex Tilton, Dylon Maertens, Jonathan Ogata, David Nataf, R. Michael Rich, Christian I. Johnson, Christina Gilligan, Brian Chaboyer Are the double-mode bulge RR Lyrae stars with identical period-ratios the relic of a disrupted stellar system? Radial velocities of fifteen double-mode bulge RR Lyrae (RR01) stars are\npresented, six of which belong to a compact group of RR01 stars in pulsation\nspace, with the ratio of first-overtone period to fundamental-mode period,\nP_{fo}/P_{f}~0.74, and P_{f}~0.44. It has been suggested that these\npulsationally clumped RR01 stars are a relic of a disrupted dwarf galaxy or\nstellar cluster, as they also appear to be spatially coherent in a vertical\nstrip across the bulge. However, the radial velocities of the stars presented\nhere, along with proper motions from Gaia DR2, show a large range of radial\nvelocities, proper motions and distances for the bulge RR01 stars in the\npulsation clump, much larger than the RR01 stars in the Sagittarius dwarf\ngalaxy (Sgr). Therefore, in contrast to the kinematics of the RRL stars\nbelonging to Sgr, and those in and surrounding the bulge globular cluster\nNGC~6441, there is no obvious kinematic signature within the pulsationally\nclumped RR01 stars. If the pulsationally clumped RR01 stars belonged to the\nsame system in the past and were accreted, their accretion in the inner Galaxy\nwas not recent, as the kinematic signature of this group has been lost (i.e.,\nthese stars are now well-mixed within the inner Galaxy). We show that the\napparent spatial coherence reported for these stars could have been caused by\nsmall number statistics. The orbits of the RR01 stars in the inner Galaxy\nsuggest they are confined to the innermost ~4~kpc of the Milky Way. Kunder_2019 Kunder et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.03256
543 1905.02734 2019-05-07 Gregory M. Green, Edward F. Schlafly, Catherine Zucker, Joshua S. Speagle, Douglas P. Finkbeiner A 3D Dust Map Based on Gaia, Pan-STARRS 1 and 2MASS We present a new three-dimensional map of dust reddening, based on Gaia\nparallaxes and stellar photometry from Pan-STARRS 1 and 2MASS. This map covers\nthe sky north of a declination of -30 degrees, out to a distance of several\nkiloparsecs. This new map contains three major improvements over our previous\nwork. First, the inclusion of Gaia parallaxes dramatically improves distance\nestimates to nearby stars. Second, we incorporate a spatial prior that\ncorrelates the dust density across nearby sightlines. This produces a smoother\nmap, with more isotropic clouds and smaller distance uncertainties,\nparticularly to clouds within the nearest kiloparsec. Third, we infer the dust\ndensity with a distance resolution that is four times finer than in our\nprevious work, to accommodate the improvements in signal-to-noise enabled by\nthe other improvements. As part of this work, we infer the distances,\nreddenings and types of 799 million stars. We obtain typical reddening\nuncertainties that are ~30% smaller than those reported in the Gaia DR2\ncatalog, reflecting the greater number of photometric passbands that enter into\nour analysis. Our 3D dust map can be accessed at\nhttps://doi.org/10.7910/DVN/2EJ9TX or through the Python package "dustmaps,"\nand can be queried interactively at http://argonaut.skymaps.info. Our catalog\nof stellar parameters can be accessed at https://doi.org/10.7910/DVN/AV9GXO. Green_2019 Green et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.02734
544 1808.03278 2019-05-04 Yuan-Sen Ting, Hans-Walter Rix The vertical motion history of disk stars throughout the Galaxy It has long been known that the vertical motions of Galactic disk stars\nincrease with stellar age, commonly interpreted as vertical heating through\norbit scattering. Here we map the vertical actions of disk stars as a function\nof age ($\tau\le$ 8 Gyrs) and across a large range of Galactocentric radii,\n$\overline{R}_{\rm GC}$, drawing on APOGEE and Gaia data. We fit\n$\widehat{J_z}(\overline{R}_{\rm GC},\tau )$ as a combination of the vertical\naction at birth, $\widehat{J_{z,0}}$, and subsequent heating $\widehat{\Delta\nJ_z}_{\, {\rm 1Gyr}}(\overline{R}_{\rm GC})$ that scales as\n$\tau^{\gamma(\overline{R}_{\rm GC})}$. The inferred birth temperature,\n$\widehat{J_{z,0}}(\overline{R}_{\rm GC})$ is 1 kpc km/s for 3 kpc <\n$\overline{R}_{\rm GC}$ < 10 kpc, consistent with the ISM velocity dispersion;\nbut it rapidly rises outward, to 8 kpc km/s for $\overline{R}_{\rm GC}$ = 14\nkpc, likely reflecting the stars' birth in a warped or flared gas disk. We find\nthe heating rate $\widehat{\Delta J_z}_{\, {\rm 1Gyr}}$ to be modest and nearly\nconstant across all radii, 1.6 kpc km/s Gyr$^{-1}$. The stellar age dependence\n$\gamma$ gently grows with Galactocentric radius, from $\gamma \simeq$ 1 for\n$\overline{R}_{\rm GC}\lesssim R_\odot$ to $\gamma \simeq$ 1.3 at\n$\overline{R}_{\rm GC}$ =14 kpc. The observed $J_z - \tau$ relation at all\nradii is considerably steeper ($\gamma\gtrsim$ 1) than the time dependence\ntheoretically expected from orbit scattering, $J_z\propto t^{0.5}$. We\nillustrate how this conundrum can be resolved if we also account for the fact\nthat at earlier epochs the scatterers were more common, and the restoring force\nfrom the stellar disk surface mass density was low. Our analysis may re-instate\ngradual orbital scattering as a plausible and viable mechanism to explain the\nage-dependent vertical motions of disk stars. Ting_2019 Ting and Rix 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1808.03278
545 1905.01364 2019-05-03 A. Rojas-Arriagada, M. Zoccali, M. Schultheis, A. Recio-Blanco, G. Zasowski, D. Minniti, H. Jönsson, R. E. Cohen The bimodal [Mg/Fe] versus [Fe/H] bulge sequence as revealed by APOGEE DR14 The Galactic bulge has a bimodal metallicity distribution function: different\nkinematic, spatial, and, potentially, age distributions characterize the\nmetal-poor and metal-rich components. Despite this observed dichotomy, which\nargues for different formation channels for those stars, the distribution of\nbulge stars in the $\alpha$-abundance versus metallicity plane has been found\nso far to be a rather smooth single sequence. We use data from the fourteenth\ndata release of the APOGEE spectroscopic survey (DR14) to investigate the\ndistribution in the Mg abundance (as tracer of the\n$\alpha$-elements)-versus-metallicity plane of a sample of stars selected to be\nin the inner region of the bulge. A clean sample has been selected from the\nDR14 using a set of data- and pipeline-flags to ensure the quality of their\nfundamental parameters and elemental abundances. An additional selection made\nuse of computed spectro-photometric distances to select a sample of likely\nbulge stars as those with ${\rm R_{GC}\leq 3.5~kpc}$. We adopt magnesium\nabundance as an $\alpha$-abundance proxy for our clean sample as it has been\nproven to be the most accurate $\alpha$-element as determined by ASPCAP, the\npipeline for data products from APOGEE spectra. From the distribution of our\nbulge sample in the [Mg/Fe]-versus-[Fe/H] plane, we found that the sequence is\nbimodal. This bimodality is given by the presence of a low-Mg sequence of stars\nparallel to the main high-Mg sequence over a range of $\sim 0.5$~dex around\nsolar metallicity. The two sequences merge above ${\rm [Fe/H]\sim0.15~ dex}$\ninto a single sequence whose dispersion in [Mg/Fe] is larger than either of the\ntwo sequences visible at lower metallicity. This result is confirmed when we\nconsider stars in our sample that are inside the bulge region according to\ntrustworthy Gaia DR2 distances. Rojas-Arriagada_2019 Rojas-Arriagada et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.01364
546 1904.10968 2019-04-24 Jason A. S. Hunt, Mathew W. Bub, Jo Bovy, J. Ted Mackereth, Wilma H. Trick, Daisuke Kawata Signatures of resonance and phase mixing in the Galactic disc Gaia DR2 has provided an unprecedented wealth of information about the\nkinematics of stars in the Solar neighbourhood, and has highlighted the degree\nof features in the Galactic disc. We confront the data with a range of bar and\nspiral models in both action-angle space, and the $R_{\mathrm{G}}-v_{\phi}$\nplane. We find that the phase mixing induced by transient spiral structure\ncreates ridges and arches in the local kinematics which are consistent with the\nGaia data. We are able to produce a qualitatively good match to the data when\ncombined with a bar with a variety of pattern speeds, and show that it is non\ntrivial to decouple the effects of the bar and the spiral structure. Hunt_2019 Hunt et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1904.10968
547 1904.10872 2019-04-24 F. Gran, M. Zoccali, R. Contreras Ramos, E. Valenti, A. Rojas-Arriagada, J. A. Carballo-Bello, J. Alonso-García, D. Minniti, M. Rejkuba, F. Surot Globular cluster candidates in the Galactic bulge: Gaia and VVV view of the latest discoveries Thanks to the recent wide-area photometric surveys, the number of star\ncluster candidates have risen exponentially in the last few years. Most\ndetections, however, are based only on the presence of an overdensity of stars\nin a given region, or an overdensity of variable stars, regardless of their\ndistance. As candidates, their detection has not been dynamically confirmed.\nTherefore, it is currently unknown how many, and which ones, of the published\ncandidates, are true clusters, and which ones are chance alignments. We present\na method to detect and confirm star clusters based on the spatial distribution,\ncoherence in motion and appearance on the color-magnitude diagram. We explain\nand apply it to one new star cluster, and several candidate star clusters\npublished in the literature. The presented method is based on data from the\nSecond Data Release of Gaia complemented with data from the VISTA Variables in\nthe V\'ia L\'actea survey for the innermost bulge regions. It consists of a\nnearest neighbors algorithm applied simultaneously over spatial coordinates,\nstar color, and proper motions, in order to detect groups of stars that are\nclose in the sky, move coherently and define narrow sequences in the\ncolor-magnitude diagram, such as a young main sequence or a red giant branch.\nWhen tested in the bulge area ($-10<\ell\ {\rm (deg)}<+10$; $-10 Gran_2019 Gran et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1904.10872
548 1903.02207 2019-04-23 Z. H. Zhang, A. J. Burgasser, L. C. Smith Primeval very low-mass stars and brown dwarfs - V. A halo L3 subdwarf with prograde eccentric orbit in the Galactic plane VVV J12564163$-$6202039 is an L subdwarf located in the Galactic plane ($b$ =\n0.831 deg) discovered by its high proper motion (1.1 arcsec yr/s). We obtained\nan optical to near-infrared spectrum of it with the X-shooter on the Very Large\nTelescope, and re-classified it as an sdL3 subdwarf. Its best-fitting BT-Dusty\nmodel spectrum has $T_{\rm eff}$ = 2220 K, [Fe/H] = $-0.9$, and log $g$ = 5.5.\nIt is just below the stellar/substellar boundary in the $T_{\rm eff}$ versus\n[Fe/H] parameter space. This object is at a distance of 66.94$^{+8.49}_{-6.77}$\npc according to the $Gaia$ astrometry. It has a halo membership probability of\n99.82 per cent according to its Galactic kinematics. It has unusually flat\n(|$Z$| < 500 pc) and extremely eccentric (e = 0.9) prograde orbit that takes\nthe source from as close as 1.2 kpc from the Galactic centre to 24 kpc out. VVV\nJ12564163$-$6202039 joined by SDSS J133348.24+273508.8 and ULAS\nJ021258.08+064115.9 are the only three known objects in the sdL subclass that\nhave halo kinematics. Zhang_2019 Zhang et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1903.02207
549 1904.09603 2019-04-21 Mohammad K. Mardini, Haining Li, Vinicius M. Placco, Sofya Alexeeva, Daniela Carollo, Ali Taani, Iminhaji Ablimit, Liang Wang, Gang Zhao Metal-poor stars observed with the automated planet finder telescope. I. Discovery of five carbon-enhanced metal-poor stars from LAMOST We report on the discovery of five carbon-enhanced metal-poor (CEMP) stars in\nthe metallicity range of $-3.3<$ [Fe/H] $<-2.4$. These stars were selected from\nthe LAMOST DR3 low-resolution (R$ \sim$ 2,000) spectroscopic database as\nmetal-poor candidates and followed-up with high-resolution spectroscopy (R$\n\sim$110,000) with the LICK/APF. Stellar parameters and individual abundances\nfor 25 chemical elements (from Li to Eu) are presented for the first time.\nThese stars exhibit chemical abundance patterns that are similar to those\nreported in other literature studies of very and extremely metal-poor stars.\nOne of our targets, J2114$-$0616, shows high enhancement in carbon\n([C/Fe]=1.37), nitrogen ([N/Fe]= 1.88), barium ([Ba/Fe]=1.00), and europium\n([Eu/Fe]=0.84). Such chemical abundance pattern suggests that J2114$-$0616 can\nbe classified as CEMP-r/s star. In addition, the star J1054+0528 can be\nclassified as a CEMP-rI star, with [Eu/Fe]=0.44 and [Ba/Fe]=$-$0.52. The other\nstars in our sample show no enhancements in neutron-capture elements and can be\nclassified as CEMP-no stars. We also performed a kinematic and dynamical\nanalysis of the sample stars based on Gaia DR2 data. The kinematic parameters,\norbits, and binding energy of these stars, show that J2114$-$0616 is member of\nthe outer halo population, while the remaining stars belong to the inner halo\npopulation but with an accreted origin. Collectively, these results add\nimportant constraints on the origin and evolution of CEMP stars as well as on\ntheir possible formation scenarios. Mardini_2019 Mardini et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1904.09603
550 1812.04151 2019-04-18 Giacomo Monari, Benoit Famaey, Arnaud Siebert, Christopher Wegg, Ortwin Gerhard The signatures of the resonances of a large Galactic bar in local velocity space The second data release of the Gaia mission has revealed a very rich\nstructure in local velocity space. In terms of in-plane motions, this rich\nstructure is also seen as multiple ridges in the actions of the axisymmetric\nbackground potential of the Galaxy. These ridges are probably related to a\ncombination of effects from ongoing phase-mixing and resonances from the spiral\narms and the bar. We have recently developed a method to capture the behaviour\nof the stellar phase-space distribution function at a resonance, by\nre-expressing it in terms of a new set of canonical actions and angles\nvariables valid in the resonant region. Here, by properly treating the\ndistribution function at resonances, and by using a realistic model for a\nslowly rotating large Galactic bar with pattern speed 39 km/s/kpc, we show that\nno less than six ridges in local action space can be related to resonances with\nthe bar. Two of these at low angular momentum correspond to the corotation\nresonance, and can be associated to the Hercules moving group in local velocity\nspace. Another one at high angular momentum corresponds to the outer Lindblad\nresonance, and can tentatively be associated to the velocity structure seen as\nan arch at high azimuthal velocities in Gaia data. The other ridges are\nassociated to the 3:1, 4:1 and 6:1 resonances. The latter can be associated to\nthe so-called 'horn' of the local velocity distribution. While it is clear that\neffects from spiral arms and incomplete phase-mixing related to external\nperturbations also play a role in shaping the complex kinematics revealed by\nGaia data, the present work demonstrates that, contrary to common\nmisconceptions, the bar alone can create multiple prominent ridges in velocity\nand action space. Monari_2019 Monari et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1812.04151
551 1807.05994 2019-04-10 Khyati Malhan, Rodrigo A. Ibata Constraining the Milky Way Halo Potential with the GD-1 stellar stream We use ESA/Gaia astrometry together with SEGUE and LAMOST measurements of the\nGD-1 stellar stream to explore the improvement on the Galactic gravitational\npotential that these new data provide. Assuming a realistic universal model for\nthe dark matter halo together with reasonable models of the baryonic\ncomponents, we find that the orbital solutions for GD-1 require the circular\nvelocity at the Solar radius to be $V_{\rm circ}(R_\odot) =244 \pm 4\,{\rm km\,\ns^{-1}}$, and also that the density flattening of the dark halo is\n$q_{\rho}=0.82^{+0.25}_{-0.13}$. The corresponding Galactic mass within 20kpc\nwas estimated to be $M_{\rm MW}(<20kpc)=2.5 \pm 0.2 \times 10^{11}\, M_\odot$.\nMoreover, Gaia's excellent proper motions also allowed us to constrain the\nvelocity dispersion of the GD-1 stream in the direction tangential to the line\nof sight to be $<2.30\,{\rm km\, s^{-1}}$ (95 % confidence limit), confirming\nthe extremely cold dynamical nature of this system. Malhan_2019 Malhan and Ibata 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1807.05994
552 1810.10036 2019-04-10 Gwendolyn Eadie, Mario Jurić The cumulative mass profile of the Milky Way as determined by globular cluster kinematics from Gaia DR2 We present new mass estimates and cumulative mass profiles (CMPs) with\nBayesian credible regions for the Milky Way (MW) Galaxy, given the kinematic\ndata of globular clusters as provided by (1) the $\textit{Gaia}$ DR2\ncollaboration and the HSTPROMO team, and (2) the new catalog in Vasiliev\n(2019). We use globular clusters beyond 15kpc to estimate the CMP of the MW,\nassuming a total gravitational potential model $\Phi(r) =\n\Phi_{\circ}r^{-\gamma}$, which approximates an NFW-type potential at large\ndistances when $\gamma=0.5$. We compare the resulting CMPs given data sets (1)\nand (2), and find the results to be nearly identical. The median estimate for\nthe total mass is $M_{200}= 0.70 \times 10^{12} M_{\odot}$ and the $50\%$\nBayesian credible interval is $(0.62, 0.81)\times10^{12}M_{\odot}$. However,\nbecause the Vasiliev catalog contains more complete data at large $r$, the MW\ntotal mass is slightly more constrained by these data. In this work, we also\nsupply instructions for how to create a CMP for the MW with Bayesian credible\nregions, given a model for $M( Eadie_2019 Eadie and Jurić 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1810.10036
553 1904.02177 2019-04-03 Julio A. Carballo-Bello Using Gaia DR2 to detect extratidal structures around the Galactic globular cluster NGC362 We explore the possibility of searching for extratidal features around the\nGalactic globular cluster NGC362 using the Gaia DR2 together with a modified\nversion of a classical statistical decontamination algorithm. Our results\nsuggest that an important stellar component is associated with this globular\ncluster, which is perfectly distinguishable from the populations in the Small\nMagellanic Cloud and that of the nearby NGC104 (47 Tucanae). We thus confirm\nonce again the power of Gaia to disentangle different stellar components along\nthe same line-of-sight. Carballo-Bello_2019 Carballo-Bello 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1904.02177
554 1904.02159 2019-04-03 Harshil Kamdar, Charlie Conroy, Yuan-Sen Ting, Ana Bonaca, Martin Smith, Anthony G. A. Brown Stars that Move Together Were Born Together It is challenging to reliably identify stars that were born together outside\nof actively star-forming regions and bound stellar systems. However, co-natal\nstars should be present throughout the Galaxy, and their demographics can shed\nlight on the clustered nature of star formation and the dynamical state of the\ndisk. In previous work we presented a set of simulations of the Galactic disk\nthat followed the clustered formation and dynamical evolution of 4 billion\nindividual stars over the last 5 Gyr. The simulations predict that a high\nfraction of co-moving stars with physical and 3D velocity separation of $\Delta\nr < 20$ pc and $\Delta v < 1.5$ km s$^{-1}$ are co-natal. In this\n\textit{Letter}, we use \textit{Gaia} DR2 and LAMOST DR4 data to identify and\nstudy co-moving pairs. We find that the distribution of relative velocities and\nseparations of pairs in the data is in good agreement with the predictions from\nthe simulation. We identify 111 co-moving pairs in the Solar neighborhood with\nreliable astrometric and spectroscopic measurements. These pairs show a strong\npreference for having similar metallicities when compared to random field\npairs. We therefore conclude that these pairs were very likely born together.\nThe simulations predict that co-natal pairs originate preferentially from\nhigh-mass and relatively young ($< 1$ Gyr) star clusters. \textit{Gaia} will\neventually deliver well-determined metallicities for the brightest stars,\nenabling the identification of thousands of co-natal pairs due to disrupting\nstar clusters in the solar neighborhood. Kamdar_2019a Kamdar et al. 2019a https://arxiv.org/abs/1904.02159
555 1806.03748 2019-04-02 Yang Huang, Xiaowei Liu, Bingqiu Chen, Huawei Zhang, Haibo Yuan, Maosheng Xiang, Chun Wang, Zhijian Tian Member stars of the GD1 tidal stream from the SDSS, LAMOST and Gaia surveys With the photometric data from the SDSS survey, the spectroscopic data from\nthe SDSS/SEGUE and the LAMOST surveys, and the astrometric data from the Gaia\nDR2, we have identified 71 highly-probable member stars of the GD-1 cold\nstellar stream spread along almost its entire length (i.e. from 126 to 203\ndegree in Right Ascension). With the accurate spectroscopic (i.e. metallicity\nand line-of-sight velocity) and astrometric (i.e. proper motions) information,\nthe position-velocity diagrams, i.e. $\phi_{1}$-$\mu_{\alpha}$,\n$\phi_{1}$-$\mu_{\delta}$ and $\phi_{1}$-${v_{\rm gsr}}$, of the GD-1 stream\nare well mapped. The stream has an average metallicity [Fe/H] $= -1.95 \pm\n0.23$. The rich information of member stars of the stream now available allow\none not only to model its origin, but also to place strong constraints on the\nmass distribution and the gravitational potential of the Milky Way. Huang_2019 Huang et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1806.03748
556 1902.02127 2019-04-01 E. Delgado Mena, A. Moya, V. Adibekyan, M. Tsantaki, J. I. González Hernández, G. Israelian, G. R. Davies, W. J. Chaplin, S. G. Sousa, A. C. S. Ferreira, N. C. Santos Abundance to age ratios in the HARPS-GTO sample with Gaia DR2: Chemical clocks for a range of [Fe/H] [ABRIDGED] The purpose of this work is to evaluate how several elements\nproduced by different nucleosynthesis processes behave with stellar age and\nprovide empirical relations to derive stellar ages from chemical abundances. We\nderive different sets of ages using Gaia parallaxes for a sample of more than\n1000 FGK dwarf stars for which he have spectra from the HARPS-GTO program. We\nanalyze the temporal evolution of different abundance ratios to find the best\nchemical clocks. We find that [$\alpha$/Fe] ratio (average of Mg, Si and Ti),\n[O/Fe] and [Zn/Fe] are good age proxies with a lower dispersion than the\nage-metallicity dispersion. Several abundance ratios present a significant\ncorrelation with age for chemically separated thin disk stars (i.e.\nlow-$\alpha$) but in the case of the chemically defined thick disk stars (i.e.\nhigh-$\alpha$) only the elements Mg, Si, Ca and TiII show a clear correlation\nwith age. We find that the thick disk stars are more enriched in light-s\nelements than thin disk stars of similar age. The maximum enrichment of\ns-process elements in the thin disk occurs in the youngest stars which in turn\nhave solar metallicity. The slopes of the [X/Fe]-age relations are quite\nconstant for O, Mg, Si, Ti, Zn, Sr and Eu regardless of the metallicity.\nHowever, this is not the case for Al, Ca, Cu and most of the s-process\nelements, which display very different trends depending on the metallicity.\nThis demonstrates the limitations of using simple linear relations based on\ncertain abundance ratios to obtain ages for stars of different metallicities.\nFinally, we show that by using 3D relations with a chemical clock and two\nstellar parameters (either Teff, [Fe/H] or stellar mass) we can explain up to\n89% of age variance in a star. A similar result is obtained when using 2D\nrelations with a chemical clock and one stellar parameter, being up to a 87% of\nthe variance explained. Mena_2019 Mena et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1902.02127
557 1904.01021 2019-04-01 A. Savino, L. Posti Gaia DR2 orbital properties for field stars with globular cluster-like CN band strengths Large spectroscopic surveys of the Milky Way have revealed that a small\npopulation of stars in the halo have light element abundances comparable to\nthose found in globular clusters. The favoured explanation for the peculiar\nabundances of these stars is that they originated inside a globular cluster and\nwere subsequently lost. Using orbit calculations we assess the likelihood that\nan existing sample of 57 field stars with globular cluster-like CN band\nstrength originated in any of the currently known Milky Way globular clusters.\nUsing Sloan Digital Sky Survey and Gaia data, we determine orbits and integrals\nof motion of our sample of field stars, and use these values and metallicity to\nidentify likely matches to globular clusters. The pivot hypothesis is that had\nthese stars been stripped from such objects, they would have remained on very\nsimilar orbits. We find that ~ 70% of the sample of field stars have orbital\nproperties consistent with the halo of the Milky Way; however, only 20 stars\nhave likely orbital associations with an existing globular cluster. The\nremaining ~ 30% of the sample have orbits that place them in the outer Galactic\ndisc. No cluster of similar metallicity is known on analogous disc orbits. The\norbital properties of the halo stars seem to be compatible with the globular\ncluster escapee scenario. The stars in the outer disc are particularly\nsurprising and deserve further investigation to establish their nature. Savino_2019 Savino and Posti 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1904.01021
558 1903.12163 2019-03-28 Nicolas Mauron, Luc P. A. Maurin, Tim R. Kendall A catalogue of oxygen-rich pulsating giants in the galactic halo and the Sagittarius stream In order to construct a catalogue of oxygen-rich (noted M) asymptotic giant\nbranch (AGB) stars in the halo, complementing those of carbon-rich (C) stars,\nprevious lists of Miras and SRa semiregulars located in the nor thern\nhemisphere are merged and cleaned of various defects. After putting aside known\nC stars, characteristics lik e colours and periods indicate that most of the\nremaining objects are M stars. Distances are obtained through the pe\nriod-luminosity relation. By considering their position in the sky, stars lying\nat $|Z| > 5$~kpc are confirmed to b e in majority in the Sgr tidal arms. The M\nstars are more numerous than C ones. Our distance scale is supported by t wo\ncool variables located in the Pal~4 globular cluster. Along the Sgr arms, there\nis reasonable agreement on distan ces of our objects with recent RR Lyrae\ndistances. A few stars may be as distant as 150~kpc, with possibly four at t he\ntrailing arm apocenter, and two in the A16 substructure, angularly close to two\nC stars. Ninety radial velocities are collected from $Gaia$ and other sources.\nA catalogue with 417 M pulsating AGB stars is provided. It contains $\sim$ 260\nstars in the halo with $|Z| > 5$~kpc. Their $K_{\rm s}$ magnitudes range from 8\nu p to 13. For comparison, the catalogue also provides $\sim 150$ stars in the\ndisc having $5$~$< K_{\rm s} <$~$8$. The catalog is available on request (NM)\nbefore being on CDS. Mauron_2019 Mauron et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1903.12163
559 1903.11036 2019-03-26 L. H. Quiroga-Nuñez, K. Immer, H. J. van Langevelde, M. J. Reid, R. A. Burns Resolving the distance controversy for Sharpless 269: A possible kink in the outer arm Sharpless 269 (S269) is one of a few HII regions in the outer spiral arm of\nthe Milky Way with strong water maser emission. Based on data from the Very\nLong Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) Exploration of Radio Astrometry (VERA)\narray, two parallax measurements have been published, which differ by nearly\n$2\sigma$. Each distance estimate supports a different structure for the outer\narm. Moreover, given its large Galactocentric radii, S269 has special relevance\nas its proper motion and parallax have been used to constrain the Galactic\nrotation curve at large radii. Using recent Very Long Baseline Array (VLBA)\nobservations, we accurately measure the parallax and proper motion of the water\nmasers in S269. We interpret the position and motion of S269 in the context of\nGalactic structure, and possible optical counterparts. S269's 22 GHz water\nmasers and two close-by quasars were observed at 16 epochs between 2015 and\n2016 using the VLBA. We measure an annual parallax for S269 of 0.241 $\pm$\n0.012 mas corresponding to a distance from the Sun of $4.15^{+0.22}_{-0.20}$\nkpc by fitting four maser spots. The mean proper motion for S269 was estimated\nas $0.16\pm0.26$ mas $\rm{yr^{-1}}$ and $-0.51\pm0.26$ mas $\rm{yr^{-1}}$ for\n$\mu_{\alpha} \ cos \delta$ and $\mu_{\delta}$ respectively, which corresponds\nto the motion expected for a flat Galactic rotation curve at large radius. This\ndistance estimate, Galactic kinematic simulations and observations of other\nmassive young stars in the outer region support the existence of a kink in the\nouter arm at $l \approx$ 140 degrees. Additionally, we find more than 2,000\noptical sources in the Gaia DR2 catalog within 125 pc radius around the 3D\nposition of the water maser emission; from those only three sources are likely\nmembers of the same stellar association that contains the young massive star\nresponsible for the maser emission (S269 IRS 2w). Quiroga-Nuñez_2019 Quiroga-Nuñez et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1903.11036
560 1903.09982 2019-03-24 C. Wang, Y. Huang, H. -B. Yuan, M. -S. Xiang, B. -Q. Chen, H. -F. Wang, Y. -Q. Wu, H. -W. Zhang, Z. -J. Tian, Y. Yang, M. Zhang, X. -W. Liu The Galactic disc phase spirals at different Galactic positions revealed by Gaia and LAMOST data We have investigated the distributions of stellar azimuthal and radial\nvelocity components $V_{\Phi}$ and $V_{R}$ in the vertical position-velocity\nplane $Z$-$V_{Z}$ across the Galactic disc of $6.34 \lesssim R \lesssim\n12.34$\,kpc and $|\Phi| \lesssim 7.5^{\circ}$ using a Gaia and Gaia-LAMOST\nsample of stars. As found in previous works, the distributions exhibit\nsignificant spiral patterns. The $V_{R}$ distributions also show clear\nquadrupole patterns, which are the consequence of the well-known tilt of the\nvelocity ellipsoid. The observed spiral and quadrupole patterns in the phase\nspace plane vary strongly with radial and azimuthal positions. The phase\nspirals of $V_{\Phi}$ become more and more relaxed as $R$ increases. The spiral\npatterns of $V_{\Phi}$ and $V_{R}$ and the quadrupole patterns of $V_{R}$ are\nstrongest at $-2^{\circ} < \Phi < 2^{\circ}$ but negligible at $4^{\circ} <\n\Phi < 6^{\circ}$ and $-6^{\circ} < \Phi < -4^{\circ}$. Our results suggest an\nexternal origin of the phase spirals. In this scenario, the intruder, most\nlikely the previously well-known Sagittarius dwarf galaxy, passed through the\nGalactic plane in the direction towards either Galactic center or anti-center.\nThe azimuthal variations of the phase spirals also help us constrain the\npassage duration of the intruder. A detailed model is required to reproduce the\nobserved radial and azimuthal variations of the phase spirals of $V_{\Phi}$ and\n$V_{R}$. Wang_2019 Wang et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1903.09982
561 1903.09456 2019-03-22 Tadafumi Matsuno, Wako Aoki, Takuma Suda Origin of the excess of high-energy retrograde stars in the Galactic halo We report on the very low $\alpha$-element abundances of a group of\nmetal-poor stars with high orbital energy and with large retrograde motion in\nthe Milky Way halo, whose excess has been reported recently from metallicity\nand kinematics. We constructed a sample of halo stars with measured abundances\nand precise kinematics, including $\sim 880$ stars with [{{Fe}/{H}}]$<-0.7$, by\ncrossmatching the Stellar Abundances for Galactic Archaeology database to the\nsecond data release of Gaia. Three regions in the energy-angular momentum space\nhave been selected: innermost halo, Gaia Enceladus/Sausage, and high-energy\nretrograde halo. While the innermost halo and Gaia Enceladus regions have\nchemical abundances consistent with high- and low-$\alpha$ populations in the\nhalo, respectively, chemical abundances of stars in the high-energy retrograde\nhalo are different from the two populations; their [{X}/{Fe}], where X\nrepresents Na, Mg, and Ca, are even lower than those in Gaia Enceladus. These\nabundances, as well as their low mean metallicity, provide a new support for\nthe idea that the retrograde component is dominated by an accreted dwarf galaxy\nwhich has a longer star formation timescale and is less massive than Gaia\nEnceladus/Sausage. Matsuno_2019 Matsuno et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1903.09456
562 1901.07564 2019-03-22 R. Mor, A. C. Robin, F. Figueras, S. Roca-Fàbrega, X. Luri Gaia DR2 reveals a star formation burst in the disc 2-3 Gyr ago We use Gaia DR2 magnitudes, colours and parallaxes for stars with G<12 to\nexplore a 15-dimensional space that includes simultaneously the initial mass\nfunction (IMF) and a non-parametric star formation history (SFH) for the\nGalactic disc. This inference is performed by combining the Besancon Galaxy\nModel fast approximate simulations (BGM FASt) and an approximate Bayesian\ncomputation algorithm. We find in Gaia DR2 data an imprint of a star formation\nburst 2-3 Gyr ago, in the Galactic thin disc domain, and a present star\nformation rate (SFR) of about 1 Msun. Our results show a decreasing trend of\nthe SFR from 9-10 Gyr to 6-7 Gyr ago. This is consistent with the cosmological\nstar formation quenching observed at redshifts z<1.8. This decreasing trend is\nfollowed by a SFR enhancement starting at about 5 Gyr ago and continuing until\nabout 1 Gyr ago which is detected with high statistical significance by\ndiscarding the null hypothesis of an exponential SFH with a p-value=0.002. We\nestimate, from our best fit model, that about the 50% of the mass used to\ngenerate stars, along the thin disc life, was expended in the period from 5 to\n1 Gyr ago. The timescale and the amount of stellar mass generated during the\nSFR enhancement event lead us to hypothesise that its origin, currently under\ninvestigation, is not intrinsic to the disc. Thus, an external perturbation is\nneeded for its explanation. Additionally we find, for the thin disc, a slope of\nthe IMF of $\alpha_3 \approx 2$ for masses M>1.53 Msun and $\alpha_2 \approx\n1.3$ for the mass range between 0,5 and 1,53 Msun. This is the first time that\nwe consider a non-parametric SFH for the thin disc in the Besancon Galaxy\nModel. This new step, together with the capabilities of the Gaia DR2 parallaxes\nto break degeneracies between different stellar populations, allow us to better\nconstrain the SFH and the IMF. Mor_2019 Mor et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1901.07564
563 1903.08212 2019-03-19 Snehalata Sahu, Annapurni Subramaniam, Mirko Simunovic, J. Postma, Patrick Côté, N. Kameswera Rao, Aaron M. Geller, Nathan Leigh, Michael Shara, Thomas H. Puzia, Peter B. Stetson Detection of a White Dwarf companion to a Blue Straggler Star in the outskirts of globular cluster NGC 5466 with the Ultraviolet Imaging Telescope (UVIT) We report the discovery of a hot white dwarf (WD) companion to a blue\nstraggler star (BSS) in the globular cluster (GC) NGC 5466, based on\nobservations from the Ultra-Violet Imaging Telescope (UVIT) on board AstroSat.\nThe Spectral Energy Distribution (SED) of the Far-UV detected BSS NH 84 was\nconstructed by combining the flux measurements from 4 filters of UVIT, with\nGALEX, GAIA and other ground-based observations. The SED of NH 84 reveals the\npresence of a hot companion to the BSS. The temperature and radius of the BSS\n(T$_{\mathrm{eff}} = 8000^{+1000}_{-250}$ K, R/R$_\odot = 1.44 \pm 0.05$)\nderived from Gemini spectra and SED fitting using Kurucz atmospheric models are\nconsistent with each other. The temperature and radius of the hotter companion\nof NH 84 (T$_{\mathrm{eff}} = 32,000 \pm 2000$ K, R/R$_\odot = 0.021 \pm\n0.007$) derived by fitting Koester WD models to the SED suggest that it is\nlikely to be a hot WD. The radial velocity derived from the spectra along with\nthe proper motion from GAIA DR2 confirms NH 84 to be a kinematic member of the\ncluster. This is the second detection of a BSS-WD candidate in a GC, and the\nfirst in the outskirts of a low density GC. The location of this BSS in NGC\n5466 along with its dynamical age supports the mass-transfer pathway for BSS\nformation in low density environments. Sahu_2019 Sahu et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1903.08212
564 1903.05954 2019-03-15 Ian Claydon, Mark Gieles, Anna Lisa Varri, Douglas C. Heggie, Alice Zocchi Spherical models of star clusters with potential escapers An increasing number of observations of the outer regions of globular\nclusters (GCs) have shown a flattening of the velocity dispersion profile and\nan extended surface density profile. Formation scenarios of GCs can lead to\ndifferent explanations of these peculiarities, therefore the dynamics of stars\nin the outskirts of GCs are an important tool in tracing back the evolutionary\nhistory and formation of star clusters. One possible explanation for these\nfeatures is that GCs are embedded in dark matter halos. Alternatively, these\nfeatures are the result of a population of energetically unbound stars that can\nbe spatially trapped within the cluster, known as potential escapers (PEs). We\npresent a prescription for the contribution of these energetically unbound\nmembers to a family of self-consistent, distribution function-based models,\nwhich, for brevity, we call the Spherical Potential Escapers Stitched (SPES)\nmodels. We show that, when fitting to mock data of bound and unbound stars from\nan N-body model of a tidally-limited star cluster, the SPES models correctly\nreproduce the density and velocity dispersion profiles up to the Jacobi radius,\nand they are able to recover the value of the Jacobi radius itself to within\n20%. We also provide a comparison to the number density and velocity dispersion\nprofiles of the Galactic cluster 47 Tucanae. Such a case offers a proof of\nconcept that an appropriate modelling of PEs is essential to accurately\ninterpret Gaia data in the outskirts of GCs, and, in turn, to formulate\nmeaningful present-day constraints for GC formation scenarios in the early\nuniverse. Claydon_2019 Claydon et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1903.05954
565 1806.09635 2019-03-05 Christopher Wegg, Ortwin Gerhard, Marie Bieth The Gravitational Force Field of the Galaxy Measured From the Kinematics of RR Lyrae in Gaia From a sample of 15651 RR Lyrae with accurate proper motions in Gaia DR2, we\nmeasure the azimuthally averaged kinematics of the inner stellar halo between\n1.5 kpc and 20 kpc from the Galactic centre. We find that their kinematics are\nstrongly radially anisotropic, and their velocity ellipsoid nearly spherically\naligned over this volume. Only in the inner regions $\lesssim$ 5 kpc does the\nanisotropy significantly fall (but still with $\beta >$ 0.25) and the velocity\nellipsoid tilt towards cylindrical alignment. In the inner regions, our sample\nof halo stars rotates at up to 50 km s$^{-1}$, which may reflect the early\nhistory of the Milky Way, although there is also significant angular momentum\nexchange with the Galactic bar at these radii. We subsequently apply the Jeans\nequations to these kinematic measurements in order to non-parametrically infer\nthe azimuthally averaged gravitational acceleration field over this volume, and\nby removing the contribution from baryonic matter, measure the contribution\nfrom dark matter. We find that the gravitational potential of the dark matter\nis nearly spherical with average flattening $q_\Phi=$ 1.01 $\pm$ 0.06 between 5\nkpc and 20 kpc, and by fitting parametric ellipsoidal density profiles to the\nacceleration field, we measure the flattening of the dark matter halo over\nthese radii to be $q_\rho=$ 1.00 $\pm$ 0.09. Wegg_2019 Wegg et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1806.09635
566 1901.08072 2019-03-05 T. J. L. de Boer, M. Gieles, E. Balbinot, V. Henault-Brunet, A. Sollima, L. L. Watkins, I. Claydon Globular cluster number density profiles using Gaia DR2 Using data from Gaia DR2, we study the radial number density profiles of the\nGalactic globular cluster sample. Proper motions are used for accurate\nmembership selection, especially crucial in the cluster outskirts. Due to the\nsevere crowding in the centres, the Gaia data is supplemented by literature\ndata from HST and surface brightness measurements, where available. This\nresults in 81 clusters with a complete density profile covering the full tidal\nradius (and beyond) for each cluster. We model the density profiles using a set\nof single-mass models ranging from King and Wilson models to generalised\nlowered isothermal limepy models and the recently introduced spes models, which\nallow for the inclusion of potential escapers. We find that both King and\nWilson models are too simple to fully reproduce the density profiles, with King\n(Wilson) models on average underestimating(overestimating) the radial extent of\nthe clusters. The truncation radii derived from the limepy models are similar\nto estimates for the Jacobi radii based on the cluster masses and their orbits.\nWe show clear correlations between structural and environmental parameters, as\na function of Galactocentric radius and integrated luminosity. Notably, the\nrecovered fraction of potential escapers correlates with cluster pericentre\nradius, luminosity and cluster concentration. The ratio of half mass over\nJacobi radius also correlates with both truncation parameter and PE fraction,\nshowing the effect of Roche lobe filling. Boer_2019 Boer et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1901.08072
567 1903.02008 2019-03-05 Jason L. Sanders, Leigh Smith, N. Wyn Evans, Philip Lucas Transverse kinematics of the Galactic bar-bulge from VVV and Gaia We analyse the kinematics of the Galactic bar-bulge using proper motions from\nthe ESO public survey Vista Variables in the Via Lactea (VVV) and the second\nGaia data release. Gaia has provided some of the first absolute proper motions\nwithin the bulge and the near-infrared VVV multi-epoch catalogue complements\nGaia in highly-extincted low-latitude regions. We discuss the\nrelative-to-absolute calibration of the VVV proper motions using Gaia. 568 1903.01572 2019-03-04 D. Deras, A. Arellano Ferro, C. Lázaro, I. H. Bustos Fierro, J. H. Calderón, S. Muneer, Sunetra Giridhar A new study of the variable star population in the Hercules globular cluster (M13; NGC 6205) We present the results from $VI$ CCD time-series photometry of the globular\ncluster M13 (NGC 6205). From the Fourier decomposition of the light curves of\nRRab and RRc stars we found an average metallicity of [Fe/H]zw = -1.58 $\pm$\n0.09. The distance to the cluster was estimated as 7.1 $\pm$ 0.1 kpc from\nindependent methods related to the variable star families RR Lyrae, SX Phe and\nW Virginis, from the luminosity of the theoretical ZAHB and from the orbit\nsolution of a newly discovered contact binary star. The RR Lyrae pulsation\nmodes are segregated by the red edge of the first overtone instability strip in\nthis OoII type cluster. A membership analysis of 52,800 stars in the field of\nthe cluster is presented based on \textit{Gaia}-DR2 proper motions which\nenabled the recognition of 23,070 likely cluster members, for 7,630 of which we\npossess $VI$ photometry. The identification of member stars allowed the\nconstruction of a clean CMD and a proper ZAHB and isochrone fitting, consistent\nwith a reddening, age and distance of 0.02 mag, 12.6 Gyrs and 7.1 kpc\nrespectively. We report seven new variables; one RRc, two SX Phe stars, three\nSR and one contact binary. V31 presents double-mode nature and we confirm V36\nas RRd. Fifteen variable star candidates are also reported. The analysis of\neighteen stars in the field of the cluster, reported as RR Lyrae from the\n$Gaia$-DR2 data base reveals that at least seven are not variable. We noted the\npresence of a high velocity star in the field of the cluster. Deras_2019 Deras et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1903.01572
569 1903.01476 2019-03-04 M. Lomaeva, H. Jönsson, N. Ryde, M. Schultheis, B. Thorsbro Abundances of disk and Bulge giants from high-resolution optical spectra III. Sc, V, Cr, Mn, Co, Ni Context. Recent observations of the Bulge, e.g., its X-shape, cylindrical\nstellar motions, and a potential fraction of young stars propose that it formed\nthrough secular evolution of the disk and not through gas dissipation and/or\nmergers, as thought previously. Aims. We measure abundances of six iron-peak\nelements (Sc, V, Cr, Mn, Co and Ni) in the local thin and thick disks as well\nas the Bulge to provide additional observational constraints for Galaxy\nformation and chemical evolution models. Methods. We use high-resolution\noptical spectra of 291 K giants in the local disk mostly obtained by the FIES\nat NOT (signal-to-noise (S/N) ratio of 80-100) and 45 K giants in the Bulge\nobtained by the UVES/FLAMES at VLT (S/N ratio of 10-80). We measure abundances\nin SME and apply NLTE corrections to the [Mn/Fe] and [Co/Fe] ratios. To\ndiscriminate between the thin and thick, we use stellar metallicity,\n[Ti/Fe]-ratios, and kinematics from Gaia DR2 (proper motions and the radial\nvelocities). Results. The observed disk trend of V is more enhanced in the\nthick disk, while the Co disk trend shows a minor enhancement in the thick\ndisk. The Bulge trends of V and Co appear even more enhanced w.r.t. the thick\ndisk, but within the uncertainties. The [Ni/Fe] ratio seems slightly\noverabundant in the thick disk and the Bulge w.r.t. the thin disk, although the\ndifference is minor. The disk and Bulge trends of Sc, Cr and Mn overlap\nstrongly. Conclusions. The somewhat enhanced [(V,Co)/Fe] ratios observed in the\nBulge suggest that the local thick disk and the Bulge might have experienced\ndifferent chemical enrichment and evolutionary paths. However, we are unable to\npredict the exact evolutionary path of the Bulge solely based on these\nobservations. Galactic chemical evolution models could, on the other hand,\nprovide that using these results. Lomaeva_2019 Lomaeva et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1903.01476
570 1901.02016 2019-02-28 Alis J. Deason, Azadeh Fattahi, Vasily Belokurov, Wyn Evans, Robert J. Grand, Federico Marinacci, Rudiger Pakmor The local high velocity tail and the Galactic escape speed We model the fastest moving (v_tot > 300 km/s) local (D < 3 kpc) halo stars\nusing cosmological simulations and 6-dimensional Gaia data. Our approach is to\nuse our knowledge of the assembly history and phase-space distribution of halo\nstars to constrain the form of the high velocity tail of the stellar halo.\nUsing simple analytical models and cosmological simulations, we find that the\nshape of the high velocity tail is strongly dependent on the velocity\nanisotropy and number density profile of the halo stars --- highly eccentric\norbits and/or shallow density profiles have more extended high velocity tails.\nThe halo stars in the solar vicinity are known to have a strongly radial\nvelocity anisotropy, and it has recently been shown the origin of these highly\neccentric orbits is the early accretion of a massive (M_star ~ 10^9 M_Sun)\ndwarf satellite. We use this knowledge to construct a prior on the shape of the\nhigh velocity tail. Moreover, we use the simulations to define an appropriate\nouter boundary of 2r_200, beyond which stars can escape. After applying our\nmethodology to the Gaia data, we find a local (r_0=8.3 kpc) escape speed of\nv_esc(r_0) = 528(+24,-25) km/s. We use our measurement of the escape velocity\nto estimate the total Milky Way mass, and dark halo concentration: M_200,tot =\n1.00(+0.31,-0.24) x 10^12 M_Sun, c_200 = 10.9(+4.4,-3.3). Our estimated mass\nagrees with recent results in the literature that seem to be converging on a\nMilky Way mass of M_200,tot ~ 10^12 M_Sun. Deason_2019 Deason et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1901.02016
571 1808.01613 2019-02-28 C. Soubiran, T. Cantat-Gaudin, M. Romero-Gómez, L. Casamiquela, C. Jordi, A. Vallenari, T. Antoja, L. Balaguer-Núñez, D. Bossini, A. Bragaglia, R. Carrera, A. Castro-Ginard, F. Figueras, U. Heiter, D. Katz, A. Krone-Martins, J. -F. Le Campion, A. Moitinho, R. Sordo Open cluster kinematics with Gaia DR2 Context. Open clusters are very good tracers of the evolution of the Galactic\ndisc. Thanks to Gaia, their kinematics can be investigated with an\nunprecedented precision and accuracy. Aims. The distribution of open clusters\nin the 6D phase space is revisited with Gaia DR2. Methods. The weighted mean\nradial velocity of open clusters was determined, using the most probable\nmembers available from a previous astrometric investigation that also provided\nmean parallaxes and proper motions. Those parameters, all derived from Gaia DR2\nonly, were combined to provide the 6D phase space information of 861 clusters.\nThe velocity distribution of nearby clusters was investigated, as well as the\nspatial and velocity distributions of the whole sample as a function of age. A\nhigh quality subsample was used to investigate some possible pairs and groups\nof clusters sharing the same Galactic position and velocity. Results. For the\nhigh quality sample that has 406 clusters, the median uncertainty of the\nweighted mean radial velocity is 0.5 km/s. The accuracy, assessed by comparison\nto ground-based high resolution spectroscopy, is better than 1 km/s. Open\nclusters nicely follow the velocity distribution of field stars in the close\nSolar neighbourhood previously revealed by Gaia DR2. As expected, the vertical\ndistribution of young clusters is very flat but the novelty is the high\nprecision to which this can be seen. The dispersion of vertical velocities of\nyoung clusters is at the level of 5 km/s. Clusters older than 1 Gyr span\ndistances to the Galactic plane up to 1 kpc with a vertical velocity dispersion\nof 14 km/s, typical of the thin disc. Five pairs of clusters and one group with\nfive members are possibly physically related. Other binary candidates\npreviously identified turn out to be chance alignment. Soubiran_2019 Soubiran et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1808.01613
572 1902.10719 2019-02-27 Harshil Kamdar, Charlie Conroy, Yuan-Sen Ting, Ana Bonaca, Benjamin Johnson, Phillip Cargile A Dynamical Model for Clustered Star Formation in the Galactic Disk The clustered nature of star formation should produce a high degree of\nstructure in the combined phase and chemical space in the Galactic disk. To\ndate, observed structure of this kind has been mostly limited to bound clusters\nand moving groups. In this paper we present a new dynamical model of the\nGalactic disk that takes into account the clustered nature of star formation.\nThis model predicts that the combined phase and chemical space is rich in\nsubstructure, and that this structure is sensitive to both the precise nature\nof clustered star formation and the large-scale properties of the Galaxy. The\nmodel self-consistently evolves 4 billion stars over the last 5 Gyr in a\nrealistic potential that includes an axisymmetric component, a bar, spiral\narms, and giant molecular clouds (GMCs). All stars are born in clusters with an\nobservationally-motivated range of initial conditions. As direct\n\textit{N}-body calculations for billions of stars is computationally\ninfeasible, we have developed a method of initializing star cluster particles\nto mimic the effects of direct \textit{N}-body effects, while the actual orbit\nintegrations are treated as test particles within the analytic potential. We\ndemonstrate that the combination of chemical and phase space information is\nmuch more effective at identifying truly co-natal populations than either\nchemical or phase space alone. Furthermore, we show that co-moving pairs of\nstars are very likely to be co-natal if their velocity separation is $< 2$ km\ns$^{-1}$ and their metallicity separation is $< 0.05$ dex. The results\npresented here bode well for harnessing the synergies between \textit{Gaia} and\nspectroscopic surveys to reveal the assembly history of the Galactic disk. Kamdar_2019 Kamdar et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1902.10719
573 1902.09925 2019-02-26 P. B. Stetson, E. Pancino, A. Zocchi, N. Sanna, M. Monelli Homogeneous photometry VII. Globular clusters in the Gaia era We present wide-field, ground-based Johnson-Cousins UBVRI photometry for 48\nGalactic globular clusters based on almost 90000 public and proprietary images.\nThe photometry is calibrated with the latest transformations obtained in the\nframework of our secondary standard project, with typical internal and external\nuncertainties of order a few millimagnitudes. These data provide a bridge\nbetween existing small-area, high-precision HST photometry and all\nsky-catalogues from large surveys like Gaia, SDSS, or LSST. For many clusters,\nwe present the first publicly available photometry in some of the five bands\n(typically U and R). We illustrate the scientific potential of the photometry\nwith examples of surface density and brightness profiles and of\ncolour-magnitude diagrams, with the following highlights: (i) we study the\nmorphology of NGC 5904, finding a varying ellipticity and position angle as a\nfunction of radial distance; (ii) we show U-based colour-magnitude diagrams and\ndemonstrate that no cluster in our sample is free from multiple stellar\npopulations, with the possible exception of a few clusters with high and\ndifferential reddening or field contamination, for which more sophisticated\ninvestigations are required. This is true even for NGC 5694 and Terzan 8, that\nwere previously considered as (mostly) single-population candidates. Stetson_2019 Stetson et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1902.09925
574 1806.03306 2019-02-24 Valeriya Korol, Elena M. Rossi, Enrico Barausse A multi-messenger study of the Milky Way's stellar disc and bulge with LISA, Gaia and LSST The upcoming LISA mission offers the unique opportunity to study the Milky\nWay through gravitational wave radiation from Galactic binaries. Among the\nvariety of Galactic gravitational wave sources, LISA is expected to\nindividually resolve signals from $\sim 10^5$ ultra-compact double white dwarf\n(DWD) binaries. DWDs detected by LISA will be distributed across the Galaxy,\nincluding regions that are hardly accessible to electromagnetic observations\nsuch as the inner part of the Galactic disc, the bulge and beyond. We\nquantitatively show that the large number of DWD detections will allow us to\nuse these systems as tracers of the Milky Way potential. We demonstrate that\ndensity profiles of DWDs detected by LISA may provide constraints on the scale\nlength parameters of the baryonic components that are both accurate and\nprecise, with statistical errors of a few percent to $10$ percent level.\nFurthermore, the LISA sample is found to be sufficient to disentangle between\ndifferent (commonly used) disc profiles, by well covering the disc out to\nsufficiently large radii. Finally, up to $\sim 80$ DWDs can be detected through\nboth electromagnetic and gravitational wave radiation. This enables\nmulti-messenger astronomy with DWD binaries and allows one to extract their\nphysical properties using both probes. We show that fitting the Galactic\nrotation curve constructed using distances inferred from gravitational waves\n{\it and} proper motions from optical observations yield a unique and\ncompetitive estimate of the bulge mass. Instead robust results for the stellar\ndisc mass are contingent upon knowledge of the Dark Matter content. Korol_2019 Korol et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1806.03306
575 1808.00451 2019-02-23 Chervin F. P. Laporte, Ivan Minchev, Kathryn V. Johnston, Facundo A. Gómez Footprints of the Sagittarius dwarf galaxy in the $Gaia$ data set We analyse an N-body simulation of the interaction of the Milky Way (MW) with\na Sagittarius-like dSph (Sgr), looking for signatures which may be attributed\nto its orbital history in the phase space volume around the Sun in light of\n$Gaia$ DR2 discoveries. The repeated impacts of Sgr excite coupled vertical and\nradial oscillations in the disc which qualitatively, and to a large degree\nquantitatively are able to reproduce many features in the 6D $Gaia$ DR2\nsamples, from the median $V_{R},V_{\phi}, V_{z} $ velocity maps to the local\n$\delta\rho(v_{z},z)$ phase-space spiral which is a manifestation of the global\ndisc response to coupled oscillations within a given volume. The patterns in\nthe large-scale velocity field are well described by tightly wound spirals and\nvertical corrugations excited from Sgr's impacts. We show that the last\npericentric passage of Sgr resets the formation of the local present-day\n$\delta\rho(v_z,z)$ spiral and situate its formation around 500-800 Myr. As\nexpected $\delta\rho(vz,z)$ grows in size and decreases in woundedness as a\nfunction of radius in both the $Gaia$ DR2 data and simulations. This is the\nfirst N-body model able to explain so many of the features in the data on\ndifferent scales. We demonstrate how to use the full extent of the Galactic\ndisc to date perturbations dating from Myr to Gyr, probe the underlying\npotential and constrain the mass-loss history of Sgr. $\delta\rho(vz,z)$ looks\nthe same in all stellar populations age bins down to the youngest ages which\nrules out a bar buckling origin. Laporte_2019 Laporte et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1808.00451
576 1902.08634 2019-02-22 Henry W. Leung, Jo Bovy Simultaneous calibration of spectro-photometric distances and the Gaia DR2 parallax zero-point offset with deep learning Gaia measures the five astrometric parameters for stars in the Milky Way, but\nonly four of them (positions and proper motion, but not parallax) are well\nmeasured beyond a few kpc from the Sun. Modern spectroscopic surveys such as\nAPOGEE cover a large area of the Milky Way disk and we can use the relation\nbetween spectra and luminosity to determine distances to stars beyond Gaia's\nparallax reach. Here, we design a deep neural network trained on stars in\ncommon between Gaia and APOGEE that determines spectro-photometric distances to\nAPOGEE stars, while including a flexible model to calibrate parallax zero-point\nbiases in Gaia DR2. We determine the zero-point offset to be $-52.3 \pm 2.0uas$\nwhen modeling it as a global constant, but also train a multivariate zero-point\noffset model that depends on $G$, $G_{BP} - G_{RP}$ color, and $T_\mathrm{eff}$\nand that can be applied to all 139 million stars in Gaia DR2 within APOGEE's\ncolor--magnitude range. Our spectro-photometric distances are more precise than\nGaia at distances $\approx 2kpc$ from the Sun. We release a catalog of\nspectro-photometric distances for the entire APOGEE DR14 data set which covers\nGalactocentric radii $2kpc\lesssim R \lesssim19kpc$; $\approx 150,000$ stars\nhave <10% uncertainty, making this a powerful sample to study the\nchemo-dynamical structure of the disk. We use this sample to map the mean\n[Fe/H] and 15 abundance ratios [X/Fe] from the Galactic center to the edge of\nthe disk. Among many interesting trends, we find that the bulge and bar region\nat $R \lesssim 5kpc$ clearly stands out in [Fe/H] and most abundance ratios. Leung_2019 Leung and Bovy 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1902.08634
577 1902.07861 2019-02-21 Jing Li, Chao Liu, Xiangxiang Xue, Jing Zhong, Jake Weiss, Jeffrey L. Carlin, Hao Tian Detecting the Sagittarius stream with LAMOST DR4 M giants \& Gaia DR2 We use LAMOST DR4 M giants combined with Gaia DR2 proper motions and ALLWISE\nphotometry to obtain an extremely pure sample of Sagittarius (Sgr) stream\nstars. Using TiO5 and CaH spectral indices as an indicator, we selected out a\nlarge sample of M giant stars from M dwarf stars in LAMOST DR4 spectra.\nConsidering the position, distance, proper motion and the angular momentum\ndistribution, we obtained 164 pure Sgr stream stars. We find that the trailing\narm has higher energy than the leading arm in same angular momentum. The\ntrailing arm we detected extends to a heliocentric distance of $\sim 130$ kpc\nat $\tilde\Lambda_{\odot}\sim 170^{\circ}$, which is consistent with the\nfeature found in RR Lyrae in \citet{sgr2017}. Both of these detections of Sgr,\nin M giants and in RR Lyrae, imply that the Sgr stream may contain multiple\nstellar populations with a broad metallicity range. Li_2019a Li et al. 2019a https://arxiv.org/abs/1902.07861
578 1805.03653 2019-02-19 Wilma H.
