Gontcharov_2016 Gontcharov 2016 https://arxiv.org/abs/1606.08814
818 1512.05367 2016-06-27 S. Pasetto, G. Natale, D. Kawata, C. Chiosi, J. A. S. Hunt, C. Brogliato Spiral arm kinematics for Milky Way stellar populations We present a new theoretical population synthesis model (the Galaxy Model) to\nexamine and deal with large amounts of data from surveys of the Milky Way and\nto decipher the present and past structure and history of our own Galaxy. We\nassume the Galaxy to consist of a superposition of many composite stellar\npopulations belonging to the thin and thick disks, the stellar halo and the\nbulge, and to be surrounded by a single dark matter halo component. A global\nmodel for the Milky Way's gravitational potential is built up self-consistently\nwith the density profiles from the Poisson equation. In turn, these density\nprofiles are used to generate synthetic probability distribution functions\n(PDFs) for the distribution of stars in colour-magnitude diagrams (CMDs).\nFinally, the gravitational potential is used to constrain the stellar\nkinematics by means of the moment method on a (perturbed)-distribution\nfunction. Spiral arms perturb the axisymmetric disk distribution functions in\nthe linear response framework of density-wave theory where we present an\nanalytical formula of the so-called `reduction factor' using Hypergeometric\nfunctions. Finally, we consider an analytical non-axisymmetric model of\nextinction and an algorithm based on the concept of probability distribution\nfunction to handle colour magnitude diagrams with a large number of stars. A\ngenetic algorithm is presented to investigate both the photometric and\nkinematic parameter space. This galaxy model represents the natural framework\nto reconstruct the structure of the Milky Way from the heterogeneous data set\nof surveys such as Gaia-ESO, SEGUE, APOGEE2, RAVE and the Gaia mission. Pasetto_2016 Pasetto et al. 2016 https://arxiv.org/abs/1512.05367
819 1606.05292 2016-06-16 P. -E. Tremblay, J. Cummings, J. S. Kalirai, B. T. Gaensicke, N. Gentile-Fusillo, R. Raddi The Field White Dwarf Mass Distribution We revisit the properties and astrophysical implications of the field white\ndwarf mass distribution in preparation of Gaia applications. Our study is based\non the two samples with the best established completeness and most precise\natmospheric parameters, the volume-complete survey within 20 pc and the Sloan\nDigital Sky Survey (SDSS) magnitude-limited sample. We explore the modelling of\nthe observed mass distributions with Monte Carlo simulations, but find that it\nis difficult to constrain independently the initial mass function (IMF), the\ninitial-to-final-mass relation (IFMR), the stellar formation history (SFH), the\nvariation of the Galactic disk vertical scale height as a function of stellar\nage, and binary evolution. Each of these input ingredients has a moderate\neffect on the predicted mass distributions, and we must also take into account\nbiases owing to unidentified faint objects (20 pc sample), as well as unknown\nmasses for magnetic white dwarfs and spectroscopic calibration issues (SDSS\nsample). Nevertheless, we find that fixed standard assumptions for the above\nparameters result in predicted mean masses that are in good qualitative\nagreement with the observed values. It suggests that derived masses for both\nstudied samples are consistent with our current knowledge of stellar and\nGalactic evolution. Our simulations overpredict by 40-50% the number of massive\nwhite dwarfs (M > 0.75 Msun) for both surveys, although we can not exclude a\nSalpeter IMF when we account for all biases. Furthermore, we find no evidence\nof a population of double white dwarf mergers in the observed mass\ndistributions. Tremblay_2016 Tremblay et al. 2016 https://arxiv.org/abs/1606.05292
820 1606.02548 2016-06-08 Douglas Boubert, N. W. Evans A Dipole on the Sky: Predictions for Hypervelocity Stars from the Large Magellanic Cloud We predict the distribution of hypervelocity stars (HVSs) ejected from the\nLarge Magellanic Cloud (LMC), under the assumption that the dwarf galaxy hosts\na central massive black hole (MBH). For the majority of stars ejected from the\nLMC the orbital velocity of the LMC has contributed a significant fraction of\ntheir galactic rest frame velocity, leading to a dipole density distribution on\nthe sky. We quantify the dipole using spherical harmonic analysis and contrast\nwith the monopole expected for HVSs ejected from the Galactic Center. There is\na tendril in the density distribution that leads the LMC which is coincident\nwith the well-known and unexplained clustering of HVSs in the constellations of\nLeo and Sextans. Our model is falsifiable, since it predicts that Gaia will\nreveal a large density of HVSs in the southern hemisphere. Boubert_2016 Boubert and Evans 2016 https://arxiv.org/abs/1606.02548
821 1509.06751 2016-06-06 Jo Bovy, Hans-Walter Rix, Gregory M. Green, Edward F. Schlafly, Douglas P. Finkbeiner On Galactic density modeling in the presence of dust extinction Inferences about the spatial density or phase-space structure of stellar\npopulations in the Milky Way require a precise determination of the effective\nsurvey volume. The volume observed by surveys such as Gaia or near-infrared\nspectroscopic surveys, which have good coverage of the Galactic mid-plane\nregion, is highly complex because of the abundant small-scale structure in the\nthree-dimensional interstellar dust extinction. We introduce a novel framework\nfor analyzing the importance of small-scale structure in the extinction. This\nformalism demonstrates that the spatially-complex effect of extinction on the\nselection function of a pencil-beam or contiguous sky survey is equivalent to a\nlow-pass filtering of the extinction-affected selection function with the\nsmooth density field. We find that the angular resolution of current 3D\nextinction maps is sufficient for analyzing Gaia sub-samples of millions of\nstars. However, the current distance resolution is inadequate and needs to be\nimproved by an order of magnitude, especially in the inner Galaxy. We also\npresent a practical and efficient method for properly taking the effect of\nextinction into account in analyses of Galactic structure through an effective\nselection function. We illustrate its use with the selection function of\nred-clump stars in APOGEE using and comparing a variety of current 3D\nextinction maps. Bovy_2016 Bovy et al. 2016 https://arxiv.org/abs/1509.06751
822 1605.08601 2016-05-27 Wilma H. Trick, Jo Bovy, Hans-Walter Rix Action-based Dynamical Modelling for the Milky Way Disk We present RoadMapping, a full-likelihood dynamical modelling machinery that\naims to recover the Milky Way's (MW) gravitational potential from large samples\nof stars in the Galactic disk. RoadMapping models the observed positions and\nvelocities of stars with a parametrized, three-integral distribution function\n(DF) in a parametrized axisymmetric potential. We investigate through\ndifferential test cases with idealized mock data how the breakdown of model\nassumptions and data properties affect constraints on the potential and DF. Our\nkey results are: (i) If the MW's true potential is not included in the assumed\nmodel potential family, we can - in the axisymmetric case - still find a robust\nestimate for the potential, with only <~ 10% difference in surface density\nwithin |z| <= 1.1 kpc inside the observed volume. (ii) Modest systematic\ndifferences between the true and model DF are inconsequential. E.g, when\nbinning stars to define sub-populations with simple DFs, binning errors do not\naffect the modelling as long as the DF parameters of neighbouring bins differ\nby < 20%. In addition, RoadMapping ensures unbiased potential estimates for\neither (iii) small misjudgements of the spatial selection function (i.e., <~\n15% at the survey volume's edge), (iv) if distances are known to within 10%, or\n(v) if proper motion uncertainties are known within 10% or are smaller than\ndelta mu <~ 1 mas/yr. Challenges are the rapidly increasing computational costs\nfor large sample sizes. Overall, RoadMapping is well suited to making precise\nnew measurements of the MW's potential with data from the upcoming Gaia\nreleases. Trick_2016 Trick et al. 2016 https://arxiv.org/abs/1605.08601
823 1605.04899 2016-05-16 H. R. Jacobson, E. D. Friel, L. Jilkova, L. Magrini, A. Bragaglia, A. Vallenari, M. Tosi, S. Randich, P. Donati, T. Cantat-Gaudin, R. Sordo, R. Smiljanic, J. C. Overbeek, G. Carraro, G. Tautvaisiene, I. San Roman, S. Villanova, D. Geisler, C. Munoz, F. Jimenez-Esteban, B. Tang, G. Gilmore, E. J. Alfaro, T. Bensby, E. Flaccomio, S. E. Koposov, A. J. Korn, E. Pancino, A. Recio-Blanco, A. R. Casey, M. T. Costado, E. Franciosini, U. Heiter, V. Hill, A. Hourihane, C. Lardo, P. de Laverny, J. Lewis, L. Monaco, L. Morbidelli, G. G. Sacco, S. G. Sousa, C. C. Worley, S. Zaggia The Gaia-ESO Survey: Probes of the inner disk abundance gradient The nature of the metallicity gradient inside the solar circle (R_GC < 8 kpc)\nis poorly understood, but studies of Cepheids and a small sample of open\nclusters suggest that it steepens in the inner disk. We investigate the\nmetallicity gradient of the inner disk using a sample of inner disk open\nclusters that is three times larger than has previously been studied in the\nliterature to better characterize the gradient in this part of the disk. We\nused the Gaia-ESO Survey (GES) [Fe/H] values and stellar parameters for stars\nin 12 open clusters in the inner disk from GES-UVES data. Cluster mean [Fe/H]\nvalues were determined based on a membership analysis for each cluster. Where\nnecessary, distances and ages to clusters were determined via comparison to\ntheoretical isochrones. The GES open clusters exhibit a radial metallicity\ngradient of -0.10+-0.02 dex/kpc, consistent with the gradient measured by other\nliterature studies of field red giant stars and open clusters in the range R_GC\n~ 6-12 kpc. We also measure a trend of increasing [Fe/H] with increasing\ncluster age, as has also been found in the literature. We find no evidence for\na steepening of the inner disk metallicity gradient inside the solar circle as\nearlier studies indicated. The age-metallicity relation shown by the clusters\nis consistent with that predicted by chemical evolution models that include the\neffects of radial migration, but a more detailed comparison between cluster\nobservations and models would be premature. Jacobson_2016 Jacobson et al. 2016 https://arxiv.org/abs/1605.04899
824 1604.07834 2016-04-26 Louise M. Howes, Martin Asplund, Stefan C. Keller, Andrew R. Casey, David Yong, Karin Lind, Anna Frebel, Austin Hays, Alan Alves-Brito, Michael S. Bessell, Luca Casagrande, Anna F. Marino, David M. Nataf, Christopher I. Owen, Gary S. Da Costa, Brian P. Schmidt, Patrick Tisserand The EMBLA Survey -- Metal-poor stars in the Galactic bulge Cosmological models predict the oldest stars in the Galaxy should be found\nclosest to the centre of the potential well, in the bulge. The EMBLA Survey\nsuccessfully searched for these old, metal-poor stars by making use of the\ndistinctive SkyMapper photometric filters to discover candidate metal-poor\nstars in the bulge. Their metal-poor nature was then confirmed using the\nAAOmega spectrograph on the AAT. Here we present an abundance analysis of 10\nbulge stars with -2.8<[Fe/H]<-1.7 from MIKE/Magellan observations, in total\ndetermining the abundances of 22 elements. Combining these results with our\nprevious high-resolution data taken as part of the Gaia-ESO Survey, we have\nstarted to put together a picture of the chemical and kinematic nature of the\nmost metal-poor stars in the bulge. The currently available kinematic data is\nconsistent with the stars belonging to the bulge, although more accurate\nmeasurements are needed to constrain the stars' orbits. The chemistry of these\nbulge stars deviates from that found in halo stars of the same metallicity. Two\nnotable differences are the absence of carbon-enhanced metal-poor bulge stars,\nand the alpha-element abundances exhibit a large intrinsic scatter and include\nstars which are underabundant in these typically enhanced elements. Howes_2016 Howes et al. 2016 https://arxiv.org/abs/1604.07834
825 1604.01407 2016-04-05 Eric David Kramer, Lisa Randall Updated Kinematic Constraints on a Dark Disk We update the method of the Holmberg & Flynn (2000) study, including an\nupdated model of the Milky Way's interstellar gas, radial velocities, an\nupdated reddening map, and a careful statistical analysis, to bound the allowed\nsurface density and scale height of a dark disk. We pay careful attention to\nthe self-consistency of the model, including the gravitational influence of the\ndark disk on other disk components, and to the net velocity of the tracer\nstars. We find that the data set exhibits a non-zero bulk velocity in the\nvertical direction as well as a displacement from the expected location at the\nGalactic midplane. If not properly accounted for, these features would bias the\nbound toward low dark disk mass. We therefore perform our analysis two ways. In\nthe first, traditional method, we subtract the mean velocity and displacement\nfrom the tracers' phase space distributions. In the second method, we perform a\nnon-equilibrium version of the HF method to derive a bound on the dark disk\nparameters for an oscillating tracer distribution. Despite updates in the mass\nmodel and reddening map, the traditional method results remain consistent with\nthose of HF2000. The second, non-equilibrium technique, however, allows a\nsurface density as large as $14\, M_\odot\,{\rm pc}^{-2}$ (and as small as 0),\ndemonstrating much weaker constraints. For both techniques, the bound on\nsurface density is weaker for larger scale height. In future analyses of Gaia\ndata, it will be important to verify whether the tracer populations are in\nequilibrium. Kramer_2016 Kramer and Randall 2016 https://arxiv.org/abs/1604.01407
826 1603.00659 2016-03-02 L. Casamiquela, R. Carrera, C. Jordi, L. Balaguer-Núñez, E. Pancino, S. L. Hidalgo, C. E. Martínez-Vázquez, S. Murabito, A. del Pino, A. Aparicio, S. Blanco-Cuaresma, C. Gallart The OCCASO survey: Presentation and radial velocities of twelve Milky Way Open Clusters Open clusters (OCs) are crucial for studying the formation and evolution of\nthe Galactic disc. However, the lack of a large number of OCs analyzed\nhomogeneously hampers the investigations about chemical patterns and the\nexistence of Galactocentric radial and vertical gradients, or an\nage-metallicity relation. To overcome this, we have designed the Open Cluster\nChemical Abundances from Spanish Observatories survey (OCCASO). We aim to\nprovide homogeneous radial velocities, physical parameters and individual\nchemical abundances of six or more Red Clump stars for a sample of 25 old and\nintermediate-age OCs visible from the Northern hemisphere. To do so, we use\nhigh resolution spectroscopic facilities (R> 62,000) available at Spanish\nobservatories. We present the motivation, design and current status of the\nsurvey, together with the first data release of radial velocities for 77 stars\nin 12 OCs, which represents about 50% of the survey. We include clusters never\nstudied with high-resolution spectroscopy before (NGC~1907, NGC~6991,\nNGC~7762), and clusters in common with other large spectroscopic surveys like\nthe Gaia-ESO Survey (NGC~6705) and APOGEE (NGC~2682 and NGC~6819). We perform\ninternal comparisons between instruments to evaluate and correct internal\nsystematics of the results, and compare our radial velocities with previous\ndeterminations in the literature, when available. Finally, radial velocities\nfor each cluster are used to perform a preliminar kinematic study in relation\nwith the Galactic disc. Casamiquela_2016 Casamiquela et al. 2016 https://arxiv.org/abs/1603.00659
827 1602.07687 2016-02-26 T. Antoja, S. Roca-Fabrega, J. de Bruijne, T. Prusti Kinematics of symmetric Galactic longitudes to probe the spiral arms of the Milky Way with Gaia We model the effects of the spiral arms of the Milky Way on the disk stellar\nkinematics in the Gaia observable space. We also estimate the Gaia capabilities\nof detecting the predicted signatures. We use both controlled orbital\nintegrations in analytic potentials and self-consistent simulations. We\nintroduce a new strategy, which consists of comparing the stellar kinematics of\nsymmetric Galactic longitudes (+l and -l), in particular the median transverse\nvelocity (from parallaxes and proper motions). This approach does not require\nthe assumption of an axisymmetric model. The typical differences between the\ntransverse velocity in symmetric longitudes in the models are of ~2 km/s, but\ncan be larger than 10 km/s for certain longitudes and distances. The kinematic\ndifferences for +l and -l show trends that depend on the properties of spiral\narms. Thus, this method can be used to quantify the importance of the effects\nof spiral arms on the orbits of stars in the different disk regions, and to\nconstrain the location of the arms, main resonances and, thus, pattern speed.\nMoreover, the method allows us to test the dynamical nature of the spiral\nstructure (e.g. grand design versus transient multiple arms). We estimate the\nnumber of stars of each spectral type that Gaia will observe in representative\nGalactic longitudes, their errors in distance and transverse velocity, and the\nerror in computing the median velocity as a function of distance. We will be\nable to measure the median transverse velocity with Gaia data, with precision\nsmaller than ~1 km/s up to distances of ~4-6 kpc for certain giant stars, and\nup to ~2-4 kpc and better kinematic precision (<= 0.5 km\s) for certain\nsub-giants and dwarfs. These are enough to measure the typical signatures seen\nin the models. We also show that a similar strategy can be used with\nline-of-sight velocities from other upcoming spectroscopic surveys.(Abridged) Antoja_2016 Antoja et al. 2016 https://arxiv.org/abs/1602.07687
828 1602.03289 2016-02-25 R. Smiljanic, D. Romano, A. Bragaglia, P. Donati, L. Magrini, E. Friel, H. Jacobson, S. Randich, P. Ventura, K. Lind, M. Bergemann, T. Nordlander, T. Morel, E. Pancino, G. Tautvaisiene, V. Adibekyan, M. Tosi, A. Vallenari, G. Gilmore, T. Bensby, P. Francois, S. Koposov, A. C. Lanzafame, A. Recio-Blanco, A. Bayo, G. Carraro, A. R. Casey, M. T. Costado, E. Franciosini, U. Heiter, V. Hill, A. Hourihane, P. Jofre, C. Lardo, P. de Laverny, J. Lewis, L. Monaco, L. Morbidelli, G. G. Sacco, L. Sbordone, S. G. Sousa, C. C. Worley, S. Zaggia The Gaia-ESO Survey: Sodium and aluminium abundances in giants and dwarfs - Implications for stellar and Galactic chemical evolution Stellar evolution models predict that internal mixing should cause some\nsodium overabundance at the surface of red giants more massive than ~ 1.5--2.0\nMsun. The surface aluminium abundance should not be affected. Nevertheless,\nobservational results disagree about the presence and/or the degree of the Na\nand Al overabundances. In addition, Galactic chemical evolution models adopting\ndifferent stellar yields lead to quite different predictions for the behavior\nof [Na/Fe] and [Al/Fe] versus [Fe/H]. Overall, the observed trends of these\nabundances with metallicity are not well reproduced. We readdress both issues,\nusing new Na and Al abundances determined within the Gaia-ESO Survey, using two\nsamples: i) more than 600 dwarfs of the solar neighborhood and of open clusters\nand ii) low- and intermediate-mass clump giants in six open clusters.\nAbundances of Na in giants with mass below ~2.0 Msun, and of Al in giants below\n~3.0 Msun, seem to be unaffected by internal mixing processes. For more massive\ngiants, the Na overabundance increases with stellar mass. This trend agrees\nwell with predictions of stellar evolutionary models. Chemical evolution models\nthat are able to fit well the observed [Na/Fe] vs. [Fe/H] trend in solar\nneighborhood dwarfs can not simultaneously explain the run of [Al/Fe] with\n[Fe/H], and viceversa. The comparison with stellar ages is hampered by severe\nuncertainties. Indeed, reliable age estimates are available for only a half of\nthe stars of the sample. We conclude that Al is underproduced by the models,\nexcept for stellar ages younger than about 7 Gyr. In addition, some significant\nsource of late Na production seems to be missing in the models. Either current\nNa and Al yields are affected by large uncertainties, and/or some important\nGalactic source(s) of these elements has not been taken into account up to now.\n[abridged] Smiljanic_2016 Smiljanic et al. 2016 https://arxiv.org/abs/1602.03289
829 1509.04899 2016-02-23 L. Wyrzykowski, Z. Kostrzewa-Rutkowska, J. Skowron, K. A. Rybicki, P. Mroz, S. Kozlowski, A. Udalski, M. K. Szymanski, G. Pietrzynski, I. Soszynski, K. Ulaczyk, P. Pietrukowicz, R. Poleski, M. Pawlak, K. Ilkiewicz, N. J. Rattenbury Black Hole, Neutron Star and White Dwarf Candidates from Microlensing with OGLE-III Most stellar remnants so far have been found in binary systems, where they\ninteract with matter from their companions. Isolated neutron stars and black\nholes are difficult to find as they are dark, yet they are predicted to exist\nin our Galaxy in vast numbers.\n We explored the OGLE-III database of 150 million objects observed in years\n2001-2009 and found 59 microlensing events exhibiting a parallax effect due to\nthe Earth's motion around the Sun. Combining parallax and brightness\nmeasurements from microlensing light curves with expected proper motions in the\nMilky Way, we identified 13 microlensing events which are consistent with\nhaving a white dwarf, neutron star or a black hole lens and we estimated their\nmasses and distances. The most massive of our black hole candidates has 9.3\nMSun and is at a distance of 2.4 kpc. The distribution of masses of our\ncandidates indicates a continuum in mass distribution with no mass gap between\nneutron stars and black holes. We also present predictions on how such events\nwill be observed by the astrometric Gaia mission. Wyrzykowski_2016 Wyrzykowski et al. 2016 https://arxiv.org/abs/1509.04899
830 1601.01313 2016-01-06 I. Minchev, C. Chiappini, M. Martig Milky Way chemo-dynamics in the era of Gaia The main goal of Galactic Archaeology is understanding the formation and\nevolution of the basic Galactic components. This requires sophisticated\nchemo-dynamical modeling, where disc asymmetries (e.g., perturbations from the\ncentral bar, spirals arms, and infalling satellites) and non-equilibrium\nprocesses are taken into account self-consistently. Here we discuss the current\nstatus of Galactic chemo-dynamical modeling and focus on a recent hybrid\ntechnique, which helps circumvent traditional problems with chemical enrichment\nand star formation encountered in fully self-consistent cosmological\nsimulations. We show that this model can account for a number of\nchemo-kinematic relations in the Milky Way. In addition, we demonstrate that\n(1) our model matches well the observed age-[alpha/Fe] and age-[Fe/H] relations\nand (2) that the scatter in the age-[Fe/H] relation cannot be simply explained\nby blurring (stars on apo- and pericenters visiting the solar vicinity) but\nsignificant radial migration (stars born elsewhere but ending up at the solar\nvicinity today because of a change in guiding radius) is needed. We emphasize\nthe importance of accurate stellar ages, such as those obtained through\nasteroseismology by the CoRoT and Kepler missions, for breaking the degeneracy\namong different Galactic evolution scenarios. Minchev_2016 Minchev et al. 2016 https://arxiv.org/abs/1601.01313
831 1601.00447 2016-01-04 C. A. Martínez-Barbosa, A. G. A. Brown, T. Boekholt, S. Portegies Zwart, E. Antiche, T. Antoja The evolution of the Sun's birth cluster and the search for the solar siblings with Gaia We use self-consistent numerical simulations of the evolution and disruption\nof the Sun's birth cluster in the Milky Way potential to investigate the\npresent-day phase space distribution of the Sun's siblings. The simulations\ninclude the gravitational N-body forces within the cluster and the effects of\nstellar evolution on the cluster population. In addition the gravitational\nforces due to the Milky Way potential are accounted for in a self-consistent\nmanner. Our aim is to understand how the astrometric and radial velocity data\nfrom the Gaia mission can be used to pre-select solar sibling candidates. We\nvary the initial conditions of the Sun's birth cluster, as well as the\nparameters of the Galactic potential. We show that the disruption time-scales\nof the cluster are insensitive to the details of the non-axisymmetric\ncomponents of the Milky Way model and we make predictions, averaged over the\ndifferent simulated possibilities, about the number of solar siblings that\nshould appear in surveys such as Gaia or GALAH. We find a large variety of\npresent-day phase space distributions of solar siblings, which depend on the\ncluster initial conditions and the Milky Way model parameters. We show that\nnevertheless robust predictions can be made about the location of the solar\nsiblings in the space of parallaxes ($\varpi$), proper motions ($\mu$) and\nradial velocities ($V_\mathrm{r}$). By calculating the ratio of the number of\nsimulated solar siblings to that of the number of stars in a model Galactic\ndisk, we find that this ratio is above 0.5 in the region given by: $\varpi \geq\n5$mas, $4 \leq \mu \leq 6$masyr$^{-1}$, and $-2\leq V_\mathrm{r} \leq\n0$kms$^{-1}$. Selecting stars from this region should increase the probability\nof success in identifying solar siblings through follow up observations\n[Abridged]. Martínez-Barbosa_2016 Martínez-Barbosa et al. 2016 https://arxiv.org/abs/1601.00447
832 1601.00649 2016-01-04 Robyn E. Sanderson Inferring the Galactic potential with Gaia and friends: synergies with other surveys In the coming decade the Gaia satellite will precisely measure the positions\nand velocities of millions of stars in the Galactic halo, including stars in\nmany tidal streams. These streams, the products of hierarchical accretion of\nsatellite galaxies by the Milky Way (MW), can be used to infer the Galactic\ngravitational potential thanks to their initial compactness in phase space.\nPlans for observations to extend Gaia's radial velocity (RV) measurements to\nfaint stars, and to determine precise distances to RR Lyrae (RRLe) in streams,\nwould further extend the power of Gaia's kinematic catalog to characterize the\nMW's potential at large Galactocentric distances. In this work I explore the\nimpact of these extra data on the ability to fit the potential using the method\nof action clustering, which statistically maximizes the information content\n(clumpiness) of the action space of tidal streams, eliminating the need to\ndetermine stream membership for individual stars. Using a mock halo in a toy\nspherical potential, updated post-launch error models for Gaia, and estimates\nfor RV and distance errors for the tracers to be followed up, I show that\ncombining either form of additional information with the Gaia catalog greatly\nreduces the bias in determining the scale radius and total mass of the Galaxy,\ncompared to the use of Gaia data alone. Sanderson_2016 Sanderson 2016 https://arxiv.org/abs/1601.00649
833 1512.05091 2015-12-16 Andreas Just, Jan Rybizki Dynamical and chemical evolution of the thin disc Our detailed analytic local disc model (JJ-model) quantifies the\ninterrelation between kinematic properties (e.g. velocity dispersions and\nasymmetric drift), spatial parameters (scale-lengths and vertical density\nprofiles), and properties of stellar sub-populations (age and abundance\ndistributions). Any consistent radial extension of the disc evolution model\nshould predict specific features in the different distribution functions and in\ntheir correlations. Large spectroscopic surveys (SEGUE, RAVE, APOGEE, Gaia-ESO)\nallow significant constraints on the long-term evolution of the thin disc. We\ndiscuss the qualitative difference of correlations (like the alpha-enhancement\nas function of metallicity) and distribution functions (e.g. in [Mg/H] or\n[Fe/H]) for the construction of a disc model. In the framework of the JJ-model\nwe build a local chemical enrichment model and show that significant vertical\ngradients for main sequence and red clump stars are expected in the thin disc.\nA Jeans analysis of the asymmetric drift provides a link to the radial\nstructure of the disc. The derived metallicity-dependent radial scale-lengths\ncan be combined in the future with the abundance distributions at different\nGalactocentric distances to construct full disc models. We expect to be able to\nconstrain possible scenarios of inside-out growth of the thin disc and to\ncharacterise those populations, which require significant radial migration. Just_2015 Just and Rybizki 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1512.05091
834 1512.05216 2015-12-16 Paula Jofre Gaia Benchmark stars and their twins in the Gaia-ESO Survey The Gaia benchmark stars are stars with very precise stellar parameters that\ncover a wide range in the HR diagram at various metallicities. They are meant\nto be good representative of typical FGK stars in the Milky Way. Currently,\nthey are used by several spectroscopic surveys to validate and calibrate the\nmethods that analyse the data. I review our recent activities done for these\nstars. Additionally, by applying our new method to find stellar twins on the\nGaia-ESO Survey, I discuss how good representatives of Milky Way stars the\nbenchmark stars are and how they distribute in space. Jofre_2015 Jofre 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1512.05216
835 1512.03835 2015-12-11 A. Rojas-Arriagada, A. Recio-Blanco, P. de Laverny, M. Schultheis, G. Guiglion, Š. Mikolaitis, G. Kordopatis, V. Hill, G. Gilmore, S. Randich, E. J. Alfaro, T. Bensby, S. E. Koposov, M. T. Costado, E. Franciosini, A. Hourihane, P. Jofré, C. Lardo, J. Lewis, K. Lind, L. Magrini, L. Monaco, L. Morbidelli, G. G. Sacco, C. C. Worley, S. Zaggia, C. Chiappini The Gaia-ESO Survey: Separating disk chemical substructures with cluster models (Abridged) Recent spectroscopic surveys have begun to explore the Galactic\ndisk system outside the solar neighborhood on the basis of large data samples.\nIn this way, they provide valuable information for testing spatial and temporal\nvariations of disk structure kinematics and chemical evolution. We used a\nGaussian mixture model algorithm, as a rigurous mathematical approach, to\nseparate in the [Mg/Fe] vs. [Fe/H] plane a clean disk star subsample from the\nGaia-ESO survey internal data release 2. We find that the sample is separated\ninto five groups associated with major Galactic components; the metal-rich end\nof the halo, the thick disk, and three subgroups for the thin disk sequence.\nThis is confirmed with a sample of red clump stars from the Apache Point\nObservatory Galactic Evolution Experiment (APOGEE) survey. The two\nmetal-intermediate and metal-rich groups of the thin disk decomposition\n([Fe/H]>-0.25 dex) highlight a change in the slope at solar metallicity. This\nholds true at different radial regions. The distribution of Galactocentric\nradial distances of the metal-poor part of the thin disk ([Fe/H]<-0.25 dex) is\nshifted to larger distances than those of the more metal-rich parts. Moreover,\nthe metal-poor part of the thin disk presents indications of a scale height\nintermediate between those of the thick and the rest of the thin disk, and it\ndisplays higher azimuthal velocities than the latter. These stars might have\nformed and evolved in parallel and/or dissociated from the inside-out formation\ntaking place in the internal thin disk. Their enhancement levels might be due\nto their origin from gas pre-enriched by outflows from the thick disk or the\ninner halo. The smooth trends of their properties (their spatial distribution\nwith respect to the plane, in particular) with [Fe/H] and [Mg/Fe] suggested by\nthe data indicates a quiet dynamical evolution, with no relevant merger events. Rojas-Arriagada_2015 Rojas-Arriagada et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1512.03835
836 1512.03658 2015-12-11 C. Cacciari, E. Pancino, M. Bellazzini Gaia A review of the Gaia mission and its science performance after one year of\noperations will be presented, and the contribution to reconstructing the\nhistory of the Milky Way will be outlined. Cacciari_2015 Cacciari et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1512.03658
837 1512.02283 2015-12-07 Luca Casagrande Lessons learnt from the Solar neighbourhood and the Kepler field Setting the timeline of the events which shaped the Milky Way disc through\nits 13 billion year old history is one of the major challenges in the theory of\ngalaxy formation. Achieving this goal is possible using late-type stars, which\nin virtue of their long lifetimes can be regarded as fossil remnants from\nvarious epochs of the formation of the Galaxy. There are two main paths to\nreliably age-date late-type stars: astrometric distances for stars in the\nturn-off and subgiant region, or oscillation frequencies along the red giant\nbranch. So far, these methods have been applied to large samples of stars in\nthe solar neighbourhood, and in the Kepler field. I review these studies,\nemphasize how they complement each other, and highlight some of the constraints\nthey provide for Galactic modelling. I conclude with the prospects and\nsynergies that astrometric (Gaia) and asteroseismic space-borne missions\nreserve to the field of Galactic Archaeology, and advocate that survey\nselection functions should be kept as simple as possible, relying on basic\nobservables such as colours and magnitudes only. Casagrande_2015 Casagrande 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1512.02283
838 1506.05369 2015-10-08 Charles King III, Warren R. Brown, Margaret J. Geller, Scott J. Kenyon Stellar Velocity Dispersion and Anisotropy of the Milky Way Inner Halo We measure the three components of velocity dispersion,\n$\sigma_{R},\sigma_{\theta},\sigma_{\phi}$, for stars within 6 < R < 30 kpc of\nthe Milky Way using a new radial velocity sample from the MMT telescope. We\ncombine our measurements with previously published data so that we can more\nfinely sample the stellar halo. We use a maximum likelihood statistical method\nfor estimating mean velocities, dispersions, and covariances assuming only that\nvelocities are normally distributed. The alignment of the velocity ellipsoid is\nconsistent with a spherically symmetric gravitational potential. From the\nspherical Jeans equation, the mass of the Milky Way is M(<12 kpc) =\n$1.3\times10^{11}$ M$_{\odot}$ with an uncertainty of 40%. We also find a\nregion of discontinuity, 15 < R < 25 kpc, where the estimated velocity\ndispersions and anisotropies diverge from their anticipated values, confirming\nat high significance the break observed by others. We argue that this break in\nanisotropy is physically explained by coherent stellar velocity structure in\nthe halo, such as the Sgr stream. To significantly improve our understanding of\nhalo kinematics will require combining radial velocities with future Gaia\nproper motions. III_2015 III et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1506.05369
839 1509.05271 2015-09-17 G. Guiglion, A. Recio-Blanco, P. de Laverny, G. Kordopatis, V. Hill, Š. Mikolaitis, I. Minchev, C. Chiappini, R. F. G. Wyse, G. Gilmore, S. Randich, S. Feltzing, T. Bensby, E. Flaccomio, S. E. Koposov, E. Pancino, A. Bayo, M. T. Costado, E. Franciosini, A. Hourihane, P. Jofré, C. Lardo, J. Lewis, K. Lind, L. Magrini, L. Morbidelli, G. G. Sacco, G. Ruchti, C. C. Worley, S. Zaggia The Gaia-ESO Survey: New constraints on the Galactic disc velocity dispersion and its chemical dependencies Understanding the history and the evolution of the Milky Way disc is one of\nthe main goals of modern astrophysics. We study the velocity dispersion\nbehaviour of Galactic disc stars as a function of the [Mg/Fe] ratio, which can\nbe used as a proxy of relative age. This key relation is essential to constrain\nthe formation mechanisms of the disc stellar populations as well as the cooling\nprocesses. We used the recommended parameters and chemical abundances of 7800\nFGK Milky Way field stars from the second internal data release of the Gaia-ESO\nSurvey. These stars were observed with the GIRAFFE spectrograph, and cover a\nlarge spatial volume (6+0.2dex. First, the velocity\ndispersion increases with [Mg/Fe] at all [Fe/H] ratios for the thin-disc stars,\nand then it decreases for the thick-disc at the highest [Mg/Fe] abundances.\nSimilar trends are observed within the errors for the azimuthal velocity\ndispersion, while a continuous increase with [Mg/Fe] is observed for the\nvertical velocity dispersion. The velocity dispersion decrease agrees with\nprevious measurements of the RAVE survey, although it is observed here for a\ngreater metallicity interval and a larger spatial volume. We confirm the\nexistence of [Mg/Fe]-rich thick-disc stars with cool kinematics in the\ngenerally turbulent context of the primitive Galactic disc. This is discussed\nin the framework of the different disc formation scenarios. Guiglion_2015 Guiglion et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1509.05271
840 1508.05942 2015-08-24 Young-Wook Lee, Seok-Joo Joo, Chul Chung The Milky Way without X: An alternative interpretation of the double red clump in the Galactic bulge The presence of two red clumps (RCs) in high latitude fields of the Milky Way\nbulge is interpreted as evidence for an X-shaped structure originated from the\nbar instability. Here we show, however, that this double RC phenomenon is more\nlikely to be another manifestation of multiple populations observed in globular\nclusters (GCs) in the metal-rich regime. As in the bulge GC Terzan 5, the\nhelium enhanced second generation stars (G2) in the classical bulge component\nof the Milky Way are placed on the bright RC, which is about 0.5 mag brighter\nthan the normal RC originated from the first generation stars (G1), producing\nthe observed double RC. In a composite bulge, where a classical bulge can\ncoexist with a boxy pseudo bulge, our models can also reproduce key\nobservations, such as the dependence of the double RC feature on metallicity\nand Galactic latitude and longitude. If confirmed by Gaia trigonometric\nparallax distances, this would indicate that the Milky Way bar is not\nsufficiently buckled to form the X-shaped structure in the bulge, and suggest\nthat the early-type galaxies would be similarly prevailed by super-helium-rich\nsubpopulation. Lee_2015 Lee et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1508.05942
841 1508.03736 2015-08-15 Paola Re Fiorentin, Mario G. Lattanzi, Alessandro Spagna, Anna Curir New Signatures of the Milky Way Formation in the Local Halo and Inner Halo Streamers in the Era of Gaia We explore the vicinity of the Milky Way through the use of\nspectro-photometric data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey and high-quality\nproper motions derived from multi-epoch positions extracted from the Guide Star\nCatalogue II database. In order to identify and characterise streams as relics\nof the Milky Way formation, we start with classifying, select, and study $2417$\nsubdwarfs with $\rm{[Fe/H] < -1.5}$ up to $3$ kpc away from the Sun as tracers\nof the local halo system. Then, through phase-space analysis, we find\nstatistical evidence of five discrete kinematic overdensities among $67$ of the\nfastest-moving stars, and compare them to high-resolution N-body simulations of\nthe interaction between a Milky-Way like galaxy and orbiting dwarf galaxies\nwith four representative cases of merging histories. The observed overdensities\ncan be interpreted as fossil substructures consisting of streamers torn from\ntheir progenitors, such progenitors appear to be satellites on prograde and\nretrograde orbits on different inclinations. In particular, of the five\ndetected overdensities, two appear to be associated, yelding twenty-one\nadditional main-sequence members, with the stream of Helmi et al. (1999) that\nour analysis confirms on a high inclination prograde orbit. The three newly\nidentified kinematic groups could be associated with the retrograde streams\ndetected by Dinescu (2002) and Kepley et al. (2007), whatever their origin, the\nprogenitor(s) would be on retrograde orbit(s) and inclination(s) within the\nrange $10^{\circ} \div 60^{\circ}$. Finally, we use our simulations to\ninvestigate the impact of observational errors and compare the current picture\nto the promising prospect of highly improved data expected from the Gaia\nmission. Fiorentin_2015 Fiorentin et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1508.03736
842 1507.08066 2015-07-29 G. Kordopatis, R. F. G. Wyse, G. Gilmore, A. Recio-Blanco, P. de Laverny, V. Hill, V. Adibekyan, U. Heiter, I. Minchev, B. Famaey, T. Bensby, S. Feltzing, G. Guiglion, A. J. Korn, S. Mikolaitis, A. Vallenari, A. Bayo, G. Carraro, E. Flaccomio, E. Franciosini, A. Hourihane, P. Jofre, S. E. Koposov, C. Lardo, J. Lewis, K. Lind, L. Magrini, L. Morbidelli, E. Pancino, S. Randich, G. G. Sacco, C. C. Worley, S. Zaggia The Gaia-ESO Survey: Characterisation of the [alpha/Fe] sequences in the Milky Way discs We investigate, using the Gaia-ESO Survey internal Data-Release 2, the\nproperties of the double sequence of the Milky Way discs (defined chemically as\nthe high-alpha and low-alpha populations), and discuss their compatibility with\ndiscs defined by other means such as metallicity, kinematics or positions.\n This investigation uses two different approaches: in velocity space for stars\nlocated in the extended Solar neighbourhood, and in chemical space for stars at\ndifferent ranges of Galactocentric radii and heights from the plane. The\nseparation we find in velocity space allows us to investigate, in a novel\nmanner, the extent in metallicity of each of the two sequences, identifying\nthem with the two discs, without making any assumption about the shape of their\nmetallicity distribution functions. Then, using the separation in chemical\nspace, we characterise the spatial variation of the slopes of the [alpha/Fe] -\n[Fe/H] sequences for the thick and thin discs and the way in which the relative\nproportions of the two discs change across the Galaxy.\n We find that the thick disc (high-alpha sequence), extends up to [Fe/H]~ +0.2\nand the thin disc (low-alpha sequence), at least down to [Fe/H]~ -0.8. Radial\nand vertical gradients in alpha-abundances are found for the thin disc, with\nmild spatial variations in its [alpha/Fe] - [Fe/H] paths, whereas for the thick\ndisc we do not detect any such spatial variations.\n The small variations in the spatial [alpha/Fe] - [Fe/H] paths of the thin\ndisc do not allow us to distinguish between formation models of this structure.\nOn the other hand, the lack of radial gradients and [alpha/Fe] - [Fe/H]\nvariations for the thick disc indicate that the mechanism responsible for the\nmixing of the metals in the young Galaxy (e.g. radial stellar migration or\nturbulent gaseous disc) was more efficient before the (present) thin disc\nstarted forming. Kordopatis_2015 Kordopatis et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1507.08066
843 1507.04353 2015-07-15 Teresa Antoja, Cecilia Mateu, Luis Aguilar, Francesca Figueras, Erika Antiche, Fabiola Hernandez-Perez, Anthony Brown, Octavio Valenzuela, Antonio Aparicio, Sebastian Hidalgo, Hector Velazquez Detection of satellite remnants in the Galactic Halo with Gaia III. Detection limits for Ultra Faint Dwarf Galaxies We present a method to identify Ultra Faint Dwarf Galaxy (UFDG) candidates in\nthe halo of the Milky Way using the future Gaia catalogue and we explore its\ndetection limits and completeness. The method is based on the Wavelet Transform\nand searches for over-densities in the combined space of sky coordinates and\nproper motions, using kinematics in the search for the first time. We test the\nmethod with a Gaia mock catalogue that has the Gaia Universe Model Snapshot\n(GUMS) as a background, and use a library of around 30 000 UFDGs simulated as\nPlummer spheres with a single stellar population. For the UFDGs we use a wide\nrange of structural and orbital parameters that go beyond the range spanned by\nreal systems, where some UFDGs may remain undetected. We characterize the\ndetection limits as function of the number of observable stars by Gaia in the\nUFDGs with respect to that of the background and their apparent sizes in the\nsky and proper motion planes. We find that the addition of proper motions in\nthe search improves considerably the detections compared to a photometric\nsurvey at the same magnitude limit. Our experiments suggest that Gaia will be\nable to detect UFDGs that are similar to some of the known UFDGs even if the\nlimit of Gaia is around 2 magnitudes brighter than that of SDSS, with the\nadvantage of having a full-sky catalogue. We also see that Gaia could even find\nsome UFDGs that have lower surface brightness than the SDSS limit. Antoja_2015 Antoja et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1507.04353
844 1507.00027 2015-06-30 P. Jofré, U. Heiter, C. Soubiran, S. Blanco-Cuaresma, T. Masseron, T. Nordlander, L. Chemin, C. C. Worley, S. Van Eck, A. Hourihane, G. Gilmore, V. Adibekyan, M. Bergemann, T. Cantat-Gaudin, E. Delgado-Mena, J. I. González Hernández, G. Guiglion, C. Lardo, P. de Laverny, K. Lind, L. Magrini, S. Mikolaitis, D. Montes, E. Pancino, A. Recio-Blanco, R. Sordo, S. Sousa, H. M. Tabernero, A. Vallenari Gaia FGK benchmark stars: abundances of alpha and iron-peak elements In the current era of large spectroscopic surveys of the Milky Way, reference\nstars for calibrating astrophysical parameters and chemical abundances are of\nparamount importance. We determine elemental abundances of Mg, Si, Ca, Sc, Ti,\nV, Cr, Mn, Co and Ni for our predefined set of Gaia FGK benchmark stars. By\nanalysing high-resolution and high-signal to noise spectra taken from several\narchive datasets, we combined results of eight different methods to determine\nabundances on a line-by-line basis. We perform a detailed homogeneous analysis\nof the systematic uncertainties, such as differential versus absolute abundance\nanalysis, as well as we assess errors due to NLTE and the stellar parameters in\nour final abundances. Our results are provided by listing final abundances and\nthe different sources of uncertainties, as well as line-by-line and\nmethod-by-method abundances. The Gaia FGK benchmark stars atmospheric\nparameters are already being widely used for calibration of several pipelines\napplied to different surveys. With the added reference abundances of 10\nelements this set is very suitable to calibrate the chemical abundances\nobtained by these pipelines. Jofré_2015 Jofré et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1507.00027
845 1412.0699 2015-06-17 C. K. Rosslowe, P. A. Crowther Spatial distribution of Galactic Wolf-Rayet stars and implications for the global population We construct revised near-infrared absolute magnitude calibrations for 126\nGalactic Wolf-Rayet (WR) stars at known distances, based in part upon recent\nlarge scale spectroscopic surveys. Application to 246 WR stars located in the\nfield, permits us to map their galactic distribution. As anticipated, WR stars\ngenerally lie in the thin disk (~40pc half width at half maximum) between\ngalactocentric radii 3.5-10kpc, in accordance with other star formation\ntracers. We highlight 12 WR stars located at vertical distances of >300pc from\nthe midplane. Analysis of the radial variation in WR subtypes exposes a\nubiquitously higher N_{WC}/N_{WN} ratio than predicted by stellar evolutionary\nmodels accounting for rotation. Models for non-rotating stars or accounting for\nclose binary evolution are more consistent with observations. We consolidate\ninformation acquired about the known WR content of the Milky Way to build a\nsimple model of the complete population. We derive observable quantities over a\nrange of wavelengths, allowing us to estimate a total number of 1200(+300,-100)\nGalactic WR stars, implying an average duration of ~0.25Myr for the WR phase at\nthe current Milky Way star formation rate. Of relevance to future spectroscopic\nsurveys, we use this model WR population to predict follow-up spectroscopy to\nK_S ~ 13 mag will be necessary to identify 95% of Galactic WR stars. We\nanticipate that ESA's Gaia mission will make few additional WR star discoveries\nvia low-resolution spectroscopy, though will significantly refine existing\ndistance determinations. Appendix A provides a complete inventory of 322\nGalactic WR stars discovered since the VIIth catalogue (313 including Annex),\nincluding a revised nomenclature scheme. Rosslowe_2015 Rosslowe and Crowther 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1412.0699
846 1410.2243 2015-06-12 Mariangela Lisanti, David N. Spergel, Piero Madau Signatures of Kinematic Substructure in the Galactic Stellar Halo Tidal debris from infalling satellites can leave observable structure in the\nphase-space distribution of the Galactic halo. Such substructure can be\nmanifest in the spatial and/or velocity distributions of the stars in the halo.\nThis paper focuses on a class of substructure that is purely kinematic in\nnature, with no accompanying spatial features. To study its properties, we use\na simulated stellar halo created by dynamically populating the Via Lactea II\nhigh-resolution N-body simulation with stars. A significant fraction of the\nstars in the inner halo of Via Lactea share a common speed and metallicity,\ndespite the fact that they are spatially diffuse. We argue that this kinematic\nsubstructure is a generic feature of tidal debris from older mergers and may\nexplain the detection of radial-velocity substructure in the inner halo made by\nthe Sloan Extension for Galactic Understanding and Exploration. The GAIA\nsatellite, which will provide the proper motions of an unprecedented number of\nstars, should further characterize the kinematic substructure in the inner\nhalo. Our study of the Via Lactea simulation suggests that the stellar halo can\nbe used to map the speed distribution of the local dark-matter halo, which has\nimportant consequences for dark-matter direct-detection experiments. Lisanti_2015 Lisanti et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1410.2243
847 1505.07858 2015-05-28 J. R. Neeley, M. Marengo, G. Bono, V. F. Braga, M. Dall'Ora, P. B. Stetson, I. Ferraro, W. L. Freedman, G. Iannicola, B. F. Madore, N. Matsunaga, A. Monson, S. E. Persson, V. Scowcroft, M. Seibert On the distance of the globular cluster M4 (NGC 6121) using RR Lyrae stars: II. Mid-infrared period-luminosity relations New mid-infrared period-luminosity (PL) relations are presented for \rrl{}\nvariables in the globular cluster M4 (NGC 6121). Accurate photometry was\nobtained for 37 \rrl{} variables using observations from the Infrared Array\nCamera onboard the Spitzer Space Telescope. The dispersion of M4's PL relations\nis 0.056, and the uncertainty in the slope is 0.11 mag. Additionally,\nweestablished calibrated PL relations at 3.6 and 4.5~\micron{} using published\nHubble Space Telescopegeometric parallaxes of five Galactic \rrl{} stars. The\nresulting band-averaged distance modulus for M4 is $ \mu = 11.399 \pm 0.007\n\textrm{(stat)} \pm 0.080 \textrm{(syst)} \pm 0.015 \textrm{(cal)} \pm 0.020\n\textrm{(ext)}$. The systematic uncertainty will be greatly reduced when\nparallaxes of more stars become available from the GAIA mission. Optical and\ninfrared period-color (PC) relations are also presented, and the lack of a MIR\nPC relation suggests that \rrl{} stars are not affected by CO absorptionin the\n4.5~\micron{} band. Neeley_2015 Neeley et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1505.07858
848 1505.04039 2015-05-15 L. Magrini, S. Randich, P. Donati, A. Bragaglia, V. Adibekyan, D. Romano, R. Smiljanic, S. Blanco-Cuaresma, G. Tautvaisiene, E. Friel, J. Overbeek, H. Jacobson, T. Cantat-Gaudin, A. Vallenari, R. Sordo, E. Pancino, D. Geisler, I. San Roman, S. Villanova, A. Casey, A. Hourihane, C. C. Worley, P. Francois, G. Gilmore, T. Bensby, E. Flaccomio, A. J. Korn, A. Recio-Blanco, G. Carraro, M. T. Costado, E. Franciosini, U. Heiter, P. Jofree, C. Lardo, P. de Laverny, L. Monaco, L. Morbidelli, G. Sacco, S. G. Sousa, S. Zaggia The Gaia-ESO Survey: Insights on the inner-disc evolution from open clusters Context. The inner disc, linking the thin disc with the bulge, has been\nsomehow neglected in the past because of intrinsic difficulties in its study,\ndue, e.g., to crowding and high extinction. Open clusters located in the inner\ndisc are among the best tracers of its chemistry at different ages and\ndistances. Aims. We analyse the chemical patterns of four open clusters located\nwithin 7 kpc of the Galactic Centre and of field stars to infer the properties\nof the inner disc with the Gaia-ESO survey idr2/3 data release. Methods. We\nderive the parameters of the newly observed cluster, Berkeley 81, finding an\nage of about 1 Gyr and a Galactocentric distance of 5.4 kpc. We construct the\nchemical patterns of clusters and we compare them with those of field stars in\nthe Solar neighbourhood and in the inner-disc samples. Results. Comparing the\nthree populations we observe that inner-disc clusters and field stars are both,\non average, enhanced in [O/Fe], [Mg/Fe] and [Si/Fe]. Using the idr2/3 results\nof M67, we estimate the non-local thermodynamic equilibrium (NLTE) effect on\nthe abundances of Mg and Si in giant stars. After empirically correcting for\nNLTE effects, we note that NGC 6705 and Be 81 still have a high [{\alpha}/Fe].\nConclusions. The location of the four open clusters and of the field population\nreveals that the evolution of the metallicity [Fe/H] and of [alpha/Fe] can be\nexplained within the framework of a simple chemical evolution model: both\n[Fe/H] and [{\alpha}/Fe] of Trumpler 20 and of NGC 4815 are in agreement with\nexpectations from a simple chemical evolution model. On the other hand, NGC\n6705, and at a lower level Berkeley 81, have higher [{\alpha}/Fe] than expected\nfor their ages, location in the disc, and metallicity. These differences might\noriginate from local enrichment processes as explained in the inhomogeneous\nevolution framework. Magrini_2015 Magrini et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1505.04039
849 1505.02598 2015-05-11 A. Sollima, H. Baumgardt, A. Zocchi, E. Balbinot, M. Gieles, V. Henault-Brunet, A. L. Varri Biases in the determination of dynamical parameters of star clusters: today and in the Gaia era The structural and dynamical properties of star clusters are generally\nderived by means of the comparison between steady-state analytic models and the\navailable observables. With the aim of studying the biases of this approach, we\nfitted different analytic models to simulated observations obtained from a\nsuite of direct N-body simulations of star clusters in different stages of\ntheir evolution and under different levels of tidal stress to derive mass, mass\nfunction and degree of anisotropy. We find that masses can be\nunder/over-estimated up to 50% depending on the degree of relaxation reached by\nthe cluster, the available range of observed masses and distances of radial\nvelocity measures from the cluster center and the strength of the tidal field.\nThe mass function slope appears to be better constrainable and less sensitive\nto model inadequacies unless strongly dynamically evolved clusters and a\nnon-optimal location of the measured luminosity function are considered. The\ndegree and the characteristics of the anisotropy developed in the N-body\nsimulations are not adequately reproduced by popular analytic models and can be\ndetected only if accurate proper motions are available. We show how to reduce\nthe uncertainties in the mass, mass-function and anisotropy estimation and\nprovide predictions for the improvements expected when Gaia proper motions will\nbe available in the near future. Sollima_2015 Sollima et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1505.02598
850 1504.07916 2015-04-29 Sergey E. Koposov, Andrew R. Casey, Vasily Belokurov, James R. Lewis, Gerard Gilmore, Clare Worley, Anna Hourihane, T. Bensby, A. Bragaglia, M. Bergemann, G. Carraro, E. Flaccomio, U. Heiter, V. Hill, P. Jofre, P. de Laverny, L. Monaco, L. Sbordone, S. Mikolaitis, N. Ryde Kinematics and chemistry of recently discovered Reticulum 2 and Horologium 1 dwarf galaxies Photometry alone is not sufficient to unambiguously distinguish between\nultra-faint star clusters and dwarf galaxies because of their overlap in\nmorphological properties. Here we report on VLT/GIRAFFE spectra of candidate\nmember stars in two recently discovered ultra-faint satellites Reticulum 2 and\nHorologium 1, obtained as part of the ongoing Gaia-ESO Survey. We identify 18\nmembers in Reticulum 2 and 5 in Horologium 1. We find Reticulum 2 to have a\nvelocity dispersion of ~3.22 km/s, implying a M/L ratio of ~ 500. We have\ninferred stellar parameters for all candidates and we find Reticulum 2 to have\na mean metallicity of [Fe/H] = -2.46+/-0.1, with an intrinsic dispersion of ~\n0.29, and is alpha-enhanced to the level of [alpha/Fe]~0.4. We conclude that\nReticulum 2 is a dwarf galaxy. We also report on the serendipitous discovery of\nfour stars in a previously unknown stellar substructure near Reticulum 2 with\n[Fe/H] ~ -2 and V_hel ~ 220 km/s, far from the systemic velocity of Reticulum\n2. For Horologium 1 we infer a velocity dispersion of 4.9^{+2.8}_{-0.9} km/s\nand a consequent M/L ratio of ~ 600, leading us to conclude that Horologium 1\nis also a dwarf galaxy. Horologium 1 is slightly more metal-poor than Reticulum\n2 [Fe/H] = -2.76 +/- 0.1 and is similarly alpha-enhanced: [alpha/Fe] ~ 0.3.\nDespite a large error-bar, we also measure a significant spread of\nmetallicities of 0.17 dex which strengthen the evidence that Horologium 1 is\nindeed a dwarf galaxy. The line-of-sight velocity of Reticulum 2 is offset by\nsome 100 km/s from the prediction of the orbital velocity of the LMC, thus\nmaking its association with the Cloud uncertain. However, at the location of\nHorologium 1, both the backward integrated LMC's orbit and the LMC's halo are\npredicted to have radial velocities similar to that of the dwarf. Therefore, it\nis likely that Horologium 1 is or once was a member of the Magellanic Family. Koposov_2015 Koposov et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1504.07916
851 1504.03497 2015-04-14 I. San Roman, C. Muñoz, D. Geisler, S. Villanova, N. Kacharov, A. Koch, G. Carraro, G. Tautvaišiene, A. Vallenari, E. J. Alfaro, T. Bensby, E. Flaccomio, P. Francois, A. J. Korn, E. Pancino, A. Recio-Blanco, R. Smiljanic, M. Bergemann, M. T. Costado, F. Damiani, U. Heiter, A. Hourihane, P. Jofré, C. Lardo, P. de Laverny, T. Masseron, L. Morbidelli, L. Sbordone, S. G. Sousa, C. C. Worley, S. Zaggia The Gaia-ESO Survey: Detailed Abundances in the Metal-poor Globular Cluster NGC 4372 We present the abundance analysis for a sample of 7 red giant branch stars in\nthe metal-poor globular cluster NGC 4372 based on UVES spectra acquired as part\nof the Gaia-ESO Survey. This is the first extensive study of this cluster from\nhigh resolution spectroscopy. We derive abundances of O, Na, Mg, Al, Si, Ca,\nSc, Ti, Fe, Cr, Ni, Y, Ba, and La. We find a metallicity of [Fe/H] = -2.19\n$\pm$ 0.03 and find no evidence for a metallicity spread. This metallicity\nmakes NGC 4372 one of the most metal-poor galactic globular clusters. We also\nfind an {\alpha}-enhancement typical of halo globular clusters at this\nmetallicity. Significant spreads are observed in the abundances of light\nelements. In particular we find a Na-O anti-correlation. Abundances of O are\nrelatively high compared with other globular clusters. This could indicate that\nNGC 4372 was formed in an environment with high O for its metallicity. A Mg-Al\nspread is also present which spans a range of more than 0.5 dex in Al\nabundances. Na is correlated with Al and Mg abundances at a lower significance\nlevel. This pattern suggests that the Mg-Al burning cycle is active. This\nbehavior can also be seen in giant stars of other massive, metal-poor clusters.\nA relation between light and heavy s-process elements has been identified. Roman_2015 Roman et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1504.03497
852 1504.02481 2015-04-09 G. R. Ruchti, J. I. Read, S. Feltzing, A. M. Serenelli, P. McMillan, K. Lind, T. Bensby, M. Bergemann, M. Asplund, A. Vallenari, E. Flaccomio, E. Pancino, A. J. Korn, A. Recio-Blanco, A. Bayo, G. Carraro, M. T. Costado, F. Damiani, U. Heiter, A. Hourihane, P. Jofre, G. Kordopatis, C. Lardo, P. de Laverny, L. Monaco, L. Morbidelli, L. Sbordone, C. C. Worley, S. Zaggia The Gaia-ESO Survey: a quiescent Milky Way with no significant dark/stellar accreted disc According to our current cosmological model, galaxies like the Milky Way are\nexpected to experience many mergers over their lifetimes. The most massive of\nthe merging galaxies will be dragged towards the disc-plane, depositing stars\nand dark matter into an accreted disc structure. In this work, we utilize the\nchemo-dynamical template developed in Ruchti et al. to hunt for accreted stars.\nWe apply the template to a sample of 4,675 stars in the third internal data\nrelease from the Gaia-ESO Spectroscopic Survey. We find a significant component\nof accreted halo stars, but find no evidence of an accreted disc component.\nThis suggests that the Milky Way has had a rather quiescent merger history\nsince its disc formed some 8-10 billion years ago and therefore possesses no\nsignificant dark matter disc. Ruchti_2015 Ruchti et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1504.02481
853 1411.7386 2015-03-30 Guido R. I. Moyano Loyola, Chris Flynn, Jarrod R. Hurley, Brad K. Gibson Tracking Cluster Debris (TraCD)- I. Dissolution of clusters and searching the solar cradle The capability to reconstruct dissolved stellar systems in dynamical and\nchemical space is a key factor in improving our understanding of the evolution\nof the Milky Way. Here we concentrate on the dynamical aspect and given that a\nsignificant portion of the stars in the Milky Way have been born in stellar\nassociations or clusters that have lived a few Myr up to several Gyr, we\nfurther restrict our attention to the evolution of star clusters. We have\ncarried out our simulations in two steps: (1) we create a simulation of\ndissolution and mixing processes which yields a close fit to the present-day\nMilky Way dynamics and (2) we have evolved three sets of stellar clusters with\nmasses of 400, 1000 and 15000 M$_{\odot}$ to dissolution. The birth location of\nthese sets was 4, 6, 8 and 10 kpc for the 400 and 1000 M$_{\odot}$ clusters and\n4, 6, 8, 10 and 12 kpc for the 15000 M$_{\odot}$. We have focused our efforts\non studying the state of the escapers from these clusters after 4.5 Gyr of\nevolution with particular attention to stars that reach the Solar annulus, i.e.\n7.5 $\le$ R$_{\rm{gc}}$ $\le$ 8.5 kpc. We give results for Solar twins and\nsiblings over a wide range of radii and cluster masses for two dissolution\nmechanisms. From kinematics alone, we conclude that the Sun was $\sim$50 per\ncent more likely to have been born near its current Galactocentric radius,\nrather than have migrated (radially) $\sim$2 kpc since birth. We conclude our\nanalysis by calculating magnitudes and colours of our single stars for\ncomparison with the samples that the $Gaia$, $Gaia$-ESO and GALAH-AAO surveys\nwill obtain. In terms of reconstructing dissolved star clusters we find that on\nshort time-scales we cannot rely on kinematic evolution alone and thus it will\nbe necessary to extend our study to include information on chemical space. Loyola_2015 Loyola et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1411.7386
854 1403.309 2015-03-24 S. Blanco-Cuaresma, C. Soubiran, P. Jofré, U. Heiter The Gaia FGK Benchmark Stars - High resolution spectral library Context. An increasing number of high resolution stellar spectra is available\ntoday thanks to many past and ongoing spectroscopic surveys. Consequently,\nnumerous methods have been developed in order to perform an automatic spectral\nanalysis on a massive amount of data. When reviewing published results, biases\narise and they need to be addressed and minimized.\n Aims. We are providing a homogeneous library with a common set of calibration\nstars (known as the Gaia FGK Benchmark Stars) that will allow to assess stellar\nanalysis methods and calibrate spectroscopic surveys.\n Methods. High resolution and signal-to-noise spectra were compiled from\ndifferent instruments. We developed an automatic process in order to homogenize\nthe observed data and assess the quality of the resulting library.\n Results. We built a high quality library that will facilitate the assessment\nof spectral analyses and the calibration of present and future spectroscopic\nsurveys. The automation of the process minimizes the human subjectivity and\nensures reproducibility. Additionally, it allows us to quickly adapt the\nlibrary to specific needs that can arise from future spectroscopic analyses. Blanco-Cuaresma_2015 Blanco-Cuaresma et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1403.309
855 1502.05069 2015-02-17 Warren R. Brown, Jay Anderson, Oleg Y. Gnedin, Howard E. Bond, Margaret J. Geller, Scott J. Kenyon Proper Motions and Trajectories for 16 Extreme Runaway and Hypervelocity Stars We measure proper motions with the Hubble Space Telescope for 16 extreme\nradial velocity stars, mostly unbound B stars in the Milky Way halo. Twelve of\nthese stars have proper motions statistically consistent with zero, and thus\nhave radial trajectories statistically consistent with a Galactic center\n"hypervelocity star" origin. The trajectory of HE 0437-5439 is consistent with\nboth Milky Way and Large Magellanic Cloud origins. A Galactic center origin is\nexcluded at 3-sigma confidence for two of the lowest radial velocity stars in\nour sample, however. These two stars are probable disk runaways and provide\nevidence for ~500 km/s ejections from the disk. We also measure a significant\nproper motion for the unbound sdO star US 708. Its 1,000 km/s motion is in some\ntension with proposed supernova ejection models, but can be explained if US 708\nwas ejected from the stellar halo. In the future, we expect Gaia will better\nconstrain the origin of these remarkable unbound stars. Brown_2015 Brown et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1502.05069
856 1502.03934 2015-02-13 K. Lind, S. E. Koposov, C. Battistini, A. F. Marino, G. Ruchti, A. Serenelli, C. C. Worley, A. Alves-Brito, M. Asplund, P. S. Barklem, T. Bensby, M. Bergemann, S. Blanco-Cuaresma, A. Bragaglia, B. Edvardsson, S. Feltzing, P. Gruyters, U. Heiter, P. Jofre, A. J. Korn, T. Nordlander, N. Ryde, C. Soubiran, G. Gilmore, S. Randich, A. M. N. Ferguson, R. D. Jeffries, A. Vallenari, C. Allende Prieto, E. Pancino, A. Recio-Blanco, D. Romano, R. Smiljanic, M. Bellazzini, F. Damiani, V. Hill, P. de Laverny, R. J. Jackson, C. Lardo, S. Zaggia The Gaia-ESO Survey: A globular cluster escapee in the Galactic halo A small fraction of the halo field is made up of stars that share the light\nelement (Z<=13) anomalies characteristic of second generation globular cluster\n(GC) stars. The ejected stars shed light on the formation of the Galactic halo\nby tracing the dynamical history of the clusters, which are believed to have\nonce been more massive. Some of these ejected stars are expected to show strong\nAl enhancement at the expense of shortage of Mg, but until now no such star has\nbeen found. We search for outliers in the Mg and Al abundances of the few\nhundreds of halo field stars observed in the first eighteen months of the\nGaia-ESO public spectroscopic survey. One halo star at the base of the red\ngiant branch, here referred to as 22593757-4648029 is found to have\n[Mg/Fe]=-0.36+-0.04 and [Al/Fe]=0.99+-0.08, which is compatible with the most\nextreme ratios detected in GCs so far. We compare the orbit of 22593757-4648029\nto GCs of similar metallicity and find it unlikely that this star has been\ntidally stripped with low ejection velocity from any of the clusters. However,\nboth chemical and kinematic arguments render it plausible that the star has\nbeen ejected at high velocity from the anomalous GC omega Centauri within the\nlast few billion years. We cannot rule out other progenitor GCs, because some\nmay have disrupted fully, and the abundance and orbital data are inadequate for\nmany of those that are still intact. Lind_2015 Lind et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1502.03934
857 1502.03223 2015-02-11 M. Schultheis, G. Kordopatis, A. Recio-Blanco, P. de Laverny, V. Hill, G. Gilmore, E. J. Alfaro, M. T. Costado, T. Bensby, F. Damiani, S. Feltzing, E. Flaccomio, C. Lardo, P. Jofre, L. Prisinzano, S. Zaggia, F. Jimenez-Esteban, L. Morbidelli, A. C. Lanzafame, A. Hourihane, C. Worley, P. Francois The Gaia-ESO Survey: Tracing interstellar extinction Large spectroscopic surveys have enabled in the recent years the computation\nof three-dimensional interstellar extinction maps thanks to accurate stellar\natmospheric parameters and line-of-sight distances. Such maps are complementary\nto 3D maps extracted from photometry, allowing a more thorough study of the\ndust properties. Our goal is to use the high-resolution spectroscopic survey\nGaia-ESO in order to obtain with a good distance resolution the interstellar\nextinction and its dependency as a function of the environment and the\nGalactocentric position. We use the stellar atmospheric parameters of more than\n5000 stars, obtained from the Gaia-ESO survey second internal data release, and\ncombine them with optical (SDSS) and near-infrared (VISTA) photometry as well\nas different sets of theoretical stellar isochrones, in order to calculate\nline-of-sight extinction and distances. The extinction coefficients are then\ncompared with the literature to discuss their dependancy on the stellar\nparameters and position in the Galaxy. Within the errors of our method, our\nwork does not show that there is any dependence of the interstellar extinction\ncoefficient on the atmospheric parameters of the stars. We do not find any\nevidence of the variation of E(J-H)/E(J-K) with the angle from the Galactic\ncentre nor with Galactocentric distance. This suggests that we are dealing with\na uniform extinction law in the SDSS ugriz bands and the near-IR JHKs bands.\nTherefore, extinction maps using mean colour-excesses and assuming a constant\nextinction coefficient can be used without introducing any systematic errors. Schultheis_2015 Schultheis et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1502.03223
858 1502.02596 2015-02-09 Jamie C. Overbeek, Eileen D. Friel, Heather R. Jacobson, Christian I. Johnson, Catherine A. Pilachowski, Szabolcs Meszaros NGC 7789: An Open Cluster Case Study We have obtained high-resolution spectra of 32 giants in the open cluster NGC\n7789 using the Wisconsin-Indiana-Yale-NOAO Hydra spectrograph. We explore\ndifferences in atmospheric parameters and elemental abundances caused by the\nuse of the linelist developed for the Gaia-ESO Survey (GES) compared to one\nbased on Arcturus used in our previous work. [Fe/H] values decrease when using\nthe GES linelist instead of the Arcturus-based linelist; these differences are\nprobably driven by systematically lower (~ -0.1 dex) GES surface gravities.\nUsing the GES linelist we determine abundances for 10 elements - Fe, Mg, Si,\nCa, Ti, Na, Ni, Zr, Ba, and La. We find the cluster's average metallicity\n[Fe/H] = 0.03 +/- 0.07 dex, in good agreement with literature values, and a\nlower [Mg/Fe] abundance than has been reported before for this cluster (0.11\n+/- 0.05 dex). We also find the neutron-capture element barium to be highly\nenhanced - [Ba/Fe] = +0.48 +/- 0.08 - and disparate from cluster measurements\nof neutron-capture elements La and Zr (-0.08 +/- 0.05 and 0.08 +/- 0.08,\nrespectively). This is in accordance with recent discoveries of supersolar Ba\nenhancement in young clusters along with more modest enhancement of other\nneutron-capture elements formed in similar environments. Overbeek_2015 Overbeek et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1502.02596
859 1501.01969 2015-01-08 Jason A. S. Hunt, Daisuke Kawata, Robert J. J. Grand, Ivan Minchev, Stefano Pasetto, Mark Cropper The stellar kinematics of co-rotating spiral arms in Gaia mock observations We have observed an N-body/Smoothed Particle Hydrodynamics simulation of a\nMilky Way like barred spiral galaxy. We present a simple method that samples\nN-body model particles into mock Gaia stellar observations and takes into\naccount stellar populations, dust extinction and Gaia's science performance\nestimates. We examine the kinematics around a nearby spiral arm at a similar\nposition to the Perseus arm at three lines of sight in the disc plane;\n(l,b)=(90,0), (120,0) and (150,0) degrees. We find that the structure of the\npeculiar kinematics around the co-rotating spiral arm, which is found in Kawata\net al. (2014b), is still visible in the observational data expected to be\nproduced by Gaia despite the dust extinction and expected observational errors\nof Gaia. These observable kinematic signatures will enable testing whether the\nPerseus arm of the Milky Way is similar to the co-rotating spiral arms commonly\nseen in N-body simulations. Hunt_2015 Hunt et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1501.01969
860 1404.6534 2015-01-05 Robyn E. Sanderson, Amina Helmi, David W. Hogg Action-space clustering of tidal streams to infer the Galactic potential We present a new method for constraining the Milky Way halo gravitational\npotential by simultaneously fitting multiple tidal streams. This method\nrequires full three-dimensional positions and velocities for all stars to be\nfit, but does not require identification of any specific stream or\ndetermination of stream membership for any star. We exploit the principle that\nthe action distribution of stream stars is most clustered when the potential\nused to calculate the actions is closest to the true potential. Clustering is\nquantified with the Kullback-Leibler Divergence (KLD), which also provides\nconditional uncertainties for our parameter estimates. We show, for toy\nGaia-like data in a spherical isochrone potential, that maximizing the KLD of\nthe action distribution relative to a smoother distribution recovers the true\nvalues of the potential parameters. The precision depends on the observational\nerrors and the number of streams in the sample; using KIII giants as tracers,\nwe measure the enclosed mass at the average radius of the sample stars accurate\nto 3% and precise to 20-40%. Recovery of the scale radius is precise to 25%,\nand is biased 50% high by the small galactocentric distance range of stars in\nour mock sample (1-25 kpc, or about three scale radii, with mean 6.5 kpc).\nAbout 15 streams, with at least 100 stars per stream, are needed to obtain\nupper and lower bounds on the enclosed mass and scale radius when observational\nerrors are taken into account; 20-25 streams are required to stabilize the size\nof the confidence interval. If radial velocities are provided for stars out to\n100 kpc (10 scale radii), all parameters can be determined with 10% accuracy\nand 20% precision (1.3% accuracy in the case of the enclosed mass), underlining\nthe need for ground-based spectroscopic follow-up to complete the radial\nvelocity catalog for faint halo stars observed by Gaia. Sanderson_2015 Sanderson et al. 2015 https://arxiv.org/abs/1404.6534
861 1412.6628 2014-12-20 Haibo Yuan, Xiaowei Liu, Zhiying Huo, Maosheng Xiang, Yang Huang, Bingqiu Chen, Huihua Zhang, Ningchen Sun, Chun Wang, Huawei Zhang, Yongheng Zhao, Ali Luo, Jianrong Shi, Guoping Li, Hailong Yuan, Yiqiao Dong, Guangwei Li, Yonghui Hou, Yong Zhang LAMOST Spectroscopic Survey of the Galactic Anti-centre (LSS-GAC): target selection and the first release of value-added catalogues As a major component of the LAMOST Galactic surveys, the LAMOST Spectroscopic\nSurvey of the Galactic Anti-centre (LSS-GAC) aims to survey a significant\nvolume of the Galactic thin/thick discs and halo for a contiguous sky area of\nover 3,400 deg$^2$ centred on the Galactic anti-centre ($|b| \leq 30^{\circ}$,\n$150 \leq l \leq 210^{\circ}$), and obtain $\lambda\lambda$3700 -- 9000 low\nresolution ($R \sim 1,800$) spectra for a statistically complete sample of\n$\sim 3$\,M stars of all colours down to a limiting magnitued of $r$ $\sim$\n17.8\,mag (to 18.5\,mag for limited fields). Together with Gaia, the LSS-GAC\nwill yield a unique dataset to advance our understanding of the structure and\nassemblage history of the Galaxy, in particular its disk(s). In addition to the\nmain survey, the LSS-GAC will also target hundreds of thousands objects in the\nvicinity fields of M\,31 and M\,33 and survey a significant fraction (over a\nmillion) of randomly selected very bright stars (VB; $r \le 14$ mag) in the\nnorthern hemisphere. During the Pilot and the first year Regular Surveys of\nLAMOST, a total of 1,042,586 [750,867] spectra of a signal to noise ratio\nS/N(7450\AA) $\ge$ 10 [S/N(4650\AA) $\ge$ 10] have been collected. In this\npaper, we present a detailed description of the target selection algorithm,\nsurvey design, observations and the first data release of value-added\ncatalogues (including radial velocities, effective temperatures, surface\ngravities, metallicities, values of interstellar extinction, distances, proper\nmotions and orbital parameters) of the LSS-GAC. Yuan_2014 Yuan et al. 2014 https://arxiv.org/abs/1412.6628
862 1411.6389 2014-11-24 Merce Romero-Gomez, Francesca Figueras, Teresa Antoja, Hoda Abedi, Luis Aguilar The analysis of realistic Stellar Gaia mock catalogues. I. Red Clump Stars as tracers of the central bar In this first paper we simulate the population of disc Red Clump stars to be\nobserved by Gaia. We generate a set of test particles and we evolve it in a 3D\nbarred Milky Way like galactic potential. We assign physical properties of the\nRed Clump trace population and a realistic 3D interstellar extinction model. We\nadd Gaia observational constraints and an error model according to the\npre-commissioning scientific performance assessments. We present and analyse\ntwo mock catalogues, offered to the community, that are an excellent test bed\nfor testing tools being developed for the future scientific exploitation of\nGaia data. The first catalogue contains stars up to Gaia G 20, while the second\nis the subset containing Gaia radial velocity data with a maximum error of\nsigmaVr=10 kms. Here we present first attempts to characterise the density\nstructure of the Galactic bar in the Gaia space of observables. The Gaia large\nerrors in parallax and the high interstellar extinction in the inner parts of\nthe Galactic disc prevent us to model the bar overdensity. This result suggests\nthe need to combine Gaia and IR data to undertake such studies. We find that IR\nphotometric distances for this Gaia sample allow us to recover the Galactic bar\norientation angle with an accuracy of approximately 5 degrees. Romero-Gomez_2014 Romero-Gomez et al. 2014 https://arxiv.org/abs/1411.6389
863 1411.4886 2014-11-18 C. Lardo, E. Pancino, M. Bellazzini, A. Bragaglia, P. Donati, G. Gilmore, S. Randich, S. Feltzing, R. D. Jeffries, A. Vallenari, E. J. Alfaro, C. Allende Prieto, E. Flaccomio, S. E. Koposov, A. Recio-Blanco, M. Bergemann, G. Carraro, M. T. Costado, F. Damiani, A. Hourihane, P. Jofre, P. de Laverny, G. Marconi, T. Masseron, L. Morbidelli, G. G. Sacco, C. C.
