Aims: Using the specific yields for competing SN Ia\nscenarios, we aim to constrain the relative fractions of exploding\nnear-Chandrasekhar mass to sub-Chandrasekhar mass primary WDs in the Galaxy.\nMethods: We extract the Mn yields from three-dimensional thermonuclear\nsupernova simulations referring to different initial setups and progenitor\nchannels. We then compute the chemical evolution of Mn in the Solar\nneighborhood, assuming SNe Ia are made up of different relative fractions of\nthe considered explosion models. Results: We find that due to the entropy\ndependence of freeze-out yields from nuclear statistical equilibrium, [Mn/Fe]\nstrongly depends on the mass of the exploding WD, with near-Chandraskher mass\nWDs producing substantially higher [Mn/Fe] than sub-Chandrasekhar mass WDs. Of\nall nucleosynthetic sources potentially influencing the chemical evolution of\nMn, only explosion models involving the thermonuclear incineration of\nnear-Chandrasekhar mass WDs predict solar or super-solar [Mn/Fe]. Consequently,\nwe find in our chemical evolution calculations that the observed [Mn/Fe] in the\nSolar neighborhood at [Fe/H] > 0.0 cannot be reproduced without\nnear-Chandrasekhar mass SN Ia primaries. Assuming that 50 per cent of all SNe\nIa stem from explosive thermonuclear burning in near-Chandrasekhar mass WDs\nresults in a good match to data. Seitenzahl_2013 Seitenzahl et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1309.2397
908 1303.2667 2013-09-05 Alison Sills, Evert Glebbeek, Sourav Chatterjee, Frederic A. Rasio Mock Observations of Blue Stragglers in Globular Cluster Models We created artificial color-magnitude diagrams of Monte Carlo dynamical\nmodels of globular clusters, and then used observational methods to determine\nthe number of blue stragglers in those clusters. We compared these blue\nstragglers to various cluster properties, mimicking work that has been done for\nblue stragglers in Milky Way globular clusters to determine the dominant\nformation mechanism(s) of this unusual stellar population. We find that a\nmass-based prescription for selecting blue stragglers will choose approximately\ntwice as many blue stragglers than a selection criterion that was developed for\nobservations of real clusters. However, the two numbers of blue stragglers are\nwell-correlated, so either selection criterion can be used to characterize the\nblue straggler population of a cluster. We confirm previous results that the\nsimplified prescription for the evolution of a collision or merger product in\nthe BSE code overestimates their lifetimes. We show that our model blue\nstragglers follow similar trends with cluster properties (core mass, binary\nfraction, total mass, collision rate) as the true Milky Way blue stragglers, as\nlong as we restrict ourselves to model clusters with an initial binary fraction\nhigher than 5%. We also show that, in contrast to earlier work, the number of\nblue stragglers in the cluster core does have a weak dependence on the\ncollisional parameter Gamma in both our models and in Milky Way globular\nclusters. Sills_2013 Sills et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1303.2667
909 1309.1283 2013-09-05 A. Micali, F. Matteucci, D. Romano The Chemical Evolution of the Milky Way: the Three Infall Model We present a new chemical evolution model for the Galaxy that assumes three\nmain infall episodes of primordial gas for the formation of halo, thick and\nthin disk, respectively. We compare our results with selected data taking into\naccount NLTE effects. The most important parameters of the model are (i) the\ntimescale for gas accretion, (ii) the efficiency of star formation and (iii) a\nthreshold in the gas density for the star formation process, for each Galactic\ncomponent. We find that, in order to best fit the features of the solar\nneighbourhood, the halo and thick disk must form on short timescales (~0.2 and\n~1.25 Gyr, respectively), while a longer timescale is required for the\nthin-disk formation. The efficiency of star formation must be maximum (10\nGyr-1) during the thick-disk phase and minimum (1 Gyr-1) during the thin-disk\nformation. Also the threshold gas density for star formation is suggested to be\ndifferent in the three Galactic components. Our main conclusion is that in the\nframework of our model an independent episode of accretion of extragalactic\ngas, which gives rise to a burst of star formation, is fundamental to explain\nthe formation of the thick disk. We discuss our results in comparison to\nprevious studies and in the framework of modern galaxy formation theories. Micali_2013 Micali et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1309.1283
910 1309.0822 2013-09-03 Ryan Leaman, Don A. VandenBerg, J. Trevor Mendel The Bifurcated Age-Metallicity Relation of Milky Way Globular Clusters and its Implications For the Accretion History of the Galaxy We use recently derived ages for 61 Milky Way (MW) globular clusters (GCs) to\nshow that their age-metallicity relation (AMR) can be divided into two\ndistinct, parallel sequences at [Fe/H] $\ga -1.8$. Approximately one-third of\nthe clusters form an offset sequence that spans the full range in age ($\sim\n10.5$--13 Gyr), but is more metal rich at a given age by $\sim 0.6$ dex in\n[Fe/H]. All but one of the clusters in the offset sequence show orbital\nproperties that are consistent with membership in the MW disk. They are not\nsimply the most metal-rich GCs, which have long been known to have disk-like\nkinematics, but they are the most metal-rich clusters at all ages. The slope of\nthe mass-metallicity relation (MMR) for galaxies implies that the offset in\nmetallicity of the two branches of the AMR corresponds to a mass decrement of 2\ndex, suggesting host galaxy masses of $M_{*} \sim 10^{7-8} \msol$ for GCs that\nbelong to the more metal-poor AMR. We suggest that the metal-rich branch of the\nAMR consists of clusters that formed in-situ in the disk, while the metal-poor\nGCs were formed in relatively low-mass (dwarf) galaxies and later accreted by\nthe MW. The observed AMR of MW disk stars, and of the LMC, SMC and WLM dwarf\ngalaxies are shown to be consistent with this interpretation, and the relative\ndistribution of implied progenitor masses for the halo GC clusters is in\nexcellent agreement with the MW subhalo mass function predicted by simulations.\nA notable implication of the bifurcated AMR, is that the identical mean ages\nand spread in ages, for the metal rich and metal poor GCs are difficult to\nreconcile with an in-situ formation for the latter population. Leaman_2013 Leaman et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1309.0822
911 1309.0315 2013-09-02 Susanne Pfalzner, Thomas Kaczmarek The expansion of massive young star clusters - observation meets theory Most stars form as part of a star cluster. The most massive clusters in the\nMilky Way exist in two groups - loose and compact clusters - with significantly\ndifferent sizes at the end of the star formation process. After their formation\nboth types of clusters expand up to a factor 10-20 within the first 20 Myr. Gas\nexpulsion at the end of the star formation process is usually regarded as only\npossible process that can lead to such an expansion.We investigate the effect\nof gas expulsion by a direct comparison between numerical models and observed\nclusters concentrating on clusters with masses >10^3 M(sun). For these clusters\nthe initial conditions before gas expulsion, the characteristic cluster\ndevelopment, its dependence on cluster mass, and the star formation efficiency\n(SFE) are investigated. We perform N-body simulations of the cluster expansion\nprocess after gas expulsion and compare the results with observations. We find\nthat the expansion processes of the observed loose and compact massive clusters\nare driven by completely different physical processes. As expected the\nexpansion of loose massive clusters is largely driven by the gas loss due to\nthe low SFE of ~30%. One new revelation is that all the observed massive\nclusters of this group seem to have a very similar size of 1-3 pc at the onset\nof expansion. It is demonstrated that compact clusters have a much higher\neffective SFE of 60-70% and are as a result much less affected by gas\nexpulsion. Their expansion is mainly driven by stellar ejections caused by\ninteractions between the cluster members. The reason why ejections are so\nefficient in driving cluster expansion is that they occur dominantly from the\ncluster centre and over an extended period of time. Thus during the first 10\nMyr the internal dynamics of loose and compact clusters differ fundamentally. Pfalzner_2013a Pfalzner and Kaczmarek 2013a https://arxiv.org/abs/1309.0315
912 1308.4727 2013-08-21 A. K. Dambis, L. N. Berdnikov, A. Y. Kniazev, V. V. Kravtsov, A. S. Rastorguev, R. Sefako, O. V. Vozyakova RR Lyrae variables: visual and infrared luminosities, intrinsic colours, and kinematics We use UCAC4 proper motions and WISE W1-band apparent magnitudes\nintensity-mean for almost 400 field RR Lyrae variables to determine the\nparameters of the velocity distribution of Galactic RR Lyrae population and\nconstrain the zero points of the metallicity- relation and those of the\nperiod-metallicity--band and period-metallicity--band luminosity\nrelations via statistical parallax. We find the mean velocities of the halo-\nand thick-disc RR Lyrae populations in the solar neighbourhood to be (U0(Halo),\nV0(Halo), W0(Halo)) = (-7 +/- 9, -214 +/- 10, -10 +/- 6) km/s and (U0(Disc),\nV0(Disc), W0(Disc)) =(-13 +/- 7, -37 +/- 6, -17 +/- 4) km/s, respectively, and\nthe corresponding components of the velocity-dispersion ellipsoids, (sigma\nVR(Halo), sigma Vphi(Halo), sigma Vtheta(Halo)) = (153 +/- 9, 101 +/- 6, 96 +/-\n5) km/s and (sigma VR(Disc), sigma Vphi(Disc), sigma Vtheta(Disc)) = (46 +/- 7,\n37 +/- 5, 27 +/- 4) km/s, respectively. The fraction of thick-disc stars is\nestimated at 0.22 +/- 0.03. The corrected IR period-metallicity-luminosity\nrelations are = -0.769 +0.088 [Fe/H]- 2.33 mathoprm log PF and =\n-0.825 + 0.088 [Fe/H] -2.33 mathoprm log PF, and the optical\nmetallicity-luminosity relation, [Fe/H]-, is = +1.094 + 0.232 [Fe/H],\nwith a standard error of +/- 0.089, implying an LMC distance modulus of 18.32\n+/- 0.09, a solar Galactocentric distance of 7.73 +/- 0.36 kpc, and the M31 and\nM33 distance moduli of DM(M31) = 24.24 +/- 0.09 (D = 705 +/- 30 kpc) and\nDM(M33) = 24.36 +/- 0.09 (D = 745 +/- 31 kpc), respectively. Extragalactic\ndistances calibrated with our RR Lyrae star luminosity scale imply a Hubble\nconstant of ~80 km/s/Mpc. Our results suggest marginal prograde rotation for\nthe population of halo RR Lyraes in the Milky Way. Dambis_2013 Dambis et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1308.4727
913 1308.4181 2013-08-19 Warren R. Brown, Judith G. Cohen, Margaret J. Geller, Scott J. Kenyon The Origin of HVS17, an Unbound Main Sequence B Star at 50 kpc We analyze Keck ESI spectroscopy of HVS17, a B-type star traveling with a\nGalactic rest frame radial velocity of +445 km/s in the outer halo of the Milky\nWay. HVS17 has the projected rotation of a main sequence B star and is\nchemically peculiar, with solar iron abundance and sub-solar alpha abundance.\nComparing measured T_eff and logg with stellar evolution tracks implies that\nHVS17 is a 3.91 +-0.09 Msun, 153 +-9 Myr old star at a Galactocentric distance\nof r=48.5 +-4.6 kpc. The time between its formation and ejection significantly\nexceeds 10 Myr and thus is difficult to reconcile with any Galactic disk\nrunaway scenario involving massive stars. The observations are consistent, on\nthe other hand, with a hypervelocity star ejection from the Galactic center. We\nshow that Gaia proper motion measurements will easily discriminate between a\ndisk and Galactic center origin, thus allowing us to use HVS17 as a test\nparticle to probe the shape of the Milky Way's dark matter halo. Brown_2013 Brown et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1308.4181
914 1308.3706 2013-08-16 Ryan Goldsbury, Jeremy Heyl, Harvey Richer Quantifying mass segregation and new core radii for 54 milky way globular clusters We present core radii for 54 Milky Way globular clusters determined by\nfitting King-Michie models to cumulative projected star count distributions. We\nfind that fitting star counts rather than surface brightness profiles produces\nresults that differ significantly due to the presence of mass segregation. The\nsample in each cluster is further broken down into various mass groups, each of\nwhich is fit independently, allowing us to determine how the concentration of\neach cluster varies with mass. The majority of the clusters in our sample show\ngeneral agreement with the standard picture that more massive stars will be\nmore centrally concentrated. We find that core radius vs. stellar mass can be\nfit with a two parameter power-law. The slope of this power-law is a value that\ndescribes the amount of mass segregation present in the cluster, and is\nmeasured independently of our distance from the cluster. This value correlates\nstrongly with the core relaxation time and physical size of each cluster.\nSupplementary figures are also included showing the best fits and likelihood\ncontours of fit parameters for all 54 clusters. Goldsbury_2013 Goldsbury et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1308.3706
915 1308.3249 2013-08-14 B. Lemasle, P. Francois, K. Genovali, V. V. Kovtyukh, G. Bono, L. Inno, C. D. Laney, L. Kaper, M. Bergemann, M. Fabrizio, N. Matsunaga, S. Pedicelli, F. Primas, M. Romaniello Galactic abundance gradients from Cepheids: alpha and heavy elements in the outer disk Context: Galactic abundance gradients set strong constraints to\nchemo-dynamical evolutionary models of the Milky Way. Given the PL relations\nthat provide accurate distances and the large number of spectral lines,\nCepheids are excellent tracers of the present-day abundance gradients. Aims: We\nwant to measure the Galactic abundance gradient of several chemical elements.\nWhile the slope of the Cepheid iron gradient did not vary much from the very\nfirst studies, the gradients of the other elements are not that well\nconstrained. In this paper we focus on the inner and outer regions of the\nGalactic thin disk. Methods: We use HR spectra (FEROS, ESPADONS, NARVAL) to\nmeasure the abundances of several light (Na, Al), alpha (Mg, Si, S, Ca), and\nheavy elements (Y, Zr, La, Ce, Nd, Eu) in a sample of 65 Milky Way Cepheids.\nCombining these results with accurate distances from period-Wesenheit relations\nin the NIR enables us to determine the abundance gradients in the Milky Way.\nResults: Our results are in good agreement with previous studies on either\nCepheids or other tracers. In particular, we confirm an upward shift of\napproximatively 0.2 dex for the Mg abundances, as has recently been reported.\nWe also confirm the existence of a gradient for all the heavy elements studied\nin the context of a LTE analysis. However, for Y, Nd, and especially La, we\nfind lower abundances for Cepheids in the outer disk than reported in previous\nstudies, leading to steeper gradients. This effect can be explained by the\ndifferences in the line lists used by different groups. Conclusions: Our data\ndo not support a flattening of the gradients in the outer disk, in agreement\nwith recent Cepheid studies and chemo-dynamical simulations. This is in\ncontrast to the open cluster observations but remains compatible with a picture\nwhere the transition zone between the inner disk and the outer disk would move\noutward with time. Lemasle_2013 Lemasle et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1308.3249
916 1308.0627 2013-08-02 Douglas A. Barros, Jacques R. D. Lépine, Thiago C. Junqueira A Galactic Ring of Minimum Stellar Density Near the Solar Orbit Radius We analyse the secular effects of a long-lived Galactic spiral structure on\nthe stellar orbits with mean radii close to the corotation resonance. By\ntest-particle simulations and different spiral potential models with parameters\nconstrained on observations, we verified the formation of a minimum with\namplitude ~ 30% - 40% of the background disk stellar density at corotation.\nSuch minimum is formed by the secular angular momentum transfer between stars\nand the spiral density wave on both sides of corotation. We demonstrate that\nthe secular loss (gain) of angular momentum and decrease (increase) of mean\norbital radius of stars just inside (outside) corotation can counterbalance the\nopposite trend of exchange of angular momentum shown by stars orbiting the\nlibrational points L_4/5 at the corotation circle. Such secular processes\nactually allow steady spiral waves to promote radial migration across\ncorotation. We propose some observational evidences for the minimum stellar\ndensity in the Galactic disk, such as its direct relation to the minimum in the\nobserved rotation curve of the Galaxy at the radius R ~ 9 kpc (for R_0 = 7.5\nkpc), as well as its association with a minimum in the distribution of Galactic\nradii of a sample of open clusters older than 1 Gyr. The closeness of the solar\norbit radius to the corotation resonance implies that the solar orbit lies\ninside a ring of minimum surface density (stellar + gas). This also implies in\na correction to larger values for the estimated total mass of the Galactic\ndisk, and consequently, a greater contribution of the disk component to the\ninner rotation curve of the Galaxy. Barros_2013 Barros et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1308.0627
917 1308.0351 2013-08-01 G. Zasowski, Jennifer A. Johnson, P. M. Frinchaboy, S. R. Majewski, D. L. Nidever, H. J. Rocha Pinto, L. Girardi, B. Andrews, S. D. Chojnowski, K. M. Cudworth, K. Jackson, J. Munn, M. F. Skrutskie, R. L. Beaton, C. H. Blake, K. Covey, R. Deshpande, C. Epstein, D. Fabbian, S. W. Fleming, A. Garcia Hernandez, A. Herrero, S. Mahadevan, Sz. Meszaros, M. Schultheis, K. Sellgren, R. Terrien, J. van Saders, C. Allende Prieto, D. Bizyaev, A. Burton, K. Cunha, L. N. da Costa, S. Hasselquist, F. Hearty, J. Holtzman, A. E. Garcia Perez, M. A. G. Maia, R. W. O'Connell, C. O'Donnell, M. Pinsonneault, B. X. Santiago, R. P. Schiavon, M. Shetrone, V. Smith, J. C. Wilson Target Selection for the Apache Point Observatory Galactic Evolution Experiment (APOGEE) The Apache Point Observatory Galactic Evolution Experiment (APOGEE) is a\nhigh-resolution infrared spectroscopic survey spanning all Galactic\nenvironments (i.e., bulge, disk, and halo), with the principal goal of\nconstraining dynamical and chemical evolution models of the Milky Way. APOGEE\ntakes advantage of the reduced effects of extinction at infrared wavelengths to\nobserve the inner Galaxy and bulge at an unprecedented level of detail. The\nsurvey's broad spatial and wavelength coverage enables users of APOGEE data to\naddress numerous Galactic structure and stellar populations issues. In this\npaper we describe the APOGEE targeting scheme and document its various target\nclasses to provide the necessary background and reference information to\nanalyze samples of APOGEE data with awareness of the imposed selection criteria\nand resulting sample properties. APOGEE's primary sample consists of ~100,000\nred giant stars, selected to minimize observational biases in age and\nmetallicity. We present the methodology and considerations that drive the\nselection of this sample and evaluate the accuracy, efficiency, and caveats of\nthe selection and sampling algorithms. We also describe additional target\nclasses that contribute to the APOGEE sample, including numerous ancillary\nscience programs, and we outline the targeting data that will be included in\nthe public data releases. Zasowski_2013 Zasowski et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1308.0351
918 1307.6217 2013-07-23 Daryl Haggard, Adrienne M. Cool, Craig O. Heinke, Roeland van der Marel, Haldan N. Cohn, Phyllis M. Lugger, Jay Anderson A Deep Chandra X-ray Limit on the Putative IMBH in Omega Centauri We report a sensitive X-ray search for the proposed intermediate mass black\nhole (IMBH) in the massive Galactic cluster, Omega Centauri (NGC 5139).\nCombining Chandra X-ray Observatory data from Cycles 1 and 13, we obtain a deep\n(~291 ks) exposure of the central regions of the cluster. We find no evidence\nfor an X-ray point source near any of the cluster's proposed dynamical centers,\nand place an upper limit on the X-ray flux from a central source of f_X(0.5-7.0\nkeV) <= 5.0x10^-16 erg cm^-2 s^-1, after correcting for absorption. This\ncorresponds to an unabsorbed X-ray luminosity of L_X(0.5-7.0 keV) <= 1.6x10^30\nerg s^-1, for a cluster distance of 5.2 kpc, Galactic column density N_H =\n1.2x10^21 cm^-2, and powerlaw spectrum with Gamma = 2.3. If a ~10^4 M_sun IMBH\nresides in the cluster's core, as suggested by some stellar dynamical studies,\nits Eddington luminosity would be L_Edd ~10^42 erg s^-1. The new X-ray limit\nwould then establish an Eddington ratio of L_X/L_Edd <~ 10^-12, a factor of ~10\nlower than even the quiescent state of our Galaxy's notoriously inefficient\nsupermassive black hole Sgr A*, and imply accretion efficiencies as low as eta\n<~ 10^-6 - 10^-8. This study leaves open three possibilities: either Omega Cen\ndoes not harbor an IMBH or, if an IMBH does exist, it must experience very\nlittle or very inefficient accretion. Haggard_2013 Haggard et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1307.6217
919 1307.4757 2013-07-17 Eugenio Carretta The fraction of first and second generation stars in globular clusters. I The case of NGC 6752 We present a new method to estimate the fraction of stars with chemical\ncomposition of first and second(s) generation(s) currently hosted in Galactic\nglobular clusters (GCs). We compare cluster and field stars of similar\nmetallicity in the [Fe/H]-[Na/H] plane. Since the phenomenon of multiple\npopulations is only restricted to the cluster environment, the number of GC\nstars whose location coincides with that of field stars provides the fraction\nof first generation stars in that cluster. By exclusion, the fraction of second\ngeneration stars is derived. We assembled a dataset of 1891 field stars of the\nthin disk, thick disk, and halo of the Milky Way in the metallicity range -3.15\n<= [Fe/H] <= +0.48 dex and with Na abundance from high resolution spectra. They\nare mostly dwarfs, but include also giants. Considering only the range in\nmetallicity spanned by most GCs extensively studied for the Na-O\nanticorrelation (-2.36 <= [Fe/H] <= -0.33 dex), we have 804 stars. The total\nsample is homogeneized by offsets in [Fe/H] and [Na/H] with respect to a\nreference sample using the same line list and NLTE correction for Na adopted in\na recent extensive survey of GC stars. This fully accounts for offsets among\nanalyses due to different temperature scales, line lists, adopted (or\nneglected) corrections for departures from LTE. We illustrate our method\nestimating the fraction of first and second generation stars in the well\nstudied GC NGC 6752. As a by-product, the comparison of [Na/H] values in GC and\nfield stars suggests that at least two classes of old stellar systems probably\ncontributed to the halo assembly: one group with characteristics similar to the\ncurrently existing GCs, and the other more similar to the present-day dwarf\nsatellite galaxies. Carretta_2013 Carretta 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1307.4757
920 1307.4467 2013-07-17 Xiyan Peng, Cuihua Du, Zhenyu Wu, Jun Ma, Xu Zhou The stellar metallicity distribution of the Milky Way from the BATC survey Using the stellar atmospheric parameters such as effective temperature and\nmetallicity derived from SDSS spectra for 2200 main sequence (MS) stars which\nwere also observed by Beijing - Arizona - Taiwan - Connecticut (BATC)\nphotometric system, we develop the polynomial photometric calibration method to\nevaluate the stellar effective temperature and metallicity for BATC multi-color\nphotometric data. This calibration method has been applied to about 160 000 MS\nstars from 67 BATC observed fields. Those stars have colors and magnitudes in\nthe ranges 0.1 < d - h < 1.4 and 14.0 < d < 21.0. We find that there is a peak\nof metallicity distribution at [Fe/H] ~ -1.5 in the distance from the Galactic\nplane |Z| > 5 kpc which corresponds to the halo component and a peak at [Fe/H]\n~ -0.7 in the region 2 < |Z| < 5 kpc where is dominated by the thick disk\nstars. The mean stellar metallicity smoothly decreases from -0.65 to -0.78 in\nthe interval 0.5 < |Z|< 2 kpc. Metallicity distributions in the halo and the\nthick disk seem invariant with the distance from the Galactic plane. Peng_2013 Peng et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1307.4467
921 1307.2894 2013-07-10 Duane M. Lee, Kathryn V. Johnston, Jason Tumlinson, Bodhisattva Sen, Joshua D. Simon A Mass-Dependent Yield Origin of Neutron-Capture Element Abundance Distributions in Ultra-Faint Dwarfs One way to constrain the nature of the high-redshift progenitors of the Milky\nWay is to look at the low-metallicity stellar populations of the different\nGalactic components today. For example, high-resolution spectroscopy of very\nmetal poor (VMP) stars demonstrates remarkable agreement between the\ndistribution of [Ti/Fe] in the stellar populations of the Milky Way halo (MW)\nand ultra-faint dwarf (UFD) galaxies. In contrast, for the neutron capture (nc)\nabundance ratio distributions [(Sr,Ba)/Fe], the peak of the small UFD sample (6\nstars) exhibits a signicant under-abundance relative to the VMP stars in the\nlarger MW halo sample (~ 300 stars). We present a simple scenario that can\nsimultaneously explain these similarities and differences by assuming: (i) that\nthe MW VMP stars were predominately enriched by a prior generation of stars\nwhich possessed a higher total mass than the prior generation of stars that\nenriched the UFD VMP stars; and (ii) a much stronger mass-dependent yield (MDY)\nfor nc-elements than for the (known) MDY for Ti. Simple statistical tests\ndemonstrate that conditions (i) and (ii) are consistent with the observed\nabundance distributions, albeit without strong constraints on model parameters.\nA comparison of the broad constraints for these nc-MDY with those derived in\nthe literature seems to rule out Ba production from low-mass SNs and affirms\nmodels that primarily generate yields from high-mass SN. Our scenario can be\nconfirmed by a relatively modest (factor of ~ 3-4) increase in the number of\nhigh-resolution spectra of VMP stars in UFDs. Lee_2013 Lee et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1307.2894
922 1307.2094 2013-07-08 M. Netopil, E. Paunzen Towards a photometric metallicity scale for open clusters Open clusters are a useful tool when investigating several topics connected\nwith stellar evolution; for example the age or distance can be more accurately\ndetermined than for field stars. However, one important parameter, the\nmetallicity, is only known for a marginal percentage of open clusters. We aim\nat a consistent set of parameters for the open clusters investigated in our\nphotometric Delta-a survey of chemically peculiar stars. Special attention is\npaid to expanding our knowledge of cluster metallicities and verifying their\nscale. Making use of a previously developed method based on normalised\nevolutionary grids and photometric data, the distance, age, reddening, and\nmetallicity of open clusters were derived. To transform photometric\nmeasurements into effective temperatures to use as input for our method, a set\nof temperature calibrations for the most commonly used colour indices and\nphotometric systems was compiled. We analysed 58 open clusters in total. Our\nderived metallicity values were in excellent agreement with about 30\nspectroscopically studied targets. The mean value of the absolute deviations\nwas found to be 0.03 dex, with no noticeable offset or gradient. The method was\nalso applied using recent evolutionary models based on the currently accepted\nlower solar abundance value Z=0.014. No significant differences were found\ncompared to grids using the former adopted solar value Z=0.02. Furthermore,\nsome divergent photometric datasets were identified and discussed. The method\nprovides an accurate way of obtaining properly scaled metallicity values for\nopen clusters. In light of present and future homogeneous photometric sky\nsurveys, the sample of stellar clusters can be extended to the outskirts of the\nMilky Way, where spectroscopic studies are almost impossible. This will help\nfor determining galactic metallicity gradients in more detail. Netopil_2013 Netopil and Paunzen 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1307.2094
923 1307.1468 2013-07-04 G. R. I. Moyano Loyola, J. R. Hurley Stars on the run: escaping from stellar clusters A significant proportion of Milky Way stars are born in stellar clusters,\nwhich dissolve over time so that the members become part of the disc and halo\npopulations of the Galaxy. In the present work we will assume that these young\nstellar clusters live mainly within the disc of the Galaxy and that they can\nhave primordial binary percentages ranging from 0% to as high as 70%. We have\nevolved models of such clusters to an age of 4 Gyr through N-body simulations,\npaying attention to the stars and binaries that escape in the process. We have\nquantified the contribution of these escaping stars to the Galaxy population by\nanalysing their escape velocity and evolutionary stage at the moment of escape.\nIn this way we could analyse the mechanisms that produced these escapers,\nwhether evaporation through weak two- body encounters, energetic close\nencounters or stellar evolution events, e.g. supernovae. In our models we found\nthat the percentage of primordial binaries in a star cluster does not produce\nsignificant variations in the velocities of the stars that escape in the\nvelocity range of 0-20 km/s. However, in the high-velocity 20-100 km/s range\nthe number of escapers increased markedly as the primordial binary percentage\nincreased. We could also infer that dissolving stellar clusters such as those\nthat we have modelled can populate the Galactic halo with giant stars for which\nthe progenitors were stars of up to 2.4 Msun. Furthermore, choices made for the\nvelocity kicks of remnants do influence the production of hyper-velocity stars\n- and to a lesser extent stars in the high-velocity range - but once again the\ndifference for the 99% of stars in the 0-20 km/s range is not significant. Loyola_2013 Loyola and Hurley 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1307.1468
924 1212.0006 2013-06-23 Yuan-Sen Ting, Hans-Walter Rix, Jo Bovy, Glenn van de Ven Constraining the Galactic potential via action-based distribution functions for mono-abundance stellar populations We present a rigorous and practical way of constraining the Galactic\npotential based on the phase-space information for many individual stars. Such\nan approach is needed to dynamically model the data from ongoing spectroscopic\nsurveys of the Galaxy and in the future Gaia. This approach describes the orbit\ndistribution of stars by a family of parametrized distribution function (DF)\nproposed by McMillan and Binney, which are based on actions. We find that these\nparametrized DFs are flexible enough to capture well the observed phase-space\ndistributions of individual abundance-selected Galactic subpopulations of stars\n(`mono-abundance populations') for a disc-like gravitational potential, which\nenables independent dynamical constraints from each of the Galactic\nmono-abundance populations. We lay out a statistically rigorous way to\nconstrain the Galactic potential parameters by constructing the joint\nlikelihood of potential and DF parameters, and subsequently marginalizing over\nthe DF parameters. This approach explicitly incorporates the spatial selection\nfunction inherent to all Galactic surveys, and can account for the\nuncertainties of the individual position--velocity observations. On that basis,\nwe study the precision of the parameters of the Galactic potential that can be\nreached with various sample sizes and realistic spatial selection functions. By\ncreating mock samples from the DF, we show that, even under a restrictive and\nrealistic spatial selection function, given a two-parameter gravitational\npotential, one can recover the true potential parameters to a few per cent with\nsample sizes of a few thousands. The assumptions of axisymmetry, of DFs that\nare smooth in the actions and of no time variation remain important limitations\nin our current study. Ting_2013 Ting et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1212.0006
925 1306.4825 2013-06-20 Andrew D. Sutton, Timothy P. Roberts, Jeanette C. Gladstone, Sean A. Farrell, Emma Reilly, Michael R. Goad, Neil Gehrels A bright ultraluminous X-ray source in NGC 5907 We present a multi-mission X-ray analysis of a bright (peak observed 0.3-10\nkeV luminosity of ~ 6x10^{40} erg s^{-1}), but relatively highly absorbed ULX\nin the edge-on spiral galaxy NGC 5907. The ULX is spectrally hard in X-rays\n(Gamma ~ 1.2-1.7, when fitted with an absorbed power-law), and has a\npreviously-reported hard spectral break consistent with it being in the\nultraluminous accretion state. It is also relatively highly absorbed for a ULX,\nwith a column of ~ 0.4-0.9x10^{22} atom cm^{-2} in addition to the\nline-of-sight column in our Galaxy. Although its X-ray spectra are well\nrepresented by accretion disc models, its variability characteristics argue\nagainst this interpretation. The ULX spectra instead appear dominated by a\ncool, optically-thick Comptonising corona. We discuss how the measured 9 per\ncent rms variability and a hardening of the spectrum as its flux diminishes\nmight be reconciled with the effects of a very massive, radiatively-driven\nwind, and subtle changes in the corona respectively. We speculate that the cool\ndisc-like spectral component thought to be produced by the wind in other ULXs\nmay be missing from the observed spectrum due to a combination of a low\ntemperature (~ 0.1 keV), and the high column to the ULX. We find no evidence,\nother than its extreme X-ray luminosity, for the presence of an intermediate\nmass black hole (~ 10^2 - 10^4 Msun) in this object. Rather, the observations\ncan be consistently explained by a massive (greater than ~ 20 Msun) stellar\nremnant black hole in a super-Eddington accretion state. Sutton_2013 Sutton et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1306.4825
926 1306.4929 2013-06-20 Sergei Nayakshin, Mark I. Wilkinson A link between feedback outflows and satellite galaxy suppression We suggest a direct link between the two "missing" baryon problems of\ncontemporary galaxy formation theory: (1) that large galaxies are known to\ncontain too little gas and stars and (2) that too few dwarf satellite galaxies\nare observed around large galaxies compared with cosmological simulations. The\nformer can be explained by invoking some energetic process -- most likely AGN\nor star formation feedback -- which expels to infinity a significant fraction\nof the gas initially present in the proto-galaxy, while the latter problem is\nusually explained by star formation feedback inside the dwarf or tidal and ram\npressure stripping of the gas from the satellite galaxy by its parent. Here we\npoint out that the host galaxy "missing" baryons, if indeed ejected at\nvelocities of hundreds to a thousand km s$^{-1}$, must also affect smaller\nsatellite galaxies by stripping or shocking the gas there. We estimate the\nfraction of gas removed from the satellites as a function of the satellite\ngalaxy's properties. Applying these results to a Milky Way like dark matter\nhalo, we find that this singular shock ram pressure stripping event may be\nquite efficient in removing the gas from the satellites provided that they are\nclose enough. We also use the orbital and mass modelling data for eight\nGalactic dwarf spheroidal (dSph) satellites, and find that it is likely that\nmany of them have been affected by the Galactic outflow. We point out that\ngalactic outflows of the host may also trigger a starburst in the satellite\ngalaxies by over-pressuring their gas discs. This process may be responsible\nfor the formation of the globular clusters observed in some of the Milky Way's\ndSphs (e.g. the Fornax and Sagittarius dSphs). Nayakshin_2013 Nayakshin and Wilkinson 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1306.4929
927 1304.2391 2013-06-14 Pieter G. van Dokkum, Joel Leja, Erica June Nelson, Shannon Patel, Rosalind E. Skelton, Ivelina Momcheva, Gabriel Brammer, Katherine E. Whitaker, Britt Lundgren, Mattia Fumagalli, Charlie Conroy, Natascha Forster Schreiber, Marijn Franx, Mariska Kriek, Ivo Labbe, Danilo Marchesini, Hans-Walter Rix, Arjen van der Wel, Stijn Wuyts The Assembly of Milky Way-like Galaxies Since z~2.5 Galaxies with the mass of the Milky Way dominate the stellar mass density of\nthe Universe but it is uncertain how and when they were assembled. Here we\nstudy progenitors of these galaxies out to z=2.5, using data from the 3D-HST\nand CANDELS Treasury surveys. We find that galaxies with present-day stellar\nmasses of log(M)~10.7 built ~90% of their stellar mass since z=2.5, with most\nof the star formation occurring before z=1. In marked contrast to the assembly\nhistory of massive elliptical galaxies, mass growth is not limited to large\nradii: the mass in the central 2 kpc of the galaxies increased by a factor of\n3.2+-0.8 between z=2.5 and z=1. We therefore rule out simple models in which\nbulges were fully assembled at high redshift and disks gradually formed around\nthem. Instead, bulges (and black holes) likely formed in lockstep with disks,\nthrough bar instabilities, migration, or other processes. We find that after\nz=1 the growth in the central regions gradually stopped and the disk continued\nto build, consistent with recent studies of the gas distributions in z~1\ngalaxies and the properties of many spiral galaxies today. Dokkum_2013 Dokkum et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1304.2391
928 1306.1287 2013-06-06 Jia-Cheng Liu, Yi Xie, Zi Zhu Aberration in proper motions for stars in our Galaxy Accelerations of both the solar system barycenter (SSB) and stars in the\nMilky Way cause a systematic observational effect on the stellar proper\nmotions, which was first studied in the early 1990s and developed by J.\nKovalevsky (aberration in proper motions, 2003, A&A, 404, 743). This paper\nintends to extend that work and aims to estimate the magnitude and significance\nof the aberration in proper motions of stars, especially in the region near the\nGalactic center. We adopt two models for the Galactic rotation curve to\nevaluate the aberrational effect on the Galactic plane. Based on the\ntheoretical developments, we show that the effect of aberration in proper\nmotions depends on the galactocentric distance of stars; it is dominated by the\nacceleration of stars in the central region of the Galaxy. Within 200 pc from\nthe Galactic center, the systematic proper motion can reach an amplitude larger\nthan 1000 uas/yr by applying a flat rotation curve. With a more realistic\nrotation curve which is linearly rising in the core region of the Galaxy, the\naberrational proper motions are limited up to about 150 uas/yr. Then we\ninvestigate the applicability of the theoretical expressions concerning the\naberrational proper motions, especially for those stars with short period\norbits. If the orbital period of stars is only a fraction of the light time\nfrom the star to the SSB, the expression proposed by Kovalevsky is not\nappropriate. With a more suitable formulation, we found that the aberration has\nno effect on the determination of the stellar orbits on the celestial sphere.\nThe aberrational effect under consideration is small but not negligible with\nhigh-accurate astrometry in the future, particularly in constructing the Gaia\ncelestial reference system realized by Galactic stars. Liu_2013 Liu et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1306.1287
929 1306.0684 2013-06-04 Kastytis Zubovas, Sergei Nayakshin, Andrew King, Mark Wilkinson AGN outflows trigger starbursts in gas-rich galaxies Recent well resolved numerical simulations of AGN feedback have shown that\nits effects on the host galaxy may be not only negative but also positive. In\nthe late gas poor phase, AGN feedback blows the gas away and terminates star\nformation. However, in the gas-rich phase(s), AGN outflows trigger star\nformation by over-compressing cold dense gas and thus provide positive feedback\non their hosts. In this paper we study this AGN-triggered starburst effect. We\nshow that star formation rate in the burst increases until the star formation\nfeedback counteracts locally the AGN outflow compression. Globally, this\npredicts a strong nearly linear statistical correlation between the AGN and\nstarburst bolometric luminosities in disc galaxies, L_* \propto L_{AGN}^{5/6}.\nThe correlation is statistical only because AGN activity may fluctuate on short\ntime scales (as short as tens of years), and because AGN may turn off but its\neffects on the host may continue to last until the AGN-driven outflow leaves\nthe host, which may be up to 10 times longer than the duration of the AGN\nactivity. The coefficient in front of this relation depends on the clumpiness\nand morphology of the cold gas in the galaxy. A "maximum starburst" takes place\nin am azimuthally uniform gas disc, for which we derive an upper limit of L_*\n\sim 50 times larger than L_{AGN} for typical quasars. For more clumpy and/or\ncompact cold gas distributions, the starburst luminosity decreases. We also\nsuggest that similar AGN-triggerred starbursts are possible in hosts of all\ngeometries, including during galaxy mergers, provided the AGN is activated.\nFinally, we note that due to the short duration of the AGN activity phase the\naccelerating influence of AGN on starbursts may be much more common than\nobservations of simultaneous AGN and starbursts would suggest. Zubovas_2013a Zubovas et al. 2013a https://arxiv.org/abs/1306.0684
930 1305.7231 2013-05-30 Robert M. Yates, Bruno Henriques, Peter A. Thomas, Guinevere Kauffmann, Jonas Johansson, Simon D. M. White Modelling Element Abundances in Semi-analytic Models of Galaxy Formation We update the treatment of chemical evolution in the Munich semi-analytic\nmodel, L-GALAXIES. Our new implementation includes delayed enrichment from\nstellar winds, supernovae type II (SNe-II) and supernovae type Ia (SNe-Ia), as\nwell as metallicity-dependent yields and a reformulation of the associated\nsupernova feedback. Two different sets of SN-II yields and three different\nSN-Ia delay-time distributions (DTDs) are considered, and eleven heavy elements\n(including O, Mg and Fe) are self-consistently tracked. We compare the results\nof this new implementation with data on a) local, star-forming galaxies, b)\nMilky Way disc G dwarfs, and c) local, elliptical galaxies. We find that the\nz=0 gas-phase mass-metallicity relation is very well reproduced for all forms\nof DTD considered, as is the [Fe/H] distribution in the Milky Way disc. The\n[O/Fe] distribution in the Milky Way disc is best reproduced when using a DTD\nwith less than or equal to 50 per cent of SNe-Ia exploding within ~400 Myrs.\nPositive slopes in the mass-[alpha/Fe] relations of local ellipticals are also\nobtained when using a DTD with such a minor `prompt' component. Alternatively,\nmetal-rich winds that drive light alpha elements directly out into the\ncircumgalactic medium also produce positive slopes for all forms of DTD and\nSN-II yields considered. Overall, we find that the best model for matching the\nwide range of observational data considered here should include a power-law\nSN-Ia DTD, SN-II yields that take account of prior mass loss through stellar\nwinds, and some direct ejection of light alpha elements out of galaxies. Yates_2013 Yates et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1305.7231
931 1305.6699 2013-05-29 Susanne Pfalzner, Thomas Kaczmarek Reaction of Massive Clusters to Gas Expulsion - The cluster density dependence The expulsion of the unconverted gas at the end of the star formation process\npotentially leads to the expansion of the just formed stellar cluster and\nmembership loss. The degree of expansion and mass loss depends largely on the\nstar formation efficiency and scales with the mass and size of the stellar\ngroup as long as stellar interactions can be neglected. We investigate under\nwhich circumstances stellar interactions between cluster members become so\nimportant that the fraction of bound stars after gas expulsion is significantly\naltered. The Nbody6 code is used to simulate the cluster dynamics after gas\nexpulsion for different SFEs. Concentrating on the most massive clusters\nobserved in the Milky Way, we test to what extend the results depend on the\nmodel, i.e. stellar mass distribution, stellar density profile etc., and the\ncluster parameters, such as cluster density and size.We find that stellar\ninteractions are responsible for up to 20% mass loss in the most compact\nmassive clusters in the Milky Way, making ejections the prime mass loss process\nin such systems. Even in the loosely bound OB associations stellar interactions\nare responsible for at least ~5% mass loss. The main reason why the importance\nof encounters for massive clusters has been largely overlooked is the often\nused approach of a single-mass representation instead of a realistic\ndistribution for the stellar masses. The density-dependence of the\nencounter-induced mass loss is shallower than expected because of the\nincreasing importance of few-body interactions in dense clusters compared to\nsparse clusters where 2-body encounters dominate. Pfalzner_2013 Pfalzner and Kaczmarek 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1305.6699
932 1305.6145 2013-05-27 G. Kordopatis, V. Hill, M. Irwin, G. Gilmore, R. F. G. Wyse, E. Tolstoy, P. de Laverny, A. Recio-Blanco, G. Battaglia, E. Starkenburg Through thick and thin: Structure of the Galactic thick disc from extragalactic surveys We aim to understand the accretion history of the Milky Way by exploring the\nvertical and radial properties of the Galactic thick disc.\n We study the chemical and kinematic properties of roughly a thousand spectra\nof faint magnitude foreground Galactic stars observed serendipitously during\nextra-galactic surveys in four lines-of-sight: three in the southern Galactic\nhemisphere (surveys of the Carina, Fornax and Sculptor dwarf spheroidal\ngalaxies) and one in the northern Galactic hemisphere (a survey of the Sextans\ndwarf spheroidal galaxy). The foreground stars span distances up to 3kpc from\nthe Galactic plane and Galactocentric radii up to 11kpc.\n Only three lines-of-sight have a sufficient number of foreground stars for a\nrobust analysis. Towards Sextans in the Northern Galactic hemisphere and\nSculptor in the South, we measure a consistent decrease in mean metallicity\nwith height from the Galactic plane, suggesting a chemically symmetric thick\ndisc. This decrease can either be due to an intrinsic thick disc metallicity\ngradient, or simply due to a change in the thin disc/thick disc population\nratio and no intrinsic metallicity gradients for the thick disc. We favour the\nlatter explanation. In contrast, we find evidence of an unpredicted metal-poor\npopulation in the direction of Carina. This population was earlier detected by\nWyse et al. (2006), but our more detailed analysis provides robust estimates of\nits location (|Z|<1kpc), metallicity (-2<[M/H]<-1 dex) and azimuthal orbital\nvelocity (V_phi ~120 km/s).\n Given the chemo-dynamical properties of the over-density towards the Carina\nline-of-sight, we suggest that it represents the metal-poor tail of the\ncanonical thick disc. In spite of the small number of stars available, we\nsuggest that this metal-weak thick disc follows the often suggested thick disc\nvelocity-metallicity correlation of dV_phi/d[M/H]~40-50km/s/dex. Kordopatis_2013 Kordopatis et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1305.6145
933 1305.5902 2013-05-25 M. Soto, R. Barba, G. Gunthardt, D. Minniti, P. Lucas, D. Majaess, M. Irwin, J. P. Emerson, E. Gonzalez-Solares, M. Hempel, R. K. Saito, S. Gurovich, A. Roman-Lopes, C. Moni-Bidin, M. V. Santucho, J. Borissova, R. Kurtev, I. Toledo, D. Geisler, M. Dominguez, J. C. Beamin Milky Way Demographics with the VVV Survey II. Color Transformations and Near-Infrared Photometry for 136 Million Stars in the Southern Galactic Disk The new multi-epoch near-infrared VVV survey (VISTA Variables in the Via\nLactea) is sampling 562 sq. deg of the Galactic bulge and adjacent regions of\nthe disk. Accurate astrometry established for the region surveyed allows the\nVVV data to be merged with overlapping surveys (e.g., GLIMPSE, WISE, 2MASS,\netc.), thereby enabling the construction of longer baseline spectral energy\ndistributions for astronomical targets. However, in order to maximize use of\nthe VVV data, a set of transformation equations are required to place the VVV\nJHKs photometry onto the 2MASS system. The impetus for this work is to develop\nthose transformations via a comparison of 2MASS targets in 152 VVV fields\nsampling the Galactic disk. The transformation coefficients derived exhibit a\nreliance on variables such as extinction. The transformed data were\nsubsequently employed to establish a mean reddening law of\nE_{J-H}/E_{H-Ks}=2.13 +/- 0.04, which is the most precise determination to date\nand merely emphasizes the pertinence of the VVV data for determining such\nimportant parameters. Soto_2013 Soto et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1305.5902
934 1303.566 2013-05-23 Paul J. McMillan, James J. Binney Analysing surveys of our Galaxy -- II. Determining the potential We consider the problem of determining the Galaxy's gravitational potential\nfrom a star catalogue. We show that orbit-based approaches to this problem\nsuffer from unacceptable numerical noise deriving from the use of only a finite\nnumber of orbits. An alternative approach, which requires an ability to\ndetermine the model's phase-space density at predetermined positions and\nvelocities, has a level of numerical noise that lies well below the intrinsic\nuncertainty associated with the finite size of the catalogue analysed. A\ncatalogue of 10000 stars brighter than V=17 and distributed over the sky at\nb>30 degrees enables us to determine the scaleheight of the disc that\ncontributes to the potential with an uncertainty below 20pc if the catalogue\ngives proper motions, line-of-sight velocities and parallaxes with errors\ntypical of the Gaia Catalogue, rising to 36pc if only proper motions are\navailable. The uncertainty in the disc's scalelength is significantly smaller\nthan 0.25kpc. McMillan_2013 McMillan and Binney 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1303.566
935 1210.7691 2013-05-19 Mark Cropper, Henk Hoekstra, Thomas Kitching, Richard Massey, Jerome Amiaux, Lance Miller, Yannick Mellier, Jason Rhodes, Barnaby Rowe, Sandrine Pires, Curtis Saxton, Roberto Scaramella Defining a weak lensing experiment in space This paper describes the definition of a typical next-generation space-based\nweak gravitational lensing experiment. We first adopt a set of top-level\nscience requirements from the literature, based on the scale and depth of the\ngalaxy sample, and the avoidance of systematic effects in the measurements\nwhich would bias the derived shear values. We then identify and categorise the\ncontributing factors to the systematic effects, combining them with the correct\nweighting, in such a way as to fit within the top-level requirements. We\npresent techniques which permit the performance to be evaluated and explore the\nlimits at which the contributing factors can be managed. Besides the modelling\nbiases resulting from the use of weighted moments, the main contributing\nfactors are the reconstruction of the instrument point spread function (PSF),\nwhich is derived from the stellar images on the image, and the correction of\nthe charge transfer inefficiency (CTI) in the CCD detectors caused by radiation\ndamage. Cropper_2013 Cropper et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1210.7691
936 1305.3997 2013-05-17 Kastytis Zubovas, Graham A. Wynn, Alessia Gualandris Supernovae in the Central Parsec: A Mechanism for Producing Spatially Anisotropic Hypervelocity Stars Several tens of hyper-velocity stars (HVSs) have been discovered escaping our\nGalaxy. These stars share a common origin in the Galactic centre and are\ndistributed anisotropically in Galactic longitude and latitude. We examine the\npossibility that HVSs may be created as the result of supernovae occurring\nwithin binary systems in a disc of stars around Sgr A* over the last 100 Myr.\nMonte Carlo simulations show that the rate of binary disruption is ~10^-4\nyr^-1, comparable to that of tidal disruption models. The supernova-induced HVS\nproduction rate (\Gamma_HVS) is significantly increased if the binaries are\nhardened via migration through a gaseous disc. Moderate hardening gives\n\Gamma_HVS ~ 2*10^-7 yr^-1 and an estimated population of ~20 HVSs in the last\n100 Myr. Supernova-induced HVS production requires the internal and external\norbital velocity vectors of the secondary binary component to be aligned when\nthe binary is disrupted. This leaves an imprint of the disc geometry on the\nspatial distribution of the HVSs, producing a distinct anisotropy. Zubovas_2013 Zubovas et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1305.3997
937 1302.7097 2013-05-10 Shigeki Inoue, Naoteru Gouda Astrometric mock observations for determining the local dark matter density To determine the local dark matter density (LDMD) of the solar system is a\nclassical problem in astronomy. Recently, a novel method of determining the\nLDMD from stellar distribution and vertical velocity dispersion profiles\nperpendicular to the Galactic plane was devised. This method has the advantage\nof abolishing conventional approximations and using only a few assumptions. Our\naims are to carefully scrutinize this method and to examine influences by\nuncertainties of astrometric observations. We discuss how the determinations of\nthe LDMD vary with observational precisions on parallax, proper motion, and\nline-of-sight velocity measurements. To examine the influences by the\nobservational imprecision, we created mock observation data for stars that are\ndynamical tracers based on an analytical galaxy model and applied parametrized\nobservational errors to the mock data. We evaluated the accuracy of determining\nthe LDMD by applying the method to the mock data. In addition, we estimated a\nsample size and observational precision required to determine the LDMD with\naccuracy. We find that the method is capable of determining the LDMD with\naccuracy if the sample size and observational precisions are satisfactory. The\nrandom errors of parallaxes and proper motions can cause systematic\noverestimation of the LDMD. We estimate the required precisions of the parallax\nmeasurements to be approximately 0.1-0.3 milliarcseconds at 1 kpc away from the\nSun; the proper motion precisions do not seem to be as important as the\nparallaxes. From these results, we expect that using the Hipparcos catalog\nwould overestimate the LDMD because of the imprecise parallax measurements if\nthis method is applied; however, we emphasize the capability of the method. We\nexpect that Gaia will provide data precise enough to determine the LDMD. Inoue_2013 Inoue and Gouda 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1302.7097
938 1211.1982 2013-05-09 Rok Roškar, Victor P. Debattista, Sarah R. Loebman The Effects of Radial Migration on the Vertical Structure of Galactic Discs We present evidence that isolated growing discs, subject to internal spiral\nperturbations, thicken due to both heating \emph{and} radial migration. We show\nthis by demonstrating that the thickness and vertical velocity dispersions of\ncoeval stars depend on their age as well as the change in their radii. While\nthe disc thickens due to internal processes, we find that this induces only a\nminor amount of flaring. We further demonstrate the consequences of such\nthickening on the structural properties of stellar populations and find that\nthey qualitatively agree with recent studies of the Milky Way disc. Roškar_2013 Roškar et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1211.1982
939 1305.1937 2013-05-08 Jason L. Sanders, James Binney Stream-orbit misalignment II: A new algorithm to constrain the Galactic potential In the first of these two papers we demonstrated that assuming streams\ndelineate orbits can lead to order one errors in potential parameters for\nrealistic Galactic potentials. Motivated by the need for an improvement on\norbit-fitting, we now present an algorithm for constraining the Galactic\npotential using tidal streams without assuming that streams delineate orbits.\nThis approach is independent of the progenitor mass so is valid for all\nobserved tidal streams. The method makes heavy use of angle-action variables\nand seeks the potential which recovers the expected correlations in angle\nspace. We demonstrate that the method can correctly recover the parameters of a\nsimple two-parameter logarithmic potential by analysing an N-body simulation of\na stream. We investigate the magnitude of the errors in observational data for\nwhich the method can still recover the correct potential and compare this to\ncurrent and future errors in data. The errors in the observables of individual\nstars for current and near future data are shown to be too large for the direct\nuse of this method, but when the data are averaged in bins on the sky, the\nresulting averaged data are accurate enough to constrain correctly the\npotential parameters for achievable observational errors. From pseudo-data with\nerrors comparable to those that will be furnished in the era of Gaia (20 per\ncent distance errors, 1.2 mas/yr proper motion errors, and 10 km/s\nline-of-sight velocity errors) we recover the circular velocity, V_c=220 km/s,\nand the flattening of the potential, q=0.9, to be V_c=223+/-10km/s and\nq=0.91+/-0.09. Sanders_2013 Sanders and Binney 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1305.1937
940 1305.1909 2013-05-08 T. Mishenina, S. Korotin, G. Carraro, V. V. Kovtyukh, I. A. Yegorova Barium and Yttrium abundance in intermediate-age and old open clusters Barium is a neutron capture element, that, in open clusters, is frequently\nover-abundant with respect to the Iron. A clear explanation for this is still\nmissing. Additionally, its gradient across the Galactic disk is poorly\nconstrained. We measure the abundance of yttrium and barium using the synthetic\nspectrum method from UVES high-resolution spectra of eight distant open\nclusters, namely Ruprecht 4, Ruprecht 7, Berkeley 25, Berkeley 73, Berkeley 75,\nNGC 6192, NGC 6404, and NGC 6583. The barium abundance was estimated using NLTE\napproximation. We confirm that Barium is indeed over-abundant in most clusters,\nespecially young clusters. Finally, we investigated the trend of yttrium and\nbarium abundances as a function of distance in the Galaxy and ages. Several\nscenarios for the barium over-abundance are then discussed. Mishenina_2013 Mishenina et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1305.1909
941 1305.1622 2013-05-07 Mario Pasquato, Gabriella Raimondo, Enzo Brocato, Chul Chung, Anthony Moraghan, Young-Wook Lee Core collapse and horizontal-branch morphology in galactic globular clusters Context. Stellar collision rates in globular clusters (GCs) do not appear to\ncorrelate with horizontal branch (HB) morphology, sug- gesting that dynamics\ndoes not play a role in the second-parameter problem. However, core densities\nand collision rates derived from surface-brightness may be significantly\nunderestimated as the surface-brightness profile of GCs is not necessarily a\ngood indicator of the dynamical state of GC cores. Core-collapse may go\nunnoticed if high central densities of dark remnants are present. Aims. We test\nwhether GC HB morphology data supports a dynamical contribution to the\nso-called second-parameter effect. Methods. To remove first-parameter\ndependence we fitted the maximum effective temperature along the HB as a\nfunction of metal- licity in a sample of 54 Milky Way GCs. We plotted the\nresiduals to the fit as a function of second-parameter candidates, namely\ndynamical age and total luminosity. We considered dynamical age (i.e. the ratio\nbetween age and half-light relaxation time) among possible second-parameters.\nWe used a set of direct N-body simulations, including ones with dark remnants\nto illustrate how core density peaks, due to core collapse, in a dynamical-age\nrange similar to that in which blue HBs are overabundant with respect to the\nmetallicity expectation, especially for low-concentration initial conditions.\nResults. GC total luminosity shows nonlinear behavior compatible with the\nself-enrichment picture. However, the data are amenable to a different\ninterpretation based on a dynamical origin of the second-parameter effect.\nEnhanced mass-stripping in the late red-giant- branch phase due to stellar\ninteractions in collapsing cores is a viable candidate mechanism. In this\npicture, GCs with HBs bluer than expected based on metallicity are those\nundergoing core-collapse. Pasquato_2013 Pasquato et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1305.1622
942 1305.1119 2013-05-06 Javier R. Goicoechea, M. Etxaluze, J. Cernicharo, M. Gerin, D. A. Neufeld, A. Contursi, T. A. Bell, M. De Luca, P. Encrenaz, N. Indriolo, D. C. Lis, E. T. Polehampton, P. Sonnentrucker Far-Infrared Spectroscopy of the Galactic Center. Hot Molecular Gas: Shocks versus Radiation near SgrA* We present a 52-671um spectral scan toward SgrA* taken with the PACS and\nSPIRE spectrometers onboard Herschel. The achieved angular resolution allows us\nto separate, for the first time at far-IR wavelengths, the emission toward the\ncentral cavity (gas in the inner central parsec of the galaxy) from that of the\nsurrounding circum-nuclear disk. The spectrum toward SgrA* is dominated by\nstrong [OIII], [OI], [CII], [NIII], [NII], and [CI] fine structure lines (in\ndecreasing order of luminosity) arising in gas irradiated by UV-photons from\nthe central stellar cluster. In addition, rotationally excited lines of 12CO\n(from J=4-3 to 24-23), 13CO, H2O, OH, H3O+, HCO+ and HCN, as well as\nground-state absorption lines of OH+, H2O+, H3O+, CH+, H2O, OH, HF, CH and NH\nare detected. The excitation of the 12CO ladder is consistent with a hot\nisothermal component at Tk ~ 10^{3.1} K and n(H2)< 10^4 cm^{-3}. It is also\nconsistent with a distribution of temperature components at higher density with\nmost CO at Tk<300 K. The detected molecular features suggest that, at present,\nneither very enhanced X-ray, nor cosmic-ray fluxes play a dominant role in the\nheating of the hot molecular gas. The hot CO component (either the bulk of the\nCO column or just a small fraction depending on the above scenario) results\nfrom a combination of UV- and shock-driven heating. If irradiated dense\nclumps/clouds do not exist, shocks likely dominate the heating of the hot\nmolecular gas. This is consistent with the high-velocity gas detected toward\nSgrA*. Goicoechea_2013 Goicoechea et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1305.1119
943 1301.6138 2013-05-06 A. Gupta, S. Mathur, Y. Krongold, F. Nicastro A Two-Phase Low-velocity Outflow in the Seyfert 1 Galaxy Ark~564 The Seyfert 1 galaxy Ark 564 was observed with Chandra high energy\ntransmission gratings for 250 ks. We present the high resolution X-ray spectrum\nthat shows several associated absorption lines. The photoionization model\nrequires two warm absorbers with two different ionization states\n(logU=0.39\pm0.03 and logU=-0.99\pm0.13), both with moderate outflow velocities\n(~100 km s^-1) and relatively low line of sight column densities (logNH=20.94\nand 20.11 cm^-2). The high ionization phase produces absorption lines of OVII,\nOVIII, NeIX, NeX, MgXI, FeXVII and FeXVIII while the low ionization phase\nproduces lines at lower energies (OVI & OVII). The pressure--temperature\nequilibrium curve for the Ark 564 absorber does not have the typical "S" shape,\neven if the metallicity is super-solar; as a result the two warm-absorber\nphases do not appear to be in pressure balance. This suggests that the\ncontinuum incident on the absorbing gas is perhaps different from the observed\ncontinuum. We also estimated the mass outflow rate and the associated kinetic\nenergy and find it to be at most 0.006% of the bolometric luminosity of\nArk~564. Thus it is highly unlikely that these outflows provide significant\nfeedback required by the galaxy formation models. Gupta_2013 Gupta et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1301.6138
944 1303.6121 2013-05-06 F. Feng, C. A. L. Bailer-Jones Assessing the influence of the solar orbit on terrestrial biodiversity The terrestrial fossil record shows a significant variation in the extinction\nand origination rates of species during the past half billion years. Numerous\nstudies have claimed an association between this variation and the motion of\nthe Sun around the Galaxy, invoking the modulation of cosmic rays, gamma rays\nand comet impact frequency as a cause of this biodiversity variation. However,\nsome of these studies exhibit methodological problems, or were based on coarse\nassumptions (such as a strict periodicity of the solar orbit). Here we\ninvestigate this link in more detail, using a model of the Galaxy to\nreconstruct the solar orbit and thus a predictive model of the temporal\nvariation of the extinction rate due to astronomical mechanisms. We compare\nthese predictions as well as those of various reference models with\npaleontological data. Our approach involves Bayesian model comparison, which\ntakes into account the uncertainties in the paleontological data as well as the\ndistribution of solar orbits consistent with the uncertainties in the\nastronomical data. We find that various versions of the orbital model are not\nfavored beyond simpler reference models. In particular, the distribution of\nmass extinction events can be explained just as well by a uniform random\ndistribution as by any other model tested. Although our negative results on the\norbital model are robust to changes in the Galaxy model, the Sun's coordinates\nand the errors in the data, we also find that it would be very difficult to\npositively identify the orbital model even if it were the true one. (In\ncontrast, we do find evidence against simpler periodic models.) Thus while we\ncannot rule out there being some connection between solar motion and\nbiodiversity variations on the Earth, we conclude that it is difficult to give\nconvincing positive conclusions of such a connection using current data. Feng_2013 Feng and Bailer-Jones 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1303.6121
945 1304.3409 2013-04-26 Lennart Lindegren, Sofia Feltzing The case for high precision in elemental abundances of stars in the era of large spectroscopic surveys A number of large spectroscopic surveys of stars in the Milky Way are under\nway or are being planned. In this context it is important to discuss the extent\nto which elemental abundances can be used as discriminators between different\n(known and unknown) stellar populations in the Milky Way. We aim to establish\nthe requirements in terms of precision in elemental abundances, as derived from\nspectroscopic surveys of the Milky Way's stellar populations, in order to\ndetect interesting substructures in elemental abundance space. We present a\nsimple relation between the minimum number of stars needed to detect a given\nsubstructure and the precision of the measurements. The results are in\nagreement with recent small- and large-scale studies, with high and low\nprecision, respectively. Large-number statistics cannot fully compensate for\nlow precision in the abundance measurements and each survey should carefully\nevaluate what the main science drivers are for the survey and ensure that the\nchosen observational strategy will result in the precision necessary to answer\nthe questions posed. Lindegren_2013 Lindegren and Feltzing 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1304.3409
946 1304.6927 2013-04-25 C. Esteban, L. Carigi, M. V. F. Copetti, J. García-Rojas, A. Mesa-Delgado, H. O. Castañeda, D. Péquignot NGC 2579 and the carbon and oxygen abundance gradients beyond the solar circle We present deep echelle spectrophotometry of the Galactic HII region NGC\n2579. The data have been taken with the Very Large Telescope Ultraviolet-Visual\nEchelle Spectrograph in the 3550--10400 \AA\ range. This object, which has been\nlargely neglected, shows however a rather high surface brightness, a high\nionization degree and is located at a galactocentric distance of 12.4 $\pm$ 0.7\nkpc. Therefore, NGC 2579 is an excellent probe for studying the behaviour of\nthe gas phase radial abundance gradients in the outer disc of the Milky Way. We\nderive the physical conditions of the nebula using several emission\nline-intensity ratios as well as the abundances of several ionic species from\nthe intensity of collisionally excited lines. We also determine the ionic\nabundances of C$^{2+}$, O$^+$ and O$^{2+}$ -- and therefore the total O\nabundance -- from faint pure recombination lines. The results for NGC 2579\npermit to extend our previous determinations of the C, O and C/O gas phase\nradial gradients of the inner Galactic disc (Esteban etal. 2005) to larger\ngalactocentric distances. We find that the chemical composition of NGC 2579 is\nconsistent with flatten gradients at its galactocentric distance. In addition,\nwe have built a tailored chemical evolution model that reproduces the observed\nradial abundance gradients of O, C and N and other observational constraints.\nWe find that a levelling out of the star formation efficiency about and beyond\nthe isophotal radius can explain the flattening of chemical gradients observed\nin the outer Galactic disc. Esteban_2013 Esteban et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1304.6927
947 1301.4024 2013-04-24 Takaya Nozawa, Masataka Fukugita Properties of Dust Grains Probed with Extinction Curves Modern data of the extinction curve from the ultraviolet to the near infrared\nare revisited to study the property of dust grains in the Milky Way (MW) and\nthe Small Magellanic Cloud (SMC). We confirm that the graphite-silicate mixture\nof grains yields the observed extinction curve with the simple power-law\ndistribution of the grain size but with a cutoff at some maximal size: the\nparameters are tightly constrained to be $q = 3.5 \pm 0.2$ for the size\ndistribution $a^{-q}$ and the maximum radius $a_{max} = 0.24 \pm 0.05$ um, for\nboth MW and SMC. The abundance of grains, and hence the elemental abundance, is\nconstrained from the reddening versus hydrogen column density, E(B-V)/N_H. If\nwe take the solar elemental abundance as the standard for the MW, >56 % of\ncarbon should be in graphite dust, while it is <40 % in the SMC using its\navailable abundance estimate. This disparity and the relative abundance of C to\nSi explain the difference of the two curves. We find that 50-60 % of carbon may\nnot necessarily be in graphite but in the amorphous or the glassy phase. Iron\nmay also be in the metallic phase or up to ~80 % in magnetite rather than in\nsilicates, so that the Mg/Fe ratio in astronomical olivine is arbitrary. With\nthese substitutions the parameters of the grain size remain unchanged. The mass\ndensity of dust grains relative to hydrogen is $\rho_{dust}/\rho_H = 1/(120\n{+10 \atop -16})$ for the MW and $1/(760 {+70 \atop -90}) for the SMC under\nsome abundance constraints. We underline the importance of the\nwavelength-dependence slope of the extinction curve in the near infrared in\nconstructing the dust model: if $A_{\lambda} \propto \lambda^{-gamma}$ with\ngamma ~ 1.6, the power-law grain-size model fails, whereas it works if gamma ~\n1.8-2.0. Nozawa_2013 Nozawa and Fukugita 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1301.4024
948 1210.6046 2013-04-23 Michael Boylan-Kolchin, James S. Bullock, Sangmo Tony Sohn, Gurtina Besla, Roeland P. van der Marel The Space Motion of Leo I: The Mass of the Milky Way's Dark Matter Halo We combine our Hubble Space Telescope measurement of the proper motion of the\nLeo I dwarf spheroidal galaxy (presented in a companion paper) with the highest\nresolution numerical simulations of Galaxy-size dark matter halos in existence\nto constrain the mass of the Milky Way's dark matter halo (M_MW). Despite Leo\nI's large Galacto-centric space velocity (200 km/s) and distance (261 kpc), we\nshow that it is extremely unlikely to be unbound if Galactic satellites are\nassociated with dark matter substructure, as 99.9% of subhalos in the\nsimulations are bound to their host. The observed position and velocity of Leo\nI strongly disfavor a low mass Milky Way: if we assume that Leo I is the least\nbound of the Milky Way's classical satellites, then we find that M_MW > 10^{12}\nM_sun at 95% confidence for a variety of Bayesian priors on M_MW. In lower mass\nhalos, it is vanishingly rare to find subhalos at 261 kpc moving as fast as Leo\nI. Should an additional classical satellite be found to be less bound than Leo\nI, this lower limit on M_MW would increase by 30%. Imposing a mass weighted\nLCDM prior, we find a median Milky Way virial mass of M_MW=1.6 x 10^{12} M_sun,\nwith a 90% confidence interval of [1.0-2.4] x 10^{12} M_sun. We also confirm a\nstrong correlation between subhalo infall time and orbital energy in the\nsimulations and show that proper motions can aid significantly in interpreting\nthe infall times and orbital histories of satellites. Boylan-Kolchin_2013 Boylan-Kolchin et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1210.6046
949 1304.5573 2013-04-20 Coleman M. Krawczyk, Gordon T. Richards, Sajjan S. Mehta, Michael S. Vogeley, S. C. Gallagher, Karen M. Leighly, Nicholas P. Ross, Donald P. Schneider Mean Spectral Energy Distributions and Bolometric Corrections for Luminous Quasars We explore the mid-infrared (mid-IR) through ultraviolet (UV) spectral energy\ndistributions (SEDs) of 119,652 luminous broad-lined quasars with 0.0641.6; the latter\nis a possible indicator of the strength of the accretion disk wind, which is\nexpected to be SED dependent. Luminosity-dependent mean SEDs show that,\nrelative to the high-luminosity SED, low-luminosity SEDs exhibit a harder\n(bluer) far-UV spectral slope, a redder optical continuum, and less hot dust.\nMean SEDs constructed instead as a function of UV emission line properties\nreveal changes that are consistent with known Principal Component Analysis\n(PCA) trends. A potentially important contribution to the bolometric correction\nis the unseen extream-UV (EUV) continuum. Our work suggests that\nlower-luminosity quasars and/or quasars with disk-dominated broad emission\nlines may require an extra continuum component in the EUV that is not present\n(or much weaker) in high-luminosity quasars with strong accretion disk winds.\nAs such, we consider four possible models and explore the resulting bolometric\ncorrections. Understanding these various SED-dependent effects will be\nimportant for accurate determination of quasar accretion rates. Krawczyk_2013 Krawczyk et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1304.5573
950 1302.6981 2013-04-18 Santi Roca-Fàbrega, Octavio Valenzuela, Francesca Figueras, Mercè Romero-Gómez, Hector Velázquez, Teresa Antoja, Bárbara Pichardo On the galaxy spiral arms' nature as revealed by rotation frequencies High resolution N-body simulations using different codes and initial\ncondition techniques reveal two different behaviours for the rotation frequency\nof transient spiral arms like structures. Whereas unbarred disks present spiral\narms nearly corotatingwith disk particles, strong barred models (bulged or\nbulge-less) quickly develop a bar-spiral structure dominant in density, with a\npattern speed almost constant in radius. As the bar strength decreases the arm\ndeparts from bar rigid rotation and behaves similar to the unbarred case. In\nstrong barred models we detect in the frequency space other subdominant and\nslower modes at large radii, in agreement with previous studies, however we\nalso detect them in the configuration space. We propose that the distinctive\nbehaviour of the dominant spiral modes can be exploited in order to constraint\nthe nature of Galactic spiral arms by the astrometric survey GAIA and by 2-D\nspectroscopic surveys like CALIFA and MANGA in external galaxies. Roca-Fàbrega_2013 Roca-Fàbrega et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1302.6981
951 1304.4385 2013-04-16 G. Brusadin, F. Matteucci, D. Romano Modelling the chemical evolution of the Galaxy halo We study the chemical evolution and formation of the Galactic halo through\nthe analysis of its stellar metallicity distribution function and some key\nelemental abundance patterns. Starting from the two-infall model for the\nGalaxy, which predicts too few low-metallicity stars, we add a gas outflow\nduring the halo phase with a rate proportional to the star formation rate\nthrough a free parameter, lambda. In addition, we consider a first generation\nof massive zero-metal stars in this two-infall + outflow model adopting two\ndifferent top-heavy initial mass functions and specific population III yields.\nThe metallicity distribution function of halo stars, as predicted by the\ntwo-infall + outflow model shows a good agreement with observations, when the\nparameter lambda=14 and the time scale for the first infall, out of which the\nhalo formed, is not longer than 0.2 Gyr, a lower value than suggested\npreviously. Moreover, the abundance patterns [X/Fe] vs. [Fe/H] for C, N and\nalpha-elements O, Mg, Si, S, Ca show a good agreement with the observational\ndata. If population III stars are included, under the assumption of different\ninitial mass functions, the overall agreement of the predicted stellar\nmetallicity distribution function with observational data is poorer than in the\ncase without population III. We conclude that it is fundamental to include both\na gas infall and outflow during the halo formation to explain the observed halo\nmetallicity distribution function, in the framework of a model assuming that\nthe stars in the inner halo formed mostly in situ. Moreover, we find that it\ndoes not exist a satisfactory initial mass function for population III stars\nwhich reproduces the observed halo metallicity distribution function. As a\nconsequence, there is no need for a first generation of only massive stars to\nexplain the evolution of the Galactic halo. Brusadin_2013 Brusadin et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1304.4385
952 1304.3961 2013-04-15 Karen M. Lewis, Maria Lugaro, Brad K. Gibson, Kate Pilkington Decoding the message from meteoritic stardust silicon carbide grains Micron-sized stardust grains that originated in ancient stars are recovered\nfrom meteorites and analysed using high-resolution mass spectrometry. The most\nwidely studied type of stardust is silicon carbide (SiC). Thousands of these\ngrains have been analysed with high precision for their Si isotopic\ncomposition. Here we show that the distribution of the Si isotopic composition\nof the vast majority of stardust SiC grains carry the imprints of a spread in\nthe age-metallicity distribution of their parent stars and of a power-law\nincrease of the relative formation efficiency of SiC dust with the metallicity.\nThis result offers a solution for the long-standing problem of silicon in\nstardust SiC grains, confirms the necessity of coupling chemistry and dynamics\nin simulations of the chemical evolution of our Galaxy, and constrains the\nmodelling of dust condensation in stellar winds as function of the metallicity. Lewis_2013 Lewis et al. 2013 https://arxiv.org/abs/1304.3961
